summary: Four potential tropical systems are threatening to form in the Atlantic, with a 70% chance of one becoming the next named storm. A system off the Carolinas has a 70% chance of reaching tropical strength within five days, while a Caribbean system has an 80% chance of reaching tropical strength, potentially impacting Central America. The 2020 hurricane season has entered its most active phase, with the US having been hit by seven of the 13 storms to form across the Atlantic this year, causing over a billion dollars in insured losses.

site_title: US: S&P 500 hits record high at open for sixth straight session
summary: The S&P 500 opened at a record high for the sixth consecutive session, reaching 3,509.73, driven by bets on an economic revival due to central bank support. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.04% and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.2% at the open. This marks the best August in decades for the S&P 500, as investors remain optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Tycoon-backed Saxo Bank reveals Hong Kong expansion plans
summary: Saxo Bank, backed by Chinese billionaire Li Shu Fu, plans to expand its operations in Hong Kong despite the region's tense political climate. CEO Kim Fournais stated the firm aims to further build its presence in the market. This move comes as Saxo Bank seeks to grow its online trading business in the region. The expansion plans are not explicitly linked to the recent economic slowdown in China, but the firm's presence in Hong Kong could be seen as a strategic move to tap into the Asian market.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare to receive S$12.6m judgement debt from Crest entities
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare has agreed to receive S$12.6 million from Crest Capital Asia, which was awarded in a Singapore High Court judgement in July. The judgement, which was appealed, was settled through three instalments, with the first payment due on September 3. The company, formerly known as International Healthway Corp, had sought the judgement against Crest entities for an aggregated sum of S$12.6 million. The outcome resolves a dispute that began in 2017.

site_title: First Reit still 'anticipating' rental restructuring proposal from Lippo Kawaraci
summary: First Reit expects to receive a rental restructuring proposal from Lippo Kawaraci (LPKR), its former parent company, as anticipated. LPKR had initiated discussions in June and granted two-month rental relief in May and June. First Reit shares fell 7.48% due to the uncertainty. The company remains in discussions with stakeholders regarding a road subsidence issue near Siloam Hospitals Surabaya.

site_title: Q2 corporate profits dive, but silver lining seen for quarters ahead
summary: Singapore-listed companies reported a 47.3% decline in Q2 earnings, with 62 in the red and 72 profitable, according to data compiled by The Business Times. Analysts say the worst is over for several sectors, with most expecting an "incrementally positive" second half of 2020. Some sectors, such as aviation, telco, and capital goods, may still struggle due to travel patterns and competition. Despite this, local lenders and Reits dragged down the total income pool, and analysts expect a gradual recovery pace and prolonged low rate environment weighing on sector profitability.

images.alt_text: For the latest quarter, total earnings of companies listed on the bourse were down 47.3 per cent to S$2.588 billion from a year earlier, according to data compiled by The Business Times.

site_title: Facebook says EU data demands included risks to staff's families
summary: Facebook has accused the European Commission of demanding irrelevant data, including details of correspondence with bereaved staff and security risks to key employees' families, in EU investigations into its classified ads service and data practices. Facebook sued the commission, winning a temporary halt to officials' demands for internal documents. The EU regulator can require companies to turn over documents mentioning certain keywords under threat of fines. Facebook is asking the EU's General Court to curb the regulator's wide powers to demand and sift information from companies.

site_title: Credit Suisse plans to double China headcount in five years
summary: Credit Suisse plans to double its China headcount in five years as the bank accelerates its pursuit of China's wealthy clients, seeking to move past a scandal involving Luckin Coffee founder Lu Zhengyao. The bank aims to increase revenue from China to 100% of its global revenue goal, targeting ultra-high net worth strategic clients. Credit Suisse's Asia chief executive officer, Helman Sitohang, plans to expand advisory and investment banking services for China's rich, while also recruiting fresh talent for its China joint venture. The bank's efforts come as China's financial opening presents opportunities for global banks and asset managers.

site_title: Nestle gets peanut allergy treatment with US$2b Aimmune buyout
summary: Nestle agreed to purchase the remaining stake in Aimmune Therapeutics for US$2 billion, gaining full ownership of the first US-approved peanut allergy treatment, Palforzia. The deal comes after Aimmune's shares more than doubled following the announcement, valuing the company at US$2.6 billion. The slow launch of Palforzia due to the COVID-19 pandemic is expected to improve as the pandemic recedes, with analysts predicting Nestle secured a bargain in the deal. The acquisition expands Nestle's Nestle Health Science division, which is expected to more than double sales by 2022.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for Singapore's economy to adapt to the post-Covid world by adopting a more integrated approach. He suggested developing human potential, spotting opportunities, and finding new ways to be a global node. Heng's speech in Parliament highlighted the importance of adapting to the changing economic landscape and seizing new connections to drive growth.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 29.57 points to 1,525.21. The trading volume reached 11.146 billion lots worth RM8.256 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 588 to 552, indicating a bearish trend in the market.

site_title: BRC Asia to sell Nassim Road house for S$38.38m
summary: BRC Asia, Singapore's largest steel reinforcement supplier, plans to sell a property at 32G Nassim Road for S$38.38 million. The property, currently under development, has a land size of 1,235 sq m and is expected to be completed by year's end. The sale price is on a "willing buyer, willing seller" basis, with the group using the net cash proceeds for full repayment of a term loan and working capital. The disposal will also result in a book value loss of approximately S$4.97 million.

site_title: China set to import largest monthly LNG volumes this year in August
summary: China is set to import its largest monthly volumes of liquefied natural gas (LNG) in August, with nearly 6.4 million tonnes expected, a 24% increase from last year. This is due to low spot prices and traders taking advantage of the situation to stockpile ahead of peak winter demand. Supply sources include Russia and Indonesia, with new terminals also ramping up output. However, with spot LNG prices recently rising due to supply outages, China's buying spree may be short-lived as inventories fill up.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer has been 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks opened lower due to Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of possible revenue shortfall in H2, with similar operating losses as H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and People's Bank of China will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Vanguard's China fund market strategy under a cloud after Asia setbacks
summary: Vanguard is expanding its presence in mainland China's US$2.6 trillion mutual funds market, despite facing challenges similar to those it faced in Hong Kong and Japan. The US asset manager is closing its operations in Hong Kong and Japan, shifting its Asian headquarters to Shanghai, and establishing a mutual fund unit. Industry experts argue that Vanguard's direct-to-client sales model may not work in China, where investment products are typically sold by agents who live on commission, and that the company risks cultural clashes and being sidelined by local players.

site_title: Singapore stocks edge up in August; STI market cap slips 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose in August, with the combined market capitalisation of 701 counters on the Singapore Exchange increasing 0.3% to S$760.4 billion. Mainboard-listed counters rose 0.2% and Catalist-listed counters rose 6.2%. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to S$445.6 billion. Top gainers included DBS, Sembcorp Marine, and Singapore Airlines, while Singtel was the biggest loser, falling S$2.9 billion. Analysts expect the market to continue on an uptrend despite the ongoing pandemic, driven by low interest rates and strong monetary easing.

site_title: Low unemployment alone not enough to justify Fed rate hikes, Clarida says
summary: US Federal Reserve vice-chair Richard Clarida stated that a low unemployment rate alone is not enough to justify interest rate hikes, as the economy is different from textbook models. The Fed's new approach acknowledges that a low unemployment rate doesn't necessarily mean higher inflation, and it will consider other factors, such as financial stability concerns, before taking action. The new policy aims to use higher inflation when the economy is strong to offset periods of weakness. This marks a "milestone" in the Fed's approach to monetary policy.

site_title: Israeli, US officials arrive in UAE on historic trip to finalise accord
summary: US and Israeli officials arrived in the UAE on a historic trip to finalize a normalization deal, marking the first open relations between the Gulf power and Israel in over 20 years. The deal was catalyzed by shared fears of Iran and does not involve land transfer. The two-day trip aims to produce a Washington signing ceremony, potentially in September, and could give President Trump a foreign policy boost ahead of his re-election bid.

site_title: Recycling value chains in South-east Asia shut down by Covid-19 risk closures
summary: South-east Asian plastic recycling stakeholders face potential bankruptcy or permanent closure due to the Covid-19 pandemic and oil prices. A study by GA Circular and Circulate Capital found that 80% of the recycling value chain was not operating during the pandemic in Vietnam, India, and the Philippines, leading to increased plastic waste in landfills and the environment. Immediate action is needed to mitigate the impact and prevent permanent closure.

site_title: YZJ Shipbuilding wins US$126m in new orders from SITC
summary: YZJ Shipbuilding has won US$126 million in new orders from SITC International Holdings for the construction and delivery of 12 1,800 TEU containerships, with six vessels confirmed as firm orders. The remaining six vessels can be exercised in three stages, totaling US$252 million.

site_title: GSK, partner Vir join race to find Covid-19 antibody treatment
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) and partner Vir Biotechnology have started testing an experimental antibody treatment for Covid-19, aiming to prevent hospitalization. The long-acting single injection is being tested on high-risk patients, and initial results may be available by the end of the year. GSK is collaborating with Vir, investing $250 million in the partnership, as it seeks to develop a best-in-class antibody. Other companies, including Regeneron and Eli Lilly, are also working on Covid-19 treatments, with initial data from trials expected in September.

site_title: Singapore shares falter despite Wall Street gains
summary: Singapore shares fell on Monday, failing to sustain gains despite a Wall Street rally, due to lingering concerns over US-China tensions and the uncertainty following Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's resignation. China's manufacturing index expanded for the sixth straight month, but doubts remain over the economy's recovery speed. Analysts attribute the market's volatility to ongoing COVID-19 uncertainties and poor labor market conditions.

site_title: Emirates got 7.3b dirham from Dubai to survive crisis months
summary: Dubai's government has invested 7.3 billion dirhams (S$2.7 billion) in Emirates since the coronavirus pandemic affected global air travel in March. The state aid is intended to support the world's largest long-haul carrier, which has been hard hit by the pandemic. Emirates expects to increase its network to 80 destinations by September and plans to resume service to all destinations by 2021. The airline has begun firing thousands of workers to preserve cash and is negotiating with Boeing on new planes.

site_title: CNMC Goldmine's Chinese workers gradually return to Sokor gold field
summary: CNMC Goldmine's Chinese migrant workers are gradually returning to work at its Sokor gold field in Malaysia's Kelantan state after completing a 14-day quarantine. A small group has already returned, with another team expected to arrive next week. A third team, primarily involved in underground mining, will return in September, subject to Malaysian authorities' approval. The company's shares fell 1.64% after the announcement. Underground mining is expected to be a key driver of growth for CNMC Goldmine, with high-grade ore yielding increased gold production.

site_title: SGX, GF Securities to promote connectivity between Singapore, China capital markets
summary: SGX and GF Securities Corporation have signed a memorandum of understanding to promote connectivity between Singapore and China's capital markets. GF Securities will expand its services in Singapore, including building on its existing distribution of SGX's derivatives products. The collaboration aims to enhance capital flows between China and Singapore, allowing Chinese enterprises and investors to access SGX's investment products and introducing yuan assets to global investors.

site_title: Keppel Land and TVS Emerald to develop premium condo in Chennai
summary: Keppel Land has entered into a joint venture with TVS Emerald to develop a freehold condominium project in south Chennai, India. Keppel Land will acquire a 49% stake in the joint-venture company for approximately $14.1 million. The total development cost is estimated at $98.2 million, with Keppel Land's share expected to be around $26 billion. Completion of the acquisition is subject to certain conditions and is expected to take place in the first half of 2021.

site_title: Philippines canned meat costs may increase on Brazil poultry ban
summary: The Philippines has banned poultry products from Brazil due to concerns over the coronavirus, potentially increasing prices of canned meat by up to 14%. Brazil accounts for 20-25% of imported mechanically-deboned meat used for canned products. The ban follows a statement from China that surface samples of chicken wings from Brazil tested positive for the virus. The move may lead to a 15-30 day shortage of mechanically-deboned meat, with prices potentially rising due to higher costs from alternative suppliers like the US and Europe.

site_title: UG Healthcare proposes 1-for-3 stock split
summary: UG Healthcare, a Malaysian glove maker listed on the CATALIST, proposes a 1-for-3 stock split to reduce share prices and enhance trading liquidity. The proposed split, subject to shareholder approval, would allot and issue an additional 410 million shares, bringing the total to 615 million shares. The board believes the split will broaden the base of shareholders and provide greater flexibility in trades. A record date will be determined later, with a circular to be dispatched to provide information on the proposed share split.

site_title: DC rates cut by average of 7.8% for hotel use, 3.6% for commercial use
summary: The Singapore government has cut development charge (DC) rates for various use groups, including commercial, non-landed residential, hotel/hospital, and industrial uses, effective September 1, 2020 to February 28, 2021. The average DC rate declines are 3.6% for commercial, 0.8% for non-landed residential, 7.8% for hotel/hospital, and 0.9% for industrial use. The cuts are based on the Ministry of National Development's assessment of land values and reflect recent land sales. The rate revisions are made annually, in consultation with the taxman's chief valuer.

site_title: United Airlines bids farewell to change fees in push for bookings
summary: United Airlines permanently eliminated change fees on tickets for US travel effective immediately, a move to stimulate bookings hit by the coronavirus pandemic. This effort follows temporary waivers of change fees implemented by major US airlines. The airline aims to give passengers more flexibility with their travel plans amid pandemic uncertainty.

site_title: Money Hacks: ETFs and unit trusts, what are the differences and misconceptions? (Ep 79)
summary: The Business Times podcast "Money Hacks" discusses the differences and misconceptions between ETFs and unit trusts. Host Chris Lim is joined by Gregory Van, CEO of Endowus, to explain that unit trusts are more suitable for investors seeking intra-day liquidity, while ETFs offer flexibility and can be traded on exchanges. The key takeaway is that while both products offer investment benefits, understanding their differences and suitability for individual investors is crucial. The discussion emphasizes the importance of consulting with a financial adviser before making any investment decisions.

images.alt_text: Gregory Van, chief executive and founding partner of Endowus

site_title: KrisEnergy says AIH offer was for assets only, applies for fourth extension of debt moratorium
summary: KrisEnergy confirmed receiving a 2017 confidential offer from AlHassan International Holdings (AIH) to acquire its assets for US$230 million, but not its shares. The offer was part of a portfolio rationalization exercise to reduce risk exposure and divest non-core assets. KrisEnergy did not receive a proposal to acquire any stake in the company. The company has applied for a fourth extension of its debt moratorium until October 27, seeking protection from creditors while restructuring US$476.8 million in debt.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open firmer
summary: European stock markets opened firmer on Monday, driven by gains on US and Asian bourses. The CAC 40 index in Paris rose 0.77% to 5,041.30 points, while the DAX in Frankfurt gained 0.65% to 13,117.61 points. Lighter trading was attributed to London's public holiday.

site_title: Damaged WTO now leaderless as chief Azevedo steps down
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) is now leaderless after Director-General Roberto Azevedo stepped down, leaving the organization in its biggest crisis in 25 years. The US administration of President Donald Trump has been a major contributor to this crisis, blocking the appointment of new judges to the WTO appeals court and questioning the effectiveness of the organization in holding China accountable for unfair trade practices. The selection process for Azevedo's replacement is uncertain, with eight candidates vying for the position, and the WTO's ability to address pressing issues such as fishing subsidies and the US tariff system is now in jeopardy.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher after US rallies
summary: Tokyo shares ended higher on Monday, driven by a rally on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.12% to 23,139.76, while the Topix index advanced 0.83% to 1,618.18. A stronger yen against the US dollar limited gains.

site_title: WP won't form shadow Cabinet, but will focus on five critical areas: Pritam Singh
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) in Singapore will focus on five key areas, rather than forming a shadow Cabinet, due to its limited number of MPs. These areas include health and ageing, jobs and the economy, education and inequality, housing and transport, and national sustainability. WP leader Pritam Singh emphasized the party's commitment to scrutinizing government policies and collaborating with other opposition parties when necessary. Despite their limited influence, Singh proposed establishing select committees to discuss divisive issues and improve governance in Singapore.

site_title: 41 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including three in the community
summary: Singapore reported 41 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 56,812. Three community cases were confirmed, all of whom are work pass holders. Seven imported cases were also reported, including six Singaporeans and/or permanent residents who returned from India and Malaysia between August 17-19. A staff member at the Lee Ah Mooi Old Age Home tested positive for Covid-19 in the Philippines, prompting a test for 90 staff and residents, all of whom tested negative.

site_title: No cramming as new Covid rules take hold in South Korean capital
summary: South Korea's capital, Seoul, has implemented stricter social-distancing rules, including closing private tuition centres, restricting restaurant and coffee shop operations, and banning onsite dining until 9 pm. The move comes after a surge in coronavirus cases, with 238 new cases reported as of Sunday, mostly in Seoul and surrounding regions. The Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention aims to sever the links of infections and control the spread, with the government cutting staffing at offices and encouraging employees to work from home.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks close over 1% lower on record selling by foreigners
summary: South Korean stocks closed over 1% lower on Monday, erasing previous gains, due to a huge foreign sell-off amid economic concerns. Foreigners sold a record 1.62 trillion won worth of shares, with the benchmark Kospi declining 27.63 points. The sell-off was driven by slower-than-expected July factory data and tougher social distancing measures. The won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield rose, with Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix heavyweights declining 2.5% and 3.5%, respectively.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall as financial, consumer firms retreat
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell on Monday, closing 0.96% lower at 25,177.05, as financial and consumer staples firms retreated. The Hang Seng China Enterprises index dropped 1.88%, while energy shares rose 0.9%. Heavyweight banking shares, including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, fell 3.6%. Consumer firms, including Tsingtao Brewery, also declined after a strong rally. Analysts fear the recovery could stall due to rising tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Sinopec sees year-on-year growth in China's fuel demand in H2
summary: China's fuel demand is expected to see year-on-year growth of 1% in the second half of 2020, according to Sinopec, Asia's largest oil refiner. The company reported its first-ever interim loss of 21.73 billion yuan in the first half of 2020 due to the pandemic's impact on fuel consumption. Despite the loss, Sinopec's operations have improved month by month and its performance has stabilized, with the company aiming to raise its refinery throughput to 130 million tonnes in the second half.

site_title: Two-storey factory in Tuas for sale with S$8m guide price
summary: A two-storey factory in Tuas, Singapore, is up for sale by expression of interest with a guide price of S$8 million. The site, zoned B2, has a land area of 4,633 sq m and a gross floor area of 3,928 sq m. It is well-positioned near the Tuas Second Link and the upcoming Tuas Mega Port, and offers convenience to employees commuting from Malaysia. The property is ideal for general industry use, such as manufacturing, precision engineering, and logistics. The expression of interest exercise closes on October 13.

site_title: US dollar set for worst August in five years
summary: The US dollar is set for its worst August in five years, with a fourth consecutive month of losses, amid a Federal Reserve policy shift that could lead to slightly higher inflation and lower interest rates. The euro is poised for a fourth month of gains, while the euro-dollar exchange rate has reached a 2018 high. The dollar index is trading below 92.50, and sustained losses could mark the longest run of monthly losses since 2017. The euro is steady at US$1.1903, on track for a 1% monthly gain.

site_title: Singapore remains open, but firms should focus on Singaporean core: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore remains open to global talent and investment, but companies should focus on strengthening their Singaporean core, said Minister Tan See Leng. The government will support Singaporean jobseekers and businesses by providing training and resources for a "lost generation" of workers, including young graduates and mature workers. The government will also help businesses adapt to the pandemic, including those in sectors that have permanently changed, and encourage them to grow and compete internationally.

site_title: Republicans don't Trump on the dollar: OCBC
summary: US dollar may not be negatively impacted by a Trump presidency, contrary to typical expectations. A Biden administration could also not be as USD-negative as believed. Instead, the administration that can deliver quick and decisive economic support should be USD-positive in the near term, according to OCBC Treasury Research. Foreign exchange strategist Terence Wu found the approach relying on the president's typical inclinations to be unsatisfactory.

site_title: Billionaire Adani to buy Mumbai airport in bold aviation bet
summary: Billionaire Gautam Adani is acquiring a controlling stake in Mumbai's international airport through Adani Airport Holdings, buying the debt of GVK Airport Developers and the 23.5% stake held by Airports Co South Africa and Bidvest Group. This move comes as the aviation industry recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic, with Adani seeking to expand its presence in India's growing aviation market. The acquisition is seen as a high-stakes bet by Adani, pitting him against rival GMR Infrastructure, which controls India's busiest airport in New Delhi.

site_title: Hong Kong will open schools from Sept 23 as virus wave recedes
summary: Hong Kong will reopen schools in phases from September 23 as the city's worst outbreak eases. The re-opening will begin with half-day face-to-face classes, ending a two-month closure. This marks the second school closure of the year, following a previous closure from February to May. The prolonged closure has seen children spend over six months at home, one of the longest periods globally.

site_title: Australia to probe foreign influence at universities
summary: Australia's parliament is set to probe foreign influence at public universities amid concerns over Chinese interference. The proposed inquiry follows a series of controversies, including hacks of university data and questionable financial donations. The move comes after the government announced new guidelines for universities and sweeping powers to scrap deals threatening the national interest. The inquiry aims to address foreign interference, with the public and government assured that there isn't foreign influence in the universities sector. The probe's terms were outlined in a letter to the committee head, but the aim of the probe is not specified.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors says former chairman Masuko dead at 71
summary: Mitsubishi Motors Corp announced the death of former chairman Osamu Masuko, 71, due to heart failure. Masuko, who resigned as chairman citing health reasons just weeks ago, had previously served as president from 2005 and oversaw the partnership between Mitsubishi and Nissan Motor Co. His death comes as the alliance between Mitsubishi, Nissan, and Renault struggles to regain profitability following Carlos Ghosn's ouster. Masuko was at the helm during a 2016 scandal that damaged Mitsubishi's brand, leading to a $2.2 billion bailout from Nissan.

images.alt_text: Mr Masuko, a veteran of the Mitsubishi conglomerate, had just weeks ago resigned as chairman citing health reasons.

site_title: AstraZeneca diabetes drug improves survival in kidney disease patients: study shows
summary: AstraZeneca's Farxiga drug has shown to improve survival chances for patients with kidney disease by 31% compared to a placebo, reducing the risk of dying from any cause and deteriorating kidney function by 39%. This benefit is not related to blood sugar control, but rather to its effect on the heart and kidneys. The company aims to request regulatory approval for expanded use of the drug in chronic kidney disease in the coming months, which could further establish its role in treating this serious condition.

site_title: Gold hits near two-week high on greenback weakness, dovish Fed
summary: Gold prices reached a near-two-week high, rising 0.2% to $1,969.03 per ounce, driven by the US dollar's weakness and the Federal Reserve's dovish monetary policy stance. The dollar index hit a two-year low, and gold has gained nearly 30% this year, as investors seek a hedge against inflation and currency debasement. Silver and other precious metals also rose, with silver jumping 1.7% and platinum gaining 0.3%.

site_title: Trump hails Abe as Japan's best-ever PM
summary: US President Donald Trump praised outgoing Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe as Japan's best-ever head of government in a late-night tweet, citing their "unprecedented" relationship and best trade deal. Abe announced his resignation for health reasons, ending his record-breaking tenure. Trump and Abe have met several times, and Trump hailed Abe as a "special man" and a major ally, despite differing views on trade and other issues.

site_title: New Zealand bourse website hit by fresh cyberattack, but keeps trading
summary: New Zealand's stock market website was hit by a cyberattack on Monday, crashing its site but allowing trading to continue through a contingency plan. The attacks, which began on August 27, have been described as the largest and most sophisticated seen in the country. NZX Ltd, the exchange, is working with cybersecurity agencies to implement additional security measures. Trading on the platform was nearly flat despite the disruptions, and the company has declined to comment on who is behind the attacks or any extortion demands.

site_title: State Street hires former BNP Paribas execs as Asia-Pacific, China heads
summary: State Street has appointed Mostapha Tahiri as head of Asia-Pacific and Joanne Chen as head of China, as part of its Asia-Pacific expansion plan. Tahiri, a former BNP Paribas executive, will oversee the company's overall business in the region, while Chen will drive strategy and growth in China. The appointments come as State Street seeks to capitalize on China's regulatory liberalization and growth of onshore domestic assets. The moves are expected to bolster the company's presence in the region and drive growth.

site_title: Pressure on capital adds caution over Singapore banks' ratings: Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings warns Singapore banks' core capital ratios should be sustained at around 14% over the next few years to avoid a rating downgrade. The agencies notes deteriorating asset quality and profitability will put downward pressure on capital ratios, with limited rating headroom. The banks' common equity tier 1 (CET1) ratios are currently between 12.5-13.5%, and Fitch expects earnings to fall by about a third from end-2019, adding pressure to their viability ratings.

images.alt_text: Fitch Ratings expects the three lenders' earnings this year to fall by about a third from end-2019.

site_title: China ministry says no environmental approval yet for copper ore blending plants
summary: China's environment ministry has not approved any copper concentrate blending plant applications this year. Chinese copper smelters, including Jinchuan Group and Jiangxi Copper, are pursuing blending projects to ensure a raw material supply amid coronavirus-related mining curbs abroad. The blending plants must undergo an environmental impact assessment (EIA) before approval.

site_title: Oil prices edge up on stimulus support despite ample supplies
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent futures set to post a fifth straight monthly gain, driven by global stimulus measures despite ample supplies and sluggish demand. Brent crude futures climbed 0.6% to US$46.08 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.3% to US$43.11 a barrel. The rise in oil prices is attributed to a weak US dollar, but analysts note that crude may face hurdles going forward.

site_title: Singapore bank lending extends slide in July for fifth straight month
summary: Singapore bank lending declined 0.2% in July for the fifth consecutive month, reaching S$678.7 billion, down from S$680.1 billion in June. Business loans fell 0.3% year-over-year, driven by a fourth consecutive month of decline in business loans, while consumer loans remained flat at S$254.5 billion. This marks the second consecutive year-on-year decline in total loans.

site_title: Singapore aims to work more closely with Guangdong in finance, talent exchange and aviation
summary: Singapore and Guangdong province in China have pledged to deepen their collaboration in key areas such as finance, talent exchange, and aviation. The two sides signed 15 agreements at the Singapore-Guangdong Collaboration Council, including a green finance and fintech initiative, talent exchanges, and aviation cooperation. Singapore Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung and Guangdong governor Ma Xingrui co-chaired the meeting, which marked the first provincial business council meeting between Singapore and China amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The partnership aims to strengthen economic relations and promote greater ease of access to market opportunities in the Greater Bay Area and South-east Asia.

site_title: Off the air: top Philippines broadcaster shuts regional stations
summary: The Philippines' top broadcaster, ABS-CBN, has shut down 53 regional stations, affecting hundreds of journalists, including anchor Dhobie de Guzman. The closure follows the loss of its free-to-air licence in May, which led to a decline in advertising revenues. The move will deprive millions of Filipinos of local news and entertainment, highlighting the critical role of ABS-CBN in the country's media landscape. The broadcaster's operations were criticized by President Rodrigo Duterte, further exacerbating the situation.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant IPO fuels frenzy not seen since dotcom bubble
summary: Jack Ma's Ant Group is set to raise at least $30 billion in its initial public offering (IPO), potentially surpassing the record $62 billion raised in 1999, according to Bloomberg data. This could propel technology capital-raising in 2020 to record heights, fueling a frenzy not seen since the dotcom bubble. The surge in IPOs, including those from DoorDash and Airbnb, has led investors to question whether a bubble is forming, but experts say there are unique aspects to this year's tech mania, including sheer size and a favorable market environment.

site_title: Mainland buyers return to Hong Kong market after unrest, Covid-19
summary: Mainland Chinese investors are returning to Hong Kong's commercial property market after prices plummeted 30% due to anti-government protests and the Covid-19 pandemic. In August, they bought at least two office towers and one hotel worth HK$4 billion. Chinese investors now account for 39% of total commercial real estate transactions in Hong Kong, up from 19% in 2019. Experts expect the influx of Chinese capital to prop up the sector as China recovers from the pandemic and Beijing asserts control over Hong Kong.

site_title: Japan's PM candidate Kishida cautious about cutting sales tax
summary: Japan's PM candidate Fumio Kishida has expressed caution over cutting the sales tax rate to 8 percent, citing concerns about burdening small and midsize companies with additional costs. Kishida stated that the sales tax is a source of revenue for social welfare and that demand won't bounce back strongly due to the prolonged COVID-19 battle. This comes as a group of ruling party lawmakers have called for cutting the tax to cushion the pandemic's blow on households, but senior officials have ruled it out. Kishida's cautious stance may impact his chances of becoming the next prime minister.

site_title: SP Group partners CapitaLand JV to develop energy-saving solutions in China
summary: SP Group and CapitaLand's joint venture company, GKC, have partnered to develop district cooling, heating, and integrated energy solutions in China's greenfield master development, the China-Singapore Guangzhou Knowledge City. The solutions will help achieve energy savings and contribute to a cleaner, more sustainable energy future. The partnership will also integrate sustainable energy solutions, such as distributed energy and energy efficiency systems, and could be extended to other projects within the CSGKC area.

site_title: Japan looks to AI as coronavirus challenges go-and-see quality control mantra
summary: Japan is shifting from its traditional "go and see" quality control system to AI-powered inspection methods, driven by the need for social distancing during the coronavirus pandemic. Robots are being used to scan parts for flaws, freeing human inspectors to focus on more creative tasks. A joint venture between Israeli entrepreneur Ran Poliakine's SixAI and Musashi Seimitsu Industry Co Ltd has developed AI-powered quality control robots, with interest from automakers and manufacturers worldwide. The approach represents a departure from Toyota's long-held "genchi genbutsu" methodology, with the goal of freeing humans to focus on improving production processes.

site_title: Demand for online doctors creates US$39b titan in Japan
summary: M3 Inc, an online provider of medical information and services backed by Sony Corp, has become a US$39 billion global behemoth with 40 subsidiaries and affiliates. Founded by Itaru Tanimura, the company has seen its shares surge 100% this year, driven by the demand for online doctor capabilities during the Covid-19 pandemic. M3's operating profit climbed 26% in the quarter, beating analyst estimates, and the company's acquisition spree has expanded its presence in Japan, China, India, and France.

site_title: Buffett's Berkshire takes stake in Japan trading firms
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has acquired 5% stakes in five leading Japanese trading companies: Itochu Corp, Marubeni Corp, Mitsubishi Corp, Mitsui & Co, and Sumitomo Corp, valued at over $6 billion. The stakes were acquired over a year through regular purchases on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, with plans to hold Japanese investments for the long term. The move was met with significant stock price increases for the five firms, with some rising as high as 10%. Buffett expressed his excitement for potential "opportunities of mutual benefit" with the Japanese firms.

site_title: Nestle in US$2.6b deal for allergy treatment maker Aimmune
summary: Nestle has agreed to purchase Aimmune Therapeutics Inc, a US biotech firm, in a US$2.6 billion deal. Aimmune's Palforzia is the only FDA-approved treatment for reducing peanut allergies in children. The deal represents a 174% premium to Aimmune's closing price on Friday. This acquisition marks Nestle's expansion of its health science arm, following its previous US$2.3 billion deal for Canadian supplements maker Atrium Innovations.

site_title: Keep on dining out, UK minister urges as popular cut-price offer ends
summary: UK Finance Minister Rishi Sunak urged people to continue dining out as the "Eat out to Help Out" scheme, offering half-price food, came to an end. The scheme boosted the hospitality sector, with over 64 million meals served and a 95% increase in average seated diners between Monday and Wednesday this month compared to last year. The government's initiative helped protect 1.8 million jobs in the sector, which was severely impacted by the coronavirus pandemic. Several restaurant chains have announced they will continue offering the discount in September.

site_title: Singapore's economy must adapt with greater integration, new connections: Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for Singapore's economy to adapt to the post-Covid world by taking a more integrated approach, developing human potential, and finding new ways to be a global node. He identified four key areas for adaptation: (1) strengthening the tripartite relationship between government, businesses, and the labor movement, (2) developing everyone to their fullest potential through lifelong learning, (3) identifying and spotting opportunities for growth, and (4) forging new connections with the rest of the world. Heng stressed the importance of adapting while staying true to Singapore's values and maintaining social cohesion.

site_title: High Court grants OCBC's application to place KS Energy, key unit under IJMs
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted OCBC's application to place KS Energy and its key unit, KS Drilling, under interim judicial management (IJM). The decision was made after OCBC sent letters of demand for a US$230.7 million term loan and a S$5 million bridging loan to KS Drilling, citing concerns over the firm's management and financial health following the filing of criminal charges against its former chairman and CEO. The court appointed Deloitte & Touche as interim judicial managers, pending a hearing on the JM application, which has been fixed for September 10.

site_title: Genting Hong Kong gets interest from investors for cruise brand
summary: Genting Hong Kong, a cruise ship operator, has received indicative letters from private investors interested in investing in one of its cruise brands, with a goal to secure funding by June 2021. The company, which has a net loss of $687.1 million, has suspended all payments to creditors and owes $3.4 billion. Genting Hong Kong plans to delay $1.3 billion in capital commitments and is applying for long-term funding from the German government's Economic Stabilization Fund. The company expects to resume shipyard operations in October and believes it can fulfill its financial obligations with new funding and cost-cutting measures.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB downgrades 'too fast, too furious' fintech iFast to 'hold'
summary: Singapore-based wealth management and brokerage platform iFast Corp has been downgraded to "hold" by CGS-CIMB from "add", but the target price was increased to S$2.44 due to expected higher stockbroking revenue and reduced operating expenses. The analyst believes iFast's collaborations with top-tier digital players will entrench its franchise value in the region, despite market exuberance pricing in the company's prospects for winning government contracts and licenses.

site_title: China building boom splits Australia into two-speed economy
summary: Australia's economy is experiencing a twin-speed phenomenon, with the western states booming due to strong demand from China for iron ore, while the eastern states struggle with Covid-19 outbreaks and border closures. This divergence poses a challenge for the Reserve Bank of Australia as it seeks to tackle spiralling unemployment and the economy's first recession in nearly 30 years. The central bank has cut interest rates to a record low, and economists predict a 6% contraction in the second quarter, with some forecasting a two-year currency surge.

site_title: Elite Partners acquires Poland warehouse for more than 30m euros from GIC unit
summary: Elite Partners, a private equity firm, has acquired a 58,500 sq m warehouse in Mszczonów, Poland for over 30 million euros from GIC's P3 Logistics Park. The facility is the largest in PepsiCo Poland's distribution network, consolidating logistics processes previously run from multiple locations. This acquisition boosts Elite Partners' presence in Mszczonów Park to six buildings, totaling over 230,000 sq m. The move aligns with the company's strategy to build a pan-European portfolio of specialized logistics assets in Poland and the UK.

site_title: Australia's IOOF to buy NAB's wealth unit for A$1.44b, eyes cost savings
summary: IOOF Holdings agreed to acquire National Australia Bank's (NAB) wealth management business for A$1.44 billion, aiming to save costs and expand its reach. The acquisition is expected to be completed by June 30, 2021, with annual pre-tax cost savings of A$150 million by the third full year. IOOF will fund about A$1 billion of the deal value through an institutional placement and entitlement offer, while the rest will be via debt. NAB will book a post-tax loss of about A$400 million on the divestment.

site_title: China's factory activity slows in August as flooding hits business
summary: China's factory activity slowed in August, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dipping to 51.0 from 51.1 in July. Heavy flooding in Sichuan and southwestern China impacted production and demand, but demand is still recovering and exports are improving. The non-manufacturing PMI rose to 55.2 points, while the PMI for small companies fell to 47.7 points, still in contraction territory. Analysts expect further growth in industrial activity with fiscal support set to increase in the coming months.

site_title: China launches second probe into Australian wine imports
summary: China has launched an anti-subsidy investigation on Australian wine imports, two weeks after launching an anti-dumping probe. The investigation aims to examine if Australian wines received subsidies from the Australian government. China's commerce ministry will review 37 subsidy items granted by the Australian government, including farm financing and business growth projects. The investigation is ongoing, with a completion deadline of either within a year or by end-February 2022. The move comes amid strained relations between China and Australia, which has been a major market for Australian wine exports.

site_title: New Zealand bourse says markets to open as usual after last week's cyber attacks
summary: New Zealand's stock exchange, NZX Ltd, plans to reopen markets on Monday after a series of cyber attacks disrupted operations for four consecutive days. The attacks, described as the largest in the country, targeted the bourse's ability to operate normally, causing trading halts and disruptions. NZX is working with cybersecurity experts to implement additional security measures to prevent similar disruptions in the future. Markets are expected to open as usual on Monday.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS says suburban malls a 'safer bet' over Orchard Road malls
summary: DBS Group Research has upgraded its outlook on suburban malls, calling them a "safer bet" over tourist-focused Orchard Road malls due to steady foot traffic and sales. Analyst Derek Tan expects a 19.7% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) in FY2021 and a forward sector yield of 6.7%. DBS maintains "buy" calls on Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT), CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT), and LendLease Global Commercial Reit, while keeping a "hold" call on SPH Reit.

site_title: Japan's July industrial output rises 8.0% m-o-m
summary: Japan's industrial output rose 8.0% in July from the previous month, marking a second consecutive month of gains amid a tentative recovery from the coronavirus-induced slump. This surpasses the median market forecast of a 5.8% increase. Manufacturers expect output to rise 4.0% in August and 1.9% in September.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rallied over 1% at the open on Monday, driven by better-than-expected data on Chinese factory activity in August. The Hang Sang Index rose 1.22% to 25,732.49, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.37% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.45%. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and fresh records for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Asia: Most markets extend rally after fresh Wall Street record
summary: Asian markets continued their rally on Monday, with most markets extending their gains after US borrowing costs were expected to remain low for the foreseeable future. The US Federal Reserve's pledge of trillions of dollars in support helped fuel the surge in equities, with the Nasdaq almost doubling since its March trough. Tokyo led the advancers, surging 2% after Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's resignation, while Hong Kong and Shanghai also saw big gains. Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway also boosted shares in Japan's big five companies.

site_title: Australia Q2 inventories, wages decline amid first recession in 30 years
summary: Australia's Q2 inventories fell 3% due to panic buying during coronavirus-driven lockdowns, while wages declined amid massive job losses, marking the country's first recession in 30 years. Gross company profits unexpectedly rose 15% in the second quarter, largely due to government subsidies. This contrasts with economists' expectations of a 6% decline in GDP. The coronavirus pandemic has shuttered entire sectors of the economy, resulting in significant job losses and a deepening recession.

site_title: Japan July retail sales fall 2.8% y-o-y: government
summary: Japan's retail sales dropped 2.8% in July from the previous year, exceeding the median forecast of a 1.7% decrease. This marks the second consecutive month of decline. The country's economy continues to be affected by the COVID-19 pandemic and other factors.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Sabana Reit, ESR-Reit, OCBC, DBS, Wing Tai, CDLHT
summary: Keppel Corporation is prepared to support KrisEnergy's final restructuring proposal, which may prevent the firm's potential liquidation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore clarified that its regulatory framework does not prohibit a shareholder group from owning substantial stakes in two Reit managers. Sabana Reit and ESR-Reit units closed flat on Friday, and the Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor optimism despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Alternative data - a much needed fuel for recovery
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the need for alternative data to improve financial inclusion, particularly for the 1 billion unbanked or underbanked individuals in Asia. Alternative data, such as telco and utility bills, can provide a more holistic view of customers, enabling lenders to make informed decisions and provide micro-loans to those who may not have a formal credit score. As online transactions rise, the rate of alternative data production is expected to increase, paving the way for improved financial inclusion and paving the road to recovery for vulnerable communities.

site_title: SBI Offshore fails to complete RTO, must make exit offer to shareholders
summary: SBI Offshore, a Catalist-listed firm, is required to make a cash exit offer to shareholders after failing to complete its proposed acquisition of the Berlitz group of 12 companies by the deadline of August 31. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has terminated its review of the acquisition and will delist SBI shares only after the company makes a fair and reasonable exit offer. SBI will appoint an independent financial adviser to advise on the offer and inform shareholders about its plans and timeline.

site_title: Australia: Shares wobble ahead of cenbank rate decision; New Zealand falls
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 6,083.60 ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's cash rate decision on Tuesday, but gains were capped by concerns over an economic recovery amid a record daily rise in coronavirus-related deaths. The decision is expected to hold the cash rate at its all-time low.

site_title: Axington requests voluntary trading suspension pending announcement
summary: Axington Inc, a Catalist-listed company, has requested a voluntary suspension of its share trading pending an announcement on "strategic changes" to its business direction. The move comes amid scrutiny over its non-executive chairman, Evangeline Shen, and her ties to the Loh family, who recently took over the company. The announcement may address concerns surrounding Shen's experience and integrity, following a series of controversies surrounding the Loh family's business ventures.

site_title: Tycoon-backed Saxo Bank reveals Hong Kong expansion plans
summary: Saxo Bank, backed by Chinese billionaire Li Shu Fu, plans to expand its business in Hong Kong despite the tense political climate. CEO Kim Fournais stated the firm aims to increase its presence in the city, citing its strategic location as a "gateway to China." Saxo had a record $60 billion in client assets at the end of June and its biggest first-half net profit in five years. The company is structuring its Chinese and global activities separately to maintain data sharing and is aligned with its majority Chinese shareholder, Zhejiang Geely Holding Group.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 1.20% at 23,157.15. The rally was driven by gains on Wall Street, as the yen strengthened against the dollar. The broader Topix index also advanced 1.16%. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Fed making room for higher inflation to help economy
summary: The US Federal Reserve has formally overhauled its mission, allowing inflation to run above its 2% target to jump-start the economy. This move signals a more accommodative stance, benefiting buyouts, leverage, and mortgage rates. US stocks rose last week, reaching a new record high, driven by trillions of dollars in Fed and government support. However, skeptics question the sustainability of these gains, citing the ongoing recession and concerns about valuations of "coronavirus winners" like Amazon and Tesla.

site_title: US real estate pain leaves foreign investors in the lurch
summary: Foreign investors who backed US real estate projects in exchange for US visas are facing financial losses due to the pandemic-driven commercial property crisis. EB-5 investors, who accepted low returns, have less leverage than usual, making it difficult for them to recover their money. Several cases, including Hudson Yards and the Nassau Coliseum, have been reported where investors are seeking arbitration or have assumed the lease to avoid financial losses. The pandemic has exposed weaknesses in the EB-5 programme, which was meant to promote investment in rural and urban areas, but has become a Wild West with false promises and conflicts of interest.

images.alt_text: Roughly 2,000 EB-5 investors poured US$1 billion into Hudson Yards through deals under EB-5, a programme meant to promote investment in rural areas, as well as urban locales with high unemployment.

site_title: LMIRT to buy strata title units of Lippo Mall Puri at lowered price of 3.5t rupiah
summary: LMIRT has agreed to buy strata title units of Lippo Mall Puri at a lower price of 3.5 trillion rupiah (S$330.2 million), a 9.47% discount to the two independent valuations. The Reit's manager will finance the acquisition through debt and a rights issue, and the mall's owner will provide vendor support and financing. The deal includes leasing of uncommitted space and a target net property income of 340 billion rupiah from FY2021 to FY2024.

site_title: Hot stock: Halcyon Agri jumps 18.2% after announcing perpetuals
summary: Halcyon Agri Corp announced plans to issue perpetual securities instead of a rights issue, proposing a more optimal and equitable funding option given current market conditions. The company's shares rose 18.2% after the announcement, with the stock trading at 23.5 cents as of 10:08am on Monday. The issuance of perpetual securities will raise greater net proceeds than the previously proposed rights issue, which would have brought in US$125.4 million in net proceeds. Chinese state-owned enterprise Sinochem International Corp plans to provide a corporate guarantee to support the issuance of up to US$200 million of perps.

site_title: In South India, Amazon builds its largest office yet
summary: Amazon has built its largest office in the world, a 1.8 million square foot facility in Hyderabad, India, marking the retail giant's expansion into the country. The office, which features amenities like prayer rooms and a helipad, is part of Amazon's growing presence in India, where it has 40 other offices, 67 shipping centers, and over 60,000 employees. However, the project faces pushback from local businesses and politicians, who argue that Amazon's dominance in e-commerce is hurting domestic trade and small businesses.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.7% or 18.5 points to 2,558.13 on Monday, driven by gains in banks and other index counters after Wall Street stocks climbed on Friday. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, rose 1.7%, 0.7%, and 0.7% respectively. Other active index counters included Singtel and Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust, which held steady and rose 1.2% respectively. The gains followed a higher open, with 122 gainers outnumbering 48 losers.

site_title: Should Sabana Reit minorities ask board, senior personnel to resign if merger does not succeed?
summary: Sabana Reit's minority unitholders must vote against the proposed merger with ESR-Reit to stop it. The merger requires 50% of Sabana Reit's unitholders, holding 75% of its units, to approve. Minority unitholders, including those advising entities owning over 10% of Sabana Reit, have already expressed opposition. Unitholders may consider asking the board and senior personnel to resign if the merger doesn't succeed, as this could lead to a more independent manager and fresh initiatives to unlock value.

site_title: US floats idea of early approval for eventual vaccine
summary: US FDA chief Stephen Hahn suggests that a future COVID-19 vaccine could receive emergency approval before the end of Phase 3 trials, which involve large-scale human testing. This would require a request from the vaccine developer. Hahn emphasized that the decision would be based on science and data, not politics. The move comes as the US and other countries await effective vaccines amid criticism of China and Russia's vaccine approvals without trial completion.

site_title: Police break up forest rave in England amid Covid-19 clampdown
summary: Police in England broke up an overnight illegal rave in Thetford Forest, amid a Covid-19 clampdown. Dozens of officers dispersed the party, which was attended by dozens of people, without making any arrests. The gathering, which took place before a three-day bank holiday weekend, was one of several illegal raves in England as the government tries to balance economic reopening with public health protection. The police dismantled the sound system and enforced a 10,000-pound fine for those facilitating or organizing the event, which was deemed a "serious breach" of restrictions.

site_title: Opening up to fresh viewpoints
summary: Singaporeans share diverse ideas on how the city-state can innovate and progress. Some propose a paperless environment, while others suggest expanding the Cabinet to include non-elected experts. Victor Mills advocates for publicly denouncing anti-foreign sentiment, while Lawrence Loh suggests widening the pool of talent for the Cabinet. Others, like Max Loh and Charles Ferguson, emphasize the need for inclusivity and citizen participation in policy-making. The experts also agree that Singapore should focus on developing human traits independent of context to thrive in Industry 4.0, and that a culture of failure and learning is crucial for innovation.

site_title: Neymar, Nike part ways after 15 years
summary: Nike has parted ways with Brazilian soccer star Neymar after 15 years, ending a high-profile sponsorship deal. The 28-year-old Paris Saint-Germain and Brazil talisman was in talks with Puma, reportedly due to contract renewal negotiations failing. Neymar's last deal with Nike was an 11-year contract worth $105 million, set to expire in 2022. Despite the split, Neymar will still wear Nike apparel on the pitch, as the company sponsors both PSG and the Brazilian national team.

site_title: Covid-19 forces rethink of operations and digitalisation
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has prompted businesses to rethink their operations and digitalize their strategies for internationalization. Consultants and experts, such as PwC and McKinsey, emphasize the importance of boots on the web, leveraging e-commerce, and remote collaboration to stay competitive. Manufacturers, in particular, are adopting digital technologies to address worker shortages and enhance productivity. The Enterprise Singapore's Scale-up SG initiative has supported over 40 companies in digitalization, business model reinvention, and internationalization efforts, with a focus on agility, innovation, and reskilling workers.

site_title: Keppel Corp ready to back KrisEnergy's final proposal
summary: Keppel Corp, a 40% stakeholder in KrisEnergy, is prepared to support the company's final restructuring proposal, which involves a debt-to-equity swap and reduced dilution for existing shareholders. The proposal, subject to inter-conditional approvals, aims to restructure KrisEnergy's debt and avoid liquidation. Keppel Corp believes the plan is a "deliverable plan" and does not expect a material impact on its net tangible assets or earnings per share. The company hopes for a successful conclusion to the financial restructuring in the next few months.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust drops independent director
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) dropped independent director Carl Gabriel Florian Stubbe after he was not re-elected by Reit managers' shareholder Mandarin West Holdings. Stubbe had offered to continue as independent director but felt the decision was "to the detriment" of stapled security holders. Despite being approved as chairman of the upcoming annual general meeting, Stubbe was notified of his non-re-election on August 28. This move comes after Mandarin West indirectly owns substantial influence over EHT through joint ownership with Urban Commons, the Reit's sponsor.

site_title: Neymar, Nike part ways after 15 years
summary: Nike has parted ways with soccer star Neymar after 15 years, ending their high-profile sponsorship deal. The 28-year-old Paris Saint-Germain and Brazil player was in talks with Puma, reportedly due to a contract dispute over renewal terms. Neymar's last deal with Nike was worth $105 million, and his current earnings are estimated at $95.5 million. The split comes after a year of controversy, including tax fraud allegations and a rape accusation.

site_title: As fintech upends banking, Japan regulator expects more cross-boundary tie-ups
summary: Japan's financial regulator expects more cross-boundary tie-ups in the country's banking industry, driven by fintech advances. Senior regulator Teruhisa Kurita said industry boundaries are likely to disappear, leading to new combinations of services. This follows SBI Holdings' tie-ups with regional banks, breaking traditional boundaries. Kurita stated that structural changes in Japan's banking industry are possible, triggered by fintech advancements.

site_title: SGX gives nod for CMT to list up to 2.78b new units, CCT to delist
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has granted in-principle approval for CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) to list up to 2.78 billion new units as part of its merger by way of a trust scheme with CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT). The SGX also has no objection to the proposed delisting of CCT, subject to the trust scheme becoming effective. The merger requires court approval, compliance with listing requirements, and approval from CMT's independent unitholders.

site_title: Relief as Davos is postponed, but it's bad news for businesses
summary: The World Economic Forum's annual gathering in Davos, Switzerland, has been postponed to the early summer due to the coronavirus pandemic. This decision brings relief to some residents but is a concern for local businesses, which rely heavily on the event for revenue. The postponement is expected to leave restaurants, bars, and hotels without the usual influx of guests, resulting in reduced income for local workers and businesses. While some business owners see a silver lining in the potential for increased local tourism in the summer, others fear a prolonged economic impact.

site_title: Dollar drops after shift in Fed policy
summary: The US dollar dropped 1.1% against the Japanese yen to 105.38 after US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's remarks at the Jackson Hole conference suggested keeping interest rates low. The yen surged due to uncertainty over Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's resignation and potential shift away from his expansionary economic policy. The dollar index fell 0.7% to 92.325, with the euro rising 0.63% to $1.1896.

site_title: Trump presses law and order message as protest turns deadly
summary: A man was shot dead in Portland, Oregon, during a pro-Trump rally, marking the latest violence in anti-racism protests. The incident occurred after a week of nationwide protests over the police shooting of Jacob Blake in Kenosha, Wisconsin. President Donald Trump has pressed his "law and order" message, criticizing Democratic nominee Joe Biden for being weak on violent crime. Trump has threatened to send federal forces to Portland if Mayor Ted Wheeler doesn't crack down on protests.

images.alt_text: A man was shot dead in the US city of Portland, police said Sunday, the latest violence to upend anti-racism protests as President Donald Trump presses an election message characterising his Democratic opponent Joe Biden as weak on violent crime.

site_title: Halcyon Agri proposes issue of guaranteed perps in place of rights issue
summary: Halcyon Agri Corp, a Singapore-based natural rubber supplier, proposes issuing guaranteed perpetual securities instead of a rights issue to raise funds. The move comes after the company's shares fell 20% since June. Chinese state-owned Sinochem International Corp has agreed to provide a corporate guarantee to support the issuance of up to $200 million in guaranteed perpetual securities, estimated to yield greater net proceeds than the earlier proposed rights issue. The provision is subject to approval from Sinochem shareholders at an upcoming meeting.

site_title: Cheaper diamonds fire life into the hidden world of gem trading
summary: The global diamond industry is showing signs of recovery after a six-month pandemic-induced standstill. De Beers and Russian miner Alrosa PJSC cut diamond prices by almost 10% in a bid to stimulate demand, sparking a surge in rough diamond sales worth about half a billion dollars. This development brings relief to a supply chain paralyzed by the pandemic and follows a report by Tiffany & Co that its jewelry sales are improving monthly. The recovery is seen as a positive sign, with industry experts citing consumer data and a rebounding Chinese market as key factors.

site_title: Subsidies to F&B sector crucial despite possibility of creating zombie firms
summary: Singapore's food and beverage (F&B) sector received substantial subsidies to weather the pandemic, raising concerns about "zombie firms" that may be artificially kept alive. Experts, including Jochen Krauss and Andrew Kwan, say subsidies are necessary to prevent job losses and economic damage, but may inadvertently extend the life of unviable businesses. While some firms may be able to pivot, a small number may remain unviable, and the government's assistance schemes require business owners to bear most costs, making it less likely for large numbers of zombie firms to emerge.

images.alt_text: Substantial subsidies administered to the food and beverage (F&B) sector to help it weather the pandemic have raised concerns about inadvertently keeping alive firms that are fundamentally unviable, referred to as "zombie firms".

site_title: EU, UK in deadlock, ahead of next round of post-Brexit trade talks
summary: The UK and EU are set to begin the next round of post-Brexit trade talks in London, with a deadline of December 31 for a deal. Key stumbling blocks include the EU's desire for a level competitive playing field and the UK's fisheries policy, particularly the control of its fishing waters. The EU is pushing for the UK to give up state aid to industries, while the UK is seeking to maintain control over its fishing waters, which could impact Scottish polls favoring independence. A deal must be reached by October for EU member states to ratify it ahead of the transition period end date.

site_title: US coronavirus cases top six million as Midwest, schools face outbreaks
summary: US coronavirus cases have surpassed 6 million, with recent increases reported in the Midwest, including record one-day increases in Iowa, North Dakota, South Dakota, and Minnesota. Many colleges and universities are experiencing outbreaks after students returned to campus, forcing some to switch to online-only learning. The US continues to struggle with testing, with many states rejecting new guidance that recommends testing asymptomatic carriers. Nationally, metrics on new cases, deaths, and hospitalizations are declining, but emerging hotspots in the Midwest and record hospitalizations in Montana and Idaho are concerning.

images.alt_text: Iowa, North Dakota, South Dakota and Minnesota have recently reported record one-day increases in new cases while Montana and Idaho are seeing record numbers of currently hospitalised covid-19 patients.

site_title: Dow Jones still in the game
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) has continued to perform well despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, increasing by over 52% since its March 2020 low. Recent changes to the index, including the replacement of Exxon Mobil with Salesforce, aim to reflect the overall economy trend and technology sector exposure. The index has broken resistance levels and formed a golden cross, indicating a potential uptrend. A bullish scenario suggests the index could continue to rise, while a bearish scenario warns of a potential correction if the RSI bearish divergence is validated.

site_title: Venice Film Festival seeks to dodge coronavirus and controversy
summary: The Venice Film Festival, the world's oldest film festival, is set to open on Wednesday, despite the ongoing coronavirus crisis and controversy over gender inequality. The festival has implemented safety measures, including limited seating and thermal scanners, to protect attendees. With most Hollywood elites unable to attend due to travel restrictions, the festival has scaled down its size and lineup. Despite this, the festival's director has promised to preserve the "liveliness of contemporary cinema" and the festival will feature a jury led by Australian actress Cate Blanchett.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust drops independent director Carl Stubbe
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) announced that independent director Carl Stubbe was not re-elected by Reit managers Mandarin West Holdings. Stubbe, who was willing to continue his role, expressed disappointment, stating the decision was "to the detriment" of stapled security holders. Despite being approved as chairman of the upcoming AGM, Stubbe was notified he was not re-elected as director on August 28. The decision is attributed to the influence of joint owners Howard Wu and Taylor Woods, who also control Urban Commons, EHT's sponsor and Reit manager.

site_title: What you need to know about Jack Ma's Ant Group as IPO looms
summary: Billionaire Jack Ma's Ant Group is set to launch the world's largest initial public offering with a valuation of $225 billion, listing in Hong Kong and Shanghai. The company, a 2011 offshoot of Alibaba Group, dominates China's payments market through its Alipay app, which has 711 million active users. Ant has diversified its business, with lending units generating 39% of revenue, and is now applying for a licence to set up a consumer finance company. The firm faces challenges, including rising US-China trade tensions and regulatory hurdles, but is expected to boost its lending capacity and expand its asset management business.

site_title: Virus lockdowns give major boost to e-commerce
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has given e-commerce a significant boost, with international e-commerce growing 41% in three months compared to 22% for the entire year. In contrast, traditional retailers have announced major layoffs, including Marks & Spencer's 7,000 staff cuts. Online giants like Amazon, Zalando, and Walmart have seen strong growth, with Amazon doubling its net profits. The trend has accelerated the digitization of commerce, with companies needing to invest in online presence to compete with big hitters like Amazon.

site_title: CDLHT rides on staycation wave with W hotel acquisition
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) has successfully acquired the W Singapore - Sentosa Cove hotel, capitalizing on the staycation trend in Singapore. The hotel's occupancy rates have reached up to 60-65% on Fridays and Saturdays, with the acquisition being well-timed to tap into the staycation business following the COVID-19 outbreak. The hotel received approval to operate as a staycation destination in July, and CDLHT completed the purchase on July 16.

site_title: Supply chain shifts and reshoring to have mixed credit impact on Asean: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service reports that supply chain shifts in Asean due to the Covid-19 pandemic and trade tensions will have mixed credit implications. While trade diversification will favor Asean economies, reshoring of supply chains could move productive capacity away, particularly in sectors with heightened security requirements. To mitigate this, Asean can enhance free trade agreements with advanced economies and deepen its linkages in Asia through regional multilateral trade agreements. The region's growing middle class will drive consumption and investment, but it needs to address structural challenges to harness its full potential.

site_title: HK survey shows increasing majority back pro-democracy goals, smaller support for protest movement
summary: A survey in Hong Kong found a growing majority (60%) opposes the national security law introduced by China, with nearly 60% also opposing the law itself. Pro-democracy movement support remains steady at 44%, while backing for key aspirations such as an independent commission of inquiry and universal suffrage remains strong. The survey also showed a rise in support for amnesty for arrested protesters and opposition to the pro-democracy movement's demands. The survey was conducted after the implementation of the security law, which critics say further eroded Hong Kong's freedoms.

site_title: Judicial manager PwC suing OK Lim and his 2 children for US$3.5b
summary: Judicial manager PwC is suing OK Lim and his two children, Evan Lim and Lim Huey Ching, for US$3.5 billion, alleging they breached their fiduciary duties as directors and engaged in fraudulent trading at insolvent oil trader Hin Leong Trading. PwC claims the Lims concealed losses, forged documents, and manipulated accounts to deceive banks into lending money. The lawsuit seeks to clawback US$90 million in dividends paid by the Lim family and recover US$623 million in outstanding debt. The case challenges earlier claims by Evan Lim about his role in hiding US$800 million in losses.

site_title: Chief Cabinet secretary Suga hopes to succeed PM Abe; race heats up
summary: Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga will run for prime minister after Shinzo Abe's sudden resignation, joining a crowded field of candidates. Suga, a longtime Abe lieutenant, will likely extend fiscal and monetary stimulus, and is seen as capable of managing crises like the COVID-19 pandemic. The Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) is expected to hold a slimmed-down leadership election on September 13-15, with Suga's candidacy seen as a surprise move despite low voter polls.

site_title: CEO of world's biggest wealth fund reflects on being unpopular
summary: Nicolai Tangen, the new CEO of Norway's $1.2 trillion wealth fund, has reflected on his unpopular appointment, stating that pleasing everyone can be a path to failure. Tangen, who will take over on September 1, drew on his experience as a hedge fund manager, saying he needs to be used to being unpopular and capable of shifting gears when the world changes. He also cited a past experience in Kristiansand, Norway, where he faced backlash over a project, but prevailed and gained experience in being unpopular.

site_title: Halcyon Agri proposes issue of guaranteed perpetual securities in place of rights issue
summary: Halcyon Agri Corp has proposed issuing guaranteed perpetual securities instead of a rights issue to raise funds. The move is seen as more optimal and equitable amid current market conditions. Chinese state-owned enterprise Sinochem International Corp has agreed to provide a corporate guarantee worth up to $200 million, estimated to yield greater proceeds than the earlier proposed rights issue. The issuance is expected to enhance the firm's financial position and provide greater financial flexibility, with no dilution of minority holdings.

site_title: China oil refining giant bleeds after Covid-19 saps fuel demand
summary: China's largest oil refiner, Sinopec, reported its first-ever half-year loss of 21.7 billion yuan due to the COVID-19 pandemic and oil price crash, despite the country's economy recovering. The company's operating loss at its main refining business was 31.69 billion yuan, down from a profit of 19 billion yuan last year. Sinopec also lowered its full-year capital expenditure outlook by 10% and plans to boost refining output in the second half. The company's total production decreased 0.4% to 225.7 million barrels of oil equivalent.

site_title: 54 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 8 in the community
summary: Singapore reported 54 new Covid-19 cases, including 8 in the community, bringing the total to 56,771. The cases include 7 community cases and 7 imported cases. 51 new cases were reported on Saturday, with 37 being dormitory residents already quarantined or isolated. 110 cases were discharged, bringing the total recovered to 55,432. The number of unlinked cases has remained stable, averaging 1 case a day over the past two weeks.

site_title: New firms crop up in F&B sector during H1 despite Covid-19
summary: Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, Singapore's food and beverage (F&B) sector saw a net increase of 96 active entities in the first half of 2020, with 1,132 firms joining and 1,036 deregistered, according to data analysis firm Handshakes. Industry experts attribute this growth to entrepreneurs seizing opportunities created by the crisis, such as diminished competition and increased demand for takeaway food.
