However, they also warn that entering the industry can be challenging, with thin margins, rising rents, and a high risk of failure, making it essential for newcomers to carefully consider their entry strategy.

site_title: New Yorkers celebrate Met's reopening as a sign life is returning
summary: The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City reopened its doors to the public after a nearly six-month closure due to the coronavirus pandemic. Visitors celebrated the reopening, despite the new virus protocol requiring mask-wearing, temperature checks, and timed ticketing. The museum's president, Daniel Weiss, expressed confidence in the city's ability to bounce back from the pandemic, citing the institution's financial adaptability and plans for a more inclusive museum. The reopening marks a step towards normalcy for New York, with officials acknowledging the financial blow but expressing optimism about the city's resilience.

site_title: Tennis: Nadal, Federer call for 'unity' as Djokovic hails new players association
summary: Novak Djokovic announced the formation of the Professional Tennis Players Association (PTPA), a new men's pro tennis players' association, amid concerns from Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer about a potential breakaway union. Djokovic said the group aims to co-exist with the ATP and has no plans for a boycott or parallel tour. Nadal and Federer expressed support for unity, urging players to work together to address challenges in the sport. The PTPA will initially focus on reaching out to top 500 singles players and 200 doubles players.

images.alt_text: Novak Djokovic shrugged off concerns of Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer and announced the formation of a new men's pro tennis players' association that promises to put him on a collision course with his two elite rivals.

site_title: Bringing home back-office bank jobs won't fix labour tensions: analysts
summary: Singapore banks are unlikely to solve labor tensions by bringing back offshore back-office jobs, analysts say. While some banks, like DBS, have chosen to keep these roles in-house, experts argue that this is a temporary fix. Many of these jobs are being phased out or automated due to digital transformation and technology advancements. Instead, analysts suggest focusing on developing local talents for higher-value-added managerial and mission-critical roles to boost Singapore's banking and finance industry.

site_title: Handshakes to launch new data sets in Vietnam and China
summary: Handshakes, a corporate data analysis platform, plans to launch data sets in Vietnam and China, capitalizing on the growing demand for private market data from potential investors. With its Singapore-based data set, clients can map connections between companies and people in the region, providing a clearer picture of local companies. The platform aims to bring greater transparency and efficiency to the due diligence process, with demand expected to increase despite frozen budgets and reduced spending.

site_title: Mustafa Centre to send back foreign workers whose work passes expire, stop paying some of its staff
summary: Mustafa Centre, a Singaporean shopping mall, will send back foreign workers whose work passes have expired due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on its business. The company will also stop paying a sustenance allowance of S$300 per month to employees not called to work, urging them to find a second job. Mustafa Centre will pay for the return tickets of foreign workers and provide a month's basic salary as a token. The company has seen a 80% decline in business since the pandemic and has closed its international borders, leading to reduced opening hours and strict safe distancing measures.

site_title: China oil refining giant bleeds after Covid saps fuel demand
summary: China's largest oil refiner, Sinopec, posted its first-ever half-year loss of 21.7 billion yuan due to the pandemic's impact on fuel demand and the oil price crash. Sinopec plans to boost refining output in the second half as the economy recovers.

site_title: Ex-Trump acting chief of staff Mulvaney starting hedge fund
summary: Former Trump administration official Mick Mulvaney is launching a hedge fund, Exegis Capital, with investor Andrew Wessel. The long-short fund aims to capitalize on knowledge of major regulatory changes affecting the financial services industry. Mulvaney, a former acting White House chief of staff and special US envoy to Northern Ireland, will utilize his experience in the Office of Management and Budget and Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. site_title: Huawei focusing on cloud business which still has access to US chips: FT
summary: Huawei is focusing on its cloud business to secure its survival, despite US sanctions. The company's cloud computing business, which sells computing power and storage, has been growing rapidly and has access to US chips. Huawei put the unit on an equal footing with its smartphones and telecoms equipment businesses in January. Beijing is supporting the company through public cloud contracts, and the unit is stepping up its offerings. This move aims to ensure Huawei's survival amid restrictions on technology exports to Chinese companies, particularly Huawei.

site_title: First Israel-Emirates commercial flight set for Monday
summary: Israel and the UAE will hold the first commercial flight between Tel Aviv and Abu Dhabi on Monday, with an Israeli-American delegation set to fly on the direct El Al flight. The flight is part of a landmark deal between the countries, aimed at boosting cooperation in areas such as aviation, tourism, trade, and security. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and US officials, including Jared Kushner and Robert O'Brien, will be on board. site_title: Jokowi's economic reboot stumbles on factories shut by outbreak
summary: Indonesia's efforts to revive its economy after the pandemic took a setback as virus outbreaks forced factories to shut in Cikarang, West Java, with over 300 workers testing positive. Indonesia's economic recovery remains at risk, with economists warning that prolonged outbreaks could keep consumers cautious, despite the government's efforts to ramp up state spending.

site_title: Spain struggles to put in place basic income scheme
summary: Spain's minimum basic income scheme, launched in May to combat poverty due to the COVID-19 pandemic, has stalled due to a high volume of applications. Despite 143,000 of 750,000 applications being analyzed, 99% of requests remain unprocessed, with many families facing lengthy waits. The scheme, expected to cost 3 billion euros annually, aims to provide 462 euros per month for an adult and up to 1,015 euros per family, but its slow rollout has left many struggling to access the aid.

site_title: Keppel Corp prepared to support KrisEnergy's final restructuring proposal
summary: Keppel Corp, which owns a 40% stake in KrisEnergy, is prepared to support the company's final restructuring proposal. Keppel Corp has evaluated the plan and believes it is a "deliverable plan," but the company requires stakeholder support for its success. The proposal involves a debt-to-equity swap, with unsecured creditors holding 46.2% and existing shareholders holding 10%. Keppel Corp does not expect the restructuring to have a material impact on its financials. The company hopes for a successful conclusion to KrisEnergy's financial restructuring in the next few months.

site_title: China reports nine new coronavirus cases, all imported
summary: China reported 9 new confirmed cases of coronavirus, all of which were imported, on Friday, marking the 13th consecutive day without local transmissions. The cases were detected in Shanghai, Fujian, Guangdong, and Sichuan. The total confirmed cases in China have reached 85,022, with 4,634 deaths.

site_title: Moderna's patents probed by US defence department: FT
summary: Moderna's patents are being investigated by the US Department of Defense's research arm, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), over alleged non-disclosure of government funding. The company received $25 million in grants from DARPA for its vaccine technology, but did not disclose this in its vaccine patents. Moderna claims it has complied with patent reporting requirements, but DARPA is researching agency awards to identify potential patents associated with the funding. The investigation may impact Moderna's patents, but the company estimates the DARPA funding was only 1% of its total private funding.

site_title: Google, Facebook dump Hong Kong cable after US security alarm
summary: Google and Facebook have withdrawn plans for an undersea cable linking the US and Hong Kong after the US security alarm raised concerns about Beijing collecting Americans' personal data. The companies have submitted a revised proposal including links to Taiwan and the Philippines, bypassing Hong Kong-based Pacific Light Data Communication, a partner of mainland China's Dr Peng Telecom & Media Group. This move comes amid escalating tensions between the US and China, with President Donald Trump taking a tougher stance on China ahead of re-election.

site_title: Boeing grounds eight 787 jets after flaws create risk of failure
summary: Boeing grounded eight 787 Dreamliner jets due to manufacturing flaws that compromise the structural integrity of the aircraft. The issues involve composite barrel sections at the rear of the plane, which can lead to a risk of in-flight failure. Despite the flaws, the rest of the global Dreamliner fleet meets Boeing's standards. The company is conducting a thorough review and is considering further action, including inspections of other Dreamliners in use.

site_title: Global virus cases cross 25m as India sets grim record
summary: Global coronavirus cases surpassed 25 million, with India setting a grim record for the highest single-day rise in cases with 78,761. Latin America continues to struggle with its first wave, with high numbers of deaths and cases in Brazil. Governments worldwide are implementing social distancing and lockdown measures to slow the spread of the virus, which has claimed nearly 843,000 lives globally.

site_title: Japan's Suga to join race to succeed PM Abe: Kyodo
summary: Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga will run for prime minister after denying interest in the role just days before his boss Shinzo Abe's resignation. Suga, a longtime Abe lieutenant, aims to lead the country through the COVID-19 pandemic and economic challenges. He joins other candidates, including former foreign minister Fumio Kishida and former defence minister Shigeru Ishiba, in the Liberal Democratic Party's leadership election. A Suga government would likely continue Abe's fiscal and monetary stimulus policies.

site_title: UK eases Covid-19 lockdown in parts of Northern England
summary: The UK has eased Covid-19 lockdown restrictions in parts of Northern England, lifting the two-household mixing ban in Greater Manchester, Lancashire, and West Yorkshire starting September 2. site_title: Canada's Reit investors get hit despite surging property market
summary: Canada's private real estate market is experiencing a surge, with home sales and prices rising sharply in major cities. site_title: Novak Djokovic, Serena Williams chase tennis history in US Open Covid bubble
summary: The US Open tennis tournament, the first Grand Slam of the Covid-19 era, begins in a spectator-free bubble at Flushing Meadows in New York. Novak Djokovic and Serena Williams headline the tournament, while Rafael Nadal and Ashleigh Barty are absent due to coronavirus concerns. site_title: Party election to pick Abe's successor around Sep 15: Kyodo News
summary: Japan's ruling party will hold an election to choose Shinzo Abe's successor around September 15, according to Kyodo News. Abe's resignation due to health reasons marks the end of his tenure, and potential candidates include former defense minister Shigeru Ishiba and former foreign minister Fumio Kishida. site_title: China's new tech export controls could give Beijing a say in TikTok sale
summary: China has revised its export controls, which may require Beijing's approval for the sale of TikTok's US operations, complicating the forced divestment ordered by President Trump. site_title: Surf Air secures US$200m funding commitment on upcoming IPO
summary: Surf Air Mobility, a membership-based private plane operator, has secured a $200 million funding commitment from Global Emerging Markets Group for its upcoming IPO. site_title: TikTok says it has not received a bid from Centricus and Triller
summary: TikTok has denied receiving a $20 billion bid from investment firm Centricus Asset Management and social media app Triller to acquire its US assets. site_title: Facebook fights UK merger regulator over Giphy acquisition
summary: Facebook has appealed to the UK's antitrust tribunal, disputing the Competition and Markets Authority's demands regarding its acquisition of Giphy. Facebook claims the demands are unreasonable and disproportionate, while the CMA maintains that Giphy's business lacks independence from Facebook due to employment contracts and restricted stock units. site_title: Japan stocks a buy for some funds betting on policy continuity
summary: Japan's stocks are seen as a buy by some funds betting on policy continuity despite Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's resignation. Market watchers expect the Bank of Japan to maintain its ultra-easy policy under Governor Haruhiko Kuroda, supporting the stock market's resilience. site_title: BlackRock gets regulators' approval to set up China mutual fund unit

site_title: Peter Thiel-backed Compass Pathways files for US IPO
summary: Compass Pathways, backed by Peter Thiel, filed for a US IPO, listing its American depositary shares on the Nasdaq under "CMPS". site_title: Oil prices dip as producers, refiners avoid worst of hurricane

site_title: Facebook CEO says 'Kenosha Guard' page was left up by mistake
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said a page titled "Kenosha Guard" was left up by mistake, violating the company's policy on militia groups, before a deadly shooting in Kenosha, Wisconsin. site_title: Food caterer Neo Group to diversify into property business
summary: Neo Group, a Catalist-listed firm, plans to diversify into the property business through a joint-venture company with construction firm Boldtek Holdings. Neo Group will leverage its existing networks and experience in the food-and-beverage industry to cater to a wider range of customers. site_title: Apple blocks Fortnite maker from game developer tools
summary: Apple has blocked Epic Games, the maker of Fortnite, from accessing developer tools needed to update games on its mobile devices, following a US court's rejection of its bid to have Fortnite reinstated on the App Store. Epic Games had released an update that dodged revenue sharing with Apple, prompting the tech giant to suspend access to tools. Players with earlier versions of Fortnite can still play, but will have to rely on Apple's payment system.

site_title: Banker Koh believes that golf is good for business
summary: Banker Koh, president of UBS Asia-Pacific, believes that golf is good for business. This sentiment is reflected in his involvement with golf-related events and his appreciation for the sport's benefits, such as networking opportunities and stress relief. As a respected figure in the finance industry, Koh's views on golf's potential for business growth are noteworthy.

site_title: What's next after Japan PM Abe quits? Potential successors?
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has resigned, triggering an election within his Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) to replace him. The party president will become the new prime minister, with a likely candidate being Shigeru Ishiba, who defeated Abe in 2012. Other contenders include Fumio Kishida, Yoshihide Suga, Taro Kono, Shinjiro Koizumi, Toshimitsu Motegi, Katsunobu Kato, Yasutoshi Nishimura, and Seiko Noda. The winner will serve until the end of Abe's LDP term in September 2021.

site_title: 'Black Panther' star Chadwick Boseman dies after battle with cancer
summary: Chadwick Boseman, star of the Marvel film "Black Panther," has died after a private four-year battle with colon cancer. The 43-year-old actor, who never publicly disclosed his condition, continued to work on major Hollywood films during his treatment. Boseman brought to life the character of King T'Challa in the record-breaking Marvel franchise, which grossed over $1 billion worldwide. His death has sent shockwaves through Hollywood and the world, with tributes pouring in from celebrities and civil rights organizations, praising his strength and legacy.

site_title: Are investment managers ready for Artificial Intelligence?
summary: Investment managers are playing catch-up on Artificial Intelligence (AI) adoption, with only 10% of fund managers or analysts using AI or Machine Learning in the past year. The first wave of AI innovation was hindered by the complexity of financial markets and the lack of applicability to investment strategies. However, a second wave of AI innovation is underway, driven by advancements in Natural Language Processing and the release of open-source models like BERT. Investment managers can catch up by leveraging AI to support fund managers with data-driven tools, such as investment dashboards, and integrating new insights into existing processes.

site_title: US consumer spending rises solidly in July
summary: US consumer spending rose 1.9% in July, exceeding expectations, and personal income rebounded after two straight monthly declines. The Federal Reserve's revised mandate puts new emphasis on the labor market. Consumer spending on goods rebounded above pre-pandemic levels, boosted by new motor vehicles and hospitality services, but services spending remains below February levels due to COVID-19 concerns. Economists expect a sharp rebound in GDP in Q3, but cut estimates for the fourth quarter.

site_title: Elon Musk's Neuralink venture unveils pig with computer chip in brain
summary: Elon Musk's Neuralink unveiled a pig with a coin-sized computer chip implanted in its brain, marking an early step toward curing human diseases. The chip has been in place for two months, demonstrating the potential of wireless brain-computer interfaces. Neuralink aims to cure conditions like Alzheimer's, dementia, and spinal cord injuries by implanting thousands of electrodes in the brain. Musk believes an implantable device can solve these problems, including memory loss, hearing loss, depression, and insomnia, and ultimately fuse humans with artificial intelligence.

site_title: HK retail property transactions rise after mortgage rules eased
summary: Hong Kong's retail property transactions rose after the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) eased mortgage rules for commercial properties, allowing lenders to offer 50% loans. This move aimed to boost liquidity in the struggling commercial property sector, which has been impacted by the coronavirus pandemic. The easing of rules gave retailers easier access to loans, increasing transaction volumes in the retail shop space market.

site_title: Pinterest nixes big San Francisco lease deal in Covid scaleback
summary: Pinterest has cancelled a large office lease deal in San Francisco, paying a $89.5 million termination fee, amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The company will keep its existing offices in the city. The move reflects a shift in how the social-sharing service thinks about its workspace in a post-Covid world. Pinterest's chief financial officer, Todd Morgenfeld, stated that the company is rethinking its future office locations. The cancellation marks one of the significant tech company scalebacks in San Francisco.

images.alt_text: Pinterest cancelled a large office lease at a building to be constructed near its San Francisco headquarters, marking one of the most significant moves yet by a big tech company to scale back real estate plans in the city amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: 2 TikTok stars who threw big parties face charges, prosecutors say
summary: TikTok stars Bryce Hall and Blake Gray are facing misdemeanor charges for hosting large parties at their Hollywood Hills mansion in defiance of Los Angeles' COVID-19 restrictions. The charges, filed by the city attorney, could result in up to a year in jail and a fine of $2,000. The hosts, known for their massive gatherings, have been criticized for their irresponsible behavior and the potential spread of COVID-19. This move is part of the city's crackdown on social gatherings during the pandemic, with Hall and Gray's parties drawing hundreds of guests and violating noise ordinances.

summary: European stocks declined 0.5% on Friday, despite a 1% gain for the week, as investors dumped technology and healthcare stocks and bid up banking shares. The US Federal Reserve unveiled a new policy framework, focusing on boosting economic growth, which analysts expect could lead to a shift in favor of value stocks over growth stocks. Banking shares rose 1.7%, with BNP Paribas, HSBC, and Banco Santander seeing significant gains. Despite optimism around Covid-19 treatment development, concerns about a potential economic rebound remain.

site_title: Gold whipsaws on US Federal Reserve's inflation shift
summary: Gold prices whipsawed within an $80 range as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's policy shift on inflation. Fed Chair Jerome Powell indicated a shift to allow a faster pace of inflation, targeting 2% average inflation over time, and hinted at acting against excessive inflation. This shift is positive for gold, but may reduce its allure as interest rates remain low. Inflation concerns, a potential Covid-19 resurgence, and an effective vaccine could still support gold as an inflation hedge.

site_title: Potential economic 'air pocket' ahead could present opportunities
summary: A potential economic "air pocket" may present opportunities for investors, despite short-term market turbulence due to waning US federal unemployment stimulus and rising US-China tensions. The US economy is expected to experience a gradual global recovery, moderately rising inflation, and a steeper US Treasury yield curve. Investors are advised to maintain core technology equity positions and rebalance portfolio weights from technology into selective cyclicals and value stocks. Additionally, gold is seen as an attractive investment opportunity due to a weaker US dollar, rising inflation, and geopolitical volatility.

site_title: Triller says it made US$20b bid with Centricus for TikTok assets
summary: Triller, a short-video app, has made a $20 billion bid with investment firm Centricus for TikTok's US assets, according to Triller's executive chairman Bobby Sarnevesht. However, ByteDance, TikTok's parent company, denies knowledge of the offer, raising questions about its validity. The bid is part of US President Donald Trump's order for ByteDance to divest TikTok in the US due to security concerns over user data. Microsoft and Oracle are also vying to acquire TikTok's assets.

images.alt_text: Triller Inc executive chairman Bobby Sarnevesht said on Friday that the short-video app had made a US$20 billion offer with investment firm Centricus Asset Management for the assets of rival TikTok that China's ByteDance is seeking to divest.

site_title: Hong Kong dividend stocks no longer in favour as payouts slashed
summary: Hong Kong's high dividend stocks, once a popular choice for retail investors, are losing favour due to companies slashing payouts amid the pandemic-driven recession. Almost one-third of Hang Seng Composite Index members are either reducing or scrapping dividends, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. This shift challenges traditional dividend investing strategies in Hong Kong's stock market.

site_title: Gold surges over 2% on waning dollar, Fed policy shift
summary: Gold prices surged over 2% on Friday, following a decline in the US dollar, as the Federal Reserve signaled a prolonged low interest rate strategy. The US dollar fell to a one-week low, making gold cheaper for holders of other currencies. The Fed's decision to adopt an average inflation target suggests rates will remain low, supporting gold prices. This shift in policy is expected to reignite the "inflation trade," historically bullish for gold, and is expected to continue the metal's 28% gain this year.

images.alt_text: Gold rebounded over 2 per cent on Friday, a day after a steep sell-off, as the US dollar weakened and the US Federal Reserve signalled a prolonged low interest rate strategy.

site_title: Hertz seeks US$54m in executive bonuses during bankruptcy
summary: Hertz Corp is seeking approval from a US Bankruptcy Judge to pay up to $5.4 million in executive bonuses, including up to $1.6 million for CEO Paul Stone, as the company navigates bankruptcy. The proposal includes incentives for top managers to meet financial targets, with lower-ranking managers eligible for up to $9.2 million. The request comes three months after Hertz agreed to pay $16.2 million in retention bonuses to 340 employees. The proposal must be approved by Judge Mary Walrath by September 17.

images.alt_text: The chief executive officer and 13 other top managers of Hertz Corp would share as much as US$5.4 million in bonuses while the company's in bankruptcy under a proposal the rental-car firm is asking a judge to approve.

site_title: Fed move boosts STI to end trading week 0.79% higher
summary: Singapore stocks ended the week higher, boosted by the Federal Reserve's decision to prioritize a strong job market over inflation, resulting in a 0.79% gain for the Straits Times Index. The benchmark index rose 19.82 points to 2,539.63, with 228 advancers outnumbering 208 decliners. Trading volume was 2.41 billion securities worth S$1.2 billion.

site_title: US: Dow erases 2020 losses as stocks charge upwards
summary: US stocks surged on Friday, erasing 2020 losses as the Dow reached a new high and the S&P and Nasdaq hit records. The Federal Reserve announced it will keep interest rates ultra-low as long as needed to support the economy, boosting stocks. Tech stocks led the gain, while European stocks closed slightly lower due to concerns over the ongoing coronavirus crisis. Despite this, investors remain optimistic, with analysts predicting a continued bull market. The Fed's policy shift is expected to provide liquidity and aid the economy's recovery, with a vaccine potentially arriving later this year.

site_title: Singapore used 20 years of previous budget surpluses to combat Covid-19: DPM
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat revealed that Singapore has drawn on 20 years of budget surpluses to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The government aims to restore its fiscal balance by strengthening revenue, with possible tax increases, while ensuring collective responsibility among generations. Heng emphasized the need for a "fair and progressive" fiscal system, where the better-off contribute more and lower- and middle-income households receive more benefits. The government plans to adjust taxes and invest reserves for long-term returns, aiming to build a stronger Singapore post-crisis.

site_title: Micro-Mechanics Q4 profit jumps 45.5% on broad-based sales growth
summary: Micro-Mechanics, a Singapore-based manufacturer of high-precision tools and parts, reported a 45.5% increase in its net profit to S$3.9 million in Q4 2020, driven by broad-based sales growth. Revenue rose 17.5% to S$16.4 million, with China being the largest market, accounting for 29% of revenue. The company's full-year net profit rose 13.1% to S$14.7 million, and a final dividend of S$0.05 per share and a special dividend of S$0.02 per share were recommended.

site_title: Malaysia extends movement control measures until Dec 31 to curb virus spread
summary: Malaysia extends movement control measures until Dec 31 to curb the spread of coronavirus infections, despite fewer than a dozen new cases per day for two weeks. The government requires face mask use in public spaces and keeps nightclubs and theme parks shut. Foreign tourists remain barred from entry. The decision comes as the virus continues to spread globally, with Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin stating it will be a long time before Malaysia is free from Covid-19 dangers.

site_title: Add volunteering to your CV
summary: Volunteering is increasingly recognized as a valuable asset for job seekers, allowing them to develop transferable soft skills, project management, and communication skills. By adding volunteer experience to one's resume, individuals can demonstrate their willingness to take on additional responsibilities, showcase their skills, and gain insight into their potential organizational culture. Research by talenTtrust shows that volunteers can develop empathy for non-profit organizations and their teams, making them more attractive to employers.

site_title: Hongkong Land converts HK$1b DBS facility to sustainability-linked loan
summary: Hongkong Land has converted a HK$1 billion revolving credit facility into a sustainability-linked loan with DBS. The loan's interest rate will be tied to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) targets, offering a tiered discount if achieved. This move aims to promote sustainable practices and reduce the company's carbon footprint. The agreement reflects the growing trend of incorporating ESG considerations into loan structures, supporting companies in meeting their sustainability goals.

site_title: Wing Tai Holdings posts S$16.8 million H2 loss
summary: Wing Tai Holdings reported a net loss of S$16.8 million for the second half of 2020, down from a net profit of S$28.4 million in the same period last year, despite a 46% increase in revenue to S$187.5 million. The company attributed the loss to the COVID-19 pandemic's disruption to the Singapore economy and subdued buying sentiment for residential property. Full-year net profit was S$16 million, down 66% from the previous year, with underlying net profit of S$70 million, up 85%.

site_title: In a world that values speed, slow down
summary: The article highlights the importance of slowing down in a world that values speed. It draws parallels between the financial services industry and the food industry, where shortcuts can lead to negative consequences. The author argues that technology has reduced the time needed to accumulate knowledge, but experience gained is often unable to keep pace. This can result in overly confident advisers lacking wisdom. The article also criticizes the mindset of tech entrepreneurs, who prioritize exit strategies over long-term sustainability and ethical considerations. Ultimately, the author advises readers to slow down and prioritize quality over speed in making financial decisions and building businesses.

site_title: Auditors give disclaimer of opinion on EHT finances
summary: Independent auditors KPMG have issued a disclaimer of opinion on the financial statements of Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT), citing insufficient audit evidence due to ongoing disagreements between EHT and its sponsor Urban Commons. The auditors noted multiple uncertainties affecting the going-concern assumption and completeness of related-party transactions, making it impossible to express an opinion on the financial statements. This comes after the auditors covered the financial positions as of Dec 31, 2019, and fund movements from April 11 to that date. The disclaimer was issued on Aug 14.

site_title: After short break, English football set to kick off again
summary: English football resumes with the Community Shield match between EPL champions Liverpool and FA Cup winners Arsenal at Wembley Stadium on Saturday. The match, played behind closed doors, marks the start of the new season, which begins two weeks later. Liverpool, fresh from their EPL title win, are favored to win, while Arsenal, who lifted the FA Cup, have a potent attacking lineup led by Mohamed Salah, Sadio Mane, and Roberto Firmino.

summary: Bulgari has denied claims that it is fitting out rooms in a Shanghai hospital built by the Loh cousins and their China partner Evangeline Shen. summary: Singapore-based online car marketplace sgCarMart expects 7% more COEs (certificates of entitlement) for the Nov-Jan 2021 quota period, with 14,801 COEs available for passenger cars. COE supply for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp is projected to drop 1%, while supply for cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp is expected to rise 17%. Despite this, unemployment remains elevated and income uncertainty could slow demand for residential real estate. The housing market's strength is attributed to people seeking more space while being stuck at home, with 25.2% gains in the Northeast and 6.8% gains in the West. The NAR revised its projection for existing home sales to 5.4 million units this year.

site_title: For the second time, Japan's Abe resigns due to health reasons
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has resigned for the second time due to poor health, citing a desire to avoid a political vacuum amid the coronavirus pandemic. The 65-year-old Abe, who battled ulcerative colitis for years, announced his decision after two recent hospital visits raised concerns about his ability to lead. His resignation will trigger a leadership race in the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, with former defence minister Shigeru Ishiba and former foreign minister Fumio Kishida among those expressing interest in the top job. Abe's tenure, which included reviving Japan's economy and bolstering its defences, will come to an end in September 2021.

site_title: Singapore seeks 'quality' labour in new foreign worker rules: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore will remain a business hub despite tightening restrictions on foreign workers, Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing said. The city-state is shifting focus to attracting higher-skilled workers and increasing minimum salaries for Employment and S Pass holders, making it tougher for firms to hire foreigners over Singaporean applicants. Officials are "quietly confident" in the city-state's economic recovery, but acknowledge that external demand will play a significant role in its progress.

site_title: New Zealand deploys spy agency against hackers who hit stock market
summary: New Zealand has deployed its spy agency to defend the stock exchange against a series of distributed-denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks that have disrupted trading for a fourth consecutive day. The attacks, which flood the website with internet traffic, have overwhelmed the NZX website and forced trading halts. The government has activated its national security plan to address the threat, but has not commented on the suspected source of the attacks, which are believed to originate from offshore. The disruptions have frustrated investors and raised concerns about the potential impact on information flows.

summary: The Volvo S60 Recharge is a plug-in hybrid electric vehicle (PHEV) that combines a conventional petrol engine with an electric motor. However, daily charging is required to fully exploit the hybrid drivetrain's efficiency, and the car's weight and fuel efficiency can be a drawback.

summary: Coca-Cola plans to offer voluntary separation to at least 4,000 employees in North America due to changes in the soft-drink business. This move comes amid growing consumer demand for low-calorie and sustainable beverages, with sugary drinks and bottled water facing increasing competition and environmental concerns.

site_title: Biodiversity loss: the next crisis
summary: Biodiversity loss is increasingly linked to the emergence of zoonotic diseases, which spread from animals to humans. The World Health Organization reports that over 60% of infectious diseases are zoonotic in nature. Climate change, deforestation, urbanization, and the wildlife trade contribute to this trend by bringing humans into close proximity with animal species. This association is evident in the COVID-19 pandemic, which is believed to have originated from an animal source. The growing connection between biodiversity loss and zoonotic diseases poses a significant threat to global health and highlights the need for conservation efforts.

site_title: Sabana-ESR merger: MAS says safeguards in place against conflicts of interest
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has clarified that safeguards are in place to prevent conflicts of interest in the proposed merger of Sabana Reit and ESR-Reit, two real estate investment trusts (Reits) managed by the same sponsor, ESR Cayman. The company advised shareholders to exercise caution when dealing in its shares due to uncertainty over the outcome of its application.

site_title: Misleading sale of critical illness plans has predatory tinge
summary: Financial advisers in Singapore are accused of making misleading sales tactics for critical illness insurance plans, claiming changes to definitions will reduce coverage. The actions of these advisers risk tarnishing the industry's reputation, particularly with the increasing use of social media for marketing.

site_title: Is time right for another young winner at US Open?
summary: US Open contender Collin Morikawa's recent PGA Championship win has sparked speculation about a new generation of golf talent. Morikawa, 25, joins a growing list of young winners, including Rory McIlroy and Justin Thomas. This shift could signal a changing of the guard in professional golf. As the US Open approaches, Morikawa and other young players are poised to make their mark, potentially altering the sport's hierarchy.

site_title: Capital One cuts card limits amid US jobless-aid impasse
summary: Capital One has cut borrowing limits on its credit cards amid the US jobless-aid impasse, affecting millions of unemployed Americans. The adjustments, made periodically, were met with swift outcry on social media, with some customers reporting limits reduced by a third to two-thirds. The move is seen as a cautious response to the industry's risk, as banks face a rising risk of borrowers maxing out credit limits and spiraling into bankruptcy. The cutbacks follow a temporary $300 weekly benefit reduction, leaving banks vulnerable to the pandemic's economic impact.

site_title: Reits (August 29-30, 2020)
summary: Reits (August 29-30, 2020) reported mixed results, with some declining and others rising. The S&P Global REIT Index fell 1.3% on August 28, while the STI REIT Index dropped 1.2%. The decline was attributed to concerns over the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on the real estate market. However, other reits like Ascendas REIT and CapitaLand Income continued to rise, driven by strong demand for logistics and industrial space.

site_title: Top Philippine diplomat recommends scrapping deals with blacklisted China firms
summary: The Philippines' foreign minister, Teodoro Locsin, recommends terminating deals with Chinese firms blacklisted by the US for their roles in constructing and militarizing artificial South China Sea islands. The US has sanctioned 24 Chinese companies and individuals, including China Communications Construction Co and China Harbour Engineering Company, which are involved in a $10 billion airport project and a $1.2 billion reclamation project in Manila Bay. The government's decision is seen as a response to the US sanctions, with President Rodrigo Duterte's administration considering the security risks posed by these deals.

site_title: Fed's Kaplan says he doesn't want to give more guidance yet
summary: US Federal Reserve President Robert Kaplan stated he doesn't want to provide more guidance on interest rates, preferring to wait for clarity on the virus path. Kaplan said the Fed has already provided enough forward guidance, including a prediction that rates will stay low for the rest of this year and next. The Fed is now aiming to keep inflation near 2% and may tolerate above-target inflation to support the economy.

site_title: Ultra-rich club stockpiles cash as US economy fears grow
summary: A group of US multimillionaire investors, known as Tiger 21, has raised their cash holdings to 19% of their total assets due to concerns over the economic consequences of the Covid-19 pandemic. This is the largest and fastest change in asset allocation for the group, with 180,000 Covid-19 deaths and a worst recession on record in the US. Despite this, they remain confident in long-term US growth and are looking for opportunities with "dramatic upside."

images.alt_text: Tiger 21, a club of more than 800 investors, said that its members have raised their cash holdings to 19 per cent of their total assets.

site_title: KS Energy says rigs in 'no jeopardy', even as OCBC seeks judicial management for firm
summary: OCBC has filed an application to place KS Energy and its subsidiary KS Drilling under judicial management, seeking to recover a US$230.7 million secured-term loan and a S$5 million unsecured bridging loan. KS Energy disputes the need for an interim management application, stating its rigs are "in no jeopardy" and its business operations will be fully monitored and supervised. The company's chairman and CEO, Richard Wiluan, has pledged to work with OCBC to resolve the bank's concerns and maximize creditor interests, citing the group's efforts to improve its financial position despite unprecedented challenges.

site_title: Oxley posts H2 S$296.3m net loss despite growth in gross profit
summary: Oxley Holdings, a Singapore-based property developer, reported a net loss of S$296.3 million for the second half of the financial year, despite a quadrupling of gross profit to S$149.3 million. The loss was mainly attributed to pandemic-related losses, including a fair-value loss of S$48.7 million and non-recurring losses of S$210.7 million.
