site_title: Mounting challenges for bike retailers amid surge in demand
summary: Bike retailers in Singapore face mounting challenges due to a surge in demand amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Sales have surged 50% between May to July compared to the same period last year, with online transactions doubling. However, global shipping and supply chain disruptions have led to shortages of bikes and cycling accessories. Manufacturers are experiencing delays of up to three months for some products, and entry-level bikes account for most of the growth. Industry players expect demand to taper off by mid-2021 as people cycle primarily for leisure rather than transportation.

site_title: Taiwan eases US beef and pork ban, eyes trade deal
summary: Taiwan has eased restrictions on US beef and pork imports, allowing American beef from cattle older than 30 months to enter the market. The move aims to pave the way for a bilateral trade pact between the two allies. Taiwan will also set a standard for ractopamine residue in pork, following a ban on US pork due to concerns over the additive. The decision is seen as a crucial step towards greater economic cooperation between the US and Taiwan, amid China's growing pressure on the island.

site_title: Libra Group applies for extension till Dec 15 to comply with resumption of trading rules
summary: Libra Group, a CATALIST-listed company, has applied for an extension of time till Dec 15, 2020, to comply with Singapore's Listing Rule 1304 on the resumption of trading. The company is undergoing a restructuring exercise and has reported progress in its debt restructuring and fund raising efforts. Trading in its shares has been suspended due to its inability to continue as a going concern, with shares last closing at 3.5 Singapore cents. The company expects to seek trading resumption if its restructuring efforts are successful.

site_title: Malaysia extends coronavirus movement curbs until end-2020
summary: Malaysia has extended its coronavirus movement curbs until December 31, 2020, amid the global spread of the virus. The country has seen a decline in virus cases, with 10 new cases reported on Friday. Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin stated that while Malaysia has the virus under control, it will take time to be free from Covid-19 dangers. The economy has shown positive signs of recovery, with restrictions including large gatherings banned and international borders closed.

site_title: Platinum assets in ETFs swell amid rush into precious metals
summary: Investors are pouring into platinum exchange-traded funds (ETFs), driving holdings to a record high, amid a surge in precious metal demand. Since mid-May, over 600,000 ounces of platinum have been added to ETFs, driven by investors seeking to catch up on the recent rally in gold and silver, as well as concerns over reduced supply from top producer South Africa. Platinum prices are seen potentially catching up with gold and silver, with some forecasts predicting a US$1,000 mark in the next 12 months.

site_title: Deutsche Bank makes bid for some Wirecard assets
summary: Deutsche Bank has submitted a non-binding bid for some Wirecard assets, including Wirecard Bank and related companies, for around 100 million euros. However, Wirecard's administrator Michael Jaffe considers the offer too low, aiming for a minimum of 100-200 million euros. This low offer could make a sale difficult, as liquidation is estimated to earn 100-200 million euros. The bid from Deutsche Bank, Germany's largest lender, is one of several non-binding offers, but it's unclear if the bank is willing to raise its offer.

site_title: Credit Suisse uncovers client fraud at wealth management
summary: Credit Suisse has uncovered client fraud at its international wealth management business, resulting in a loss of approximately 10 million francs (S$15 million) for the bank. A Zurich-based banker forged documentation for an African wealth management client, impacting additional clients and prompting a restructuring of the risk function. The bank has taken legal measures and informed affected clients and regulators, with clients being compensated. This incident follows recent scandals, including a spying scandal and involvement in deals linked to failed companies, and comes as CEO Thomas Gottstein seeks to bolster oversight.

site_title: Football: Messi to sign for Liverpool? No chance, says Klopp
summary: Liverpool manager Juergen Klopp expressed interest in signing Barcelona's Lionel Messi, but a deal is unlikely due to the high cost involved. Messi reportedly earns 8.2 million euros per month, which is out of Liverpool's budget. Klopp stated that having Messi would make it even more difficult to beat Manchester City, but he wouldn't rule out the possibility of signing him in the future.

site_title: US consumer-spending rebound cools, hinting at more risk ahead
summary: US consumer spending rebounded in July, but at a slower pace, with outlays increasing 1.9% from the prior month, below economists' estimates of a 1.6% gain. The moderation in spending, driven by a surge in virus cases, raises concerns about further softening ahead, particularly after the expiration of $600 weekly jobless benefits. Wages and salaries rose 1.4% in July, while the personal savings rate fell to a four-month low, but jobless claims remain high, and the economy has only recouped half of the jobs lost in March and April.

site_title: Government to take 'Strong Partnerships' approach to rebuilding post-crisis Singapore
summary: Singapore's government plans to take a "whole-of-government" approach, dubbed "Strong Partnerships," to rebuild the country post-crisis. This involves partnerships among various government agencies, including the Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth, Ministry of Finance, and the Prime Minister's Office. The three key thrusts of this approach are to build a resilient society, transform the public service, and speed up digitization in the government. This collaborative effort aims to address the challenges brought about by COVID-19 and create a better Singapore for its citizens.

site_title: Indian rupee posts biggest weekly gain in 20 months as RBI stands aside
summary: The Indian rupee posted its biggest weekly gain in 20 months, rising nearly 2% for the week, its highest level in nearly six months. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) refrained from intervening, allowing foreign investors to drive the currency's strength. Dollar inflows into the stock market and gains in other Asian peers fueled the rupee's rise. The rupee ended Friday at 73.3850 per US dollar, its strongest level since March 5, with traders expecting the RBI to continue intervening intermittently to build forex reserves.

site_title: Shopee Singapore web visits jump 82% in Q2
summary: Shopee Singapore saw a 82% surge in web visits from Q1 to Q2, reaching an average of 10.9 million monthly visits on desktop and mobile. It surpassed its closest competitor Lazada, which recorded a 10% increase to 8.6 million monthly visits. E-commerce platforms in Singapore experienced a 23% growth in total web visits, with an average basket size expanding by 51% year-over-year, and users spending an average of SGD 113 during the period.

site_title: US real estate pain leaves foreign investors holding the bag
summary: Foreign investors who backed US real estate projects through the EB-5 visa program are losing money due to the pandemic-driven commercial property crisis. EB-5 investors, who prioritized obtaining US visas over financial returns, have limited leverage against developers. In Manhattan, Chinese investors are seeking arbitration to recover their $1 billion investment in Related Cos' Hudson Yards. Similar cases are emerging on Long Island, where a group assumed the lease to the Nassau Coliseum after Onexim Sports and Entertainment walked away. Experts predict more defaults in the months to come due to the program's "risky capital" nature.

site_title: Independent audit of Top Glove's labour practices completed
summary: Top Glove Corporation has completed an independent audit of its labor practices, which was initiated by the US Customs and Border Protection following allegations of forced labor. The audit involved virtual interviews with 1,100 migrant workers and is expected to be completed within 10 days. The company has already begun part remediation for recruitment fees totaling RM4.4 million, with a total estimated cost of RM53 million. Top Glove remains committed to enhancing its migrant workers' environment and facilities. The audit's report will be submitted to the US authorities.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore clarified its regulatory framework, allowing a shareholder group to own substantial stakes in two Reit managers managing Reits in the same property class. The government also tightened restrictions on foreign workers to protect local jobs. OCBC filed applications to place KS Energy and its subsidiary under judicial management. CARESHIELD Life, a lifetime care insurance scheme, will start on Oct 1 for Singapore residents born in 1980 or later. The STI ended the week up 0.79%, lifted by the Federal Reserve's new approach to monetary policy.

images.alt_text: On Friday, MAS pointed out that there are regulatory safeguards under the Securities and Futures Act to mitigate potential conflicts of interest.

site_title: Yorkshine Holdings to delist from Sept 28, unable to give reasonable exit offer
summary: Yorkshine Holdings will delist from the Singapore Exchange's Mainboard on September 28 due to its inability to provide a reasonable exit offer to shareholders. Trading in its shares has been suspended since August 3, 2017. The company cited a depressed economic climate and decreased asset valuations, including a net liability of 47.5 million yuan (S$9.4 million) in its only operating subsidiary. Yorkshine will continue to exist as an unlisted public limited company with its existing shareholders after the delisting.

site_title: Wing Tai Holdings posts H2 net loss of S$16.8m, for full-year profit of S$16m
summary: Wing Tai Holdings reported a net loss of S$16.8 million for the second half, despite a 46% increase in revenue to S$187.5 million. The company's full-year net profit fell 66% to S$16 million, but underlying net profit rose 85% to S$70 million. The group attributed the loss to the impact of Covid-19 on the Singapore economy, recommending a 3-cent dividend per share.

site_title: Japan Prime Minister Abe resigns over worsening health
summary: Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has resigned due to worsening health, ending his eight-year tenure as the country's longest-serving premier. Abe, 65, cited poor health as the reason for his resignation, which will trigger a leadership race within the ruling Liberal Democratic Party. His resignation comes amid an uncertain geopolitical environment and Japan's ongoing novel coronavirus outbreak. Abe's policies, including "Abenomics," are likely to continue under the new leader, but his legacy of longevity as a politician may be a challenge to replicate.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer has been oversubscribed 9.8 times. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue below target and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are expanding green and transition finance cooperation.

site_title: STI ends trading week up 0.79%; investors seek comfort in Fed's latest policy move
summary: Singapore stocks ended the week higher, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.79% to 2,539.63, driven by the Federal Reserve's decision to prioritize a strong job market over inflation. Investors sought comfort in the news of low interest rates for the foreseeable future, with banks, real estate investment trusts, and aviation counters among the top gainers. However, analysts warned that low interest rates may not last, citing the need for the US government to cover its fiscal deficits.

site_title: Thailand to offer 24b baht in loans to pandemic-hit airlines
summary: Thailand's government plans to offer 24 billion baht (S$1.05 billion) in loans to seven local airlines to help them survive the pandemic and avoid layoffs. The loans, from state banks, will be offered for a five-year period. The move aims to revive the tourism and trade-reliant economy, which is expected to face its worst crisis ever. The government is also easing flight restrictions and allowing tourism, urging airlines to cooperate and stop competing with prices. Foreign tourist arrivals are forecast to plummet to eight million this year.

site_title: Wing Tai Properties posts HK$485.7m H1 net loss
summary: Wing Tai Properties, a Hong Kong-based associate of Singapore-listed Wing Tai Holdings, reported a net loss of HK$485.7 million for the six months ended June 30, despite revenue more than quadrupling to HK$1.96 billion. The company attributed the loss to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the Hong Kong residential property market. However, launches have been well-received, with 93% of one project sold and 83% of another pre-sold. The company expects steady recurring income from commercial properties, but lease renewal and occupancy may be under pressure.

site_title: Goldman pays Malaysia US$2.5b 1MDB payment
summary: Goldman Sachs has made a $2.5 billion payment to the Malaysian government to settle allegations of misconduct related to 1MDB. The funds will be used to repay 1MDB's outstanding debt, including $3.5 billion in bonds. In return, Malaysia will drop criminal charges against Goldman Sachs, allowing it to move forward from the scandal. This payment comes at a crucial time for Malaysia, which is seeking funding to boost its economy after the pandemic. Goldman Sachs will face a case management hearing on September 4.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group has made the US$2.5 billion payment it pledged to the Malaysian government to settle allegations of misconduct related to 1MDB, and the funds will be used to repay outstanding debt of the disgraced state fund, according to a person familiar with the matter.

site_title: 94 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 4 in the community
summary: Singapore reported 94 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 56,666. The cases include 4 community cases, 10 imported cases, and 80 cases residing in dormitories. The Ministry of Health will provide more details on Friday night. The number of new daily cases in the community has increased to two, with an average of one unlinked case per day. Globally, the virus has infected over 24.6 million people and killed over 834,700.

site_title: Changi Airport unveils food-delivery service Changi Eats
summary: Changi Airport Group (CAG) has launched a food-delivery service called Changi Eats, allowing customers to order from up to five F&B outlets in the airport and Jewel Changi Airport. The service offers no markup on prices and a minimum order of S$50. Orders can be made up to two hours before scheduled delivery slots, available daily from 12:30pm to 8pm. Nearly 30 F&B establishments are currently participating in the platform.

site_title: Independent auditors issue disclaimer of opinion on Eagle Hospitality Trust finances
summary: Independent auditors KPMG have issued a disclaimer of opinion on Eagle Hospitality Trust's finances, citing "multiple uncertainties" due to ongoing disagreements between EHT and its sponsor Urban Commons. The auditors were unable to obtain sufficient evidence to form an opinion on the financial statements, citing concerns over the completeness of related-party transactions and liabilities. This disclaimer affects the financial statements of EH-BT, EH-Reit Group, and EHT. The report was released on August 14, 2020, and the auditors' findings have significant implications for the trust's financial health and future prospects.

site_title: Oxley Holdings posts S$296.3m net loss for H2 despite gross profit quadrupling
summary: Oxley Holdings posted a net loss of S$296.3 million for the second half of 2020, despite revenue quadrupling to S$638.9 million. The loss was mainly due to other losses incurred due to the Covid-19 pandemic, including a fair-value loss of S$48.7 million. The company's full-year net loss was S$280.6 million, with a recommended final dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents per share. Construction projects were delayed by four to six months due to lockdowns, but the company expects to return to full operation and higher revenue in the new financial year.

site_title: Alibaba logistics arm launches Singapore-China air freight route
summary: ALIBABA Group's logistics arm, Cainiao Smart Logistics Network, launched its first Singapore-China air freight route, operating four weekly chartered flights between the two cities. The new route aims to support 72-hour global deliveries and anticipate shipment surges from upcoming shopping festivals. The service will enable e-commerce merchants in South-east Asia to expand their reach to Chinese consumers, offering value-added services such as delivery time slot options and goods assembly. The move is in line with the predicted growth of South-east Asia's e-commerce sector, set to reach $150 billion by 2025.

site_title: Japan to lift foreigner re-entry ban from Sept 1
summary: Japan will lift its foreigner re-entry ban starting September 1, allowing those with proper visas to return after leaving the country, while taking measures to prevent COVID-19 infection. This decision comes amid criticism of the country's strict border policy, which has kept out most non-citizens, including those with long-term residency. The move aims to rebuild Japan's economy hit by the pandemic, which has seen fewer than 1,200 cases and 65,000 total cases.

site_title: Men accused of helping ex-Nissan boss Carlos Ghosn escape face US extradition hearing
summary: A US judge will hear arguments on whether two Massachusetts men, Michael Taylor and his son Peter, can be extradited to Japan to face charges of helping former Nissan chairman Carlos Ghosn escape in 2019. The Taylors, who were arrested in May, are accused of smuggling Ghosn out of Japan on a private jet. Prosecutors say the escape was "one of the most brazen and well-orchestrated" in recent history, allowing Ghosn to flee to Lebanon. The US government will decide whether to extradite the Taylors, with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo holding the final say.

site_title: Singapore seeks 'quality' labour in new foreign worker rules: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore is introducing new rules to limit foreign worker visas, focusing on attracting higher-skilled workers and protecting local jobs. The city-state aims to create more space for top talent while discouraging low-skilled foreign workers. The new rules increase the minimum salary for employment pass holders to S$4,500 and S-pass holders to S$2,500, making it tougher for firms to hire foreigners over Singaporean applicants. Despite tightening restrictions, Singapore remains open to foreign talent and will continue to be a business hub, with officials expressing confidence in the city-state's economic recovery.

site_title: SoftBank Group to sell 1.33t yen of wireless unit stock
summary: SoftBank Group announced plans to sell approximately 1.33 trillion yen (S$17.07 billion) of its stock in its Japanese wireless operation, SoftBank Corp. This sale, part of a broader asset sale program, aims to help the conglomerate recover from past missteps in startup investments. The company will sell 927 million shares, roughly a third of its stake, and also plans to buy back up to 1.68% of its shares for around 100 billion yen.

site_title: SIA plane among eight Boeing Dreamliners found with defect
summary: Boeing has identified two manufacturing issues in the fuselage of its 787 Dreamliner jets, prompting the removal of eight affected planes from service. The issues, found in the join of fuselage sections, do not meet Boeing's design standards. The company has notified the Federal Aviation Administration and is conducting a review. Affected airlines, including Singapore Airlines, United Airlines, and Air Canada, will work with Boeing to repair the jets before resuming service. The issues are a significant setback for Boeing, which has faced several teething problems with the Dreamliner since its 2011 debut.

site_title: Amazon buys 1,800 electric Mercedes vans in latest green effort
summary: Amazon has agreed to purchase 1,800 electric Mercedes-Benz vans, the largest commitment to date by the retailer to reduce its carbon footprint in Europe. The deal, worth an undisclosed amount, will be completed by the end of the year and marks Amazon's continued effort to become a net zero emitter of carbon by 2040. This move follows Amazon's previous deals to buy electric vans from Rivian Automotive and comes after the company's CEO, Jeff Bezos, announced the Climate Pledge, an open invitation for companies to match Amazon's carbon reduction goals.

site_title: Food caterer Neo Group to diversify into property business with Boldtek JV
summary: Neo Group, a Catalist-listed food caterer, plans to diversify into the property business through a joint-venture (JV) with construction firm Boldtek Holdings. The JV aims to expand into property development, investment, and management, providing diversified revenue streams and enhancing shareholder value. The new business will leverage Neo Group's existing networks and resources, and Boldtek's property development expertise. The proposal is expected to change the company's risk profile and is subject to shareholder approval.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down more than 1.4% after reports Japan PM to resign
summary: Japan's benchmark Nikkei index closed down 1.41% or 326.21 points to 22,882.65, after reports that Prime Minister Shizo Abe was set to resign due to health reasons, contrary to earlier gains. The Topix index also fell 0.68%. Abe was due to speak at a news conference before the reports surfaced, hours before his expected resignation announcement.

site_title: OCBC seeks to put KS Energy under judicial management
summary: OCBC has filed applications with the High Court of Singapore to place KS Energy and its principal subsidiary KS Drilling under judicial management due to a US$230.7 million secured term loan and a S$5 million unsecured bridging loan owed by KS Drilling. KS Energy proposes alternative measures for OCBC to monitor and supervise its business operations, but the bank is seeking interim judicial managers. The court hearing for the interim JM application is set for August 31, and the pre-trial conference is on September 10.

site_title: UK business confidence rises from lows, job cuts on the way: Lloyds
summary: UK business confidence has risen 8 points to -14, the largest monthly increase in three years, as the economy struggles with social distancing and job cuts. Despite optimism about trading prospects and economic recovery, economists warn that the bounce-back could be short-lived due to rising unemployment as the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme is wound down. Only 18% of businesses expect to retain all staff on furlough, and Finance Minister Rishi Sunak has ruled out extending the scheme.

site_title: Hong Kong's battered dividend investors go for growth stocks
summary: Hong Kong's high-dividend stocks are losing favor among investors, who are shifting to growth stocks in technology and healthcare due to companies' pandemic-driven payout cuts. Almost one-third of Hang Seng Composite Index members are reducing or scrapping dividends, the most since 2009. Global payouts are expected to shrink 23% this year, making 2020 the worst year for dividends since the financial crisis. Investors are focusing on "dividend growers" in industries like tech and healthcare, which may increase payouts, as they reassess their strategies in response to the economic uncertainty.

site_title: TikTok wrestling with two competing offers: sources
summary: TikTok is in the final stages of negotiations with two competing groups to buy its US operations: Microsoft and Walmart, and Oracle. The deals, valued between $20 billion and $50 billion, would likely take TikTok down different paths, with a Microsoft and Walmart deal potentially integrating e-commerce into the app and a deal with Oracle focusing on data. The US government's pressure on ByteDance, TikTok's owner, to sell its US operations has driven the negotiations, with a decision expected in the coming days.

site_title: Hongkong Land obtains HK$1b sustainability-linked loan from DBS
summary: Hongkong Land has secured a HK$1 billion sustainability-linked loan from DBS, with the interest rate tied to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) targets. The targets include reducing greenhouse gas emissions and increasing solar energy generation. If met, Hongkong Land will receive a tiered discount on the interest rate. The loan proceeds will be used for working capital and funding green building initiatives. This is DBS's 9th sustainability-linked loan, totaling around S$13 billion since 2018.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain as country stops short of toughest virus rules
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.40% on Friday, driven by gains in Wall Street and eased concerns over economic fallout from the coronavirus. The country extended its current social distancing measures instead of tougher rules, despite a triple-digit increase in daily new cases. The benchmark Kospi index rose 2.14% for the week, snapping a 4.27% fall in the previous week. Foreigners were net sellers of 229.4 billion won worth of shares, while the won rose 0.06% against the US dollar.

site_title: Axington EGM postponed; company confirms resignation of director Kirk Wagar
summary: Axington's EGM has been postponed due to recent developments in the media. The company's board cited a need for more time to conduct an internal assessment after Cousins Nelson Loh and Terence Loh acquired a 92.5% stake in Axington. The Lohs have faced controversy after doctored images of them with former US President Barack Obama surfaced online. Additionally, independent director Kirk Wagar has resigned, urging more transparency in light of the recent revelations and developments.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 29.57 points to 1,525.21. The index saw a significant decline in volume, with 11.146 billion lots traded worth RM8.256 billion. The market had a net loss of 36 shares, with 588 losers outnumbering 552 gainers.

site_title: Europe: Equities open higher on Fed news
summary: European stock markets opened higher on Friday after US Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell indicated that US interest rates will remain ultra low to recover from the coronavirus pandemic. Powell said the Fed would stick to a new framework allowing for low interest rates for a "some time" to focus on a healthier jobs market. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.2%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index added 0.4%, and Paris's CAC 40 rose 0.3%.

site_title: Gold advances as investors weigh Fed's new approach on inflation
summary: Gold prices rose 0.6% to $1,941 an ounce after the Federal Reserve announced a more relaxed stance on inflation, allowing for price gains to overshoot its 2% target. The Fed's new approach suggests lower interest rates and higher inflation tolerance, supporting gold prices. However, doubts remain about the extent of US inflation expectations, which could impact gold's path to record highs.

site_title: Thousands arrested for 'virus-related crimes' in China
summary: Nearly 5,800 people suspected of committing epidemic-related crimes, including killing health workers, selling defective medical equipment, and lying about their travel history, have been arrested in China since January. The cases include violent acts such as beating someone to death for not wearing a mask and stabbing a health inspector. The country has largely controlled the spread of the novel coronavirus with strict lockdowns and contact tracing. China has reported no locally transmitted infections in recent days, with strict mask mandates in public places and widespread use of smartphone apps to track people.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend rally; STI resumes afternoon up 1.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.7% to 2,563.50 points, extending its morning rally. The benchmark index was boosted by a stronger US yield curve, which lifted banking and property shares. Local lenders DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank also saw significant gains. The rally comes after the Federal Reserve announced a policy shift prioritizing a strong job market over inflation fears, leading to expectations of lower interest rates for longer.

site_title: Feel-good hit 'Fall Guys' knocks out the competition on PlayStation, PC
summary: Independent British firm Tonic Games' "Fall Guys: Ultimate Knockout" has become a hit on PlayStation and PC, outperforming the competition in the battle royale genre. The game's popularity stems from its fresh spin, inspired by classic TV shows, and its emphasis on fun and humor. With over 45 million PlayStation Plus subscribers accessing the game, it has become the service's most downloaded title. The game has also been purchased over seven million times on Steam, driven by its engaging gameplay and social media presence, with revenue streams including costume sales and charity auctions.

site_title: CareShield Life starts Oct 1 for Singapore residents born in 1980 or later
summary: Singapore's CareShield Life, a lifetime payout scheme for severe disabilities requiring long-term care, will start on Oct 1 for residents born in 1980 or later. Those 30-40 years old will pay annual premiums using their Medisave accounts, stopping at age 67. The scheme provides up to S$600/month payouts, with subsidies for lower-income residents and government support for those who cannot afford premiums. The amount of payouts will increase over time, and once a person starts collecting a payout, it will remain fixed.

site_title: Malaysia's July exports unexpectedly rise 3.1% y-o-y, beats forecast
summary: Malaysia's exports unexpectedly rose 3.1% in July from a year earlier, beating a forecasted 1.2% drop, driven by higher shipments of manufactured goods and agricultural commodities. The country's trade surplus widened to a historical high of RM25.15 billion, exceeding the previous record of RM20.9 billion in June. Meanwhile, imports shrank 8.7% from a year earlier, faster than the 5.6% decline in the prior month.

site_title: Chinese consumers could boycott Apple if US bans WeChat: ministry
summary: China's foreign ministry warned that Chinese consumers could boycott Apple if the US bans WeChat, citing the "no reason why Chinese shall keep iPhone and apple products" if WeChat is banned. US President Donald Trump's order to block WeChat and TikTok, accusing them of threatening national security, has stoked tensions between Beijing and Washington. The ban is set to take effect in mid-September.

site_title: Genting empire keeps dividends even as casino, resorts sting
summary: Genting Group, a conglomerate with casinos, cruises, and resorts, is maintaining dividend payments despite facing its worst financial challenge due to the pandemic. Genting Bhd and Genting Malaysia Bhd reported record-low quarterly results, with Genting Bhd's worst quarter since 1999 and Genting Malaysia's largest net loss since 2000. The group remains pessimistic about its financial performance due to global travel restrictions. Genting has taken drastic measures, including pay cuts and workforce reductions, and may attempt to restructure debt with creditors.

site_title: Trump promises tariffs on companies that leave US to create jobs overseas
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to impose tariffs on companies that leave the US to create jobs overseas if he is re-elected. In his acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention, Trump stated that his administration would target companies that "leave America to produce jobs overseas." This move is seen as a challenge to China's influence on global trade, with Trump claiming his agenda is "Made in the USA." The announcement has surprised Vietnam, which has called for a lower tariff rate.

site_title: Japan PM Shinzo Abe plans to resign due to health reasons: report
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe plans to resign due to health reasons, according to local media reports. He is expected to hold a news conference to discuss his health, which has led to a drop in Japan's Topix index and a rebound of the yen. No specific details about his health are provided, but his resignation is expected to have significant economic implications.

site_title: Xiaomi's stock surge is a big turnaround after post-IPO struggles
summary: Xiaomi's stock has surged a record 59% this month, reaching all-time highs, as the company benefits from Huawei's struggles with US restrictions on its 5G technology. Xiaomi's second-quarter report showed its phones are gaining traction in China, leading to a more than double profit increase. Additionally, an electric vehicle company Xiaomi invested in saw a 41% gain in its US debut.

site_title: Asia: Most markets up with Federal Reserve rates seen low for longer
summary: The Federal Reserve's Jerome Powell announced that interest rates will stay ultra-low for a longer period to support the US economy, helping lift Asian equities. Powell stated the Fed would focus on achieving "maximum employment" and not rush to control inflation, even if it overshoots the 2% target. This news boosted markets, with Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Singapore rising, while Sydney slipped. Investors remain cautious due to fresh virus spikes in Europe and ongoing pandemic fallout.

site_title: Micro-Mechanics Q4 profit jumps 45.5% on broad-based sales growth
summary: Micro-Mechanics reported a 45.5% increase in its net profit to S$3.9 million for its fourth fiscal quarter, driven by strong revenue growth of 17.5% year-over-year. Revenue rose to S$16.4 million, with China being the largest market, accounting for 29% of group revenue. The company's full-year net profit rose 13.1% to S$14.7 million, while earnings per share increased to 10.54 Singapore cents. A final dividend of S$0.05 per share and a special dividend of S$0.02 per share are recommended, raising the total dividend payout by 20%.

site_title: Vast home market boosts China's air travel recovery
summary: China's largest airlines, Air China, China Eastern, and China Southern, are expected to report earnings showing a nascent recovery in air travel due to a booming domestic market. July traffic figures rose 25% from June, with passenger numbers exceeding 22 million domestically, as travel within China picks up. Revenue passenger kilometres also jumped, but remain below pre-pandemic levels. The recovery is driven by the easing of government restrictions, leading to a 50% increase in the FTSE China A 600 Travel & Leisure Index in three months.

site_title: US surpasses 180,000 virus deaths: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US surpassed 180,000 coronavirus deaths, with 931 new deaths reported in 24 hours, according to Johns Hopkins University's tracker. The total death toll stands at 180,527, with 5,860,397 cases and 2,101,326 recoveries. The country is still far from out of the woods, with varying case numbers by region.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on cheap yen, US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by a cheaper yen and US rallies. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.24% to 23,265.28, while the Topix index gained 0.48%. The US market also saw a rally after Federal Reserve chief comments on allowing inflation to rise above 2%.

site_title: Singapore stocks advance after US inflation policy shift; STI up 1% at open
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1% to 2,545.65 at open, following a Wall Street rally after Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell announced changes to US monetary policy. Banking stocks led the gain, with DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank rising 1-1.5%. US indices also advanced, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 posting record gains, while the Nasdaq retreated 0.4%.

site_title: Japan, eyeing Olympics, lines up half-billion doses of Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Japan plans to secure 521 million doses of Covid-19 vaccines by 2021, aiming to inoculate its population four times over, in a bid to host the delayed 2021 Summer Olympics. The country has signed multiple deals with global vaccine makers, including Pfizer and AstraZeneca, and local companies like Shionogi. Critics argue that Japan's rush to secure vaccines is driven by a desire to host the Olympics, with some experts questioning the feasibility of staging the Games during a pandemic.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Suntec Reit, IHH Healthcare, SIA Engg, Thomson Medical, Creative
summary: Suntec Reit cut 85 jobs at its Singapore Convention and Exhibition Centre amid the Covid-19 pandemic. IHH Healthcare posted a net loss of RM120.6 million for its second quarter, reversing from a profit a year ago. SIA Engineering Company acquired the remaining 35% stake in Heavy Maintenance Singapore Services. Thomson Medical Group posted a net loss of S$97.5 million for the second half of its fiscal year. Creative Technology sank into the red with a net loss of US$9.1 million for its second half.

site_title: South Korea to consider 4th extra budget if coronavirus situation worsens
summary: South Korea's finance minister plans to consider a fourth extra budget if the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic worsens. The government has already pledged 277 trillion won (S$319.1 billion) in fiscal stimulus this year. With 371 new coronavirus cases reported, the minister said the impact of tougher social distancing rules would be more serious, affecting the economy. A fourth extra budget would bolster the existing stimulus and bolster the country's fight against the pandemic.

site_title: E-commerce startup Intrepid Group bags pre-Series B funding co-led by Thakral, Sun SEA Capital
summary: Intrepid Group, a Singapore-headquartered e-commerce startup, has secured pre-Series B funding co-led by Thakral Corp and Sun SEA Capital. The undisclosed funding will help brands and SMEs accelerate growth on e-commerce platforms in South-east Asia. The region's e-commerce volumes have multiplied by 10 between 2015 and 2020, with expectations of tripling by 2025. Intrepid will use the funding to boost brands' e-commerce presence, following a growing trend in the industry driven by the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Further policy levers to support Asean SMEs available: HSBC
summary: HSBC has released policy recommendations to support Asean SMEs amid the impact of Covid-19 on supply chains. The recommendations include improving SME access to trade finance, facilitating reforms to attract foreign investment, fast-tracking policies to support the digitisation of trade, driving critical mass in sustainability adoption, and ratifying multi-lateral trade agreements. These measures aim to help companies strengthen their resilience post-Covid-19 and create more sustainable long-term operations, particularly given the trade-dependent nature of businesses in the region.

site_title: Spies called in as cyberattacks again halt New Zealand stock exchange
summary: New Zealand's stock exchange was forced to halt trading for a fourth consecutive day due to ongoing cyberattacks. The NZX cited connectivity issues similar to those caused by Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks. The country's spy agency, GCSB, was called in to help combat the security breaches. The disruption occurred during earnings season, affecting companies like Air New Zealand and Spark. Experts speculate that the attacks may be state-sponsored or the work of online activists, with no internal systems compromised and trading information not breached.

site_title: Musk confirms Tesla Nevada factory was target of 'serious' cyberattack
summary: Elon Musk confirmed that Tesla's Nevada factory was targeted in a "serious" cyberattack, following a media report that an employee helped the FBI thwart the attack. A Russian national, Egor Igorevich Kriuchkov, was arrested and charged with conspiracy to intentionally cause damage to a protected computer. Kriuchkov had promised an employee $1 million to introduce malware into Tesla's system, but the employee alerted the FBI, preventing the attack. Musk's confirmation comes after a statement by the US Department of Justice about a Russian national's arrest in connection with the planned attack.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.26 points, or 0.08%, to 1,556.04. The market saw 268.01 million lots traded, worth RM69.13 million, with gainers beating losers 229 to 132.

site_title: Pentagon slams Chinese missile launches in South China Sea
summary: The US Defense Department condemned China's recent ballistic missile launches in the South China Sea, calling them "threatening peace and security" in the region. China's military exercises near the Paracel islands, where up to four missiles were fired, violate its 2002 commitment to avoiding provocative activities. The Pentagon urged China to reduce its "militarisation and coercion" in the region, but China responded by saying the US was interfering in its internal affairs.

site_title: US seeks to seize 280 cryptocurrency accounts tied to North Korean hacks
summary: The US Department of Justice has sought to seize 280 cryptocurrency accounts linked to North Korean hackers who stole millions of dollars in cryptocurrency from two virtual exchanges. The hackers allegedly used Chinese traders to launder their funds, with US authorities accusing Pyongyang of using hackers to circumvent sanctions. This move comes after two Chinese nationals were charged in March with laundering over $100 million in cryptocurrency on behalf of North Korea. The US government is seeking to freeze the assets and disrupt North Korea's alleged cryptocurrency laundering operations.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Friday, with the Hang Sang Index increasing 0.20% to 25,330.77, following a statement from the Federal Reserve's head that the US central bank will maintain low interest rates to boost the economy. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, despite easing slightly.

site_title: Australia: Shares retreat on rising cases, stimulus worries
summary: Australian shares declined 1.1% to 6,056.3, weighed down by rising Covid-19 cases in Victoria and concerns over the US stimulus bill. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell for its second consecutive week, with gold miners and tech stocks taking a hit. Heavyweight mining stocks dropped 2% and tech stocks fell 3.1%, while financials added 0.3%.

site_title: Criminal recycling scams 'profit from plastic waste surge'
summary: Criminal networks are profiting from the surge in plastic waste being shipped from rich countries to Asia, where it is often burned and dumped, stoking pollution and environmental destruction. The report, written with input from 40 countries, found that many recycling targets are impossible to verify due to poor visibility into waste treatment, and that exporting nations may report artificially high recycling rates. The illicit waste trade has surged towards South and Southeast Asian nations, with quantities overwhelming some countries, and Interpol warns of an urgent need to identify how criminals are exploiting loopholes in regulation.

site_title: Japan Display to sell screen plant to Sharp for US$390m, repay debt to Apple
summary: Japan Display has agreed to sell a smartphone screen plant to Sharp Corp for US$390 million, raising funds to repay Apple Inc for construction costs. The company will also sell equipment for US$285 million, with sources indicating Apple is the buyer. Japan Display owes Apple over US$702.5 million for the US$1.5 billion plant construction. The funds raised will be used to repay Apple.

site_title: Sabana-ESR merger: MAS says safeguards in place, manager notes 'fair' scheme
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has clarified that safeguards are in place to mitigate potential conflicts of interest in the proposed merger of Sabana Reit and ESR-Reit, two real estate investment trusts (Reits) managed by the same sponsor, ESR Cayman. Independent directors make up at least half of the boards, and there is no overlap of management teams. The merger will be conducted through a trust scheme of arrangement, providing a binary outcome for unitholders. Only independent unitholders have a say in approving or rejecting the proposal, with a majority vote required for approval.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end lower as Federal Reserve boost offset by resource losses
summary: European stocks ended lower, down 0.6%, as resource stocks declined, despite the US Federal Reserve's aggressive growth strategy. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index lagged US peers, with mining stocks among the biggest percentage losers. European shares are yet to recover from pandemic lows, unlike Wall Street, which touched new highs after the Fed announcement.

site_title: Walmart says teaming with Microsoft in bid for TikTok
summary: US retail giant Walmart has teamed up with Microsoft in a bid to buy Chinese-owned short-form video app TikTok, following President Donald Trump's executive order giving Americans 45 days to stop doing business with its Chinese parent company ByteDance. The move aims to meet US government regulators' concerns while satisfying TikTok's US user base. Analysts believe Walmart's partnership with Microsoft would give the retailer access to TikTok's younger audience, valuable for marketing and product development. The deal is likely to be worth $35 billion to $40 billion.

site_title: US: Major indices rise, tech retreats after Federal Reserve policy shift
summary: US stocks ended in a mixed fashion on Thursday, with the Dow Jones rising 0.6% to a record high of 28,492.27, while the S&P 500 rose 0.2% to a record high of 3,484.55. However, the Nasdaq retreated 0.4% to 11,926.16. The Federal Reserve announced a policy shift to prioritize maximizing employment for low-income families, indicating it will keep interest rates low for longer. This move was welcomed by Wall Street, which saw the decision as a sign of support for the economy.

site_title: Trump to announce deal to buy 150 million rapid Covid-19 tests
summary: US President Donald Trump will announce a deal to purchase 150 million rapid Covid-19 tests from Abbott Laboratories for $750 million, aiming to control the spread of the virus ahead of the November elections. The tests, which cost $5 and provide results in 15 minutes, were granted emergency approval by the FDA earlier this week. The deal is part of a broader effort to expand testing and help the US return to normal life, with White House officials citing the need to get Americans back to work and kids back to school.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump will announce on Thursday a deal for 150 million rapid Covid-19 tests as he eyes a return to normal life ahead of November's elections, White House officials told AFP.

site_title: Employment Pass minimum pay rises to enable business growth and openings for locals
summary: Singapore's government has announced a second increase in the minimum qualifying salary for Employment Pass (EP) and S Pass holders, with EP minimum qualifying salary rising to S$4,500 and S Pass minimum qualifying salary to S$2,500, starting September 1 and October 1, respectively. The move aims to support local employment opportunities and business growth amid a weakened job market outlook. The government also plans to tighten its foreign workforce policies and introduce measures to encourage local talent in the financial services sector.

site_title: Evolution or extinction? Leadership through innovation in a time of crisis
summary: The COVID-19 crisis has accelerated the shift to remote work, forcing leaders to adapt quickly to changing work dynamics. Organizations that invested in digital business and infrastructure have navigated the transition with minimal disruption, while those that clung to traditional structures struggled with communication and governance. This crisis has highlighted the importance of long-term resilience and digital transformation, as stated by Gartner's senior research director Sandy Shen. Companies must prioritize innovation and adaptability to thrive in uncertain times, and leaders who can effectively manage complexity and uncertainty will be better equipped to navigate the future of work.

images.alt_text: When the work-from-home mandates hit, those with the right policies and infrastructure in place endured the massive shift to remote work with minimal disruption.

site_title: WHO opens door to change for global public health alerts
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is setting up a committee to consider changing its rules on declaring international health emergencies, following criticism of its response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The current International Health Regulations (IHR) do not allow for intermediate levels of alert, which has been criticized for being too slow to sound the alarm. The WHO director-general, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, hopes the committee will present a progress report in November and a full report in May, with the goal of building a "healthier, safer, fairer world."

site_title: Federal Reserve unveils major policy shift to maximise job growth
summary: The US Federal Reserve has unveiled a major policy shift to prioritize job growth, particularly for lower-income families, by allowing inflation to stay above its 2.0% target for some time before raising interest rates. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that the change reflects the Fed's appreciation for a strong labor market, which can be sustained without causing inflation. This shift marks a significant departure from the Fed's historical focus on fighting inflation, and its impact will keep borrowing rates low for a longer period.

site_title: Trump assails rival Biden, accepting Republican nomination for second White House term
summary: US President Donald Trump accepted the Republican nomination for a second term, assailing his Democratic rival Joe Biden as a threat to the country's values and stability. Trump claimed a Biden victory would lead to a "socialist agenda" and worsen the nation's crises, including the coronavirus pandemic. Despite the pandemic, Trump delivered his remarks in front of a large crowd, with chants of "Four more years!" and "USA!" The convention aimed to counterbalance defections from Republicans who have endorsed Biden, featuring emotional appeals and messages from former Democratic voters who now support Trump.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump, accepting the Republican nomination for a second term, said on Thursday that he alone stands as a bulwark against the forces of socialism, anarchy and extremism that his Democratic rival Joe Biden would champion if elected in November.

site_title: Creative sinks into the red with US$9.1m H2 loss
summary: Creative Technology reported a net loss of US$9.1 million for its second half of 2020, compared to a net profit of US$7.2 million in the same period last year. The main cause of the loss was a fair value loss on financial assets, while revenue rose 17% to US$29.9 million. The company also warned that its H2 revenue may be below target, with an operating loss similar to the first half of the year.

site_title: CECA 'does not give special treatment to Indian nationals'
summary: A Ministry of Trade and Industry spokesperson clarified that the India-Singapore Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) does not grant Indian nationals automatic access to Singaporean citizenship, permanent residence, or employment. Despite concerns that the agreement disadvantages local professionals, the spokesperson stated that foreign nationals, including those from India, must meet prevailing criteria and comply with rules on fair hiring. Intra-corporate transfers under CECA account for less than 5% of all Employment Pass holders, with Indian nationals making up a small segment.

site_title: Oil prices slip as Hurricane Laura's blow unlikely to have sustained impact
summary: Oil prices dropped 1.2% to $45.09 a barrel for Brent crude futures and 0.8% to $43.04 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate crude futures. Hurricane Laura's impact on the Gulf of Mexico's oil production was less severe than expected, with 1.56 million barrels per day shut down. Refiners also halted operations, reducing demand for crude oil. Despite the initial concerns, oil experts believe production will recover quickly, with some predicting minimal impact on the market.

site_title: Japan PM Abe set to hold news conference amid health concerns
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to hold a news conference on Friday to address growing health concerns after two recent hospital examinations. Abe's health is reportedly fine, but hospital visits have fueled speculation about his ability to continue in office until September 2021. Abe has been struggling with ulcerative colitis since his teens and has vowed to continue working despite health concerns. He is expected to provide an explanation of his health and outline new measures to fight the coronavirus pandemic, including securing enough vaccines for the nation by early 2021.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to hold a news conference on Friday afternoon in which he is expected to address growing concerns about his health after two recent hospital examinations within a week.

site_title: Air New Zealand to draw on government loan after first annual loss in 18 years
summary: Air New Zealand has agreed to draw on a NZ$900 million government loan to weather the Covid-19 pandemic after reporting its first annual loss in 18 years. The airline reported an underlying pretax loss of NZ$87 million in the 12 months ended June 30, driven by aircraft impairments and restructuring charges. The loan comes with interest rates of 7-9% and gives the government the right to seek repayment through a capital raising or convert the loan to equity. The airline forecasts another loss this fiscal year, but expects to reduce cash burn if domestic travel restrictions are lifted.

site_title: New Amazon health wristband gauges happiness
summary: Amazon unveiled the Halo wristband, a health-tracking device that gauges happiness by analyzing a wearer's voice. The wristband combines data with AI tools to provide feedback on physical and mental health. Priced at $65, with a $4 monthly membership fee, Halo tracks activity levels, body fat, and offers a Tone feature to assess a person's happiness through their voice. The device syncs with a smartphone, and speech samples are deleted after analysis. Amazon aims to improve population health with its expertise in AI and machine learning.

site_title: STI falls 0.88% despite overnight Wall Street rally
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.88% to close at 2,519.81, mirroring regional market trends amid US-China tensions. The Straits Times Index's performance was attributed to "clouded overall sentiment in Asia" following Beijing's missile firings and US sanctions on Chinese firms. Despite a Wall Street overnight rally, driven by expectations of loose monetary policy, investors remained cautious due to escalating tensions.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: Kenjiro 'Hatch' Hashida has reopened his private dining concept, Hashida Private Dining, at OUE Social Kitchen with a nine-course menu priced at S$250. The intimate pop-up omakase features unique culinary creations, including 'fish noodle' and 'Mackerel head to tail'. For charity, Cerebral Palsy Alliance Singapore (CPAS) is offering special delivery meals, including Italian dishes, priced at S$600 and S$1000, with a tax exemption of 2.5 times applicable for up to 70% of the full amount donated.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust rejects sponsor's allegations of breaches
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has rejected allegations by its sponsor, Urban Commons (UC), of breaches in master lease agreements. UC had accused EHT's subsidiaries of failing to pay $15.3 million, maintaining hotels, and refunding rents for a hurricane-damaged hotel. EHT's managers called the allegations baseless and misguided, stating they would focus on meeting business challenges rather than addressing baseless claims. The managers also accused UC's master lessees of wrongly presupposing obligations and ignoring EHT's defaults dating back to 2019.

site_title: Many KrisEnergy investors remain unhappy over revised debt workout
summary: KrisEnergy, a Singapore-based upstream oil and gas company, is facing resistance from investors over its debt workout plan. Despite tweaks to the proposal, bondholders remain unhappy, seeking a US$20 million share of restructured debt and a US$10 million cash payment. The company is trying to restructure debt of US$476.8 million, with its Cambodian project being a key focus. Investors are questioning the project's viability, and some have expressed regret that the company did not consider a sale to a Middle Eastern suitor in 2016. The company's restructuring plan has been delayed, with no clear outcome in sight.

site_title: Thomson Medical sinks into red with half-year S$97.5m net loss
summary: Thomson Medical Group posted a net loss of S$97.5 million for the six months ended June 30, 2020, reversing from a net profit of S$240,000 in the previous year. Revenue declined 12.3% to S$98 million due to movement restrictions and safe-distancing measures amid the coronavirus pandemic. The company's operating loss was S$82.6 million, with demand for obstetric services in Singapore mitigating the impact. The group has seen a gradual recovery of patient volumes as restrictions eased, and shares dropped 3.6% to close at 5.4 cents.

site_title: Rolls-Royce consolidates Singapore and UK operations
summary: Rolls-Royce is consolidating its Singapore and UK operations, moving its aero engine assembly and test volume from Singapore to the UK and its wide-chord fan blade manufacturing volume from the UK to Singapore. The transition is expected to start in Q3 2021, with no additional job losses announced. Employees in Singapore will be offered opportunities within the Rolls-Royce ecosystem, and the company is collaborating with the Singapore government and unions to support the affected employees. The moves are part of a global restructuring driven by the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on the global aviation industry.

site_title: A taste of Portugal
summary: Tuga Singapore, a new restaurant, has opened in Dempsey Village offering a taste of Portugal in the heart of Singapore. The restaurant, located at #01-15 Dempsey Rd, Block 8, Singapore 247696, is open daily from 11am to 11pm. Its menu features Mediterranean cuisine, with a foreign language menu that adds to its unique charm. The restaurant is a welcome addition to Singapore's dining scene, bringing a taste of Portugal to the local community.

Organised in a grid-like pattern, the dining tables are positioned between the shelves, like study tables in a library.

site_title: US dollar gains after Fed shifts inflation target
summary: The US dollar gained 0.53% against the euro on Thursday after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell announced a new strategy to lift US employment and inflation to 2% over time. However, doubts remain about the Fed's ability to achieve its new target, with some analysts warning that the policy could be negative for the US dollar in the long term. The dollar index initially sank before rebounding, while the British pound reached an eight-month high and the Chinese yuan reached its strongest level since January.

site_title: China wants speedy free trade deal with Norway
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi urged a speedy conclusion to a free trade deal with Norway, citing the impact of Covid-19 on global supply chains. Talks on the China-Norway FTA began in 2008, with negotiations resuming in 2017 after a freeze due to the Norwegian Nobel Committee awarding a Peace Prize to a Chinese dissident. Wang warned against "politicising" the Nobel Prize, specifically regarding a proposal to nominate the people of Hong Kong. The minister also criticized US President Trump's description of the coronavirus as a "Chinese" illness, stating the virus likely originated elsewhere.

site_title: Silverlake earnings likely to recover, SaaS offering may drive growth: CGS-CIMB
summary: Singapore-based fintech firm Silverlake Axis is expected to recover its earnings in FY21, with a projected 9.2% increase in top line, according to CGS-CIMB. The brokerage upgraded Silverlake to an "add" call from "hold" and raised its target price to S$0.39. Analysts attribute the recovery to higher project-related revenue assumptions and the company's recently launched cloud-ready core banking system, which can be made available as a software-as-a-service (SaaS) offering.

site_title: Salesforce to cut 1,000 jobs even after banner quarter results
summary: Salesforce plans to cut about 1,000 jobs worldwide, despite reporting record quarterly revenue and forecasting further gains. The job cuts primarily affect sales and customer-support roles, particularly in the US, and are part of the company's effort to streamline its business. CEO Marc Benioff stated that there is no lifetime employment at Salesforce, and the company will rebalance 5-10% of its workforce annually to focus on strategic areas. Affected employees will receive 60 days to search for a new job within the company.

site_title: The whimsical life
summary: Terence Neo, founder of boutique interior design firm EightyTwo, designed his family home around his two daughters, aged three and five, incorporating whimsical and nostalgic elements. The 50-year-old apartment, with its arched doorways and terrazzo flooring, was gutted and renovated to create a "fairytale-like" space with a modern eclectic design. The home features a colour palette inspired by his daughters, with pinks, peach, and grey tones, as well as a man-cave and private spaces for each family member, showcasing the designer's ability to balance his clients' wishes with his own.

site_title: Fed targets 2% average inflation and elevates focus on jobs
summary: The US Federal Reserve has introduced an aggressive new strategy to restore full employment and lift inflation to 2% average levels. The central bank aims to offset below-2% periods with higher inflation "for some time" and ensure employment reaches its maximum level. This approach reflects increased downward risks to employment and inflation, with the Fed seeking to balance growth with price stability. The new strategy is aimed at achieving a healthier economic environment.

site_title: The problem with beautiful, plentiful greens
summary: Singapore's vegetable supply faces challenges due to high pesticide contamination in Malaysia, where 40% of imported produce originates. The issue highlights the need for stricter regulations and better monitoring. Meanwhile, the financial profession is slow to adopt AI and machine learning tools, with only 10% of investment managers using them in the past year. Experts warn of the dangers of overly confident advisors who prioritize speed over wisdom.

site_title: All cleared up
summary: Beauty industry veterans debunk common skincare misconceptions, including the frequency of face washing, the necessity of toners, and the effectiveness of anti-aging products. Experts agree that face washing should be tailored to skin type, not a one-size-fits-all routine. Toners are not crucial, but can be beneficial for balancing skin pH. Anti-aging products work in combination with medical treatments and good lifestyle habits. Facial oils can be used by those with oily or combination skin, but must be non-comedogenic. Sunscreen should be applied last, after moisturizer, and moisturizer should be allowed to absorb fully before sunscreen. The industry veterans also emphasize that there is no gender in skincare, and men can use women's beauty products. Facial rollers can be effective, but technique and consistency are key.

site_title: Higher salary floor for foreign hires may put financial hub aspirations at risk
summary: The Singapore government has raised the salary floor for Employment Passes in finance to S$5,000, aiming to encourage local hiring amid recessionary pressures. However, some economists warn this "protectionist response" could deter financial institutions from investing and expanding in Singapore, potentially hindering the city-state's aspirations to become a major financial hub. The move may lead to higher wage costs and a smaller talent pool, negatively impacting financial institutions' decisions.

site_title: 10 new courses in built environment sector on offer for mid-career workers
summary: SkillsFuture Singapore is introducing 900 new opportunities in the built environment sector for mid-career workers, starting from this month. The courses, offered by various training providers, aim to equip workers with the necessary skills for new roles. The initiative supports the sector's growth and development, providing mid-careerists with a chance to upskill and reskill, ultimately contributing to the sector's competitiveness and sustainability.

site_title: Criminal Legal Aid Scheme founder Harry Elias dies, aged 83
summary: Senior Counsel Harry Elias, founder of the Criminal Legal Aid Scheme, died at 83 due to a long illness. Elias was a pioneer in pro bono criminal legal services for the needy.

site_title: MND to step up transformation of building sector
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) in Singapore plans to accelerate the transformation of the construction sector by adopting advanced building technologies, enhancing professionalism, and creating new jobs for Singaporeans. The government also aims to develop healthier communities, protect nature reserves, and promote sustainability through initiatives such as green building masterplans, smart infrastructure, and reducing carbon footprints. Additionally, the Ministry of Sustainability and Environment will focus on pushing for a green recovery, investing in water management and conservation, and unlocking more spaces for farming to achieve food security goals.

site_title: Reviving air hub is top and immediate priority for Singapore: Ong
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung has stated that reviving the country's air hub is a top priority, following the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on air travel. Changi Airport has lost 50% of its air links and 95% of scheduled passenger services. The government plans to improve aviation infrastructure, including a three-runway system, and develop a more competitive terminal for the future. Additionally, the government will work to enhance digitalisation in port clearances and establish new land connections with Malaysia.

site_title: AIP, Tokyu Land plan Singapore Reit IPO for Australian properties
summary: AIP Asset Management and Tokyu Land Corp plan to list a Singapore Reit backed by Australian commercial properties, with a potential IPO of around S$400 million. The companies are working with advisers and will reach out to potential cornerstone investors next week. This would be the third Reit listing in Singapore this year, following the United Hampshire US Reit and Elite Commercial Reit, which raised a combined US$487 million. Details of the offering are still being deliberated.

site_title: Art galleries brace for the worst
summary: Singapore's commercial art galleries are struggling to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic, with many reporting a significant decline in sales and foot traffic. Despite efforts to pivot to digital showcases, collectors remain cautious, citing economic uncertainties and travel restrictions. Gallerists predict that it will take at least 12 months for the market to rebound. Permanent losses have already been suffered, with galleries such as Chan+Hori Contemporary and the NTU Centre of Contemporary Art closing their doors. Some gallerists are rethinking their business strategies, including participation in art fairs, and are exploring new ways of operating in the post-pandemic art world.

site_title: Trade and trust between India and China are at odds
summary: India's trade deficit with China has declined sharply, falling to $1.2 billion in June, down from $2.4 billion in May. This is a welcome development for India, which has long been concerned about the growing trade deficit. Despite the decline, India's trade deficit with China remains significant, accounting for a large chunk of its overall trade deficit. The decline is attributed to Indian exports surging by 78% in June, driven by higher Chinese demand for Indian goods such as organic chemicals and mineral fuels. However, the trust deficit between India and China remains a concern, and efforts to address this issue are needed to restore normalcy in their trade relations.

site_title: Watch that balance sheet of behaviour
summary: A pandemic has prompted a reevaluation of how companies are judged, shifting from solely focusing on shareholder value to considering their environmental and social impact. Corporations reflect human behavior, and their purpose is to create and sell products for a profit while obeying business rules. However, globalization has led to a decline in cooperation, and companies are now aware of their responsibility to benefit people globally to maintain their freedom. A new approach is needed, with a "Balance Sheet of Behaviour" assessing a company's use of the planet and population, rather than just its financial performance.

site_title: Higher minimum salary criteria for Employment and S Pass applicants
summary: Singapore is raising the minimum qualifying salary for Employment Pass (EP) applicants to S$4,500 from September 1 and for S Pass applicants to S$2,500 from October 1. The EP minimum qualifying salary in the financial services sector will be raised to S$5,000 from December 1. These changes aim to encourage and support local hiring, particularly in the financial services sector, amid an uncertain economic outlook. The government also plans to extend the Fair Consideration Framework to promote greater awareness of job vacancies among local job seekers.

site_title: There's more to German wine than Riesling
summary: German wine offers a diverse range of options beyond Riesling, with 12 exceptional bottles showcasing the country's lesser-known varieties. Climate change and improved farming methods have enhanced German Pinot Noir, while other grapes like Pinot Blanc, Silvaner, and Trollinger produce delightful wines. Natural wines, made without additives, are also gaining popularity. The article highlights 12 exceptional bottles, including a Mosel Elbling Trocken 2018, a Württemberg Trollinger Trocken 2019, and a Baden Pinot Noir Liaison 2018. These wines demonstrate Germany's wine diversity and value, challenging the perception that Riesling represents the entire country's wine story.

site_title: Uncertainty is now the new normal
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted global business and economies, with most experts believing that normalcy can only return with a reliable vaccine or therapy. The US, Brazil, South Korea, and Spain are experiencing new cases and second waves, while Australia has locked down again. The economic damage from lockdowns and the potential for uncontrolled spread of the virus pose significant risks. Businesses must adapt to new models, including remote work and flexible employment, and be prepared for volatility and uncertainty, with some predicting a prolonged recovery or permanent output reduction.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims drift around 1m
summary: US weekly jobless claims remain around 1 million, indicating a stalled labor market recovery amid the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and expiring government financial aid. Initial claims for state unemployment benefits totaled 1.006 million for the week ended Aug 22. Economists attribute a sharp rebound in activity to government support, dialing back growth estimates for the third quarter. The economy suffered its deepest contraction in at least 73 years in the second quarter, with a 31.7% annualized rate of decline.

site_title: Minority shareholders hampering Darco's growth, says deputy chairman
summary: Darco Water Technologies, a Singapore-based environment-solutions company, has struggled to secure long-term concession projects despite efforts to diversify its income streams. The company's non-executive deputy chairman, Robert Wang Zhi, attributes the lack of progress to minority shareholders' "resentment" and "mistrust" towards him, citing concerns over his intentions and decisions. Wang, who holds a 44% stake in the company, believes the issues are distracting the management from growing the business and have led to a negative impact on shareholders' returns.

site_title: US pending home sales rise for third straight month in July
summary: US pending home sales rose 5.9% in July, marking the third consecutive month of growth, according to the National Association of Realtors. The increase was higher than economists' forecast of a 3% gain. Pending home sales surged 15.5% from the previous year, driven by record low interest rates and a shift to low-density residential areas. This growth contrasts with the broader economy, which has been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Suntec Singapore cuts 85 jobs as events business dries up
summary: Suntec Singapore Convention and Exhibition Centre has cut 85 jobs due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on the meetings, incentives, conventions, and exhibitions (MICE) industry. The affected workers comprise 60 local and 25 non-local staff, with Suntec Singapore having 149 local and 29 non-local employees after the exercise. Eligible employees will receive a month's salary for every year of service as severance payment, and assistance with job placement and training will be provided by the union and NTUC.

site_title: New Kajima hub to serve as Apac HQ, drive R&D for construction
summary: Kajima Corporation, a Japan-listed construction company, has announced plans to establish its Asia-Pacific (Apac) headquarters at its new S$100m innovation centre in Changi Business Park, Singapore. The centre, named Kajima Global Hub, will consolidate 400 staff and drive R&D for the construction industry, focusing on advanced technologies and sustainable development. The hub aims to create better jobs and reduce environmental impact, and will be completed by 2023.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Ministry of Manpower announced that the minimum salary for Employment Pass (EP) holders in the finance sector will be raised to S$5,000 from December, exceeding the S$4,500 threshold for other sectors. This move aims to attract more skilled professionals in the financial services industry.

images.alt_text: This is the first time that the Singapore authorities have set higher qualifying salaries for a specific sector to hire foreign professionals.

site_title: NTUC steps up efforts to strengthen safeguards for local PMEs
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) in Singapore is establishing a taskforce with the Singapore National Employers Federation to review existing policies and strengthen safeguards for professionals, executives, and managers (PMEs). The taskforce will be led by NTUC assistant secretary-general Patrick Tay and SNEF executive director Sim Gim Guan, with NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng and SNEF president Robert Yap serving as advisors. This move aims to better understand the needs of PMEs and enhance relevant safeguards.

images.alt_text: NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng says some degree of market failure has occurred, and that middle-aged local PMEs are vulnerable.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) has acquired the remaining 35% stake in Heavy Maintenance Singapore Services (HMSS), a joint-venture company, from Airbus Services Asia Pacific. The transaction was completed on August 27, 2020, with a cash consideration of S$1. HMSS is now a wholly-owned subsidiary of SIAEC. The acquisition was made following a joint review of the business in view of the COVID-19 pandemic. SIAEC will continue to collaborate with Airbus on projects and review joint opportunities.

site_title: Salary floor for Employment Pass holders in finance to be raised to S$5,000
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Manpower has announced a salary floor for Employment Pass (EP) holders in the finance sector to be raised to S$5,000 from December, surpassing the increased threshold for other sectors. The monthly salary requirement for entry-level EP holders in financial services will be raised first to S$4,500 from September, followed by a further increase to S$5,000 in December. The move aims to prevent discriminatory hiring practices and attract foreign talent with specialized skills in areas like cyber security and machine learning.

site_title: Apple losing dominant market share for wireless earbuds
summary: Apple is expected to boost AirPods sales by a third this year, but will lose its dominant grip on the wireless earbuds market. Apple accounts for 35% of the market, down from nearly 50% in 2019, due to cheaper alternatives from Chinese rivals such as Xiaomi and Samsung. Specialized Chinese brands like Lypertek and 1More offer better fit and sound quality at lower prices, threatening Apple's lead.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as Fed targets 2% average inflation
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday as Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell announced an aggressive strategy to restore full employment and lift inflation to healthier levels. The Dow Jones rose 52.15 points, the S&P 500 gained 6.41 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 23.14 points, driven by optimism over the Fed's new approach. The moves come despite ongoing US-China trade tensions and mixed views on the Fed's policy shift.

site_title: Amazon jumps into wellness tracking, challenges Apple and Fitbit
summary: Amazon has introduced Halo, a wearable fitness gadget that uses AI to track physical activity, sleep, and emotions, entering the market dominated by Apple and Fitbit. The device includes features like 3D body scans and voice-tone detection. Amazon is offering invite-only early access starting at $64.99, which includes six months of service. The company's move aims to improve population health despite the lack of improvement in the US over the last decade, according to Amazon Halo's principal medical officer.

site_title: BOK holds fire for now as growth outlook cut
