summary: The Bank of Korea (BOK) held its benchmark rate steady at 0.5% despite a cut to its economic growth forecast, expecting a 1.3% contraction this year. The central bank cited the resurgence of the coronavirus, floods, and a slower recovery in exports and consumption as reasons for the downgrade. Governor Lee Ju-yeol emphasized the need to carefully weigh the benefits and side effects of further stimulus, warning against fueling property gains. The decision underscores the BOK's balancing act between supporting the economy and curbing inflation.

site_title: IHH Healthcare records Q2 net loss of RM120.6m
summary: IHH Healthcare recorded a net loss of RM120.6 million (S$39.5 million) in its second quarter, down from a profit of RM185 million in the same period last year. The loss was attributed to lower operating performance and foreign exchange losses, but was partially offset by a fair-value gain on cross-currency swaps. The company expects the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic to continue for the rest of the year, but remains optimistic about its resilience and ability to mitigate losses through new revenue streams and cost discipline.

site_title: Hurricane Laura's damage may cost insurers US$15b
summary: Hurricane Laura caused catastrophic damage across Louisiana, with a "catastrophic storm surge," flash floods, and devastating winds. The storm, matching a record set in 1856, is estimated to inflict more than $15 billion in insured losses. Mandatory evacuations were issued in coastal areas, targeting the US energy industry, with over 80% of Gulf oil production and a third of refining capacity shut down. The losses may impact reinsurers, which provide insurance for insurers, serving as backstops for premiums.

site_title: US commercial property prices fall, 'worst yet to come'
summary: US commercial property prices are falling, with indexes for office, retail, and lodging properties slipping year-over-year in July. Transaction volume plummeted to $14 billion, down 69% from 2019. The decline is expected to worsen, with senior vice-president Jim Costello predicting "the worst is yet to come." Hotel prices dropped 4.4%, retail declined 2.8%, and office prices fell 0.9%. However, apartment building prices rose 6.9% and industrial values increased 8.3%, leading to a 1.5% gain for all property types.

site_title: Walmart joins Microsoft in pursuit of deal to acquire TikTok
summary: Walmart and Microsoft have teamed up to bid on acquiring TikTok, a surprise move by the retail giant to expand into technology and media. The joint bid signals Walmart's desire to grow its third-party online marketplace and advertising arm. Walmart's shares surged 3.6% after news of the joint pursuit. Microsoft has been in discussions to buy TikTok's US operations, and other companies like Oracle and Twitter have also emerged as potential bidders. The move comes as TikTok is fielding interest in its US assets, following President Trump's order to sell its US assets within 90 days.

site_title: China's Xpeng IPO raises US$1.5b for smart EV technologies, expansion
summary: China's Xpeng, an electric vehicle maker, raised US$1.5 billion in its initial public offering (IPO), exceeding its initial target of US$1.11 billion. The company, founded by CEO He Xiaopeng, plans to use the funds for research and development and expanding sales, focusing on mass-market segment cars priced between 150,000 yuan to 300,000 yuan. Xpeng has sold over 20,000 electric vehicles and has a strong backing from Chinese e-commerce titan Alibaba and Xiaomi Corp. The company's shares will start trading in New York on Thursday.

site_title: Six shops at Aljunied condo for sale
summary: Six strata-titled shops at Sims Urban Oasis condominium in Singapore are up for sale by private treaty, offering bulk discounts, adjoining units, and critical mass in floor space. The shops range from 323-678 sq ft and have a combined floor area of 2,895 sq ft. The average price translates to S$3,000 psf, with discounts and a 5% per annum return guaranteed by the developer. The investment is open to foreigners and has a residential catchment of over 1,000 households.

site_title: Maybank cites pandemic for 52% Q2 profit drop to RM942m
summary: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank), Malaysia's largest lender by assets, reported a 51.5% drop in Q2 profit to RM942 million due to pandemic-induced restrictions and interest rate cuts. Revenue fell 9.7% to RM11.8 billion, with net interest income and Islamic banking income also declining. Maybank expects a squeeze in net interest margin and expects provisioning to remain elevated. The bank's chairman described the quarter as challenging, citing uncertainty due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Thailand eyes more foreign patients as hospitals urge easier access
summary: Thailand is easing its novel coronavirus procedures to allow more foreign patients to receive treatment from next month, with 100 hospitals and clinics set to be approved to receive patients. The country, a major hub for medical tourism, has seen 632,000 overseas patients in 2019, but restrictions since April have kept most foreign patients out. Only 172 foreign patients have been allowed in since July, and hospital operators have urged authorities to clarify and relax the process, citing humanitarian issues due to patients needing urgent treatment.

site_title: New season of 'Fortnite' is here, Apple users miss out
summary: Epic Games launched the new season of Fortnite, featuring Marvel characters, but excluded iPhone and iPad users due to a legal fight with Apple Inc. The game's direct payment feature, which allows users to pay Epic directly at a cheaper price, is still available. Many users, including parents, expressed disappointment and frustration on social media. The move is part of a larger dispute between Epic and Apple over the company's policy of taking a cut of purchases made inside the Fortnite app.

site_title: SIA Engineering buys remaining stake in former JV company
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) acquired the remaining 35% stake in Heavy Maintenance Singapore Services (HMSS) from Airbus Services Asia Pacific for S$1, with an additional S$7.39 million in cash received upon termination of the joint-venture agreement. The transaction, completed on August 27, 2020, marks HMSS as a wholly-owned subsidiary of SIAEC. The acquisition was made following a joint review of the business amidst the Covid-19 pandemic, with SIAEC and Airbus to continue collaborating on projects.

site_title: Suntec Singapore cuts 85 jobs as Covid-19 takes toll on MICE industry
summary: Suntec Singapore Convention and Exhibition Centre is cutting 85 jobs due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on the MICE industry. The affected workers, comprising 60 local and 25 non-local staff, will be let go in a one-off retrenchment exercise. The move is part of the company's efforts to renew its business strategy and reduce its workforce from 149 local and 29 non-local employees to 89 local and four non-local employees.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust rejects sponsor's allegations of breaches
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has rejected allegations by its sponsor, Urban Commons (UC), of breaches in master lease agreements. UC had claimed EHT's subsidiaries were in breach of agreements, citing failures to pay over $15.3 million and other obligations. EHT's managers described the allegations as "baseless" and "misguided," stating they will focus on addressing business and economic challenges rather than responding to the baseless claims. The managers also warned that UC's master lessees have defaulted on payments and accumulated liabilities, contributing to EHT's challenges.

site_title: Britain's RWS scoops up SDL in all-share merger
summary: Britain's RWS Holdings has agreed to an all-share deal with SDL, valuing the latter at 854 million pounds (S$1.53 billion) to create the world's largest language services and software company. SDL shareholders will receive 1.2246 new RWS shares for each SDL share, representing a 52% premium to its closing price. The deal is expected to see SDL surge, with shares rising 35% to their highest in over two decades, while RWS shares slipped 11% following the announcement.

site_title: Ping An's profits fall sharply as pandemic hits new business
summary: Ping An Insurance, a Chinese insurer deemed globally systemically important, reported a 29.7% drop in first-half net profit to 68.68 billion yuan, its largest decline in over a decade, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company's gross written premiums fell 0.2% and investment income dropped 16.7%. Despite a positive impact on auto claims from travel disruptions, Ping An's banking business saw a 11.2% decline in profit. The company attributed the decline to "sharp year-on-year capital markets fluctuations."

site_title: 'Tricky moment' for Europe as schools reopen
summary: Europe is entering a "tricky moment" with the new school year, as the World Health Organization warns of growing evidence of youth infecting others at social gatherings. Countries on the continent have recorded higher numbers of Covid-19 infections among young people, with the virus attacking multiple organs, including the lungs and heart. This poses a concern for the long-term impact of the virus on young people, despite the fact that they may not die from it.

images.alt_text: Europe is entering a "tricky moment" with the new school year, and while classrooms have not played a major role in spreading coronavirus, there is growing evidence of youth infecting others at social gatherings.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.20 points to 1,554.78. The market saw 13.706 billion lots traded worth RM5.559 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 580 to 544.

site_title: China's biggest carmaker posts 39% drop in H1 profit
summary: SAIC Motor, China's largest carmaker, reported a 39% drop in first-half net profit to 8.4 billion yuan due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Revenue fell 25% to 274.5 billion yuan, but improved in the second quarter with a 32% increase in net profit. The company faces competition from electric vehicle newcomers like Tesla and NIO, which have better weathered the outbreak and lured buyers away from SAIC's electric-car offerings.

site_title: US Vice-President Pence warns against Biden win
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence warned that a Joe Biden presidency would lead to a path of socialism and decline, citing the recent police shooting of Jacob Blake in Wisconsin. Pence described the election as a choice between law-and-order and lawlessness, stating "You won't be safe in Joe Biden's America." Biden responded by calling for an end to violence and defending the right to protest, while also criticizing Trump's handling of the pandemic. Pence's comments were seen as a strategic move to sway evangelical voters and undermine Biden's campaign.

site_title: STI falls 0.88% despite overnight Wall Street rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.88% to 2,519.81 on Thursday, despite a Wall Street overnight rally, due to escalating US-China tensions and fresh concerns over monetary policy. The decline followed four missiles fired by Beijing into the South China Sea and US sanctions on Chinese firms. Investors await US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's speech, expecting hints of lower rates and inflation targets to overshoot.

site_title: Abbott's US$5 rapid covid test takes US$22b bite out of peers
summary: Abbott Laboratories' US$5 rapid COVID-19 test received emergency authorization in the US, causing competitors to experience significant market losses. Quidel's value dropped by over a third, while Hologic and Quest Diagnostics fell 12% and 5% respectively. Other diagnostic companies also saw declines, totaling at least $22 billion in market value. Analysts predict Abbott's test demand could be "ENORMOUS," but supply concerns may limit its impact on competitors.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise ahead of Powell's speech
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 6,126.20, driven by better-than-expected business investment data and Victoria's lowest rise in Covid-19 cases in nearly two months. Investors are awaiting US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's speech for hints on policy tweaks to boost inflation. Gold stocks and heavyweight miners, including BHP Group and Fortescue Metals, rose, while financials fell 0.6%. The speech is expected to influence Australian equities due to the country's exporting and commodity-based economy.

site_title: Fed to target 2% average inflation, elevates focus on jobs
summary: The US Federal Reserve has adopted a new strategy to restore full employment and lift inflation to 2% on average, shifting its focus from inflation targeting to employment goals. The Fed aims to ensure employment doesn't fall short of its maximum level, with the possibility of keeping interest rates lower for longer. The new approach reflects the Fed's appreciation for a strong labor market, particularly for low- and moderate-income communities, amid the ongoing US economic crisis and the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve on Thursday rolled out an aggressive new strategy to restore the United States to full employment and lift inflation back to healthier levels in a world where it now believes that "downward risks to employment and inflation have increased."

site_title: Reviving air hub top and immediate priority for Singapore
summary: Singapore prioritizes reviving its air hub, with Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung stating it's a top priority. Changi Airport has lost 50% of air links and 95% of scheduled passenger services due to Covid-19. The government aims to improve aviation infrastructure, including a three-runway system and digitalize port clearances. Plans for Tuas Port, a world's largest fully automated container terminal, are on track for completion in the 2040s. The government is also working on building new land connections with Malaysia and enhancing public transport, including more inclusive options for the less ambulant.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower ahead of PM presser, Fed speech
summary: Tokyo's key Nikkei index closed 0.35% lower at 23,208.86 ahead of Japan's prime minister press conference and the Jackson Hole conference. The broader Topix index also fell 0.53% to 1,615.89. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and comes despite the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records in the US.

site_title: Rolls-Royce to merge some Singapore, UK operations
summary: Rolls-Royce plans to consolidate its Singapore aero engine assembly and test volume into its UK operations in Derby, while moving its wide-chord fan blade manufacturing volume to the Seletar Aerospace Park in Singapore. The move is part of a global restructuring, which also includes the axe of 240 roles in Singapore, mostly technical positions. The transition is expected to start in Q3 2021, and Rolls-Royce will explore options for the Singapore assembly and test facility for "near-term aerospace growth activities".

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower on fresh China-US tensions
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Thursday due to fresh China-US tensions. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.83%, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.61%. Meanwhile, the US Federal Reserve's Jerome Powell is set to deliver a speech later in the day. Despite the uncertainty, some Asian markets, such as Singapore and China's second exchange, saw gains.

site_title: Shell pilots virtual-plant technology at Singapore refinery
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has selected its Singapore refinery site, Pulau Bukom, as the first site globally to pilot its virtual-manufacturing technology, Digital Twin. The technology, set to be completed in 2024, will create a "complete virtual representation" of the physical site, allowing for real-time collaboration, reduced downtime, and improved operational efficiency. The rollout is expected to bring a 25% improvement in productivity, reliability, and safety by 2025, and will be accompanied by a training program for all employees.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks snap four-day rally on coronavirus worries
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted 1% on Thursday, snapping a four-day winning streak, amid concerns over the country's highest daily coronavirus cases since early March. The benchmark Kospi closed at 2,344.45, as the Bank of Korea downgraded its 2020 growth outlook and kept interest rates steady. Foreigners were net sellers of 23.8 billion won, and the central bank left the door open for more monetary stimulus to support the economy.

site_title: Criminal Legal Aid Scheme founder Harry Elias dies
summary: Senior Counsel Harry Elias, 83, who co-founded the Law Society's Criminal Legal Aid Scheme, has died. Elias was a litigation lawyer known for his compassion and contributions to society. He was one of the first 12 lawyers appointed Senior Counsel in 1997 and received the CC Tan Award in 2005. His law firm described him as a fearless and first-class advocate, a true friend, teacher, and kind soul. Elias' legacy will be remembered through his work in providing free legal representation to those in need.

site_title: Pace of transformation for Singapore construction sector to be stepped up
summary: The Singapore government plans to step up the pace of industry transformation in the construction sector to support a post-Covid-19 recovery. The Ministry of National Development aims to adopt advanced building technologies, enhance professionalism, and create new jobs for Singaporeans. Additionally, the government will focus on greening efforts, including developing 'Healthy Towns for all ages', conserving native flora and fauna, and integrating nature into urban areas. Other initiatives include investing in technology for water management and conservation, and intensifying efforts to diversify Singapore's imports and strengthen food supply chains.

site_title: Grab extends hawker-food delivery programme to 16 more locations
summary: Grab is expanding its Hawker Centre 2.0 pilot programme to 16 more locations, bringing the total number of hawkers to 188. The programme, launched in May 2020, aims to support hawkers hit by the Covid-19 pandemic and promote digitalisation. The expanded programme will test its effectiveness on a larger scale until December, following a successful trial run in Ang Mo Kio Central. Participating hawkers will pay a reduced commission rate, with Grab taking a commission of 25-35% of the order value.

site_title: Trade bodies alliance unveils framework to uplift Singapore beauty services industry
summary: The Beauty Services Alliance in Singapore has launched a competency framework to uplift the industry, representing 6,000 businesses in beauty and wellness. The framework aims to increase local job positions by 30% in the next five years, providing career progression pathways for over 13,300 employees. The framework guides education and training providers in designing courses and certifications, and will be adopted by 10 organisations, including the Jean Yip Group.

site_title: Bollywood star Aamir Khan under fire over China, Turkey links
summary: Bollywood star Aamir Khan is under fire in India after being linked to China due to his popularity and business ties. Khan, a brand ambassador for Vivo and a major draw in China with films like "Dangal", has been criticized by the Hindu far-right group Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) for being "The Dragon's favourite Khan". The group has put Khan on the cover of its magazine, highlighting his connections to China and sparking outrage among some Indians.

site_title: Rolls-Royce eyes asset sales to boost pandemic-hit finances
summary: Rolls-Royce plans to sell its Spanish unit ITP Aero and other assets to raise at least £2 billion, aiming to boost its finances hit by the pandemic. The company also announced a £1 billion cost-cutting plan, with finance chief Stephen Daintith resigning to join retail technology firm Ocado. Rolls-Royce's revenues plummeted due to reduced flying hours, resulting in an underlying loss of £3.2 billion for the first six months of the year. The company will continue to assess options to strengthen its balance sheet, amid uncertainty in the civil aviation sector.

site_title: NTUC and SNEF set up taskforce to protect older PMEs' employability
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) and the Singapore National Employers Federation (SNEF) are setting up a taskforce to protect the employability of professionals, executives, and managers (PMEs) aged 40-60. The taskforce aims to understand the needs of PMEs, develop relevant skills, and work with the government to review policies. NTUC Secretary-General Ng Chee Meng and SNEF president Robert Yap will lead the taskforce, which will engage PMEs in dialogue and discussion for 6-12 months to come up with recommendations. The taskforce will kick off operations in October.

site_title: Ant Group's IPO may push down cost of borrowing in Hong Kong
summary: Ant Group's upcoming IPO in Hong Kong may lower borrowing costs due to anticipated demand for cash, potentially pushing the local currency to its strong end of the trading band. This could prompt the Hong Kong Monetary Authority to sell Hong Kong dollars, increasing available liquidity and reducing interbank rates. The one-month lending rate, Hibor, has already fallen to 0.26% from 2.27% in January, and may continue to drop as banks have more cash to lend. This could benefit local businesses struggling with the effects of the pandemic and protests.

site_title: TikTok CEO Kevin Mayer quits after less than three months: memo
summary: TikTok CEO Kevin Mayer has left the company less than three months after joining, citing a change in the "corporate structural changes" and the "global role" he signed up for. Mayer, who was also appointed as chief operating officer of ByteDance's Chinese parent, will be replaced by US general manager Vanessa Pappas on an interim basis. The departure comes days after TikTok sued the Trump administration over an executive order banning transactions in the US with the app. ByteDance's founder Zhang Yiming stated the company is moving quickly to find resolutions to global issues, particularly in the US and India.

site_title: Kajima invests S$100m in first overseas innovation centre in Singapore
summary: Kajima Corporation has invested S$100 million in its first overseas innovation centre, the Kajima Global Hub, in Singapore. The 13,088 sqm facility will serve as the Asia-Pacific headquarters and house R&D labs for advanced construction technologies. The centre, expected to be completed by 2023, will also consolidate 400 staff across various business functions. The hub aims to increase local research personnel, create jobs, and reduce the environmental impact of new developments, with a focus on robotics and sustainable technologies.

site_title: India-Singapore free-trade agreement doesn't grant automatic access to citizenship, PR status or a job: MTI
summary: The India-Singapore Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) does not automatically grant Indian nationals citizenship, permanent residence, or employment in Singapore. Foreign professionals, managers, and executives (PMEs) from India, including intra-corporate transferees, are subject to prevailing work-pass rules and must meet Singapore's criteria for employment passes. Intra-corporate transfers account for less than 5% of EP holders, with Indian nationals making up a small segment, contradicting claims that CECA is the primary source of PMEs in Singapore.

site_title: Europe: Equities slip on hurricane fears
summary: Europe's major stock markets declined 0.3% in early deals on Thursday amid concerns over the US economic outlook due to Hurricane Laura. The London FTSE 100 index fell to 6,025.71 points. Investors also awaited a key speech by Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell, which may influence US monetary policy.

site_title: Saks faces eviction in Miami over US$1.9m in unpaid rent
summary: Saks Fifth Avenue, owned by Hudson's Bay, is facing eviction from its Miami-area mall, Bal Harbour Shops, due to unpaid rent of approximately $1.9 million. The mall claims Saks has not paid rent since March 16, despite generating significant revenue during the COVID-19 pandemic. Saks disputes the eviction, stating its landlord has not acted in good faith and has bullied tenants. The pandemic has accelerated retail trends, with several department stores filing for bankruptcy, including JC Penney and Neiman Marcus.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB upgrades Silverlake to 'add', expects earnings recovery
summary: Brokerage firm CGS-CIMB upgraded Silverlake Axis to 'add' from 'hold' and raised its target price to S$0.39, citing a strong order backlog and easing lockdown measures, which it expects to drive a 22.5% year-on-year increase in project-related revenue in FY21. Analysts forecast Silverlake's earnings to recover, with earnings per share growth of 4.2% and 4.9% for FY21 and FY22, respectively.

site_title: KrisEnergy board passed up potential lifeline: source
summary: KrisEnergy, an upstream oil and gas company, was offered US$230 million by AlHassan International Holdings in 2016 to buy its stakes in several oil fields. The offer was never announced due to disagreements over terms, and KrisEnergy ultimately restructured its debt of US$476.8 million. The company is now trying to restructure debt and has scheduled an informal investor meeting. If the offer had been accepted, it could have prevented KrisEnergy's current financial struggles.

site_title: Maybank Q2 profit drops 52%
summary: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank), Malaysia's largest lender, reported a 51.5% drop in second-quarter profit to RM942 million, lagging behind analyst estimates. Revenue fell 9.7% to RM11.8 billion, while net interest income and Islamic banking income also declined 8.2%. Allowances for impairment losses on loans and financing rose 344.1%. The bank attributed the decline to significant interest rate cuts and the impact on net interest margin, which it aims to offset by growing current and savings deposits.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 2.86 points, or 0.18%, to 1,546.72 on Thursday, opening lower. The market saw 1.13 billion lots traded worth RM322.87 million. Gainers outpaced losers 322 to 212.

site_title: Gold slips as investors book profit, await Fed's cues
summary: Gold prices fell 0.8% to $1,938.32 per ounce, as investors booked profits and awaited US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell's potential change in monetary strategy. The decline followed a 1.3% rise in the previous session. Analysts attributed the decrease to "punters pulling profits" in the thinner Asian trading session. Investors are watching for Powell's cues on monetary policy, which could impact gold prices.

site_title: SEC approves NYSE proposal to allow IPO alternative
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) approved a proposal by the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) to allow companies to raise capital through direct listings, an alternative to traditional initial public offerings (IPOs). This move creates options for private companies to go public without the involvement of investment banks. The SEC deemed the NYSE's proposal consistent with its rules and regulations, following similar requests by the exchange operator in December. The ruling comes amid an extended resurgence in US capital markets and follows the direct listing route taken by companies such as Palantir Technologies and Asana.

site_title: Australia's Q2 business investment slide not as bad as feared, plus for GDP
summary: Australian business investment declined 5.9% in Q2 to A$26.1 billion, better than forecasted 8.4% slump. However, firms remain confident about future spending plans, with an estimated A$98.6 billion for 2020/21, 8.9% higher than the previous estimate. Analysts expect a 4.5% contraction in GDP for the June quarter, down from an earlier prediction of a 6.5% slump, suggesting the economic recession may not be as deep as initially feared.

site_title: Maybank appoints KPMG as receiver for Xihe vessel
summary: Maybank has appointed KPMG as receiver for the Xihe vessel Ocean Success, as well as two other vessels owned by subsidiaries of Xihe Holdings. The move comes as the Lim family's businesses face pressure. Maybank had extended a mortgage to An Ya Shipping, the vessel's owner, in 2015. The appointment of KPMG is in relation to Maybank's interests and the restructuring of Xihe Holdings, which has been placed under interim judicial management. The exact role of the three vessels within the IJM arrangement is unclear.

site_title: New Zealand court sentences mosque shooter to life imprisonment without parole
summary: A New Zealand court has sentenced Brenton Tarrant, the 29-year-old Australian who killed 51 Muslim worshippers in the 2019 Christchurch mosque shootings, to life imprisonment without parole. This is the first time such a sentence has been handed down in the country. Judge Cameron Mander stated that Tarrant's crimes were "so wicked" that even a finite term would not be sufficient for punishment and denunciation. Tarrant, who represented himself, did not react to the sentence and had previously expressed a desire to instill fear in those he deemed "invaders."

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin Thursday's session with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened Thursday with losses, easing 0.09% to 25,469.77, amid anticipation of a key speech by Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell later in the day. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.11%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.16%. The Hang Sang Index, however, declined.

site_title: Smartphone giant Xiaomi jumps to two-year high after profit beats analyst estimates
summary: Xiaomi shares surged to a two-year high after reporting better-than-expected profit in its June quarter, driven by strong growth in the Chinese market and overseas business. The company's net income more than doubled to 4.49 billion yuan, beating analyst estimates, and sales increased 3.1%. Xiaomi's overseas business has recovered to pre-Covid-19 levels, with analysts predicting strong value share gains starting in the second half of 2020. The stock climbed as much as 7.5% in Hong Kong, adding to a 78% gain this year.

site_title: Honda goes small with first all-electric car
summary: Honda Motor has launched its first all-electric car, the Honda e, a compact model designed for city driving. The vehicle contrasts with larger EVs from competitors like Tesla and Audi, which focus on sedans and SUVs with long driving ranges. The Honda e is aimed at a premium market due to high battery costs, but its compact size makes it more affordable and suitable for urban use.

site_title: Six shops at Aljunied condo for sale at S$3,000 psf before bulk discounts
summary: Six strata-titled shops at Sims Urban Oasis condominium in Singapore are up for sale by private treaty, offering bulk discounts and adjoining units. The average price is S$3,000 psf, with discounts reducing the price to S$2,360 psf for a cluster of four shops and S$2,395 psf for a cluster of two. The investment comes with a two-year 5% per annum return guaranteed by the developer and is open to foreigners. The shops are located near Aljunied MRT station and have a combined floor area of 2,895 sq ft.

site_title: DBS, Singtel partner Fave on digital payments, cashback
summary: DBS Bank and Singtel have partnered with digital payments platform Fave to offer consumers more digital and safer payment options. Starting from August, DBS PayLah! users can scan SGQR codes at Fave-partnered merchants to receive up to 20% cashback. Similarly, Singtel Dash users will receive up to 20% cashback from early September. Over 12,000 merchants, including food and beverage outlets, will accept QR payments. This collaboration aims to enhance convenience and cashback savings for millions of users, while providing merchants with access to payment reconciliation and customer insights.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 3.54 points or 0.1% to 2,545.62. Advancers outpaced decliners 82 to 48, driven by gains from ComfortDelGro, Wilmar International, and local lenders DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank. The US and European markets also continued their winning streak, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq posting record closes.

site_title: Wilmar, DBS ink agribusiness industry's first SORA loan
summary: Wilmar International has secured a S$200 million corporate loan pegged to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (SORA) from DBS, marking the agribusiness industry's first SORA loan. The loan's interest rate is a compounded daily SORA rate calculated in arrears and an applicable margin. DBS aims to facilitate the industry's transition towards adopting SORA as the new interest-rate benchmark for the Singapore dollar cash and derivatives markets, with the loan and interest-rate swap expected to promote greater adoption of risk-free rates.

site_title: South Korea's central bank holds rates, but cuts 2020 GDP forecast on coronavirus concerns
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, maintained its key policy rate at a record low 0.50% despite rising home prices. The decision came amid concerns about the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the economy. The bank also reduced its 2020 GDP forecast due to the pandemic's effects. The BOK is balancing the need for stimulus with the risk of encouraging more borrowing and fueling a home buying frenzy. The decision was expected by all 26 economists surveyed.

site_title: UK services firms report heavy job cuts as bleak autumn nears: CBI
summary: UK services firms reported heavy job cuts in the three months to August, with a record pace since May 2009. Companies reliant on consumer spending cut jobs at the fastest pace, citing uncertainty over the UK's post-Brexit trading relationship and the end of the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme. The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) urged the government to take bold action to protect jobs, warning that unemployment is expected to almost double to 7.5% by the end of 2020.

site_title: Sheng Siong outlet at Elias Mall, Our Tampines Hub among new places visited by infectious Covid-19 patients
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health (MOH) has added Sheng Siong supermarkets at Elias Mall and Our Tampines Hub to the list of places visited by Covid-19 patients while they were infectious. The list aims to monitor the health of those who visited these places from a specific date for two weeks. The MOH assures that close contacts have been notified and that the places have been cleaned if necessary, making it unnecessary for people to avoid these locations. The full list can be found on the MOH's website.

images.alt_text: There were 77 new coronavirus cases confirmed as at Thursday noon, taking Singapore's total to 56,572.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens flat on Thursday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened flat on Thursday, 0.02% higher at 23,295.13, amid cautious trade ahead of the Jackson Hole conference. The broader Topix index fell 0.12% to 1,622.55. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. Meanwhile, the US stock market edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: US to spend US$625m on super-computing research centres
summary: The US Department of Energy announced a $625 million investment over five years to establish a dozen research institutes focused on artificial intelligence and quantum computing. The funding, combined with $340 million from private sector and academic institutions, brings the total investment close to $1 billion. The research centers aim to advance the development of AI and quantum computing technologies.

site_title: Afterpay adds Asia to expansion plans as annual loss halves, sales jump
summary: Afterpay, an Australian buy now, pay later service, has announced plans to expand into Asia and Canada, following a strong quarterly performance. The company's annual loss more than halved to A$22.9 million, while sales jumped to A$11.10 billion, with underlying sales doubling in the US, where the company has seen rapid growth. Afterpay's shares rose 6% before reversing to be 5% down, and the company plans to acquire a Singapore-based BNPL operator to drive expansion into Asia.

site_title: South Korea urges work from home as country reports most daily cases since March
summary: South Korea reported 441 new coronavirus cases, the highest daily number since March, prompting the government to urge businesses to have employees work from home. Health Minister Park Neung-hoo warned about the risk of new clusters in densely-populated workspaces, such as call centres and logistics warehouses. The surge is attributed to recent outbreaks in a church and an anti-government rally. The country has seen 18,706 infections and 313 deaths, with the majority linked to the Seoul metropolitan area. The government is considering imposing the highest level of social distancing measures.

site_title: Pandemic may push Japan banks' credit costs to crisis levels: BOJ's Suzuki
summary: Bank of Japan board member Hitoshi Suzuki warns that Japan's financial institutions may see credit costs balloon to crisis levels due to a potential resurgence of coronavirus infections. The BOJ's massive stimulus program has so far cushioned the economic blow, but the strain on financial institutions could intensify as they respond to government requests to boost lending to firms hit by Covid-19. Suzuki notes that the benefits of ultra-loose policy still outweigh the costs, but the ultra-low interest rates may pose a challenge for financial institutions.

site_title: Australia: Shares advance as new coronavirus cases ease
summary: Australian shares rose on Thursday, driven by a record-setting rally on Wall Street and easing new coronavirus cases in the southeastern state of Victoria. The state reported 23 deaths and 113 new cases, its lowest daily rise in nearly two months, following strict lockdown measures. This lifted sentiment, contributing to the gains in the Australian market.

site_title: Asia: Markets hurt by fresh tensions, eyes on Powell speech
summary: Asia markets fell on Thursday ahead of Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's key policy speech, amid fresh tensions between the US and China. Beijing fired four ballistic missiles into the South China Sea, and the US sanctioned Chinese firms linked to the disputed region. Despite a fourth successive record on Wall Street, the mood in Asia was downbeat due to concerns over the virus and China-US tensions. Markets in Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Singapore dropped, while Shanghai and Seoul eased slightly.

images.alt_text: Most markets fell on Thursday ahead of a key policy speech by Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell, while geopolitical concerns returned after Beijing fired missiles into the South China Sea and the US sanctioned several Chinese firms linked to the disputed region.

site_title: Singapore expat jobs under threat in recession, local hire push
summary: Singapore faces a growing challenge as a magnet for global talent due to its worst recession in history, forcing some firms to rethink expansion and hiring plans. Barriers to entry for expats, such as soaring unemployment and anti-foreigner rhetoric, are mounting. An experienced nurse from New Zealand has struggled to secure a work pass after 11 months of failed applications, highlighting the difficulties faced by expats. This trend is expected to impact the city's reputation as a desirable destination for Western expats.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end higher on tech boost, stimulus hopes
summary: European stocks rose 0.9% on Wednesday, driven by tech shares and hopes for additional stimulus in Germany and France. Germany agreed to extend economic measures at a cost of up to 10 billion euros, while France is set to present its recovery plan on September 3. Despite concerns over rising Covid-19 cases, investors remain optimistic, citing the coordinated EU response and the potential for a US economic recovery.

site_title: China calls for talks with US on spat over stock listings
summary: China has called for direct talks with the US to resolve a long-standing dispute over stock listings, amid a push by US regulators to gain access to audit working papers for Chinese companies trading in the US. China has made concessions, proposing to allow US regulators to audit some of its most sensitive companies. The standoff has deteriorated since 2017, threatening global markets and potentially leading to the delisting of shares from companies like Alibaba Group Holding and Baidu. China is "sincere" in wanting to solve the issue, according to vice-chairman Fang Xinghai.

site_title: Raffles Education says no merit to tycoon's EGM request; posts S$16.4m FY loss
summary: Raffles Education Corp's board of directors will not convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to vote on tycoon Oei Hong Leong's proposed resolutions to remove founder Chew Hua Seng as chairman and CEO. The board obtained legal advice, which deemed the request as having no merit due to the proposed resolutions falling outside the shareholders' province. The company reported a net loss of S$16.4 million for FY20, citing a challenging global education environment and COVID-19 pandemic impact.

site_title: Alibaba puts India investment plan on hold amid China tensions: sources
summary: Alibaba Group has put on hold plans to invest in Indian companies due to souring business relations and rising tensions between China and India. The investment freeze will last for at least six months, but there are no plans to reduce stakes or exit existing investments. This decision comes amid a clash on their Himalayan border and follows Alibaba's fueling of growth for several Indian startups.

site_title: US: Wall Street forges onward as oil producers brace for hurricane
summary: Major US Wall Street indices reached new records on Wednesday, driven by strong earnings reports and a stock split announcement from Apple, despite concerns over Hurricane Laura's impact on the US oil-producing region. Oil prices surged, testing five-month highs, but traders elsewhere in New York remained optimistic. The Dow finished up 0.3% despite weak opening momentum, while coronavirus fears persisted in Europe, where several countries are seeing a strong rise in Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Federal Reserve official warns of 'uncertain' US recovery
summary: Federal Reserve official Michelle Bowman warns that the US recovery from the coronavirus economic downturn is "highly uncertain" and many businesses will continue to struggle. The economy is still far from normal, with the future course and timing of the recovery uncertain. Unemployment, currently at 10.2%, could spike further when government aid expires, and many businesses will fight for survival in the months ahead. Despite this, Bowman remains optimistic about the country's economic fundamentals and the resilience of the American people.

site_title: Argentina opens talks with IMF over rescheduling debt
summary: Argentina has begun talks with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to agree on new terms for repaying a $57 billion bailout agreed in 2018. President Alberto Fernandez and Economy Minister Martin Guzman spoke with IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva to negotiate a new understanding. Argentina put repayments on hold and renounced outstanding tranches of the bailout, citing the need to "sort out the disorder" inherited from the previous government. The country aims to restructure a $66 billion debt with creditor groups and has already put its accounts in order with international creditors.

site_title: Singapore, Thailand to expedite green lane talks
summary: Singapore and Thailand will expedite discussions on a reciprocal green-lane agreement for essential business travel, with public health safeguards. The agreement aims to strengthen supply chains and connectivity networks. Meanwhile, border measures are being tightened for travelers arriving in Singapore from South Korea, with a 14-day stay-home notice requirement starting August 29. The move is in response to a resurgence of cases in South Korea. The talks with Thailand and ongoing discussions with Indonesia aim to deepen regional economic integration and strengthen bilateral relations.

site_title: Virus-hit Air New Zealand posts NZ$454m million loss
summary: Air New Zealand reported a NZ$454 million annual net loss due to the coronavirus pandemic, with passenger revenues plummeting 74% in the final quarter. The airline secured additional liquidity and reduced its cost base, but expects to make a loss in 2021. The airline's cash burn averaged NZ$175 million a month from April to June, with efforts underway to reduce this figure. At least one-third of Air New Zealand's 12,500 workforce is expected to lose their jobs due to pandemic-related cutbacks.

site_title: EU trade chief Hogan quits over Ireland Covid-19 'golfgate' controversy
summary: EU Trade Commissioner Phil Hogan resigned on Wednesday amid controversy over his breach of Covid-19 guidelines during a trip to Ireland. Hogan cited the distraction from his work as the reason for his departure, despite Irish officials stating he broke rules. His departure will be a blow to EU credibility, particularly in key recovery talks and trade negotiations with the US. Hogan had been considered for the director-general of the World Trade Organization before his resignation, which he called the end of his "political chapter."

images.alt_text: Phil Hogan quit as the EU's Trade Commissioner on Wednesday after days of pressure over allegations he breached Covid-19 guidelines during a trip to his native Ireland, saying it had become clear the controversy was a distraction from his work.

site_title: Women may mount stronger Covid-19 immune response
summary: A new study found that women tend to mount a stronger immune response to COVID-19, with women producing more robust T lymphocyte responses and lower levels of inflammatory cytokines, which can contribute to severe cases. In contrast, older men showed weaker T cell activity and higher cytokine levels, increasing their risk of severe illness. The study suggests that treatments may need to be tailored differently for men and women, with vaccines enhancing T cell responses for men and treatments dampening cytokine responses for women.

images.alt_text: A new study looking at male and female immune responses to the new coronavirus may shed new light on why men are more likely to become seriously ill with Covid-19, researchers said Wednesday.

site_title: Hurricane Laura takes aim at US Gulf Coast, armed with 'unsurvivable storm surge'
summary: Hurricane Laura, a Category 4 storm, is expected to bring catastrophic damage and "unsurvivable storm surge" to the US Gulf Coast, particularly Texas and Louisiana. With maximum sustained winds of 240 km/h, Laura is forecast to cause widespread flooding, tornadoes, and power outages. Mandatory evacuations have been ordered for over 620,000 people, and emergency teams are being positioned. The storm surge could reach 6m in parts of Louisiana, with temporary housing being set up outside the storm surge zone. Oil production in the Gulf of Mexico has been paralysed, and environmental concerns are raised about potential pollution and damage to the oil industry.

site_title: Hong Kong skyscrapers will scale new heights again
summary: Hong Kong's skyscrapers are expected to scale new heights again, with shares in developers Hongkong Land, Swire Properties, and Sun Hung Kai Properties partially recovering from the pandemic-induced trough. Commercial rents have slumped 11% year-over-year, but the city centre is expected to hold up, with vacancy rates reaching a 14-year high. Despite geopolitical tensions, working patterns and fresh demand from mainland China may contribute to a gradual rebound, with history suggesting that tower landlords can recover quickly from past crises.

site_title: Top European clubs circle as Messi calls time at Barcelona
summary: Lionel Messi has told Barcelona he wants to leave the club, sparking a potential legal battle over a buy-out clause worth hundreds of millions of dollars. The six-time Ballon d'Or winner, who has won four Champions League titles, has requested to terminate his contract "unilaterally" by triggering the release clause. Top European clubs such as Manchester City, Paris Saint-Germain, and Inter Milan are reportedly interested in signing Messi, who has a reported weekly salary of nearly one million euros.

site_title: Razer cuts H1 loss on record sales amid lockdowns
summary: Razer reported a narrower loss of $17.3 million for the first half of 2020, compared to a loss of $48.1 million the previous year, driven by record sales amid the COVID-19 lockdowns. Revenue rose 25.3% to $447.5 million, with the hardware segment contributing 85.5% of revenue. The company expects continued growth in the second half, driven by new products and the growing services segment.

site_title: Facebook says Apple mobile software will cut ad revenue
summary: Facebook reports that a forthcoming Apple mobile software update will significantly reduce ad revenue for developers relying on its in-app ad network. The update, iOS 14, requires apps to obtain user permission to collect and share device-identifying data, effectively limiting targeted advertising. Facebook's Audience Network platform, which relies on this data, saw revenue fall by more than half when personalization was thwarted. As a result, Facebook plans to reassess its strategy to support publishers affected by the changes.

site_title: More than 6,300 jobs and openings for training and attachments in manufacturing
summary: Nearly 1,000 Singaporean manufacturing firms are offering over 6,300 jobs, traineeships, attachments, and training opportunities through the SGUnited Jobs and Skills programme. The majority of these opportunities are for Professionals, Managers, Executives, and Technicians (PMETs). This move aims to support the sector despite the current crisis.

images.alt_text: From right: Manpower Minister Josephine Teo, Communications and Information Minister S Iswaran and Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing being shown Becton Dickinson's Sars CoV-2 test device at the company.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Tan Chong, Silverlake, Straits Trading, Yunnan Energy, Raffles Edu
summary: Tan Chong International reported a HK$75.3 million (S$13.3 million) loss for its first half, while Silverlake Axis' net profit fell 12% to RM59.1 million (S$19.4 million) for its fourth quarter. Straits Trading acquired a UK business park for £76.7 million (S$137.9 million), while Yunnan Energy narrowed its loss to HK$7.07 million (S$1.2 million) for the six months ended June 30. Raffles Education Corp reported a full-year net loss of S$16.4 million.

site_title: Melania Trump ends night of rancour with note of empathy on virus
summary: Melania Trump delivered a speech at the Republican convention, shifting from the party's incendiary tone to focus on the toll of the coronavirus pandemic and national unity. She acknowledged over 178,000 American deaths and called for national unity, a departure from her husband's handling of the virus. The speech was seen as an attempt to soften her husband's image and shore up weaknesses among crucial voting groups. Melania also acknowledged racial unrest and called for the nation to come together, while emphasizing her husband's commitment to the country's safety.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Tan Chong International reported a loss of HK$75.3 million for the first half of its financial year due to Covid-19 measures affecting its business. Revenue decreased 16% to HK$5.78 million, resulting in a loss per share of HK$0.04. An interim dividend of HK$0.01 per share was declared. Meanwhile, Straits Trading Company acquired a UK business park for £76.7 million.

site_title: Service Properties to end management deal with InterContinental Hotels over missed payments
summary: Service Properties Trust will terminate its management agreement with InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG) for 103 hotels due to missed payments. The agreement, set to end on November 30, will see the branding and management transferred to Sonesta International Hotels Corp. The portfolio includes 81 extended-stay and 22 full-service hotels in the US, Canada, and Puerto Rico. IHG cited its commitment to financial stability and reduced costs, while Service Properties cited failed payments of $26.4 million and a 65% decline in the company's shares in 2020.

site_title: The art of surviving a pandemic
summary: Singapore's commercial art galleries face a significant decline in business, with some experiencing a 90% drop in sales. The industry is bracing for the worst as economic sentiment remains poor. Meanwhile, a local dad has designed his family home with a whimsical, bubblegum pink theme, and skincare has become a priority for many, with beauty experts debunking common myths.

site_title: Melania Trump's not-so-secret weapon: compassion over combat
summary: US First Lady Melania Trump delivered a highly anticipated speech, garnering widespread praise for her compassionate tone on Covid-19, racial tensions, and opioid abuse. The speech marked a departure from her husband's aggressive approach, with Melania expressing sympathy for those suffering and acknowledging the nation's mistakes. Her words were seen as a personal attempt to connect with voters and appeal for her husband's re-election bid without alienating the opposition. The speech was her own words, delivered without professional speechwriters, and analysts praised her for showing empathy and sympathy for the country's struggles.

site_title: Deserted, New York subway threatens drastic cut in services
summary: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) in New York warned it will significantly cut subway services if it doesn't receive $12 billion in federal aid due to a severe decline in ridership caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The MTA is considering reducing services by 40% if aid is not received. Chairman Patrick Foye stated that the decline in ridership is unprecedented, even during the Great Depression.

site_title: China's Perfect Diary gives cosmetics world a makeover
summary: China's Perfect Diary, a cosmetics giant, is set to launch a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) after driving into South-east Asia and targeting millennials. The company, which has 4% of China's colour cosmetics market, has a valuation of around $4 billion and plans to raise up to $500 million in its IPO. Perfect Diary's rise has been fueled by low prices, social media platforms, and charismatic influencers, with a focus on younger, Generation Z consumers.

site_title: New schemes to boost investment and support local entrepreneurship
summary: Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing outlined plans to boost investment and support local entrepreneurship in Singapore, amid the uneven impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on different sectors. The government will focus on sectors such as biomedical sciences, electronics, and digital economy, which still see growth opportunities. To support these sectors, the government will help companies invest and expand, generate business for other companies, and create good jobs for Singaporeans. The government will also assist companies in sectors that have permanently changed due to Covid-19, such as mass-market tourism and social entertainment.

site_title: US durable goods orders unexpectedly accelerate on auto demand
summary: US durable goods orders unexpectedly accelerated in July, rising 11.2% from the prior month, driven by a surge in automobile demand. This exceeded the median estimate of a 4.8% gain. Core capital goods orders, a barometer of business investment, also rose 1.9%, slightly more than forecast. The increase indicates factories will support the economic rebound in coming months.

site_title: Salesforce Q2 results up on revived software demand; boosts projections
summary: Salesforce reported Q2 revenue of $5.15 billion, exceeding analysts' estimates by 29% and boosting full-year projections to $20.8 billion. The company's sales and profit before certain items rose 29% and 44%, respectively. Salesforce's growth was driven by corporate customers upgrading technology systems to bolster their businesses during the pandemic. The company also announced plans for its third-quarter revenue of $5.25 billion and highlighted its recent acquisitions, such as Tableau, as key contributors to its growth.

site_title: Chinese demand for HK property climbs
summary: Mainland Chinese developers have won six of 13 government land tenders in Hong Kong since July last year, accounting for about 60% of the total spent on parcels. Chinese investors also dominated cross-border property deals, and state-owned companies are providing support for Hong Kong's financial hub. This influx of investment is seen as a vote of confidence in the city despite growing concerns over diminishing freedom and a lacklustre economy. China's resilient economy and cross-border financial initiatives are cited as drivers of demand in Hong Kong's leasing and investment markets.

site_title: US commercial mortgage debt in distress surges 320%: Moody's
summary: US commercial mortgage debt in distress has surged 320% since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, with $54.3 billion transferred to loan workout specialists. Hotel and retail properties, hit by travel restrictions, account for the majority of the transferred debt. This represents a significant increase from the start of the pandemic, highlighting the sector's vulnerability to economic disruptions.

site_title: Silverlake Axis Q4 net profit down 12% to RM59.1m
summary: Silverlake Axis reported a 12% decline in Q4 net profit to RM59.1 million (S$19.4 million) due to the Covid-19 pandemic affecting deal closures. Revenue fell 17% to RM156.8 million. The firm secured new contracts but faced challenges in closing large deals. A final dividend of 0.33 Singapore cents per share is proposed, down from 0.7 cents in the previous year. Full-year profit fell 25% to RM184.7 million, with revenue down 3% to RM663.7 million.

site_title: Oil steadies; virus concerns weigh as hurricane heads to US
summary: Oil prices steadied on Wednesday as U.S. producers shut output in the Gulf of Mexico ahead of Hurricane Laura, despite renewed concerns about the coronavirus pandemic. Brent crude fell 22 cents to $45.64 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 4 cents to $43.39 a barrel, settling at a five-month high on Tuesday. The pandemic worries were dampened by the shutdowns, which are expected to impact demand outlook.

site_title: Salary criteria for Employment and S Pass holders to be raised: MOM
summary: Singapore's government plans to raise the salary criteria for Employment Pass (EP) and S Pass holders, reflecting the changed labor market conditions due to the COVID-19 pandemic and economic disruption. The adjustments will support economic growth and create jobs for Singaporeans. The minister emphasized the importance of fair treatment for Singaporeans, achieving greater diversity in the workforce, and investing in developing a strong Singaporean core. The government will also closely examine retrenchment exercises and require businesses to invest in developing their local workforce.

images.alt_text: Manpower Minister Josephine Teo says that even as Singapore continues to stay open to the world to accelerate the country's recovery, the crisis makes it "all the more important" that employers give fair treatment to Singaporeans.

site_title: 'Fortnite' maker Epic Games will keep in-app payment feature on Apple devices
summary: Epic Games, the maker of Fortnite, has decided not to remove its in-app payment feature on Apple devices, despite a court order to comply with Apple's 15-30% commission rate. The decision was made after a federal judge blocked Apple from shutting down Unreal Engine, a software tool used by hundreds of other app makers. This move keeps Fortnite from being updated on Apple devices and blocks the distribution of Unreal Engine, which was previously affected by Apple's decision. Epic Games has chosen to comply with Apple's terms instead.

site_title: Bank Indonesia to also manage country's growth and employment
summary: Indonesia plans to consolidate its financial regulatory structure by placing the central bank, Bank Indonesia (BI), in charge of managing economic growth and employment. This move aims to unify macro and micro monitoring of the financial system under one authority. Currently, the Financial Services Authority (OJK) oversees the banking industry, while BI manages the value of the rupiah through inflation and exchange-rate management. The plan is part of efforts to support economic recovery and close the gap between the authority of the central bank and OJK.

site_title: US housing regulator postpones new mortgage refinancing fee
summary: The US housing regulator, Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA), has postponed a new mortgage refinancing fee, originally set for September 1, until December 1. The 0.5% fee was intended to recoup potential losses of billions of dollars due to the coronavirus pandemic. The fee will not apply to mortgages worth less than $125,000. The delay may give Congress time to explore alternative solutions to boost Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac's finances.

site_title: Equinor to cut jobs in US, Canada and UK amid oil price fall
summary: Norwegian oil and gas firm Equinor plans to cut 20% of its US, Canada, and UK employees and 50% of contractors to adjust to the falling oil prices. The company will also stop drilling new unconventional wells in the US. This move aims to ensure the company's profitability in a lower price scenario.

site_title: Australian banks use bloated cash balances to reduce debt
summary: Australian banks are taking advantage of the pandemic-driven surge in deposits to repay debt, reducing their funding costs. Deposits grew 12% to A$2.29 trillion, while loans only increased 3%, creating excess liquidity. The big four banks have repaid A$95 billion of costly term debt and accumulated A$145 billion of excess deposits. This has led to lower funding costs, with banks only needing to offer half of their historical spread to issue debt. The low funding rates and excess liquidity are a net negative for banks, as they are not earning much from the cash.

site_title: American Air sees 19,000 job cuts once US payroll aid ends
summary: American Airlines plans to cut 19,000 workers, including 17,500 furloughed employees and 1,500 management staff cuts, once federal payroll aid expires on October 1. The airline will reduce its workforce by 30% since the pandemic, with long-haul international flights expected to operate at 25% of 2019 levels. The cuts are part of a broader industry trend, with thousands more job losses at US airlines expected after the September 30 expiration of payroll support. Analysts predict a long recovery for the airline industry, with some estimating it could take three to seven years to return to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Teva's US unit charged with generic-drug price-fixing
summary: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, the world's largest generic-drug maker, has been charged by the US Justice Department with conspiring to raise prices for generic drugs from May 2013 to December 2015. The indictment alleges Teva colluded with competitors to increase prices for medications treating various conditions. The company has rejected the allegations and refused to settle, instead opting to fight the charges. This is the most significant case to come out of a years-long investigation into price-fixing by pharmaceutical companies.

site_title: SGX RegCo open to virtual general meeting platforms
summary: SGX RegCo is open to allowing virtual general meeting platforms that support live voting and live questions, replacing physical meetings. These platforms must ensure the identities of attendees and voters, as well as the accuracy of votes cast. This move comes after past shareholder resistance to virtual meetings.

images.alt_text: CEO Tan Boon Gin says SGX RegCo has been navigating its way based on three principles: listening to the market, shaping the right culture and raising standards across the entire market community.

site_title: Q3 factory output off to rocky start
summary: Singapore's third-quarter economic showing is off to a rocky start, with the manufacturing sector experiencing a worse-than-expected year-on-year drop in factory output in July, falling 8.4%. However, growth rates suggest stabilization in the sector, and analysts expect manufacturing to continue driving the economy, with flat or small positive growth for the full three months, driven by a lower base for electronics in August and September.

site_title: Making Singapore sustainable
summary: Singapore is taking steps to make the city-state sustainable, with companies and government agencies recognizing the importance of reducing waste and mitigating environmental impact. Local companies like Xylem are using technology to improve water security, while the Building and Construction Authority is promoting efficient construction methods to reduce waste. The government has also launched initiatives such as the Zero Capital Partnership scheme to help building owners implement energy-efficient retrofit projects. Additionally, companies like Boxgreen are adopting sustainable practices, such as reducing food waste and using recyclable packaging.

site_title: Forex markets in subdued mood ahead of Fed speech
summary: The US dollar and euro traded cautiously ahead of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's speech at the Jackson Hole retreat, with investors speculating about a possible new policy stance towards inflation. Powell's announcement could lead to lower interest rates, benefiting the US dollar, but also fueling speculation about a potential rebound. The US dollar index rose 0.1% to 93.11, while the euro declined 0.4% to US$1.1818. The yuan reached a seven-month high against the US dollar, and the British pound rose 0.7% to US$1.3135.

site_title: Are we all Keynesians now?
summary: The global economy has shifted towards increased state intervention in times of crisis, with governments acting as insurers of last resort to provide social insurance against shocks. This is particularly true for aggregate shocks, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, where private insurance markets fail to provide adequate support. Governments have spent trillions of dollars in response to the pandemic, with rich countries able to borrow at low interest rates. However, emerging and developing countries face challenges in mobilizing resources to fill the gap in social insurance systems, and there are concerns about intergenerational equity and the long-term sustainability of government debt.

site_title: STI falls 0.66% to 2,542.08 amid grim economic data
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.66% to 2,542.08, snapping a three-session rally, amid grim economic data. Industrial production in July decreased 8.4% year-over-year, worse than June's 6.5% fall. Economists expect a sequential recovery in the second half, but forecast a 5.3% contraction in GDP. Advancers outpaced decliners 204 to 201, with ComfortDelGro gaining 2.1% and DBS analyst Yeo Kee Yan citing increased demand for transport as a beneficiary.

site_title: Analysts ditch AirAsia after record loss; AirAsia X does poorly
summary: AirAsia Group Bhd posted a record loss of RM992.9 million (S$326 million) for the quarter through June, prompting at least eight analysts to revise down their recommendations or price targets on the airline's shares. The airline's shares fell 2.8% to RM0.68, taking its loss for the year to 60%. AirAsia X Bhd, its long-haul unit, has also fared poorly, with analysts assigning sell or equivalent ratings to the airline and averaging a price target of RM0.56.

site_title: Bosses fear tighter rules for foreign hires may stunt growth, raise costs
summary: Singapore is tightening salary criteria for S Pass and Employment Pass (EP) holders to support local wages, but this move may impact costs, labour shortages, and the country's competitive edge. Economists believe the revised rules aim to support local wages, rather than drastically cut the foreign workforce. However, some business owners, such as those in the construction and ICT sectors, are concerned about the increased costs and potential labour shortages. The government has acknowledged trade-offs, but stresses that the revised criteria are meant to improve the quality of the workforce over time.

site_title: Cross-border data protection needs less formal, bottom-up approach
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has accelerated the need for cross-border data protection, but Asia's patchwork of different laws governing data collection, use, and transfer creates a fragmented landscape. Recent decisions, such as the European Court of Justice striking down the Privacy Shield, have major implications for policy and practice globally. The US has also taken action, with President Trump signing an executive order giving ByteDance 90 days to comply with US regulations, potentially leading to a patchwork of "digital fiefs." To address these challenges, international cooperation and collective action are needed, with a focus on less formal, bottom-up approaches to governance.

site_title: To deal with China, Trump should learn German
summary: US President-elect Joe Biden will face a more aggressive China, seeking to supplant American technology dominance and undermine democracy in Hong Kong. To counter this, Biden should learn from Trump's mistake of not building a partnership with Germany. The Cold War with China will be fought in Berlin, with Germany's influence in the European Union crucial in shaping global digital commerce rules. A US-China alliance with Germany's support could set the rules for global commerce in the 21st century.

site_title: Boeing, Transport Canada pilots to conduct 737 MAX flight test
summary: Boeing and Transport Canada pilots are conducting a 737 MAX flight test, marking a crucial step in the jetliner's path to resume commercial service after two fatal crashes. The test follows a similar evaluation by the US Federal Aviation Administration two months prior. This test aims to assess the safety upgrades implemented on the aircraft, paving the way for its potential return to service.

site_title: Should MAS, SGX RegCo weigh in on Sabana-ESR merger?
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) are being considered to weigh in on the proposed merger of Sabana Reit and ESR-Reit, both controlled by Hong Kong-listed ESR Cayman. Minority investors may face risks of being disadvantaged in these incestuous Reit mergers. The proposed deal would see holders of every 100 units of Sabana Reit receive 94 new units of ESR-Reit, resulting in a value loss of 6.5% for Sabana Reit unitholders. Regulators are debating whether to ban or regulate these mergers to mitigate risks.

site_title: Nervous investors want out as Lohs' Bellagraph controversy raises questions
summary: Nervous investors are pulling out millions of dollars invested in entities under Novena Global Healthcare Group, founded by Singapore's Loh cousins, amid controversy surrounding their £280 million bid for Newcastle United. The investors, including executives from a private equity firm, a technology company, and a former investment banker, have met with the Lohs to assure them of taking care of the matter. The group's bid has raised questions about their experience, expertise, and integrity, following a scandal involving doctored photographs of former US President Barack Obama and concerns over their financial dealings.

site_title: US: Nasdaq opens higher after Salesforce, HP Enterprise results
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq Composite gaining 50.15 points, or 0.44%, to 11,516.62, following upbeat business updates from Salesforce and HP Enterprise. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 9.44 points, or 0.03%, and the S&P 500 opened higher by 6.35 points, or 0.18%, despite the S&P 500 closing at a record high for three sessions in a row.

site_title: 18,000 jobs, skills training programmes in ICT sector available to Singaporeans: S Iswaran
summary: Singaporeans have access to 18,000 jobs and skills training opportunities in the ICT sector, including software engineer, system analyst, data scientist, and cyber security specialist positions. The government plans to create an additional 1,800 job opportunities in the sector within the next 12 months, as announced by Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran.

site_title: Banks in bonus balancing act as economies shrink but trading booms
summary: Major international banks may still pay out big bonuses to high-flyers despite the pandemic's impact on the global economy, as fears of losing talent to rivals during a trading boom outweigh concerns about a big compensation bill. A poll found 63% of financial firms have not made or considered changes to bonus structures, and some banks are reducing costs by waiving scheduled pay rises and taking voluntary salary cuts. However, some banks are planning for future payouts and may consider adapting their bonus models to keep costs in check.

site_title: US says China 'bullying' UK, cites HSBC Hong Kong-related accounts
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo criticized British bank HSBC for treating pro-democracy customers in Hong Kong unfairly, accusing China of "bullying" the UK. HSBC allegedly maintains accounts for sanctioned individuals while shutting those of freedom-seekers. Pompeo urged the British government to resist CCP influence and stand for freedom. The US is ready to help. Representatives for HSBC declined to comment.

site_title: New Zealand stock trading hit by second cyber attack
summary: New Zealand's stock exchange was halted for over three hours on Wednesday due to a cyber attack, the second incident in as many days. The NZX website and feed of company announcements were also disrupted, but have since been restored. The attack is considered "very serious" and "sophisticated" by experts, who warn of the potential for ongoing disruptions. The NZX has launched an investigation into the source of the issue, but no indication has been given as to who may have mounted the attack.

site_title: Singapore's financial sector still resilient despite Covid-19: Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam of Singapore stated that the country's financial sector remains resilient despite the Covid-19 pandemic, thanks to strong balance sheets, digitalization, and sound business continuity planning. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has taken an "accommodative monetary stance" to support the economy, and the sector is on track to meet its targets for growth and job creation. The government is also investing in research and innovation to strengthen Singapore's preparedness for future pandemics and grow capabilities in sustainable technologies.

site_title: Governor Carney to head green investments at Canadian asset manager Brookfield
summary: Former Bank of England Governor Mark Carney is joining Canadian asset manager Brookfield to head its green investment program. Carney, 55, will oversee environmental, social, and governance-focused investment strategies. His appointment comes as Canada's prime minister Justin Trudeau appointed his ally Chrystia Freeland as finance minister. Carney previously advised Trudeau on economic policy and served as a UN special envoy on climate change and finance. He emphasized the need for a net-zero economy and sees it as a major commercial opportunity. Brookfield manages around $550 billion of assets.

site_title: WEF postpones 2021 Davos summit due to pandemic
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) has postponed its 2021 Davos summit to early summer due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, citing safety concerns. The decision to reschedule the event, which had been scheduled for January, was made to reduce risks to participants. The WEF may also reconsider hosting the summit in the future, citing the urgent need for global leaders to come together to address the pandemic's economic impact. A digital "Davos Dialogues" event will take place in January instead.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.38 points to 1,549.58. Volume reached 12.121 billion lots worth RM6.184 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 705 to 424.

site_title: A legislative lifeline for distressed firms even beyond the pandemic
summary: Singapore has introduced a new omnibus statute combining personal bankruptcy, corporate insolvency, and debt restructuring rules into a single law, providing a legislative lifeline for pandemic-stricken businesses. The law aims to support hard-hit sectors such as travel, retail, and commodities, which are battling the economic fallout of the coronavirus. Despite the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act, which curbs creditors' rights, applications for compulsory liquidation have trebled, with 31 companies wound up in June alone. The new law is seen as a crucial support measure for struggling firms.

site_title: China to buy record amount of American soybeans in 2020
summary: China plans to buy a record 40 million tons of American soybeans in 2020, a 25% increase from 2017, as lower prices boost purchases under the phase-one trade deal. This would be around 10% more than the 2016 record. China's purchases are expected to rise in the second half, including from the US, but hitting the target may be challenging due to peak monthly loadings and potential Brazilian crop next year.

site_title: Straits Trading buys freehold business park in the UK for £76.7m
summary: Straits Trading Company has acquired a freehold business park in Addlestone, England, for £76.7 million (S$137.9 million). The acquisition includes six standalone office buildings with a total net lettable area of 182,364 square feet, currently 96% leased to multiple tenants. The deal is expected to provide a stable stream of income and potential value-add opportunities through refurbishment or redevelopment. The consideration will be satisfied by internal funds and bank borrowings.

site_title: Tan Chong logs H1 loss of HK$75.3m as Covid-19 measures curb operations
summary: Tan Chong International reported a loss of HK$75.3 million for the first half of its financial year, reversing the HK$97.1 million profit in the same period last year. Revenue declined 16% to HK$5.78 million due to Covid-19 measures curbing its business activities. The company expects a "gradual and intermittent recovery" in Singapore and Hong Kong, but notes the pandemic's impact on its year-end results will be material.
