Senior Minister of State for Transport and Foreign Affairs Chee Hong Tat emphasized the importance of talent in enabling Singapore to seize new opportunities in the reorganized global supply chains.

site_title: EU trade chief fights to keep job after 'Golfgate'
summary: EU Trade Commissioner Phil Hogan published a 1,400-word account of his visit to Ireland, amid a scandal over attending a golf society dinner during a coronavirus lockdown. Hogan acknowledged he should not have attended but claimed he adhered to COVID-19 rules. The fallout has led to resignations, including an Agriculture Minister. Hogan's job is at risk, and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen is assessing the situation, with the EU's top trade post being a challenging position to fill.

site_title: JTC launches Tampines North, Gul Circle industrial sites for tender
summary: JTC launches two industrial sites, Tampines North Drive 3 (Plot 2) and 160 Gul Circle, for tender. The sites, zoned for heavier industrial use, have a 20-year tenure and a 60-month project completion period. Tampines North Drive 3 (Plot 2) is the first of three confirmed list sites for the 2020 Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme, while 160 Gul Circle was made available through the reserve list system. Tenders for both sites close on October 20 and October 6, respectively, with minimum purchase prices set at S$2 million.

site_title: Mandatory conditional cash offer for Tee International closes with 24.66% valid acceptances
summary: Tramore Global's mandatory conditional cash offer for Tee International has closed with 24.66% valid acceptances. The offer price of 3.38 Singapore cents per share represented a 25.19% premium over the three-month VWAP and a 33.73% discount to the 12-month VWAP. After the close, Tramore Global's stake in Tee International rises to 66.69%. The company intends to continue Tee International's existing business and maintain its listing status following completion of the offer.

site_title: Amcorp gives notice of three years' of losses
summary: Amcorp Global, a Singapore-listed firm, has reported three consecutive years of losses based on its audited full-year consolidated accounts. The company's market capitalization fell below S$40 million, triggering a watch-list status on the Singapore Exchange. Trading in its shares has been suspended since March 18, after it lost its free float. Amcorp aims to restore its free float through a private placement by October 20.

site_title: US new home sales jump 13.9% in July
summary: US new home sales surged 13.9% in July, exceeding expectations, with an annual rate of 901,000 homes sold, 36% above July 2019. Low borrowing rates contributed to the increase. However, regional sales were uneven, with the Midwest seeing a 58.8% jump and the Northeast experiencing a 23.1% drop.

site_title: Credit Suisse may eliminate 500 Switzerland jobs in wider revamp
summary: Credit Suisse Group may cut up to 500 jobs in Switzerland as part of a wider revamp to save about 100 million francs annually starting in 2022. The bank will integrate the Neue Aargauer Bank unit and merge its advisory and trading businesses into a single division. Job cuts will primarily come from supporting functions and reduced bank branches. The bank plans to operate with 109 locations across Switzerland by the end of 2020, down from 146.

site_title: US bank profits down 70% from year before coronavirus uncertainty
summary: US bank profits declined 70% in the second quarter of 2020 due to economic uncertainty from the coronavirus pandemic. Despite small profits, banks built up cushions to guard against future losses and deposits rose by over $1 trillion for the second consecutive quarter. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported strong capital and liquidity levels, and banks reserved a 382% increase for potential credit losses. Economic activity grinding to a halt led to a 16% rise in loans over 90 days past due, primarily driven by mortgages and small business loans.

site_title: US: S&P 500 opens at record high on trade deal assurance
summary: US stocks opened at record highs on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 rising 4.67 points, or 0.14%, to 3,435.95. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also rose, while the Nasdaq Composite fell. The positive move was driven by reassurances from US-China officials on the Phase-1 trade deal and optimism over COVID-19 treatments and vaccines.

site_title: Fitbit unveils stress-tracking smartwatch with Google deal pending
summary: Fitbit unveiled a stress-tracking smartwatch, the Fitbit Sense, priced at $329, which measures electrodermal activity to detect stress levels. The device also includes a GPS sensor, phone-calling functionality, and a new stress score to help users decide on self-care actions. The Sense, Versa 3, and Inspire 2 activity tracker will ship in late September. Fitbit's pending sale to Google remains under review due to antitrust concerns, potentially delaying the deal to 2021.

images.alt_text: Fitbit on Tuesday unveiled a fitness tracker and two smartwatches, including one that purports to help monitor users' stress levels, as the company's pending sale to Alphabet's Google remains mired in antitrust reviews globally.

site_title: QT Vascular shares jump 112% as investors react to RTO news
summary: QT Vascular shares surged 112.5% to close at 1.7 Singapore cents after the company announced plans to acquire Tengri Coal and Energy for S$1 billion in cash and new shares, potentially leading to a reverse takeover and a mainboard listing. Investors welcomed the deal, with the counter being the most actively traded on the Singapore bourse for the day. The acquisition is expected to give the company "a new lease of life" and increase its market capitalisation.

site_title: American Airlines to cut 19,000 jobs when US aid expires in October
summary: American Airlines plans to cut 19,000 US jobs in October due to the expiration of US government aid for airline employee payrolls. The airline received $25 billion in stimulus funds in March, but talks for another $25 billion have stalled. The job cuts include 17,500 furloughs of union workers and 1,500 management positions. As a result, American's workforce will shrink to around 100,000 from 140,000 in March. The airline expects to fly less than 50% of its normal schedule in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Wirecard to cut 730 jobs as court starts insolvency process
summary: Wirecard, a German payments company, will cut approximately 730 jobs and make further "far-reaching cuts" amid insolvency proceedings initiated by a Munich court. The court appointed Michael Jaffe as permanent administrator, taking control from the current supervisory board. Wirecard's financial situation is considered "extremely difficult" due to a lack of liquidity and scandalous circumstances surrounding its accounting and business practices. The company has begun selling assets to pay creditors and has agreed to sell its Brazilian and UK businesses.

site_title: UK retailers cut jobs by most since 2009
summary: UK retailers have cut the most jobs since 2009, according to the Confederation of British Industry, amid tough trading conditions. The data also shows an unexpected drop in sales this month, contrasting with recent demand after the coronavirus lockdown. CBI economist Alpesh Paleja warned of an expected sharp rise in unemployment. The retail sector faces challenges, with job losses accelerating despite a recent pick-up in consumer demand.

site_title: Finnair to cut 1,000 jobs as pandemic rips through its business
summary: Finnair, Finland's national carrier, plans to cut 1,000 jobs (15% of workforce) and increase cost savings to 100 million euros due to the ongoing pandemic crisis. The airline aims to streamline operations, digitalize customer processes, and find savings in real estate and aircraft leasing. Traffic recovery is expected to take 2-3 years, and CEO Topi Manner stated that a rapid recovery is unlikely.

site_title: STI 0.8% higher following Wall Street gains; glove-maker stocks among biggest losers
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.8% on Tuesday, driven by a Wall Street rally and news of a newly-approved Covid-19 vaccine. Healthcare stocks declined, with glove makers Top Glove and UG Healthcare losing 8.22% and 10.16% respectively. Singapore Airlines was the top gainer, adding 3.26% to close at S$3.80. The Straits Times Index closed at 2,559.03, with DBS and OCBC banks also gaining.

site_title: Founder's legal case has no impact on company: Trek 2000
summary: Trek 2000 International, a Mainboard-listed firm, stated that founder Henn Tan's legal case has no impact on the company's operations and businesses. Tan stepped down as chairman emeritus in June and faces nine outstanding charges, but the charges are against him personally and do not involve the company. The company clarified that its current management team, in place since early 2018, has ensured continuity in business operations, providing assurance to shareholders and eliminating concerns.

site_title: Apple to open India online store in September
summary: Apple plans to launch an online store in India in September, ahead of the Diwali festive season. The move will allow the company to sell its products directly to consumers in the country, bypassing third-party vendors like Amazon and Flipkart. This is part of Apple's strategy to expand its presence in the Indian market, which is expected to be a significant growth area for the tech giant.

site_title: Malaysia's AirAsia posts loss as revenue tumbles, but business 'stabilised'
summary: Malaysia's budget airline AirAsia Group reported a fourth consecutive quarterly loss in the second quarter, with a net loss of 993 million ringgit due to a 96% drop in revenue. Despite the loss, AirAsia's president stated that the airline has stabilized its business and is maintaining sustainable operations through domestic services. Fares have improved, and the airline has pivoted to its digital business, with revenue on its e-commerce platform AirAsia.com up 137% on the year. The airline has sufficient working capital to sustain business operations.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 13.62 points lower to 1,554.96 on Tuesday, with a trading volume of 10.224 billion lots worth RM7.629 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 842 to 323.

site_title: Bellagraph pulls statement after Obama photo scandal; Axington shares fall again
summary: BELLAGRAPH Nova Group has withdrawn a press statement announcing the launch of its NETX division, citing a purported private meeting with former US President Barack Obama. The statement, which included a photo of Obama, was retracted after it was revealed that BN Group had doctoring the photo. The company's controlling shareholders, the Loh cousins, are also facing scrutiny over their involvement with Axington, a Catalist-listed firm. Axington's shares have fallen 13.6% after the news.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Tuesday, following a two-day rally, as a pledge by US and Chinese officials to press ahead with their trade agreement failed to inspire further gains. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.26% to 25,486.22, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.36% to 3,373.58.

site_title: Mirach Energy gets further and final extensions for FY2019 AGM, annual report
summary: Mirach Energy has received a final extension to publish its FY2019 annual report by September 4, subject to external auditor BDO finalizing the audit. This extension is to meet financial criteria requirements for removal from the watch-list. The company had previously had its AGM deadline extended from August 3.

site_title: Bright idea in Belgium: UV zappers to disinfect shopping carts
summary: Engineers in Belgium have developed a machine that uses ultraviolet light to sanitize shopping carts, reducing the need for manual disinfection. The UV zapper, costing 7,000 euros, works by bombarding trolleys with a powerful UVC light, killing or inactivating microorganisms. Three stores in Belgium are testing the technology, which could pay for itself within three months by reducing the need for staff to wipe down trolleys between customers.

site_title: Scoot: No data breach in e-mails mistakenly sent for Guangzhou flight
summary: Scoot has clarified that an e-mail meant for passengers booked on flight TR100 from Singapore to Guangzhou was mistakenly sent to other customers. The e-mail, sent on August 25, informed passengers about new travel requirements for the flight. Scoot's spokesperson stated that there was no data breach, but "many" individuals received the e-mail erroneously. The airline is investigating the matter and apologizes for the oversight, prioritizing rectification of the errors.

site_title: SGX to decide if Spackman divestment is an interested person transaction: sponsor
summary: SGX is set to determine if Spackman Entertainment's proposed divestment of an associate is an interested person transaction. The Singapore Exchange will consult with the company, RHT Capital, and Spackman Equities Group on the matter. Spackman Entertainment will sell its 43.88% stake to Spackman Equities Group at a minimum price of S$32 million. Corporate governance expert Mak Yuen Teen has raised concerns about the independence of shareholders due to confidentiality around share swaps and placements. The proposal is non-binding and may lead to a definitive agreement after consultation with SGX.

site_title: Tackle Covid-19 but keep long-term vision; 7,500 healthcare jobs till end-2021: MOH
summary: Singapore's healthcare sector will focus on long-term goals while tackling COVID-19, with 7,500 jobs and 1,600 traineeships offered until end-2021. The Ministry of Health aims to improve health and preventive care, enhance community-based services, and review healthcare affordability and subsidy frameworks. Amid the pandemic, the government will maintain adequate quarantine and community isolation capacity and deepen international cooperation. Long-term healthcare goals include expanding healthcare capacity, enhancing subsidies for vaccinations and healthy aging, and reviewing subsidy frameworks to ensure they remain adequate and directed at those who need it most.

site_title: Singapore, region must work towards post-virus 'win-win' growth: Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for post-pandemic "win-win" growth in the region, prioritizing ordinary people and small businesses. He stressed the potential for a more integrated Asian supply chain and markets that are open to the world. Tharman believes that investing in human capital and fostering trust among players is crucial for ordinary people to bounce back from the pandemic. Despite remote working, Singapore remains competitive due to its cost-effectiveness and trusted business environment.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health (MOH) has outlined a plan to tackle COVID-19, focusing on improving healthcare, community services, and affordability. Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for a "win-win" post-virus growth, prioritizing ordinary people and small businesses. Meanwhile, Sunpower secured a 76.8 million yuan waste-heat-to-power project, and Scoot clarified a data breach incident. The STI index rose 0.8% due to Wall Street gains, with glove-maker stocks among the biggest losers. The MOH also announced a partnership with the Singapore Business Federation to improve IP management.

site_title: 31 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore in five-month low; no community cases
summary: Singapore reported 31 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 56,435, the lowest daily figure in over five months. There were no community cases, with the last instance being last Thursday. This follows a period of sustained efforts to control the spread of the virus.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets extend gains at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Tuesday, building on the previous day's strong gains. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.7% to 6,145.45 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices jumped 1.0% and 0.8% respectively. The gains were driven by hopes for a coronavirus treatment and the ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Australian employment falls further, intensifying labour market stress
summary: Australian employment fell by 1% in August, intensifying labor market stress. Job prospects were particularly hard hit in Victoria, with payroll jobs declining 2.8% due to fresh coronavirus infections. The government predicts unemployment will reach 13% by the end of September, a 22-year high of 7.5% in July. This underlines deepening cracks in the labor market, with Victoria suffering its largest decline in employment since mid-March.

site_title: Delta set to furlough over 1,900 pilots in October
summary: Delta Air Lines plans to furlough 1,941 pilots in October due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and declining air travel demand. The airline cited being "simply overstaffed" and reduced the number of involuntary furloughs following retirement and voluntary departure programs. The Air Line Pilots Association is "extremely disappointed" in the decision, while US airlines are warning of tens of thousands of job losses once US government stimulus funds run out in September.

site_title: US dollar slips, trade-related currencies rise on successful US-China call
summary: The US dollar fell, while the Australian dollar and Chinese yuan rose after a successful phone call between US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He. The call reaffirmed investors' faith in the trade relationship between the two countries despite fraying diplomatic ties. This positive development has boosted investor confidence, leading to a rise in trade-related currencies.

site_title: Itochu aims to take FamilyMart private as tender offer succeeds
summary: Japan's second-largest convenience store operator FamilyMart Co will become a wholly owned subsidiary of top shareholder Itochu Corp after the trading house succeeded in its tender offer for the retailer's shares. Itochu's stake in FamilyMart will rise to 65.7% from 50%, allowing the trading company to begin delisting the convenience store operator from the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The deal comes as FamilyMart faces challenges, including a saturated market and the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on convenience store sales.

site_title: Singapore, Indonesia to open talks on reciprocal green lane for essential travel
summary: Singapore and Indonesia plan to discuss a "reciprocal green lane" for essential travel, aiming to gradually resume travel while prioritizing public health and safety. Indonesian Foreign Minister Retno Marsudi met with Singapore's Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan, agreeing to strengthen public health cooperation, enhance economic growth, and facilitate safe travel. The talks aim to establish a framework for essential travel between the two countries, paving the way for a more relaxed travel policy.

site_title: Norway in recession as second-quarter GDP falls at record pace
summary: Norway's economy contracted at the fastest pace ever recorded in the second quarter, with a 6.3% decline in mainland GDP from the preceding three months. This marks the deepest ever recorded decline and the second consecutive quarterly fall in GDP. The economy's performance was better than neighboring Finland's 3.2% decline and Sweden's 8.6% decline, but weaker than the eurozone's 12.1% decline. The government's efforts to contain the coronavirus pandemic led to the recession, with restrictions gradually being lifted to allow a partial rebound.

site_title: Starbucks Cafe's Covid outbreak spared employees who wore masks
summary: A COVID-19 outbreak at a Starbucks cafe in South Korea's Paju city resulted in 27 patrons testing positive after a woman with the virus visited the cafe on August 8. However, the four employees who wore masks escaped infection, highlighting the effectiveness of face masks in limiting transmission. This supports the use of face masks as a measure to combat the spread of COVID-19, according to health authorities and experts, including a pediatric infectious diseases physician.

site_title: Emirates and Etihad airlines ask crew to take more unpaid leave
summary: Middle East airlines Emirates and Etihad Airways have asked cabin crew to take voluntary unpaid leave due to the ongoing impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. Emirates crew are offered one to three months of unpaid leave from September 1 to November 30, while Etihad staff can take between 10 days to six months of unpaid leave from September 16. Both airlines have cut thousands of jobs and have been gradually resuming passenger services since June. The moves aim to manage staffing requirements and sustain the business amid significant losses, including Emirates' reported $758 million core operating loss in the first half of the year.

site_title: Aveva buys OSIsoft for US$5b as virus fuels software demand
summary: Aveva, a British industrial software group, has agreed to buy US rival OSIsoft for $5 billion, capitalizing on the growing demand for digital transformation during the coronavirus pandemic. OSIsoft's strong growth this year is attributed to the increasing need for efficiency, flexibility, sustainability, and resilience in industrial operations. The acquisition is seen as Aveva's move to capitalize on technological megatrends driving digital transformation in the industrial world.

site_title: Hong Kong to relax social distancing rules as virus cases drop
summary: Hong Kong will relax social distancing rules starting Friday, allowing evening dining at restaurants and outdoor exercise without masks, as Covid-19 cases in the city dwindle. Current measures, including limited restaurant seating and mask requirements, will remain in place until August 27. Despite the easing, some restrictions, such as mask mandates at beauty parlors, will remain. The government aims to strike a balance between easing restrictions and preventing community outbreaks, with a focus on testing and monitoring.

site_title: New CEO of US$1.2t sovereign investor drops hedge fund
summary: Norway's new CEO, Nicolai Tangen, has agreed to sever ties to his hedge fund, AKO Capital LLP, in a move to address concerns over potential conflicts of interest. Tangen will transfer his 43% stake and dividend rights in AKO to a charity and sell his personal holdings, including $763.5 million in AKO funds. The agreement, reached with Norges Bank, the sovereign wealth fund's manager, allows Tangen to start his new job on September 1, as planned. The move appears to satisfy demands from Norway's parliament and opposition parties, who had threatened to derail his appointment due to concerns over conflicts of interest and tax havens.

site_title: AstraZeneca starts trial of Covid-19 antibody treatment
summary: AstraZeneca has begun testing its antibody-based treatment, AZD7442, for Covid-19 prevention and treatment. The early-stage trial, involving up to 48 healthy participants, aims to evaluate the safety and tolerability of the treatment. If successful, AstraZeneca plans to proceed with larger trials to test AZD7442 as a preventative treatment and medicine for patients. The company's Covid-19 vaccine candidate is already among the most advanced, further indicating progress in finding medical solutions to the disease.

site_title: Gold's rally to give way to biggest jeweller share sale in India
summary: Kalyan Jewellers India plans to raise up to $322 million through its initial public offering (IPO), the largest by an Indian jeweller, despite tumbling demand for gold due to the coronavirus pandemic. The company, which has 107 stores in India and 30 showrooms in the Middle East, expects to benefit from the 30% jump in gold prices this year. Analysts say the IPO will sail through due to the limited options for investors in the Indian jewellery sector, which has a market share of less than 3% of the country's retail sector.

site_title: Australia's Blackmores nixes dividend, to cut 10% jobs as virus hits profit
summary: Australian vitamin maker Blackmores Ltd scrapped its final dividend and cut around 100 jobs due to a two-third drop in annual profit, primarily affected by the coronavirus outbreak in China, its largest overseas market. The company reported a net profit of A$18.1 million for the year ended June 30, down from A$53.5 million a year earlier. Blackmores will implement an organizational redesign to reinvest in high-growth markets across Asia, and plans to sell its whey protein-based products and divest its Global Therapeutics business.

site_title: IPOS, SBF tie up to help Singapore firms improve IP management
summary: The Intellectual Property Office of Singapore (IPOS) and the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) have partnered for the Workforce for IP-Savvy Enterprises (Wise) initiative to help Singapore firms improve IP management. The pilot programme aims to identify new business opportunities, acquire IP capabilities, and build human resources. It includes online IP courses, consultation sessions, and access to flagship events. Since April 2020, several companies have participated, and the programme will conclude in the third quarter of 2020. The partnership aims to raise awareness and knowledge of IP as a value-creator and provide training for Singapore firms.

site_title: Asana files for direct listing amid slew of software IPOs
summary: Asana, a corporate software maker co-founded by Facebook's Dustin Moskovitz, filed to go public via a direct listing, disclosing a net loss that has more than doubled year over year and growing revenue. The company reported a net loss of $36 million in the three months through April on revenue of $48 million. Asana has over 3.2 million activated accounts and 1.2 million paid users, and plans to list its shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

site_title: China Mengniu, Kirin scrap Australia deal over political tension
summary: China Mengniu Dairy Co has scrapped its plans to buy Kirin Holdings' Australian beverage unit due to likely regulatory approval issues amid strained diplomatic ties between Australia and China. The deal, worth 45.6 billion yen, was blocked by Australia's Treasurer Josh Frydenberg, citing national interest concerns. The collapse of the deal signals a reversal of sentiment from a year ago when Mengniu won approval to buy organic infant formula maker Bellamy's Australia. China's growing appetite for milk and increasing tensions with Australia may hinder future overseas acquisitions.

site_title: Taiwan says won't let China firms 'pull a fast one' to get into market
summary: Taiwan's Premier Su Tseng-chang stated that the country will not allow Chinese firms to bypass regulations by using indirect methods to operate in the Taiwanese market. The government plans to stop local sales of Chinese internet streaming services and has given e-commerce site Taobao Taiwan six months to re-register as a Chinese-backed company or leave the island. This move aims to uphold regulations and laws governing Taiwan's relations with China, which claims the democratic island as its own sovereign territory.

images.alt_text: Taiwan will not allow Chinese companies to "pull a fast one" by using indirect methods to bypass rules and regulations to operate in the island's market, Premier Su Tseng-chang said on Tuesday.

site_title: Virgin Australia creditors lose almost everything under Bain Capital
summary: Virgin Australia creditors will lose almost all their money under a $3.5 billion deal to sell the airline to Bain Capital. Unsecured creditors will receive between 9-13% return, while priority creditors and employees will be repaid in full. Shareholders, including Singapore Airlines and Etihad Airways, will receive nothing. The airline failed in April under $6.84 billion of debt due to coronavirus-related travel restrictions.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks see biggest gain in a month on trade hopes
summary: South Korean stocks closed 1.6% higher on Tuesday, their largest gain in nearly a month, following positive US-China trade talks and declining Covid-19 cases. The Kospi index rose 36.90 points, or 1.58%, to 2,366.73. Foreigners invested $128.04 million in shares on the main board. The Bank of Korea is expected to keep interest rates on hold, weighing concerns about rising household debt and property prices.

site_title: Cloud data firm Snowflake files for IPO showing revenue growth
summary: Snowflake, a cloud data platform valued at $12.4 billion, filed for an initial public offering (IPO) with disclosed revenue more than doubling year over year. The company listed a placeholder offering size of $100 million, which is expected to change. This filing follows other software companies, including Unity Software, Sumo Logic, and JFrog, also planning to go public.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks started the day with gains, driven by hopes for a virus vaccine and the ongoing US-China trade pact. The Hang Sang Index rose 0.14% to 25,586.99, while the Shanghai Composite Index increased 0.21% to 3,392.88. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares opened Tuesday morning with further gains, boosted by hopes for a virus vaccine and after Chinese and US officials agreed to push on with their trade pact signed earlier this year.

site_title: Alaska mine project hits roadblock on environmental concerns
summary: The US Army Corps of Engineers has blocked the Pebble mining project in Alaska, citing significant environmental degradation and adverse effects on the aquatic system and human environment. The project, proposed by Northern Dynasty Minerals Ltd, was met with opposition from conservationists, local activists, and prominent Republicans, including Donald Trump Jr. The decision reverses an administration's previous stance on allowing a review of the plan to proceed. The project's impact on the world's most productive salmon fishery in Bristol Bay is a major concern.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on trade talk optimism, virus treatment hopes
summary: Australian shares ended higher on Tuesday, boosted by optimism over Sino-US trade talks and positive COVID-19 treatment developments. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.5% to 6,161.4, while New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.6% to its highest close since February. Weak unemployment data and a second wave of virus infections in Victoria limited gains. Analysts noted the market is being propped up by stimulus and vaccine hopes, despite a struggling economy.

site_title: Jewellery firms in Malaysia soar 400% as retail chases gold rally
summary: Malaysian jewellery firms have seen a 400% surge in shares following a gold rally. The precious metal's record price, driven by inflation concerns and central bank easing, has led investors to seek alternative ways to play the market. Shares in Niche Capital Emas and Tomei Consolidated, two small-cap gold-related equities, have more than doubled in the past few weeks, taking advantage of the gold price rally. This trend is expected to continue as investors seek exposure to the gold market.

site_title: Ansell profit rises on pandemic-driven demand, expects strong annual earnings
summary: Ansell Ltd., an Australian company, reported a 43% increase in annual profit due to surge in demand for personal protective equipment and healthcare products during the COVID-19 pandemic. The company's global healthcare unit saw a 13% growth in sales, driven by increased demand for single-use protective products. Ansell expects higher earnings in fiscal 2021, with a midpoint of 8% growth, and plans to invest in capacity to meet the increased demand.

site_title: Facebook blocks group critical of Thai monarchy amid govt pressure
summary: Facebook has blocked a group with over 1 million members in Thailand that criticized the country's monarchy, amid government pressure. The "Royalist Marketplace" group, created by a self-exiled academic, was blocked due to its content deemed critical of the king. Facebook plans to challenge the government's demand. The move comes as Thailand experiences near-daily youth-led protests calling for reforms of the monarchy.

site_title: Foreign travellers from Brunei, New Zealand can apply for air travel pass from Sept 1: CAAS
summary: Foreign travellers from Brunei and New Zealand can apply for an air travel pass to enter Singapore on or after Sept 8. The pass allows visitors to be contacted for changes to health and border measures, and helps manage the number of incoming visitors. Applicants must have spent 14 consecutive days in Brunei or New Zealand, travel directly from these countries to Singapore, and undergo a Covid-19 test upon arrival. The pass can be applied for at no charge through the SafeTravel portal, with requirements including downloading the TraceTogether app and being responsible for medical bills if needed.

site_title: Japan firm to sell bonds with coupons linked to green goals
summary: A Japanese real estate developer, Hulic Co., plans to sell a 10-year sustainability-linked bond worth 10 billion yen, tied to its environmental targets. If it misses its green goals by 2025, the bond's coupon will increase by 10 basis points. The company aims to develop mega solar systems and a fire-resistant commercial facility using renewable energy and wood grown in Japan. This is the first sustainability-linked bond issued in Japan, following the International Capital Market Association's guidelines. Global sales of sustainable bonds have jumped 27% to $196 billion this year.

site_title: Gold rally sputters with bets on vaccine, economies denting ETFs
summary: Gold prices are losing steam as hopes for a coronavirus treatment and improving economies reduce the metal's appeal as a haven. The metal posted back-to-back weekly losses for the first time since June, with holdings of gold exchange-traded funds (ETFs) showing a four-session flat streak. This slowdown follows gold's surge to an all-time high two weeks ago. The decline is attributed to investors shifting focus to vaccine developments and economic recovery, which may reduce gold's value as a safe-haven asset.

site_title: JTC launches two sites at Tampines North, Gul Circle for tender
summary: JTC launches two land parcels for tender at Tampines North Drive 3 (Plot 2) and 160 Gul Circle. The 0.48-hectare plot at Tampines has a gross plot ratio of 2.5 and will close for tender on Oct 20, while the 0.37-hectare plot at 160 Gul Circle has a gross plot ratio of 1.4 and will close on Oct 6. Both sites are zoned Business 2 for heavier industrial use with a 20-year tenure, with a committed bid price of at least S$2 million.

site_title: CredoLab secures US$7m in Series A funding led by GBG
summary: CredoLab, a Singapore-based alternative credit scoring provider, secured US$7 million in Series A funding led by GBG. The funding will be used to enhance product features and strengthen its core scoring algorithm. CredoLab aims to expand its market reach in Asia, Latin America, and Africa, while consolidating its leadership in South-east Asia. The company has powered over US$2 billion in loans issued by 70 clients across 20 countries since its inception in 2016.

site_title: CEOs speed up digital push and downsize offices, KPMG survey shows
summary: Companies worldwide have accelerated their digital push and downsized offices since the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a KPMG survey. 80% of business leaders have expanded their digital operations, and 69% plan to reduce office space in the short term. The shift to remote work has increased the pool of job candidates by 73%, leading to teams with more global interaction. Talent risk has become the top concern for CEOs, followed by supply chain and environmental risks. CEOs are split on the global economy's three-year outlook, with 32% less confident and 32% more confident than initially.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at open tracking Wall Street gains; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to 2,548.39, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street due to optimism over a newly-approved coronavirus treatment. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, also gained, while Aspen Holdings and Avarga rose 13.4% and 12.8% respectively. The rally follows recent gains, with the STI having extended its 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Qantas to cut up to 2,500 jobs as it outsources ground handling
summary: Qantas plans to cut up to 2,500 jobs by outsourcing its Australian ground handling operations to reduce costs. The move is part of the airline's efforts to cope with a A$10 billion revenue hit due to the pandemic. The job cuts, on top of 6,000 previously announced, would account for nearly 30% of its pre-pandemic roles. Outsourcing is expected to save A$100 million in operating costs annually and avoid A$100 million in equipment investments over five years.

site_title: Asia-Pac fintech funding up 9% as investors set sights on S-E Asia, Australia: S&P
summary: Asia-Pacific fintech funding grew 9.1% in the second quarter to US$1.4 billion, driven by investments in Australia and South-east Asia. Indian fintechs, which accounted for 42.9% of the region's total investments in the first quarter, saw funding fall to US$339 million due to the Indian government's clampdown on foreign investments. In contrast, South-east Asian and Australian fintechs attracted US$455 million and US$371 million, respectively. Payment companies and digital lending firms were major draws for investors, with payment unicorn Airwallex raising US$160 million in a Series D round.

site_title: Partial Zoom outage is fixed after school disruptions in US
summary: A partial Zoom outage affected thousands of users in the US, causing disruptions to schools, businesses, and governments on the first day of classes. The outage, which lasted nearly four hours, prevented users from starting and joining meetings, and some users were unable to sign up for paid accounts or manage their service. Zoom attributed the issue to a "authentication problem" and resolved it by 12:40pm. The outage was particularly concerning for schools, which rely heavily on Zoom for online learning, and courts, which use Zoom for virtual proceedings.

images.alt_text: A widespread outage on the video call service Zoom caused problems for students, teachers and professors around the United States on Monday morning, the first day of classes for many schools and universities that are reopening online because of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Egypt's blossoming trade in fragrant jasmine flowers
summary: Egypt's Gharbiya region is the world's largest producer of jasmine flowers, accounting for over half of the global supply. The aromatic oils extracted from these flowers are used in perfumes and other fragrances. Over 50,000 people, mostly small-scale farmers, earn around $6.5 million annually from the jasmine trade. The flowers are harvested from June to November, typically at night when they are fully open, and are then processed into essential oils at factories like the Fakhry essential oils factory. Despite the economic benefits, many farmers struggle with low prices and back-breaking work.

site_title: Toronto seeks to save oak tree older than Canada
summary: Toronto is working to preserve a centuries-old Northern Red Oak tree, estimated to be around 300 years old, which sits on a residential property in the North York neighborhood. The city council voted in 2018 to buy the property and raze the house to turn the land into a small public park. However, the deal is conditional on private donations to cover half of the purchase price, which has slowed down fundraising efforts during the pandemic. As of mid-July, about 30% of the target $430,000 has been collected, and the city may need to consider alternative plans if the goal is not met.

images.alt_text: In the shadow of Canada's largest cluster of skyscrapers, Toronto is looking to preserve a majestic, centuries-old oak tree - but efforts have been complicated by the pandemic.

site_title: UK seeks to ban supermarkets selling goods from deforestation
summary: The UK government plans to ban supermarkets from selling beef, soy, and other commodities sourced from illegally deforested land. Companies will be required to demonstrate compliance with local environmental laws in their supply chains. Failure to comply will result in fines. The proposal is part of a consultation by the Department for Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) to improve the UK's land-use strategy, following recommendations from a panel of business leaders.

images.alt_text: British supermarkets will be banned from selling beef, soy and other key commodities sourced from illegally deforested land, under new government plans.

site_title: As convention opens, Trump sets tone by warning without evidence of 'rigged' vote
summary: US President Donald Trump warned Republicans that the November election could be "rigged" despite no evidence, sparking concerns about voter fraud. The Republican National Convention, held in Charlotte, North Carolina, began with Trump outlining his vision for the future. The convention comes as Trump trails Democratic candidate Joe Biden in national polls and faces challenges from within his own party, including investigations into his family business and the COVID-19 pandemic. Trump will accept his party's nomination on Thursday night before a crowd on the White House South Lawn.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GuocoLand, Axington, SATS, Aspen, SIA, Koufu
summary: Singapore stocks to watch: GuocoLand's net profit halves to S$114.1 million, Axington's chairman faces scandal, SATS swings into loss, Aspen's shares soar 80.5% on diversification plans, and Singapore Airlines' Scoot modifies aircraft to carry cargo. Koufu Group expands Supertea and R&B Tea brands to the Philippines, while Avarga explores paper manufacturing opportunities. Boustead Singapore bags A$30 million contract for geographic information systems technology.

site_title: South Korea closes most schools in Seoul area to battle resurgent coronavirus
summary: South Korea has closed most schools in the Seoul area and moved classes online until September 11 due to a resurgence in coronavirus cases, with 280 new cases reported as of Monday. The country's total cases are now 17,945 with 310 deaths. Health authorities have called on people to stay home and limit travel, citing the densely populated capital area as a key factor in the outbreak. The move comes after at least 150 students and 43 school staff tested positive in the greater Seoul area over the past two weeks.

site_title: Philippine lawmakers approve 165.5b peso pandemic relief bill
summary: The Philippines' House of Representatives approved a 165.5 billion-peso pandemic relief bill, providing subsidies to the unemployed, assistance to businesses, and loan repayment extension to borrowers. The measure, awaiting President Rodrigo Duterte's signature, will also allocate funds for emergency health workers and contact tracers. Approximately 40.5 billion pesos will go towards health programs, while 55 billion pesos will be used to boost government financial institutions. The bill aims to support the country's efforts to combat the largest coronavirus outbreak in South-east Asia.

site_title: Foxconn, other Asian firms consider Mexico factories as China risk
summary: Taiwan-based electronics manufacturers Foxconn and Pegatron are considering new factories in Mexico as a response to the US-China trade war and coronavirus pandemic. The plans, which could bring in billions of dollars in fresh investments, are seen as part of a broader shift of global supply chains away from China. Foxconn is reportedly planning to make Apple iPhones in Mexico, while Pegatron is in early discussions with lenders about an additional facility to assemble chips and other electronic components. Mexico's low wages, favorable geography, and trade deal with the US are attractive factors for the companies, despite concerns about the country's handling of the pandemic.

site_title: Nongfu seeks HK$8.35b in year's second biggest F&B IPO
summary: China's bottled water giant Nongfu Spring is seeking HK$8.35 billion (S$1.48 billion) in its Hong Kong IPO, the second-largest food and beverage IPO this year. The company will offer 388.2 million shares at HK$19.50 to HK$21.50 each, attracting five cornerstone investors. Nongfu plans to use proceeds for brand building, equipment purchase, and production facility construction. The IPO, valued at US$1.1 billion, is the second-largest F&B IPO after JDE Peet's's US$2.8 billion offering in May, with Yum China also set to list shares in Hong Kong later this year.

site_title: Avarga says it is exploring a listing of its paper manufacturing business
summary: AVARGA, a mainboard-listed company, is exploring opportunities for its paper manufacturing business, including expansion and/or potential listing. The move comes after a 33.1% jump in its shares due to an SGX query. Avarga cited strong earnings growth from its subsidiary Taiga Building Products and noted that companies in the building materials industry have performed well in the stock market. The company has confirmed its compliance with listing rules, but the terms of the potential paper business listing are still under consideration.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, extending rallies on Wall Street, following news of a newly approved coronavirus treatment. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.05% to 23,227.69, while the Topix index gained 1.07% to 1,624.25. This is the latest in a series of positive market moves, which have been driven by investor optimism and a decline in COVID-19 cases.

site_title: Fauci says rushing out a vaccine could jeopardise testing of others
summary: US infectious diseases expert Anthony Fauci warns that rushing out a COVID-19 vaccine without full testing could jeopardize the testing of other vaccines. Fauci stated that the FDA's guidance requires a demonstration of safety and effectiveness, and that premature approval could hinder the enrollment of participants in large-scale clinical trials. The concern comes as President Trump is under pressure to deliver a vaccine before November to boost his re-election bid, despite Fauci's warning that this approach could have a chilling effect on vaccine testing.

site_title: Exxon booted from Dow industrials in major embrace of technology
summary: Exxon Mobil, Pfizer, and Raytheon Technologies have been removed from the Dow Jones Industrial Average, marking a significant shift towards technology companies. Salesforce.com, Amgen, and Honeywell International will replace them, boosting the influence of tech giants. The move reflects the decline of commodity companies in the American economy and the dominance of technology companies in the stock market. The changes come as tech companies have come to dominate the market, with the Nasdaq 100 nearly 20% above its pre-pandemic all-time high.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 5.09 points, or 0.32%, to 1,563.49 at 9:15am on Tuesday, with 230.5 million lots traded worth RM104.1 million.

site_title: Alibaba's e-commerce site told to re-register or leave Taiwan
summary: Taiwan's investment commission has given Alibaba's e-commerce site Taobao six months to re-register as a Chinese investment or leave the island, amid growing political tension between China and Taiwan. Taobao Taiwan is operated by a British-registered company controlled by Alibaba, and the commission is concerned about information security due to user data being sent to China. The company has been fined T$410,000 and must decide whether to disinvest or rectify its investment.

site_title: Usain Bolt quarantines as he awaits result of coronavirus test
summary: Usain Bolt has quarantined himself after taking a coronavirus test, awaiting the results. The Olympic gold medalist, 34, has had no symptoms of the virus and is taking precautions to ensure safety. Bolt attended a surprise party on Friday, where attendees danced without wearing masks, although it's unclear if any others had tested positive. He will remain in quarantine until the test results are available.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB says worst could be over for SATS, upgrades to 'hold'
summary: CGS-CIMB has upgraded its call on SATS to "hold" from "reduce" with a target price of S$3.00, citing the worst being over for the ground handler and food solutions provider. The research team believes the company can be seen as a recovery play for long-term investors. SATS reported a loss of S$43.7 million for the first quarter, missing revenue and associate performance estimates. The analyst expects improving cargo volume and freight rates to positively impact the company's performance heading into peak season.

site_title: MAS expected to stand pat on Singapore dollar despite inflation slide
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is expected to maintain its currency policy settings unchanged at the next review in October despite core inflation touching a decade low in July. Core inflation fell to -0.4% in July, and analysts predict it will remain tepid, even negative, until the end of the year. The MAS will likely maintain the slope, width, and centre of the policy band for the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER), as fiscal policy is expected to remain the heavy-lifter in supporting the economy.

site_title: Rupiah diverging from Indonesia's bond market
summary: Indonesia's bond and currency markets are diverging, with the rupiah being the worst-performing Asian currency this quarter, while the country's benchmark sovereign bond outperforms peers. This divergence is due to the government's massive borrowings to fund pandemic-recovery stimulus, leading to reduced foreign ownership and increased domestic borrowing. Bank Indonesia's debt monetization efforts have also contributed to the shift, with offshore holdings of bonds dropping to 29% from 39% at the start of the year.

site_title: Sequoia-backed Snowflake tests IPO investor appetite with wider losses
summary: Snowflake, a cloud-based data warehouse firm backed by Sequoia, has published its financial statements, revealing a surge in revenue growth and huge losses. The company confidentially filed to go public earlier this year, with a valuation of over $12 billion. Its public listing is expected to mark another marquee public listing for a Silicon Valley startup, following Airbnb, Palantir, and DoorDash.

site_title: Oil prices rise as storms cut US production
summary: Oil prices rose due to storms cutting US production, with over 1 million barrels per day shut in the Gulf of Mexico. Brent crude rose 1.76% to $45.13 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.66% to $42.62 a barrel. The storms, Tropical Storms Marco and Laura, are expected to impact production and exports, with refiners idling plants as a precaution. This may lead to a shortage of supplies, supporting oil prices.

site_title: Europe: Stocks start the week strong on virus treatment hopes
summary: European stocks rose 1.6% on Monday, their best day in nearly two weeks, driven by hopes of progress in developing a Covid-19 treatment. The US health regulator authorized the use of blood plasma from recovered patients as a treatment, boosting shares of companies like Grifols and AstraZeneca. Oil and gas stocks also gained, while travel stocks declined due to concerns about a resurgence in virus cases. Despite UK government data showing a possible increase in the number of people infected by one Covid-19 patient, the market is optimistic about a better situation in terms of hospitalization and death rates.

site_title: Government open to ideas, ready for tough choices: Halimah
summary: Singapore's President Halimah Yacob emphasized the government's openness to constructive criticism and new ideas, while also acknowledging the need for tough decisions in the national interest. In her address to the opening of the 14th Parliament, she highlighted the government's focus on jobs, sharing growth benefits, strengthening national identity, and adapting to the evolving politics and Covid-19 crisis. She also called for a broad consensus on economic and social changes, national identity, and politics, and encouraged citizen initiatives and participation.

site_title: De Beers adjusting marketing strategy to revive diamond sales
summary: De Beers is adjusting its marketing strategy to revive diamond sales, following research in the 3 largest consumer markets. The company is surveying consumers during the Covid-19 crisis and planning for a pandemic-free world. The strategy aims to capitalize on the current uncertain market conditions, providing an education primer for other businesses.

site_title: Delta to furlough 1,941 pilots in October: memo
summary: Delta Air Lines plans to furlough 1,941 pilots in October due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and depressed air travel demand. The airline, citing being "overstaffed," is making the difficult decision to reduce its workforce. Delta had originally estimated a surplus of 2,558 pilots but reduced the number following voluntary departure programs. The airline expects to need 9,450 active pilots for the summer 2021 schedule, which is expected to be the peak flying period for the next 12-18 months.

site_title: Sunpower clinches 76.8m yuan waste-heat-to-power project
summary: SunPower Group secured a 76.8 million yuan (S$15.2 million) tender from Chongqing Iron & Steel Company to provide comprehensive turnkey services for waste-heat-to-power facilities. The project, valued at 76.8 million yuan, will improve operational efficiency and reduce emissions. Sunpower aims to invest 2.5 billion yuan in green investments by 2021, with the project expected to positively impact the company's financial performance for FY2020 and FY2021. The company's green investments business has "bounced back" after the coronavirus pandemic, with improved profitability in the first half of this year.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq close at new highs as Wall Street rides bull momentum
summary: US stocks reached new record highs on Monday as the S&P 500 and Nasdaq closed at fresh highs, driven by optimism over potential medical advances in the coronavirus pandemic. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.35% to 28,308.46, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq gained 1% and 0.6% respectively. The rally is attributed to new developments in the global fight against the pandemic, including the FDA's emergency authorization for plasma treatment and the Trump administration's consideration of fast-tracking an experimental vaccine.

site_title: Hong Kong buyers rush for UK properties after security law
summary: Hong Kong buyers are rushing to purchase UK properties due to concerns over the national security law and a weaker pound. The UK government's offer of a path to British citizenship for Hong Kong residents has sparked interest, while a stamp duty holiday for homes below £500,000 has also encouraged investment. Property agents report a surge in sales, with over 60 apartments sold in July alone, and a waiting list of clients due to a shortage of supply. The surge in interest has prompted UK developers to target Hong Kong for their first international launch.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Three Singapore-listed companies reported financial results: Ley Choon Group Holdings posted a net profit of S$7.6 million, up 131% from the previous year, while Tiong Woon Corporation saw a 6% increase in revenue and a 100% increase in net profit. GuocoLand reported a 50% decline in net profit due to the absence of fair-value gains, but proposed a 6-cent dividend. The companies' earnings and net tangible assets are not expected to be significantly impacted by the contracts secured by Ley Choon Group.

site_title: 'Unhinged' makes US$4m in encouraging US theatrical debut
summary: US movie thriller "Unhinged" starring Russell Crowe earned $4 million in its North American debut, a modest but encouraging start in the post-COVID-19 era. The film, released in 1,823 locations, showed consumers' willingness to return to theatres, but revenue will remain limited due to ongoing restrictions and limited locations. The debut is a far cry from pre-pandemic standards, but sets the stage for the upcoming release of "Tenet" on September 3.

site_title: SGX RegCo weighs in on Axington links to scandal-hit BN Group
summary: SGX RegCo has engaged Novus Corporate Finance, the continuing sponsor of Axington, over its assessment of chairman Shen Che, who is also a co-founder of scandal-hit BN Group. The group was embroiled in a scandal over doctoring photos of former US President Barack Obama for marketing purposes. Axington's shares fell 22% on Monday after SGX RegCo expressed concerns over Shen's suitability to sit on the board, citing recent developments.

site_title: University of Tokyo to sell first-of-its-kind bond in Japan
summary: The University of Tokyo is set to issue a 40-year bond worth 20 billion yen (S$259 million) in early October, making it the first of its kind in Japan. The move comes as demand for higher-education debt is increasing overseas amid falling interest rates. The bond is expected to be sold through Daiwa Securities Group Inc.

site_title: Far-sighted SMEs press on with expansion despite Covid-19
summary: Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, some Singapore SMEs are pursuing long-term expansion plans, aided by government support schemes and business advisers. King of Prawn Noodles, SIS Premium Meats, and JML Uniforms are opening new outlets and launching new business offerings to create additional revenue streams. These SMEs have carefully examined their options, weighed costs, and invested in infrastructure to ensure success. They are confident that investing in the right opportunities will pay off when the pandemic subsides, enabling them to emerge stronger and better prepared for the upswing.

site_title: Aspen hits record high amid proposed foray into glove making
summary: Aspen's shares surge 80.5% to a record high of 37 Singapore cents amid a proposed move into glove manufacturing, following a trading surge after its August 12 announcement. The company plans to diversify its property business to include manufacturing and distribution of rubber gloves. Analysts note that entering the glove manufacturing industry has high entry barriers, requiring certifications and investments in automation. Aspen plans to convene an extraordinary general meeting on the proposed diversification on September 18.

site_title: Singapore currency to stay strong until 2021 on broad USD weakness
summary: Singapore's currency, the Singapore dollar (SGD), is expected to continue strengthening until 2021 due to the broad weakness of the US dollar. The SGD has reached a high of S$1.3715 to the USD, with forecasts predicting it could reach S$1.35 by early next year. Experts attribute the strengthening to the USD's weakness, particularly against the Chinese yuan, and the Singapore government's swift use of its strong fiscal reserves to support the economy during the pandemic.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with key events including NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer being 9.8 times oversubscribed and OCBC's incoming CEO Tan Teck Long's background as a former DBS veteran. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss, while MAS and PBOC announced plans to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Why gold is surging and how US Fed can shift its trajectory
summary: The price of gold reached an all-time high of $2,000 per ounce, sparking renewed interest in the metal. Three factors contributing to the surge include the US Federal Reserve's easing of monetary policy, rising risk perceptions, and investors' desire for a safe-haven alternative to the dollar. The Fed's accommodative stance, low real interest rates, and depreciated dollar have created an environment conducive to gold prices. Additionally, the increasing eagerness to diversify holdings and concerns over US governance and the dollar's status as a safe-haven currency have also driven gold prices up.

site_title: US dollar falls, riskier currencies gain
summary: The US dollar fell 0.2% against the euro and other currencies, while riskier currencies like the Norwegian krone, British pound, and Aussie and Kiwi dollars rose. This comes after the US approved a Covid-19 treatment using blood plasma from recovered patients, ahead of the Republican National Convention. Analysts attribute the pickup in sentiment to short-term optimism, with many skeptical about the treatment's impact and expecting a vaccine by year-end. The dollar has lost 0.5% against the basket of currencies this month.

site_title: Apple judge 'inclined' to unblock Epic's Unreal Engine but not Fortnite
summary: US District Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers expressed her inclination not to order Apple to reinstate Fortnite, citing the dispute over the App Store's standard fee of up to 30% as not a "slam dunk" for either side. The judge appeared sympathetic to Epic Games' argument that Apple retaliated by cutting off access to Unreal Engine, a key graphics technology used by developers. The judge also noted that Apple's decision to block Unreal Engine "does to me look retaliatory". Epic's reputation is reportedly suffering due to the Fortnite ban, with over a billion iPhone and iPad customers affected.

images.alt_text: The judge hearing Apple's fight with Epic Games said she's "inclined" not to order the iPhone maker to reinstate the Fortnite app as the companies faced off in their first courtroom showdown.

site_title: Seasoned operators find ways to stay relevant
summary: Singaporean SMEs, such as CYC Made To Measure and Lam Soon Singapore, are adapting to the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, including reduced retail sales and disrupted supply chains. CYC, a 85-year-old clothing tailor, has shifted focus to producing reusable face masks and e-commerce, while Lam Soon, a consumer goods supplier, has expanded its product range to meet changing consumer needs. Despite these efforts, both companies acknowledge the difficulties in staying relevant in the new normal.

site_title: AMP chairman quits, funds unit CEO demoted over exec misconduct
summary: AMP Ltd chairman David Murray resigned following concerns over alleged misconduct by the CEO of its funds management unit, Boe Pahari. Pahari was appointed in June despite an internal investigation into his 2017 comments to a female colleague, which found he breached the company's code of conduct. Pahari's role will be demoted, marking a significant overhaul of the company's leadership. The board's decision comes amid increasing scrutiny over executive misconduct in the Australian financial sector.

site_title: Japan's creaking computer systems hampering economic recovery
summary: Japan's outdated computer systems are hindering the country's economic recovery from the coronavirus crisis. The government has recognized the issue and included a "digital new deal" in its annual policy goals, aiming to boost data-sharing and update websites by the end of the year. Economists say Japan is behind the world in administrative technology, ranking 23rd out of 63 nations, and that its outdated systems are dampening the benefits of fiscal stimulus and hindering technological progress in the private sector.

site_title: Danish bond experiment aims to bring some clarity to ethical investing
summary: Denmark's central bank plans to sell green certificates tied to existing bond series to bring clarity to the opaque world of ethical investing. The certificates will be clearly labeled as green only if they meet certain environmental, social, and governance goals. This approach aims to allow investors to compare the price of green bonds to regular bonds, enabling them to calculate the exact cost of ESG designation. Denmark's move is similar to Germany's, and the European Union is introducing an ESG taxonomy to address the lack of transparency in ESG financing.

site_title: Airplane mode and prepaid SIMs: some Israelis dodge Covid-19 tracking
summary: In Israel, some individuals are evading Covid-19 contact-tracing by switching their cellphones to airplane mode or using prepaid SIM cards. This low-tech tactic is reportedly being used by Israelis who fear quarantine orders after being near a coronavirus carrier. Despite the state's efforts to track cellphone activity, these methods seem to be effective in rendering users untraceable. This workaround highlights the challenges faced by authorities in implementing their Covid-19 tracking policies.

site_title: China banks' H1 profits to drop for first time in over a decade
summary: China's largest banks are expected to post their first drop in first-half profits in over a decade, hit by a surge in bad debt and higher loan-loss provisions due to the pandemic. The six biggest banks posted a 12% profit fall from a year ago, while Chinese commercial banks saw a 9.4% decline. Authorities have urged financial institutions to sacrifice 1.5 trillion yuan in profit to support companies, with some banks being asked to slash bankers' salaries and increase buffers for bad loans. The banking regulator has also urged banks to set aside more cash as loan-loss buffers.

site_title: Asian firms including Foxconn eye Mexico factories as China risks grow
summary: Taiwan-based electronics manufacturers Foxconn and Pegatron are considering new factories in Mexico, potentially ushering in billions of dollars in fresh investments for the Latin American country. The plans come amid the US-China trade war and coronavirus pandemic, prompting firms to reexamine global supply chains. Foxconn is reportedly planning to use a Mexico factory to make Apple iPhones, while Pegatron is in discussions with lenders about an additional facility mainly to assemble chips and electronic components. The investment could boost Mexico's economy, which is primed for its worst recession since the 1930s Great Depression.

site_title: Worst may be over for S-Reits: Eastspring, OCBC
summary: Analysts at Eastspring Investments and OCBC believe the worst may be over for Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits). The market is overpricing the potential decline in retail and office S-Reits. Eastspring's Adam Matthews and Sarah Lien stated that S-Reits remain attractive, while OCBC's top picks include Frasers Logistics and Commercial Trust, and Manulife US Reit.

images.alt_text: While the office segment is still under stress, demand is likely to persist for Grade-A office space, say Eastspring Investments analysts.

site_title: Smaller funding rounds buck overall downtrend for Asean tech ecosystem
summary: A new report by Cento Ventures indicates that despite a slowdown in overall funding for Southeast Asia's tech ecosystem due to the Covid-19 pandemic, smaller funding rounds have bucked the trend. The number of regional internet tech companies valued between US$100 million and US$500 million has continued to rise, with the report citing investments in fashion brand Pomelo and food and beverage player Grain. This suggests a positive outlook for smaller tech companies in the region.

site_title: Billionaire car-part supplier aims to triple sales in 5 years
summary: Billionaire car-part supplier Vivek Chaand Sehgal's company, Motherson Sumi Systems Ltd, aims to triple annual sales to $36 billion by 2025. Sehgal plans to achieve this by acquiring distressed companies, particularly small- to medium-sized ones, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company's customers include major carmakers such as General Motors and Volkswagen. Sehgal, 63, expects to retire around 68, handing over the reins to his son Laksh Vaaman. Despite the challenges of the pandemic, Motherson Sumi's stock has doubled this financial year, and its actual net worth is likely to be higher than the $2 billion listed.

site_title: Spanish hotel mergers expected as pandemic keeps tourists away
summary: Spanish hotels, severely impacted by the pandemic, may merge or be acquired by larger chains to survive. Industry officials expect 40% of hotel executives to sell or be acquired due to the 71% decline in international tourist spending. Consolidation was already underway before the pandemic, with Blackstone Group acquiring several hotels in 2018. City-based hotels with 70-80 rooms are most likely to be sold or tied up, and executives who rent properties are under pressure to sell.

site_title: Tiong Woon full-year net profit jumps to S$7.6m, proposes final dividend
summary: TIONG Woon Corporation Holding reported a full-year net profit of S$7.6 million, more than doubling the previous year's S$2.9 million. Revenue rose 6% to S$124.7 million, driven by improved performance across its three segments. The company has proposed a final dividend of 0.3 Singapore cent per share, with the date of payment to be announced later.

site_title: Standard Chartered extends title sponsorship of Singapore Marathon to 2023
summary: Standard Chartered Bank has renewed its title sponsorship of the Singapore Marathon for four years, until 2023. The bank's commitment is seen as a way to express gratitude to partners, stakeholders, and runners who have contributed to the marathon's growth. Due to the ongoing pandemic, this year's marathon will have a unique alternative format, with both virtual and possible physical components, prioritizing athlete and public safety.

site_title: STI closes 0.4% higher on first trading day of the week
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.4% to 2,538.61 on the first trading day of the week, driven by low inflation data and interest rates. Core inflation fell to a decade-low of -0.4%, and investors sought deals amid subdued forecasts. Advancers outnumbered decliners 251 to 191, with SATS and Singapore Airlines gaining, while Thai Beverage declined. UOB economist Barnabas Gan expects deflation pressures to persist, citing falling domestic and tourism-led demand.

site_title: Hedge fund manager Ken Griffin's Citadel to open Singapore office this year
summary: Citadel, a hedge fund managed by billionaire Ken Griffin, plans to open a Singapore office this year, expanding its presence in Asia. The office will be shared by Citadel's hedge fund business and its securities unit, Citadel Securities, which is also growing its operations in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Sydney. The move comes as trading has boomed globally due to the Covid-19 pandemic and oil shock, and Asia-Pacific represents over 34% of world stock market value. The expansion aims to tap into the Singapore talent pool and compete with rival market makers in the region.

site_title: Biden's a 'nice guy', but is that enough to win?
summary: US presidential candidate Joe Biden's campaign is centered around his persona as an empathetic and kind leader, contrasting with President Donald Trump's persona as a misogynist and racist. Biden's personal narrative, including overcoming personal tragedies and remaining dedicated to social-economic equality, is highlighted as a key difference. However, the article questions whether these personal qualities are enough to convince voters, particularly those who have lost jobs and homes to Trump's policies, to support Biden's campaign. The article concludes that Biden's campaign must provide more concrete answers to key questions, such as how he will address the pandemic, fix the economy, and respond to foreign policy threats.

site_title: Changi Airport launches first online shopping campaign
summary: Changi Airport has launched its first online shopping campaign, running for seven weeks on iShopChangi, featuring deals on nearly 9,000 tax and duty-absorbed products. Shoppers can expect vouchers, rewards, and discounts of up to 60% on select products, including electronics, beauty items, and wines. The campaign aims to cater to shifting shopping patterns driven by the coronavirus.

site_title: Under-the-radar movies for offbeat times
summary: A guide to under-the-radar movies for offbeat entertainment has been compiled, featuring lesser-known streaming films. Recommendations include "Knife + Heart," a provocative and graphic story of a serial killer in 1970s Paris; "The Peanut Butter Falcon," a gentle comedy-drama about a young man with Down syndrome on a journey of self-discovery; and "The Weekend," a wise and witty romantic comedy starring Sasheer Zamata. Other notable mentions include "I Will Follow," a character study by Ava DuVernay; "Terri," a seriocomic drama by Azazel Jacobs; and "Western Stars," a visual album and film by Bruce Springsteen.

site_title: Virtual banking: sound execution critical to success
summary: The virtual banking market in the Asia-Pacific region is rapidly gaining traction, driven by regulatory infrastructure changes and technological capabilities. Developed markets such as Singapore and Hong Kong are embracing virtual banking to drive innovation and improve financial services, while new entrants and traditional banks are digitizing their offerings to stay relevant. The World Bank estimates that over 1 billion people in Asia lack access to formal financial services, and virtual banks can play a key role in increasing financial inclusion and transparency. Successful virtual banks must have reliable and efficient technological capabilities, including a scalable and extensible platform, to compete effectively in a highly competitive and rapidly evolving marketplace.

site_title: Apple's Tim Cook poised to get US$279m annual stock payout
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook is set to receive a $278.6 million annual stock payout, based on the company's record third quarter and its stock's performance. Cook, 59, will receive 560,000 shares, exceeding the threshold for the payout. His annual payouts are tied to continued service and Apple's stock performance relative to other companies in the S&P 500 index over three years. Cook has already donated millions of dollars worth of Apple shares and plans to give most of his fortune away.

site_title: It's in US' long-term strategic interests to keep status quo on Taiwan
summary: US Secretary of Health and Human Services Alex Azar met with Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen in Taipei, marking the highest-level visit by an American official since 1979. The US maintains a "robust unofficial" relationship with Taiwan, including arms sales, but does not recognize the island as an independent country. This approach has helped stabilize the relationship between Washington and Beijing, but now faces challenges as the US and China engage in growing tensions, with some hawks pressing for a more confrontational approach.

site_title: Sats to cut more staff after S$43.7m Q1 loss
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based ground handler and food solutions provider, has swung into a net loss of S$43.7 million in its fiscal first quarter, primarily due to a sharp decline in aviation volume. The company has already reduced its staff count from 16,700 to 13,500 year-over-year and plans to continue cutting costs, with the final headcount reduction not specified. SATS aims to "reshape the organisation to a lower cost base" and pivot to new revenue streams, including food services and retail.

site_title: Cleaning, facilities management sector gets tech boost
summary: Singapore is upgrading its cleaning and facilities management sector with cutting-edge technology to combat the spread of airborne diseases like Covid-19. Companies are adopting automated disinfection systems, air cleaning robots, and robots to improve sanitation standards. The government is also introducing new legislation to enhance public hygiene standards. Trane Technologies has developed air cleaning systems that use photo-catalytic oxidation, ultraviolet irradiation, and high voltage electrostatic filtration to destroy viruses and bacteria. Cleaning companies are also embracing automated solutions, citing manpower constraints and cost savings.

site_title: European commercial property deals beat those for Covid-ravaged US
summary: US commercial real estate deals fell behind European transactions in the second quarter, with a $19 billion gap, according to Real Capital Analytics. The decline was attributed to the harsher public health situation in the US, where investors face greater uncertainty around underwriting future income trends for properties. In contrast, European countries' social safety nets can provide investors with a clearer understanding of economic losses. This marks a reversal from the US's long-standing lead in commercial real estate deals.

site_title: QT Vascular seeks 'new lease of life' from Mongolia mining, energy with S$1b RTO
summary: QT Vascular, a Singapore-listed medical technology firm, is seeking a new business direction by acquiring Mongolian mining and energy group Tengri Coal and Energy (TCE) for S$1 billion in cash and shares. The deal, expected to result in a reverse takeover, will see QT Vascular become a shell company. TCE plans to build and run an electricity supply business in Mongolia, with potential for growth and significant upside. The acquisition is expected to give QT Vascular "a new lease of life" and increase its market capitalization.

site_title: Ford CEO vows flawless launches of its high-stakes F-150
summary: Ford is overhauling its two factories to produce the redesigned F-150 pickup truck, aiming for a flawless launch. The company will temporarily shut a Michigan factory and idle another in Missouri to install new machinery and prepare for production. The overhaul, starting in September, will trim output by about 100,000 vehicles this fall. The new electric F-150 is expected to start production in 2022, with a new facility being built in Michigan. The critical launch is under scrutiny after Ford botched the rollout of its redesigned Explorer last year, and the company is set to face its first full-year loss in over a decade.

site_title: TikTok confirms suing over ban ordered by Trump
summary: TikTok has filed a lawsuit against the US government, challenging the executive order signed by President Donald Trump that effectively orders the sale of the app to a US company within 45 days. The company argues that Trump's order is a misuse of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act and that it has not provided any US user data to the Chinese government. TikTok claims the order strips the rights of its community without evidence to justify such an extreme action, and that the US government ignored its efforts to address concerns in good faith.

site_title: Merkel and Macron plot Europe's future
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel held a mini-summit to plot the future of the European Union, seeking to steer the EU's future internally and externally.
