The two leaders aim to realize their ambitions during Germany's six-month EU presidency, focusing on issues like the turmoil in Belarus, Lebanon, and Mali, as well as re-imagining the EU's post-Brexit shape. They also agreed on an EU-led mediation for Belarus and a post-pandemic role for Europe as a defense power. The meeting reflects a combined context of an uncertain election outlook for Macron and Merkel's desire to ensure the EU's voice is heard, despite not enjoying global leadership.

site_title: Trek 2000 founder fined over interested party transactions
summary: Henn Tan, founder of mainboard-listed technology firm Trek 2000, was fined S$80,000 for neglecting to disclose 24 interested person transactions worth over US$10.4 million in 2010 and 2013. Tan pleaded guilty to two Securities and Futures Act offences and has nine other charges outstanding, including abetting the falsification of accounts and forgery. The court considered Tan more culpable than co-accused Poo Teng Pin, who was sentenced to nine months' imprisonment for similar charges.

images.alt_text: Trek 2000's founder Henn Tan has nine other charges hanging over his head - for allegedly abetting the falsification of accounts, cheating external auditors and forgery.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.54 points to 1,568.58. Volume reached 9.949 billion lots worth RM5.769 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 645 to 504, indicating a relatively positive trading day despite the overall decline.

site_title: Former GOP lawmakers join Republicans for Biden campaign
summary: Former Republican lawmakers, including Senators Jeff Flake and John Warner, have joined Joe Biden's campaign, citing Trump's corruption, destruction of democracy, and disregard for moral decency as reasons. The 27 former lawmakers, who previously supported the GOP, are supporting Biden due to his ability to "get the country back on course" and because Trump's failures as president have superseded partisanship. This national effort aims to enlist disenchanted GOP supporters behind the Democratic nominee.

site_title: Bayern Munich wins Champions League - victory for tradition and team
summary: Bayern Munich won the Champions League, defeating Paris Saint-Germain in a moment of elation. The team's victory is seen as a triumph for tradition and the team itself, with players like Neymar visibly heartbroken after the loss. Bayern Munich's win marks a significant achievement in the football world, solidifying their position as a top-tier team.

site_title: Boustead unit bags A$30m contract from Australian government department
summary: Boustead Singapore's unit, Esri Australia, has secured a $30 million contract with the Australian federal government department to provide geographic information systems technology. The contract, which is a renewal of an existing arrangement, is expected to positively impact the group's profitability and earnings per share in the current financial year.

site_title: New York landlords press finance bosses to speed up return-to-work and save city
summary: New York landlords are pressuring finance executives to return to the office, citing the city's economic fate and the need to support local businesses. A coalition of top property owners and managers, including Related Cos and RXR Realty, is calling on CEOs to bring back workers, promising to make necessary changes to ensure safety. The landlords argue that every office job supports multiple service workers, and a decline in office jobs would lead to business closures and a loss of talent. They aim to speed up the return to the office by Labor Day, with some predicting a return of 30-50% of staff by summer.

site_title: Zoom working to fix partial outage at video conferencing service
summary: Zoom is working to fix a partial outage affecting its video conferencing service, with nearly 15,000 users reporting issues. The company identified an authentication issue causing users to be unable to log in to the website and join meetings. Shares fell 1.5% in early trade as the company struggles to meet the surge in demand for its service due to remote work arrangements during the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia's parliament approves raising government debt ceiling to 60%
summary: Malaysia's parliament approved a plan to raise the government's debt ceiling to 60% of gross domestic product (GDP) for the first time in over a decade. This comes as the country grapples with the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic. The temporary measure aims to mitigate the effects of the pandemic on the public and local businesses. The last time Malaysia raised its debt ceiling was in 2009 during the global financial crisis, when it increased its maximum borrowings by 10 percentage points to 55% of GDP.

site_title: Facebook to pay more than US$110m in back taxes in France
summary: Facebook's French subsidiary has agreed to pay over 100 million euros (approximately $161.6 million) in back taxes, including a penalty, after a 10-year audit of its accounts. The audit found that the company had funneled sales generated in France to its Irish headquarters, avoiding taxes. The payment is part of France's efforts to overhaul international tax rules on digital companies. Facebook's total net revenue in France almost doubled in 2019 after including advertising sales in its annual accounts.

site_title: The MAS' prescription for bifocal vision
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has emphasized the importance of Anti-Money Laundering (AML) compliance for financial institutions (FIs) and service providers in Singapore. The MAS has reviewed FIs' AML processes and enforced actions against those found non-compliant. The regulator has also published a paper outlining expectations for FIs to exercise oversight over AML outsourcing arrangements, including due diligence and sample checks. The MAS expects FIs and service providers to have a "bifocal view" of AML implementation, with both in-house and outsourced functions, and for the FI to remain ultimately responsible for its compliance programme.

site_title: S-Reits now cheap with upside potential, worst is over, say Eastspring, OCBC
summary: Eastspring Investments and OCBC believe the worst is over for Singapore-listed retail and office real-estate investment trusts (S-Reits), citing oversold valuations and attractive dividend yields. The sector is expected to recover from the third or fourth quarter of this year and into 2021, driven by government support measures and a shift to suburban office complexes. Eastspring and OCBC recommend focusing on high-quality assets at discounted prices and complementing winners with beaten-down sub-sectors, with top picks including Frasers Logistics and Commercial Trust and Manulife US Reit.

site_title: Republican ex-lawmakers back Biden on first day of Trump convention
summary: More than 27 former Republican US lawmakers, including Senator Jeff Flake, have endorsed Democrat Joe Biden for president, criticizing President Donald Trump for his "corruption, destruction of democracy" and leadership. This move comes as 73 former Republican national security officials have also endorsed Biden, citing Trump's alleged corruption and unfit leadership. The opposition groups object to Trump's response to the coronavirus pandemic and economic downturn, and the Trump campaign has dismissed them as "disaffected former officials trying to take down the President." The endorsements mark a significant rebuke of Trump from within his own party.

site_title: Far-sighted SMEs press on with expansion despite Covid-19
summary: Despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, some Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are pressing on with expansion plans. Food and beverage brand King of Prawn Noodles opened its second outlet in Hillion Mall after receiving guidance from business advisers and tapping business support grants. This trend highlights the resilience of SMEs in the face of uncertainty, with many seeking to capitalize on available financial support schemes to drive growth.

site_title: Sovereign wealth funds rethink once-reliable real estate
summary: Sovereign wealth funds are retreating from real estate investments due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with a 65% decline in US$4.4 billion investments in the sector in the first seven months of 2020. Funds are shifting to logistics space, such as warehousing, amid the pandemic's impact on online commerce. The real estate market is expected to drop by 14% in 2020 before rising by 3.4% in 2021. Some funds have seen significant drops in property asset values, while others are looking for bargains in distressed properties.

site_title: Axington shares close lower on Monday amid owners' controversy; SGX RegCo weighs in
summary: Shares of Axington fell on Monday amid controversy over its owners' bid for Newcastle United. The Singapore Exchange's regulatory arm, SGX RegCo, has engaged Axington's continuing sponsor Novus Corporate Finance. Axington is controlled by cousins Nelson and Terence Loh, who acquired the company using their co-founded Dorr Global Healthcare. The move has raised concerns about the company's independence and governance.

site_title: At least 70 feared trapped in India building collapse
summary: At least 70 people are feared trapped after a five-storey apartment building in western India collapsed late Monday. The building, with 47 flats, collapsed during the monsoon season, with rescue teams and canine squads deployed to the scene. Fifteen injured people have been rescued and taken to hospital. The cause of the accident is unclear, but building collapses are common during India's monsoon season, which has already claimed over 1,200 lives this year, including more than 800 in India.

site_title: Hong Kong researchers report first documented coronavirus re-infection
summary: A Hong Kong man, 33, has become the first documented case of coronavirus re-infection, four-and-a-half months after recovering from the initial infection. The patient, who had been cleared of Covid-19 and discharged from a hospital in April, tested positive again after returning from Spain. Researchers found he had contracted a different strain of the virus and remained asymptomatic. The case suggests the disease may continue to spread despite herd immunity, but experts caution that the finding does not mean vaccines will be useless and more research is needed to understand the effectiveness of immunity induced by vaccination versus natural infection.

site_title: WHO says 172 countries engaging with global Covid-19 vaccine plan
summary: The World Health Organization announced that 172 countries are engaging with the Covax facility, a global Covid-19 vaccine plan, to ensure equitable access to vaccines. Countries must submit expressions of interest by August 31 and make binding commitments by September 18. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus emphasized the facility's importance in ending the pandemic, pooling risk for vaccine development and purchase, and keeping prices low.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open at new highs on Covid-19 treatment hopes
summary: US stocks opened at new highs on Monday, driven by hopes for a Covid-19 treatment and a potential vaccine candidate. The S&P 500 rose 0.62%, the Nasdaq gained 1.22%, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 0.53%. The US health regulator approved the emergency use of blood plasma in Covid-19 patients, while the Trump administration may fast-track a vaccine candidate, boosting market sentiment. The record opening marks a positive start to the week for US stocks.

site_title: GuocoLand's full-year net profit halves to S$114m, proposes 6 cents per share dividend
summary: GuocoLand reported a 50% drop in full-year net profit to S$114.1 million, mainly due to fair-value losses on investment properties. Revenue rose 2% to S$941.8 million, driven by a 5% increase in property-development business revenue, but hotels revenue declined 30% due to the pandemic. The company proposed a 6 cents per share dividend. GuocoLand has resumed construction of its development projects and is monitoring the Covid-19 situation.

site_title: Government will be open to new ideas, but be prepared to make tough choices: President Halimah
summary: Singapore's President Halimah Yacob emphasized the government's openness to constructive criticism and new ideas, but also its willingness to take tough decisions in the national interest. In her address to the 14th Parliament, she outlined plans to focus on jobs, sharing economic benefits, and strengthening the Singaporean identity. The government will encourage citizen initiatives and participation, while also addressing the challenges posed by Covid-19 and the country's worst recession since independence.

site_title: Wirecard innovation team moves to Berlin-based fintech
summary: A technology team from Wirecard, a German payments company that collapsed in June, is joining a new digital innovation unit in Berlin-based fintech group finleap. The six-strong team, led by Joern Leogrande, will support companies in their digital transformation. Leogrande will head a corporate innovation and corporate venture building unit, which runs a stable of 11 startups. This move comes ahead of Wirecard's formal insolvency proceedings, likely to lead to job losses. The team's relocation to Berlin is seen as a strategic shift for the company's remaining viable assets.

site_title: Tesco to create 16,000 more permanent jobs in online boom
summary: Tesco plans to create 16,000 permanent jobs to support its online growth, with 10,000 pickers and 3,000 drivers. The roles will be filled by temporary employees who want to stay with the company permanently. This move comes as UK supermarkets have taken on additional staff to meet increased demand for online deliveries and groceries. This contrasts with other companies, such as high-street retailers, that have laid off workers to cut costs.

site_title: Indonesia's top drugmaker Kalbe Farma weighs food unit IPO
summary: Indonesia's top drugmaker Kalbe Farma is considering an initial public offering (IPO) for its nutritional food unit PT Sanghiang Perkasa, which could raise approximately $500 million. This would be the country's largest IPO since 2011, and could boost Southeast Asia's largest economy, which has seen a low volume of IPOs this year. Kalbe Farma has picked advisers for the IPO, which could list on the Jakarta stock exchange later this year, but the company has not confirmed plans for the offering.

site_title: Taiwan tells Alibaba's local Taobao site to re-register or leave island
summary: Taiwan has given Alibaba's local Taobao site six months to re-register as a Chinese investment or leave the island, amid growing political tension. The investment commission is concerned about information security due to user data being sent to China and has fined Taobao Taiwan $13,960.77. The company must decide whether to disinvest or rectify its investment, with Taiwan treating investment from foreign countries differently than from China, applying stricter rules. Taobao Taiwan has previously claimed it is an entirely different platform from Taobao China.

site_title: Tourist hotspot Bali to stay closed to foreign visitors all year
summary: Bali, Indonesia, will remain closed to foreign visitors for the rest of 2020 due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. Despite allowing local visitors since July, the island's infection rate has increased, with 4,513 confirmed cases and 52 deaths as of Sunday. The government will focus on increasing domestic visitors to help the tourism industry recover, with over 6 million foreign tourists visiting Bali last year. The closure is expected to worsen Indonesia's tourism revenue forecast, which could reach over US$10 billion in losses this year.

images.alt_text: The Indonesian island of Bali will remain closed to foreign visitors for the rest of 2020 after authorities postponed a plan to welcome back international tourists from Sept 11 as the coronavirus continues to spread.

site_title: STI closes 0.4% higher on first trading day of the week
summary: Singapore's STI index rose 0.4% to 2,537.56 on the first trading day of the week, driven by gains from Gateway services provider SATS and Singapore Airlines. Despite core inflation slipping to a decade-low of -0.4%, economists expect deflation pressures to persist due to low oil prices and falling domestic and tourism-led demand. The government's full-year forecast for inflation remains subdued, ranging between zero and -1%.

site_title: Real estate investors skip paying loans while raising billions
summary: Real estate investors, including Brookfield Property Partners, Starwood Capital Group, and Blackstone Group, are skipping payments on commercial mortgage-backed securities backed by hotels and malls, despite raising billions for new opportunities. This trend illustrates the economic fallout from the pandemic, which has devalued some real estate while creating new targets for these investors. Experts say the investors' willingness to walk away from debt does not necessarily tarnish their reputation for future endeavors.

site_title: Ley Choon units secure four contracts worth S$42m in total
summary: CATALIST-listed Ley Choon Group Holdings' units have secured four contracts worth S$41.98 million for underground services installation and construction works. The contracts, secured by subsidiaries Ley Choon Constructions and Engineering and Teacly (S), are not expected to impact the company's earnings or net tangible assets for the current financial year. Shares closed up 16.67% at S$0.014 on Monday after the announcement.

site_title: Takeda to sell Japan consumer health unit valued at 242b yen to Blackstone
summary: Takeda Pharmaceutical agreed to sell its Japanese consumer healthcare business to US investment fund Blackstone Group for 242 billion yen, valued at S$3.13 billion. The sale is expected to boost Takeda's net profit by 105 billion yen and is subject to regulatory closing conditions, with a target closing date of March 31. This follows Blackstone's previous acquisition of Ayumi Pharmaceutical Corp for US$1 billion in 2019, and is part of Takeda's efforts to refocus its business and reduce debt after its US$59 billion acquisition of Shire.

site_title: Koufu expands two of its tea brands to the Philippines via franchise
summary: Koufu Group has expanded its Supertea and R&B Tea brands to the Philippines through a master franchise agreement with Shakey's Pizza Asia Ventures. The agreement grants Shakey's the rights to retail the brands for seven years, with a "co-branding" strategy to sell R&B Tea drinks at Shakey's and Peri Peri stores initially, and opening at least five self-operated R&B Tea outlets. Koufu will collect franchise fees, royalties, and marketing fees under the agreement, following its stringent selection criteria for strategic partners.

site_title: Glencore backs new initiative to support informal miners of cobalt
summary: Glencore, the world's top cobalt producer, has backed the Fair Cobalt Alliance, a new initiative to support informal miners in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The group aims to end child labor and improve working conditions in the country's mines. Glencore's move comes as the industry seeks to reassure carmakers about ethically sourced cobalt. The company has also secured a deal with Tesla to supply cobalt from its Congo mines. This initiative is seen as a step towards addressing concerns about cobalt sourcing and supply chain transparency.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed sharply higher on Monday, following a rally across Asia, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.74% to 25,551.58. The gains were in line with a record lead from Wall Street. Other Asian markets also saw significant increases, including the Shanghai Composite Index and the Shenzhen Composite Index. The rally comes despite ongoing US-China trade tensions and uncertainty around the Fed's monetary policy.

site_title: New Covid-19 cluster in Tuas View Dormitory
summary: A new Covid-19 cluster was announced in Singapore, linked to a workers dormitory in Tuas View. The cluster, which includes five previous cases, brings Singapore's total cases to 56,404. The cluster is the third in consecutive days, following clusters linked to Sungei Tengah Lodge and Homestay Lodge. The Ministry of Health (MOH) confirmed 51 new cases, including one community case and seven imported cases. MOH also reported that 423 patients have been discharged, with 54,572 fully recovered.

site_title: De Beers cuts diamond prices after Covid-19 curbs demand
summary: De Beers, the world's largest diamond producer, has cut the prices of its diamonds by almost 10% in a bid to boost sales after the COVID-19 pandemic severely impacted the industry. The price cut applies to larger stones, with prices for rough diamonds bigger than 1 carat reduced. The move comes after De Beers and rival Alrosa sold a combined $130 million in rough diamonds in the second quarter, down from $2.1 billion a year earlier. The price cut aims to stimulate demand and counter smaller rivals selling at a 25% discount.

site_title: Multiplex stocks bounce back in India despite empty theaters
summary: Indian multiplex stocks PVR Ltd and Inox Leisure Ltd have rebounded 50% since May, despite a four-month closure due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Analysts from HSBC Securities and Capital Market India Pvt. attribute the growth to cost cuts and sufficient liquidity, and reiterate their buy rating on the companies. They see multiplexes as an exponential growth opportunity in India, with a preference for big launches due to the buzz and experience provided. Theaters are expected to welcome back audiences with safety measures once restrictions ease.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on tech surge, virus slowdown optimism
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to a record peak on Monday, driven by tech stocks, as a slowdown in new coronavirus cases in Victoria fueled optimism about a potential second wave. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 6,129.60, snapping two straight sessions of losses. The country's second-most populous state reported its smallest daily rise in fresh Covid-19 cases in seven weeks, following strict lockdown curbs. The tech surge and virus slowdown optimism contributed to the market's recovery.

site_title: Mongolia mining, energy group to be injected into QT Vascular in S$1b RTO
summary: QT Vascular, a Singapore-based balloon catheter specialist, is set to acquire Tengri Coal and Energy (TCE) for S$1 billion in a reverse takeover (RTO). The acquisition will give QTV a new business area in the coal and energy industry in Mongolia, which has potential for growth. QTV's board expects the deal to increase its market capitalization and provide a "new lease of life" for the company. The acquisition is conditional on QTV becoming a shell company and disposing of its existing assets and liabilities.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's core inflation fell to a decade low of -0.4% in July, widening from -0.2% in the previous month. Trek 2000 founder Henn Tan pleaded guilty to Securities and Futures Act violations. A $1 billion deal saw QT Vascular acquiring Tengri Coal and Energy. Nets partnered with Singtel and Amazon to expand digital payment services regionally. S-Reits are considered cheap with upside potential, according to Eastspring and OCBC. The STI closed 0.4% higher on its first trading day of the week.

images.alt_text: Headline or all-items inflation came in at ‐0.4 per cent, picking up slightly from -0.5 per cent in June, and beating analysts' estimates of a 0.6 per cent drop.

site_title: Spanish hotel mergers expected as pandemic keeps tourists away
summary: Spanish hotels, severely impacted by the pandemic, may merge or sell to larger chains or investors to survive. Industry officials predict 40% of hotel executives will sell establishments struggling due to a 71% decline in international tourist spending. The pandemic has already led to consolidation in the industry, with larger chains like Blackstone acquiring smaller hotels. Executives see opportunities for growth in the crisis, with some chains already planning to "leverage all the opportunities" in the new stage of the industry.

site_title: Hong Kong buyers rush for UK properties after security law
summary: Hong Kong buyers are rushing to purchase UK properties due to concerns over the national security law and increasing politicization in Hong Kong. In the past two months, over double the usual number of apartments were sold to Hong Kong buyers, with prices increasing by nearly 15% since April. The UK government's offer of a path to British citizenship for Hong Kong residents has also encouraged investment, with buyers looking for cheaper options outside of London.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets jump at open
summary: European stock markets surged at the start of trading Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 1.2%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index rising 1.4%, and Paris's CAC 40 advancing 1.5%. The gains followed a rally in Asia. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise 1% on virus treatment hopes, drop in new cases
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1% on Monday, following the US FDA's authorization of a Covid-19 treatment using blood plasma from recovered patients. New domestic cases slowed, contributing to the increase. The Kospi index closed at 2,329.83, with the pharmaceutical sector sub-index jumping 2.9%. The US FDA's decision lifted sentiment, while Asian peers also rose in line with South Korea's gains.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on investor sentiment
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index advancing 0.28% to 22,985.51. Investor sentiment improved after a strong lead from Wall Street and Hong Kong shares, which rose 1.47%. The exception to the market's positivity is an address by Fed Chair Jay Powell at the Kansas City Fed Jackson Hole symposium, which may influence the week's data. Key shares, including Nintendo and Sony, also gained, while automakers Toyota, Honda, and Nissan fell.

site_title: Scoot doubles aircraft's cargo-carrying capabilities with modification
summary: Scoot, a budget carrier of Singapore Airlines, has modified one of its A320ceo aircraft to carry cargo in the cabin by removing all seats, doubling its cargo-carrying capacity to nearly 20 tonnes. The move comes as a result of a decline in bellyhold space due to reduced passenger flights during the Covid-19 pandemic. The aircraft has already taken off on its first cargo charter flight from Fuzhou to Singapore, and another aircraft is scheduled for modification this week. The move aims to provide an alternative revenue stream for the carrier.

site_title: Sulzer buys Swiss-German device maker Haselmeier for US$118m
summary: Sulzer, a Swiss-German company, has acquired Haselmeier, a privately-held device maker, for $118 million. Haselmeier, which makes self-injection pens for various health conditions, aims to boost Sulzer's applicator systems business. The deal is expected to close on October 1 and is seen as a potential growth driver. Sulzer's applicators division has been hurt by a slump in sales, with a 7% decline in 2019, and is now seeking to expand its healthcare business.

site_title: Microsoft defends Fortnite maker in Apple fight
summary: Microsoft has defended Epic Games, the maker of Fortnite, in its legal battle with Apple, stating that cutting off Epic's access to Apple's programming tools would harm other game creators and players as well. In a court filing, Microsoft's general manager of gaming developer experiences, Kevin Gammill, said Unreal Engine, a software platform used by many video game studios, including Microsoft, would be negatively impacted. Epic Games is fighting Apple's decision to remove Fortnite from its online store due to a revenue sharing dispute.

site_title: Tencent gains US$26b after US reassures on WeChat ban
summary: Tencent Holdings jumped 4.2% in Hong Kong after US officials reassured American businesses that a ban on its WeChat app won't be as broad as feared. The White House is privately seeking to reassure companies that they can still do business with WeChat in China, amid concerns of devastating impact on US tech and retail industries. The ban, signed by President Trump on August 6, erased $66 billion from Tencent's value, but the stock has recouped all but $22 billion of those losses.

site_title: New Zealand extends Auckland coronavirus curbs
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern extended the Auckland coronavirus lockdown until Sunday, a four-day extension from its original end date, to enable the country to step down its emergency restrictions. Mandatory mask wearing on public transport nationwide was introduced. The lockdown, which has affected 150 people, will ease to Level 2 restrictions on Monday, with public gatherings limited to 10 people in Auckland and 100 people nationwide.

site_title: Tour de France ready to roll in time of Covid
summary: The 2020 Tour de France is set to begin next Saturday with 176 riders, including defending champion Egan Bernal, and will feature a unique Covid-19 testing unit and protocols to minimize the risk of transmission. The event, delayed by two months, will take place in the French Riviera before concluding in Paris on September 20, with global audiences from 190 countries expected to watch. The Tour has introduced measures such as PCR nasal tests, mask-wearing, and social distancing to ensure rider safety, with the goal of completing the three-week endurance test.

site_title: Australia's AMP says chairman resigns, funds unit CEO demoted
summary: Australia's AMP announced the resignation of its chairman, David Murray, and the demotion of funds management unit CEO Boe Pahari. Pahari will step down as CEO of AMP Capital and resume work at a lower level, following an internal investigation into comments he made to a female colleague in 2017. The decision was made after shareholder concerns about Pahari's promotion to AMP Capital CEO, despite the internal investigation's finding that he breached the company's code of conduct. Debra Hazelton will replace Murray as chairman.

site_title: Kuwait to rebuild Lebanon's only large grain silo after blast - report
summary: Kuwait has announced plans to rebuild Lebanon's only large grain silo, destroyed in the 2020 Beirut port explosion, in an effort to alleviate food shortages in the financially struggling country. The 120,000-tonne capacity silo was first built in 1969 with a Kuwaiti development loan. The rebuilding aims to maintain a symbol of cooperation between the two countries. Lebanon's caretaker economy minister has reassured the public that there will be no flour or bread crisis, despite the port's destruction and lack of government storage facilities.

site_title: RHB recommends Reits, defensive stocks with selective cyclical exposure
summary: RHB Research recommends investors stick with real estate investment trusts (Reits) and defensive stocks in Singapore, citing rising optimism over economic recovery. Analyst Shekhar Jaiswal expects a rebound in gross domestic product (GDP) growth and investors to build confidence in sustained earnings growth. RHB's cyclical recovery picks include CapitaLand, City Developments, and Thai Beverage Public Co, while its defensive picks include Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust, Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust, Sheng Siong, Singtel, and ST Engineering. The analyst notes downside risks, including tapering government support measures and external risks from the US-China relationship.

site_title: Tougher EU climate target technically, economically feasible, researchers say
summary: The European Union plans to cut greenhouse gas emissions to 55% below 1990 levels by 2030, which researchers say is technically and economically feasible. The European Commission will propose a new climate goal, potentially setting a 50% or 55% emissions reduction target for 2030. To achieve this, the EU carbon market could be revamped to cut emissions by 61% below 2005 levels, requiring reforms to the Emissions Trading System. EU countries are divided on the proposal, with some supporting the more ambitious level and others refusing to consider bigger cuts until the costs are assessed.

site_title: Safe bet? Sovereign funds rethink once-reliable real estate
summary: Sovereign wealth funds are rethinking their reliance on real estate investments amid the COVID-19 pandemic. In the first seven months of 2020, they invested $4.4 billion in the sector, a 65% decline from the same period last year. The funds are shifting towards logistics space, such as warehousing, and cutting back on office and retail deals. This shift could have significant effects on the global real estate market, with sovereign funds being major investors. The changes may be temporary or structural, but experts say property remains a solid bet for savvy investors.

site_title: Singapore core inflation falls to decade low at -0.4% in July
summary: Singapore's core inflation fell to a decade low of -0.4% in July, according to government data, driven by a steeper decline in electricity and gas costs. Headline inflation also dropped to -0.4%, beating analysts' estimates. The decline in private transport costs moderated, while food inflation remained stable. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry attributed the drop to lower energy prices and a revision of household electricity tariffs. The central bank maintains its forecast of subdued inflation for 2020, ranging between zero and -1%.

site_title: China vows continued support for Hong Kong as financial hub
summary: China's banking regulator has pledged continued support for Hong Kong as a finance hub, reiterating its commitment to opening up the Chinese financial sector amid tensions with the US. The China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) stated that China will provide support for financial institutions operating in Hong Kong while complying with regulations. This move aims to maintain Hong Kong's status as a global financial center and attract more foreign financial institutions to the Chinese market.

site_title: China turns net aluminium importer in July for 1st time since 2009
summary: China's July aluminium imports surged nearly sevenfold to 391,297 tonnes, the second-highest level on record, marking the country's first time as a net importer since 2009. The significant increase was driven by a price disparity between domestic and international prices, allowing Chinese consumers to source metal more cheaply from overseas. This arbitrage window has now closed, but large volumes of imports were still possible due to contracts signed earlier.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street record, bankers' meeting in focus
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, following a record on Wall Street, amid a possible easing of US anti-China rhetoric. Hong Kong led gains, boosted by Tencent's tech performance after reports of the White House reassuring US firms on doing business with WeChat in China. The US decision to restrict WeChat and TikTok has strained relations between the two countries. Markets will focus on a meeting of central bankers later in the week.

site_title: University of Tokyo to sell bond in first of Its kind for Japan
summary: The University of Tokyo is set to sell a 40-year bond worth 20 billion yen (S$259.35 million) in early October, marking the first such bond offering by a Japanese university. The move follows Japan's education ministry's relaxation of debt-sale rules in June, allowing universities to finance research and education projects. This comes as investors seek debt of elite universities in the US, with American universities such as Harvard and Princeton selling over $30 billion in bonds this year.

site_title: China: Newly-listed ChiNext shares surge in historic reform
summary: China's ChiNext shares surged on their debut, with 18 companies jumping in morning trading, driven by a historic reform that streamlines the IPO process and loosens trading restrictions. The largest gainer, Ningbo KBE Electrical Technology, rose over 500%. Market watchers warn of bubble risks, but regulators say they will have "zero tolerance" for market misbehaviors. The reform aims to strengthen China's capital markets, which face growing US scrutiny, and benefit Chinese venture capitalists.

site_title: Apple Korea, under antitrust probe, proposes 100b won to support small businesses
summary: Apple Korea has proposed measures to address antitrust concerns and offered 100 billion won (S$115.19 million) in support programs for small businesses, consumers, and others. The proposal includes building a research and development center, establishing an academy for developers, and offering consumer discounts on warranty repair costs. The Korea Fair Trade Commission will review the proposal and close the case if the remedies are deemed reasonable, without determining if Apple did anything illegal. This comes after Apple was under investigation for allegedly abusing its dominant position by forcing mobile carriers to pay for advertising and warranty repairs.

site_title: Seoul mandates face masks as South Korea battles spike in coronavirus
summary: South Korea's capital Seoul has mandated the wearing of face masks in all public places, indoor and outdoor, amid a surge in coronavirus cases. The Korea Centres for Disease Control and Prevention reported 266 new cases, a drop from the previous day's 397 cases. This is the first time Seoul has implemented a nationwide mask mandate, with health officials concerned about the need for stricter social distancing measures. The country has experienced triple-digit daily increases in cases for over a week.

site_title: Mexico posts lowest weekly coronavirus death toll in two months
summary: Mexico reported 226 coronavirus deaths, the lowest weekly total in over two months, with 3,723 fatalities for the week, according to the government. This decline lends weight to government assertions that the pandemic is being beaten back. However, low testing rates and concerns about underreporting may impact the accuracy of the data, and officials caution that cases could surge again.

site_title: In California's wine country, a familiar threat of smoke and flame
summary: Wildfires in California's wine country have reached their second-largest size in state history, yet the region's residents appear to be adapting to the threat. Despite a thick smoke haze, downtown Napa was bustling with shoppers, families, and couples enjoying outdoor activities. Locals have become accustomed to checking for fires during peak fire season, likening it to checking the tide for surfing. The area's wine industry continues to operate, with wineries and restaurants offering wine tastings and outdoor dining.

images.alt_text: If it were not for the thick blanket of smoke hanging low in the cloudy afternoon sky, there would be no way to tell that anything was amiss in downtown Napa on Saturday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 2.83 points higher, or 0.18%, at 1,579.95 on Monday, with 307.6 million lots traded worth RM100.6 million. Gainers outpaced losers 327 to 86.

site_title: Hot stock: Avarga receives SGX query after shares jump 33.1%
summary: Avarga, a mainboard-listed investment holding company, received a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after its shares jumped 33.1% to an intraday high of 22 cents due to unannounced information. The company's shares rose 42.9% to 21.5 cents, with 42.3 million shares changing hands. SGX asked Avarga to explain the trading and confirm compliance with listing rules. This follows Avarga's 37% drop in net profit to S$14.9 million for the six months ended June 30, with revenue up 5% to S$720.3 million.

site_title: Chinese banks to post first H1 profit drop in over a decade amid pandemic pain
summary: China's largest banks, including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, China Construction Bank, and Bank of China, are set to post their first drop in first-half profits in over a decade due to a surge in bad debt and higher loan-loss provisions caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The 9.4% decline in first-half net profit for commercial banks and 12% profit fall for the six biggest banks is attributed to authorities pushing financial institutions to sacrifice 1.5 trillion yuan in profit to support companies and lower lending rates and fees.

site_title: New Zealand mosque shooter spent years preparing for attack: sentencing hearing
summary: A New Zealand man, Brenton Tarrant, has pleaded guilty to 51 murder charges and one charge of committing a terrorist act for killing 51 people at two mosques in Christchurch in 2019. Tarrant meticulously planned the attack, which he livestreamed on Facebook, and expressed regret for not taking more lives. He faces a life prison term, possibly without parole, in what would be a first for New Zealand. Tarrant's sentencing hearing is ongoing, with over 200 victim impact statements received, and a High Court judge set to deliver the sentence later this week.

site_title: Nets ties up with Singtel, Amazon to provide more digital payment services regionally
summary: Nets, a digital payment service provider, has partnered with Singtel and Amazon Web Services (AWS) to enhance cross-border digital payment opportunities in South-east Asia. This collaboration will allow Singaporeans to make purchases at regional retail outlets using Nets and enable foreign visitors to make payments to Nets merchants in Singapore using overseas e-wallets. The partnership leverages Singtel's advanced network and AWS's cloud computing platform to provide secure, swift, and reliable cross-border financial transactions.

site_title: Qantas international head to depart as overseas flying remains grounded
summary: Qantas has announced that its international division head, Tino La Spina, will leave the company due to cost-saving measures amid the coronavirus pandemic. The airline has grounded all international flights until at least mid-2021, and CEO Alan Joyce has consolidated the domestic and international business units under a single divisional CEO, Andrew David. The changes will take effect from September 1. The airline expects a significant loss this financial year, forecasting an underlying pre-tax loss of around A$260 million, and CEO Alan Joyce will take a 65% pay cut until November.

site_title: South Korea's latest virus wave may peak in August: JPMorgan
summary: South Korea's latest COVID-19 wave may peak in August with approximately 7,000 net infections by early November, according to a JPMorgan report. The outbreak is expected to be smaller in scale due to strengthened testing and tracing, as well as stricter social distancing rules. The Korean government is considering raising social-distancing restrictions, following a recent surge of 2,150 new cases in the past week. The resurgence is attributed to the country's economic reopening and relaxed social-distancing measures.

site_title: Brazil's Omega Geracao buys stake in EDF Renewables wind farms
summary: Brazil's renewable energy company Omega Geracao SA has acquired a 50% stake in EDF Renewables' wind farms in the Brazilian state of Bahia, valued at 661.7 million reais. Omega will pay 55% in cash and take over long-term debt. The deal expands Omega's generating capacity to 1.8 gigawatts, with potential for 2 gigawatts. Omega previously acquired operational wind farms from Eletrobras and a share of EDF's Pirapora solar complex, reaching 1.7 gigawatts. The company is in talks to buy additional wind farms with 265 MW capacity.

site_title: EPA to OK American Airlines use of surface coating to fight Covid-19
summary: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is set to approve an emergency exemption for American Airlines to use a surface coating, SurfaceWise2, manufactured by Allied BioScience Inc, to kill coronaviruses on surfaces for up to seven days. The coating, which inactivates viruses and bacteria within two hours, will be allowed for use at American Airlines airport facilities in Texas and on flights originating in the state. The EPA emphasizes that the product is not a replacement for routine cleaning and disinfection, and Allied BioScience plans to pursue a non-emergency approval for public purchase.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.1% to 2,530.32 on Monday, driven by gains in Jiutian Chemical, Vicplas International, and Singtel. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS and OCBC up and UOB down. The move comes as Singapore aims to welcome visitors from Brunei and New Zealand, a unilateral move announced on Friday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Monday, resisting rallies on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.04% to 22,912.27, while the Topix index rose 0.01% to 1,604.28. The lack of fresh market-moving events hindered investor interest, despite a strong US stock market, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records.

site_title: Trek 2000 founder Henn Tan pleads guilty to Securities and Futures Act violations
summary: Trek 2000 founder Henn Tan pleaded guilty to two counts of Securities and Futures Act violations for negligently failing to make immediate announcements on 24 interested person transactions in 2010 and 2013. He was fined S$80,000 and stepped down as CEO in 2018. Tan faces additional charges of falsifying accounts, cheating external auditors, and forgery, which will be dealt with separately. His son Wayne Tan is the current group president and executive director.

site_title: Windfall tax likely considered in Malaysia Budget 2021, but unlikely to be sufficient: Citi Research
summary: Malaysia's Budget 2021 may consider a windfall tax on glove makers, but it's unlikely to generate sufficient revenue. Citi Research estimates the tax contributions at RM1.8 billion for CY20 and RM3.3 billion for CY21, but a 10% corporate tax rate would only yield RM2 billion, a small percentage of GDP. Instead, the government may explore other revenue diversification strategies, such as sin and wealth taxes, or tweaks to personal and corporate tax structures, to meet its fiscal deficit reduction goals of 1.1% of GDP.

site_title: China: Flood of IPOs to test ChiNext resilience
summary: China's ChiNext board, a key platform for tech startups, is set to face a test of investor demand with a flood of new initial public offerings (IPOs) on Monday. 18 firms, including electronic product manufacturers and medical instrument makers, will debut under revised rules removing daily price limits. The IPOs raised a combined 20 billion yuan, with retail demand outstripping supply by an average of 5,700 times. However, the surge in new share sales may put pressure on existing equities, which have surged almost 50% this year, and may lead to greater volatility in the market.

site_title: China-focused venture funds struggle for money amid Trump heat
summary: The US Trump administration's increased scrutiny of Chinese firms has led to a decline in venture capital funding for China-focused venture funds. Just six US-dollar funds with exposure to China have sought to raise capital this year, down from 21 last year. The US State Department has urged colleges and universities to divest from Chinese holdings, and the US Senate has passed a bill that could remove Chinese companies from US stock exchanges. This has created roadblocks for venture funds seeking to invest in China's fast-growing tech industry, potentially hurting American investors.

site_title: Hot stock: Aspen shares surge 70.7%, prompting SGX query
summary: Aspen shares surged 70.7% to 35 cents on the Singapore Exchange after the company proposed diversifying into manufacturing and distribution of rubber gloves, prompting a query from the exchange. The stock traded 58.5% higher at 10:45am, with 86.7 million shares changing hands. Aspen acquired a dormant company and entered into a memorandum of understanding with a state-linked company to support the new business. The proposal comes after the company's president and CEO Murly Manokharan announced the diversification plans on August 12.

site_title: Tale of two cities: 'Sensational' for Bayern fans, sadness and tear gas in Paris
summary: Bayern Munich celebrated their Champions League final win with a socially-distanced open-air cinema in Munich, while 5,000 fans in Paris gathered to watch their team lose 1-0. In Munich, a large police presence enforced pandemic restrictions, with fines for offenders. The contrast between the two cities' celebrations highlights the differing approaches to COVID-19 protocols during the pandemic.

site_title: Australia's Victoria state reports lowest rise in Covid-19 cases in seven weeks
summary: Victoria state in Australia reported 116 new Covid-19 cases and 15 deaths, its lowest daily rise in seven weeks, fueling optimism that a deadly second wave is subsiding. The state has seen a downward trend in cases since a total lockdown in Melbourne, which has also curtailed the spread but caused economic havoc. Nearly half a million people could lose their jobs due to the lockdown, with Australia's effective unemployment rate expected to climb above 13%.

images.alt_text: The Australian state of Victoria reported its lowest daily rise in new coronavirus infections in seven weeks on Monday, fuelling optimism that a deadly second wave there is subsiding.

site_title: Singapore dollar powers to six-month high on fiscal stimulus
summary: Singapore's dollar reached a six-month high, surpassing S$1.3718 per US dollar, after the government unveiled a new stimulus package financed by unused fiscal reserves. The move is seen as a boon for the nation's currency, with analysts predicting further gains. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has a large pool of fiscal reserves, contrasting with many other developed economies relying on debt and rate cuts for stimulus. The MAS has two scheduled policy decisions a year, with the next one not due until October, with immediate focus on Singapore's economic data and the greenback's direction.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat as virus cases slow, NZ hits six-month high
summary: Australian shares remained flat on Monday, closing 0.05% higher at 6,112.4 points, as the country reported a low daily rise in new coronavirus cases in Victoria. The state's 116 new cases and 15 deaths marked a decrease from a peak of over 700 cases earlier this month. Technology stocks boosted the market, offsetting losses in energy and healthcare. The S&P/ASX 200 index had fallen 0.2% last week, snapping two straight weeks of gains.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the open on Monday, following a record performance on Wall Street. The Hang Sang Index climbed 0.95% to 25,352.79, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. The rally came ahead of a meeting of the world's central bankers, with investors focusing on the potential impact on global markets.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares started Monday with healthy gains following another record performance on Wall Street, with focus this week on a meeting of the world's central bankers.

site_title: Oil steady with US hurricane threat offset by virus resurgence
summary: Oil prices remained steady despite a third weekly gain, as the threat of US hurricanes disrupting production was offset by signs of a coronavirus resurgence in Asia and Europe. October futures traded near $42.50 a barrel, with US Gulf Coast production closed due to Hurricane Marco and Laura. The pandemic appears to be staging a comeback in Europe and Asia, while the US has seen a steady decline in domestic supplies and tentative signs of returning demand, encouraging the return of production.

site_title: A time for CSR to shine
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, some firms in ASEAN, such as Singapore Telecommunications and Gojek, stepped up their corporate social responsibility (CSR) efforts, building social capital at various levels. This included providing financial support to employees, offering emergency shelters, and temporarily deploying idle staff to other sectors. A people-cum-private CSR model emerged in the F&B sector, connecting businesses to raise donations and provide low-rate goods and services to the needy. Traditional CSR practices, such as distributing hand sanitizers and essential goods, were also observed. These efforts have accumulated social capital, motivated employees, and improved firm reputation, and can lead to a more collaborative and sustainable economic system.

site_title: Bigger role for service robots in pandemic
summary: Service robots are gaining prominence in Singapore as the Covid-19 pandemic compels firms to reduce contact points with customers. Robots are fulfilling frontline roles and serving safe distancing purposes, moving beyond mere curiosity. This shift is driven by the need for reduced contact and increased productivity. As a result, service industry robots are gaining traction and playing a more significant role in Singapore's service sector.

site_title: Pandemic boosts host of little-known Japanese tech stocks
summary: Japan's TSE Mothers Index has surged nearly 100% since mid-March, outperforming China's ChiNext Index, driven by investments in biotech, e-commerce, and online learning companies. The index has reached a new high for the year, with top performers including BASE Inc (+987%), Vega Corp (+755%), and Ficha Inc (+627%). These companies have benefited from the pandemic's shift to online platforms and stay-at-home trends, with many reporting significant increases in operating profits.

site_title: S Korea warns of 'massive' coronavirus outbreak, strictest restrictions
summary: South Korea is at risk of a "massive nationwide outbreak" due to a surge in new virus cases, with 397 reported on Sunday, the highest number since March 7. The country has exceeded 300 cases for three consecutive days and cases are rising in 17 cities and provinces. In response, the government has expanded Level 2 social-distancing rules to the rest of the country, prohibiting gatherings of 50 or more people indoors and 100 or more outdoors. The government is studying the need to raise restrictions to Level 3, which would prohibit meetings and events of 10 people or more.

site_title: Billionaire car-part supplier aims to triple sales in five years
summary: Billionaire car-part supplier Motherson Sumi Systems aims to triple annual sales to $36 billion by 2025, according to CEO Vivek Chaand Sehgal. The company, which has exceeded its previous five-year targets, plans to achieve this goal through acquisitions, including buying up distressed companies due to the coronavirus pandemic. Sehgal's strategy involves targeting small- to medium-sized companies that are struggling financially, which will provide Motherson with new opportunities for growth. The company's customers include major carmakers such as General Motors, Jaguar Land Rover, and Volkswagen.

site_title: Australia's Afterpay buys Spanish firm to expand into Europe, shares leap to record high
summary: Australia's Afterpay acquires Spanish firm Pagantis to expand into Europe, bolstering its operations during the pandemic-driven boom in online shopping. The deal, valued at $80.9 million, aims to launch Afterpay in key European countries by the third quarter of 2021. The acquisition provides regulatory licensing and infrastructure, sending Afterpay's shares to a record high of A$83. This expansion follows a surge in popularity of alternative credit firms like Afterpay, as young consumers turn to buy-now-pay-later services due to limited access to credit cards and loans.

site_title: B Capital appoints Arijit Sengupta as new operating partner
summary: B Capital Group appointed Arijit Sengupta as its new operating partner to help lead its portfolio companies in Asia. Sengupta brings experience as a founder and operator of several technology companies, including WNS Global Services and Mu Sigma. He will provide guidance on strategy, operations, and business development to portfolio companies. This move aims to help B Capital's portfolio companies scale and grow, particularly in Asia, amid challenges such as capital scarcity and lack of guidance. Sengupta's leadership is expected to be instrumental in identifying key corporate partnerships and driving innovation.

site_title: Bilateral agreements have not jeopardised employment opportunities for Singaporeans: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat has addressed concerns that bilateral agreements with other countries have jeopardized employment opportunities for Singaporeans. He stated that such agreements do not compromise protection for Singaporean jobs, and that the government has measures in place to monitor and address discriminatory hiring practices. Heng also announced additional funding for training Singaporeans, with a focus on areas such as technology and risk management, amid the post-COVID-19 economic slump.

site_title: Electric vehicle makers find a back door to Wall Street
summary: Electric vehicle maker Lordstown Motors has agreed to merge with a special-purpose acquisition company (SPAC), DiamondPeak Holdings, in a deal valued at $675 million. The merger will net Lordstown Motors $1.6 billion and list the company on Nasdaq. The deal is part of a surge in SPAC activity, with $31.3 billion in transactions this year, and is seen as a way for Lordstown Motors to quickly go public and raise capital. The company, which has received backing from investors including Goldman Sachs, plans to start producing electric pickups next year.

site_title: Australia's Fortescue Metals posts record profit as chairman gains US$800m
summary: Fortescue Metals Group reported a record profit for the full year ending June, driven by record iron ore shipments and a surge in ore prices in 2020. The company's shares surged 70% this year, and its chairman, Andrew Forrest, will receive a windfall of over A$1 billion ($983 million) from the increased dividend payout. The booming iron ore prices have benefited the Australian economy, which is experiencing its first recession in a generation, as China ramps up infrastructure spending to counter the coronavirus-induced economic slump.

images.alt_text: Fortescue Metals Group posted a record full-year profit and quadrupled its final dividend on Monday, helped by robust iron ore output and firm prices on the back of Chinese appetite for the steelmaking ingredient.

site_title: Billionaire Ken Griffin's Citadel opens Singapore office
summary: Billionaire Ken Griffin's finance companies, Citadel and Citadel Securities, plan to open a Singapore office this year, expanding their presence in Asia. The new office will be shared between the two firms and will also grow their existing Hong Kong operations. Citadel Securities is also expanding in Shanghai and Sydney to broaden trading activities. The move is seen as a strategic push to further extend the companies' presence in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Japan Prime Minister Abe to visit hospital again on Monday: Yomiuri
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is scheduled to visit a Tokyo hospital on Monday to receive the results of a medical check-up, amid concerns about his health and ability to continue as premier due to fatigue from handling the coronavirus crisis. Abe, 65, had undergone a seven-and-a-half-hour examination last week, and his office has not given a detailed explanation of his hospital visit. The visit is part of his regular check-ups, but Abe's health has been a subject of speculation, with some reports suggesting he may be suffering from fatigue and possibly ulcerative colitis.

site_title: AEM appoints chief technology officer
summary: AEM Holdings appoints Samer Kabbani, 46, as its chief technology officer, leading the development and organisation of the company's overall technology strategy. Kabbani, an industry veteran with over 20 years of experience, joins the mainboard-listed firm as it accelerates its growth and delivers application-specific solutions. His appointment comes two months after the company named Leong Sook Han as its chief financial officer, and AEM shares rose 1.3% to close at S$4.05 on Friday.

site_title: Shenzhen's ChiNext challenges Shanghai for tech listings; adds fuel to 'technology war' with US
summary: China's Shenzhen exchange, ChiNext, will officially challenge Shanghai for tech listings with a new US-style IPO system, amid a "technology war" with the US. Eighteen companies will begin trading on the Nasdaq-style start-up board on Monday, boosting financing for tech firms and strengthening China's capital markets. The reform could contribute to a decoupling between the US and China in technology development, with potential repercussions for capital markets and the telecommunication and software sectors.

site_title: Neo chairman continues to build interest
summary: The Straits Times Index declined 2.6% from Aug 14 to 20, bringing its 2020 year-to-date decline to 19.1%. The iEdge S-Reit Leaders Index fell 1.6% during the same period, with a 2020 year-to-date decline of 7.4%.

site_title: With China tensions rising, US joins Taiwan to mark battle anniversary
summary: US de facto ambassador to Taiwan, Brent Christensen, participated in commemorations of the 62nd anniversary of the start of the second Taiwan Straits crisis, marking the last time Taiwanese forces joined battle with China on a large scale. The event, held on Kinmen island, comes amid rising tensions between the US and China. The US has strengthened ties with Taiwan, providing significant military support, and China has stepped up military activity around the island, which Taiwan's government sees as intimidation to force acceptance of Chinese rule.

site_title: SATS sinks into the red with S$43.7m Q1 loss on lower aviation revenue
summary: SATS, a ground handler and food solutions provider, reported a Q1 loss of S$43.7 million, down from a profit of S$54.7 million a year ago. Revenue fell 54% to S$209.4 million, mainly due to a decline in aviation revenue of 72.9%. The company's non-aviation revenue grew 73.3%. SATS' group expenditure decreased 39.9%, with staff costs down 58.7%. No dividend was declared for the quarter, and shares closed up 0.3%.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for August 21, 2020, states that the capesize market decreased to $17,918, down $1,998 week on week. The market direction became clearer as the week progressed.

site_title: Tight security as New Zealand mosque gunman sentencing set to begin
summary: New Zealand is set to begin the sentencing of Brenton Tarrant, the Australian white supremacist who killed 51 Muslim worshippers in Christchurch in 2019. Tarrant, representing himself, will hear statements from 66 survivors before High Court Judge Cameron Mander hands down a sentence. The hearing is expected to last four days, with lawyers anticipating a life sentence without parole, the first of its kind in New Zealand. The court has imposed strict security measures and reporting restrictions due to the sensitive nature of the case.

site_title: Emirates nearing deal on Boeing 777X, 787 deliveries
summary: Emirates has finalized its preferred mix of new Boeing wide-body planes, favoring smaller aircraft over jumbo jets due to the Covid-19 pandemic slump in demand. The airline plans to swap more of its 115 ordered 777X jets for 787 Dreamliners, according to Chief Operating Officer Adel Al Redha. This decision aims to adapt to changing market conditions and prioritize more efficient aircraft for its fleet.

site_title: EU trade commissioner apologises for virus breach
summary: EU trade commissioner Phil Hogan has apologized for attending an Irish parliamentary golf society dinner that breached coronavirus guidelines, just 24 hours after new restrictions were announced. The event, attended by a cabinet minister, a supreme court judge, and lawmakers, has sparked calls for his resignation. Hogan acknowledged his actions have "touched a nerve" for the Irish people and said he was "profoundly sorry" for his actions. A report is to be prepared detailing the event, and Hogan has spoken to Irish Prime Minister Micheal Martin, who has decided to recall parliament.

site_title: Swee Hong gets delisting notice
summary: Swee Hong, a construction engineering company, has received a delisting notice from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading due to failing to meet financial criteria and market capitalization requirements. The company was placed on the watch list in 2016 but failed to improve its financials and market capitalization over the next three years. Trading in Swee Hong shares has been suspended since May 2020, with the last close price at S$0.003. The company must now offer a fair and reasonable exit offer to shareholders by September 21.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SATS, Yanlord, AEM, Cortina, Spackman, Vicplas
summary: SATS fell into the red with a S$43.7 million loss in its first quarter, while Yanlord Land Group acquired a prime residential development site in Shanghai. AEM Holdings announced Samer Kabbani as its new chief technology officer, causing its shares to rise. Cortina Holdings declined 6.3% after saying it explored merger and acquisition opportunities. Spackman Entertainment Group's proposed divestment raised concerns about a considerable loss. Vicplas International's share price surged 47.5% after no apparent reason was cited.

site_title: Japan's athletes give Tokyo Olympic stadium a test run
summary: Japan's top athletes tested the new Tokyo Olympic stadium in a track meet held behind closed doors due to the pandemic. The event, held one year before the postponed Olympics, featured high jumpers, sprinters, and javelin throwers. Despite the absence of fans, athletes expressed excitement and relief to be competing. The event comes as Japan takes cautious steps to reopen its economy, with professional sports resuming in front of limited crowds. The stadium's construction is still ongoing, with details on the Games' spectator capacity yet to be decided.

site_title: Gold mixed amid US dollar recovery?
summary: Gold prices have surged nearly 32% since the beginning of 2020, driven by geopolitical uncertainties and a weakening US dollar. Despite a large pullback in August, the precious metal remains above the $1,880 level, with bullish sentiment on gold and bearish sentiment on the US dollar suggesting a potential gold move back above the $2,000 handle. Technical analysis indicates that gold prices are in an uptrend channel and holding above key support levels, supporting a continued upward trend.

site_title: Dollar beats euro for first week since mid-June after bullish data
summary: The US dollar surpassed the euro for the first week since mid-June, driven by strong US business activity data. The data showed a resurgence in new orders in the manufacturing and services sectors, outperforming Europe's economic recovery. The euro fell to a one-week low against the dollar, while the dollar index rose 0.60% to 93.24. This marks a significant turnaround for the dollar, which had been struggling due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and unprecedented policy stimulus.

site_title: Saudi Aramco eyes growth opportunities with new development organisation
summary: Saudi Aramco is establishing a new corporate development organisation to oversee assets and drive growth in emerging markets and technologies. Led by senior vice president Abdulaziz al-Gudaimi, the organisation aims to maximise value for shareholders. The move follows the company's 73% profit decline in the second quarter due to the coronavirus crisis. Al-Qahtani will lead the downstream portfolio, while Nasir Naimi will serve as acting head of upstream. The new organisation will support rapid decision-making on growth opportunities and portfolio activities, starting operations on September 13.

site_title: Singtel's sagging stock isn't an opportunity for investors but a sign of increasing risks
summary: Singtel's recent financial update revealed a decline in operating revenue and Ebitda, attributed to lower equipment sales and reduced roaming revenues in Singapore and Australia. The company's net debt has nearly doubled over the past decade, reaching S$12.5 billion, and its free cash flow remains unchanged. Analysts see potential value in Singtel's associate stakes, but investors should be cautious due to the company's deteriorating financial position and potential threat to dividends. Singtel may need to fortify its balance sheet through asset sales or capital raising to restore investor confidence.

site_title: ETF demand driving gold fever in 2020; banks with vault space stand to benefit
summary: ETF demand for gold and silver has surged in 2020, driving up fees and benefiting financial firms, banks, and security companies. The top 10 gold ETFs charge around $610 million in annual fees, while the top 5 silver ETFs charge $110 million. Banks like JPMorgan Chase & Co and HSBC Holdings are seeing a boost in vaulting fees, with HSBC's vault in London holding $300 million worth of gold. The strain on the system has led to increased demand for vault space, but logistics providers say there is still room available in London.

site_title: VC firms stay bullish on Indonesian startups despite economic downturn
summary: Despite Indonesia's economic downturn, venture capital firms remain bullish on the country's startup sector, with funding reaching US$1.21 billion in the first half of 2020. The pandemic has accelerated digital transformation, driving growth in sectors such as healthcare, education, and logistics. Investors are shifting focus to essential spending and recession-resistant sectors, and are re-evaluating investment priorities. Notable startups have already benefited from the trend, with companies like Tokopedia and Bhinneka expanding their customer base and offering tech-based solutions.

site_title: China investors brace for record defaults in risky end to 2020
summary: China's corporate bond market is bracing for record defaults as the economy recovers, but policymakers are unlikely to intervene. Delinquencies have risen after a quiet second quarter, with 3.65 trillion yuan of notes maturing by year-end. Analysts expect onshore defaults to reach a new annual record, with non-state companies, lower-rated developers, and local government financing vehicles particularly vulnerable. The government's focus on avoiding defaults is easing, and funding stress will likely concentrate in non-state borrowers, impacting more property firms.

site_title: Thailand seeks safe way of reopening borders to boost economy
summary: Thailand is considering a plan to reopen its borders to boost its economy, which has been severely impacted by the pandemic. The country is expected to allow foreign visitors as early as October, with tourists from countries with limited infections required to wear GPS tracking wristbands and undergo 14-day quarantine. The plan, which may be tested in Phuket province, aims to control the spread of the virus while promoting domestic tourism. Thailand's economy is predicted to shrink by 8.5% this year, its worst contraction on record, due to the pandemic's impact on manufacturing and international travel.

site_title: US House approves US$25b for postal service
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a bill providing $25 billion in funding for the postal service to ensure timely delivery of mail-in ballots in the November presidential election. The bill, which passed 257-150 along party lines, aims to counter changes made by President Trump's appointee, Postmaster General Louis DeJoy, that Democrats claim threaten the integrity of the election. The Senate is expected to reject the bill, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell calling it a "partisan stunt."

site_title: JL Family Office buys 65 Club Street for $15.7m
summary: JL Family Office has bought 65 Club Street for $15.7 million, a 999-year conservation shophouse in Singapore. The property, which has three storeys and a mezzanine level, was sold by boutique property agency JerryTan Residential. The sale reflects stable demand for shophouses, driven by pent-up demand and a low interest rate environment. The property will be the new home of JL Family Office, headed by Mr. Lim's son, Andy, who is currently located at Balmoral Plaza.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Cortina Holdings clarifies it has not inked a definitive agreement to acquire Sincere Watch Limited, despite considering possible merger and acquisition opportunities. VicPlas International's share price surged 47.5% last Friday, but the company has no explanation for the unusual price movements. Swee Hong has received a notification to be delisted from the watch list due to failing to meet financial criteria and market capitalization requirements. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss.

site_title: A rift with consequences - and opportunities
summary: The US-China tensions have a significant impact on businesses globally, with potential ripple effects on the global economy. Companies must adapt to a possible bifurcated global economic system, diversify supply chains, and tap into new digital technologies. While the tensions increase uncertainty and costs, they also create opportunities for businesses in the region, particularly in Southeast Asia. Experts emphasize the need for stability, collaboration, and trust to navigate the situation. The US-China relationship's impact on businesses will be severe, with potential disruptions to supply chains, trade, and investment, but also opportunities for growth in emerging markets and tested hubs.

site_title: Boeing testing hand-held wand to sanitise cockpits, cabins
summary: Boeing is developing a hand-held wand emitting ultraviolet light to disinfect aircraft cockpits, cabins, and surfaces. The technology, tested with 13 airlines, eliminates the need for damaging disinfectants. Boeing plans to license and manufacture the wands, with commercial use expected in the future. This follows heightened cleaning practices, including electrostatic disinfectants and anti-microbial sprays, as airlines aim to restore confidence in flying amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: China approves BlackRock, Temasek, China Construction Bank JV
summary: China has approved a wealth management joint venture between BlackRock, Temasek Holdings, and China Construction Bank, marking a step towards opening up the financial market to foreign companies. This deal comes as China gradually relaxes restrictions on international firms, following the scrapping of foreign bank restrictions in October last year. The move is seen as a move to increase the presence of top global financial players in the Chinese economy, which remains dominated by domestic state firms.

images.alt_text: China has approved a wealth management joint venture between US asset manager BlackRock, Singapore state investor Temasek Holdings and China Construction Bank (CCB).

site_title: Noir The Batman footage thrills fans at DC virtual event
summary: Hollywood A-listers, including Robert Pattinson and Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, hosted a virtual DC FanDome event, premiering footage and panels for upcoming DC movies. The Batman, starring Pattinson, showcased dark, detective-style mystery elements, while Johnson teased Black Adam, a film about a 5,000-year-old rebel slave. Footage also premiered for Wonder Woman 1984, The Suicide Squad, and The Flash, which features a young hero who hops through time and space. The event comes after real-world extravaganzas were cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Skyscrapers give way to warehouses as Covid-19 changes UK real estate
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the shift to e-commerce, leading to a surge in demand for warehouse space in the UK. This has made warehouses one of the hottest assets in real estate, with the value of rent surging at more than twice the rate of offices. As a result, developers are prioritizing warehouse projects, and investors such as Amazon and Blackstone are snapping up space. The UK's e-commerce boom has also led to a decline in traditional retail and landlords, with companies like Intu Properties and Hammerson struggling. Despite the uncertainty of the economic outlook, logistics firms believe that the changes brought about by the pandemic will become permanent.

site_title: Doubts raised over Spackman's proposed divestment of an associate for at least S$32 million
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group has proposed a non-binding deal to sell its 43.88% stake in Spackman Media for at least S$2.30 per share, or 27.9 billion won, to Canada-listed Spackman Equities Group. The deal has raised concerns due to the significant loss and the buyer becoming a subsidiary of the Catalist-listed firm. Corporate governance advocate Mak Yuen Teen questioned the low selling price, citing Spackman Entertainment's previous acquisition of Spackman Media at a higher price. The deal also raises questions about the financial ability of Spackman Equities and the independence of shareholders voting on the proposal.

site_title: Missing school is greater risk to kids than Covid-19: UK govt health advisers
summary: UK's chief medical officers warn that missing school poses a greater risk to children than catching Covid-19, urging them to return to school after the summer holidays. This joint statement supports British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's national priority of getting children back to school.

site_title: Cortina Holding says it is exploring M&A opportunities but no firm deal as yet
summary: Cortina Holding, a luxury watch retailer, has confirmed it occasionally explores merger and acquisition opportunities, including a rumored acquisition of Sincere Watch Limited. However, no definitive agreement has been inked. The company made this clarification in a regulatory statement following a report by The Business Times. Cortina's share price declined 6.25% to S$1.50 on Friday, amidst the uncertainty. The company will make announcements if any significant developments arise or merger opportunities crystallize.

site_title: Most small businesses satisfied with Singapore's Covid-19 relief measures: survey
summary: Small businesses in Singapore are more satisfied with the government's Covid-19 relief measures than their peers in Asean, with 72% expressing satisfaction. They ranked government measures such as loan and wage assistance as most preferred. However, respondents across Asean and Singapore highlighted a need for more investment in digital infrastructure to support innovation efforts.
