Most requested more funding support, education and training programs to upskill employees, and better digital tools to navigate the new normal.

site_title: V3 Group appoints George Yeo as senior adviser
summary: V3 Group, a Singapore fintech company, has appointed George Yeo as its senior adviser. Yeo, a former minister and independent director of AIA and Pinduoduo Inc., will leverage his expertise on China, ASEAN, and global e-commerce trends to advise V3 on harnessing growth catalysts and creating sustainable value for stakeholders. V3, led by Ron Sim, is part of a consortium applying for a digital bank licence in Singapore.

site_title: Closely watched Tenet earns critical praise as US cinemas reopen
summary: Christopher Nolan's thriller Tenet received critical praise as US cinemas reopened with safety measures. The film, starring John David Washington, opened in 70 countries on Aug 26 and in the US on Sept 3, earning an 87% approval rate on Rotten Tomatoes. Critics praised its "globetrotting" and "jaw-dropping" nature, while some found its time-bending plot convoluted. The film's success will be closely watched as a gauge of audience willingness to return to theaters.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine shareholders must now decide on rights takeup
summary: Sembcorp Marine shareholders must decide on the takeup of rights after the company's capital raising exercise was approved at the extraordinary general meeting. The shareholders have three options: do nothing, sell their rights, or subscribe to the issue. This decision must be made within a specific timeline, and the experience of the Securities and Investor's Association suggests that many small shareholders may be in the dark about the process and timeline involved.

site_title: Money FM: Podcasts of the week (Aug 24)
summary: Money FM podcast highlights include "Embrace technology to enable supply chain resilience" featuring Dan Roberts, global head of business banking at HSBC, and "Why the US is losing the 5G battle to China" featuring Paul Schulte, author of The Race for 5G Supremacy. The article also mentions recent podcasts on market trends, wealth management, and private equity.

site_title: Black Sea at 'just the beginning' of new gas finds, Turkey says
summary: Turkey's discovery of natural gas deep under its territorial waters in the Black Sea is expected to alter the geopolitics of energy trade in the region, with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's spokesman saying it's "just the beginning." The find, the largest of its kind in the Black Sea, has given fresh impetus to Turkey's search for more energy resources and will allow the country to function as an energy producer, rather than just a consumer and conduit. Turkey is also conducting exploratory work in the eastern Mediterranean Sea, where it is seeking to find energy resources and share them with neighboring countries.

site_title: China vows continued support for Hong Kong as financial hub
summary: China's banking regulator pledged continued support for Hong Kong as a finance hub, reiterating a commitment to opening the Chinese financial sector amid a US-China standoff. The China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) stated it will provide support for Chinese financial institutions operating in Hong Kong while complying with regulations. This comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. The CBIRC also vowed to deepen cooperation with the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the People's Bank of China to develop green and transition finance.

site_title: Champagne-makers get ready to gather bumper pandemic harvest
summary: French champagne producers are gathering a bumper grape harvest, but due to the Covid-19 pandemic, sales of champagne have plummeted, leading to a glut of the drink. To avoid a price war, producers have set a quota limiting the amount of grapes that can be harvested from a hectare to 8,000 kg, resulting in an estimated 20% of the harvest going to waste. The quota, one-fifth less than last year's, is attributed to climate change and hot sunny weather.

site_title: US markets continue to be powered by tech stocks
summary: The S&P 500 index reached a new high of 3,397.16 points, driven by tech stocks, including Apple, which surpassed the $2 trillion market value. Despite concerns over investor exuberance and regulatory scrutiny, Apple plans a 4-for-1 stock split. Tech companies face risks from the US-China geopolitical rivalry, including a patent infringement lawsuit in China. Supply chain adjustments are underway, with some companies shifting production to Bangladesh, Mexico, and Vietnam, while others may delay alternatives to China.

site_title: CCSS teams up with Trafigura to empower vulnerable families
summary: CCSS teams up with Trafigura to empower vulnerable families in Singapore. The initiative, Project Trafigura Liven 2020, provides a customised case management service to around 100 local families for up to 12 months, equipping them with skills to improve adult employment opportunities. The project includes workshops, temporary financial assistance, and support from grassroots organisations and school-based Student Care Centres. The collaboration aims to inspire, invigorate, enhance, and nourish these families, who are particularly vulnerable due to the COVID-19 outbreak.

site_title: Movers in New York City are so busy they're turning people away
summary: Movers in New York City are struggling to keep up with the high demand for relocation services, with many turning away potential clients due to the busy season. In a heat wave, the physical demands of the job are exacerbated, with foreman Vladislav Grigor describing the experience as "terrible." The busy season is a welcome relief for Empire Movers, but it highlights the challenges faced by the industry.

site_title: Thai central bank reiterates banks are strong, able to handle virus impact
summary: The Thai central bank has reassured that the country's banking system is strong, with high capital buffers (19.2%) and ample liquidity, despite the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. The Bank of Thailand is working with lenders to restructure debt and ensure borrowers can service their obligations, aiming to maintain financial system stability. Governor Veerathai Santiprabhob emphasized the need for a greater fiscal policy role in supporting the economy's recovery.

images.alt_text: Thai banks remain strong with high capital buffers and can handle the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Pandemic digital boom: Some tech firms hiring boldly to capture growth
summary: Tech companies in Singapore are hiring despite the ongoing pandemic, with e-commerce firm Shopee and US tech giant Amazon seeking staff. The Manpower Ministry has announced over 4,600 job openings, including 860 traineeship opportunities, under the SGUnited Jobs and Skills scheme. Startups and companies in e-commerce, online education, and food delivery are driving the hiring, while layoffs remain a regular fixture as firms adapt to changing market needs. The tech sector is also seeing an increase in applicants, with industry watchers predicting structural unemployment will be temporary.

images.alt_text: Amazon's staff preparing orders at their Prime Now facility, their largest global Prime Now facility located at the Mapletree Logistics Hub on Toh Guan Road East on 27 July 2017.##########ophire##########Kua Chee Siong
The hiring sprees, including by Amazon, bring some respite to a labour market threatened by mass redundancies amid Covid-19 shutdowns.

site_title: Vicplas says it doesn't know what caused Friday's unusual price movements
summary: Vicplas International, a pipe manufacturer and distributor, stated that it is unaware of any information that could explain the unusual price spike of nearly 47.5% in its share price on Friday, which led to a trading volume of 126.9 million shares. This is the second time this month the company has been queried by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for trading activity, with its financial results for the year ending July 30 scheduled for release on September 29. Vicplas has given similar replies to previous queries.

site_title: US international airline passenger contact tracing plan stalls, sources say
summary: The Trump administration's efforts to require airlines to collect contact tracing information from US-bound international passengers have stalled, with a mandate unlikely before the end of 2020. Despite CDC efforts since February, airlines have protested, citing data collection concerns. The White House has tasked an interagency working group to find an interim solution, but no plan is expected to be adopted before year-end, with some officials citing privacy concerns. Airlines continue to work with the federal government to implement contact tracing, but a solution remains elusive.

site_title: Exxon limits Guyana crude output due to more gas injection issues
summary: ExxonMobil is limiting output at its Guyana project to 100,000 barrels-per-day due to mechanical issues with gas compressing equipment, preventing the reinjection of natural gas. Initially, the project aimed to reach full capacity of 120,000 barrels-per-day in August. The issues have prompted the company to limit output to prevent excessive gas flaring, a significant source of climate-warming greenhouse gas emissions. Exxon plans to complete final commissioning of the gas handling system and produce at full capacity once it's fully commissioned.

site_title: 87 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 1 in community
summary: Singapore reported 87 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 56,353, including one community case and 13 imported cases. The community case is a 56-year-old woman who worked at the Institute of Technical Education, despite exhibiting symptoms. Two other cases linked to a dormitory cluster were also reported. The number of new daily community cases remains stable at an average of two cases per day. Globally, over 23.3 million people have been infected, with more than 807,000 deaths.

site_title: Success comes from overseas for AMTD
summary: AMTD Group, led by Chairman and CEO Calvin Choi, believes a digital bank would be unsuccessful if operating only in its home country, citing the need for regional connectivity. The firm is bidding for a digital wholesale bank licence in Singapore to tap into the SME market and has expressed interest in a digital banking licence in Malaysia. AMTD's push for greater regional connectivity aims to offer comprehensive, cross-border services.

site_title: Costly, but transparent masks are boon for hard of hearing
summary: Transparent facemasks and shields, though costly, may benefit the deaf and hard of hearing by facilitating communication during the coronavirus pandemic. Proponents, such as French Secretary of State Sophie Cluzel, have showcased their use in various settings, including Parliament and hospitals. The concept has gained traction, with some individuals, like American football coach Nic Saban, incorporating them into their daily routines. This innovation may provide a valuable tool for those struggling to communicate in a world with increased mask-wearing.

site_title: With China tensions rising, US joins Taiwan to mark battle anniversary
summary: The US joined Taiwan in commemorating the 62nd anniversary of the start of the second Taiwan Straits crisis, with US de facto ambassador Brent Christensen participating in the event. Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen and Christensen laid wreaths and offered respects, symbolizing US support for the island. The event comes amid rising tensions between China and Taiwan, with China increasing military activity around the island. The US has no formal ties with Taiwan but is its largest arms supplier, and has been bolstering relations despite Beijing's anger.

site_title: Brazil prosecutors accuse two in alleged Petrobras-Maersk corruption scheme
summary: Brazilian prosecutors charged two individuals, Viggo Andersen and Wanderley Gandra, in an alleged corruption scheme involving Petrobras and Maersk. The scheme allegedly led to $31.7 million in losses for Petrobras between 2006 and 2014. Andersen, a former Maersk executive, denies the accusations, while Gandra's lawyer could not be reached for comment. A judge must decide whether to proceed with the case. Maersk has cooperated with authorities and Petrobras has been collaborating since 2014.

site_title: China approves BlackRock, Temasek and CCB joint wealth venture
summary: China has approved a wealth management joint venture between BlackRock, Temasek Holdings, and China Construction Bank (CCB), marking the country's gradual opening of its financial sector to international firms. The announcement comes after China scrapped restrictions on foreign banks' operations in October last year. This move follows previous approvals for international firms like Amundi and Bank of China Wealth Management to set up joint ventures in China. The joint venture will offer wealth management services, but details remain unclear.

site_title: China's unlicensed asset management firms still a threat, says central bank exec
summary: China's central bank executive, Fan Yifei, warned that unlicensed asset management firms pose a "serious threat to financial stability". Despite China introducing asset management rules in 2018, 5,000 third-party firms remain unlicensed, including those selling insurance and public offerings of funds. The People's Bank of China extended a grace period for implementing these rules until the end of 2021, but standards remain unchanged.

site_title: TikTok to challenge Trump's executive order
summary: TikTok plans to file a lawsuit against President Donald Trump's executive order, which prohibits transactions with the app and its Chinese parent ByteDance. The company claims it was not given due process and had tried to engage with the US administration for nearly a year. ByteDance has also announced it will officially file a lawsuit against the Trump administration on Monday. The move comes after Trump issued an executive order giving ByteDance 90 days to divest the US operations of TikTok. The company is seeking to ensure the rule of law and fair treatment for its users and investors.

site_title: Gold fever in 2020 means exchange-traded funds
summary: Gold fever in 2020 has led to a surge in exchange-traded funds (ETFs) backed by physical gold and silver, accumulating over $50 billion of bullion. This has generated significant windfall fees for ETFs, financial firms, and banks storing gold and silver, with the top 10 gold ETFs earning around $610 million annually. The demand has strained the system, with some ETFs holding gold in alternative vaults, such as the Bank of England, due to limited space in traditional vaults. The surge in demand has benefited the mining industry and gold-related businesses, but also poses logistical challenges.

images.alt_text: ETFs backed by physical gold and silver accumulated more than US$50 billion of bullion this year.

site_title: Indonesia signs agreement with Sinovac for Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Indonesia signed an agreement with China's Sinovac Biotech to receive 50 million doses of a Covid-19 vaccine concentrate, allowing state-owned Bio Farma to produce doses locally. The vaccine will be shipped in five stages between November and March. This move comes as Indonesia struggles with over 150,000 Covid-19 cases and 6,500 fatalities. The country is also exploring partnerships with other Chinese pharmaceutical companies, including Sinopharm Group, to boost its vaccination efforts.

images.alt_text: Indonesia signed an agreement with China's Sinovac Biotech for 50 million doses of a Covid-19 vaccine concentrate that will allow state-owned Bio Farma to produce doses locally.

site_title: South Korea expands social distancing rules as virus outbreak grows
summary: South Korea expands social distancing rules nationwide in response to a growing coronavirus outbreak, with 315 new domestic infections reported as of midnight Friday. The country's total cases now stand at 17,002, with 309 deaths. The Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (KCDC) aims to curb the spread by restricting large gatherings, banning in-person church meetings, and closing nightclubs and other crowded areas. The guidelines will be enforced nationwide starting Sunday, although some areas with fewer infections will be recommended rather than obligatory.

site_title: Yankees-Mets baseball series postponed due to positive Covid-19 tests
summary: The New York Yankees' three-game series against the New York Mets has been postponed due to two positive COVID-19 tests, with the games scheduled for this weekend. The Mets returned to New York after a series against the Miami Marlins was postponed for the same reason. The postponed games will allow for additional testing and contact tracing within the Mets' organization.

site_title: Apple reverses move for WordPress to add in-app payments
summary: Apple has reversed its decision to force WordPress to add in-app purchases to its app, a move that could ease tensions between Apple and developers amid a public battle with Epic Games. The decision comes after WordPress removed the display of its service payment options from the app, making it a free standalone app. Apple stated that the issue with the WordPress app has been resolved and that the company will continue to be responsive to the app store rules. This move may help calm tensions with developers who have sided with Epic Games in a battle over Apple's payment structure.

site_title: Cricket: Australia's Smith admits he'll miss jeering English fans
summary: Steve Smith, Australia's master batsman, admits he'll miss being jeered by English fans during their upcoming limited-overs tour. Smith, who faced hostile crowds during their 2019 trip, scored 774 runs in four Tests last year, citing the taunts as motivation. The team will play in empty stadiums due to the coronavirus pandemic, and Smith is looking forward to the challenge, stating they'll "do what we need to and play it day by day, stick together as a bunch and help each other out." The tour starts on September 4 with three Twenty20s in Southampton.

site_title: South Korea reports biggest rise in coronavirus cases since March
summary: South Korea reported 397 new coronavirus cases on Sunday, its highest daily rise since early March, with the total number of infections reaching 17,399 and 309 deaths. The cases are linked to a Seoul church and political demonstrations attended by its members. The Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (KCDC) attributed the surge to increased transmission and a lack of herd immunity.

site_title: US regulator proposes scaling back personal information from trading database
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has proposed scaling back personal information from a trading database, the Consolidated Audit Trail (CAT), amid concerns over security. The proposal, subject to public consultation, aims to increase security requirements and limit the scope of sensitive information required by the database. This move follows pressure from the brokerage industry, which warned that the project would be vulnerable to hacks. The SEC's plan seeks to protect brokers, their clients, and staff from potential cyber breaches.

site_title: Chinese EV maker XPeng seeks to raise US$1.1b in US IPO
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker XPeng Motors is seeking to raise $1.1 billion in its US initial public offering (IPO), slightly topping its rival Li Auto Inc.'s listing last month. XPeng plans to sell 85 million American depositary shares for $11 to $13 each, giving the company a market value of around $9.17 billion. This comes as the electric vehicle market has seen a surge in investor interest following strong share price gains by Tesla and NIO Inc.

site_title: DoorDash plans Q4 IPO after pandemic delay
summary: DoorDash plans to proceed with an initial public offering (IPO) in the fourth quarter of 2020, with a potential listing in November or December, according to people familiar with the matter. The company had filed confidentially with the US Securities and Exchange Commission earlier this year, but the plans were delayed due to the pandemic. DoorDash joins a list of companies expected to go public, including Unity Technologies, Snowflake Inc, and Airbnb, and aims to raise capital after raising $400 million in June, valuing the company at almost $16 billion.

site_title: Goldman plans to raise about US$2b for a new venture fund
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to raise approximately US$2 billion for a new venture and growth fund, aiming to increase its presence in technology investing. The fund, expected to start fundraising next year, will focus on investing between US$30 million to US$200 million in companies, with an average deal size of about US$50 million. This move aligns with the bank's ambitious growth plan, which also includes infrastructure, real estate, and private equity funds, and aims to free up capital and generate a consistent revenue stream.

site_title: TikTok to challenge US order banning transactions with the video app: sources
summary: TikTok is preparing to challenge a US order banning transactions with the app and its Chinese parent ByteDance. President Trump's executive order, issued on August 14, gave ByteDance 90 days to divest US operations. ByteDance has been in talks with potential acquirers, including Microsoft and Oracle. TikTok's legal challenge is related to an earlier executive order, which directed the Secretary of Commerce to list transactions to be banned. ByteDance's progress in talks and potential investors could impact the outcome.

images.alt_text: TikTok is preparing to mount a legal challenge as early as Monday to President Donald Trump's executive order prohibiting transactions with the popular short video app and its Chinese parent ByteDance, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Navigating the toxic maze safely
summary: Toxic substances in everyday products and foods can pose significant health risks. BPA and phthalates, found in plastics, cosmetics, and food packaging, can disrupt genetic material and affect reproductive health. Persistent organic pollutants (POPs) in food, such as lead, mercury, and arsenic, can increase cancer risk and cause developmental issues. To navigate this "toxic maze" safely, choose BPA-free and phthalate-free products, limit exposure to POPs through food, and opt for organic or non-contaminated options like wild salmon and rice from non-contaminated soils. By making informed choices, individuals can reduce potential health risks and promote a healthy lifestyle.

site_title: Company that wants to buy Newcastle United admits to photoshopping Obama
summary: A Singapore-registered company, Bellagraph Nova Group (BN Group), has admitted to photoshopping images of former US President Barack Obama in marketing materials for its takeover bid of Newcastle United. The company claimed to have a turnover of $12 billion and described itself as the "world's fastest growing conglomerate." However, BN Group's claims have been inconsistent, with no company registered in France and no permanent office in Paris. The company's CEO acknowledged the photo editing, stating it was a "photoshop picture" and not a malicious attempt.

site_title: Shenzhen's ChiNext challenges Shanghai, adds fuel to 'technology war' with US
summary: Shenzhen's ChiNext, a start-up board, will launch a new US-style IPO system, challenging Shanghai for tech listings and fueling a "technology war" with the US. 18 companies will begin trading on Monday under the new system, which allows for vetting of IPO applications and more flexible stock price fluctuations. The reforms aim to strengthen China's capital markets and contribute to a decoupling between the US and China in technology development, potentially leading to a megatrend of polarisation.

site_title: WeChat users sue to block Trump's ban of messaging app
summary: A group of WeChat users has sued the Trump administration to block a ban on the Chinese messaging app due to concerns it violates free speech and due process rights. The ban, set to take effect in mid-September, restricts Americans from using WeChat and another Chinese social media platform, TikTok, citing national security concerns. The lawsuit claims the executive order lacks concrete evidence to support its claims and was issued during a time of heightened tensions with China. The users argue the ban would effectively ban WeChat's use in the US, affecting millions of Americans.

site_title: More Singapore firms set to adopt fintech to boost efficiency: CPA poll
summary: About 73% of Singapore businesses plan to adopt fintech products or services within the next 12 months, up from 67% previously, to improve operational efficiency. Mobile payments and digital wallets are expected to drive adoption, with 42.7% of businesses citing them as the most likely to be used. The top barriers to adoption are cybersecurity concerns (33.6%) and a lack of fintech understanding within senior management (30%). CPA Australia recommends establishing a fintech committee and providing training to employees to drive adoption and enhance the customer experience.

site_title: Hong Kong gives approval in principle to OSL for first crypto exchange licence
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission has agreed in principle to issue a licence to cryptocurrency firm OSL Digital Securities, a unit of Fidelity-backed BC group. This is the first licence to be granted to a crypto exchange firm under new rules allowing crypto exchanges to opt into regulation. Final approval is subject to certain conditions, with regulators citing a "conservative approach" in a financial hub. The move follows similar efforts by other Asian regulators, including Singapore and Japan, to regulate cryptocurrency companies.

site_title: Oil majors begin offshore evacuations as storms take aim at Gulf of Mexico
summary: Oil majors BP, Shell, and Chevron have begun evacuating offshore oil facilities in the US Gulf of Mexico as two tropical cyclones approach the region. The evacuations are part of a precautionary measure due to the already active 2020 Atlantic hurricane season. Production at the Thunder Horse, Atlantis, Mad Dog, and Na Kika platforms has been shut-in, with Chevron evacuating personnel from four platforms and initiating shut-in procedures. The tropical cyclones could make landfall as hurricanes next week, posing a significant disruption to the region's energy infrastructure.

site_title: Euro weakens on virus woes, pound falls on Brexit stalemate
summary: The euro weakened against the dollar as eurozone economic activity slowed in August, with IHS Markit's PMI index falling to 51.6 points from 54.9 points in July. The pound also fell against the dollar due to a Brexit stalemate between the EU and Britain. European stock markets ended the week in the red, while US stocks reached new closing records, driven by optimism over a potential COVID-19 vaccine. Despite concerns about the US economy, some sectors, such as the US real estate market, showed resilience.

site_title: India to hire Deloitte, SBI Caps to help LIC prepare for IPO
summary: India plans to hire Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu India and SBI Capital Markets to help Life Insurance Corp of India (LIC) prepare for its initial public offering (IPO). The advisers will evaluate LIC's capital structure and rework its financial statements. The government aims to plug a widening budget gap with the potentially India's biggest IPO, as revenue slumped following a nationwide lockdown. The move is part of the administration's efforts to boost market borrowing amid the coronavirus pandemic. A tender document has been issued, and bids are expected to be invited soon.

site_title: Amazon names first black executive to Jeff Bezos's ruling council
summary: Amazon has named Alicia Boler Davis, 51, its first black woman to join the company's top leadership council, the S-team, alongside CEO Jeff Bezos. Davis, who oversees Amazon's warehouse network, is the second executive to be added to the council following criticism of Amazon's largely white, male upper ranks. The move follows the addition of two other women, Colleen Aubrey and Christine Beauchamp, to the team last year. The S-team now comprises 26 members, with a rule requiring consideration of women and people of color in board vacancies.

site_title: Children over 12 should follow same mask rules as adults: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that children over 12 should wear masks in the same contexts as adults to combat the Covid-19 pandemic. The guidance varies by age group, with children under five not recommended to wear masks and those between six and 11 advised to wear them in specific situations. Children with developmental disorders or specific health conditions are exempt from mask-wearing. The recommendation aims to minimize the spread of the virus while considering children's developmental needs and limitations.

images.alt_text: The World Health Organization on Friday recommended that children over 12 should wear masks in the same contexts as adults in the bid to rein in the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Oil falls 1% on sluggish coronavirus recovery, supply concerns
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Friday due to concerns over a sluggish coronavirus recovery and rising crude supply. The euro zone's economic recovery stalled, while US housing and manufacturing data were better than expected. Brent crude futures settled at $44.35 a barrel, down 55 cents, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell to $42.34 a barrel, down 86 cents. Libya's oil exports are expected to resume after a ceasefire, adding to the global supply concerns.

site_title: STI finishes the week with slight recovery of 0.02%
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore closed at 2,528.54 on Friday, ending a four-day decline with a slight recovery of 0.02%. Hongkong Land was the top gainer, increasing 2.93% to close at US$3.86. OCBC Bank, however, ended the week with the largest decline, dropping 1.81% to S$8.67.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: VicPlas International has been queried by the Singapore Exchange for unusual price movements in its shares, the second time this month, after shares rose 48% on Friday. The company was asked to explain the spike. Meanwhile, Pison Investments extended the expiration deadline for tender application forms for Hyflux, citing "very encouraging" responses, and received numerous requests for an extension from eligible creditors.

site_title: WHO hopes end to pandemic in 'less than two years'
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) chief, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, stated that the planet should be able to rein in the novel coronavirus pandemic in less than two years, faster than the 1918 flu pandemic. He attributed this to the advantages of better technology and global connectivity, while also utilizing available tools to maximize the impact of vaccines. This optimistic prediction aims to bring an end to the pandemic sooner than expected.

images.alt_text: "We have a disadvantage of globalisation, closeness, connectedness, but an advantage of better technology, so we hope to finish this pandemic before less than two years," Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus told reporters.

site_title: 'FreeFortnite' tournament taunts Apple amid legal battle
summary: Epic Games, the maker of Fortnite, has launched a "FreeFortnite Cup" tournament to highlight its ongoing legal battle with Apple over the tech titan's App Store fee policy. The tournament is free to enter and features awesome prizes, including a virtual "Tart Tycoon" outfit. Players with top scores will be sent caps with a "Free Fortnite" logo, and Epic is encouraging players to express their displeasure with Apple on Twitter using the #FreeFortnite hashtag. The move comes after Apple removed Fortnite from its App Store due to a payment system that bypasses the App Store's 30% revenue share.

site_title: KrisEnergy makes changes to restructuring proposal
summary: KrisEnergy, an upstream oil and gas company, has revised its restructuring proposal, allocating more equity to unsecured debt holders and reducing dilution for existing shareholders. The changes were made to the proposal, which was released to the Singapore Exchange. The updates aim to address concerns from stakeholders and pave the way for the restructuring plan.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P end week with new records, Dow up 0.7%
summary: US stocks ended the week with new records, with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 posting gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.7% to close at 27,930.33. Tech stocks, including Apple, Amazon, and Alphabet, drove the gains, reaching new highs and surpassing $1 trillion in market value. The rally was fueled by strong existing home sales data and a strong earnings report from Deere & Co. Despite concerns over economic growth and the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, investors remain attracted to tech names.

site_title: Unilateral move to welcome visitors aimed at reviving business
summary: Singapore has unilaterally allowed visitors from Brunei and New Zealand to travel freely without serving a stay-home notice (SHN) period, provided they test negative on arrival. The move aims to revive the aviation sector and bring business back to Singapore. The decision is based on the countries' low epidemic situation and low flight capacity. The government will continue to monitor the situation and explore reciprocal green lane arrangements.

site_title: Gold's bull rally rattled again
summary: Gold's price rebounded due to increasing Sino-US trade tensions and a weaker US dollar, but was rattled by the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting minutes, which showed a less dovish stance than expected. Despite this, long-term fundamentals remain unchanged, and gold's rally has seen its first significant retracement since mid-March. Market analysts expect higher volatility and a potential second wave of the virus to boost gold investment demand.

site_title: Europe: Faltering PMIs add to a lacklustre week for stocks
summary: Europe's stock markets declined as the pan-European Stoxx 600 index marked weekly losses due to downbeat economic data, including a near standstill in the euro zone's service sector activity in August, despite factory activity rebounding. Coronavirus cases rose across the continent, further exacerbating the economic concerns.

site_title: Singapore researchers discover new Covid-19 variant which causes milder infections
summary: Singapore researchers have discovered a new Covid-19 variant, which causes milder infections, with a 382 nucleotide deletion. The variant was detected in a cluster of cases in Singapore in January and February and was found to have better clinical outcomes, with fewer patients requiring supplemental oxygen. The discovery could provide new avenues for vaccine and therapeutic development. Experts note that while mutations can make a virus more or less deadly, the impact is rarely significant, and further study is needed to understand the implications of this variant.

site_title: Banks get tactical to cash in on miles-card market
summary: Singapore banks are adapting to the shift in consumer spending habits during the pandemic by tweaking their miles-card spending and award redemption options. Many banks have increased miles earned on online spending, partnered with travel search engines like Agoda, and introduced bonus miles for specific categories. Despite concerns about airline devaluations, banks remain committed to promoting rewards and air miles cards, which tend to attract more affluent customers. The miles-card market has seen a resurgence, with some banks offering attractive promotions, such as doubling miles earned on certain cards or offering cash rewards for new sign-ups.

site_title: Cocoa prices to remain weak this year but grinders, chocolate makers optimistic about long-term demand trend
summary: Cocoa prices are expected to remain weak this year, with a forecasted average price of US$2,247 per tonne, down from US$2,555 in May, due to a "material decline" in chocolate demand, particularly for higher-value products. However, cocoa grindings in the Asian region continue to be strong, and suppliers are optimistic about long-term demand trends, driven by growth in Asia and a shift towards home baking and online sales. Companies like Wilmar International and Barry Callebaut are investing in their operations to capitalize on these trends, despite the current low prices.

images.alt_text: Wilmar expects Aalst Chocolate to grow rapidly with the ability to leverage its manufacturing, distribution network in Asia (above).
Barry Callebaut in June added a fourth chocolate line to its chocolate factory in Singapore.

site_title: Offices yield to warehouses as Covid-19 changes UK real estate
summary: The UK's real estate market is shifting towards warehouses as e-commerce growth surges. The pandemic has accelerated online shopping, leading to record demand for warehouse space, with online retailers accounting for nearly half of the market. Amazon is driving this trend, with its recent lease of the largest warehouse in Europe. Landlords are reaping the benefits, with Segro's shares soaring to £11.5 billion. Traditional retailers are struggling, while urban warehouses are in high demand, with rents expected to continue rising. The growth is expected to be permanent, despite the UK's recession and Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Yanlord JV clinches site in Shanghai Pudong New District for 4.5b yuan
summary: Yanlord Land Group, a Singapore-based property developer, has acquired a 4.5 billion yuan (S$0.89 billion) low-density prime residential development site in Shanghai's Pudong New District. The site, with a plot ratio of 1.1 times, will be developed into a high-end international community. The joint venture, held by Yanlord and Huafa Industrial Co Ltd Zhuhai, was acquired through a public land auction. The site is expected to commence construction soon, with pre-sales scheduled for next year to sustain Yanlord's contracted pre-sales growth.

site_title: The pandemic performance review
summary: Companies are rethinking performance reviews amid the pandemic, with many adopting new systems to assess employees' work from home. Goldman Sachs has introduced a new grading system, while Singapore firms like Singapore Press Holdings and Millennium Hotels and Resorts have laid off employees. To better manage performance, companies are considering more frequent and regular conversations, using project management tools, and recognizing effort and behavior instead of just output. Some employers are also focusing on soft skills and individual ability, rather than just hard targets. However, furloughed employees cannot be objectively assessed, and employers need to re-evaluate their business strategies when they resume work.

images.alt_text: Companies are finding it difficult to assess employee performance due to a lack of face-to-face interaction, according to human resources consultants.
THE PANDEMIC PERFORMANCE REVIEW: Companies are rethinking how they assess performance, in a year when business targets and individual jobs have been upended.
In Singapore, firms have been urged to see job cuts as a last resort, but that may become less tenable as the crisis wears them out.

"The absence of direct supervision, face-to-face interaction and the inability to confirm that the employees are spending sufficient time on the job rather than watching Netflix is starting to bother a lot of managers." - Kartikey Singh (above), senior client partner at Korn Ferry Singapore

SAP's Eileen Chua (above) says: "When we look at career development, it's not just the immediate term... and it's important to take a holistic view of how the employee is contributing. If they don't meet the targets, we can look at other measures, such as customer adoption. It's how our employee steps up, not just the hard targets."

ManpowerGroup's Linda Teo (above) says: "Most employees will continue to perform to their best ability as they are aware that should the situation worsen and a reduction of headcount is required, underperformers will most likely be first on the chopping block."

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant said to target US$225 billion valuation in IPO
summary: Ant Group, backed by Alibaba founder Jack Ma, plans to file for a dual listing in Hong Kong and Shanghai, targeting a valuation of around $225 billion, making it the world's largest initial public offering (IPO). The share sale could raise around $30 billion, and Ant aims to float its shares simultaneously on the Hong Kong stock exchange and the tech-focused Star board in Shanghai by October.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust Q1 gain dives 75.4%; independent adviser approves proposed divestment
summary: Accordia Golf Trust's Q1 net profit plummeted 75.4% to SGD 7.4 million due to a significant decline in golf course performance amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Operating income fell 27.1% and earnings per unit declined to 0.52 yen. The trust's manager will hold an EGM on September 14 to vote on the proposed divestment of its golf courses for SGD 848.4 million, representing an implied price of SGD 0.772 per unit, according to an independent financial adviser's opinion that the deal is on normal commercial terms.

site_title: Muhyiddin's Bersatu joins Muafakat to form grand Malay Muslim alliance
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's party, Bersatu, has joined the Muafakat Nasional alliance, a grand Malay Muslim organisation, with 40% of federal MPs. The move brings together the three biggest Malay Muslim parties, Umno, PAS, and Bersatu, potentially leading to more stable politics and less politicking among the ruling alliance. However, critics worry this alliance might weaken minority rights. Muafakat has around 98 lawmakers, a bloc of 44% of MPs, and is seen as a key player in the next general election, which is rumoured to be called soon.

site_title: Reits (August 22-23, 2020)
summary: Realtors reported strong demand for Singapore's prime properties with prices above S$3,000 per square foot. US mortgage rates rose for the first time in five weeks, and Manhattan rents reached another record. In the UK, homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, while Goldman Sachs acquired a large portfolio of Seoul hotel and retail assets. New World Development is selling its China property assets after securing a loan deal. In Singapore, OCBC announced the retirement of its CEO, Helen Wong, and named Tan Teck Long as her successor.

site_title: Covid-19: An unexpected catalyst for a lower carbon world
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the digitalisation trend, highlighting the developments that have already been made in a sustainable economy. Economic activity is rebounding in some markets, but sectors like retail and in-person entertainment will struggle until normal activity levels resume. The crisis has spurred on a structural shift towards digitalisation, key to reaching a sustainable economy.

site_title: Millennial workers miss working from office: survey
summary: A survey of 1,500 corporate employees across five Asia-Pacific countries found that 2/3 of millennials (aged 35 and below) missed working in an office setting, citing the social aspect as the main reason. In contrast, older employees (50+) cited productivity as the main factor. Millennials value social engagement at work, wanting to connect with teams, collaborate, and unleash their creativity. To adapt to the changing work landscape, businesses will need to reimagine office space, incorporating flexibility, collaboration, and employee experience, while considering business needs and costs.

site_title: Beer truly is the champagne of cocktails
summary: Beer is a versatile ingredient in cocktails, offering a range of flavors and low alcohol content. Historically, beer was used in punches and drinks, adding undertones of malt flavor and smoothing out the overall taste. Today, beer-based cocktails can be simple or complex, pairing well with spirits and liqueurs. To make beer-based cocktails, choose a beer with a unique flavor profile and pair it with ingredients that complement or contrast its taste. Adding ice at the end can help preserve carbonation, and experimenting with different beers and ingredients can create refreshing and unique drinks.

site_title: Tesla-dependent ETF sees record inflow
summary: A record $124 million was added to the ARK Innovation ETF (ARKK) on Wednesday, bringing its total assets to $7.4 billion. The fund, heavily weighted in Tesla, has seen almost $3.1 billion in inflows this year, with a 77.4% return year-to-date. The fund's success is attributed to Cathie Wood's thematic investing approach, which has led to a surge in Tesla's stock price by 350% this year.

site_title: Wuthelam forking out 1.29t yen to tighten grip on Nippon Paint
summary: Wuthelam Holdings, a Singapore-based company, is acquiring a majority stake in Nippon Paint Holdings, a Japanese paint company, in a deal worth 1.29 trillion yen (S$16.72 billion). The deal increases Wuthelam's stake to 55.1% and marks a significant shift in focus for Nippon Paint, which will now prioritize the Asia region for sustainable growth. The acquisition is part of Nippon Paint's efforts to enhance its financial base and maximize shareholder value.

site_title: Singapore lifting travel curbs for Brunei, NZ; reducing SHN period for mainland China, Vietnam, Malaysia, Australia excluding Victoria
summary: Singapore is lifting travel restrictions for visitors from Brunei and New Zealand, while reducing the stay-home notice (SHN) period for travelers from low-risk countries, including mainland China, Vietnam, Malaysia, and Australia (excluding Victoria). Travelers from these countries will need to apply for an Air Travel Pass and undergo a Covid-19 test upon arrival. The move is seen as a step towards rebuilding the Singapore air hub, with the Singapore Airlines Group calling it a positive development.

site_title: CGS-CIMB keeps 'add' call on Wilmar, says Chinese unit's value underestimated
summary: CGS-CIMB maintained its "add" call on Wilmar International, citing the planned listing of Yihai Kerry Arawana (YKA) as a positive factor. The analyst also reaffirmed its target price at S$5.53 despite a short-term overhang from Archer Daniels Midland's share sale. Wilmar International's shares ended the day at S$4.45, up 2.1%.

site_title: Greed, for lack of a better word, is good for Hong Kong
summary: Hong Kong's capitalist miracle is facing a crisis, with the city's government struggling to address socioeconomic and political issues. The territory's reliance on laissez-faire economics has led to a decline in its can-do attitude and ingenuity. The recent National Security Law and arrest of prominent publisher Jimmy Lai Chee-Ying have eroded trust in the government. However, a 300% rise in the stock value of Next Digital Limited suggests that many residents are willing to invest in the city's future. To restore confidence, Hong Kong's leaders must develop a vision and build consensus, rather than relying on blunt police action.

site_title: Wells Fargo resumes job cuts in break with top US competitors
summary: Wells Fargo has resumed its job cuts, breaking with top US competitors that resisted workforce reductions amid the pandemic. The San Francisco-based lender quietly ended a moratorium on terminations in early August and expects to make deeper cuts in the months and years ahead, potentially eliminating tens of thousands of positions. Executives anticipate more significant steps later this year, Bloomberg News reported.

site_title: Asia's entrepreneurs seeking more direct, speedier loans, says top PE investor
summary: Asia's entrepreneurs are seeking more direct and speedy loans due to the novel coronavirus pandemic drying up other funding avenues. KKR & Co, the region's largest private equity investor, is lending over $1 billion a year and preparing to raise its first dedicated credit fund. This trend is driven by a growing middle class in Vietnam, Malaysia, and Indonesia, creating opportunities for businesses in property, healthcare, and other consumer areas.

images.alt_text: Mr Dillard says Asia represents an enormous opportunity, with returns several hundred basis points above what's on offer in the competitive US and European markets.

site_title: Lim's Genting empire pressured by cruise unit's debt woes
summary: Lim Kok Thay's Genting Bhd saw its stock drop 4.5% amid pressure from Genting Hong Kong's debt woes. The Hong Kong-listed cruise operator suspended all payments to creditors, citing available funds to maintain critical services. Analysts predict a pragmatic deal with creditors and additional financing to keep the company afloat. The pandemic has halted demand for cruises and kept casinos and resorts closed, affecting Genting Bhd's various business units. The company's debt, totaling $3.4 billion, has raised investor concerns about the impact on other group companies.

images.alt_text: In an industry battered by travel curbs across the globe, the company operates the Star Cruises, Dream Cruises and Crystal Cruises lines.

site_title: US existing-home sales surged in July by most on record
summary: US existing-home sales surged 24.7% in July, reaching a record 5.86 million annualized rate, driven by lower mortgage rates and pent-up demand. The median home price jumped 8.5% from last year to $304,100, the highest on record. The housing market is now in a "booming stage," according to NAR's chief economist, with suburban markets gaining popularity. However, lean inventory and higher asking prices remain hurdles to further gains.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue below target and similar operating loss to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Stymied at home, South Korea's mom-and-pop investors charge into China tech stocks
summary: South Korean retail investors are investing heavily in Chinese tech stocks, with $240 million spent in July alone, a record high. The surge is driven by tightened regulations on domestic investments and the promise of China's speedy economy recovery. Investors, including a 40-year-old chef with over $500 million invested, are betting on Beijing's push for tech self-sufficiency to counter US trade sanctions. Chinese tech companies, such as Shennan Circuits and ZTE, have seen significant gains, with the Shanghai Composite index up 10.3% and Korean tech heavyweights lagging behind.

site_title: Neymar ready to deliver on Europe's biggest stage
summary: PSG's Neymar is poised to deliver on the biggest stage, aiming to win another Champions League title with his team against Bayern Munich in the final. The 28-year-old Brazilian has been crucial to PSG's success, scoring 70 times in 84 matches, and is desperate to win his second Champions League title. If he performs well, it could solidify his position as the world's best player. Bayern, led by manager Hansi Flick, is looking to complete his treble-winning season with a Champions League victory, aiming to make history as the first team to do so in 10 months.

site_title: Rouble falls sharply as Moscow says ready to help Belarus if asked
summary: The Russian rouble fell to multi-month lows against the US dollar and euro after Moscow said it's ready to help Belarus resolve its internal crisis if asked. The rouble dropped 1.5% against the dollar and 0.6% against the euro, with the Belarusian rouble also crashing 2% against the US dollar. The move came after Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov stated Russia would do its best to help resolve the situation in Belarus. Russian stocks were mixed, with Sberbank shares jumping on dividend payouts.

site_title: China's Pinduoduo beats quarterly revenue estimates
summary: China's Pinduoduo reported beating quarterly revenue estimates, recovering from lost ad sales due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The e-commerce firm attributed the growth to healthy advertising demand from merchants. This comes amid escalating tensions between China and the US, including President Donald Trump's proposed bans on transactions with Chinese-owned apps. Pinduoduo's results suggest a resilient market, despite global economic challenges.

site_title: Fragrance Group buys back some notes due 2021
summary: Fragrance Group has repurchased S$500,000 in notes due April 2021, representing 0.4% of the aggregate principal amount of outstanding notes. The repurchased notes were acquired through an on-market purchase for S$503,277, inclusive of accumulated interest. The company views the repurchase as reducing its interest expense, following previous repurchases of S$250,000 and S$500,000.

site_title: Jump in VicPlas' share price prompts another query from SGX
summary: VicPlas International has been queried by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for the second time this month due to unusual price movements in its shares, which rose 48% to 59 Singapore cents on Friday. The query follows a similar incident on August 3, and VicPlas has been asked to provide an immediate explanation for the spike.

site_title: Biden emerges from shadow and into 'the light'
summary: US President Joe Biden accepted the Democratic Party's nomination for the November election, delivering an austere address that likened his campaign to a speech from the Oval Office. He cast himself as a healer of a divided nation, invoking former President Franklin D. Roosevelt and promising to be "an ally of the light, not the darkness." Biden's remarks were seen as a response to President Donald Trump's narrative, and were praised by some high-profile Republicans. The speech marked a shift in Biden's campaign, which will focus on unity and decency, and comes ahead of the Republican convention next week where Trump is expected to accept the nomination.

site_title: Silicon Valley startups tap a new talent pool - pandemic-weary college students
summary: Several Silicon Valley startups are offering remote internships to pandemic-weary college students, providing an alternative to a dismal school year. Companies such as NIE, Amazon Web Services, and others have launched these opportunities, aiming to tap into the talent pool. The internships are designed to offer students a chance to gain practical experience and skills in the tech industry, while also providing a flexible and remote work environment. This move is seen as a win-win for both students and startups, allowing students to gain experience and startups to access fresh talent.

images.alt_text: Many college students are facing the prospect of a year of school during a pandemic - with virtual classes, restricted movements and no parties.

site_title: US election mail will be handled 'securely and on time', postal chief says
summary: US Postmaster General Louis DeJoy assured lawmakers that the Postal Service will deliver election mail "securely and on time" in the November presidential election, amid concerns over service delays. DeJoy suspended mail service changes until after the election, amid criticism that they could interfere with mail-in balloting. Senate Democrats expressed concerns about DeJoy's leadership, while Republicans defended him, citing his efforts to reduce costs. The House is set to vote on a bill providing $25 billion in funding for the Postal Service and requiring the reversal of operational changes.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Wuthelam Group agreed to buy out Nippon Paint for 1.29 trillion yen (S$15.37 billion), increasing its stake in the Japanese company from 39% to nearly 60%. This deal marks a significant expansion for Wuthelam Group, which will become the largest shareholder of Nippon Paint.

site_title: How to integrate ESG factors into equity analysis
summary: Integrating Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) factors into equity analysis can provide a more holistic view of a company, altering risk and valuation numbers. Analysts identify relevant ESG factors, such as employee welfare and environmental risks, and assess their materiality. ESG factors can be integrated into financial models by adjusting discount rates or conducting scenario analysis. Tweaking model inputs in a forward-looking discounted cashflow model is the most challenging method, requiring in-house ESG specialists. Companies may consider subscribing to ratings companies or hiring dedicated ESG analysts to obtain primary research and confidence in modeling intrinsic value.

site_title: KrisEnergy revises restructuring proposal
summary: KrisEnergy, an upstream oil and gas company, has revised its restructuring proposal, allocating 46.2% of equity to unsecured debt holders and 43.8% to zero coupon note holders. Existing shareholders will hold 10%. The proposal aims to complete restructuring by November 18, with failure likely resulting in liquidation. Stakeholders will vote on the proposal through a scheme of arrangement, consent solicitation, or shareholders' approval.

site_title: Euro zone economic recovery falters in August
summary: The euro zone's economic recovery stalled in August, driven by dwindling pent-up demand following the easing of coronavirus lockdowns. After a surge in July, activity slowed due to rising infection rates and the reinstatement of some earlier restrictions. This marks a setback for the region, which had been experiencing its fastest expansion since mid-2018 in July. The economic slowdown is attributed to the resurgence of the virus, which has infected over 22.5 million people globally.

site_title: Cracks in the crystal kingdom
summary: Swarovski, a century-old Austrian luxury crystal company, is undergoing a significant overhaul due to declining revenue and profits. The company's CEO, Robert Buchbauer, plans to focus on higher-quality products with unique designs, exiting low-margin wholesale business and reducing its network of 3,000 boutiques. This move has sparked opposition from the family, who fear it will cause irreversible damage to the company's components business. The crisis is partly due to changing consumer trends, with shoppers favoring high-end designers and fast-fashion alternatives. Swarovski's future and brand image are at risk, with the company's 30,000 employees facing job cuts and the town of Wattens, where the company is based, losing revenue.

site_title: Fragrance Group buys back some notes due 2021
summary: Fragrance Group has repurchased S$500,000 in notes due April 2021, representing 0.4% of the aggregate principal amount. The repurchased notes were acquired through an on-market purchase for S$503,277, inclusive of accumulated interest. The company believes this repurchase will reduce its interest expense. This is the third repurchase announced by Fragrance Group, following two previous repurchases of S$250,000 and S$500,000.

site_title: Empty jewellery shops plague India market as Dubai exports arrive
summary: India's gold market is experiencing a surge in imports from the UAE, with gold futures trading at a record high of 56,191 rupees per 10 grams. However, buyers are staying away due to volatile prices, resulting in discounts of up to US$20 an ounce. The COVID-19 pandemic continues to affect demand, with China also seeing a decline in gold sales. Analysts predict that the situation is unlikely to improve this year, with retailers hoarding gold materials in China due to a significant price difference between the country and international markets.

site_title: Opportunities emerging for investment property deals; discounts up to 20% may be had, says consultant
summary: Singapore property investors may find opportunities to purchase assets at discounted prices, with discounts of 10-20% possible in the next few quarters, according to Cushman & Wakefield's Christine Li. Despite the worst recession on record, capital appreciation from investments during challenging periods tends to outperform gains during normal times. Key sectors to watch include office, retail, and logistics, with hospitality and retail sectors expected to offer more attractive discounts due to their negative impact from the pandemic. Investors should be cautious of fire sales, unlike previous crises, and consider the impact of quantitative easing on the market.

site_title: Ryanair to cut significantly fewer jobs after pay deals
summary: Ryanair has significantly reduced its estimated job cuts from 3,000 to an unknown number after 97% of pilots and 90% of cabin crew agreed to pay cuts and work changes. The airline had initially warned of one in five pilot and cabin crew redundancies due to the Covid-19 crisis. Ryanair has struck pay deals with Spanish pilots and is in talks with Belgian pilots and Italian and German cabin crew. The airline's director of operations said the number of redundancies will depend on winter booking fares and travel disruptions next year.

site_title: Erdogan announces historic Turkish gas find in Black Sea
summary: Turkey's President Erdogan announced the country's largest ever natural gas find in the Black Sea, holding 320 billion cubic meters. The discovery could help reduce Turkey's dependence on imports from Russia, Iran, and Azerbaijan, and aid the country's goal to become a net energy exporter by 2023. The find could also boost the Turkish government's finances and help ease its current account deficit. However, officials caution that it could take up to a decade for the gas to come online and require significant investment to build infrastructure.

site_title: Saudi Aramco suspends US$10b China oil refinery venture
summary: Saudi Aramco has suspended a US$10 billion refining and petrochemicals complex in China's Liaoning province due to uncertain market outlook. The decision was made after negotiations with Chinese partners, with Aramco cutting spending to cope with low oil prices. The company declined to comment, while partners China North Industries Group and Panjin Sincen were unavailable for comment. The move is the latest in Saudi Aramco's efforts to adapt to the current oil market.

site_title: Rolls-Royce boosts supersonic propulsion effort in Reaction deal
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings has invested £20 million in Reaction Engines to work on high-speed aircraft engines for a potential Virgin Galactic Holdings supersonic jet. Reaction Engines' "air-breathing rocket engine" can reach speeds of up to five times the speed of sound. Rolls-Royce plans to explore this technology in its combustion engines and hybrid-electric propulsion systems, aiming to make flying more efficient and sustainable. This move comes as the company downsizes its traditional wide-body engine business due to the coronavirus.

site_title: Amazon names Dave Clark consumer CEO to replace retiring Jeff Wilke
summary: Amazon names Dave Clark as chief of its retail business, replacing retiring Jeff Wilke in the first quarter of 2021. Clark, a veteran executive, will oversee the Worldwide Consumer unit, including the retail website and logistics empire. Clark joins Amazon out of business school the same year as Wilke and has played a key role in building the company's logistics capabilities. Bezos praises Wilke's leadership and succession, citing Clark as a suitable replacement, in an email to employees.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com has tapped Dave Clark as chief of its retail business.

site_title: Russia approves trial of AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine: registry filing
summary: Russia has approved a trial of AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine, AZD1222, with 150 participants in four medical facilities in St Petersburg and Moscow. This trial is part of the Phase Three trial, which is ongoing in Britain and Brazil. Russia is also developing its own Covid-19 vaccines, with the front-runner candidate, "Sputnik-V", set to begin late-stage trials next week. AstraZeneca has manufacturing agreements with Russian firm R-Pharm to produce the vaccine in Russia.

images.alt_text: Britain's AstraZeneca has received regulatory approval to conduct part of a Phase Three trial of its potential Covid-19 vaccine in Russia, a filing in the Russian registry of clinical trials showed on Friday.

site_title: US: Wall Street subdued at open ahead of US business surveys
summary: US stocks opened little changed on Friday, shifting focus from the Nasdaq's all-time high to business surveys for economic recovery cues. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 6.51 points to 11,258.45, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 18.40 points to 27,758.13. The market is awaiting business surveys for more insights on the economic recovery.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Friday, rising 1.74 points to 1,577.12, with 707 gainers outnumbering 390 losers. The index saw a volume of 7.718 billion lots worth RM5.023 billion.

site_title: Philippines construction to bounce back in 2021: report
summary: The Philippines' construction industry is expected to bounce back in 2021, growing at an annual average rate of 8.3% from 2021 to 2024, driven by infrastructure projects such as the US$18.9 billion Build, Build, Build programme. The industry contracted 9.2% in 2020 due to the pandemic, but is expected to rebound with increased government spending on infrastructure, housing, and energy. Output is forecast to reach US$75.1 billion by 2024, up from a pre-pandemic level.

site_title: Bayer to pay US$1.6b to halt Essure contraceptive suits
summary: Bayer AG has agreed to pay $1.6 billion to resolve about 90% of the 39,000 lawsuits over its now-withdrawn Essure contraceptive device, which some women claimed caused health issues. The deal will provide expedited relief to thousands of women, who suffered from excessive bleeding, pelvic pain, and other problems. The settlement, which covers about 90% of the consolidated lawsuits, does not amount to an admission of wrongdoing or liability. The agreement comes after Bayer reserved $2.03 billion to settle litigation over the device.

site_title: Relaxed travel measures aimed at reviving business, aviation sector: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung has announced relaxed travel measures to revive the business and aviation sectors, welcoming visitors from Brunei and New Zealand without requiring a stay-home notice (SHN) period. The measures aim to balance safety with economic revival, with travellers from the two countries allowed to test negative on arrival and travel freely. The decision is part of Singapore's efforts to open up to the world, following its unilateral approach to promoting free trade since its beginning.

site_title: 117 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 6 in the community
summary: Singapore reported 117 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 56,216, with 6 community cases and 13 imported cases. Migrant workers in dormitories made up the majority of the new cases. The number of daily community cases has decreased, with 309 cases discharged on Thursday, and 53,104 patients have fully recovered.

site_title: Pence leads Republican counterattack after Democrats savage Trump at convention
summary: Vice-President Mike Pence launched a Republican counterattack to criticism of President Donald Trump at the Democratic convention, stating that a Joe Biden presidency would crush the US economy and lead to civil unrest. Pence made the comments in a series of TV interviews, countering Biden's vision of healing the country after a pandemic and divided presidency. Pence's remarks aimed to shift the focus away from Trump's criticism and towards Biden's policies, setting the stage for the Republican response to the Democratic nomination.

site_title: Asset managers wary about Libor oversight as loans still reliant on benchmark
summary: US regulators are scrutinizing asset managers' plans to transition away from the London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor), a key benchmark for trillions of US dollar investments. The Office of Compliance Inspections and Examinations (OCIE) will conduct examinations to assess firms' readiness and exposure to Libor-linked contracts. The transition is set to end in 2021, with the Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR) expected to replace Libor. Asset managers are concerned about the slow adoption of SOFR in the US leveraged loan market, with some firms still relying on Libor.

site_title: BTS hopes 'Dynamite' blows away fans amid coronavirus gloom
summary: South Korean boy band BTS released their new digital single "Dynamite" amid the COVID-19 pandemic, hoping it will bring energy and lift fans' spirits. The song, their first English-language single, was contributed to by David Stewart and Jessica Agombar. Despite a cancelled US tour and limited live concerts, BTS has maintained a strong online presence, with 756,000 fans paying to watch an online concert in June. The group plans to return with two concerts in Seoul in October and a full album release later this year.

site_title: Amazon Alexa unit pauses hiring amid pressure to make money
summary: Amazon has paused hiring at its Alexa division amid growing pressure to make money from the voice-activated digital assistant. The pause, which began in the early spring, is due to the company's need to cut costs and increase profits. Amazon has recently begun letting managers fill some openings with special approval, and the company has added thousands of employees to its Alexa organization since April. The move marks a shift in Amazon's ambitious experiment with Alexa, which has yet to offer a transformative new experience.

site_title: Toyota sees higher vehicle output in Japan in Sept
summary: Toyota Motor plans to increase domestic vehicle production in Japan by 1% in September, producing around 230,000 vehicles, up 2,300 units from its initial plan. This follows a recovery in production levels after a steep drop due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Toyota expects global sales to be 15% lower in the July-September quarter and 5% lower in October-December, with a total of 7.2 million vehicles to be sold in the year to March, down 20% from last year.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor on Friday said its domestic vehicle production would be 1 per cent higher than initially planned in September, as its plants resume output levels following a steep drop because of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: UK retail sales surge past pre-Covid peak in July
summary: UK retail sales surged past their pre-Covid peak in July, with a 3.6% rise from June and a 1.4% increase from 2019. The rebound is attributed to strong consumer demand despite other parts of the economy struggling to recover. Public debt reached £2 trillion (100.5% of GDP) in July, the highest since 1961. Economists warn the broad retail recovery could be temporary, and the UK's economy is expected to shrink for a second month, with unemployment forecast to rise sharply once a job support scheme ends.

site_title: Japan, India and Australia said to seek supply chain pact
summary: Japan, India, and Australia are discussing a supply chain resilience initiative to counter China's dominance, amid escalating trade and geopolitical tensions. The three nations are considering a bilateral agreement to diversify supply chains, with Japan seeking a higher level of engagement. India's government is weighing participation, while Australia's involvement has not been confirmed. The initiative aims to promote trade facilitation, foreign direct investment, and cooperation in the Indo-Pacific region, potentially involving nations from South-east Asia.

site_title: Yanlord JV acquires residential development site in Shanghai
summary: Yanlord Land Group has acquired a prime residential development site in Shanghai's Kangqiao, Pudong New District, for 4.5 billion yuan. The site, with a plot ratio of 1.1 times, will be developed into a high-end, international community. Yanlord holds a 51% stake in the joint venture with Huafa Industrial Co Ltd Zhuhai. The development is expected to commence shortly, with pre-sales scheduled for next year to sustain contracted pre-sales growth. This acquisition reiterates Yanlord's confidence in the high-end residential market in first-tier cities, according to its chairman and CEO, Zhong Sheng Jian.

site_title: Hong Kong leader announces mass Covid-19 testing to begin Sept 1
summary: Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam announced mass Covid-19 testing starting Sept 1, with a 60-person team from the mainland assisting. The testing, voluntary and expected to take two weeks, will increase testing capacity by over 10-fold. The move comes as daily infections have fallen from triple digits to low double digits, with 4,600 cases reported since January and 75 deaths. Restrictions, including dining bans and mask mandates, will remain in force until at least Aug 25.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished the week sharply higher, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.30% to 25,113.84, driven by hopes for a virus vaccine. Asian bourses also saw gains, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.50% and the Shenzhen Composite Index climbing 1.09%. The rally follows an advance across Asian bourses and extends a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks.

site_title: No breakthrough in latest round of Brexit talks, says EU official
summary: The European Union (EU) and the UK have concluded their latest round of Brexit talks with no breakthrough on key sticking points, including state aid rules and fishing quotas. The talks, which are ongoing, aim to negotiate a new partnership from 2021 on trade, transport, energy, and security. The EU is pushing for a deal to be finalized by October 15 for approval at an EU summit, while the UK's lead negotiator David Frost remains relatively upbeat about reaching an agreement. Disagreements also persist on migration, security, and human rights guarantees.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebound on foreign buying, recovery hopes
summary: South Korean stocks rebounded 1.34% on Friday, following a selloff in the previous session, driven by foreign buying and hopes for economic recovery. The benchmark Kospi rose 30.37 points to 2,304.59. The Korean won edged up, and the benchmark bond yield rose. The rally was also boosted by Wall Street's overnight rally and preliminary trade data.

site_title: Europe: Shares struggle to gain, PMI data awaited
summary: European shares were flat on Friday ahead of business activity data, with the Stoxx 600 index up 0.1% despite weak US data and a stronger pound. Retail sales surged past pre-coronavirus levels in July, but economists fear a temporary recovery. Travel and leisure stocks rose 1.2%, while financial services and telecoms stocks declined. The focus shifts to the Markit flash survey of European purchasing managers, expected to show business activity stagnated in August.

site_title: Metal magnate targets string of smaller steel buys in India
summary: British metals tycoon Sanjeev Gupta aims to acquire at least six smaller steel plants in India by 2025, after losing out on bigger purchases. GFG Alliance plans to scale up its production to 2 million tonnes, with its recent acquisition of Adhunik Metaliks as its first step. Gupta believes the "string of pearls" strategy will help the company establish a strong presence in India. The move comes as the global market experiences a wave of consolidation due to the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Virgin Australia bondholders withdraw plans for proposal to rival Bain Capital deal
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings bondholders have withdrawn plans for a proposed recapitalisation, which aimed to rival a deal from US private equity firm Bain Capital. The withdrawal comes after a court ruling made it impossible to complete due diligence and present a substantially unconditional proposal. The bondholders hold around A$300 million of Virgin's A$2 billion in unsecured bonds. Administrator Deloitte will issue a report outlining expected returns under the Bain deal, and the bondholders reserve their rights to take action to protect their interests. The withdrawal allows Deloitte to focus on the binding agreement with Bain.

site_title: Software company MobileIron to explore potential sale
summary: MobileIron, a Mountain View, California-based infrastructure software provider, is exploring options including a potential sale. The company is working with a financial adviser and has not made a final decision. MobileIron's stock rose less than 1% to close at $6, giving the company a market value of about $701 million. The company's software helps employees securely access work-related applications and networks on mobile devices, primarily used by financial services, healthcare, and other companies. A sale decision has not been made, and the company could remain independent.

site_title: Stymied at home, Korea's mom and pop investors charge into China tech stocks
summary: South Korean retail investors are investing record amounts in Chinese tech stocks, spending $240 million in July alone, a seven-fold increase from last year. This surge accounts for a third of the total $719 million net investment in China stocks for the first seven months of the year. Investors are drawn to the sector due to its growth potential, despite unfavorable investment conditions at home.

site_title: British public debt tops £2t for first time
summary: Britain's public debt has surpassed £2 trillion for the first time, according to official data released in July. This represents a 100.5% of the country's economic output, its highest level since 1961. The debt increase was largely due to increased public spending during the coronavirus pandemic and decreased tax revenues. Finance Minister Rishi Sunak warned that difficult decisions will be needed to return the public finances to a sustainable footing. The UK's economy also contracted for the second month in a row, adding to the economic challenges faced by the country.

site_title: An heir to US$2.2b fortune in Brazil bets on organic farms
summary: Brazilian heir Pedro Paulo Diniz is investing in organic farming, aiming to convert 350,000 hectares of land to regenerative soy and corn production by 2030. He believes yields can match conventional crops and prices can absorb extra costs, making it a profitable venture. Diniz's venture, Rizoma Agro, has already gained contracts with major food companies, including Tyson Foods and Nestle. However, environmental concerns and Brazil's poor environmental reputation may hinder investor interest, forcing the company to rely on its green credentials to attract funding.

site_title: Food delivery giant Meituan Q2 revenue rises 8.9%, beats estimates
summary: China's food delivery giant Meituan reported a 8.9% rise in Q2 revenue to 24.72 billion yuan, beating analyst estimates. Revenue from food delivery grew 13.2% to 14.54 billion yuan, with Meituan controlling 67% of the Chinese market.
