The company's profit for the period rose to 2.21 billion yuan, up from 875.8 million yuan a year earlier. Meituan's operations likely recovered to pre-pandemic levels in terms of traffic and revenue.

images.alt_text: China's Meituan Dianping, whose on-demand service apps span grocery delivery and hotel booking, reported a steeper-than-expected rise in second-quarter revenue on Friday as eased lockdown measures saw more people venture out.

site_title: Thai government should use fiscal policy more to help economy: BOT
summary: Thailand's central bank governor, Veerathai Santiprabhob, advises the government to use fiscal policy more to aid the economy's recovery from the pandemic. The benchmark interest rate remains at a record low. Santiprabhob emphasized the government's role in stimulating the economy, citing the pandemic's severe and widespread impact. A debt restructuring program for businesses was launched to assist with debt restructuring. The Bank of Thailand will focus on debt restructuring to help the economy recover.

site_title: Singapore's Wuthelam Group to buy out Nippon Paint for 1.29 trillion yen
summary: Singapore's Wuthelam Group agreed to buy out Nippon Paint for 1.29 trillion yen, a deal that will give Wuthelam majority control of the Japanese company. The transaction, valued at S$15.37 billion, is one of Asia's largest cross-border deals in 2020 and marks the latest consolidation in the paints and coatings industry. Nippon Paint will use the funds to acquire Wuthelam's Asian joint ventures and wholly owned business in Indonesia, with the deal expected to be finalized in January.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge lower as US jobless data stokes recovery fears
summary: Australian shares closed 0.1% lower, snapping a two-week gain streak, as healthcare stocks fell 1.3% and US jobless data rose unexpectedly above 1 million, sparking concerns of a prolonged economic recovery. Energy stocks rose 1.3% on rising oil prices, while New Zealand's benchmark index rose 1.5% boosted by technology stocks.

site_title: STI finishes the week with slight recovery of 0.02%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week with a slight recovery, closing at 2,528.54, a 0.62-point or 0.02% gain. Hongkong Land was the top gainer, while OCBC Bank declined 1.81%. The bank announced its first sustainable finance transaction in South Korea, providing a green loan to refinance a green building. Asian markets also rebounded, with the Nikkei 225 and Shanghai Composite Index rising 0.17% and 0.5%, respectively.

site_title: 89 BTO projects have resumed works, only one site pending approval: HDB
summary: Construction works have resumed at 89 Build-To-Order (BTO) sites in Singapore, with only one site pending approval from the Building and Construction Authority (BCA). The resumption began on June 2, after circuit breaker measures were eased, with companies adhering to strict safe management measures. The estimated delay timeline remains unchanged, with the Housing Board (HDB) working with contractors to minimize delays. The resumption of works marks a gradual return to normalcy, with some projects, like the Senja Valley project, now on track for their original completion date in the fourth quarter of 2021.

site_title: CEO drama at Norway's US$1.2 trillion wealth fund hits new hurdle
summary: Norway's $1.2 trillion sovereign wealth fund is facing a new hurdle as the CEO, Nicolai Tangen, faces growing opposition from the parliamentary majority, who demand a review of his contract for potential conflicts of interest. The Progress Party has thrown its weight behind the demands, creating a conflict within the ruling coalition. The government has ordered a fresh legal review and initiated a dialogue with the fund's manager, Norges Bank. The parliamentary Finance Committee is set to decide on the matter on Friday, which could potentially derail Tangen's appointment on September 1.

site_title: Tesla-dependent ETF sees record inflow after 24 weeks of gains
summary: A record $124 million was added to the ARK Innovation ETF (ARKK), which is heavily weighted in Tesla, in a single day. This brings the fund's total assets to $7.4 billion, with a 77.4% year-to-date return. The fund's popularity has surged since the pandemic, with shares of Tesla rising 350% this year, making it the top-performing equity ETF. ARKK's success is attributed to Cathie Wood's thematic investing approach and her team's work.

site_title: GE eases CEO's path to US$230m payout in contract extension
summary: General Electric's board extended CEO Larry Culp's contract by two years, with the option for a one-year extension, after the COVID-19 pandemic impacted his plan to turn around the company. The new contract makes it easier for Culp to receive up to $230 million in compensation, as the company's shares have tumbled 44% this year. The extension and revised compensation package are seen as a vote of confidence in Culp's revitalization strategy, despite the company's revenue decline in the second quarter.

site_title: Tanjong Katong conservation shophouse for sale with S$8.8m starting price
summary: A freehold conservation shophouse at 240 Tanjong Katong Road in Singapore is up for sale with a starting price of S$8.8 million. The 2,064 square foot property is fully occupied, with the ground floor leased to an eatery, and is zoned for residential and commercial use. The sale is notable due to the restrictions on new eateries along Tanjong Katong Road, which is set to limit the property's potential for redevelopment.

site_title: KKR says retrenching banks boost direct lending demand in Asia
summary: KKR & Co, Asia's largest private equity investor, reports an increase in demand for direct loans in the region due to the coronavirus pandemic. Entrepreneurs are seeking speedier access to cash as banks have grown cautious. KKR has lent over $1 billion in the past year and is preparing to raise its first dedicated credit fund for Asia. Private credit in Asia is still nascent, but has gained momentum, with returns several hundred basis points above traditional lending channels. The sector is expected to continue growing as Asia represents a significant opportunity for investment.

site_title: China Baowu Steel to take control of stainless steelmaker Tisco
summary: China Baowu Steel Group has agreed to take a 51% stake in stainless steelmaker Tisco, worth 14.5 billion yuan, as part of a state-backed restructuring move to consolidate China's steel sector and achieve orderly market competition. The deal, pending approval from regulators, aims to enhance Baowu's competitiveness in the stainless steel sector and give it more influence over pricing. Tisco, China's second-largest stainless steelmaker, has an annual steel capacity of 12.9 million tonnes, including 4.5 million tonnes of stainless steel.

site_title: Skyscrapers give way to sheds as Covid changes UK real estate
summary: The UK's real estate market is shifting as e-commerce growth drives demand for warehouses. During the pandemic, internet sales surged, and warehouses became a hot asset, with record demand in the second quarter. Global giants like Amazon and Blackstone are investing heavily, with Amazon leasing the largest warehouse in Europe, a 2.3 million sq ft mega-box. This trend is expected to continue, with online retailers accounting for nearly half of warehouse space and traditional retailers adapting to the post-Covid economy. The growth in demand is expected to lead to increased rents and a reordering of the real estate pecking order.

images.alt_text: On a building site about 20 miles east of London, workers are busy putting up the largest warehouse in Europe. Just leased to Amazon.com, it can't go up fast enough.

site_title: Fitness app ClassPass sues Hilton over cancelled stock purchase
summary: Fitness app ClassPass has sued Hilton Worldwide Holdings over its decision to cancel a $17 million investment in the company. The investment was part of an effort to raise new investor cash and valued ClassPass at over $1 billion. Hilton allegedly exercised a provision to cancel the payment in July, citing the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the travel and hotel industries. The lawsuit claims Hilton did not act in good faith, and the outcome is unclear.

site_title: Singapore-based lessor BOC Aviation says airline clients repaying delayed rentals
summary: Singapore-based lessor BOC Aviation reports that most airline clients have resumed rental payments, a sign of cautious optimism after deferring payments during the pandemic. The company has completed repayment negotiations with the bulk of its customers, with airlines in China and the US recovering well. BOC Aviation's top executive, Robert Martin, said that experienced airlines moved quickly to react to the situation, while entrepreneur-led airlines with big orders in emerging markets are still working to catch up. The company reported flat first-half net profit and a 11% rise in total revenue and other income.

site_title: Hedge fund that gained 103% on gold rally trims exposure
summary: Delbrook Capital Advisors, a Vancouver-based hedge fund specializing in metals and mining, reported a 103% gain for the year through July, driven by the precious metals rally. The fund manager, Matthew Zabloski, attributed the success to overweighting mid-capitalization production and development names and increasing portfolio hedging. However, Zabloski is now trimming exposure to specific sub-sectors, citing strengthened gold stock valuations and the risk of a rapid exit from the space if economic data surprises positively and the US dollar strengthens.

site_title: KKR expands board diversity at its US-based businesses
summary: KKR & Co has added at least two diverse directors to the boards of every US-based company it controls, resulting in about 30% of directors being women or ethnic minorities. The firm aims to expand its focus on underrepresented groups globally, pushing each company it backs to include diverse directors. KKR's efforts come as companies across the US focus on diversity in the wake of the George Floyd protests. The firm's push for diversity is part of its commitment to "portfolio company diversity starting at the top," making better decisions and driving diversity into organizations.

site_title: Yuan rises to seven-month high, set for best week in six
summary: The yuan rose to a seven-month high of 6.9107 per US dollar, its strongest level since January 22, due to broad US dollar weakness and a dip in Treasury yields. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint at this level, indicating comfort with recent yuan strength. If the yuan holds at this level, it would be its best weekly gain since mid-July, with a 0.58% gain to the US dollar.

images.alt_text: The yuan on Friday edged up to a new seven-month high before paring some gains at midday, thanks to broad US dollar weakness, and also looked set for its best week in six.

site_title: Former Zoox employees sue, alleging rival offer was better than Amazon's
summary: Two former Zoox employees, James Wei and Zhang Yanxin, have filed a lawsuit against the company alleging that Amazon's $1.3 billion offer created disproportionate rewards for executives and investors holding preferred shares at the expense of common stockholders. They claim a competing offer from Cruise would have been more favorable to common stockholders. The lawsuit seeks to open Zoox's books to determine if wrongdoing occurred during the acquisition process.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge up on US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks edged up marginally on Friday, tracking US rallies. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.17% to 22,920.30, while the Topix index gained 0.30% to 1,604.06. Investors remained cautious with few other market-moving events, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: J&J borrows US$7.5b for Momenta in latest M&A bond sale
summary: Johnson & Johnson has borrowed $7.5 billion from the bond market to fund its $6.5 billion acquisition of Momenta Pharmaceuticals, the pharmaceutical industry's largest takeover this year. The deal is the latest sign of companies seeking funding for mergers and acquisitions amid the coronavirus pandemic. J&J sold the debt in six parts, with the longest portion yielding 110 basis points over Treasuries. The bond sale represents J&J's first time in the market in almost three years, but Moody's Investors Service warns that higher leverage may hurt the company's flexibility to handle potential litigation fees.

site_title: OCBC provides 115b won green loan to M&G Real Estate Asia
summary: OCBC Bank has provided a 115 billion won (S$132.6 million) green loan to M&G Real Estate Asia to refinance an investment in Northgate, a green building in Seoul. This is South Korea's first green loan supporting the property sector and OCBC's first sustainable finance transaction in the country. The loan will be used to refinance existing advances for the investment in Northgate, a high-rise office building with green features. The lender aims to grow its sustainable finance portfolio to S$25 billion by 2025.

site_title: Arcturus CEO says in talks with a dozen countries for Covid-19 vaccine supply deals
summary: Arcturus Therapeutics CEO Joseph Payne is in talks with approximately a dozen countries, including US government agencies, for supply deals of its coronavirus vaccine currently in early human testing. The company is discussing two "levers" for negotiations: the number of doses involved and clinical trial support. Arcturus recently signed a deal with Israel for 1 million doses, worth up to $275 million, and has received $10 million from the Singapore government to develop its vaccine. Discussions aim to secure supply deals for the vaccine, pending regulatory approval.

site_title: Lim's Genting empire pressured by cruise unit's debt woes
summary: Shares of Genting Bhd fell 4.5% on Friday, pressured by cruise operator Genting Hong Kong's debt woes. Genting Hong Kong suspended payments to creditors and announced a restructuring proposal, owing US$3.4 billion as of July 31. Analysts expect a pragmatic deal with creditors, but the company's debt and related-party transactions raise investor concerns. Genting Bhd's other units, including casino and resort operations, also fell, with Genting Malaysia Bhd slumping 6.1%.

site_title: Banks cut exposure to Dubai's MENA Energy as virus roils trade
summary: Several banks, including Natixis and Emirates NBD, have reduced or stopped lending to Dubai-based oil trader MENA Energy DMCC due to the coronavirus' impact on commodity businesses. MENA Energy's CEO, Rashid Al Ghurair, remains optimistic about the industry's future as lockdown measures ease. The company faces financial challenges, with some of its peers, such as Hin Leong, experiencing significant difficulties. MENA Energy plans to adapt its strategy for long-term sustainable growth.

site_title: Trump threatens tariffs for US companies that won't move jobs back
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to impose tariffs on US companies that refuse to bring jobs back to the country from overseas if re-elected. During a campaign event, Trump stated that he will offer tax credits to companies to relocate jobs back to America, and those that don't comply will face tariffs. The remarks came as a rebuttal to former Vice-President Joe Biden's acceptance speech. However, no details on the proposed system were provided, and it's unclear if the White House is developing such a policy.

site_title: Evictions loom for Hong Kong retailers with little rent relief
summary: Retailers in Hong Kong are facing eviction due to unpaid rent, with almost half of surveyed members receiving legal letters from landlords for delayed payments. The Hong Kong Retail Management Association warns that one in four shops may close this year without substantial support. Despite the government's verbal urging to landlords to provide relief, many have ignored pleas, and big companies have been forced to close stores temporarily. The government has offered one-time relief to retailers but has not legislated substantial support, leaving shop owners like Don Leung to endure until their rental contracts expire.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades Sea to 'buy' on gaming, e-commerce strength
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded Singapore-based Sea Limited to "buy" from "sell" due to structural strength in gaming arm Garena and e-commerce business Shopee. Analyst Sachin Mittal more than doubled his target price to US$183, citing a sharp rise in Garena's profitable gaming business and mounting free cash flow. DBS now projects a 103% compound annual growth rate for e-commerce and 40% for gaming, with Sea's revenue expected to rise sharply in FY20 and FY21.

site_title: CDL's New Zealand unit sells former hotel site to Catholic church
summary: CDL's New Zealand unit, Millennium & Copthorne Hotels New Zealand, sold a 2,154-square metre freehold plot in Christchurch to the Roman Catholic Diocese of Christchurch for an undisclosed amount. The site is the former location of the Copthorne Hotel Christchurch Central, which was damaged by an earthquake in 2011. The sale is expected to settle in late-May 2021, with no further comments to be made until then.

site_title: Goldman sees pandemic spurring growth in ESG bond issuance
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts a surge in ESG (environmental, social, and governance) bond issuance due to the pandemic, with potential issuers from various sectors. Global issuance of social and sustainability bonds has reached a record $76.97 billion this year, exceeding last year's $55.4 billion. Goldman expects $100-150 billion in total issuance, with sovereigns and supra-nationals also issuing more social debt in the next couple of years. This trend is driven by investors seeking sustainability and environmental alignment, with issuers gaining benefits from better pricing and investor diversification.

site_title: Spending boom means South-east Asia yield curves will get steeper
summary: Asian governments' economic stimulus efforts are boosting spending, leading to steeper yield curves in South-east Asia. Indonesia, Thailand, and Malaysia are seeing widening differences between short-term and long-term bond yields, with Indonesia's yield curve being the steepest in almost a decade. The trend is attributed to concerns over outsized budget deficits and central bank bond purchases. Despite this, the yield curves in Thailand and Malaysia may soon flatten as the central banks' forecast for this year's fiscal deficit increases and global funds turn sellers of the region's debt.

site_title: Germany to take on more debt in 2021 due to virus: finance minister
summary: Germany plans to take on more debt in 2021 to mitigate the impact of the coronavirus on its economy. Finance Minister Olaf Scholz stated that the country will need to suspend its debt rule and spend funds to protect citizens and stabilize the economy. Germany has already borrowed around 218 billion euros this year to support the economy through the pandemic. The government aims to recover from the virus shock by the end of 2021 or early 2022.

site_title: Tesla resumes rally to surpass US$2,000 ahead of stock split
summary: Tesla's shares have surpassed US$2,000, quadrupling in value over the past five months, and crossed Walmart's market value. The stock, which touched a low of US$350 in March, has closed at records on four of the past five trading days. To make the stock more accessible, Tesla plans a 5-for-1 split, effective August 31. The company's valuation now stands at US$373.1 billion, outpacing Walmart's US$369.8 billion. Analyst Adam Jonas notes that Tesla's high valuation is attracting capital and talent, giving the company an edge in the electric vehicle market.

site_title: Singapore researchers discover new Covid-19 variant which causes milder infections
summary: Singapore researchers have discovered a new Covid-19 variant that causes milder infections, according to a study published in The Lancet. The variant, which emerged in Wuhan, China, was exported to Singapore and Taiwan. Experts say this discovery could lead to new avenues for vaccine and therapeutic development. The study's findings could provide valuable insights for future treatments and treatments.

site_title: Joe Biden accepts Democratic nomination: 'I will draw on the best of us'
summary: Joe Biden accepted the Democratic presidential nomination, promising to bridge the country's divisions and draw on the best of Americans. In his address, Biden urged Americans to have faith that they could "overcome this season of darkness" and pledged to work for those who didn't support him. The party has framed the election as a rescue mission for a country beset by a pandemic and a White House defined by incompetence, racism, and abuse of power. Biden's running mate, Kamala Harris, was introduced as the first woman of color on a major party's presidential ticket, and the party has highlighted its commitment to diversity and inclusivity.

site_title: After Huawei, spotlight now on China's role in UK nuclear power projects
summary: The UK is scrutinizing China's involvement in its nuclear power projects, following the removal of Huawei from its 5G network. China General Nuclear Power (CGN) is a minority partner in two projects, Hinkley Point and Sizewell, but holds the majority stake in the Bradwell reactor. The UK's nuclear ambitions are crucial to its goal of achieving carbon neutrality by 2050. If CGN were to exit Hinkley, a British state bailout may be necessary, and the government is banking on nuclear power to meet its energy needs, with nuclear providing 20% of the country's electricity.

site_title: Family offices will keep hunting for unicorns amid lockdown
summary: Family offices plan to continue investing in early-stage startups despite the pandemic, with over 90% having invested in venture capital. To mitigate risks, they will deploy capital more slowly and diversify across sectors. According to a survey, family offices will maintain or increase existing allocations, with a focus on collaborating with other investors to provide unique capital to founders. This trend is expected to continue, with family offices emerging as a significant source of capital for innovation globally.

site_title: More Singapore firms set to adopt fintech to boost efficiency: CPA poll
summary: About 73% of Singapore businesses plan to adopt fintech products or services within the next 12 months, up from 67% in the previous year, according to a CPA Australia survey. The increase is driven by a desire to improve operational efficiency. The survey, conducted among 110 CPA Australia members in Singapore, found the largest representations came from consulting, financial services, and public practice/CPA firms. This trend suggests that Singapore firms are looking to leverage fintech to boost efficiency and stay competitive in the market.

site_title: US, China differ over plans for Phase One trade deal talks
summary: The US and China differ over plans for Phase One trade deal talks, with China stating bilateral discussions will be held "in the coming days" to evaluate the agreement's progress. The US Commerce Ministry declined to acknowledge any plans for talks, with no new meeting date scheduled. China's purchases of US goods are running behind pace, but farm product purchases have increased. US President Donald Trump has expressed anger at China and has turned to tougher talk and actions, including sanctions and tariffs, as his re-election campaign ramps up.

site_title: US charges former Uber security chief with covering up massive 2016 hacking
summary: A former Uber security chief, Joseph Sullivan, has been charged with felony obstruction of justice for allegedly covering up a 2016 hacking that exposed personal data of 57 million customers and drivers. The US Department of Justice claims Sullivan took "deliberate steps" to conceal the incident from the Federal Trade Commission while monitoring Uber security. This is the first time a corporate information security officer has been charged with concealing a hack. Sullivan, 52, faces felony charges.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares edge down at Friday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 1.72 points or 0.1% to 1,573.66. Trading volume reached 497.5 million lots worth RM355.7 million, with 271 gainers and 251 losers.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant is said to target US$225 billion valuation in IPO
summary: Billionaire Jack Ma's Ant Group plans to file for a dual listing in Hong Kong and Shanghai, targeting a valuation of about US$225 billion. The IPO could raise around US$30 billion, making it the world's largest initial public offering. Ant, a fintech platform, has morphed into an online mall offering loans, travel services, and food delivery. The move aims to win back shoppers lost to Tencent Holdings, and could surpass Saudi Aramco's record US$29.4 billion IPO.

site_title: Greenback on defensive as fresh jobs pain hits US economy
summary: The US dollar faced a defensive stance against most currencies after a rise in US jobless claims and a decline in Treasury yields. The euro, boosted by European stimulus measures, is expected to gain further momentum with upcoming manufacturing data. Analysts attribute the dollar's weakness to the Fed's quantitative easing and concerns about the US economy's recovery. The dollar declined against the euro, British pound, Swiss franc, and yen, while the Australian and New Zealand dollars edged up.

site_title: EU reaches coronavirus vaccine deal with CureVac
summary: The EU has reached a deal with German pharmaceutical firm CureVac to secure 225 million doses of a potential coronavirus vaccine. This is the fourth agreement the bloc has made with companies working on a vaccine, following deals with Sanofi-GSK, Johnson & Johnson, and AstraZeneca. The vaccine must first be shown to be safe and effective before an agreement to purchase it can be finalized.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.76% to 23,055.38 and the Topix index up 0.68% to 1,610.02. Investors took heart from US rallies, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The rally was largely driven by few market-moving events, with traders brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: Petronas said to show interest in buying Permian's DoublePoint
summary: Malaysia's state-backed oil company Petronas has had preliminary talks about buying Permian Basin shale driller DoublePoint Energy, according to people familiar with the matter. If a deal occurs, it could be worth several billion dollars. The talks are in the early stages and no guarantee of a transaction exists. The Chevron deal to buy Noble Energy earlier this year raised hopes of a pickup in dealmaking, but buyers are unwilling to pay high premiums for shale producers due to low oil prices.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB keeps 'add' on Wilmar, says Chinese unit's value underestimated
summary: Brokerage firm CGS-CIMB maintained its "add" call on Wilmar International, citing the planned listing of its Chinese unit Yihai Kerry Arawana and undervaluation of the Chinese unit. Despite a short-term overhang from ADM's share sale, CGS-CIMB reaffirmed its target price of S$5.53. Wilmar's shares rose 1.1% to S$4.43, making it the most actively traded counter on the Singapore bourse.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Friday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened higher on Friday, gaining 0.4% or 10.26 points to 2,538.18. Gainers outnumbered losers 111 to 37, with 71.6 million securities worth S$80.3 million changing hands. Key gainers included Genting Singapore, Wilmar International, and Singapore Telecommunications. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day winning streak.

site_title: F1's engine mode changes to be delayed to after Belgium
summary: Formula One is delaying plans to restrict engine modes in qualifying until after the Belgian Grand Prix, aiming to slow down Mercedes' strong qualifying performance. The change, initially considered for the Italian Grand Prix, would require teams to use the same engine modes in qualifying and racing. Mercedes team boss Toto Wolff believes the ban could help his team in the race, as it would allow them to avoid damaging their power unit in qualifying and maintain more performance in the race. This move follows a statement from world champion Lewis Hamilton, who said the rule change would slow him down.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, SGX, Wilmar, Accordia Golf Trust, China Aviation, Keppel
summary: Singapore stocks to watch include SIA, which deployed staff to share customer service expertise, and SGX, which plans to develop a multi-asset index derivatives offering with FTSE Russell. Wilmar International's shares fell 10.3% after a large shareholder announced plans to sell $800 million worth of shares. Accordia Golf Trust's net profit sank 75.4% due to a decline in golf course performance. China Aviation Oil denied allegations of breaching a letter of credit, while Keppel Corp had its administrative enforcement procedure suspended by the Brazilian government.

site_title: Toughest finance job in India keeps Yes Bank CEO awake at night
summary: Yes Bank CEO Prashant Kumar accepted the job of rescuing the country's most troubled private-sector bank in March 2020, following a run on deposits and a massive bad-loan portfolio. Under his leadership, the bank has made efforts to restore depositors' confidence, with deposits rising by about 120 billion rupees. However, the bank still faces challenges, including containing bad loans and restoring its low-cost deposits. Kumar aims to raise deposits to two trillion rupees by March 2021, and has implemented measures to recover his money from delinquent borrowers. Despite progress, the bank's shares have fallen over 90% since the beginning of last year.

site_title: TikTok pulls 380,000 videos in US for hate content
summary: TikTok has removed over 380,000 videos in the US this year for hate content, banned 1,300 accounts, and deleted 64,000 comments. The platform aims to "eliminate hate" and acknowledges that these numbers do not represent a 100% success rate. This effort is part of TikTok's commitment to addressing hateful content and behavior on its platform, as stated by Eric Han, US head of safety.

images.alt_text: TikTok on Thursday said it has removed more than 380,000 videos in the US this year as part of a part of a mission to "eliminate hate" on the platform.

site_title: Tesla seeks approval for sensor that could detect child left in hot cars
summary: Tesla has asked the FCC for approval to market a short-range interactive motion-sensing device that can detect children left in hot cars. The device uses millimetre-wave radar technology, which provides depth perception and can "see" through soft materials. It can differentiate between a child and an object, reducing false alarms, and detect micromovements like breathing patterns and heart rates. The device aims to prevent child abandonment and boost theft-prevention systems. The FCC is seeking public comment on the request through September 21.

images.alt_text: Tesla asked the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) for approval to market a short-range interactive motion-sensing device that could help prevent children from being left behind in hot cars and boost theft-prevention systems.

site_title: Shell explores sale of a Norwegian natural gas business
summary: Royal Dutch Shell is considering the sale of its Norwegian natural gas supplier, Gasnor, to infrastructure funds or private equity firms. The company has approached potential buyers after exploring a disposal of the business, which delivers liquefied natural gas to industrial and marine customers in Norway. This move comes as Shell transitions to low-carbon energy and amid the ongoing impact of the coronavirus pandemic on the energy sector. The sale could be part of Shell's efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions and reduce its market value, which has fallen 48% this year to around $115 billion.

site_title: Uber, Lyft back off plans to suspend California ride services
summary: Uber and Lyft have backed off plans to suspend California ride services after an appeals court granted them a temporary reprieve from reclassifying drivers as employees. The court granted Uber and Lyft a stay of the original order, allowing them to continue operations while they appeal the decision. The companies had initially planned to suspend services in California to avoid compliance with a new labor law that requires gig workers to be classified as employees.

site_title: American Airlines to cut service to 15 smaller US markets
summary: American Airlines announced it will cut service to 15 smaller US markets, affecting airports in 10 states, starting October 7. The move is part of the airline's efforts to downsize operations due to the ongoing coronavirus crisis. The airline could lay off up to 25,000 workers and is re-evaluating plans for other markets. Unions are campaigning for Congress to extend federal support for industry jobs, but prospects for additional aid remain uncertain, with daily passenger visits to US airports still 70% below pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Asia: Stocks lifted by vaccine hopes, but new cases cause concern
summary: Asian stocks rose on hopes for a vaccine, despite concerns over the spread of the virus and the US stimulus stalemate. The surge in tech stocks, led by Amazon and Apple, pushed the Nasdaq to record highs. However, a weak US jobs report and new unemployment claims reinforced concerns about the US economy. Despite this, investors remain optimistic, citing vast central bank support and the potential for a vaccine.

site_title: A primer for Biden's foreign policy team
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has been criticized for his approach to China, with former Singapore ambassador Kishore Mahbubani arguing in his book "Has China Won?" that Pompeo's strategy of targeting the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) is misguided. Mahbubani believes the CCP is deeply connected to Chinese civilization, and that the US should focus on engaging with the broader Chinese people, rather than trying to change the party's behavior. He also argues that the US should work with allies in Southeast Asia, such as Singapore and the Philippines, to counter China's growing influence.

site_title: Singtel's AIS to rent 155 telco towers from CAT Telecom under settlement
summary: Singtel's Thai associate AIS has agreed to rent 155 telecommunication towers from CAT Telecom under a settlement, resolving disputes worth 860 million baht (S$37.4 million). AIS subsidiary Advanced Wireless Network will rent the towers, while CAT will use the space and maintenance services for five years from July 2020 to September 2025 for a net value of 186 million baht. The agreement ends arbitration and civil court disputes and paves the way for a long-term tower use agreement between the two companies.

site_title: Turkey makes significant Black Sea gas find: sources
summary: Turkey has discovered significant gas resources in the Black Sea, with estimated reserves of 26 trillion cubic feet, enough to meet the country's energy needs for 20 years. The discovery, made by the Turkish drilling ship Fatih, could help reduce Turkey's dependence on energy imports if the gas can be commercially extracted. However, production is expected to take 7-10 years and investment costs are estimated at $2-3 billion. If confirmed, the find could significantly reduce Turkey's energy import bill, boosting government finances and easing a chronic current account deficit.

site_title: Malaysian tycoon behind tumbling cruise firm Genting HK puts fortune on the line
summary: Malaysian tycoon Lim Kok Thay has pledged nearly his entire stake in Genting Hong Kong Ltd, a cruise operator, as collateral for loans, after the stock plummeted 38% on Thursday. The pledge, worth 6 billion shares, is part of Mr Lim's efforts to maintain critical services after suspending payments to creditors. His fortune has declined to US$700 million, down from US$1.5 billion at the beginning of the year. The move has raised concerns about the risk of a margin call, which could lead to further declines in the stock price and a higher crash risk.

images.alt_text: Malaysian tycoon Lim Kok Thay has pledged nearly his entire stake in embattled cruise operator Genting Hong Kong Ltd as collateral for loans, raising the risk of a margin call after the stock plunged 38 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Russia to test coronavirus vaccine on 40,000 people
summary: Russia plans to start clinical trials of its coronavirus vaccine, Sputnik V, involving over 40,000 people. The trials, equivalent to Phase 3 trials, will assess the vaccine's immunogenicity and safety. Mass vaccinations in Russia are expected to start in October, with foreign deliveries in November or December. The vaccine has drawn skepticism from Western scientists, but the head of the Russian Direct Investment Fund says the WHO is starting to evaluate the vaccine, and individual regulators may approve it without WHO approval.

site_title: Facebook confirms Zuckerberg interviewed in FTC investigation
summary: Facebook confirmed that CEO Mark Zuckerberg was interviewed by the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) as part of the US government's antitrust probe into the social media company. The interview, conducted remotely over two days, was under oath and involved staff from states investigating Facebook. This comes after Facebook agreed to pay a record-breaking $5 billion fine to resolve a separate FTC probe into its privacy practices in 2019. The FTC is also investigating Facebook's business practices, including prior acquisitions and digital advertising.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: Rolex is launching a new initiative, "Perpetual Music," to support musicians and singers affected by the pandemic. The initiative includes three concerts in Italy, Germany, and France, featuring renowned artists such as Juan Diego Flórez, Sonya Yoncheva, and Renaud Capuçon. The concerts will be streamed in over 180 countries until the end of October, providing a platform for 100 artists whose work has been impacted by the crisis. The event aims to support musicians during a difficult time, offering them the opportunity to perform with prestigious artists and in fine acoustics.

images.alt_text: Tenor Juan Diego Flórez (left) will perform at Teatro Rossini, Pesaro, on Aug 21. Tenor Rolando Villazòn (right) and violinist Renaud Capuçon will perform on Sept 3 at the Opéra national de Paris (Palais Garnier) with a repertoire of baroque and chamber music.

Tenor Juan Diego Flórez will perform at Teatro Rossini, Pesaro, on Aug 21. Tenor Rolando Villazòn and violinist Renaud Capuçon (above) will perform on Sept 3 at the Opéra national de Paris (Palais Garnier) with a repertoire of baroque and chamber music.
Soprano Sonya Yoncheva will lead a recital programme at the Berlin Staatsoper on Sept 1.

site_title: Gold gains on higher US jobless claims, economic recovery fears
summary: Gold prices rose 0.6% to $1,940.14 per ounce after US jobless claims unexpectedly exceeded one million, fueling economic recovery fears. The US Federal Reserve minutes reiterated concerns over the economy, prompting investors to seek safe-haven assets like gold. The Fed's accommodative stance to help consumers stay afloat during the coronavirus pandemic also supported gold prices.

site_title: Europe: Shares slide on risk-off mood after gloomy Fed view
summary: European stocks slid 1.1% to a 10-day low, with miners and banks falling 1.6-2.9%, due to a risk-off mood triggered by the US Federal Reserve's gloomy view on the world's largest economy's recovery. Policymakers expressed doubt on a quick rebound and may extend aggressive stimulus measures, driving Wall Street indices off record highs.

site_title: World Bank chief warns extreme poverty could surge by 100m
summary: World Bank President David Malpass warned that the coronavirus pandemic may have driven 100 million people into extreme poverty, surpassing the initial estimate of 60 million. The situation is "imperative" for creditors to reduce debt held by poor countries at risk, going beyond the commitment to suspend debt payments.

site_title: Oil falls 1% on Opec+ oversupply, US jobless data
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Thursday after a Reuters report indicated that Opec+ needed to address a daily oversupply of over 2 million barrels. This, combined with a rise in US unemployment benefit claims, signaled a slow economic recovery. Brent crude fell to $44.90 a barrel and WTI to $42.58 a barrel, with Opec+ members required to cut output by 2.31 million barrels per day to make up for the oversupply.

site_title: Pay cuts help spare 224,800 workers from pink slips: MOM
summary: In Singapore, cost-cutting measures have resulted in pay cuts for 224,800 workers across 6,300 companies over the last five months. The latest numbers, released by the Ministry of Manpower, appear to be tapering off since the end of the circuit breaker in April and May. Despite this, wage recovery is expected to lag the economic rebound, indicating a prolonged impact. The pay cuts are a response to the pandemic's economic effects, and the situation is being closely monitored by the government.

site_title: Tourists kicked off Mediterranean cruise for violating virus rules
summary: A family of tourists was removed from an MSC Grandiosa Mediterranean cruise after violating the ship's anti-Covid regulations by leaving an organized excursion. The cruise, which departed from Genoa on Sunday, had 70% passenger capacity due to pandemic restrictions. The incident occurred on the ship's first major voyage in the Mediterranean after a long lockdown. The family was reportedly kicked off the ship, but the exact reason for their removal is not specified. The incident highlights the strict measures in place to prevent the spread of the virus on cruise ships.

site_title: Kamala Harris accepts US vice-presidential nomination with call for change
summary: US Vice Presidential Nominee Kamala Harris accepted her party's nomination, calling for change in the country. In her speech, she criticized President Donald Trump's leadership, saying it has cost lives and livelihoods. Harris urged Americans to elect a president who will bring something different and better, and she endorsed Joe Biden as that candidate. The Democratic convention highlighted the party's priorities, including combating gun violence and climate change. Harris, the first Black and Indian-American woman to be nominated for vice president, emphasized the importance of treating people with dignity and respect.

site_title: Performance appraisal in a pandemic
summary: Companies are rethinking performance appraisals amid the pandemic, as employees work from home and business goals are rendered moot. With shrinking bonus pots, it's crucial to identify deserving staff. The shift to digitalization has accelerated, with the pandemic accelerating a lower carbon world. Integrating Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) factors into investment analysis can change risk and valuation numbers, and companies must adapt to this new reality to assess staff performance fairly.

site_title: SIA has used S$4.4b of funds raised in recent rights issue
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has utilized half of the S$8.8 billion raised in a recent rights issue, with S$4.4 billion spent on various expenses including operating costs, fuel hedging trades, and ticket refunds. SIA used S$2 billion to repay a bridge loan and S$1.1 billion for operating expenses, fuel hedging trades, and ticket refunds. The airline group also has the option to raise up to S$6.2 billion in additional mandatory convertible bonds by July next year.

site_title: Good, clean jobs data a win-win for Singapore
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Josephine Teo has released a new-format jobs report, providing weekly updates on the job situation. The reports aim to shed light on how the pandemic has affected workers, help job seekers access available opportunities, and give the public important information on a regular and timely basis. The move is a welcome step towards data transparency, following criticism of lagging employment data. The reports will cover different aspects of the job situation, including under-employment and gig workers, but some analysts suggest greater granularity is needed to address the changing nature of the Singaporean labour market.

site_title: China, US agree to hold trade talks, Chinese commerce ministry says
summary: China and the US have agreed to hold trade talks "in the coming days" to evaluate the progress of their Phase One trade deal, six months after it took effect in February, according to the Chinese commerce ministry. The talks will assess the implementation of the agreement and determine the next steps. No further details were provided by the ministry spokesperson, Gao Feng.

site_title: Genting Hong Kong suspends payments to creditors
summary: Genting Hong Kong, a cruise ship operator, has temporarily suspended all payments to its creditors, which may lead to defaults. This announcement resulted in a 37.5% drop in the company's shares on Thursday. The move follows the company's financial struggles, and its shares have been volatile in recent times.

site_title: Singaporean faces 2 more Wirecard related charges
summary: A Singaporean, R Shanmugaratnam, faces two additional charges related to falsifying letters about Wirecard's escrow accounts. The charges, under Section 477A of the Penal Code, involve misrepresenting balances held by Citadelle, a company handling Wirecard's funds, as at March 2016. This brings Shanmugaratnam's total charges to six, following previous charges for falsifying letters to Wirecard UK & Ireland and Cardsystems Middle East FZ.

site_title: Accor considered possible merger with UK rival: report
summary: Accor SA, a French hotel company, considered a possible merger with UK rival InterContinental Hotels Group plc due to the pandemic's impact on the tourism industry. A team was formed in June to study the transaction, but Accor's CEO decided it was not the right moment. A combination would bring together 5,000 Accor properties and 6,000 InterContinental hotels, offering cost savings and geographic fit, but analysts question its merits due to InterContinental's rebounding shares and complexities of the deal.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust Q1 net profit plunges 75.4% on Japan's Covid-19 state of emergency
summary: Accordia Golf Trust's Q1 net profit plummeted 75.4% to 570 million yen due to Japan's Covid-19 state of emergency. Operating income fell 27.1% to 10.65 billion yen, with golf course performance showing a significant decline. Total players fell 12.3% to 1.42 million, and revenue per player decreased 21.6%. The company rolled out discounts and outreach programs to attract local golfers, but expects muted performance in the coming months due to high uncertainty. Units of AGT ended Thursday at 74 Singapore cents, up 0.5 cent or 0.7%.

site_title: Retooling strategy for a post-pandemic world
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for businesses to adapt, predict, and be resilient in a rapidly changing world. A retooled strategy is essential to navigate uncertainty, and companies must rebalance investment in adaptability, prediction, and resilience. To succeed, leaders should focus on developing Agile organizations, creating an "Engine 2" to challenge industry boundaries, and improving prediction through scenario planning. Resilience requires attention to five key aspects of the business, including strategy and customer relevance, and companies must prioritize building resilience over time.

site_title: Sports Hub a 'national icon' with much potential to flourish: new CEO Lionel Yeo
summary: The Sports Hub in Singapore, a major sports and entertainment venue, is facing a challenging year due to the COVID-19 pandemic. However, under new CEO Lionel Yeo, the venue is being repurposed to house temporary dormitories for migrant workers, showcasing its versatility. Despite a 85% drop in attendance, Yeo is optimistic about the venue's future, with foreign event organizers already making provisional bookings for 2021. He emphasizes the Sports Hub's advantages, including its global city status, business confidence, and reputation for delivering high-quality events. Yeo's vision is to revive the venue with top sporting and entertainment events, aligning with government initiatives and partnering with sponsors and patrons.

images.alt_text: It has been an eventful first six months on the job for Mr Yeo with the global sports industry in a tailspin.

site_title: Quicker cut-off will surface better startups
summary: Enterprise Singapore (ESG) is launching a three-month venture building programme to help entrepreneurs form co-founding teams, validate business ideas, and find capital. The programme, in partnership with Singapore's five autonomous universities, aims to separate promising startups from the rest. ESG will also raise the grant support of the Startup SG Founder programme to S$50,000 from September, providing more resources for startups to develop their business ideas. The move is seen as a vital key in helping stakeholders identify and support high-quality startups, particularly in a post-COVID-19 economy.

site_title: HK mortgage relief fails to revive commercial property
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) raised the loan-to-value ratio cap for commercial properties to 50% from 40%, allowing buyers to borrow more for office and retail space. However, this move is unlikely to significantly boost the commercial property market, which has been battered by the pandemic and recession. Despite the relaxation of loan rules, the market remains sluggish, and the HKMA's move is seen as a limited response to address the market's struggles.

site_title: Nissan's aggressive EV plans include Singapore
summary: Nissan plans to expand its electric vehicle (EV) offerings in Singapore, with the launch of its new electric sport utility vehicle (SUV), the Ariya, expected in the first quarter of 2022. The company aims to sell one million electrified cars annually by 2023 and will use its e-Power models to bridge the gap in markets with underdeveloped EV infrastructure. Nissan has already sold over 500 units of its e-Power models in Singapore, and the company is engaging with government agencies to accelerate EV adoption, following the introduction of incentives such as revised road tax structures and public charging network development.

site_title: Qantas posts A$2.7b loss, confirms job cuts
summary: Qantas posts an almost A$2.7 billion annual loss due to a "near-total collapse" in demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Revenues collapsed 82% between April and June, prompting the airline to ground 100 planes for up to a year and retrench 6,000 staff. Qantas expects a "significant loss" in the coming financial year, with the global aviation industry facing its biggest crisis to date. Despite this, the airline believes it remains "well positioned" to take advantage of the eventual return to air travel.

site_title: Beijing's Workers' Stadium razed as China eyes football World Cup bid
summary: Beijing's Workers' Stadium, a landmark since 1959, was demolished in a few days as part of China's plans to revamp its football infrastructure ahead of a potential 2030 FIFA World Cup bid. The stadium, which hosted the 2008 Olympic Games and 2004 Asian Cup final, will be rebuilt and completed by December 2022 with a capacity of around 65,000. China is on a football-stadium building spree, with new venues springing up across the country, including a 100,000-seat venue by Guangzhou Evergrande.

images.alt_text: The famous Workers' Stadium in Beijing was built in 1959 and was home to Chinese Super League club Beijing Guoan. It hosted football matches for the 2008 Olympic Games.

site_title: Forget French Rosé, Italy's under-explored pink wines offer big value
summary: Italy's lesser-known rosé wines offer a diverse range of hues and flavors, from pale salmon to intense dark-cherry pink. Produced from native grapes, these wines showcase Italy's rich wine heritage. The country boasts several regions known for rosé production, including Bardolino, Valtenesi, Abruzzo, Puglia, and Calabria. Italian rosés have gained popularity in recent years, with high-quality examples becoming more accessible due to the US trade tariffs imposed on French rosés. Affordable and delicious, Italian rosés are a great alternative to French rosés and offer a unique taste experience.

site_title: SGX finds new index partner in FTSE Russell as battle for index business heats up
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has partnered with FTSE Russell to develop and market a multi-asset index derivatives offering focusing on Asian and Emerging Markets. The partnership aims to meet the needs of global investors, particularly in ESG, dividend, sector, and duration strategies. This move comes after MSCI Inc migrated from Singapore to Hong Kong, dealing a blow to SGX's lucrative derivatives business. SGX and FTSE Russell will roll out products in the coming months, expanding on their existing relationship and track record in existing products.

site_title: Forming corporate diamonds under pressure
summary: Organisations that focus on innovation have outperformed the market average during the 2009 financial crisis and continue to thrive during the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite challenges, forward-thinking companies have rapidly innovated, spinning off or building new businesses to capitalize on digital adoption and market shifts. Examples include a retailer launching a new e-commerce business in 13 weeks, and Microsoft's CEO Satya Nadella noting that two years' worth of digital transformation occurred in just two months.

site_title: Apple's value hits US$2t, punctuating Big Tech's grip
summary: Apple has become the first US company to reach a $2 trillion valuation, surpassing Saudi Aramco, the world's most valuable company. The milestone was achieved in just two years, with Apple's second $1 trillion milestone coming in just 21 weeks, despite the global economy shrinking during the coronavirus pandemic. Tech giants Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, Alphabet, and Facebook have seen their values swell by nearly $3 trillion since March 23, with investors betting on their size and power as refuges from the pandemic-induced recession.

site_title: Oil prices fall amid demand threat, drop in stockpiles
summary: Oil prices dropped 0.8% to $45.03 a barrel for Brent crude and $42.57 a barrel for US oil, amid warnings of a risk to demand recovery if the coronavirus crisis is prolonged. US crude inventories fell less than expected, but global demand is expected to recover to pre-pandemic levels in the fourth quarter, according to Saudi Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman. The Opec+ group left output reductions unchanged, despite concerns over non-compliance from some members, citing a second extended wave of the pandemic as a major risk to the oil market recovery.

site_title: Trump laments arrest of former adviser Bannon as a 'sad event'
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed regret over the arrest of his former adviser Steve Bannon, calling it a "sad event." Bannon, a key figure in Trump's nationalist populism, has been charged with defrauding Trump supporters in a $25 million crowdfunding campaign to build the US-Mexico border wall. Trump stated he had not dealt with Bannon for years and expressed uncertainty about the project, saying it sounded like "showboating." Bannon and three others face up to 40 years in prison for conspiracy to commit wire fraud and money laundering.

site_title: With bankers stuck at home, Asia wealth management hits snag
summary: Wealth management in Hong Kong and Singapore has been hit by the pandemic, with bankers unable to freely travel to meet new prospects and verify client wealth. Despite easing regulations, banks are still catching up with digitization, and some executives are reluctant to step away from traditional checks. The growth of new money in Asia has taken a hit, with UBS and JPMorgan Chase & Co seeing a decline in new assets. However, some banks are adapting, with Bank of Singapore reporting a rise in assets and Credit Suisse seeing a 80% increase in net new assets in the second quarter.

site_title: Five former remisiers charged with false trading
summary: Five former remisiers in Singapore have been charged with false trading, accused of rigging the prices of 55 securities over a year. The charges include 80 against Alan Lee, 79 against Chew Wei Zhan, and 61 against Lee Wei Kai. They face up to seven years in jail and fines of up to S$250,000 if convicted. The offences allegedly took place between March 2015 and April 2016, involving various brokerages and companies, including Japfa and Sunningdale Tech. The court has adjourned their cases to Sept 17.

site_title: Singtel's fiscal 2021 Ebitda forecast to drop 11-13% to between S$3.9b and S$4.1b: S&P
summary: Singtel's Ebitda forecast for fiscal 2021 is expected to decline 11-13% to between S$3.9 billion and S$4.1 billion, according to S&P Global Ratings. Adjusted Ebitda is forecasted to drop 6-8% to between S$5.1 billion and S$5.2 billion. The decline is attributed to pandemic-related movement restrictions and economic deterioration, with improvements anticipated in the second half of 2021.

site_title: Digital theatre is here to stay
summary: Singapore theatre practitioners have adapted to the age of social distancing by creating digital solutions, with the most adaptable ones reformulating their scripts and incorporating Zoom and social media elements. Those who rely on popular Broadway or West End scripts have been slower to adapt, as there are limited scripts written for the digital stage. This shift has allowed original Singapore works to thrive, highlighting the potential of digital theatre to stay relevant and exciting.

site_title: China Aviation Oil refutes claims made by Swiss bank BCP, seeks legal advice
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) has refuted claims made by Swiss bank BCP, stating that allegations of false representations and breach of a letter of credit are "entirely unmeritorious and misconceived". CAO has sought legal advice and plans to "vigorously resist and refute" BCP's claims. BCP had paid CAO $19 million after receiving documents showing the cargo had been loaded and delivered, but CAO denies this and claims to have presented confirming documents to the confirming bank. CAO's shares fell 3.35% on the news.

site_title: US dollar rebounds from 2-year trough
summary: The US dollar rebounded from a two-year low, climbing 1% above 92.12, its highest level in two months. The rebound was fueled by less dovish minutes from the Federal Reserve policy meeting, prompting bears to buy into the heavily shorted currency. The dollar index closed at 93.01 in late morning London trading, marking its biggest one-day surge in over two months.

site_title: Saudi sovereign fund sets up real estate unit to meet housing demand
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has established a real estate subsidiary, Roshn, to meet the country's increasing demand for housing. The move aims to diversify the economy, as the government seeks private sector partnerships to supplement its finances. With Saudi Arabia having already spent billions on housing, Roshn will help address the gap in the local housing market.

site_title: Art for the end of the world
summary: STPI's new exhibition "Turning The Axis Of The World" explores a world gone mad, featuring over 30 works by 16 artists from the region, including Rirkrit Tiravanija, Teppei Kaneuji, and Heri Dono. The exhibition imagines a cataclysmic overturning of the natural order, with works touching on death, destruction, and rebirth. Notable pieces include Hema Upadhyay's mixed media assemblage, Dinh Q. Le's panoramic image of Angkor Wat, and Tiravanija's installations featuring silvery spheres and mathematical equations, which suggest doorways to other worlds.

site_title: Delta to block middle seats through Jan 6 but allow more people on flights
summary: Delta Air Lines will block middle seats on flights through January 6, covering the holiday season, but will raise the cap on passengers to 75% in October. This policy change aims to increase revenue, despite depressed travel demand due to the coronavirus pandemic. The airline is also extending a waiver on change fees for new flights purchased through September 30.

site_title: Wilmar sinks 10% after major shareholder reveals plans to cut stake
summary: Wilmar International's shares dropped 10% after major shareholder Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) announced plans to sell US$800 million worth of shares and bonds. This move led to a decline in the company's stock price to S$4.36. The sale, worth 10% of ADM's stake in Wilmar, was revealed on the same day the company's shares closed at S$4.36.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Corp's subsidiaries Keppel Offshore & Marine, Keppel Fels, Keppel Fels Brasil, BrasFELS, and Prismatic Services have had their administrative enforcement procedure suspended by the Office of the Comptroller General of Brazil due to alleged irregularities under the Brazilian Anti-Corruption Statute. Secura Training Academy in Singapore has been suspended from funding schemes for a year due to breaches, with the company appealing the decision and implementing internal controls to prevent similar incidents.

site_title: Living and working in the post-pandemic era
summary: Architects and designers in Singapore share their ideas on how living, dining, shopping, and vacationing may be like in the post-pandemic era. Key trends include a focus on greenery, comfort, and technology to enhance the home and work experience. Homeowners want more space for leisure activities, while office spaces will need to adapt to accommodate remote work. Dining establishments are prioritizing private rooms and efficient layouts to ensure social distancing. Retailers are exploring ways to enhance the shopping experience, such as seamless online-offline interactions and experiential spaces.

site_title: Only sustainable tech startups can drive jobs growth
summary: Singapore's tech startups are generating thousands of job vacancies under the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package, but many have also conducted layoffs or collapsed due to underlying business model factors. To determine if these startups can provide a silver lining to the job market, business sustainability is key. Venture capital-backed startups, in particular, must be mindful of their funding and business fundamentals to create value-adding jobs. The pandemic may serve as a stress test for the local startup ecosystem, potentially leading to a more resilient and sustainable future.

site_title: Skoda Superb review: Still a Superb proposition
summary: The Skoda Superb has undergone a facelift, offering improved value for its price. The updated executive sedan boasts new engine, crisp styling, and features such as electric memory front seats, panoramic sunroof, and adaptive cruise control. The car's new 2.0-litre turbocharged petrol engine provides a 10-hp increase and 70Nm of torque, making it more sprightly to drive. The Superb also features a roomy cabin, huge boot, and premium quality interior, making it an attractive option for Singaporean buyers. Available for S$153,900, the Superb is a "cheap and good" proposition for those seeking an executive car.

site_title: Golden Energy focuses on acquisitions, cost optimisation amid low coal prices
summary: Golden Energy Resources (Gear) is seizing opportunities in the low coal price environment by acquiring assets and optimizing costs. The company has increased its stake in ASX-listed Stanmore Coal to 60% and acquired a gold mine in Australia, allowing it to diversify its portfolio. Gear is also exploring acquisitions of smaller Australian miners and is working to expand its Ravenswood Gold Mine. The company's cost discipline has supported its financial performance, with record revenue and a 32.4% increase in net profit in the first half of the year.

site_title: Global outage hits Google as users face e-mail, storage disruption
summary: A seven-hour global outage affected Google services, including email, storage, document, and videoconferencing, on August 20, 2020. The disruption, reported by 10,000 users in Singapore, caused issues with attachments, log-in problems, and email receipt. Google confirmed the outage and reported services restored at 7pm. The cause of the disruption remains unknown, and Google has not provided details on redundancy plans. The outage occurred during a critical time, exacerbating productivity challenges during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Knock on Wood
summary: This article highlights various home decor pieces featuring natural wood accents, from furniture to decorative panels, that offer a sensory and comforting experience. Designers and local retailers showcase their collections, emphasizing the beauty and durability of wood. Items range from affordable wooden bowls to high-end wooden furniture pieces, including a reclaimed teak wood speaker cabinet and a hand-carved wooden stool. The focus is on sustainable and eco-friendly designs that bring warmth and character to any home.

site_title: Airbnb bans parties in Covid-19 fight
summary: Airbnb has implemented a global ban on parties and events in homes listed on its platform to enforce social distancing norms during the Covid-19 pandemic. The new rules cap occupancy at 16 and may result in a ban from the community and even legal action for hosts or guests who skirt the rules. This move comes as the company files confidentially for an initial public offering (IPO) and sees a rebound in bookings, with over one million nights booked in a single day for the first time since March.

site_title: Former Trump adviser Bannon charged with fraud by federal prosecutors
summary: Former Trump adviser Steve Bannon has been charged with conspiracy to commit wire fraud in a $25 million crowdfunding campaign for the US-Mexico border wall. Bannon and others allegedly defrauded hundreds of thousands of donors, who thought the funds would go towards building the wall. However, the founder of the campaign, Brian Kolfage, used some of the money to fund a lavish lifestyle. Bannon and others are accused of orchestrating the scheme. The indictment marks a significant development in a federal investigation into the fundraising campaign.

site_title: STI falls for 4th straight session on concerns over recovery of US economy
summary: Singapore stocks fell for the fourth consecutive day, closing 1.29% lower at 2,527.92 due to US Federal Reserve officials' caution over the country's economic outlook. The US Fed expressed concerns over the ongoing public health crisis weighing on economic activity, employment, and inflation. Asian markets also declined, with the Hang Seng Index and Nikkei 225 Index falling 1.54% and 1%, respectively.

site_title: Airbnb files for IPO as short-term rental market rebounds
summary: Airbnb has filed for an initial public offering (IPO) with US regulators, marking a rebound in the travel industry following the COVID-19 pandemic. The company, which suspended marketing activities and cut 25% of its workforce in 2020, has seen a surge in bookings, with over 1 million nights booked in a single day. Airbnb aims to list before the end of the year, with Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs serving as lead advisers. The company's valuation and IPO details have not been disclosed.

images.alt_text: The number of shares Airbnb will sell and the valuation it will seek have not yet been determined, says the company.

site_title: Football: Liverpool to begin Premier League title defence against Leeds
summary: Liverpool will begin their Premier League title defense against newly promoted Leeds United on September 12 at Anfield, marking the start of the new season. Manchester City and Manchester United will not participate on the opening weekend due to their European seasons. The season will conclude on May 23, with the first major derby set for October 17 when Everton hosts Liverpool. A series of title rival matches, including the first showdown between Liverpool and Manchester City, will take place in November and February.

site_title: MAS acts to stop misleading sale of critical illness plans
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has taken action to stop financial advisers from misleadingly selling critical illness (CI) plans, citing exaggerated claims about the difficulty of claiming benefits. The regulator confirmed it issued a circular to licensed firms, reminding them to provide proper advice and avoid aggressive sales tactics. The changes to CI definitions, announced by the Life Insurance Association (LIA) Singapore in June, aim to provide greater clarity and transparency for customers.

site_title: Fintech Advance.AI riding wave of buy-now pay-later online shopping
summary: Singapore fintech Advance.AI has seen a surge in demand for its buy-now pay-later checkout financing solution, driven by younger shoppers seeking to manage cash flow amid the pandemic. The service has aided a tripling in online transactions for its 500-odd merchants, with gross merchandise volume growing 11 times. Advance.AI's AI technology assesses credit risk and is now available at malls under CapitaLand, with no fees charged to consumers but commissions for merchants. The fintech is investing in research and development and hiring staff to support its growing retail offering.

images.alt_text: Mr Chen: The buy-now pay-later service is popular among Gen Z and millennials, who are "concerned about... spending and saving".

site_title: German bund yields drop to -0.50% as investors get nervous
summary: German benchmark yields dropped to -0.50% as investors sought safe-haven German debt amid rising coronavirus cases and concerns over a US economic recovery. The European Central Bank's flexibility in emergency bond purchases was debated, and US Federal Reserve minutes released, contributing to lower yields. Strong demand at a German auction and concerns over a second coronavirus wave also played a role, with the German 10-year Bund yield falling to its lowest since August 11.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower after jobless claims top 1m
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, falling 0.25% in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, 0.43% in the S&P 500, and 0.45% in the Nasdaq Composite. The decline was driven by weekly jobless claims exceeding 1 million, lending weight to the Federal Reserve's view of a difficult economic recovery. The news followed a previous day's rally, as investors remained cautious despite the US-China trade talks and a new funding round for Airalo.

site_title: CFM Holdings warns of net loss for FY20
summary: CFM Holdings, a metal stamping services provider, expects to record a net loss for FY20 due to a decline in revenue and profit margin caused by the economic slowdown from the pandemic and higher administrative expenses. The company attributes the decline to a key client pushing back manufacturing of their products. Further details on the group's performance will be disclosed on or before August 28. The company's counter closed at 2.6 Singapore cents, up 0.3 Singapore cent, on Thursday.

site_title: Former top civil servant Ngiam Tong Dow dies, aged 83
summary: Former top civil servant Ngiam Tong Dow, 83, has died peacefully after a four-and-a-half-year battle with illness. A Singaporean born to a court interpreter and washerwoman, Ngiam spent 40 years in the administrative service, working closely with Singapore's founding leaders, including Lee Kuan Yew and Goh Chok Tong. Known for being outspoken, he advocated for growing local small- and medium-sized enterprises and a more compassionate approach to policy-making. Ngiam received numerous public service awards during his career, including the Public Administration Medal and the Distinguished Service Order.

site_title: Companies that are agile can still grow during crisis: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat said companies that have remained agile and invested in innovation can still grow during crisis. He visited Forefront Medical Technology, a precision engineering company that expanded into manufacturing Covid-19 diagnostic products and hired 80 more staff. The company's success highlights the potential for growth in the midst of the pandemic. The government's Jobs Growth Incentive scheme aims to support companies in increasing their local workforce, particularly older workers, with subsidies of up to 50% of salaries for one year.

images.alt_text: DPM Heng says the Jobs Growth Incentive will support companies in increasing their local workforce, with more help for mature workers.

site_title: CBL Properties expects to file for bankruptcy
summary: CBL Properties, a US mall owner, is planning to file for bankruptcy due to dwindling foot traffic, shuttered retail space, and unaffordable rents. The company reached an agreement with creditors to hand control to holders of unsecured notes, aiming to eliminate $900 million of debt. The bankruptcy filing, expected by October 1, will be funded by $220 million in cash, allowing the company to continue operating during the court process. The restructuring plan will see common and preferred stockholders share 10% of the reorganized company.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson to test coronavirus vaccine in 60,000 volunteers
summary: Johnson & Johnson plans to conduct a late-stage trial of its coronavirus vaccine in up to 60,000 volunteers across 180 sites in the US and other countries starting in September. This is larger than rival vaccine makers Moderna and Pfizer's target of 30,000 volunteers. The trial's results will be crucial in determining the vaccine's effectiveness against the virus.

site_title: Kia Seltos review: You can't myth this
summary: The Kia Seltos is a small sport utility vehicle that excels in daily motoring, offering convenience and a funky name inspired by the mythical King of the Celts, Celtos. Despite its compact size, the Seltos has been designed to make a big impression, boasting a bold exterior and impressive features. In review, the Kia Seltos is found to be a capable and practical choice for those seeking a reliable and feature-packed vehicle.

site_title: Appetite for a new dining experience
summary: Appetite, the sister outlet of Michelin-starred Nouri, has opened in Singapore, marrying food, art, and music in an innovative lifestyle environment. The two-level space features a gallery-level art exhibit, a record library, and an informal open-concept kitchen serving cross-cultural snacks and larger plates. The menu showcases hints of global cuisines, including Hokkaido scallop and Sakura ebi, while the record library offers a curated selection of 3,000 records. With workshops, book launches, and art events on the horizon, Appetite aims to create a unique experience that combines art, culture, and food.

images.alt_text: It's like wandering around the home of an art collecting friend before sitting down for dinner.
It's like wandering around the home of an art collecting friend before sitting down for dinner.
A record library, filled with 3,000 records.
Left: Foie gras and chicken liver parfait and Szechuan Burrata open-faced sandwiches. Right: Bunuelo de Viento with Hokkaido scallop.
Big-headed Carabinero prawn expertly poached and minimally dressed in flavoured oil and aromatics.

site_title: Estee Lauder posts 32% fall in sales, to cut up to 2,000 jobs
summary: Estee Lauder reported a 32% fall in fourth-quarter sales, mainly due to travel restrictions and store closures caused by the coronavirus. The company also announced plans to cut 1,500 to 2,000 jobs globally and close 10-15% of its freestanding stores. This move comes as the beauty industry continues to face challenges.

site_title: OPEC+ needs to fix daily oversupply of more than 2m barrels: document
summary: OPEC+ needs to cut daily oil production by 2.31 million barrels per day to offset oversupply, according to an internal report. This would require an additional 1.54 million barrels per day cut from non-OPEC members. The report also forecasts a 9.1 million barrel per day decline in global oil demand in 2020, with a risk of a 11.2 million barrel per day decline if a second wave of infections hits major economies.

site_title: Google services down for users around the world
summary: Google services, including Gmail and Drive, were down for users worldwide on August 20, 2020, with reports of disruptions in multiple continents. The outage was acknowledged by Google, which stated it was "aware of a service disruption" and advised users to check back later. The issue affected users in countries such as Australia, Japan, France, and the US, with frustrated customers taking to social media to report the problem. Google referred users to its G Suite Dashboard for status updates.

site_title: See-Mode raises US$7m Series A funds led by MassMutual Ventures
summary: Singapore-based medtech startup See-Mode has raised US$7 million in a Series A round led by MassMutual Ventures Southeast Asia. The funding will be used to expand its products to Europe and the US, double its headcount, and build partnerships with research institutions. See-Mode's AI-based medical software, Augmented Vascular Analysis (AVA), aims to improve stroke prediction. The startup plans to use the funds to drive growth and expand its capabilities, with confidence from investors that its products will deliver transformative healthcare solutions.

site_title: Sterling holds above US$1.31 as dollar jumps after Fed minutes
summary: Sterling holds above US$1.31 as the US dollar jumps after the release of less dovish than expected minutes from the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The pound traded at US$1.3127, up 0.2% on the day, despite a session low and a recent eight-month high. The Fed minutes were vague on policy strategy changes and economic recovery, prompting a short-lived correction in risk assets, including sterling. The UK still hopes for a post-Brexit trade deal by September, but time is limited given the lack of progress so far.

site_title: Trump must give his tax returns to NY prosecutor, judge rules
summary: A US federal judge ruled that Donald Trump must give eight years of his tax returns to a New York prosecutor, rejecting the president's claims of immunity. Judge Victor Marrero stated that letting Trump block the subpoena would expand presidential immunity, and Trump has quickly appealed the decision. The case concerns a 2019 subpoena related to a criminal probe into Trump and his organization, and it's unlikely that Trump's financial records will become public before the presidential election in November. Trump has long fought efforts to obtain his tax returns, departing from decades-long practice of his predecessors.

site_title: Secura Group subsidiary suspended from SkillsFuture Singapore Agency funding schemes for a year
