summary: Secura Group's subsidiary, Secura Training Academy, has been suspended from SkillsFuture Singapore Agency funding schemes for a year due to breaches. The suspension is a result of an inadvertent administrative oversight by STA's management. As a result, STA has been required to refund approximately S$42,111 to the SSG. The company has implemented rectification measures and will conduct an internal audit review to ensure compliance with the SkillsConnect general terms and conditions.

site_title: South Korea Covid-19 infections 'in full swing' after protest outbreak
summary: South Korea is experiencing a surge in COVID-19 infections, with 288 new cases reported as of midnight on Wednesday, marking a week of triple-digit daily increases. The outbreak is linked to a church attended by members who participated in a political demonstration in Seoul. Authorities warn that without aggressive contact tracing, the country may experience a nationwide pandemic, similar to the US and Europe. The government has banned in-person church meetings and restricted rallies to fewer than 10 people.

site_title: Chinese EV maker Nio launches battery leasing service, eyes global market
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio has launched a battery leasing service, called "battery as a service" (BaaS), allowing drivers to buy an EV without owning the battery pack, reducing the starting price of its cars. The service, priced at 273,600 yuan for the cheapest Nio car, enables customers to pay a monthly rental fee for use of the batteries. Nio plans to expand its battery-swapping stations to 300 next year, with international market entry starting in the second half of 2021, targeting European countries.

site_title: Could the new GLA make Mercedes Singapore's number one car brand this year?
summary: Mercedes-Benz has launched a redesigned GLA in Singapore, which could potentially make the brand the number one car brand in Singapore this year. The new model features a more elevated driving position, increased room inside, and practical new features such as sliding rear seats and dual widescreen displays. The GLA 200 and GLA 200 AMG Line variants have been priced at S$176,888 and S$182,888, respectively. With its strong sales history and growing SUV lineup, Mercedes-Benz is optimistic about the GLA's impact on its market position.

site_title: Chinese insurance tech firm Waterdrop raises US$230m, plans US IPO
summary: Chinese insurance tech firm Waterdrop has raised US$230 million in a funding round led by Swiss Re and Tencent Holdings, valuing the company at nearly US$2 billion. The funding comes ahead of Waterdrop's planned US IPO and will be used to tap into artificial intelligence and big data for its products and services, and accelerate its initiatives in medical and healthcare services. Waterdrop plans to double its total written premium in 2020, with 120 million unique policy holders.

site_title: SGX signs new index partner FTSE Russell
summary: SGX and FTSE Russell signed an agreement to deliver new Asian multi-asset solutions, jointly developing and marketing index derivatives for Asian and emerging markets. The products will be anchored on FTSE Russell's global benchmark indices. The partnership aims to support growing demand for index-based listed futures and options in Asia, and to develop sustainable investment solutions aligned with globally recognized ESG standards.

site_title: B Capital leads US$15m raise in CRM platform Yalochat
summary: B Capital, led by Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin, has led a $15 million Series B funding round in CRM platform Yalochat, its first investment in the Latin American market. The platform, which helps large enterprises use messaging apps like WhatsApp for sales and customer service, has seen a tenfold increase in message volume since the COVID-19 pandemic. Yalochat plans to expand into the Asian market while consolidating its presence in Brazil and Spanish-speaking Latin America. B Capital's investment is seen as a strategic move to help Yalochat bridge the gap between existing software solutions and messaging apps.

site_title: China to allow first football fans in stadiums since coronavirus
summary: China has allowed 1,000 football fans to attend a match in the Chinese Super League, the first time spectators have been allowed since the coronavirus pandemic. The move is a step towards normalizing football in China, where the virus was first detected last year. Fans must provide a recent coronavirus test, wear masks, and maintain social distancing to attend the match. This is a significant development for football leagues worldwide, which have restarted despite the pandemic and are now exploring ways to safely allow fans to return.

site_title: UBS revamps wealth unit structure to free up billions for loans
summary: UBS Group is overhauling its wealth management unit's legal structure, Project Rigi, to free up billions for lending outside Switzerland. The move, expected to run through 2022, will transfer large customer deposits into the bank's main UBS legal unit, allowing for increased lending to wealthy clients. The change partially reverses measures from the 2008 financial crisis, which isolated Swiss entity deposits. The overhaul aims to boost loans to $20-30 billion annually, driving down expenses and improving efficiency.

site_title: Asian Micro Holdings reports lower losses in FY20
summary: Asian Micro Holdings reported a narrowed net loss of S$210,000 for FY20, down from S$886,000 a year ago. Revenue declined 11% to S$3.96 million due to lower trading and natural gas vehicle-related business revenue. Earnings per share improved to 0.002 Singapore cent, compared to a loss of 0.033 Singapore cent in FY19. The company expects a challenging business environment due to the pandemic and plans to focus on operational efficiency, cost control, and cash conservation.

site_title: Brazil suspends administrative enforcement procedure against 5 Keppel units
summary: The Office of the Comptroller General of Brazil (CGU) has suspended its administrative enforcement procedure against five Keppel subsidiaries, including Keppel Offshore & Marine and Keppel Fels, due to lack of factual particulars in the notice. The suspension will not affect Keppel's ongoing negotiations with Brazilian authorities over a $422.2 million fine imposed in 2017 for corrupt payments. Keppel will make further announcements if "material developments" arise.

site_title: Indonesia's rate cuts on pause for now: economists
summary: Indonesia's central bank has decided to keep its policy rate unchanged at 4% for now, signaling an end to rate cuts for the time being. Economists attribute this decision to quantitative measures supporting the economy's recovery, citing encouraging higher-frequency indicators such as retail sales growth and rising consumer confidence. The focus is expected to shift to driving growth via quantitative easing and tweaking macroprudential measures, rather than further rate cuts, due to concerns about currency stability and yield attractiveness.

site_title: China Aviation Oil refutes claims made by Swiss bank BCP
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) has refuted claims made by Swiss bank BCP, stating the allegations are "entirely unmeritorious and misconceived". BCP had issued a writ of summons last month over a letter of credit for a gasoil purchase in January, but CAO claims the allegations are baseless. CAO has sought legal advice from a local law firm, citing documents showing the cargo was loaded onto a tanker and ZenRock Commodities Trading took delivery.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims back over 1m
summary: The US saw a rise in weekly jobless claims, exceeding 1 million for the first time since March, according to the Labor Department. Initial claims for state unemployment benefits rose to 1.106 million for the week ended August 15, surpassing economists' forecasts. The extra $600 weekly unemployment benefit lapsed on July 31, and its implementation has been unclear due to funding issues. The US economy has regained only 9.3 million of the 22 million jobs lost between February and April, with new COVID-19 infections spreading across the nation.

images.alt_text: The number of Americans filing a new claim for unemployment benefits rose unexpectedly back above the one million mark last week, a setback for a struggling US job market crippled by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: China's top court slashes maximum legal private lending rate
summary: China's Supreme People's Court reduced the maximum private loan interest rate from 24% to 15.4%, capping it at four times the benchmark loan prime rate. This move aims to curb usurious loans and lower borrowing costs for struggling small businesses, particularly those affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The decision also targets China's non-bank lending market, which has faced regulatory pressure to curb financial risks. The central bank reported outstanding loans to small businesses stood at 13.7 trillion yuan, averaging 5.27% in July.

site_title: A 5,000% surge makes Medtecs Singapore's top stock
summary: Medtecs International, a medical apparel maker, has seen its shares surge 5,000% in six months due to high demand for essential protective equipment and workwear during the pandemic. The company's net income grew 100 times, with CEO William Yang predicting better profits for the second half. However, experts warn investors to be cautious, as the vaccine's availability may lead to a surplus of medical supplies and reduced demand.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Nearly 23,000 workers in Singapore took wage cuts in July, mainly due to the construction sector. The SGUnited Jobs and Skills scheme saw 330 new workers hired, with mid-career professionals making up half of them. Singapore Airlines spent half of its S$8.8 billion raised in a rights issue, while five former remisiers were charged for false trading. Archer Daniels Midland plans to sell shares in Wilmar International for US$500 million. Singapore stocks fell for the fourth straight session due to concerns over the US economy's recovery.

site_title: ESG raises Startup SG Founder grant to S$50,000, sets up 3-month venture building programme
summary: Enterprise Singapore (ESG) has increased the grant support of the Startup SG Founder programme to S$50,000 from September, aiming to extend the runway for startups to develop their business ideas. The programme now requires a co-matching amount of S$10,000 from founders. A three-month venture building programme will also be set up, with partnerships with Singapore's five autonomous universities, to help entrepreneurs form co-founding teams and validate business ideas. The enhanced programme aims to encourage founders to start with a range of competencies and provide mentorship to graduates.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close sharply down
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.54% on Thursday, following a global sell-off, as concerns about the US outlook and a lack of stimulus agreement weighed on the market. The Hang Seng Index fell to 24,791.39, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined by 1.30% and 1.24%, respectively. The losses were in line with a global sell-off, with the US Federal Reserve raising concerns about the US outlook.

site_title: Alibaba beats quarterly revenue, profit estimates
summary: Alibaba Group Holding reported a stronger-than-expected quarterly revenue and profit, driven by a shift to online shopping and cloud computing amid the coronavirus crisis. The company's core commerce business jumped 34% to 133.32 billion yuan, while cloud computing revenue surged 59% to 12.35 billion yuan. Excluding items, Alibaba earned 14.82 yuan per American depository share, beating analyst estimates of 13.78 yuan. The company's US-listed shares rose marginally before the bell, marking a 23% gain for the year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower in cautious trade
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 1.00% to 22,880.62, and the Topix index ending down 0.90% at 1,599.20. Investors took a cautious approach with no new market-moving events.

site_title: Shares in hoteliers Accor, IHG rise after reported merger interest
summary: Shares in Accor and IHG rose after Le Figaro reported a potential merger between the two hotel groups, creating the world's biggest hotel group with a market value of around $17 billion. Accor's management board is in favor of a deal, but the company's chairman is cautious. The move could propel the firms ahead of US rival Marriott and make geographical sense, with Accor's brands skewed towards Europe and IHG's operations in the US and Greater China. Both firms have announced job cuts and cost savings plans due to the pandemic.

site_title: Japan startup raises US$28m to help fund Moon mission
summary: ispace, a Tokyo-based space startup, has raised $28 million from Japanese investors to fund its first mission to the Moon. The company aims to land on the Moon in 2022 and explore its surface with a rover in 2023. The investment brings the total raised to $125 million, supporting ispace's plans to develop a platform for customers to plan their own lunar missions. The company's founder, Takeshi Hakamada, sees the investment as key to establishing ispace as a leader in the lunar economy and expanding humanity's presence in space.

site_title: Thai July domestic car sales tumble 24.8% y-o-y: industry federation
summary: Domestic car sales in Thailand plummeted 24.8% in July from a year ago to 59,335 vehicles, the 14th consecutive month of decline, due to the coronavirus outbreak. However, sales rose 2.28% from June, aided by easing virus restrictions and the Bangkok international motor show. Thailand remains a significant vehicle production and export hub for global automakers.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall after US Fed's grim view on recovery
summary: European stocks fell 1% on Thursday after the US Federal Reserve signaled a long and difficult path of recovery for the US economy, prompting investors to reassess their views on global growth. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index led by miners, banks, and automakers dropped between 1.2% and 2%. A Reuters poll also predicted a full bounceback from the euro zone's deepest recession on record will take two years or more, and economists warned of a high risk of job recovery reversing by the end of 2020.

site_title: New initiative by IRAS, ACRA allows SMEs to seamlessly prepare, file returns
summary: IRAS and ACRA have launched a joint initiative allowing SMEs to automatically prepare and file statutory returns using dedicated accounting software. The software, linked to both agencies' systems, enables seamless filing without manual logging in to multiple portals. This aims to simplify the process for smaller firms, reducing preparation time from 9 hours to 30 minutes, benefiting approximately 200,000 SMEs. The initiative is part of Singapore's Smart Nation push to digitalize operations and improve productivity.

site_title: In US-China tech war, investors bet on China's localisation push
summary: Investors are betting on China's efforts to replace US technologies with indigenous applications as the US-China "tech war" widens. Chinese IT stocks have jumped nearly 30% this year, driven by plans and procurements from local governments and state firms to foster a home-grown tech ecosystem. Market watchers warn valuations may be frothy, but analysts see growth potential and direct government backing as justification for price levels. Chinese vendors are poised to gain local market share under US pressure, with a predicted one trillion yuan opportunity over the next three years.

site_title: STI falls for 4th straight session, following concerns over recovery of US economy
summary: Singapore stocks fell for the fourth consecutive day, with the Straits Times Index dropping 1.29% to close at 2,527.92. The decline was attributed to US Federal Reserve officials' caution over the country's economic outlook, citing the ongoing public health crisis as a significant risk to economic activity. Decliners outnumbered advancers 298 to 161, with shares of Wilmar International, Keppel Corporation, and Hongkong Land among the worst performers.

site_title: Gold rebounds as slow recovery fears resurface after US Fed minutes
summary: Gold prices rose 0.6% to $1,941.24 per ounce, rebounding from a 3.5% decline the previous session, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid cautious views on the US economic recovery from the coronavirus-induced slump. The US Federal Reserve's minutes reiterated the need for additional fiscal stimulus, sparking a retreat in US stocks and Asian markets. The dovish remarks also led to a rise in the dollar index and US Treasury yields, making gold sensitive to US monetary policy expectations.

site_title: China, US agree to hold trade talks, Chinese commerce ministry says
summary: China and the US have agreed to hold trade talks "in the coming days" to evaluate the progress of their Phase One trade deal, six months after its implementation. The talks follow recent comments from the White House Chief of Staff that no new high-level trade talks were scheduled. The Phase One deal, signed in January, set ambitious targets for China to boost purchases of US farm and manufactured goods, but ties have soured since the COVID-19 pandemic and China's imposition of a national security law in Hong Kong.

site_title: US ends agreements with Hong Kong which says it is a 'pawn'
summary: The US State Department notified Hong Kong that it has suspended or terminated three bilateral agreements due to China's imposition of a national security law, following President Donald Trump's order to end Hong Kong's special status. The agreements covered fugitive offenders, sentenced persons, and tax exemptions. Hong Kong's government condemned the move, calling it "disrespect for bilateralism and multilateralism." The decision is seen as a move to create tension in the China-US relationship, with the US concerned over Beijing's decision to impose the National Security Law, which has crushed Hong Kong's freedoms.

site_title: 14,500 workers in Singapore still serving Covid-19 quarantine
summary: About 14,500 workers in Singapore are still serving their Covid-19 quarantine after testing in dormitories was completed on August 11. The Ministry of Health reported 68 new cases, with 66 in dormitories and two imported cases. The number of new daily community cases has remained stable at two cases per day, and 309 patients have been discharged, with 53,104 fully recovered.

site_title: SIA to deploy some staff to provide specialised training services for other companies
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will deploy staff to provide specialised training services to other companies and organisations, diversifying its non-airline revenue streams. The airline will offer courses and workshops in customer experience, service excellence, digital transformation, and airline operations. Starting from September, SIA will conduct a customer service training course for Khoo Teck Puat Hospital's new Patient Care Officer (PCO) programme. This collaboration aims to share SIA's expertise in customer service and service excellence with other industries, exploring potential areas of collaboration, including crew resource management practices.

site_title: Rakuten CEO urges review of Japan's Covid-19 entry curbs on foreigners
summary: Rakuten CEO Hiroshi Mikitani is urging Japan's government to review its strict Covid-19 entry restrictions on foreign nationals, citing concerns over innovation stagnation and Japan's appeal being tarnished. The restrictions, imposed since the pandemic, have effectively banned entry for tourists and long-term visa holders from over 140 countries, leaving many permanent residents stuck outside. Business lobbies from major economies, including the US, Europe, and Australia, have also protested the policy, calling it out of step with other economies and potentially harming investment.

site_title: Ex-Warburg property veteran to team up with Hillhouse: sources
summary: Joe Gagnon, a former Warburg Pincus managing director focusing on Asia real estate, has left the firm to explore opportunities with Hillhouse Capital Group. Gagnon, who was once Warburg's head of Asia real estate, is in talks with Hillhouse to develop its real estate capabilities. The exact terms of his potential role at Hillhouse have not been finalized. This move marks a significant development for Hillhouse, which has no existing real estate fund or team, but has invested in Chinese online real estate broker KE Holdings.

site_title: Genting Hong Kong suspends payments to creditors
summary: Genting Hong Kong, a cruise ship operator, has suspended payments to its creditors, which may lead to defaults and immediate payment of outstanding debts of US$3.37 billion. The company cited financial stress caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, which resulted in the suspension of sailing globally. The move has caused a 20% drop in its shares.

images.alt_text: Genting Hong Kong, a cruise ship operator, will temporarily suspend all payments to its creditors, which will likely result in events of defaults, it said in a stock exchange filing.

site_title: More workers take wage cuts in July, dragged down by construction sector
summary: Nearly 23,000 workers in Singapore faced wage cuts in July, with 42,000 construction sector workers affected, a spike from 25,000 in June. The accommodation and food services sector, including hotel and restaurant workers, was also hit, with 52,600 employees affected. Wholesale and retail trade businesses, such as eateries and department stores, fared third-worst. The number of affected workers has trended downwards since the "circuit-breaker" shutdown, with 224,800 workers impacted since March 12.

site_title: Trump calls arrested Hong Kong media mogul Lai a 'brave man'
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed support for arrested Hong Kong media mogul Jimmy Lai, calling him a "brave man" after he was briefly detained under a new Chinese law clamping down on Hong Kong's freedoms. Lai was arrested last week. Trump's comments come amid increased pressure on Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement.

site_title: Nearly 5,500 openings at Singapore startups under SGUnited Jobs and Skills scheme so far
summary: The SGUnited Jobs and Skills scheme has seen nearly 5,500 job openings at Singapore startups from April to June, including 330 mid-career workers and 150 fresh and recent graduates. The vacancies include roles such as software developers, chefs, and engineering professionals, with median pay cheques comparable to industry norms. The government's initiatives aim to support local workers and businesses, with a S$1 billion Jobs Growth Incentive scheme also announced.

site_title: Philippine central bank allows lenders to make more real estate loans
summary: The Philippine central bank increased the lending limit on real estate loans to 25% of total loans from 20%, providing an additional 1.2 trillion pesos (S$33.8 billion) liquidity for real estate lending. The move aims to support the property sector as the country reopens its economy after coronavirus lockdowns. Real estate loans accounted for a fifth of total loans for economic activities, with outstanding loans rising by a tenth to 1.719 trillion pesos in June from a year ago. The central bank expects credit activity to pick up in the coming months.

site_title: Five former remisiers in Singapore charged for false trading
summary: Five former remisiers in Singapore have been charged for false trading, involving up to 55 securities listed on the mainboard and Catalist of the Singapore Exchange. The charges, brought by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Singapore Police Force, relate to conspiring to create a false appearance in share trading to support or raise prices. The five individuals, including Alan Lee and Chew Wei Zhan, face up to seven years in jail and a maximum fine of S$250,000 each if found guilty. The cases have been adjourned to September 17 for further mention.

site_title: Delivery Hero to replace Wirecard in Germany's DAX Index
summary: Delivery Hero will replace defunct Wirecard in Germany's DAX Index, effective Monday, following an index rule change allowing insolvent companies to be removed with two trading days' notice. The food delivery company, which went public three years ago, has gained nearly 50% in stock value since January due to increased demand for food delivery during the pandemic. Its addition to the DAX may spark controversy due to its lack of profitability. The change is part of Deutsche Boerse's review of DAX rules, which will be further reviewed with results due by year-end.

site_title: Singaporean slapped with two more charges related to Wirecard scandal
summary: A Singaporean, R Shanmugaratnam, has been charged with two more counts of falsifying letters related to the Wirecard scandal. The letters misrepresented balances held by his company's escrow accounts as of March 31, 2016. Shanmugaratnam, a 54-year-old director at Citadelle Corporate Services, has previously faced four charges of similar offenses. The new charges are punishable under Singapore's Penal Code. Citadelle handled money for Wirecard in a trustee capacity without proper licensing or supervision.

site_title: Taiwan to stop local sales for Chinese TV streaming services, not block them
summary: Taiwan plans to stop local sales for Chinese internet television streaming services, including iQiyi and Tencent Holdings, effective September 3, as part of regulations aimed at preventing Chinese influence. The move is part of efforts to counter Chinese attempts to sway Taiwan's population through fake news and media influence. Taiwanese companies will no longer be allowed to sell or operate as sales agents for these services.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks plunge most in 2 months on infection surge, Fed's gloom
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted 3.7% on Thursday, the largest two-month decline, amid concerns over rising domestic coronavirus infections and a cautious outlook from the US Federal Reserve. The benchmark Kospi index fell 86.32 points to 2,274.22. The Korean won weakened, but the benchmark bond yield rose. Foreigners were net sellers of 276.2 billion won worth of shares, and the won closed trading at 1,186.9 per US dollar, 0.48% lower than its previous close.

site_title: Qantas posts A$2b loss on pandemic-linked accounting charges
summary: Qantas Airways reported a full-year net loss of A$1.964 billion due to pandemic-linked accounting charges and restructuring costs. The airline's underlying pre-tax profit was A$124 million, exceeding analyst expectations. Qantas' chief executive, Alan Joyce, warned that the coronavirus pandemic will continue to impact the business, with a significant underlying loss expected in FY21. The airline had previously raised A$1.4 billion from shareholders and cut staff, but faced further setbacks in the domestic market due to state border closures.

site_title: UOB resumes full branch operations in Singapore
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has resumed full branch operations in Singapore, reopening its remaining seven branches following a safe reopening plan amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Customers are encouraged to use digital channels and make appointments to minimize time spent outside their homes. The bank maintains precautionary measures, including mask-wearing, temperature screening, and self-disinfecting coatings at high-touch areas. This follows DBS' similar reopening plan, with both banks trading lower due to the economic uncertainty.

site_title: Soilbuild Construction injects additional S$9.4m into Myanmar business
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group has injected S$9.4 million into its wholly-owned subsidiary Soilbuild Construction International (SBCI), raising its investment to S$9.5 million. The additional funding, from internal resources, aims to strengthen SBCI's capital base and is expected to have no material effect on the group's earnings per share or net tangible assets per share for FY20.

site_title: Adyen clinches Wirecard clients during online shopping boom
summary: Adyen, a Dutch payment processing company, has secured new clients from Wirecard, a German payments firm that filed for insolvency in June due to a scandal. Adyen reported a 27% rise in revenue for the first half of the year, with processed payments increasing by 23%. The company benefited from the Wirecard scandal, which led retail merchants to seek alternative payment processing options. Adyen expects to continue growing its revenue at a mid-20s to low-30s rate and increase its earnings margin to above 55% in the long term.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.46% at 23,005.02, and the Topix index down 0.46% at 1,606.23. The falls were partly offset by a cheaper yen against the dollar. This is the article content.

site_title: Australia to reject China-backed company's offer to buy dairy firm: media
summary: Australia will reject China Mengniu Dairy's A$600 million offer to buy some of Australia's top milk brands from Japan's Kirin Holdings. Treasurer Josh Frydenberg has gone against the Foreign Investment Review Board's (FIRB) advice to approve the deal, citing concerns. The proposal was made in November last year.

site_title: Wealth management in Hong Kong, Singapore hits snag with bankers stuck at home
summary: Private bankers in Hong Kong and Singapore face challenges in pursuing millionaires due to the pandemic, which has limited their ability to travel to China and other regions. Relationship managers have focused on trading among existing clients instead, leading to a shrinking pipeline. Regulators are easing rules, but banks are still catching up with digitization. This has resulted in a hit to the growth of new money in Asia, with UBS Group and JPMorgan Chase & Co among those affected.

site_title: Asia: Markets track US losses as Federal Reserve raises economy concerns
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday, following US losses, as the Federal Reserve expressed concerns over the US economic outlook. The Fed's minutes highlighted the need for fiscal support to aid small businesses and the jobless, amid a weak labor market. US lawmakers' stalemate on a new stimulus package has raised fears of a prolonged economic downturn, with Asia's markets tracking the US losses. Despite record-low borrowing costs, the drop in US stocks has put pressure on Asian markets, with key indices down 0.7-2.0% in Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Taipei.

site_title: TikTok poised for deal to avoid millions in privacy damages
summary: TikTok's Chinese owner, ByteDance, is proposing a settlement in principle to resolve consumer privacy litigation, potentially avoiding millions in damages. The deal, reached during a 12-hour mediation session, would resolve claims of unlawfully recording facial-scan images of children and sending confidential information to China. However, attorneys representing California consumers claim they were excluded from settlement talks, raising concerns that the deal could be scuttled. The proposed settlement is subject to certain conditions and must be filed within 90 days.

site_title: Hot stock: Wilmar sinks 10% after major shareholder reveals plans to cut stake
summary: Wilmar International's shares dropped 10% on Thursday after Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) announced plans to sell 170.5 million shares worth US$500 million, representing 2.68% of Wilmar's total issued share capital. ADM, a Chicago-based grain trader, expects to retain at least a 20% stake in Wilmar. The shares were trading at S$4.34 as of 1:50pm, down S$0.52 from Wednesday's close. Wilmar attributed the share price volatility to the ADM announcement, with no other reason mentioned.

site_title: Afterpay shares rise nearly 10% to record after hiking core profit view
summary: Afterpay shares rose nearly 10% to a record high after the company raised its annual core earnings forecast, citing lower-than-expected losses on customer transactions. The firm now forecasts full-year EBITDA of A$44 million, up from prior guidance of A$20-25 million. This move was driven by Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group's 5% stake acquisition in the company. The surge follows a period of multiple life highs for Afterpay shares, driven by swelling online transactions during the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Millions of Chinese investors rushed into July's stock market rally
summary: Millions of Chinese investors flocked to the stock market in July, with 2.4 million new investors entering mainland Chinese shares, the largest number in five years. This represents a 60% jump from the previous month and a 124% year-on-year increase. The surge in new investors boosted trading turnover and brokerage earnings, with over 25 brokerages reporting a 50% profit jump in July. The stock market jumped over 10% in July, helping to increase stamp duty income from securities trading by 35.3% year-on-year.

site_title: Singtel hit 'especially hard' in Q1 2021 by pandemic-related curbs, economic decline: S&P
summary: Singtel's Q1 2021 performance was impacted "especially hard" by pandemic-related curbs and economic decline, according to Standard & Poor's (S&P). The telco's reported Ebitda is forecast to decline 11-13% to between S$3.9 billion and S$4.1 billion, while cash dividends are expected to reduce to S$1.8-2 billion. Improvements are anticipated in the second half of 2021, with careful management of dividend payouts and debt-to-Ebitda ratio expected to remain largely unchanged.

site_title: Singapore Airlines has spent half of the S$8.8 billion raised in rights issue
summary: Singapore Airlines has spent half of the S$8.8 billion raised in its rights issue, using S$4.4 billion for various purposes, including operating expenses, debt servicing, and aircraft purchases. The airline has also repaid a bridge loan facility from DBS Bank and secured additional loans, bringing its total liquidity to around S$11 billion. SIA's cash burn rate remains a concern, with the airline operating at just 7% of its original capacity, and it may need to raise up to S$6.2 billion in additional mandatory convertible bonds if needed.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines burned through half of the S$8.8 billion it raised through share sales in just two months, highlighting how carriers' expenses keep incurring even as planes are grounded.

site_title: Sembcorp bags S$40m DBS loan facility for Tuas floating solar farm
summary: Sembcorp Industries has secured a S$40 million loan facility from DBS Bank to build a 60 MWp floating solar photovoltaic system on Tengeh Reservoir in Tuas, Singapore. The project, scheduled for completion next year, will be one of the world's largest inland floating solar farms, covering an area of around 45 football fields and generating enough energy to power 16,000 homes. The project aims to offset 32 kilotonnes of carbon emissions annually and solidify Sembcorp's position as a leading renewable energy player in Singapore.

site_title: Haidilao couple is Singapore's richest on Forbes list
summary: Singapore's top 10 richest saw their fortunes rise by US$37 billion to US$167 billion, with the 50 richest individuals experiencing a 28% gain in combined wealth. Haidilao founder Zhang Yong and his wife Shu Ping topped the list with a combined net worth of US$19 billion. Other notable entries include Li Xiting, a naturalized Singapore citizen, and Goh Cheng Liang, who owns a stake in Japan's Nippon Paint Holdings. The list includes tycoons from around the world who have taken up citizenship or residency in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Haidilao founder Zhang Yong and wife Shu Ping are Singapore's richest couple, with a combined net worth of US$19 billion, according to Forbes.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Thursday, August 20, 2020, due to tempered expectations of further monetary easing measures from the Federal Reserve and a distant prospect of new stimulus from Congress. The Hang Sang Index fell 0.49% to 25,055.35, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.65% and 0.71% respectively.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks started Thursday on the back foot following Federal Reserve minutes that tempered expectations of any further monetary easing measures, while the chance of a new stimulus from Congress appeared a distant prospect.

site_title: Covid-19 vaccine won't be mandatory in US, says Fauci
summary: US infectious diseases official Dr. Anthony Fauci stated that Covid-19 vaccines will not be mandatory for the general public, despite local jurisdictions having the authority to make it mandatory for certain groups, such as children. The decentralized US government system and anti-vaccine sentiments make a nationwide program unlikely. However, states can make vaccine mandates for children attending school, and the administration has pre-ordered hundreds of millions of vaccine doses from six companies for free distribution.

site_title: Archer Daniels Midland to cut stake in Wilmar, sell shares for US$500m
summary: Archer Daniels Midland Co (ADM) plans to sell shares and bonds in Wilmar International with a combined value of US$800 million. ADM, Wilmar's largest shareholder, expects to retain at least a 20% stake in the agribusiness firm, down from 24.6% as of March 4. The sale is part of ADM's strategy to diversify its portfolio and focus on core businesses. The transaction is valued at US$500 million, with the remaining US$300 million coming from bonds.

site_title: Britney Spears 'strongly opposed' to father as her sole guardian
summary: Britney Spears is seeking to alter the terms of her conservatorship, which has been in place since 2008 and is largely governed by her father Jamie. Her lawyer, Samuel Ingham, filed court papers to remove her father as conservator and replace him with Jodi Montgomery, a licensed professional conservator, as the permanent head. Spears is "strongly opposed" to her father's return to overseeing her affairs and prefers to move control of her finances away from him. A status hearing is scheduled for Wednesday in Los Angeles.

site_title: Wallich Residence 62% sold, 68 units left for sale
summary: Wallich Residence, a luxury project in Singapore's Central Business District, has sold 62% of its units, with 68 units remaining for sale. The project, launched in 2017, features ultra-luxury units on floors 39-64 of Guoco Tower. High rentals have been achieved, with leased units fetching S$8-11/sq ft. The median rent for high-end condos in Singapore is around S$4.06-4.97/sq ft. The project's super penthouse, once sold for S$73.8 million, is still available.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on souring ties with China, New Zealand dips
summary: Australian shares fell 0.8% on Thursday due to concerns over souring ties with China, following the government's rejection of a China-backed company's offer to buy a dairy firm. Energy stocks plummeted, with Santos and Origin Energy dropping 4% and 6% respectively. Mining stocks also fell, with South32 reporting an 80.5% slump in underlying profit. In contrast, technology stocks rose 2.4% to a record high, led by Afterpay's surge to an all-time high. New Zealand's benchmark index dropped 0.4%.

site_title: Scotiabank in US$127.4m US settlement on rigged trades
summary: The Bank of Nova Scotia (Scotiabank) has agreed to pay US$127.4 million to settle charges of attempted market manipulation and making false statements to regulators. Four precious metals traders at the Canadian bank engaged in fraudulent trades in gold, silver, platinum, and palladium between 2008 and 2016, manipulating market prices to benefit their positions. The traders cancelled out transactions, but moved the market in their favor, causing harm to other traders. Scotiabank has agreed to appoint an independent monitor and cooperate with ongoing investigations.

site_title: Federal Reserve officials say US economy probably needs more aid
summary: Federal Reserve officials expressed concerns that the US economy may need additional aid to recover from the coronavirus downturn, citing a weak labor market and the expiration of key spending measures. The Fed cut interest rates to zero and rolled out trillions of dollars in liquidity, but FOMC members worried about the impact of stimulus measures running their course. A broad and sustained reopening of businesses is seen as crucial for labor market improvement, with a focus on health measures to limit the spread of the virus.

site_title: Europe: Wall Street sets upbeat tone for stocks, UK airlines jump
summary: European stocks closed higher on Wednesday, following Wall Street's record highs, with the Stoxx 600 climbing 0.7% and UK airlines rallying on hopes of a shorter quarantine period. British Airways-owner IAG surged 7.6% and easyJet rose 3.3% on news of a Covid-19 testing plan. Danish shipping group Maersk's shares jumped 5.0% after beating forecast-beating earnings, and the S&P 500 reached new record highs.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, Singtel, GuocoLand, China Aviation Oil, Sabana Reit, ESR-Reit
summary: Stocks to watch on Thursday included CDL, Singtel, GuocoLand, China Aviation Oil, Sabana Reit, and ESR-Reit. CDL cut 159 jobs, or 15% of its Singapore workforce, following earlier reductions. Singtel faces challenges due to pandemic-related movement restrictions and economic deterioration. GuocoLand's Guoco Midtown project remains relevant, with 62% of Wallich Residence sold. China Aviation Oil is being sued over an alleged fraudulent deal, while Sabana Reit-ESR-Reit merger awaits guidance from the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.8% to 2,539.73, as losers outnumbered gainers 96 to 57. Key movers included Wilmar International, Singapore Telecommunications, and Genting Singapore, which all fell. Meanwhile, DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank also declined, while Singapore Airlines gained 0.8%. The decline was partly offset by a cheaper yen against the dollar, which boosted Tokyo stocks.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat from records as Apple hits US$2t in value
summary: US stocks retreated from record highs on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq ending at all-time highs the previous day. Apple became the first US company worth $2 trillion, but analysts attributed the retreat to profit-taking after Tuesday's strong session. Briefing.com analyst Patrick O'Hare noted that it's common for stocks to backtrack after achieving a record high. The retreat comes amid tariff uncertainty and split views among Fed policymakers.

site_title: Original ideas for Guoco Midtown still relevant even in the new normal, says group MD
summary: GuocoLand's managing director Cheng Hsing Yao believes original ideas for Guoco Midtown remain relevant despite the pandemic, as trends like work from home and e-commerce have accelerated to become part of the norm. The development's design allows for seamless transitions between air-conditioned spaces and greenery, offering a marketing edge. Cheng forecasts a shift towards better-quality office buildings, with individual workstations potentially becoming larger for well-being. Guoco Midtown, set to be completed in phases between 2022 and 2024, will feature 3.8 hectares of landscape area, 20 gardens, and public spaces for occupants to enjoy.

site_title: Glove maker UG Healthcare proposes S$19.1m share placement
summary: UG Healthcare Corporation, a Singapore-listed glove manufacturer, proposes a share placement to raise S$19.1 million. The placement involves up to 7.5 million shares at S$2.545 apiece, a 9.9% discount to the volume-weighted average price of S$2.8247. The move is aimed at strengthening the company's financial position.

site_title: GE signs power agreements worth over US$1.2b with Iraq
summary: General Electric (GE) has signed two power agreements worth over US$1.2 billion with the Iraqi Ministry of Electricity to undertake maintenance programs and bolster transmission networks. The deals are facilitated by multiple export credit agencies and come as US companies plan to unveil investments during Iraqi Prime Minister Mustafa al-Kadhimi's visit to the White House.

site_title: Finland imposes 'Europe's tightest' border restrictions
summary: Finland has imposed "Europe's tightest" border restrictions, removing most EU countries from its "green travel list" and allowing only arrivals from Italy, Hungary, Slovakia, Estonia, and Lithuania to enter without coronavirus restrictions. The country's Interior Minister, Maria Ohisalo, stated that Finland's border policy aims to preserve the relatively good virus situation, with a cut-off point of fewer than 10 new coronavirus cases per 100,000 population. The restrictions also include loosening land border rules for residents living on either side of Finland and Norway.

site_title: Amazon makes it harder for sellers to handle own shipment
summary: Amazon is introducing new shipping performance requirements for third-party sellers, requiring them to deliver on Saturdays and meet one- and two-day delivery pledges starting in February. Failure to meet these targets may result in losing the Prime fast-shipping badge. The move could lead to higher prices for consumers, potentially raising antitrust concerns, as Amazon's logistics costs may become more expensive than competitors.

site_title: UK trade minister accused by opponents of hiding think-tank meetings
summary: UK trade minister Liz Truss has been accused of hiding meetings with a pro-hard Brexit think tank, the Institute of Economic Affairs (IEA), from the public record. The meetings, initially listed as discussing trade, were reclassified as personal discussions, sparking opposition allegations of concealing influence on public policy. The IEA promotes free-markets and has argued for a clean break from the EU since the 2016 Brexit referendum. The opposition Labour Party claims Truss is evading rules designed to ensure transparency and honesty in public office, leading to accusations that she wants to conceal the think tank's influence.

images.alt_text: Two meetings with trade minister Liz Truss and the IEA had originally been included in quarterly transparency data published on the government's website and described as discussing trade. They were removed on Wednesday with a note explaining they were personal meetings - the first such revision since the department was created in 2016.

site_title: Trump urges Goodyear tire boycott over ban on political garb
summary: US President Donald Trump urged consumers to boycott Goodyear tires after a report showed the company had banned attire featuring his "Make America Great Again" slogan. Trump claimed the ban was a form of "political campaigning" and threatened to swap out the tires on his limousine. Goodyear denied the report, stating the ban was part of its diversity training policy, which prohibits "political affiliated slogans or material." The incident sparked a reaction from Joe Biden, who attacked Trump's "petty political grievances" and criticized his treatment of Goodyear workers.

site_title: US to impose UN sanctions 'snap back' on Iran: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump authorized Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to activate a mechanism to reimpose UN sanctions on Iran, escalating a diplomatic spat with European allies. The move will restore virtually all suspended UN sanctions on Iran, with huge repercussions for the Iran nuclear deal. The decision was made under the "snap back" provision, which allows the US to immediately re-impose sanctions if Iran violates the terms of the 2015 nuclear deal. The move is seen as a significant escalation of tensions between the US and Iran.

site_title: US could hit 150,000 Covid cases a day under current policies
summary: The US is on track to reach 150,000 daily Covid-19 cases under current policies, according to a Morgan Stanley model, potentially devastating the economy. The US ranks first in cases and deaths among developed nations, and its economic recovery lags behind Europe. To bring the economy back, the US needs better compliance with social distancing measures, improved testing and contact tracing, and regional shutdowns. The White House's failure to respond adequately to the pandemic, led by President Trump, has exacerbated the crisis.

site_title: Oil slips as demand worries outweigh US stocks draw
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Wednesday due to lingering concerns over soft US fuel demand and a potential second wave of the coronavirus pandemic. US crude oil stockpiles fell 1.6 million barrels, while fuel demand was down 14% from the year-ago period. Brent crude futures settled at $45.37 a barrel, down 9 cents, while US West Texas Intermediate crude ended 4 cents higher at $42.93 a barrel. Global oil demand is expected to recover to pre-pandemic levels by the fourth quarter, according to the Saudi Energy minister.

site_title: Airbnb files for initial public offering
summary: Airbnb has confidentially filed for an initial public offering (IPO) as the travel industry recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic. The company, which has seen a "bounce" in bookings, aims to promote short-range travel through partnerships with local organizations and tourist bodies. Airbnb recently slashed 1,900 jobs to survive the pandemic and has introduced new cleaning protocols to reassure travelers. The IPO will help the company continue to stimulate economic activity and capitalize on the growing trend of day-tripping. Details on the IPO, including the number of shares and price, have yet to be determined.

images.alt_text: Home-sharing startup Airbnb on Wednesday said it has confidentially filed with US regulators for an initial public offering.

site_title: Singapore sets example for Libor shift with 'ground-breaking' debt sale
summary: Singapore has successfully auctioned S$500 million of six-month notes linked to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (SORA), a key step in replacing the London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor). The move is part of a global effort to develop new benchmarks, with hundreds of trillions of dollars of assets tied to Libor. Analysts say Singapore's example could encourage banks, businesses, and other authorities to follow, with the US Treasury reportedly studying the issue and expected to formally announce SOFR-linked debt later this year.

site_title: Trump has 'never' taken presidency seriously: Obama
summary: Barack Obama will state at the Democratic convention that Donald Trump has "never" taken the US presidency seriously and lacks the skills to grow into the job. Obama expressed his disappointment that Trump showed no interest in putting in the work or finding common ground. The comments are part of Obama's critical assessment of the sitting president, highlighting his lack of seriousness and commitment to the role.

images.alt_text: "I did hope, for the sake of our country, that Donald Trump might show some interest in taking the job seriously.... But he never did," the 44th president will say, according to excerpts of his speech released by convention organisers.

site_title: Opec+ presses for compliance with oil cuts
summary: Opec+ urged its members and allies to boost compliance with oil output cuts, with global demand expected to recover to pre-pandemic levels in the fourth quarter. The group, including Russia, aims to reduce output by 7.7 million barrels per day. Compliance levels were high in July, but some countries, such as Iraq and Nigeria, lagged behind. Opec+ sources indicate no changes to the output policy, and countries are expected to compensate for past overproduction by September.

site_title: Millennium Hotels and Resorts cuts 159 more jobs
summary: Millennium Hotels and Resorts (MHR) cut 159 jobs, about 15% of its Singapore-based workforce, amid the pandemic's impact on the global tourism industry. Nearly one-third of its 145 hotels worldwide were temporarily shuttered, and those remaining operated at depressed occupancies. MHR collaborated with the Food Drinks and Allied Workers Union (FDAWU) to offer a severance package, post-employment support, and job matching assistance. The company aims to use government funds to upskill its talent as the economy recovers.

site_title: Democrats nominate Biden for president, vow to end Trump 'chaos'
summary: Democrats formally nominated Joe Biden for president, vowing to repair a pandemic-battered America and end the chaos of Donald Trump's administration. The party's national convention featured former presidents Bill Clinton and Jimmy Carter, as well as prominent Republicans, who made the case that Biden would return integrity to the White House and normalcy to American lives. The nomination comes after a pandemic-battered America, and the Democratic party is seeking to repair the damage and bring stability to the country.

site_title: Singaporeans hold 43% of senior roles in financial sector: MAS chief
summary: Singaporeans hold 43% of senior roles in the financial sector, according to MAS chief Ravi Menon, reflecting the country's role as an international financial centre. Despite this, a "good number" of Singaporeans have assumed regional leadership roles, and the regulator is working to develop a strong local leadership pipeline. Meanwhile, Singaporeans make up 70% of the sector's overall workforce, with permanent residents accounting for 14%. MAS plans to intensify its engagement with senior management to grow the Singaporean core, while also attracting high-quality and diverse foreign talent.

site_title: Disclosure, threshold fee for non-sponsor jobs being reviewed: SGX RegCo
summary: SGX Regulation (SGX RegCo) has released a report highlighting areas for improvement in the sponsor regime of the Catalist board, where most sponsors and issuers are in compliance. However, less than 5% of issuers pay non-sponsor fees exceeding 100% of sponsor fees. The regulator is reviewing disclosure levels and calibrating the 100% threshold for non-sponsor fees to sponsor fees. The report also touches on monitoring trading activities, maintaining documentation and audit trails, and the escalation and approval process within sponsor organizations.

site_title: Israeli peace deal coaxes UAE investors out of the shadows
summary: Israeli peace deal coaxes UAE investors out of the shadows, with Tel Aviv-based financier Edouard Cukierman seeing a surge in 20-30 messages a day from Emiratis eager to do deals without concealment. The shift comes after a US-brokered peace process aimed at ending decades of official hostility between the two Middle East nations. This increase in investment activity is expected to boost the Israeli technology industry.

site_title: COE prices end mostly higher
summary: COE prices in Singapore ended mostly higher at the latest tender, reaching their highest this year. Car premiums for vehicles up to 1,600 and 130bhp finished at S$35,710 and S$38,802, respectively. Commercial vehicle COE closed at S$25,006, while motorcycle premium decreased to S$7,432. The increase is attributed to the smaller quota and pent-up demand from the circuit breaker period. Motor traders expect premiums to soften in future tenders as the backlog of orders eases.

site_title: Target hits sales record on online surge
summary: Target Corp reported its best quarterly comparable sales growth and online revenue nearly tripled during the Covid-19 pandemic, driven by videogames, kitchenware, and clothes sales through same-day delivery services. In-store shopping also saw significant growth, with apparel sales increasing by double-digits and electronics sales up over 70%. The company's comparable sales jumped 24.3%, surpassing expectations, and net earnings rose 80.3% to $1.69 billion.

site_title: Maersk lifts profit outlook for 2020
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container line, has reinstated its full-year profit guidance at a higher level, citing ability to serve customers despite the Covid-19 crisis. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) for 2020 are expected to be between $6 billion and $7 billion, up from the previous estimate of $5.5 billion. The company reported a second-quarter Ebitda of $1.7 billion, close to analyst estimates. Despite a 16% drop in volumes, Maersk reduced costs by 16% and saw a 4.5% rise in freight rates, offsetting losses.

site_title: GM bets on electric Cadillacs, micro-vans to reverse China slide
summary: General Motors (GM) is revamping its Chinese line-up to focus on electric cars and autonomous-drive technology to stem declining sales. New China boss Julian Blissett aims to regain momentum lost due to intense competition and shifting consumer tastes. GM will renew its focus on luxury Cadillacs, roll out bigger electric SUVs, and target entry-level buyers with low-cost micro electric vehicles. The company expects over 50% of its capital and engineering deployment to go towards electrification and autonomous-drive technology in the next five years, with a goal of reaching 4 million vehicles in sales annually.

site_title: Straits Times Index dips 0.08% despite Wall Street rally
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended down 2.05 points or 0.08% at 2,561.04, despite a global Wall Street rally. Asian markets, including the Shanghai Composite Index and Hang Seng Index, also declined due to escalating China-US trade tension. Wilmar International was the top gainer, while Singapore Airlines was the biggest decliner. The decline was attributed to the ongoing trade tensions, with US President Donald Trump postponing trade talks with China.

site_title: Work-from-home boom is bust for big office furniture makers
summary: US office furniture manufacturers, including Herman Miller and Steelcase, are struggling due to the shift to remote work caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The companies, which previously relied on selling through dealers to companies that employed teams of designers and technicians, found themselves unprepared for the surge in demand for affordable, easy-to-assemble home office furniture. Sales declined sharply, with Steelcase reporting its lowest sales since 1998, and shares of both companies plummeted. However, the companies are adapting by expanding their online options and exploring new products, with some predicting a long-term shift towards smaller, satellite offices.

site_title: Trump cancels China talks, raising questions about trade deal
summary: US President Donald Trump has cancelled last weekend's trade talks with China, raising questions about the future of the phase-one trade deal. The deal, which came into force in February, aimed to discuss implementation every six months. Trump cited no reason for the cancellation, but Chinese stocks slumped amid growing concern over tensions between the world's biggest economies. Despite the cancellation, talks continue at lower levels, with US officials saying progress is being made and that the deal remains crucial for the relationship.

site_title: South Korea is a role model for other economies
summary: The Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has revised its 2020 real GDP forecast for South Korea, projecting a contraction of -0.8% compared to a previous forecast of -1.2%. This is a more optimistic outlook than the OECD's average forecast of a 7.6% real GDP contraction for its 37 member states, including the UK, which reported a record-breaking second-quarter contraction of 20.4%. The revised forecast suggests South Korea may be performing better economically than expected.

site_title: GuocoLand to develop second condo, third retail cluster at Guoco Midtown mega project
summary: GuocoLand is expanding its Guoco Midtown mega project with a second luxury residential condominium, Midtown Modern, and the third retail cluster, Midtown Square. The 30-storey towers will feature over 500 apartments and a retail podium, with prices starting from S$1.38 million for a one-bedroom unit. The development, which includes an office tower, Network Hub, and 20 concept gardens, is expected to be completed in phases between 2022 and 2024 and will bring an additional 10,000 workers, residents, and visitors to the district daily.

images.alt_text: Guoco Midtown is expected to be completed in phases between 2022 and 2024, starting with the 30-storey office tower with 770,000 sq ft of premium Grade A office space, three concept retail clusters, two residential condominiums, and a five-storey Network Hub building (above).

site_title: Outdoor Shakespearean medicine for the play-starved soul
summary: The Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey's Back Yard Stage presents outdoor Shakespearean performances, offering a sense of normalcy during the pandemic. The show, "Crazy Love!", features two programs: "The Love Doctor" and "Verily, Madly Thine". The troupe, the Shrewd Mechanicals, a non-Equity company, performs with actors up close, allowing for a sense of community and relaxation. The production, directed by Bonnie J Monte, is a mix of comedy and medicine for the play-starved soul, leaving the audience feeling energized and relaxed, with a physical sensation that was a welcome return to collective gratitude.

site_title: Building a Singapore core in the financial sector
summary: Singapore is aiming to build a core in the financial sector, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) focusing on developing local talent. According to MAS, Singaporeans hold 43% of senior roles in the sector. Former DBS veteran Tan Teck Long has been named OCBC's incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong who is retiring. Meanwhile, MAS and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) are deepening cooperation on green and transition finance. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising concerns for policymakers.

site_title: Big banks sit on US$250b of murkiest trades
summary: Banks globally have increased their opaque assets, known as Level 3 assets, by over 20% since the Covid-19 pandemic, totaling around $250 billion. These assets, including complex debt securities and distressed debt, are difficult to value and pose a risk to lenders. The surge is attributed to various factors, including pandemic turmoil and banks' desire to maintain competitiveness. Regulators are concerned about the potential for errors and mispricing, and experts warn that the increases may translate into losses.

site_title: Upcoming US election in November is this generation's D-Day
summary: The US election in November poses a threat to American democracy, with President Donald Trump's actions potentially undermining the integrity of the vote. Trump's administration has sabotaged the US Postal Service, leading to concerns that mail-in ballots may not be counted. If Trump loses, the outcome could be disputed, potentially leading to a Civil War or another Supreme Court decision. To mitigate this, voters must make their voices heard by participating in the election, volunteering to work at polling stations, and supporting efforts to protect mail-in voting.

site_title: Indonesia puts relocation of Jakarta on hold to tackle pandemic
summary: Indonesia has put on hold plans to relocate its capital city from Jakarta to Borneo due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The US$33-billion project, which aims to relocate the capital, will be shelved until the pandemic is under control. Indonesia's planning minister, Suharso Monoarfa, stated that the construction of government buildings for the new city will be delayed until the pandemic subsides, indicating a temporary pause in the ambitious project.

site_title: London office property market likely to see structural changes
summary: The London office property market is expected to undergo significant structural changes due to the shift towards work-from-home caused by the pandemic. Valuations and rents of office and retail buildings are likely to decline, with some experts predicting a 9.4% decline in average values and a 10% fall in rents. This trend is also affecting struggling retail businesses, with many closures and job losses reported. In contrast, logistics and warehouse property are experiencing growth due to accelerating e-commerce. Developers are exploring ways to repurpose vacant office space into workable, profitable properties.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse rides trading, IPO surge to record profit
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEX) reported a one per cent gain in profit for the first half of the year, driven by a 13 per cent increase in core revenue. The exchange benefited from a surge in Chinese stock listings and trading activity amid pandemic and political tensions. However, investments slumped 45 per cent, contributing to the lower result. This marks a record profit for HKEX, highlighting the exchange's resilience in a volatile market.

site_title: US curbs on Huawei may impact S Korea's recovery
summary: The US Commerce Department has restricted Huawei Technologies Co from accessing commercially available US-made chips, potentially impacting South Korea's economy. South Korea relies heavily on chip exports to China, with Samsung and SK Hynix generating significant revenue from trading with Huawei and other Chinese firms. The US curbs may lead to a decline in Chinese tech exports containing South Korean semiconductors, affecting the country's exports worth $94 billion last year.

site_title: A huge Tesla bet pays off big for one British fund
summary: A British fund, Scottish Mortgage Investment Trust Plc, has seen a 55% year-to-date return, significantly outperforming its peer group, thanks to a large bet on Tesla's stock, which has surged to a record. The fund's holding of 1.87 million Tesla shares has increased in value by over $2 billion since March, contributing to its position in the UK's FTSE 100 benchmark and cementing its spot among the top five winners of 2020.

site_title: The fight over Myanmar's marble hills
summary: In Myanmar, locals are fighting to regain control over the country's prized white marble hills, which have been exploited by large companies and shadowy Chinese firms. The hills, a source of livelihood for generations, are being ravaged by cutting and grinding machines, threatening the livelihoods of over 80% of the village's 2,000 households. Locals accuse outsiders of plundering their resources, and demand that they be allowed to mine and sculpt the marble, while also fearing that companies will destroy the hills until they are gone.

site_title: Living and working in the post-pandemic era
summary: Singapore's post-pandemic era has brought mixed results, with life not fully returning to normal. Architects and designers predict a future environment with permanent changes, including sustainable and flexible spaces. The pandemic has accelerated the shift to virtual platforms, such as Zoom, for arts and entertainment. New dining experiences, like Appetite, combine food, art, and culture. Meanwhile, businesses like Thevar 2.0 and The Social Kitchen promote sustainability and community engagement. As Singapore moves forward, it's clear that the pandemic has left a lasting impact on the city-state's environment and lifestyle.

site_title: Sea's Q2 revenue doubles, lifted by Garena and Shopee growth
summary: Sea Ltd's Q2 revenue doubled to US$1.29 billion, driven by 61.6% growth in digital entertainment and 141.4% growth in e-commerce revenue. Garena's self-developed game Free Fire and Shopee's e-commerce marketplace contributed to the growth. Despite a net loss of US$393.5 million, analysts raised their target price to US$158.20, citing strong user momentum and potential for sustained growth in the second half of the year.

site_title: Singapore needs to encourage ESG integration to further financial hub ambitions
summary: Singapore needs to further integrate Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) factors into its financial hub ambitions. Despite being a regional leader in the "G" dimension, the country lags in the "E" and "S" aspects. A joint study found that ESG integration remains in infancy in the Asia-Pacific, with investors and analysts calling for guidance. A "comply-or-explain" regime is in place, but Singapore can strengthen its stance by taking a decisive lead on ESG disclosure, which will benefit its ambitions as a financial hub and market forces.

site_title: Sabana Reit minority shareholders await MAS, SGX guidance on ESR-Reit merger
summary: Sabana Reit minority shareholders, including Quarz Capital Management, are awaiting guidance and support from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX Regco) on the proposed merger between Sabana Reit and ESR-Reit. The proposed deal has raised concerns over potential conflicts of interest, with over 50 minority unitholders voicing concerns about the arrangement. Quarz has stated that the offer price for the merger is too low, at a 26% discount to Sabana's book value. The regulators have promised to review the matter and provide guidance to address any conflicts of interest.

site_title: Upscaling, cross-scaling eGSS to help businesses amid pandemic
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted Singapore's businesses, particularly in the retail, food & beverage, and tourism sectors. To mitigate the effects, the government is launching the eGSS 2020 initiative, which aims to upscale and cross-scale eGSS to help businesses amid the pandemic. The initiative includes promoting bundled deals and value-differentiated promotions to encourage consumers to shop and secure attractive deals, while also supporting local businesses. The goal is to foster holistic collaboration and provide a platform for industry players to cross-sell products and experiences to visitors and customers.

site_title: More buildings here going greener as 376 projects bag BCA's Green Mark Award
summary: Singapore has awarded the Building and Construction Authority's (BCA) Green Mark Award to 376 projects, including 16 overseas, for their environmental impact and performance. The award includes 22 super low energy buildings and three that use 100% renewable energy. Major developers like CapitaLand have set targets for reducing energy use and carbon footprint, with CapitaLand winning the Green Mark Platinum Champion Award for its sustainability efforts, including installing 21,000 solar panels and a climate-friendly refrigerant system. The BCA's Green Mark certification scheme has seen a doubling of non-residential building projects obtaining higher tier certifications over the past five years.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand's Ms Leong says: "We place sustainability at the core of what we do, and we are heartened by BCA's recognition..."

site_title: Fixing blockchain's vulnerabilities
summary: Ethereum Classic (ETC) suffered two attacks in a single week, resulting in millions of dollars worth of stolen ETC currency tokens. Miners exploited a "chain-reorganisation attack," removing transactions from the blockchain history to spend coins twice. This highlights the myth that blockchain is immutable and the need to choose the right type of blockchain for specific use cases. The attacks demonstrate vulnerabilities in the technology, emphasizing the importance of participation and proper blockchain selection.

site_title: Goldman, Malaysia sign off on US$3.9b 1MDB settlement
summary: Goldman Sachs and Malaysia have signed a US$3.9 billion settlement over the 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) scandal, allowing for its implementation. The settlement includes a cash payment of US$2.5 billion to Malaysia and a guarantee that at least US$1.4 billion in assets acquired with misappropriated funds will be recovered. The agreement completes the process announced last month, with Malaysia ending all criminal proceedings against Goldman and receiving a total of US$4.5 billion from the settlement and previously returned 1MDB funds. Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak was convicted and jailed for 12 years in connection with the scandal.

site_title: Certis partners charity SPD to help empower persons with disabilities
summary: Certis has partnered with charity SPD to empower persons with disabilities, particularly those with physical disabilities. Two individuals, Loo Poh Thye and J P Thanumadhya, who work with Certis as call centre operators, have benefited from the partnership. They assist people under quarantine due to Covid-19 with health and well-being checks, and provide support with medical assistance. The partnership aims to promote inclusivity and provide job opportunities for individuals with disabilities.

site_title: BondEvalue aims to help retail investors access bond market
summary: BondEvalue, a Singapore-based fintech firm, has launched the world's first blockchain-based exchange, BondbloX, allowing retail investors to access the bond market through fractional ownership of bonds. The platform enables transparency in bond prices and instantaneous trade settlement, connecting banks, wealth managers, and robo-advisers globally. BondEvalue aims to increase financial inclusion for investors, making bond ownership possible for those with smaller investments, and is currently limited to accredited investors in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Mr Banerjee notes the complex nature of bonds had hindered any progress in improving access for investors.

site_title: LifeSG app replaces Moments of Life; offers over 40 government e-services
summary: Singapore's LifeSG app has been upgraded to provide over 40 government services, replacing the Moments of Life (MOL) app. The new app offers improved user experience, including personalized access to services such as CPF top-ups, season parking renewals, and passport applications. The app aims to provide a one-stop service for citizens, with a personalized dashboard featuring relevant content and job hunting guides. The government plans to add more services progressively and evaluate user feedback to improve the app.

site_title: Swiss bank BCP alleges fraud in oil deal between ZenRock, China Aviation
summary: Swiss bank BCP has sued China Aviation Oil (CAO) over an alleged $19 million fraudulent deal. BCP claims CAO presented false documents to secure the payment, as no cargo was shipped or delivered. CAO is accused of breaching a letter of credit and BCP seeks damages and interest. The case is set for a hearing on September 2, with CAO's shares falling 1.1% after the news.

site_title: Amazon sticks with office expansion plans in New York
summary: Amazon has announced plans to hire 3,500 white-collar employees across the US, including 2,000 in New York, despite the coronavirus pandemic. The new jobs will fill office space acquired by Amazon in 2020, including the Lord & Taylor building on Fifth Avenue. The company's expansion plans in New York and other US cities demonstrate its resilience during the pandemic. Amazon's growth is also reflected in its record sales and profits, with the company selling 57% more products than last year and doubling its profit to $5.2 billion.

site_title: US dollar struggles near 27-month low
summary: The US dollar struggled near a 27-month low against a basket of currencies, trading flat at 92.262, due to simmering trade tensions between Washington and Beijing, a record run for stocks on Wall Street, and concerns about the US economic recovery. The dollar index has shed over 5% since June, its largest monthly loss in a decade, with investors betting on stronger economic recoveries outside the US. The euro rose 6% against the dollar since the end of June, while sterling consolidated recent gains.

site_title: Saudi sovereign fund sets up real estate unit to meet housing demand
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has set up a real estate unit, Roshn, to meet increasing local housing demand. The move aims to diversify the economy and increase strategic partnerships with real estate investors. PIF did not provide details on spending or the number of houses to be built. Roshn will support the development of the contracting sector by adopting modern technologies. This follows Saudi Arabia's efforts to address housing shortages despite spending billions of riyals in recent years.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 2.47 points lower at 1,575.38 on Wednesday, with 8.551 billion lots traded worth RM7.010 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 614 to 447.

site_title: Mall owner CBL Properties expects to file for bankruptcy
summary: CBL Properties, a mall owner, plans to file for bankruptcy due to dwindling foot traffic, shuttered retail space, and high debt. The company expects to eliminate $900 million of debt and keep operating with $220 million in cash. Analysts predict a shakeout in malls, particularly those in less affluent areas, as retailers continue to struggle. The company's restructuring plan involves shared ownership among common and preferred stockholders, to be approved by a bankruptcy judge.

site_title: STI dips 0.08% despite Wall Street rally
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended down 2.05 points or 0.08% at 2,561.04 on Wednesday, despite a global Wall Street rally. Wilmar International was the top gainer, while Singapore Airlines declined. Asian markets also fell, with China-US trade tensions escalating. The US President postponed trade talks with China, citing uncertainty.

site_title: Russia's Novak calls for strict Opec+ deal compliance
summary: Russian Energy Minister Alexander Novak emphasized the importance of strict Opec+ deal compliance, stating that the current agreement has been successful in reducing global oil inventories. Despite concerns about the impact of US tariffs, Opec+ is unlikely to change its output policy, which calls for a 7.7 million barrel-per-day reduction. The upcoming meeting will focus on conformity and compensation rather than major policy changes, aiming to support oil prices amid the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: GM says over 40% of new China launches in next five years will be EVs
summary: General Motors plans to launch over 40% of its new vehicles in China as electric vehicles (EVs) over the next five years, with manufacturing and parts sourced from local suppliers. The move aims to stem declining sales in the country, which contributes nearly a fifth of GM's profit. This shift in strategy follows Reuters reporting that GM is overhauling its Chinese line-up.

site_title: J&J to buy Momenta for about US$6.5b for autoimmune drugs
summary: Johnson & Johnson agreed to buy Momenta Pharmaceuticals for approximately $6.5 billion to expand its treatments for autoimmune diseases. The deal includes full global rights to Momenta's experimental drug nipocalimab, which showed positive results in a phase 2 trial for myasthenia gravis. This acquisition follows Sanofi's earlier deal to acquire Principia Biopharma for $3.4 billion, further expanding the treatment landscape for autoimmune disorders.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Temasek Holdings' unit, Fullerton Fund Management, sold 696,800 Keppel Corp shares worth S$3.39 million, reducing Temasek's stake in Keppel from 21.03% to 20.99%.
