The project will be developed over nine years. iFast Corp's Malaysian arm has received in-principle approval to carry out regulated securities dealing, aiming to launch its services in early 2026. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Rebates to lift aviation; spending vouchers to boost tourism sector
summary: Singapore's government is extending support to the aviation and tourism sectors with an allocation of S$187 million for the Enhanced Aviation Support Package and S$320 million in tourism credits for Singaporeans. The move aims to retain core capabilities and position these sectors for recovery. The government's strategy is part of its efforts to support key sectors of the economy, which have been hit hard by the pandemic.

site_title: Retail, F&B firms welcome further job support but face foreign labour, rental challenges
summary: Singapore's Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) has been extended to March 2021, providing 30% wage subsidy for the first S$4,600 of wages for local employees in the retail and F&B sectors. Firms welcomed the extension, citing it as a "safety blanket" to help them digitalise and upgrade their businesses. However, some companies expressed concerns about the need for foreign labour support and rental challenges, with some calling for measures to protect businesses that need to terminate individual shop leases early.

images.alt_text: F&B and retail businesses will get 30 per cent subsidy on the first S$4,600 of wages for local employees until March 2021.

site_title: Built sector highlights other rising costs even as job support extended
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced an extension of the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) for construction firms, providing 50% wage support for two months and 30% for five months. The move aims to revive the built sector, but experts, including Straits Construction Singapore and BBR Construction Systems, say it may not be enough to get the sector back on track in seven months. Costs, including equipment rental and overheads, still pose a significant challenge, with on-site productivity expected to be affected by stringent virus-safety measures.

site_title: SGX RegCo urges caution in trading of Kitchen Culture shares
summary: SGX RegCo has warned investors to exercise caution when trading Kitchen Culture Holdings shares due to potential manipulation by a group of accounts linked to previously highlighted traders. The shares plummeted 31.6% to close at 14.7 cents after the regulator observed "substantial price movements" prior to two corporate actions, including a non-binding loan agreement and a proposed placement of new shares. SGX RegCo is reviewing the trades and will take necessary actions, including referring the case to statutory authorities if warranted.

site_title: China Evergrande shares slump as virus, discounts slash profit
summary: China Evergrande shares plummeted 13% in early Hong Kong trading, the largest intraday decline in five months, due to the novel coronavirus pandemic and discounting that slashed earnings. The developer's net income fell 46% to 14.7 billion yuan (S$2.9 billion) in the six months ended June 30, with increased marketing expenses, foreign exchange losses, and an electric car venture contributing to the decline. The company's profit warning comes despite its pledge to reduce debt by half in three years.

site_title: Insurance firms should take fresh look at transfer pricing plans
summary: The insurance sector is facing significant challenges due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with estimated losses of $107 billion in 2020. To address this, insurance firms should review their transfer pricing plans, reprice where necessary, and develop robust systems to gather internal and external information on the pandemic's impact. Tax authorities in Southeast Asia, such as Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore, will scrutinize related-party pricing arrangements, including management service fees and reinsurance transactions. Insurance groups should also analyze the impact of market conditions on pricing and develop adequate documentation to support commercially supportable arrangements.

site_title: ThaiBev shares climb 5% amid active trading
summary: ThaiBev shares rose 5% amid active trading on Monday, driven by the company's resilient revenue and earnings before interest, taxation, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) despite the Covid-19 pandemic. Q3 revenue declined about 15% year-on-year, while Ebitda fell 7%, beating expectations. The spirits arm saw a 4.9% increase in Ebitda, while the non-alcoholic beverage arm quadrupled its Ebitda. Analysts upgraded ThaiBev's stock to "buy" and maintained a positive outlook on the company's long-term fundamentals.

site_title: July exports up 6% to beat forecasts, helped by non-monetary gold
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 6% in July, beating forecasts and driven mainly by strong shipments of non-monetary gold, which more than tripled in the month. Excluding gold, NODX would have declined by 5.6% year on year. Electronics NODX grew 2.8%, while pharmaceuticals growth slowed to 15.5% from 30.8% in June. Despite the NODX improvement, total trade fell 8.9% year on year, with total exports down 7.9% and imports up 4.8%. Economists remain positive about Singapore's NODX outlook, citing resilient demand for electronics and pharmaceuticals.

site_title: Oil price upside looks limited amid rising supply
summary: Oil prices remain stable, with further upside limited due to rising supply and a slowdown in demand. Opec+ has pared back production cuts, and global demand growth has faltered, with secondary lockdowns in the US and weaker demand in China and India. Physical oil markets face headwinds, including high stocks, slowing Chinese buying, and global refining maintenance. Platts Analytics predicts Dated Brent prices will remain around $40/barrel for the third quarter, with global oil supply expected to increase by 4.5 million b/d through July and August.

site_title: EU regulators okay with conditions on Mastercard's Scandinavian e-pay deal
summary: EU antitrust regulators have cleared Mastercard's acquisition of three divisions of Scandinavian payments group Nets, after the companies agreed to sell a Nets technology to a rival. The deal, valued at $3.4 billion, was initially met with concerns about the impact on account-to-account core infrastructure services. Mastercard offered concessions, including the transfer of a global license to distribute Nets' Realtime 24/7 technology, to boost competition in the market. The deal is now expected to proceed with the conditions in place.

site_title: US further tightens restrictions on Huawei's access to technology, chips
summary: The US Commerce Department announced further restrictions on Huawei's access to commercially available chips, expanding restrictions announced in May. The new measures will prevent the Chinese telecommunications giant from obtaining semiconductors without a special license, including chips made by foreign firms with US software or technology. The restrictions aim to crack down on Huawei's access to technology and chips, following similar actions taken by the US in May.

images.alt_text: Mr Ross: "The new rule makes it clear that any use of American software or American fabrication equipment is banned and requires a licence."

site_title: French holidaying in a summer like no other
summary: French resorts are thriving this summer, with wealthy French and European clients filling the gap left by foreign visitors from Russia and the US who are staying away due to the pandemic. The government has actively encouraged domestic vacations to boost the economy, which has been severely impacted by the pandemic. Despite the looming shadow of the coronavirus, a week-long summer holiday is a sacred ritual for the French, and resorts are grateful for the influx of domestic tourists.

site_title: STI retreats 0.4% despite new Covid-19 support measures
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) retreated 0.4% to 2,571.55, despite the Singapore government's announcement of additional S$8 billion support measures to aid businesses and workers hit by the pandemic. Thai Beverage Public Company was the best performer, gaining 4.96%, while NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. The market remained cautious, with no lift from the government's efforts to support the economy.

site_title: US home builder confidence matches record high
summary: US home builder confidence reached a record high in August, matching a 22-year record set in 1998, with the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index rising 6 points to 78. This is the third consecutive month of growth, driven by record-low interest rates and increased customer traffic, particularly in suburban markets. Measures of both current and future home sales also improved.

site_title: Is gaming the future of the virtual world?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the rise of gaming as a dominant form of entertainment, with global gaming revenues expected to hit $160 billion this year. Gaming platforms have become venues for various events, such as online classes, weddings, and concerts, and have enabled the creation of immersive 3D worlds. Companies like Epic Games are pioneering the "metaverse" concept, a parallel online world that blurs the lines between physical and virtual commercial spaces. Internet giants like Apple and Google are racing to control the metaverse, but critics argue they are taking an unfair cut of the gaming market, fueling a potential shift in power dynamics.

site_title: IMDA supports interim deployment of partial 5G capabilities
summary: IMDA in Singapore supports the deployment of partial 5G capabilities, allowing trials for consumers to enjoy faster mobile speeds on existing 4G infrastructure. This move will pave the way for the nationwide rollout of 5G standalone networks by 2025. Mobile Network Operators (MNOs) will be allowed to conduct market trials and offer early commercial 5G services to consumers, with IMDA developing a regulatory framework to ensure a smooth transition. Singapore's 5G SA networks are expected to support innovative use cases such as remote surgery and cloud gaming.

site_title: UK U-turns on school exam grades after widespread criticism
summary: The UK government has U-turned on its school exam grading system, ditching an algorithm that downgraded results for nearly 40% of students due to Covid-19. The algorithm was widely criticized after it lowered predicted grades for students who did not take tests. Instead, students will now receive the grade predicted by their teachers based on past performance. The decision comes after days of public outcry and pressure from the government.

site_title: US tightening restrictions on Huawei access to technology, chips
summary: The US has tightened restrictions on Huawei's access to commercially available chips, expanding existing restrictions announced in May. The Commerce Department added 38 Huawei affiliates in 21 countries to the economic blacklist, raising the total to 152 affiliates. The new rules ban the use of American software or fabrication equipment without a license and will prevent Huawei from circumventing US law through alternative chip production. The move aims to prevent Huawei from accessing data for spying by the Chinese government, with the company denying such allegations.

site_title: Independence of Catalist sponsors crucial
summary: A study by the National University of Singapore Business School and an investor highlights the independence of Catalist sponsors in Singapore, who often face conflicts of interest due to their provision of non-sponsor services to sponsored companies. The sponsors' commercial and regulatory roles should be separated to maintain their independence and avoid conflicts. A clearer framework governing sponsors' independence is needed, including effective Chinese walls and internal control procedures. The study's findings have implications for the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and other exchanges with similar sponsor regimes, such as the Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing.

site_title: US: Wall Street kicks off big retail earnings week on high note
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, with the S&P 500 inching closer to a record high, as retailers prepare to wind down a better-than-feared quarterly earnings season. The Dow Jones rose 39.03 points, the S&P 500 gained 8.01 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 63.94 points, driven by a strong retail earnings week. Despite US-China trade tensions, stocks continued to rally, with investors focusing on the earnings season and the potential for future growth.

site_title: Bitcoin hits highest in 13 months as 2020 rally gathers steam
summary: Bitcoin reached its highest price in 13 months, jumping 4.4% to $12,424, as part of a 2020 rally that has seen its price more than triple since March. The surge is attributed to plummeting interest rates and central banks' bond-buying programs, which have boosted demand for the cryptocurrency as a hedge against inflation.

site_title: SoftBank builds US$1.2b Amazon stake; invests in Netflix, Tesla
summary: SoftBank Group has invested approximately US$1.2 billion in Amazon, building a stake worth around that amount, as part of its expansion into liquid stocks. The conglomerate has also invested in Netflix, Tesla, Microsoft, Alphabet, Nvidia, and Chinese video sites Bilibili and iQIYI. SoftBank is pivoting away from its US$100 billion Vision Fund, focusing on unlisted startups, and is in talks over the possible sale of chip designer Arm. The investments are driven by a tech stock rally, with Tesla's shares rising over 60% since June.

site_title: Israel planning UAE flights over Saudi: Netanyahu
summary: Israel is planning to establish a corridor over Saudi Arabia for flights to the UAE, following a historic normalization deal between the two countries. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced that Israel is working to open an air route, which will shorten flights between Tel Aviv and Dubai. The agreement is seen as a major revolution and will also impact Israel's maritime trade, with Dubai's free trade zones expected to benefit the country. The move is part of a series of normalization deals between Israel and Arab countries, and Saudi Arabia has yet to officially react to the deal.

site_title: Worst heat in years threatens to take down California's grid
summary: California is experiencing its worst heat wave in years, pushing the state's power grid to the brink of collapse. The region has declared two grid emergencies and instituted rolling blackouts due to high demand for power and power plants tripping offline. Temperatures are expected to reach 44 degrees Celsius in some parts of the state, with the demand for power reaching a record 49,700 megawatts. The blackouts are a result of climate change, which is causing extreme weather events to become more frequent.

site_title: Offer to take Perennial Real Estate private closes
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings, a mainboard-listed company, has accepted an offer by consortium Primero Investment Holdings to take the company private. The offer, which closed on Monday, resulted in 1.65 billion shares being owned by Primero and its affiliated parties, representing 99.01% of the total issued share capital. As a result, the company will delist from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: China food supply gap to hit 130m tonnes by 2025: think tank
summary: China is expected to face a food supply gap of approximately 130 million tonnes by 2025, according to a government think tank, citing the growing urban population and aging rural workforce. The report also warns of declining rural residents and increased industrialization and urbanization pressures on the country's land and water resources. To address this, the Chinese government has implemented initiatives to limit urban and industrial encroachment on rural regions and clean up polluted land and water for agriculture. Maintaining food security is a major priority for the ruling Chinese Communist Party.

site_title: iFast gets in-principle nod for securities dealing in Malaysia
summary: The Malaysian arm of Singapore-based iFast Corp has received in-principle approval from the Securities Commission Malaysia to deal in securities. iFast Malaysia expects to launch its stock dealing services by early next year, aiming to provide a comprehensive wealth management platform in Malaysia. The company holds various licenses, including a capital markets services licence and a financial advisers licence. Its shares fell 2.6% after the announcement.

site_title: Sri Lanka plunged into darkness as power outage hits entire nation
summary: A power outage affected the entire nation of Sri Lanka, leaving 21 million people without electricity for six hours. The outage, caused by a technical issue at the Kerawalapitiya power station, was the worst disruption since March 2016. The country relies heavily on thermal power, with the Kerawalapitiya station accounting for about 12% of the country's electricity demand. Despite localized power failures being common, nationwide outages are rare. Steps are being taken to restore power, but no timeline has been provided.

site_title: Trump administration approves oil leasing in Alaska wildlife refuge
summary: The Trump administration approved oil and gas drilling in Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, a 7.7 million hectare area off-limits for decades. US Interior Secretary David Bernhardt announced the final approval, which puts the government on track to sell oil and gas leases within months. Environmentalists and Democratic lawmakers oppose the move, citing harm to wildlife and the Arctic ecosystem. The decision is seen as fulfilling a Republican-passed tax bill mandate, with oil production expected to begin in about 8 years and last about 50 years.

site_title: Changi Airport faces long and difficult road to recovery
summary: Changi Airport, once the seventh busiest airport globally, faces a long and difficult road to recovery after the COVID-19 pandemic. With 400 passenger movements a day, the airport is now ranked 50th in the world and has seen a 40-year decline in traffic. The government is exploring ways to revive the air hub, including replacing mandatory isolation periods with rigorous testing regimes and allowing tourists from controlled regions to fly in. Passenger traffic is expected to remain low until proper travel bubbles are established, with current green lanes having a low take-up rate.

site_title: China's JD.com reports quarterly revenue above estimates
summary: China's JD.com reported quarterly revenue above estimates, with net product revenue rising 33.5% to 178.19 billion yuan, and total net revenue increasing 33.8% to 201.1 billion yuan. The company's net income attributable to shareholders rose to 16.45 billion yuan, beating analyst expectations. US-listed shares of JD.com rose over 2% in trading following the announcement.

site_title: UK exam crisis deepens as Johnson faces another week of chaos
summary: The UK government is facing an exam crisis as thousands of 16-year-olds receive GCSE results on Thursday, amid public outrage over the handling of school leavers' test results during the Covid-19 pandemic. The algorithm-based system led to widespread criticism, particularly affecting students from economically disadvantaged areas, sparking calls for Education Secretary Gavin Williamson to resign. The government has announced that the appeals process will be free of charge, but concerns remain about the impact on students' futures, with many universities making conditional offers based on A-level grades.

site_title: S$8b more to buy time for firms, help create and keep jobs
summary: Singapore is providing an additional S$8 billion in COVID-19 support, including up to seven months of wage subsidies, a new S$1 billion Jobs Growth Incentive for new hires, and an extended grant for unemployed Singaporeans. The support aims to buy time for firms, reduce the fiscal burden, and help create and keep jobs. Hard-hit sectors such as aerospace, aviation, and tourism will receive extra support, while the government will also position itself to seize opportunities in a post-COVID world, including setting aside S$150 million for the Startup SG Founder programme.

images.alt_text: A further S$8 billion in continued Covid-19 support is on the way, including up to seven more months of wage subsidies; a new S$1 billion Jobs Growth Initiative for new hires; and an extended grant for Singaporeans who are unemployed or have seen significant income loss.

site_title: Thailand suffers biggest economic slump since 1998, government announces more stimulus
summary: Thailand's economy suffered its largest annual contraction since 1998, contracting 12.2% in the second quarter due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on tourism and exports. The government slashed its GDP forecast for the year, expecting a 7.3-7.8% decline. To support the economy, the government announced more stimulus measures, while the central bank has cut interest rates to a record low. The country's tourism sector, heavily reliant on exports, saw a record 9.7% quarterly contraction, with foreign tourist numbers expected to drop to 6.7 million this year.

site_title: Opec+ compliance with oil output cuts in July around 97%
summary: Opec+ oil output cuts are seen at around 97% in July, two days ahead of a meeting to review adherence with the production pact. The figure is based on two Opec+ sources and has not yet been finalized by a technical panel. The pact, which was eased to 7.7 million barrels per day, is expected to remain unchanged. Opec oil output has risen by over 1 million barrels per day in July, despite efforts to improve compliance among countries such as Iraq, Nigeria, and Kazakhstan.

site_title: Two office floors at Samsung Hub up for sale with S$104.88m indicative price
summary: Two office floors at Samsung Hub, a 30-storey Grade A office tower in Singapore's central business district, are up for sale with an indicative price of S$104.88 million, translating to about S$4,000 per square foot. The floors, located on levels nine and 10, can be purchased collectively or individually and are currently tenanted. This is a rare opportunity for investors to acquire consecutive floors in a sought-after building, with the developer Sun Ventures receiving strong interest for the two floors after selling the 11th floor earlier this year for S$49.8 million.

site_title: Singapore operators may deploy 5G non-standalone networks in interim: IMDA
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) will support mobile network operators in deploying 5G non-standalone (NSA) networks, allowing for faster mobile speeds and partial 5G experiences for consumers before the nationwide rollout of 5G standalone (SA) networks by 2025. This interim move will enable market trials and early commercial 5G services, with IMDA working on a regulatory framework for a smooth transition to SA networks.

site_title: China Jishan sees 330.7m yuan in pre-sales from project
summary: China Jishan Holdings' indirect wholly-owned subsidiary has secured approximately 330.7 million yuan (S$65.2 million) in pre-sales for a residential project in Shaoxing, China. The sale proceeds will be used to repay a loan and pay project costs. The company notes that pre-sales revenue will not impact its FY20 profit and loss, as it is only recognized upon property delivery in 2023. Trading in China Jishan shares has been suspended due to concerns over the company's ability to continue as a going concern.

site_title: SGX RegCo urges caution in trading of Kitchen Culture shares
summary: SGX RegCo warned shareholders and investors to exercise caution when trading Kitchen Culture Holdings shares due to suspicious trades. The regulator identified a group of accounts connected to previous traders highlighted in a trade-with-caution notice as the likely culprits. The shares plummeted 31.6% to close at 14.7 cents after a surge of 364% from April 15 to August 11, with two corporate actions announced by the company potentially influencing the price movements. SGX RegCo is reviewing the trades and may take necessary actions, including referring the case to statutory authorities.

site_title: NTUC's fair-retrenchment guidelines to be added to advisory
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) of Singapore has agreed to have its fair-retrenchment guidelines incorporated into the tripartite advisory on managing excess manpower and responsible retrenchment. The guidelines, which were announced last month, propose that employers protect the Singaporean core workforce and retain foreigners with critical skills. The advisory will also include minimum notice periods for retrenchment and prevailing norms for retrenchment benefits. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that retrenchments will be inevitable, but the government will support workers who have fallen on hard times.

site_title: KS Energy says OCBC's demand is for guarantee of US$150m under unit's term loan, S$5m bridging loan
summary: KS Energy received demands from OCBC Bank for guarantees totaling US$150m for a US$230.7m term loan and S$5m for a bridging loan. The demands follow an announcement by the bank that it had sent letters to KS Energy, its 80.09%-owned subsidiary KS Drilling, and six other subsidiaries seeking repayment of loans. KS Energy is seeking legal advice and will engage with OCBC to remedy the situation, advising shareholders to exercise caution in trading its shares. The company's shares are suspended.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine expands into new market with contracts for 'smart' fish farms
summary: Marco Polo Marine has secured shipbuilding contracts from Singapore Aquaculture Technologies to construct two "smart" floating fish farms, its first foray into the aquaculture market. The "smart" fish farms aim to produce at least 500 megatonnes of food fish annually using advanced technology and green processes. The contracts are expected to contribute positively to the group's performance for the 2021 financial year, although they may not have a material impact on its net tangible assets per share and earnings per share.

site_title: Hong Kong shipping terminal hit by coronavirus, threatening movement of goods
summary: Hong Kong reported 31 local coronavirus cases, including 11 of unknown origin, as new clusters emerged, including a shipping terminal that could disrupt goods movement. The Kwai Tsing Container Terminals cluster rose to 65, raising concerns about operations. Authorities extended social distancing restrictions for another week, citing a "considerably high" risk of an explosive community outbreak. Testing will be increased at the terminal, and some workers have been sent to quarantine, but shutting down the terminal is being considered to prevent further transmission.

site_title: STI closes 0.4% lower despite new Covid-19 support measures
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.4% lower on Monday, despite the Singapore government's introduction of S$8 billion support measures to aid workers and businesses affected by the coronavirus pandemic. Thai Beverage Public Company (ThaiBev) was the best performer, gaining 4.96% after posting resilient revenue. The STI fell 9.77 points to 2,571.55, with ThaiBev being the most heavily traded stock with 470.2 million shares traded.

site_title: Malaysia's government to face popularity test in state election
summary: Malaysia's government, led by Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin, will face a popularity test in the state election on September 26, where over 1 million registered voters in Sabah will decide between his Perikatan Nasional government and the loose federal opposition alliance, Pakatan Plus. The election, expected to have a 70% turnout, will determine the popularity of Perikatan versus Pakatan Plus, with analysts suggesting it could lead to calls for a nationwide snap election to end the country's political instability. The outcome may also impact the government's control in parliament.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore extends Covid-19 support with S$8 billion, including up to seven months of wage subsidies and a new S$1 billion Jobs Growth Initiative for sectors hiring. The Jobs Support Scheme will be extended for another seven months, and a grant is available for Singaporeans who are unemployed or have seen significant income loss. The government aims to support sectors that are still hiring and provide relief to those affected by the pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished Monday with gains, driven by China's central bank injecting cash into financial markets. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.65%, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 2.34%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also increased 1.92%. The gains come as investors monitor US-China relations and stimulus talks.

site_title: New Zealand new wage subsidy scheme expected to cost NZ$510m
summary: New Zealand's Finance Minister Grant Robertson announced a new wage subsidy scheme expected to cost NZ$510 million, covering 470,000 jobs. The scheme was introduced to support cash flow and confidence following the lockdown of Auckland due to coronavirus. Additionally, the mortgage deferral scheme will be extended to March 31, 2026, from its current end-date of September 27.

site_title: Sembcorp unit to develop Myanmar Singapore Industrial Park
summary: Sembcorp Industries' unit, SEMBCORP Development, will develop the Myanmar Singapore Industrial Park, a 436-hectare integrated urban development in Hlegu township, Yangon Region, Myanmar. The joint venture company will be responsible for the master development of the industrial park over nine years. The project was approved by the Myanmar Investment Commission and has a paid-up capital of US$2 million. Sembcorp Development's effective ownership is 50.6%, and the development is expected to have minimal impact on SCI's earnings per share and net asset value per share.

site_title: Hong Kong records 44 new coronavirus cases as social distancing restrictions extended
summary: Hong Kong reported 44 new coronavirus cases on August 17, with 31 local transmissions, as social distancing measures are extended until August 25. The number of daily cases has decreased from triple digits but authorities caution against complacency. Restrictions include a 6pm restaurant ban and mask mandates in public areas, which will remain in place for seven days. Over 4,500 people have been infected since late January, with 69 deaths.

site_title: Ascendas Reit raises S$100m from maiden green bond
summary: Ascendas Reit has raised S$100 million through its maiden green bond, exceeding an order book of S$650 million. The 10-year bond has a fixed coupon rate of 2.65% and will be issued under its S$7 billion euro medium-term securities programme. The green bond framework was established to support the trust's environmental, social, and governance (ESG) goals. This move demonstrates Ascendas Reit's commitment to sustainable investing and green finance.

site_title: Panama Canal shipping rebounds in hopeful sign for global trade
summary: The Panama Canal saw a rebound in global trade with total transits rising to 933 in July, up from 845 in June, as shipping recovers from pandemic-related depressed levels. Container shipping between the US and Asia, the canal's most important route, began to increase in August. However, cruise ships continue to cancel slots, and the trade in Liquid Natural Gas may take more time to recover. The canal authority plans to invest up to $2 billion in alternative water sources to address ongoing drought issues affecting Gatun Lake.

site_title: Singapore to pump S$150m into Startup SG Founder programme
summary: Singapore is investing up to S$150 million in the Startup SG Founder programme to support innovation and entrepreneurship during the Covid-19 pandemic. The funds will increase the startup capital grant to S$30,000 and provide mentorship to startups. The programme aims to spur economic growth and transform the Singapore economy for a post-Covid world. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat cited successful pivots by firms like Decks Private Limited and Certact Engineering as examples of the programme's impact.

site_title: Goldman boosts S&P 500 target by 20% as strategists catch up
summary: Goldman Sachs has boosted its S&P 500 target to 3,600, a 20% increase, as the benchmark US gauge rallies off its March lows. Strategist David Kostin cited positive news on the vaccine front and a falling equity risk premium as key factors. The S&P 500 is now 51% off its March lows, threatening to eclipse its February closing record. The rally has caught many investors by surprise, with Goldman's forecast joining others, including Yardeni Research and RBC Capital Markets. A rising stock market is expected to lift the index to 3,600 by year's end.

site_title: Britain's hot weather keeps shopper numbers low
summary: Britain's shopper numbers rose 0.8% in the week to Aug 15, driven by a state-funded eating out scheme, but remained low due to extremely hot weather. This marks a decrease from the 3.8% increase in the previous week. The UK retail sector continues to struggle with high rents, taxes, and online competition, with thousands of job losses already announced. The hot weather may have contributed to the muted increase in shopper numbers, but it's unclear how long this trend will continue.

site_title: China's Geely Automobile trims full-year sales outlook after profit plunge
summary: China's Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd reported a 43% drop in half-year profit to 2.3 billion yuan, trimming its full-year sales goal to 1.32 million vehicles, down 3% from last year. The company's sales climbed for the fourth consecutive month in July, but overall sales are still down 12.7% for the year to date. Geely's shares fell 4% following the announcement, which was largely in line with analyst expectations. The company is working to revamp factories and expand European exports under its premium brand Lynk & Co.

site_title: China's Cabinet to guide lending rates lower, avoid flood-like stimulus
summary: China's Cabinet has decided to guide lending rates lower and avoid a flood-like stimulus to combat economic slowdown. The decision was made in a meeting chaired by Premier Li Keqiang, with a focus on making macro policies more targeted and effective. The goal is to maintain reasonable liquidity while preventing excessive stimulus, according to state TV.

site_title: Thai court extends Thai Airways bankruptcy hearings until Aug 25
summary: Thai Airways International's bankruptcy court has extended hearings on the airline's request for restructuring until August 25. The court required two additional days to complete proceedings, with more evidence to be presented. The airline has submitted its bankruptcy and restructuring petition, giving it a stay on debt repayment, and has nominated a committee of seven to plan the company's restructuring. Major creditors, including the Ministry of Finance, support the airline's request, holding a 47.86% stake in the airline. The court must approve the airline's request for restructuring and a plan to be developed in one to two months.

site_title: 91 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 6 imported; no community cases
summary: Singapore reported 91 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 55,838. Six of the cases were imported, with the remaining 85 cases linked to migrant workers in dormitories. No community cases were reported, and the number of unlinked cases in the community has remained stable at one case per day over the past two weeks. With 432 cases discharged, 51,938 patients have recovered from the disease, and 27 deaths have been reported.

site_title: Covid-19 Support Grant extended until December, eligibility for Workfare Special Payment widened
summary: The Singapore government has extended the Covid-19 Support Grant (CSG) until December 2020, benefiting over 60,000 residents with more than S$90 million disbursed. The extension is open to both existing and new applicants, requiring job search or training efforts. Additionally, the eligibility for the Workfare Special Payment (WSP) will be widened to include those who received or will receive workfare this year. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need to support vulnerable employees and self-employed persons, and the government will share more details in early September.

site_title: Jobs Support Scheme extended by up to 7 months depending on sector
summary: Singapore's Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) wage subsidy will be extended by up to seven months, covering wages paid up to March 2021. The scheme's support levels and durations vary by sector, with hardest-hit sectors like aerospace and tourism receiving 50% support for seven months. Other sectors, such as arts and entertainment, will receive 30% support for seven months. Exceptions include biomedical sciences, financial services, and ICT, which will receive 10% support for four more months. The extension aims to support businesses and workers amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Baring Private Equity makes 146b yen counter bid for Bain target Nichiigakkan
summary: Baring Private Equity Asia has made a counter offer of 2,000 yen per share for Japanese nursing home operator Nichiigakkan, valuing the company at 146 billion yen, higher than Bain Capital's offer of 1,670 yen. The proposal could put pressure on Bain to further sweeten its offer amid government pressure for better corporate governance. Baring also offered to assist with a management buyout and tender offer for all outstanding shares. Nichiigakkan's shares rose 2% after the announcement, with some analysts estimating the fair value of the company at 2,400 yen per share.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.3% to 6,105.51 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 index and Paris CAC 40 index also climbed 0.3% and 0.4%, respectively. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks. US stocks also reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging higher.

site_title: Ex-KKR dealmaker launches healthcare-focused buyout firm
summary: Jim Momtazee, a former KKR dealmaker, has launched Patient Square Capital, a healthcare-focused private equity firm. Momtazee, who led KKR's Americas healthcare team for a decade, plans to invest in various healthcare sectors, including technology-enabled services, biopharmaceuticals, and medical devices. The move comes as the COVID-19 pandemic has driven growth in some healthcare areas. Prior to leaving KKR, Momtazee worked on several high-profile healthcare deals, including the $33 billion take-private of HCA Healthcare.

site_title: Government to allocate S$187m towards extending Enhanced Aviation Support Package
summary: The Singapore government will allocate S$187 million to extend the Enhanced Aviation Support Package to March 2021, providing cost relief to airlines, ground handlers, and airport tenants. The package also aims to support local carriers in regaining air connectivity. Additionally, S$320 million will be set aside for tourism credits, dubbed SingapoRediscovers Vouchers, to encourage local tourism. The government will also redeploy workers to create around 4,000 new jobs in the healthcare sector and provide further support to businesses in the arts and culture sectors.

site_title: S$8 billion in continued Covid-19 support, including extension of Jobs Support Scheme
summary: Singapore's government will provide an additional S$8 billion in COVID-19 support, including a 7-month extension of the Jobs Support Scheme wage subsidy, a new S$1 billion Jobs Growth Incentive, and an extended grant for unemployed or income-losing individuals. The measures aim to support hard-hit sectors like aerospace, aviation, and tourism, as well as create new jobs and stimulate economic growth. The government also plans to boost domestic tourism with S$320 million in tourism credits and enhance the Startup SG Founder program with up to S$150 million.

site_title: Singapore launches S$1b Jobs Growth Incentive scheme with special focus on mature workers
summary: Singapore has launched a S$1 billion Jobs Growth Incentive (JGI) scheme to create new jobs, focusing on mature workers aged 40 and above. The scheme co-pays up to 25% of salaries for new hires and up to 50% for those 40 and above, to encourage firms to increase local worker headcount. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for skilled workers in sectors like biomedical sciences, financial services, and ICT, while also promoting jobseekers to utilize the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Centres.

site_title: Europe's biggest pork exporter reopens plant shuttered by Covid
summary: Danish Crown, Europe's largest pork exporter, is reopening an abattoir in Denmark after a Covid-19 outbreak among staff was brought under control. The plant, which processes 62,000 pigs weekly, had been shut down after over 140 workers tested positive for the virus. It will reopen at half capacity starting August 21, with other facilities making up for lost production. The reopening is pending results of staff tests and comes after the halt in exports to China due to the outbreak.

site_title: Two adjoining plots at Jalan Lembah Kallang for sale at S$17m guide price
summary: Two adjoining plots at 1 and 3 Jalan Lembah Kallang in Singapore are up for sale with a guide price of S$8.5 million each or S$17 million for both. The plots, situated near Bendemeer and Boon Keng MRT stations, have a total land area of 16,919 sq ft and potential redevelopment of up to 21,000 sq ft. With 43 years remaining on their 99-year leasehold tenures, the properties are expected to attract buyers seeking to redevelop the site into corporate headquarters. An expression-of-interest exercise closes on September 30.

site_title: Malaysia's Penang halts medical tourists after arrivals from Indonesia
summary: Malaysia's Penang state has halted medical tourism until new health and safety procedures are finalized, following the arrival of three Indonesian patients seeking treatment. The patients, two cancer victims and one in need of immediate treatment, arrived without informing authorities, prompting the ban. The state government regrets the oversight and has ordered health tourism agencies to provide notifications and information. The ban will remain in place until the healthcare ministry completes procedures to deal with healthcare tourism.

site_title: Show goes on for French holidays in summer like no other
summary: French resorts, including the Mediterranean town of Saint-Tropez, are bustling with domestic tourists during the summer holiday season, unlike previous years when foreigners were the main visitors. The government encouraged people to take vacations to boost the economy, which was severely impacted by the pandemic. This year's summer is seen as a unique situation, with the coronavirus still looming large, yet the French are embracing their domestic holidays.

images.alt_text: The glitzy Mediterranean resort of Saint-Tropez -- usually a magnet for the international jet-set -- is far from empty but it is domestic tourists who are filling the town and not free-spending foreign visitors.

site_title: Malaysia detects coronavirus strain that's 10 times more infectious
summary: Malaysia has detected a coronavirus strain, D614G, that is 10 times more infectious. The mutation was found in cases linked to a restaurant owner returning from India and breaching quarantine. The strain has become prevalent in Europe and the US, with the World Health Organization stating it does not lead to a more severe disease. Director-General of Health Noor Hisham Abdullah warned people to take greater precautions, citing the potential for existing vaccine studies to be incomplete or ineffective.

images.alt_text: Malaysia has detected a strain of the new coronavirus that's been found to be 10 times more infectious.

site_title: Singapore air crew returning from overseas to be routinely tested for Covid-19: CAAS
summary: Singapore air crew returning from overseas will undergo Covid-19 testing starting August 20. This is on top of existing health and safety protocols. Crew members from countries where travellers can serve their stay-home notice at their own accommodation will be exempt from testing. The move aims to maintain safety amid the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Reliance in talks to buy online furniture retail, milk delivery startups: report
summary: Reliance Industries is in talks to acquire online furniture retailer Urban Ladder and milk delivery firm Milkbasket to strengthen its e-commerce business. The talks are at an advanced stage, with a potential deal for Urban Ladder pegged at around $30 million. This comes as the Covid-19 pandemic fuels online shopping in India, with Reliance's online grocery service JioMart gaining traction. The move is part of Reliance's efforts to raise $20 billion for its digital arm, Jio Platforms, with recent investments from Facebook and Google.

site_title: Sanofi to buy US autoimmune drugmaker in US$3.4b deal
summary: Sanofi is acquiring US-based autoimmune drugmaker Principia Biopharma in a $3.4 billion deal. The all-cash acquisition will see Sanofi take full control of Principia, focusing on treatments for multiple sclerosis and autoimmune disorders. The deal represents a 10% premium over Principia's Friday closing price, with Sanofi paying $100 per share. The acquisition will give Sanofi a pipeline of BTK inhibitors, aiming to rejuvenate the company's focus on innovative therapies and spur growth.

images.alt_text: Sanofi plans to acquire San Francisco, California-based Principia Biopharma in a deal with an enterprise value of US$3.4 billion as the French drugmaker pivots towards innovative therapies to spur growth.

site_title: Keppel associate Floatel's bonds forbearance agreement extended to Aug 31
summary: Keppel associate Floatel has extended its forbearance agreement with bondholders to August 31, allowing it to delay coupon payments of approximately $22.8 million. The agreement has been extended several times since April, when it was initially signed. Floatel remains in constructive negotiations with key stakeholders, including bondholders, to discuss a financial restructuring. The company's vessels and business continue to operate normally, despite a second-quarter net loss of $697 million for Keppel, which was attributed to massive impairments.

site_title: Japan's Mitsui cleared to export gas from West Australian project
summary: Japan's Mitsui & Co has been cleared to export gas from the Waitsia Stage 2 project in Western Australia. The state government allowed half of the gas to be exported as liquefied natural gas (LNG) through the North West Shelf LNG plant to help kickstart the project. The exemption comes as the government aims to stimulate the regional economy and provide jobs and royalties. The project, one of Australia's largest onshore gas discoveries, is expected to export 1.5 million tonnes of LNG per year for about seven years.

images.alt_text: Japan's Mitsui & Co won an exemption from the Western Australian government on Monday to export gas from a new onshore field, in a push to jump start the project and help the state's recovery from the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: IBM rolls out newest processor chip, taps Samsung for manufacturing
summary: IBM unveiled its newest processor chip, the Power10, capable of handling three times the workload of its predecessor. Manufactured by Samsung, the chip uses the 7-nanometer manufacturing process and boasts faster artificial intelligence computing capabilities, up to 20 times faster than its predecessor. The move is seen as a strategic response to Intel's delayed next-generation manufacturing technology, which analysts believe will give IBM's rivals a market share advantage. The Power10 chip is designed for data centers and is part of IBM's focus on high-performance computing systems.

site_title: Australian state premier apologises for cruise ship failures after Covid-19 spike
summary: NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian apologised for the state's handling of the Ruby Princess cruise ship outbreak, which led to 22 deaths and 914 infections. The inquiry found NSW health officials made "inexcusable" mistakes, including failing to screen passengers and isolate sick individuals. The apology comes as Victoria state reports a record 25 deaths from a second wave of infection. The number of Covid-19 cases in Australia remains lower than many other developed nations, but missteps in handling the outbreak have proven costly. Berejiklian also apologised to those who contracted the virus from a passenger, describing it as "trauma" they continue to experience.

site_title: Japan PM Abe enters hospital for examination
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe entered a Tokyo hospital for an examination, with government sources describing the situation as not worrying. The reason for the visit was not immediately known, but was reported to be for a regular check-up. Abe's office did not respond to a request for comment.

site_title: China adds cash into banking system to ease liquidity stress
summary: China's central bank injected 700 billion yuan into the financial system through a one-year funding facility to alleviate liquidity stress and support banks amid a fragile economic recovery. The move more than offsetted 400 billion yuan in loans coming due and 150 billion yuan maturing on August 26, keeping interest rates unchanged at 2.95%. The injection is seen as a sign of a neutral monetary policy with an easing bias in August, potentially leading to a drop in 10-year government yields to around 2.8%.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, ComfortDelGro, Mapletree Industrial Trust, Halcyon Agri
summary: Singapore stocks saw mixed performances on Monday, with Singtel and ComfortDelGro Corp experiencing losses due to earnings declines. Mapletree Industrial Trust agreed to sell a data centre for S$125 million, while Halcyon Agri Corp reported a widened net loss. ST Engineering plans to cut costs to offset pandemic headwinds, and DBS announced a collaboration with Amazon Web Services to train employees in AI and machine learning.

site_title: Oil prices advance as China ramps up US crude imports
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday as China booked large volumes of US crude, outweighing concerns over demand recovery and supply. Brent crude increased 0.7% to $45.10 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.8% to $42.35 a barrel. China's record crude imports and easing Covid-19 restrictions supported oil prices, but new outbreaks are expected to cool consumption. Demand has risen 8 million barrels per day over the past four months, but still lags 13 million barrels per day below pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Developers sell 1,080 Singapore private homes excluding ECs in July, up 8.2% from June
summary: Developers in Singapore sold 1,080 private homes in July, up 8.2% from June, but down 8.4% from the same period last year. This includes 1,142 units when including executive condominiums, a 10.8% increase from June but a 26.7% decrease from July last year. Experts attribute the rise to investors seeking safe-haven assets amid economic uncertainties and low interest rates. New home launches are expected to boost sales in August, with several upcoming projects set to hit the market.

site_title: The rise of Asean manufacturing
summary: ASEAN's manufacturing bloc is expected to bounce back strongly despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The region's economy, valued at $3.0 trillion, is forecast to grow at an average annual rate of 4.9% to reach $4.9 trillion by 2030. Asean's population of over 660 million people, with 450 million of working age, is a significant demographic advantage. The region's manufacturing shift towards Southeast Asia is driven by increasing costs in China and the need for labor-intensive products. Reshoring is a real possibility, with automation and robotics making it a viable solution for advanced manufacturing markets.

site_title: Britain encourages at-risk groups to sign up for Covid-19 vaccine trials
summary: Britain is urging at-risk groups, including the elderly and minority groups, to sign up for Covid-19 vaccine trials to boost efforts to find a vaccine effective against the disease. Over 100,000 people have volunteered, but more are needed, particularly from Black, Asian, and minority ethnic backgrounds, which have been disproportionately affected by the pandemic. The UK government aims to protect those at risk and is keen to find a vaccine quickly to protect vulnerable groups.

site_title: China grants country's first Covid-19 vaccine patent to CanSino: state media
summary: China has granted CanSino Biologics Inc, its first Covid-19 vaccine patent, according to state media. The approval was issued on August 11 for CanSino's Ad5-nCOV vaccine candidate. This is the first Covid-19 vaccine patent granted by China. CanSino's shares rose 14% in Hong Kong and 6.6% in Shanghai after the announcement. The company is also in talks to launch Phase III clinical trials in Saudi Arabia, Russia, Brazil, and Chile.

site_title: India's bond market is so hot even a yoga guru is selling debt
summary: India's bond market is experiencing a surge as unprecedented stimulus measures reduce borrowing costs to the cheapest since 2005. First-time bond issuers, including yoga guru Baba Ramdev's Patanjali Ayurved and Wipro Enterprises, are rushing into the market. The increase in debut bond sales will add depth to the debt market, but also raises concerns about borrowers lacking a track record. Indian policymakers' stimulus measures, including slashing interest rates and funding banks, have led to a significant drop in borrowing costs, with top-rated three-year notes yielding 5.09% compared to loans at 6.3%.

site_title: Volvo owner's China business posts 43% profit drop on pandemic
summary: Geely Automobile Holdings, a Chinese carmaker controlled by Volvo Cars owner Li Shufu, reported a 43% drop in first-half profit due to the coronavirus pandemic. Net income was 2.3 billion yuan, and revenue plunged 23% as car deliveries sank. The company cut its annual sales target to 1.32 million vehicles. With the pandemic receding in China, sales have started to recover, and Geely is betting on the world's largest market to help return to growth. A merger between Geely Auto and Volvo Cars is also planned, creating a potential global carmaker.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks slip as economy shrinks at record rate on pandemic hit
summary: Japan's stocks fell 0.83% to 23,096.75, their largest drop in over two weeks, after data showed the country's economy shrank at a record pace in the second quarter due to the pandemic. Investors locked in profits as the economy slowly emerges from lockdowns, with industrial and healthcare stocks pulling down the Nikkei 225 Index. The decline was not affected by a report that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has entered hospital for an examination.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start with gains on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.12% to 25,212.28. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.41% to 3,373.90, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.30%. The gains came despite China-US trade talks being postponed and US lawmakers struggling to agree on a new stimulus package, which has investors remaining cautious.

site_title: Australia's Lynas posts annual loss, to raise capital to build local facility
summary: Australia's Lynas Corp Ltd posted a smaller-than-expected annual loss of A$19.4 million due to halted operations at its Malaysian plant during the Covid-19 pandemic. To mitigate global economic uncertainties, Lynas plans to raise A$425 million to build a local facility in Kalgoorlie, Western Australia, processing low-level radioactive material. The project has received strong support from local and national governments.

site_title: Selfridges jumps into clothing rental to seek younger shoppers
summary: Selfridges is launching a clothing rental service in partnership with HURR, offering 100 items from 40 brands for up to 20 days at a time. The move aims to attract younger, eco-conscious customers amid growing demand for renting and buying secondhand items. Selfridges also plans to sell vintage clothing and accept used accessories for credit, building on its existing secondhand clothing concession. The initiative is part of the retailer's efforts to reduce its environmental impact, with a goal to become carbon-neutral by 2050.

images.alt_text: Selfridges & Co is offering fashion items for rent in a bid to attract younger and ecologically minded customers at a challenging time for UK retail.

site_title: Thousands of South Korea church members quarantined over virus
summary: South Korea has quarantined thousands of Protestant church members in Seoul after a surge in new cases linked to the Sarang Jeil Church, which has reported over 315 cases, with around 3,400 members asked to quarantine. The country's "trace, test and treat" approach has been criticized due to inaccuracies in the church's member list, making testing and isolation procedures challenging. The church's leader, Jun Kwang Hun, and the Shincheonji Church's leader, Lee Man Hee, have been accused of hindering epidemic control efforts and are facing police complaints.

images.alt_text: Thousands of Protestant church members in Seoul have been asked to quarantine, South Korean authorities said on Monday, as the country battles virus clusters linked to religious groups.

site_title: China Evergrande shares slump as virus, discounts slash Profit
summary: China Evergrande Group shares plummeted 13% in early Hong Kong trading, the largest intraday decline since March, due to a 46% drop in net income to 14.7 billion yuan (S$2.88 billion) for the six months ended June 30. The decline was attributed to the coronavirus pandemic, discounting to kickstart apartment sales, increased marketing expenses, foreign exchange losses, and the company's venture into electric cars. This profit warning follows the developer's pledge to reduce its total debt load by half in three years, which has been met with skepticism.

site_title: Thai Q2 GDP shrinks 12.2% y-o-y, weakest in 22 years
summary: Thailand's economy contracted 12.2% in the second quarter, the weakest in 22 years, due to the coronavirus outbreak. This is lower than the 13.3% decline forecast. On a quarterly basis, the economy shrank 9.7% in the June quarter, the deepest pace on record. The National Economic and Social Development Council cut its GDP forecast for 2020 to a 7.3-7.8% contraction, down from a previous 5-6% projection.

site_title: Hot stock: ThaiBev up 5.8% on resilient spirits business; RHB upgrades it to 'buy'
summary: Thai Beverage Public Company (ThaiBev) shares rose 5.8% on Monday after the beverage giant reported resilient revenue and Ebitda despite the coronavirus pandemic. The company's implied Q3 revenue and Ebitda were above expectations, driven by the spirits segment, which saw a 4.9% Ebitda growth. Analysts upgraded the stock to "buy" with a target price of 72-90 cents, citing the company's ability to control costs and maintain resilient spirits sales.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop as Victoria records highest Covid-19 daily death toll
summary: Australian shares dropped 0.9% on Monday, the largest intraday percentage decline since August 5, amid Victoria's deadliest day of the Covid-19 pandemic, with 25 fatalities and 282 new infections. Financial stocks led the retreat, with the "Big Four" banks losing between 1.1% and 2.3%. Technology stocks also fell 1.1%, while New Zealand's benchmark index rose 1.1% despite a lockdown in Auckland.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares drop as GDP shows record quarterly fall
summary: Tokyo shares dropped on Monday following the release of Japan's GDP data, which showed a record quarterly contraction of 7.8%. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.33% to 23,212.38, while the Topix index eased 0.11% to 1,621.62. The economic contraction is the largest on record, indicating a significant impact from the pandemic and ongoing economic uncertainty.

site_title: Cattle slaughter in beef exporter Uruguay to hit 17-year low
summary: Uruguay's cattle slaughter is expected to hit a 17-year low due to a shrinking herd and drop in exports. According to Eduardo Urgal, director at Ontilcor SA, the country's meatpacking plant, Uruguay could slaughter 1.9 million head, a 15% decrease from last year. This decline is attributed to ranchers shipping more cattle to Middle Eastern abattoirs and China's insatiable demand for beef, which led to a steady slaughter rate over the years.

site_title: Bain's revival of Virgin Australia faces growing legal obstacle
summary: Bain Capital's planned takeover of Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd is facing growing legal opposition from bondholders who want to derail the deal and rescue the airline themselves. UBS Group AG and other creditors are supporting a plan to muscle out Bain, which had planned to cut a third of the workforce and scale back the fleet. Virgin Australia filed for bankruptcy in April with A$6.8 billion in debt, and the court filings reveal that creditors are seeking to recover more of their debt than Bain's proposed deal. This development may threaten Bain's revival plans.

site_title: CCCS clears Alstom's proposed acquisition of Bombardier's train business
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has cleared the proposed acquisition of Bombardier's train business by French transport infrastructure company Alstom, valued at around $7 billion. Following public feedback, the CCCS concluded that the deal will not infringe the Competition Act, citing the Land Transport Authority of Singapore's significant bargaining power and barriers to entry in the industry. Alstom will continue to supply railway vehicles and signalling systems to Singapore, with no substantial lessening of competition expected.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed with eyes on China-US tensions, stimulus
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday as investors weighed ongoing China-US tensions and a struggle to pass a new stimulus. Despite a postponed trade review talk between the US and China, Donald Trump continued to warn against Beijing, potentially targeting Chinese tech firms. The US president also issued an executive order requiring ByteDance to sell its Musical.ly interest. Markets remained largely unaffected, with stocks continuing a 5-day rally in Singapore and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records in the US.

site_title: British home sales hit record after lockdown, Rightmove says
summary: British home sales reached a record high between mid-July and early August, with transactions 20% higher than the previous record, according to Rightmove data. The surge in demand was driven by pent-up demand from the coronavirus lockdown and a desire to leave London, with average asking prices 4.6% higher than last year. The UK's housing market rebounded after the Bank of England's announcement of a tax break on moving home, with only London's commuter belt seeing a typical 2% monthly fall in asking prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.39 points, or 0.09%, to 1,563.20. Volume was 396.59 million lots worth RM176.94 million. The market saw a slight edge in gains, with 282 stocks gaining compared to 130 losers.

site_title: German watchdog launches Amazon investigation: report
summary: Germany's anti-trust authority has launched an investigation into Amazon's relationship with third-party traders selling on its site, according to President of the Federal Cartel Office Andreas Mundt. The investigation focuses on whether Amazon influences how traders set prices on the marketplace. This probe is Germany's second major antitrust action against Amazon, following a 2019 investigation into its dominance in the German e-book market.

site_title: Football: Newcastle United in takeover talks with Singapore investors
summary: Newcastle United, an English Premier League club, is in talks with the Singapore-backed Bellagraph Nova Group over a possible takeover bid. The group, co-founded by Nelson Loh and Terence Loh, has provided a letter of intent and proof of funds, and is willing to "massively contribute" to the club's development. The talks come after a previous takeover bid by a Saudi Arabian-backed consortium collapsed last month due to concerns over human rights and pirate broadcasts of Premier League games. Negotiations are at an advanced stage, with England captain Alan Shearer and former player Michael Chopra enlisted to facilitate the engagement.

site_title: Australian watchdog urges action on local gas prices
summary: Australia's competition watchdog urges the government to step up pressure on gas producers to close the 50% price gap between local users and export customers. The ACCC says domestic gas prices are around $8-$11 per gigajoule, significantly higher than the $6/GJ netback price for liquefied natural gas (LNG) exports. The regulator is concerned this will impact Australia's industrial sector during a difficult economic period, and is calling for the government to extend a supply agreement that expires this year, including price commitments.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Monday's open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% or 1.46 points to 2,582.78 on Monday, driven by gains in Thai Beverage Public Company and Medtecs International. Non-oil domestic exports in July rose 6% year-over-year, slower than June's 13.9% expansion. Investors await details on pandemic support to be announced by Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat.

site_title: Hundreds protest in Madrid against virus restrictions
summary: Hundreds of people in Madrid protested against virus restrictions, including mandatory facemasks and social distancing measures, in a rally calling for "freedom" and questioning the existence of the virus. Attendees held homemade placards with slogans like "Masks kill" and "We are not afraid." Some cited a documentary with false claims about the virus, and many protesters did not wear masks despite the law requiring them. The protest comes after the government announced new restrictions to curb the spread of the virus.

site_title: Google slams Australia law forcing tech giants to pay for news
summary: Google is opposing Australia's plan to force tech giants like itself and Facebook to pay for news content. The plan, which includes fines and transparency around algorithms, was announced after 18 months of negotiations. Google claims the law would put users' search data at risk and artificially inflate news media companies' rankings. The technology giant argues it already partners with Australian news media and pays them millions, but the law would give big media companies special treatment and unreasonable demands. The legislation is expected to be introduced this year.

site_title: A fifth billionaire emerges from Malaysia's glove-making industry
summary: Malaysia's glove-making industry, which has driven the country's economy and created vast fortunes, is experiencing a rapid decline. The industry's value has surged in the past year, but shares have plummeted after Russia's president announced his nation had cleared the world's first Covid-19 vaccine, reducing demand for protective products. Wong Teek Son, a billionaire co-founder of Riverstone Holdings, has seen his net worth rise to $1.2 billion, but the company's shares have slumped 13% in the worst week since March. The decline highlights the industry's vulnerability to the development of a vaccine.

site_title: Singapore Reinsurance proposes sale of its 85% stake in publishing unit for S$1.3m
summary: Singapore Reinsurance Corporation proposes the sale of its 85% stake in INS Communications, a publishing unit, for S$1.3 million in cash. The sale includes the US's oldest continually published insurance medium, Insurance Advocate, and one of the oldest insurance magazines worldwide. The consideration exceeds INS's book value by S$868,700. The sale is expected to raise Singapore Reinsurance's profit per share from 1.45 cents to 1.61 cents, benefiting the group's continued development and focusing on core operations.

site_title: GIC, Charter Hall buy stake in Australian convenience-store property trust from Ampol
summary: Australian convenience-store property trust Ampol Ltd will sell a 49% stake to GIC and Charter Hall Group for A$682 million. The deal values the trust at A$1.4 billion, with Ampol retaining a 51% stake and control. The trust, which owns 203 convenience retail sites, will receive A$77 million in rental payments in the first year. Ampol plans to use the deal's net proceeds to reduce debt amid COVID-19 uncertainty.

site_title: China releases video of HK garrison in South China Sea drill
summary: China has released footage of its Hong Kong garrison conducting a drill in the South China Sea, showcasing cannons and torpedoes firing and helicopter operations. The exercise, which included anti-terrorism and rescue training, follows the deployment of a US Navy carrier strike group in the area. The move aims to demonstrate the PLA's capabilities and comes amid rising tensions between Beijing and Washington over Hong Kong's status. The drill highlights China's military presence in the region, sparking concerns about regional security.

site_title: Hyundai Motor to make electric cars in Singapore: ST
summary: Hyundai Motor plans to manufacture electric vehicles in Singapore starting in 2022, with 30,000 units produced annually. The 28,000 square meter factory will primarily produce electric cars, with 6,000 set to be sold in Singapore. Construction began in October after being delayed due to the coronavirus outbreak. This marks Hyundai's entry into electric vehicle production in Singapore, following a US$2.5 billion electric car project by Dyson Ltd that was abandoned earlier this year.

site_title: Singtel Q1 earnings fall 24.2% on 'intense' competition, travel restrictions
summary: Singtel's Q1 earnings fell 24.2% due to intense competition, travel restrictions, and a global economic slowdown. Group revenue declined 13.9% to S$3.54 billion, with operating revenue in Singapore and Australia segments also dropping. The telco's enterprise and digital life segments experienced declines, while Amobee's revenue was impacted by reduced advertising spend. Singtel shares fell 1.2% to S$2.41.

site_title: Japan shouldn't ignore TikTok's possible data risks, says LDP's tax panel chief
summary: Japan's ruling party official, Akira Amari, warns that the country should not ignore potential data security risks posed by Chinese music video app TikTok, citing concerns from other countries including the US, UK, and India. Amari states that partnerships with Chinese firms could lead to data leaks, compromising Japan's position in the global supply chain and undermining its values of freedom, democracy, and the rule of law. The LDP is set to probe the risks associated with Chinese-developed apps, amid growing national security concerns.

site_title: Championing the spirit of entrepreneurial resilience
summary: Singapore's Enterprise 50 Awards highlights local businesses' resilience amidst the global pandemic. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are diversifying offerings and reimagining business models to serve their communities. Examples include food delivery services and online education classes. The awards serve as a reminder for businesses to prioritize innovation as a growth strategy, despite economic headwinds.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports up 6% in July
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 6% in July, exceeding the 3.6% consensus forecast, driven mainly by strong shipments of non-monetary gold. Electronics and non-electronics exports also grew, with non-electronic NODX rising 6.9%. However, pharmaceuticals export growth slowed, and total trade fell 8.9% year on year, while total imports rose 4.8%. Despite this, economists remain optimistic about Singapore's NODX outlook, citing resilient demand for electronics and pharmaceuticals.

site_title: Japan's economy shrinks at record pace as pandemic hits spending
summary: Japan's economy shrank at a record pace of 27.8% in the second quarter, driven by the coronavirus pandemic's impact on spending. Private consumption fell 8.2% and capital expenditure declined 1.5%. The economy is emerging from lockdowns but a resurgence in infections clouds the outlook for business and household spending. Policymakers are under pressure for bolder action to prevent a deepening recession. This marks the third straight quarter of contraction, the biggest decline since comparable data became available in 1980.

site_title: Jamie Salter builds empire from washed-up retailers
summary: Jamie Salter's Authentic Brands Group has acquired or explored deals for several well-known American retailers, including Forever 21, Lucky Brand, and Brooks Brothers. The company's portfolio now has retail revenue estimated at nearly $15 billion, and Salter expects it to rise by 50% this year. Authentic's strategy is to compile a portfolio of brands that appeals to all shoppers, with a focus on traditional retail and e-commerce. The company has teamed up with mall operators to manage risk and create a portfolio effect, which benefits both Authentic and the landlords.

site_title: French new coronavirus cases above 3,000 for second day
summary: France's health ministry reported 3,015 new coronavirus cases for the second consecutive day, surpassing 3,000 for the first time since July 4. The daily count is below Saturday's post-lockdown high of 3,310 cases. Authorities have expanded mask mandates in Paris and Marseille, and the UK has imposed a 14-day quarantine for people arriving from France. The country's cumulative death toll from Covid-19 has risen to 30,410, with 4,860 people in hospital and 376 in intensive care.

site_title: New Zealand PM delays election by four weeks amid virus outbreak
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has delayed the country's election by four weeks to October 17 due to a renewed coronavirus outbreak. The outbreak, which forced Auckland into lockdown, also halted 102 days of community transmission. The delay allows for more time for campaigning and ensures the Electoral Commission can proceed with the election. The original election date was set for September 19.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern on Monday delayed New Zealand's looming election by four weeks to October 17 after a renewed coronavirus outbreak hampered campaigning.

site_title: Seize the moves with Reit Index Futures
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is launching two futures contracts: the SGX FTSE EPRA Nareit Asia ex Japan Index Futures and the SGX iEdge S-Reit Leaders Index Futures. These contracts, designed according to Commodity Futures Trading Commission guidelines, allow for broad distribution to US and global institutional investors. They provide exposure to Reit securities listed in Singapore, Hong Kong, Malaysia, and Thailand, with the iEdge S-Reit Leaders Index featuring five heavyweight Reits that have delivered defensive performance. The futures market is aimed at sophisticated investors and those qualified to trade Specified Investment Products.

site_title: British trade minister pledges to fight 'unfair' US tariffs: The Telegraph
summary: British Trade Secretary Liz Truss has pledged to fight US tariffs on Scotch whisky, calling them "unacceptable and unfair". The 15% tariff on Airbus aircraft and 25% tariff on other European goods is part of a long-running trade dispute. Truss will meet with her US counterpart, Robert Lighthizer, to address existing tariffs on single malt Scotch and other products. She also reaffirmed the UK's goal to clinch a trade agreement with Japan by the end of the year.

site_title: UK dines out on government-backed restaurant scheme
summary: The UK government's "Eat Out to Help Out" scheme, which offers 50% off meals up to £10 per person, has boosted restaurant sales by over a quarter year-on-year despite the pandemic. A study by the Centre for Economics and Business Research found that the scheme increased diner numbers. The scheme, which ran from Monday to Wednesday in August, was a success in encouraging people to dine out, helping to revitalize a sector devastated by the coronavirus.

site_title: Mall landlord URW mulling over 3b-euro share offer
summary: Unibail-Rodamco-Westfield, a major mall landlord, is considering a 3 billion-euro (S$4.87 billion) share offering to raise capital amid the pandemic's impact on the retail industry. The company, which operates Westfield shopping centers in Europe and the US, has seen a 10.6% decline in European rental income in the first half. This move comes as competitors, such as Intu Properties and Hammerson Plc, also face financial challenges. The deliberations are at an early stage, and there's no certainty a deal will be reached.

site_title: Appointment of Norway wealth fund CEO triggers controversy
summary: Norway's $1.1 trillion wealth fund has faced criticism over the appointment of its new CEO, Tan Teck Long, who has ties to tax havens and personal wealth that could create conflicts of interest. The fund's watchdog stated that these risks were not fully eliminated. The move has reignited debate over who controls the world's largest sovereign investor, with the Labor party opposing the appointment. The controversy highlights concerns about the fund's governance and oversight.

site_title: UAE-Israel phone lines open after accord to normalise ties
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) and Israel have established telephone lines, marking a significant step in normalizing their ties after a US-sponsored agreement announced on Thursday. The foreign ministers of both countries spoke by phone, agreeing to meet soon and sign bilateral agreements on investment, tourism, and direct flights. The UAE has also unblocked calls to Israel's country code, and the first business deal was signed on Saturday, including a Covid-19 research and development partnership. Reciprocal visas are expected to be agreed upon in the coming weeks.

site_title: Asia's contribution at UBS primed to cross 30% of global earnings
summary: UBS is targeting Asia to account for over 30% of its global earnings, with the region aiming to close the current financial year on an all-time record. Asia's wealth franchise achieved a strong first-half showing, driven by a 71% year-on-year profit before tax increase to a record US$233 million. The bank's invested assets under management (AUM) rose to US$449 billion, and it expects to maintain its earnings momentum in the second half, with some 60% of its full-year earnings typically made in H1.
