UBS remains risk-on in Asia, seeing opportunities in sectors such as technology, healthcare, and e-commerce.

site_title: US convention season set to begin, with spotlight on Biden
summary: US Democrats open their virtual convention, united behind Joe Biden's bid to defeat Donald Trump in November's election. The four-day convention, originally planned for Milwaukee, takes place amid controversy over Trump's mail-in voting efforts. Keynote speaker Bernie Sanders emphasized the importance of defeating Trump. The convention's online format comes amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The Democratic party's unity is seen as a contrast to the divisions within the party during the 2020 primary.

site_title: Citi's US$900m 'clerical error' raises stakes in Revlon showdown
summary: Citi wired nearly $900 million to lenders of troubled cosmetics giant Revlon, citing a "clerical error", sparking a battle between Revlon and creditors. The mistake plunged Citigroup into a dispute with Revlon's lenders, who claim the company was in default and are seeking a court order to return collateral. The lenders, including Brigade Capital Management, are refusing to return the funds, which could impact Revlon's turnaround strategy and financial stability.

site_title: Trump campaign makes huge digital ad buy during Democratic convention
summary: The Trump campaign is launching a massive digital ad campaign during the Democratic National Convention, taking over YouTube's banner for 96 hours and blanketing the home pages of major news sites, including The Wall Street Journal, The Washington Post, and FoxNews.com. The campaign is expected to cost "high-seven figures," potentially exceeding $10 million, and will feature premium, unskippable ads on Hulu and other platforms. The move is seen as an attempt to dominate online conversations during the convention, with the Trump campaign touting its ability to reach a large audience.

site_title: Thousands stage Thailand's anti-government protest in Bangkok
summary: Thousands of protesters, mostly students, gathered in Bangkok, Thailand, on Sunday, demanding democratic reforms and calling for the overthrow of the military-aligned government. The protest, which drew at least 10,000 people, is part of a growing pro-democracy movement that has been inspired by the Hong Kong democracy movement. The protesters are seeking major reforms, including a rewriting of the constitution and the abolition of a law protecting the monarchy. The government has responded to the protests with arrests and warnings, but the movement shows no signs of slowing down.

site_title: Unemployment insurance: why it's elusive
summary: Singapore's government is considering introducing unemployment insurance amid rising job uncertainty, but private insurers are hesitant due to risks such as anti- or self-selection behavior, lack of reliable data, and discouraging return to work. The proposed scheme could be unsustainable as a business proposition, and the government may need to consider alternative options, such as the Central Provident Fund (CPF), which could offer a compulsory, mandatory scheme. Insurers warn that the product would require a system of differential pricing and a reliable database of claims experience, and may face moral hazard concerns.

site_title: Event firms find digital capabilities crucial for business in new normal
summary: Event firms pivot towards digital capabilities, expecting "hybrid" events with a mix of physical and online elements. Organisers must provide online interaction channels, translation services, and more to cater to attendees joining virtually from around the world. Digital events are increasingly incorporating features such as convention booths, simultaneous translation, recordings, and interactive tools. Companies like Informa Markets, GlobalSign.in, and SingEx Exhibitions are investing in technology solutions to host successful digital and hybrid events, aiming to create a seamless experience for attendees and exhibitors alike.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust posts US$38.9m Q2 loss
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has reported a Q2 loss of US$38.9 million due to impairment losses on trade receivables and rental payments. Revenue fell 34.4% to US$15.7 million, and net property income declined 31.6% to US$13.9 million. The trust's earnings were wiped out by an impairment loss of US$26.3 million. As of June 30, the net asset value per stapled security was US$0.81.

site_title: US dollar slides, posts worst weekly run of losses in a decade
summary: The US dollar experienced its worst weekly run of losses in a decade, falling for eight consecutive weeks due to the US economy's struggles to manage the COVID-19 pandemic. The delay in stimulus relief and higher coronavirus case counts in the US led to slower economic growth expectations. Despite a 1.2% rise in retail sales, the dollar was unmoved. The euro continued its rise, while the New Zealand dollar saw its worst weekly fall since mid-June. The dollar's losses against other currencies, such as the yen, were offset by a 0.3% gain.

site_title: Covid-19 should flush out zombie performance from pre-crisis times
summary: Singapore corporates face increased leverage risk, with debt-to-GDP ratio reaching 157% in Q2 2019, primarily from the property and commerce sectors. This structural weakness has been exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, with consumer-facing sectors and oil-related firms particularly affected. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's annual review highlights concerns over high-risk companies, including SMEs, and the potential for a "cliff effect" when relief measures unwind. Experts warn that some companies may need to be "stirred out" of their debt-driven lull in innovation and efficiency, and that Singapore's economy may need to adapt to a post-COVID reality.

site_title: 'Fortnite' app removal threatens social lifeline for young gamers
summary: Fortnite has been removed from Apple's Store and Google Play store due to a dispute over in-app payment guidelines, threatening the social lifeline for young gamers worldwide. The game, popular among kids aged 8-14, has become a vital outlet for social interaction during the coronavirus pandemic. Epic Games, Fortnite's owner, has challenged Apple's policy, and the move has sparked a heated debate on social media. The game will continue to function for existing players, but new downloads are no longer possible.

site_title: Responsible retrenchment
summary: Business leaders and unions emphasize the importance of treating retrenched workers with dignity and fairness. Retrenchment should be the last resort, with companies exhausting all other measures such as salary cuts and job redeployment. Employers should communicate transparently, provide adequate compensation and support, and work with unions to help affected employees find new jobs. The goal is to minimize the impact on the remaining workforce and maintain goodwill, while also ensuring the company's ongoing quest for talent.

site_title: First major cruise line set to depart Genoa for Mediterranean
summary: The MSC Grandiosa, a major cruise ship, is set to depart from Genoa, Italy, marking the first major cruise ship to sail in the Mediterranean since the COVID-19 pandemic. The ship's departure represents a high-stakes test for the global cruise industry, which hopes to regain ground after a prolonged hiatus. New, tighter protocols are in place to control the lingering threat of COVID-19, and the Mediterranean market is a key focus for the industry. The successful launch of this voyage could signal a return to normalcy for the travel sector.

site_title: First major Mediterranean cruise liner sets sail since pandemic
summary: The first major Mediterranean cruise liner, MSC Grandiosa, set sail from Genoa, Italy on August 16, 2020, marking a significant step for the cruise industry after the pandemic. The ship, carrying approximately 2,500 passengers, departed with tightened protocols to control the spread of coronavirus. The industry faces a high-stakes test to regain ground after a bruising hiatus, with Italy's economy heavily reliant on the cruise sector. The successful launch is seen as a "tangible sign of comeback" for the city of Genoa, which had over 2 million cruise passengers last year.

images.alt_text: The departure of the MSC Grandiosa from the northwestern port city shortly after 17.30 GMT represents a high-stakes test for the global cruise sector.

site_title: Money FM: Podcasts of the week (Aug 17)
summary: Singapore-Malaysia border set to reopen, marking a significant development for businesses. The reopening aims to boost trade and economic growth between the two countries. The reopening is part of a broader effort to strengthen bilateral relations. Experts weigh in on the implications, citing a potential tech war, geopolitical tensions, and a capital war. The move is seen as a positive step for businesses, but its impact on the economy remains to be seen.

site_title: DBS to train staff in artificial intelligence, machine learning via Amazon tie-up
summary: DBS Bank has partnered with Amazon Web Services to equip 3,000 employees with artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) skills by the end of the year. The program, called DBS x AWS DeepRacer League, uses gamified learning to teach employees the basics of AI and ML through hands-on online tutorials. Employees will then program their own autonomous model race cars and compete with each other in a virtual racing environment. This initiative aims to accelerate the use of AI and ML across DBS's business and is part of the bank's drive to ingrain digital learning behaviors among its workforce.

site_title: Cautious Hollywood edges back to work
summary: Veteran actor Gregg Daniel completed filming a movie in Los Angeles, one of the few productions to resume since Governor Gavin Newsom gave the green light in June. Despite health fears and a second wave of coronavirus cases, the production followed strict safety protocols, including testing, social distancing, and sanitation stations. However, the main hold-up for movie studios is talks between employers and unions to agree on industry-wide safety protocols, including daily testing for actors performing high-risk scenes. A deal is expected by next month, but coronavirus insurance remains a major concern.

site_title: Can Wall Street keep booming during a Main Street bust?
summary: US stocks rose last week, nearing new record highs despite a deep recession and over 200,000 COVID-19 deaths. Earnings from major retailers and stimulus negotiations this week will determine the S&P 500's next move. The market's performance is puzzling, with the S&P 500 nearly doubling since its last record high six months ago, while the economy struggles. Analysts like Ryan Detrick attribute the disparity to market momentum, leaving many bears questioning how the market's "reality" has diverged from the "economic reality".

site_title: China should guard against shadow lending rebound: banking regulator
summary: China's banking regulator, Guo Shuqing, warns that the country must guard against a rebound in off-balance sheet lending, known as shadow banking, amid a weakening economy. The regulator fears that high-risk banks with complex structures may stage a comeback, and that a slight relaxation of regulations could lead to a full resurgence. Guo also warns that leverage is expected to rebound significantly and bad debts of financial institutions may rise substantially due to the coronavirus epidemic. Financial institutions should dispose of non-performing assets as early as possible to avoid serious consequences.

site_title: Deep relationships are supporting Boustead's order book amid pandemic
summary: Boustead Singapore, a conglomerate, has maintained a strong order book despite the COVID-19 pandemic, driven by its long-established relationships with clients and a growing geospatial division. The company's order book backlog exceeds S$775 million, and its healthcare division has seen revenue increase 54% year-over-year to S$726.6 million. However, the pandemic has disrupted the energy and real estate businesses, with oil prices crashing and construction work halted. Boustead's chairman and CEO, Wong Fong Fui, is confident in the company's resilience and ability to ride out the crisis, citing its sizeable order book and net cash position.

site_title: China's CATL is developing new EV battery with no nickel, cobalt
summary: China's Contemporary Amperex Technology Co Ltd (CATL), a major electric vehicle (EV) battery supplier, is developing a new EV battery with no nickel or cobalt, a key ingredient in current batteries. This move aims to reduce costs and address concerns about the environmental impact of cobalt mining. CATL's new battery type will be different from existing types and will be integrated into an EV's frame to extend its driving range. The company's move is seen as a response to Tesla's boss Elon Musk's warning about the high cost of batteries being a hurdle to the company's growth.

site_title: Temasek is right to abandon Keppel for deal with Sembcorp
summary: Temasek Holdings has withdrawn its partial offer for Keppel Corp, citing a "material adverse change" (MAC) in the company's financial situation. The decision comes after Keppel's poor H1 2020 financial results, which included a net loss of S$537 million. In contrast, Temasek has backed out of a deal to recapitalize Sembcorp Marine (SCM) and demerge it from Sembcorp Industries (SCI), opting for a more attractive 5-for-1 rights issue that will give Temasek a significant stake in SCI. Keppel's share price has fallen 10.7% since the decision, while SCI's share price has risen 24.8% since the recapitalization announcement.

site_title: Ship that oozed oil off Mauritius coast splits in 2
summary: A Japanese bulk carrier, MV Wakashio, that leaked over 1,000 tonnes of oil off Mauritius' coast has split in two, with nearly all oil pumped off and 90 tonnes remaining. Salvage teams plan to pull the front two-thirds of the ship out to sea and let it sink, while the remaining portion remains stuck on the reef. Mauritius has declared an environmental emergency and vowed to seek compensation from the ship's owner and insurer. The government has faced criticism for its response, and Japan and France are contributing to the relief effort, with environmental experts and cleanup teams deployed to the island.

site_title: Amazon considers relocating some staff out of Seattle
summary: Amazon is considering relocating some staff out of Seattle due to the Covid-19 outbreak and a new local employers tax. The company is offering Seattle-based employees a choice of smaller offices in nearby communities, including Tacoma and Redmond, Washington. In a message to employees, Amazon asked which communities they would prefer, but declined to comment on the matter. This move suggests Amazon is looking for alternatives to its hometown due to increasing costs.

site_title: Hamilton takes dominant win in Spain
summary: Lewis Hamilton won the Spanish Grand Prix for the fourth consecutive year, securing his 88th career victory and 156th podium finish. He stretched his championship lead to 37 points, surpassing Michael Schumacher's record of 91 wins. Max Verstappen finished second, with Valtteri Bottas taking third place and the fastest lap.

site_title: Golfers show their charitable side
summary: Singapore's junior golfers joined forces to raise funds for those affected by Covid-19. The charity event, organized by the country's golfing community, saw an average collection of S$250,000 from each of the 1,000 charity events held annually, totaling S$250 million in annual returns to various charities. This initiative is part of the long-standing tradition of golf and charity in Singapore, where golfers have consistently supported various causes through charity events.

site_title: US suburbs can woo city people by being more city-like
summary: US suburbs are facing an opportunity to attract city dwellers by offering more dense, diverse, and affordable housing. As big cities struggle with the pandemic, suburbs can capitalize on the trend of remote work and increasing crime rates in urban areas. Suburbs can also benefit from the rise of social technologies making suburban life more enjoyable. To succeed, suburbs will need to adapt and become more city-like, with a focus on building affordable and diverse housing options.

site_title: Safety requirements, new metrics to shape post-pandemic events landscape
summary: Singapore is set to resume business events with a new framework that incorporates safety measures, including hybrid events with digital and physical components. The framework, developed by the Singapore Tourism Board, outlines five key outcomes for safe event management. Industry experts predict increased costs, reduced revenue, and a shift towards virtual events. To measure success, event organizers will focus on engagement metrics, such as attendee interactions and data collection, rather than attendance figures. The shift towards digital events may also lead to increased competition and potential loss of market share for Singapore as a top meeting city in Asia-Pacific.

site_title: Citi's US$900m blunder raises stakes in Revlon showdown
summary: Citi wired nearly $900 million to lenders of troubled cosmetics giant Revlon in error, sparking a battle between the Perelman empire and impatient creditors. The mistake has plunged Citigroup into a dispute with hedge funds that claim Revlon was in default on the loan, with several funds refusing to return the funds. The incident has raised questions about how the error occurred and has set tongues wagging in financial markets.

site_title: SMEs in events industry face tough road ahead
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the events industry face a tough road ahead, as the Jobs Support Scheme measures come to an end in August. The scheme, which provided financial support, will no longer be in place after June. Event organizers and venue operators will continue to receive 75% wage subsidies, while the rest of the industry will see wage co-funding reduced to 25% subsidies. This may force some SMEs to adapt or fold, as the sector continues to recover from the pandemic's impact.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hiap Seng Engineering posted a net profit of S$1.3 million in Q1, reversing a net loss of S$2.1 million a year ago due to government grants. The group blamed the Covid-19 pandemic for a 77.4% revenue fall and a 50% gross profit drop. GYP Properties expects to slide into the red for FY2020 due to an unrealised fair valuation loss on investment properties. Yinda Infocomm's controlling shareholder sold 76 million shares to raise funds, but stated it would not result in significant management changes.

site_title: Centurion's non-executive director increases interest
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1.4% from Aug 7-13, bringing its 2020 year-to-date decline to 17.1%. The iEdge S-Reit Leaders Index declined 0.4% over the same period, with its 2020 year-to-date decline at 5.9%. In share buybacks, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Fortnite battle is the new TV blackout
summary: Epic Games, the owner of Fortnite, has filed a federal lawsuit against Apple and Alphabet's Google, claiming they violated antitrust laws by removing the game from their app stores. The move comes after Epic introduced a new payment method that avoided paying Apple and Google a commission on in-app purchases. The lawsuit seeks to challenge the tech firms' rules, with Epic claiming it does not want money but rather to challenge the rules. The outcome hinges on public pressure, with Epic using a public relations campaign to paint Big Tech as greedy monopolists.

site_title: Coronavirus: Technician who boarded affected vessel among 2 new community cases
summary: A technician boarding a vessel with imported coronavirus cases was among two new community cases reported in Singapore. The technician, a 47-year-old Malaysian, tested positive after being asymptomatic. Another new case was a 48-year-old Singaporean man who was a contact of a previously confirmed case. Six new imported cases were also reported, with most arriving on August 4. Singapore's total cases reached 55,747, with 51,938 patients fully recovered.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for August 14, 2020, reveals a range-bound trading week for the tanker and dry bulk market. The capesize market remained stable, with the Atlantic basin C8 and Pacific basin C10 trading in the $18,250 to $22,250 region. Panamax and ultramax markets showed positive gains, with the timecharter average increasing to $16,415. The handysize market reached its year's peak, driven by a surge from the continent. Owners in the Middle East Gulf and East Africa saw increased enquiry and gains, while the VLCC sector remained static.

site_title: Oil companies wonder if it's worth looking for oil anymore
summary: Oil companies are reevaluating the economic viability of extracting oil, with some considering projects as "stranded assets" due to declining demand and increasing costs. The COVID-19 pandemic is expected to hasten the shift to cleaner energy, making fossil fuels less profitable. Companies like BP and Premier Oil have made significant investments in projects that may not be economically viable, such as the Sea Lion project in the Falkland Islands and the Sunrise oil sands project in Alberta. With oil prices currently around $45 a barrel, projects may require even higher prices to break even, making them increasingly unlikely to proceed.

site_title: Record price for Montreal house resale bolsters city's cachet
summary: A six-bedroom, 1924 Montreal mansion with an outdoor saltwater pool has sold for C$18 million, setting a record for the city's luxury real estate market. The sale, made during the pandemic, strengthens Montreal's appeal as a luxury destination, with home sales in the metropolitan area jumping 46% in July compared to 2019. The sale bolsters the city's cachet, marking a shift in investor interest after years of lagging behind Vancouver and Toronto, with Montreal's median family home price still relatively low at C$423,000.

site_title: Chilean honey vendor in sticky situation with Braveheart star
summary: A Chilean honey vendor, Yohanna Agurto, has been threatened with legal action for using an image of Mel Gibson from the 1995 movie Braveheart to promote her honey, Miel Gibson. Agurto's use of Gibson's name and likeness is allegedly a violation of his rights, according to his lawyers. However, Agurto's lawyers argue that she only earned enough to support her family and had no intention of profiting from the use of Gibson's image. The situation has sparked a public outcry, with Agurto's social media following increasing exponentially after she shared the letter with Chilean media.

site_title: Dubai's Arabtec reports first-half loss, seeks debt restructuring advisor
summary: Arabtec Holding, the UAE's largest listed contractor, reported a net loss of 794 million dirhams (S$296.2 million) in the first half of 2020, citing tight liquidity and limited new projects. The company is seeking a debt restructuring advisor amid the ongoing construction sector slump, exacerbated by the coronavirus pandemic and delayed Expo 2020. Total accumulated losses stand at 1.46 billion dirhams, with the group negotiating with advisory firms such as AlixPartners and Alvarez & Marsal. This marks the third restructuring exercise for Arabtec in the last four years.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit H1 DPU down 15% to 1.74 euro cents
summary: Cromwell E-Reit reported a half-year distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.74 euro cents, 15% lower than the same period last year. Excluding one-off items, DPU would have been 3.4% lower. Gross revenue was up 13.7% year-over-year, driven by recent property acquisitions, and net property income was 6.6% higher. The manager resumed investment activity, focusing on acquiring logistics properties in Germany and eyeing divestment of office assets. Cromwell E-Reit's net gearing was 34.4% as of June 30.

site_title: Will Nikkei 225 surpass 24,000?
summary: The Nikkei 225 Index has shown a strong V-shaped recovery despite economic downturns caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The index rose due to quantitative easing measures by the Bank of Japan and a possible meeting between the US and China. However, technical analysis suggests a possible higher-high after two years of corrective movement, with the index testing its psychological resistance level at 24,000 for the fourth time. A break above this level may indicate a strong bullish move, but a failure to clear the resistance zone could lead to a premature primary phase correction.

site_title: Argentina approves revised debt offer, set for SEC filing
summary: The Argentine government has formalized its revised debt offer and will submit it to the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) on August 17, aiming to bring public finances into balance. The offer, worth about $65 billion, was reached after months of talks with creditor groups, the International Monetary Fund, and other international bodies. The government aims to avoid a messy sovereign bond default, which would harm the already weak economy further. Talks with the IMF will begin after the bond revamp is completed.

site_title: Trump says looking at pressuring other Chinese companies after Bytedance
summary: US President Donald Trump said he is considering pressuring other Chinese companies, such as Alibaba, following his move to ban TikTok. Trump announced that ByteDance must divest its US operations of TikTok within 90 days. Trump has been critical of China while praising its agricultural purchases, as part of a trade agreement. The move is part of his efforts to change the US-China trade relationship.

site_title: NZ coalition partner calls for vote delay due to Covid-19
summary: New Zealand Deputy Prime Minister Winston Peters has called for a delay to the September general election due to the recent resurgence of Covid-19 in the country. With 13 new confirmed infections, Peters suggests alternative dates of October 17 or November 21. The opposition National Party also wants a delay, hoping to impact Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern's popularity. Ardern is set to decide by Monday, considering the views of party leaders and the ongoing investigation into the source of the outbreak, which Peters believes may be linked to a breach in quarantine procedures.

site_title: Mauritius braces for split of oil-oozing ship off coast
summary: A Japanese-owned oil tanker, MV Wakashio, is breaking apart off the coast of Mauritius, releasing 90 tonnes of remaining oil into pristine waters. The ship, which leaked over 1,000 tonnes of oil after striking a reef in July, is nearing complete separation. Salvage crews are racing to pump the remaining oil, with France and Japan providing assistance. Mauritius has declared an environmental emergency and deployed booms to absorb oil, with thousands of volunteers helping to clean the affected waters, which threaten the country's tourism industry.

site_title: Trump gets verified account on TikTok competitor Triller
summary: US President Donald Trump has been verified on the TikTok competitor Triller, amid the White House's disfavor towards ByteDance-owned TikTok. Trump ordered ByteDance to divest the US operations of TikTok within 90 days, following an executive order signed on August 6. This move comes as Triller has seen a surge in downloads since the executive order. The development is another sign of the administration's preference for Triller over TikTok.

site_title: UAE, Israeli companies sign agreement on coronavirus R&D
summary: The UAE's APEX National Investment company signed a strategic commercial agreement with Israel's Tera Group to cooperate on Covid-19 research and development, including a testing device. The deal, facilitated by US President Donald Trump, comes after the UAE and Israel announced a normalization of diplomatic relations. The agreement aims to strengthen research and studies on the novel coronavirus, and both countries will meet in the coming weeks to sign agreements on investment, tourism, and security. This partnership is considered a significant milestone in the growing business ties between the UAE and Israel.

site_title: Tennis: Serena falls to 116th-ranked Shelby Rogers at US Open tuneup
summary: Serena Williams suffered her first loss since 2012, falling to 116th-ranked American Shelby Rogers in a quarter-final at the Top Seed Open. Williams, ranked ninth, lost 1-6, 6-4, 7-6 (7/5) after two hours and seven minutes. This marks Williams' first defeat since her 2012 loss to Jelena Jankovic. Rogers credited her victory, saying it's every kid's dream to achieve.

site_title: Two million Californians go dark and the heat is just beginning
summary: Two million Californians experienced power outages for approximately four hours late Friday, with the California Independent System Operator declaring a Stage 3 emergency due to soaring demand from air conditioning use during a record-breaking heat wave. The outages, initiated at 6:30pm local time, affected about 750,000 homes and were the first rolling outages in the state since the 2001 energy crisis. Grid operators planned to restore power by 11pm.

site_title: What happens when AI is used to set students' grades?
summary: The International Baccalaureate Organization (IBO) used artificial intelligence (AI) to set grades for high-school graduates due to cancelled exams during the Covid-19 pandemic. However, the results were highly anomalous, with thousands of students and parents protesting the unfair grades. The IBO's appeals process was inadequate, as it only allowed for re-marking of individual student work, rather than a human-led re-evaluation of grades. A better approach would involve specifying input data for appeal panels, adjusting the AI algorithm for affected schools, and allowing for corrections to be made to all affected students at once.

site_title: Facebook bashes Apple for refusing to waive commission fees, seizing on backlash
summary: Facebook criticized Apple for refusing to waive a 30% commission fee for its new paid online events product, which would benefit small businesses. The move comes as Apple removed popular game "Fortnite" from its app store for violating guidelines, sparking a backlash. Facebook had requested the waiver to avoid charging Apple's cut for the new product, and the company expects to hear back from Apple within the next few days. The dispute highlights the ongoing competition and regulatory scrutiny between tech giants.

site_title: US Postal Service watchdog to probe service woes as worries rise about mail ballots
summary: The US Postal Service's internal watchdog is investigating cost-cutting measures that have slowed mail delivery and raised concerns about mail ballots ahead of the presidential election. The investigation focuses on new Postmaster General Louis DeJoy, who has donated to President Trump and has financial interests in rival postal companies. The Postal Service has warned states that voters may not have enough time to complete and return mail ballots, with some states pushing back deadlines. The issue has raised concerns about election security and the potential for mail ballots to go uncounted.

site_title: Seoul returns to tougher social distancing rules as virus cases spike
summary: South Korea has reimposed tougher social distancing rules in the Seoul area amid a spike in coronavirus cases, with 166 new cases reported as of Friday. The country's total cases have reached 15,039 and 305 deaths. The move comes after multiple church gatherings emerged as a source of infection. Authorities have upgraded social distancing guidelines to the second stage, limiting indoor gatherings to below 50 and outdoor gatherings to below 100, and banning spectators in sports matches. The measures aim to prevent a fresh wave of the disease.

site_title: StanChart, NTUC plan digital-only bank in Singapore
summary: Standard Chartered is planning its second digital-only bank in Asia, teaming up with NTUC Enterprise in Singapore. The London-based bank will hold a majority stake, with NTUC holding the remainder. Alex Twigg, co-founder of Judo Bank, has been hired for the venture, code-named "Project Phoenix". The partnership aims to expand digital banking services in the region.

images.alt_text: Standard Chartered is planning its second digital-only bank in Asia, teaming up with a unit of Singapore's biggest labour union.

site_title: Australian surfer punches shark to save wife
summary: An Australian surfer, identified as Mark Rapley, punched a 3-meter great white shark that had bitten his wife, injuring her right leg, near Port Macquarie, Australia. Rapley repeatedly punched the shark until it released his wife's leg, saving her life. Witnesses described him as a "hero" for his actions, while he downplayed his efforts, stating he "did what anyone would have done." The incident occurred just days after a fatal shark attack in Tasmania and marks one of Australia's highest incidences of shark attacks this year.

site_title: Alibaba's Freshippo says will test all Shenzhen employees for Covid-19
summary: Alibaba-owned supermarket chain Freshippo has shut 21 stores in Shenzhen, China, after three employees tested positive for COVID-19. The company is requiring all employees in the city to undergo nucleic acid testing. The cases were found at a store in the IBC mall, and two staff members and one brand promoter tested positive. The company will announce test results and offer free tests to anyone who visited the store from July 24. This comes as China reported 22 new COVID-19 cases on August 14, with 14 imported cases.

site_title: New Zealand Covid-19 outbreak grows, Australia still struggles
summary: New Zealand reported seven new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 1258, with 56 active cases and 22 deaths. The Auckland lockdown was extended for nearly two weeks in response to the outbreak. In contrast, Australia's Victoria state continues to struggle with a strict six-week lockdown, recording 303 new cases and four deaths on Saturday. Despite swift lockdown measures, New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern faces pressure ahead of a general election, and Victoria's Premier Daniel Andrews urged vigilance, stating the outbreak is not over.

images.alt_text: New Zealand on Saturday reported seven new cases of the coronavirus as a lockdown in the country's biggest city, Auckland, was extended on Friday in response to the country's first coronavirus outbreak in months.

site_title: Robert Trump, president's brother who shunned the spotlight, dies
summary: US President Donald Trump's younger brother, Robert Trump, a business executive and real estate developer, died on Saturday at 71, a day after the president visited him in a New York hospital. The cause of death was not revealed. Trump announced his brother's passing in a statement, calling him his "best friend" and saying he will be "greatly missed." The president was expected to attend the funeral and has a busy travel schedule ahead, including visits to four battleground states for his re-election campaign.

site_title: Japan's Abe sends offering to war dead shrine as conflict's legacy lingers in East Asia
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe sent a ritual offering to Tokyo's Yasukuni Shrine for war dead on the 75th anniversary of Japan's World War II surrender, avoiding a personal visit that could anger China and South Korea. At least four Japanese cabinet ministers paid their respects in person, while Abe sent an offering via an aide. The move comes amid strained relations with South Korea over compensation for forced labor and the comfort women issue, with South Korean President Moon Jae-in saying Seoul is ready to discuss history disputes with Tokyo.

site_title: Trump orders ByteDance to sell TikTok's US assets within 90 days
summary: US President Donald Trump ordered ByteDance, the Chinese owner of TikTok, to sell its US assets within 90 days due to national security concerns. The decision comes after an investigation by the Committee on Foreign Investment (CFIUS), which found potential threats to US users' personal data. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that the action aims to protect US users from data exploitation. Microsoft Corp is exploring an acquisition of TikTok's US operations, potentially sparking a bidding war for the assets.

site_title: US formalises F-16 jet sale to Taiwan with China tensions high
summary: The US has formally signed an agreement to sell 66 advanced F-16 fighter jets to Taiwan, a move likely to heighten tensions between the US and China. The $62 billion sale, announced by the Pentagon, marks the first sale of advanced fighter jets to Taiwan since 1992. The move is expected to be denounced by Beijing, and delivery of the jets may take years. The sale comes amid rising tensions in the region, with China viewing Taiwan as a part of its territory.

site_title: Gold posts first weekly loss since June after big plunge
summary: Gold experienced its first weekly decline since June, falling 4.4% to $1,945.12 an ounce, as climbing real yields and profit-taking weighed on the market. The decline came after a week of big price fluctuations, with gold and silver spot prices heading for their first weekly decline since June 5. Despite the drop, gold remains up 28% this year, with forecasters predicting a new high in 2021. Uncertainty over US-China trade talks and a stalemate in US stimulus talks also contributed to the decline.

site_title: China must guard against rebound in shadow lending: regulator
summary: China's banking regulator, Guo Shuqing, warns that the country must guard against a rebound in shadow lending due to a weakening economy. As the coronavirus epidemic continues to affect businesses and individuals, authorities fear that shadow lending and illegal loans may surge. Guo advises financial institutions to dispose of non-performing assets as soon as possible, and implement targeted measures to deal with high-risk institutions. External factors, including US restrictions on Chinese companies, also pose a threat to financial security, and China should deepen international cooperation to mitigate risks.

site_title: Modi promises locally-made Covid-19 vaccine for all Indians
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced plans for a locally-made Covid-19 vaccine for all citizens, with three vaccines under trial. He also introduced the National Digital Health Mission, digitizing health records and registering doctors and health facilities. Every Indian will receive a health ID, including test results and prescriptions, and the nation aims to become a global manufacturing hub. Modi reiterated his plan to boost foreign investment and create infrastructure projects worth over $2 trillion, moving forward with "Make for World" alongside "Make in India."

site_title: Oil prices down on demand worries, growing supply
summary: Oil prices dropped on Friday due to concerns over slower-than-expected demand recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. The International Energy Agency and Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries trimmed their 2020 oil demand forecasts, while Opec and its allies are increasing output this month. Brent crude fell 16 cents to $44.80 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate fell 23 cents to $42.01 a barrel. Despite a decline in US oil and gas rigs, prices were boosted by falling inventories earlier in the week.

site_title: Turkey says France should refrain from escalating Mediterranean tensions
summary: Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu urged France to refrain from escalating tensions in the eastern Mediterranean, where Turkey is disputing Greek control of oil and gas exploration in disputed waters. France's military conducted training exercises with Greek forces in the region. Switzerland offered to mediate the dispute, which also drew attention from US President Donald Trump and French President Emmanuel Macron. The two leaders expressed concern over increased tensions between NATO allies Greece and Turkey.

site_title: Glitter of gold hides its weakness
summary: Gold's recent surge in price, from around $500 an ounce in 2006 to over $2,000, has sparked debate about its value as an investment. While gold has historically been seen as a hedge against inflation and uncertainty, its lack of reward while owned, unlike other asset classes, raises questions. Investors have fared better with stocks, such as the Nasdaq Composite Index, which has risen five-and-a-half times since 2006, and companies like Microsoft and Apple, which have seen significant share price appreciation. The article concludes that gold's value lies in its utility as an adornment, rather than as a long-term investment.

site_title: Singapore shares end week in negative territory
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index ended the week down 14.65 points or 0.56% at 2,581.32 points, as investors remained cautious amid the virus-hit economy. Big decliners included Jardine Matheson Holdings and Jardine Strategic Holdings, while Singapore Technologies Engineering and Singapore Airlines were the top performers, gaining 3.67% and 2.16% respectively. Banks also fell, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB shedding 1.63%, 0.22%, and 0.05% respectively.

site_title: OCBC, CGS-CIMB lower targets for CDL, cut earnings estimates
summary: OCBC Investment Research has lowered its fair value estimate for City Developments Ltd (CDL) to S$10.64 from S$10.74, while CGS-CIMB has cut its target price to S$10.10. OCBC maintains its "buy" call on CDL, citing attractive valuation, despite reduced earnings estimates due to the Covid-19 pandemic. CDL shares closed at S$8.42, down S$0.04 or 0.47%. The company plans to redevelop two properties and divest non-core assets to unlock value.

site_title: Bling no longer king in India as gold loses its shine
summary: India's gold market is experiencing a downturn, despite the metal's value increasing 30% this year. Coronavirus fears and lockdowns have led to a decline in sales, with many jewellers struggling to stay afloat. The country's biggest gold market, Zaveri Bazaar, remains desolate, and even the wedding season, a traditionally lucrative time for gold sales, has failed to boost spending. Gold consumption has fallen by 56% in the first half of 2020, with many Indians opting for gold-backed loans or digital gold instead. Experts predict a recovery in the market once the economy improves, but for now, consumers are cautious due to the ongoing pandemic and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Ex-FBI lawyer expected to plead guilty in review of Russia inquiry
summary: A former FBI lawyer, Kevin Clinesmith, is expected to plead guilty to falsifying a document related to the Russia investigation. Clinesmith altered an email from the CIA that investigators relied on to seek renewed court permission to wiretap former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page in 2017. Clinesmith's lawyer says he made a mistake while trying to clarify facts for a colleague. President Donald Trump has promoted the plea agreement as proof that the Russia investigation was illegitimate and politically motivated, despite prosecutors not revealing any evidence of a broader conspiracy.

site_title: Temasek buys stake worth US$3.5b in BlackRock
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singaporean state-owned investor, has acquired a 3.9% stake in BlackRock Inc worth approximately US$3.5 billion, making it the firm's fifth-largest shareholder. The investment was made in the second quarter, following PNC Financial Services Group's sale of a US$14 billion stake in BlackRock. The move has already generated dividends for Temasek, with BlackRock rising 8.4% since June 30. Temasek's portfolio value has also been trimmed, with US holdings of Alibaba Group reduced by half.

site_title: US: Stocks flat as data points to sluggish recovery
summary: US stocks ended flat on Friday, finishing a positive week, despite mixed data on retail sales and industrial production. Retail sales rose 1.2% in July, while industrial production increased 3% for the third consecutive month. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 stood near all-time highs, driven by stimulus packages. However, economists warn that a further deterioration in the health situation or lack of fiscal support could hinder the recovery, with President Trump opposing a new stimulus package.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks finished a positive week on a tepid note, ending little changed following mixed data on US retail sales and industrial production.

site_title: Green lanes for leisure travel seen helping Changi Airport regain some traffic
summary: Singapore may consider introducing reciprocal green lanes at Changi Airport for tourists from countries with similar or better Covid-19 situations, aiming to lift passenger numbers to 40% of pre-Covid levels. This arrangement would exempt leisure travelers from a 14-day quarantine. Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung proposed the idea to boost passenger numbers at Changi Airport.

site_title: Updated NWC wage guidelines likely in September
summary: The National Wages Council (NWC) in Singapore is set to reconvene in August to update its guidelines, expected to be released in September. This comes as the jobs market has softened due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with total employment falling and unemployment rising. The updated guidelines will provide timely guidance to employers, focusing on reducing non-wage costs, managing excess manpower, and minimizing retrenchments. This will be the fourth time the NWC meets twice in a year, with previous instances in 2009, 2001, and 1998.

site_title: US-China trade talks set for Saturday postponed: reports
summary: US-China trade talks have been postponed, according to US media reports. High-level talks between US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin with China's Vice-Premier Liu He were scheduled for Saturday but were cancelled. The talks were intended to assess the progress of the "Phase One" trade agreement, which aimed to increase Chinese imports of US goods. The agreement, signed in January, obligated China to import $200 billion in US products over two years, but progress has been slow due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin reportedly were scheduled to hold a video conference with China's Vice-Premier Liu He, according to the reports, including from Bloomberg, citing people familiar with the issue.

site_title: Prosecution of Lim Oon Kuin deepens Hin Leong's woes
summary: Tycoon Lim Oon Kuin, 78, founder of Singapore's Hin Leong oil trading empire, was charged with abetment of forgery for cheating and granted court bail of S$3 million. The offence carries a maximum punishment of up to 10 years and a fine. He is also facing a US$19 million claim from court-appointed managers of one of Hin Leong's debt-hit units. Lim's case is part of the group's ongoing woes, which have been exacerbated by the prosecution.

site_title: World's airports are catching Covid too
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted the world's airports, causing a decline in passenger traffic and forcing them to diversify their revenue sources. Many airports, including Singapore's Changi, have been forced to mothball terminals and delay expansion plans. To adapt, airports are exploring new ways to generate income, such as selling tax-free shopping packages, opening drive-in movie theaters, and investing in renewable energy. The International Air Transport Association predicts $100 billion in aviation industry losses by next year, with a return to pre-pandemic traffic not expected until 2024.

site_title: Between mugging and slacking at work is the 80/20 rule
summary: A Singaporean article discusses the outdated "mugging culture" of hard work and diligence, where individuals prioritize tasks over results, and instead advocates for a "mindful workforce" that focuses on the 80/20 rule, where 20% of effort yields 80% of results. This approach encourages mental diligence, learning, and adaptability, rather than mere task completion and title inflation. By shifting focus to the 20% effort required to solve complex problems, individuals can build resilience, mental agility, and effective results, ultimately preparing for a future workforce that values skills over corporate ranks.

site_title: Enbloc activity in Geylang attracting smaller developers
summary: Enbloc activity is on the rise in Singapore's Geylang district, a former red-light area, with two successful sales this year. Yuen Sing Mansion, a four-storey development, was sold for S$15.2 million, while Tivoli Lodge, an 8-storey residential development, is currently up for sale via private treaty. The sales follow the first enbloc deal in 2020, Casa Sophia, which sold for S$29 million. The success of these sales is attributed to the area's transformation into a commercial environment, with nearby developments such as Paya Lebar Quarter and the Central Business District.

site_title: US-China tech spat is less costly than tariffs
summary: The US-China tech spat is less costly than the original trade war, with officials hinting that a deal will remain in place despite China falling short of its import commitments. The Phase One pact, reached in January, aims to boost US imports by $200 billion over two years, but China has only met about half of its obligations. Markets in both countries have rallied in response, and limiting the spat to one sector is seen as a better alternative to restarting a tariff battle affecting thousands of product lines.

site_title: ST Engineering focuses on ways to ensure sustainability without government support
summary: ST Engineering, a Singapore-based conglomerate, is cutting costs to offset the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on its aerospace sector, which saw a 17% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$105 million. The company plans to streamline its business portfolios and implement cost-reduction measures, including salary cuts and layoffs, to cushion the blow of potential government subsidies ending next year. Despite a 4.4% decline in overall net profit, ST Engineering expects to receive over S$300 million in government support this year and remains hopeful for a partial recovery in demand for its products and services next year.

site_title: China's middle class is staying home. So is its money
summary: China's middle class is shifting its spending habits due to anti-Chinese sentiment abroad and a desire for domestic products. A survey of 1,600 shoppers found that 70% plan to wait at least four months to travel internationally, and 73% have delayed or cancelled international education plans. This shift is driving demand for local goods, such as food, appliances, and traditional medicine, and giving domestic brands an edge. Sales of traditional Chinese medicine, cosmetics, and household appliances have seen significant growth, while international travel and schooling have become less popular, benefiting Chinese stocks and a president who prioritizes self-sufficiency.

site_title: Indonesia president urges economic reboot, boost to healthcare
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo proposed a $187 billion 2021 budget, representing 5.5% of the GDP deficit, to reboot the country's economy amid the Covid-19 pandemic. He aims to accelerate healthcare reform, slash oil imports, and invest in infrastructure, with a focus on vaccine development and food supply chains. Economic growth is expected to rebound to 4.5-5.5% next year, surpassing government projections.

site_title: Bukalapak co-founder appointed as chairman of Telkom Indonesia's venture arm
summary: Fajrin Rasyid, co-founder of Indonesian e-commerce unicorn Bukalapak, has been appointed as chairman of Telkom Indonesia's corporate venture capital arm MDI Ventures. Rasyid will work with MDI Ventures' CEO and COO to boost Telkom's digital revenue, aiming to increase the company's digital business revenue from 10% to 90%. This move comes after Rasyid stepped down from Bukalapak's president role in June to focus on Telkom's digital business.

site_title: Singapore wins rights to host Lions Clubs convention in 2028
summary: Singapore has won the rights to host the 110th Lions Clubs International Convention in 2028, expected to attract 20,000 foreign delegates and generate S$58 million in tourism receipts. This is the first time the event will be held in Singapore, following the cancellation of the 2020 edition due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: JTC to launch Gul Circle site for tender
summary: JTC has accepted an application to put up an industrial site at 160, Gul Circle in Tuas for sale by public tender, with a committed bid price of not less than S$2 million. The site, zoned Business 2, spans 0.37 hectares and has a 20-year tenure. It will be released for sale on Aug 25 for a six-week period. The site's gross plot ratio is 1.4, suitable for heavier industrial use.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality flags unauthorised loan application, tax delinquency by sponsor
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has reported two major issues: an unauthorized Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loan application submitted on behalf of the master lessor of the Queen Mary hotel, resulting in a loan of over $2 million, and tax delinquencies by certain master lessees at three EHT properties, totaling over $1.2 million. The managers and trustee are consulting professionals to address the issues, which may impact the Reit's operations and finances.

site_title: Darco's ex-CEO says allegations undermine his contributions
summary: Former Darco Water Technologies CEO Thye Kim Meng has responded to the company's allegations that he breached his duties, calling them an attempt to undermine his contributions. He claims the company's losses and damages of US$1.6 million are unreasonable and accuses Darco of "single[ing] him out" and "tarnish[ing] his reputation." Darco's solicitors dispute Thye's claims, stating he is "disingenuous and lying" about receiving the letter of demand. Thye demanded a confirmation from the board regarding the issuance of the letter, which Darco's spokesman said the company cannot comment on due to potential litigation.

site_title: Covid-19 weighs on dividends of Asian companies
summary: The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has cast uncertainty over dividend payouts by Asian companies, with the oil and gas sector bearing the highest level of uncertainty. IHS Market has expressed low confidence that 57% of oil and gas dividends in Australia and 78% in banks will be paid out. In contrast, state-owned oil majors in China are expected to retain dividends. The financial sector in Malaysia is also expected to suspend dividends, with several companies facing suppressed net interest margins and weakened debt-servicing capacity.

site_title: Govt to 'extend and taper' Covid-19 support for firms and workers; details to come on Monday
summary: Singapore's government plans to "extend and taper" COVID-19 support for firms and workers, with details to be released on Monday. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat said the support will evolve and reduce as sectors reopen, but targeted support will be provided to hardest-hit sectors. Economists welcome the phased approach, citing concerns that abrupt cuts could jeopardize the tentative recovery. Businesses hope for extended rental relief and assistance in transforming their business models, while economists caution against scaling back support too quickly.

site_title: Gender lens equity funds: The first major test
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic and economic downturn have significantly impacted gender lens equity funds, with most declining in the first quarter. The Solactive Equileap Global Gender Equality 100 Leadership Index fell 23.9%, while the Bloomberg Gender Equality Index declined over 30%. Despite this, some funds outperformed their benchmarks, such as the RobeccoSAM Global Gender Equality Fund and the Impact Shares YWCA Women's Empowerment ETF. The current downturn presents a significant test for gender lens investing, which can help address themes like the global care economy and pay equity, particularly in countries with low AUM-weighted allocations.

site_title: Kris Wiluan steps down from KS Energy, son takes over as CEO and chairman
summary: Kris Wiluan, Indonesian tycoon facing 112 charges, has stepped down as chairman, CEO, and director of KS Energy. His son, Richard James Wiluan, 42, has taken over as chairman and CEO. The move comes after KS Energy defended Wiluan's suitability despite the charges, citing he had not breached company policies. The company faces a potential winding-up, with outstanding debts of US$230.7 million and S$10.3 million. Richard Wiluan assumes the position just as KS Energy faces a financial crisis.

site_title: Indonesia revises down 2020 GDP forecast
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati revised the country's 2020 GDP forecast to a range of 1.1% contraction to 0.2% growth, down from the previous 0.4-2.3% range due to weaker-than-expected economic activity in the second quarter, largely attributed to the coronavirus pandemic. This marks a significant downgrade from 2019's 5% expansion.

site_title: China rebound fragile as domestic demand lags
summary: China's economic rebound remains fragile as retail sales continued to fall in July, dropping 1.1% despite expectations of a 0.1% rise. The decline is attributed to massive flooding and social distancing measures, which led to a 11% decrease in spending on catering. Top-end retail sales have recovered, but overall consumer spending remains cautious. Analysts expect some aspects of demand to pick up as the virus remains under control, but substantial risks weigh on growth due to receding pent-up demand, policy easing, and rising US-China tensions.

images.alt_text: Floods which wreaked havoc mostly in the Yangtze river also weighed on retail sales and food prices.

site_title: ComfortDelGro books H1 loss of S$6m, no interim dividend declared
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore-based transport operator, reported a net loss of S$6 million for the half-year ended June 30, 2020, due to weak ridership during the pandemic. Revenue declined 20.8% to S$1.5 billion, with the public transport services business experiencing a 12.9% drop. The company also faced challenges related to supply chain and labour supply, leading to additional costs. For the first time, ComfortDelGro decided not to declare an interim dividend, citing exceptional circumstances.

site_title: Retailers launch coalition to fight counterfeits on Amazon
summary: Retailers have formed a coalition with RILA to fight counterfeits on Amazon. The Buy Safe America Coalition will support legislation requiring digital marketplaces to verify third-party merchant information. This move comes as Amazon faces scrutiny from lawmakers and the White House over the sale of counterfeit items. The coalition's goal is to increase transparency and safety for online shoppers.

site_title: Higher CPO prices to give Golden Agri a lift even as H1 net loss widens to US$156.9m
summary: Golden Agri-Resources (GAR) expects a boost in financial performance in the second half of 2020 due to a 40% increase in crude palm oil (CPO) prices since May 4. The company reported a net loss of US$156.9 million for the first half of 2020, despite a 7.1% increase in revenue to US$3.39 billion. GAR's upstream segment saw a 8.9% revenue increase, while its downstream segment saw a 7.3% increase. The company expects CPO prices to remain in the "current range" of US$650 to US$700 per tonne, supporting its financial performance.

site_title: Beware of the 'BEVI' bubble in Asia
summary: A speculative fervor has taken hold in certain sectors in Asia, particularly among retail investors, with parallels to the 1999/2000 TMT bubble. The "BEVI" bubble, concentrated on biotech, electric vehicle, and internet stocks, is characterized by unsustainable price rises and increasing concerns about risks to the market. Domestic retail investor flows, margin financing, and oversubscribed initial public offerings have fueled the rally. While some internet giants like Alibaba and Tencent may justify their recent strength, others lack network effects and may be vulnerable to a market downturn.

site_title: In defence of the new Defender
summary: The 2020 Land Rover Defender has been revamped to cater to a new audience, offering improved comfort and daily driveability while maintaining its off-road capabilities. The new model boasts a larger size, premium interior, and advanced features such as a touchscreen interface and digital instruments. The Defender 110 model tested features a 3.0-liter turbocharged engine, producing 400hp and 550Nm of torque. With its refined suspension and spacious interior, the Defender is suitable for both hardcore off-road enthusiasts and those seeking a luxurious daily driver. A range of engine options and accessories are available, making the Defender a versatile choice for various users.

site_title: Prominent Thai democracy activist arrested
summary: Thai police arrested democracy activist Parit Chiwarak, also known as "Penguin," on Friday after participating in protests calling for government reforms and a new constitution. He was charged with sedition and breaking coronavirus regulations. The arrest marks the third detention of a protester in a week, following two others released on bail. Demonstrators, inspired by the Hong Kong democracy movement, are demanding a rewrite of the military-scripted 2017 constitution and an end to a law protecting the monarchy.

site_title: Online lending startup Oriente cuts over 25% of team
summary: Oriente, an online lending startup co-founded by Skype's co-founder Geoffrey Prentice, has laid off under 100 employees in June, reducing its workforce by slightly more than a quarter. The layoffs, which started in Q4 2019, were part of a phased organization-wide exercise aimed at right-sizing the firm. The company, which operates online money-lending apps in the Philippines, Indonesia, and Vietnam, has reduced its staff to around 1,550 employees. Founders will forgo salaries for the year, and senior management will take salary cuts ranging from 30% to 50%.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust to divest data centre for S$125m
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) agreed to sell a data centre in Singapore to Equinix Singapore for S$125 million, a 23.3% premium over its development cost. The 7-storey data centre, fully leased to Equinix, contributed 2.2% to MIT's portfolio gross revenue in 2020. The sale is expected to be completed by the fourth quarter of 2020, subject to JTC Corporation approval.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed the week lower, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.19% to 25,183.01, following a positive week. Investors are concerned about a stalemate in US-Washington talks. In contrast, China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices rose 1.19% and 1.25%, respectively.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower H2 revenue and similar operating loss to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, was a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and People's Bank of China are expanding cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Reits (August 15-16, 2020)
summary: Realtor Reits reported steady performance in August 2020, with key trends emerging in the US, Singapore, and globally. US mortgage rates rose after five consecutive weeks of decline, while Singapore's prime condo market was set to face a Q3 wave of launches. In the US, Manhattan rents hit another record, and UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. Globally, New World sold China property assets after securing a loan deal, and WeWork secured new tenants at its Singapore office post-bankruptcy. These developments indicate a resilient real estate market despite challenges.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Kris Wiluan, Indonesian tycoon facing 112 charges for alleged market rigging, has resigned as chairman, CEO, and director of KS Energy. His son, Richard James Wiluan, has taken over as chairman and CEO, also assuming the role of chairman of KS Drilling. The Singapore Exchange Regulation has reported accounting irregularities in Vibrant Group's subsidiary Blackgold International Holdings, requiring consultation before appointing Blackgold management. Meanwhile, Mapletree Industrial Trust has agreed to sell a data centre to Equinix Singapore for S$125 million, a 23.3% premium over development cost.

site_title: Pressure grows on Norway's new wealth fund chief to divest hedge fund stake
summary: Norway's new wealth fund chief, Nicolai Tangen, faces pressure to divest his stake in a hedge fund, AKO Capital, before taking the job. The opposition Labour Party claims the 43% stake poses a conflict of interest, and the party's leader, Jonas Gahr Stoere, says the risks are too great. The central bank's supervisory council criticized the appointment, and the Labour Party's criticism puts pressure on the centre-right minority government. The sovereign wealth fund, worth $1.1 trillion, is vital to Norway's public finances.

site_title: Gold stages recovery after sell-off
summary: Gold prices rebounded after a two-week low, triggered by a sharp sell-off triggered by US producer prices rising higher, boosting US 10-year Treasury yields and sparking massive long liquidation. The dollar's strength further pressured gold, with the benchmark Comex contract sinking over $200 in a week to $1,874.2. Gold staged a recovery, with prices rising from the low, but the article does not provide further details on the current price or market trends.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 11.83 points lower at 1,564.59 on Friday, with 981 losers outpacing 213 gainers. The index saw a 10.456 billion lots volume worth RM 5.153 billion.

site_title: US: S&P 500 dips as retail sales growth slows
summary: US stocks declined on Friday as the S&P 500 fell 0.14% due to slower-than-expected retail sales growth in July. This added to concerns about the economic recovery without a new fiscal stimulus bill. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.24% and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.27%. The decline follows a recent rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records earlier in the week.

site_title: SoftBank commits US$1.1 billion to WeWork amid drop in membership
summary: SoftBank Group is committing an additional US$1.1 billion to WeWork amid declining membership due to the coronavirus pandemic. This investment boosts WeWork's available cash and unfunded commitments to US$4.1 billion. SoftBank's continued support for WeWork is seen as a positive sign for the co-working company. The new financing is in the form of senior secured notes.

site_title: Brokers' take: OCBC trims fair value estimate of CDL; CGS-CIMB lowers target price
summary: OCBC Investment Research has lowered its fair value estimate of City Developments Ltd (CDL) to S$10.64 from S$10.74, citing redevelopment plans. However, both OCBC and CGS-CIMB maintain "buy" and "add" calls, citing value creation from CDL's redevelopment plans. CDL shares are trading at S$8.43, down 0.4% after the downgrade.

site_title: UK quarantine moves, data knock European stocks lower
summary: European shares fell 1.2% on Friday, with travel and leisure stocks down 2.3% after the UK added countries to its quarantine list, including France, the Netherlands, and Malta. Weak global data and concerns over US-China trade talks also weighed on the market. Despite this, the Stoxx 600 recorded its second straight week of gains, driven by stimulus and optimism over a Covid-19 vaccine.

site_title: Motor racing: Mercedes make U-turn over F1 deal
summary: Mercedes team chief Toto Wolff announced the team's decision to sign the Formula One commercial agreement after initially refusing to do so. The change of heart comes after Wolff realized that unifying the teams was impossible. He cited a "blame culture" in the media and decided to move forward with a pragmatic approach. Mercedes will likely sign the agreement before the extended deadline of August 18. The deal, which binds the team to the sport for five years, was previously rejected due to dissatisfaction with certain clauses.

site_title: Refreshed plan to speed up digitalisation in logistics sector amid virus outbreak
summary: Singapore's logistics sector has been refreshed with a new digital plan, expanded to cover air-transportation support services. The plan aims to speed up digitalisation and improve supply chains amid the coronavirus pandemic. Five new solutions have been added, including supply chain analytics and distributed ledger technology, to enable real-time, data-driven decision making. The plan is expected to benefit 5,300 logistics SMEs and 86,300 workers, with 90% of companies surveyed in 2018 reporting improved manpower efficiency. The refreshed plan is part of efforts to boost the industry and support businesses in adopting digital systems.

images.alt_text: Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling (right) being shown how parcels are assigned to drivers at IM Holdings' logistics facility in Jurong on Friday.

site_title: Jimmy Lai says don't buy his stock; investors buy it anyway
summary: Jimmy Lai, media mogul and owner of Apple Daily, warned investors not to buy Next Digital's stock due to its fundamentals, but the shares still surged 42% on Friday after pro-democracy supporters bought up the company's shares as a form of protest. Lai, who was released on bail after being arrested under Hong Kong's national security law, stated that the recent buying was largely driven by supporters expressing their anger and support for the company. Despite a request from Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission to monitor trading activity, Lai ruled out issuing new shares at inflated prices and plans to keep his shares in the company.

site_title: US manufacturing output rises strongly in July, but still below pre-pandemic levels
summary: US factory output rose 3.4% in July, driven by a surge in motor vehicle production, but remains below pre-pandemic levels. The manufacturing sector accounts for 11% of the US economy, struggling due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and the Trump administration's trade war with China. Despite a 28.3% increase in motor vehicle production, capacity utilization for the manufacturing sector increased only 2.3 percentage points to 69.2% in July, indicating room for further growth before inflationary pressures rise.

site_title: Alibaba, Xiaomi to join Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index
summary: Alibaba, Xiaomi, and WuXi Biologics will join the Hang Seng Index in September, marking a significant shift towards internet companies in Hong Kong's traditionally financial services-dominated index. The change follows the Hang Seng Indexes Company's rule change in May, which allows for greater weight on secondary listings. This move reflects China's growing emphasis on internet companies as a key driver of its economy.

site_title: Towards a 'better normal' for global sports
summary: Sportfive's Asia-Pac president Adrian Staiti predicts the sports industry will bounce back stronger than ever in the post-Covid world, entering a "better normal". Despite the pandemic's disruption, the industry is adapting to create new engagement opportunities, such as branded content, archived content, and behind-the-scenes footage. E-sports has seen significant growth, with revenues expected to reach $1 billion by 2022. Staiti believes live sports will return, but with a focus on safety and comfort, potentially incorporating technology like AI and 5G to enhance the fan experience.

site_title: Halcyon Agri posts US$40.4m net loss for H1
summary: Halcyon Agri Corp, a natural rubber supplier, reported a net loss of US$40.4 million for the half-year ended June 30, 2020, widening from a loss of US$3.4 million the previous year. Revenue fell 15.5% to US$770.2 million due to weaker demand during the pandemic. Gross profit slumped 48.6% to US$33.7 million, and loss per share was 2.53 US cents. The company's factory capacity was under-utilized due to lower sales volume, resulting in higher fixed costs.

site_title: ComfortDelGro books H1 loss of S$6m, no interim dividend declared
summary: ComfortDelGro, a transport operator, reported a net loss of S$6 million for the half-year ended June 30, 2020, due to weak ridership during the pandemic. Revenue declined 20.8% to S$1.5 billion, with public transport services revenue falling 12.9%. The group did not declare an interim dividend and faced challenges including supply chain and labor supply issues. Operating costs decreased 10.8% to S$1.5 billion, but were offset by a provision for impairment on vehicles and goodwill of S$30.8 million.

site_title: The role of gold in a portfolio
summary: Gold has gained 66% in the last two years, reaching a new all-time high of $2,075 in August 2020, but has since pulled back. Historically, gold has shown significant volatility, with a 45% loss in value over five years after reaching an all-time high in 2011. The recent rise in gold is attributed to central bank helicopter money, rekindling investor interest in the metal as an investment. Adding gold to a portfolio can provide diversification benefits, despite its volatility, and could be driven by dollar asset diversification, particularly in Asia.

images.alt_text: Gold, given its multi-millennia history of being seen as money, benefits from flights to safety during periods of military conflict, heightened geo-political risk, paper currency debasement, and negative inflation-adjusted interest rates.

site_title: China will promote yuan's internationalisation, PBOC says
summary: China will promote the internationalization of its yuan currency, making it easier for foreign investors to use the yuan to invest in Chinese bonds and stocks. The central bank aims to bolster the yuan's global clout, amid rising tensions with the US, and expects the yuan to play a bigger role in pricing and settling commodities trade. Cross-border yuan settlements reached 19.67 trillion yuan in 2019, with 38.1% of overall settlements, and the central bank will step up monitoring of cross-border capital flows to ward off potential risks.

site_title: World leaders praise Israel-UAE deal as Palestinians cry foul
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a historic deal between Israel and the UAE, allowing the two countries to normalise relations, with Israel suspending its planned annexation of Palestinian lands. The agreement was welcomed by European and pro-Western Arab governments, but strongly rejected by Palestinians, who called it a "betrayal" of their cause. The deal is seen as a major foreign policy achievement for Trump and may pave the way for similar agreements with other Gulf states.

site_title: Hong Kong cuts full year economic outlook, recovery depends on virus control
summary: Hong Kong has revised its full-year economic outlook, cutting its GDP forecast to a 6-8% contraction, down from an earlier estimate of 4-7%. The economy shrank 9% in the second quarter, marking the fourth consecutive quarter of year-on-year decline. A recovery is contingent on controlling a new wave of coronavirus infections. This contraction follows a 9% decline in the preceding quarter, in line with advance estimates.

site_title: Bukalapak co-founder appointed as chairman of Telkom Indonesia's venture arm
summary: Fajrin Rasyid, co-founder of Indonesian e-commerce unicorn Bukalapak, has been appointed as chairman of Telkom Indonesia's corporate venture capital arm MDI Ventures. Rasyid will work closely with MDI Ventures' new CEO and COO to boost digital revenue, aiming to increase the company's digital revenue from 10% to 90%. He steps down from his role at Bukalapak, where he left in June, following the departure of other founding team members.

site_title: easyJet finances still under review after US$266m sale and leaseback deal
summary: easyJet has raised an additional US$266 million from the sale and leaseback of 5 aircraft, bringing total proceeds to £608 million. The airline will continue to review its liquidity position and assess further funding opportunities amid the ongoing pandemic. The sale and leaseback deal marks the conclusion of a plan announced in May, and the airline's finances remain under review. The pandemic continues to impact travel, with the UK adding France to its quarantine list, potentially forcing easyJet to cancel more flights.

site_title: Axa said to mull US$177m sale of Greek business to Generali
summary: Axa is in talks to sell its Greek business to Generali for approximately $243.2 million, as part of the insurer's plan to divest surplus business lines. The Greek operations, which serve 576,000 customers and generate over $160 million in revenue, would be valued at around 150 million euros. Axa is seeking to raise funds amid the COVID-19 crisis, which has led to a 30% decline in its shares this year. The sale would be Generali's second major acquisition in the insurance sector this year, following its purchase of XL Group in 2018.

site_title: Singapore government support for firms and workers to 'evolve and taper'; details to come on Monday
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that the government's support for firms and workers will "evolve and taper" as the Covid-19 pandemic continues. The government has provided nearly S$100 billion in support, but job losses and retrenchments are expected in coming months. A ministerial statement on Monday will provide details on how support will be extended and modified. The economy is likely to recover unevenly, with some sectors growing and others taking years to recover.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore government to continue supporting firms and workers, but indefinite support is not possible. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat made the statement. Hin Leong founder OK Lim charged with forgery over a US$56 million trade financing deal. Singapore won the rights to host the 2028 Lions Clubs International Convention, expected to attract 20,000 foreign delegates and generate S$58 million in tourism. The National Wages Council will reconvene to review wage guidelines in September. Singapore shares ended the week in negative territory, down 0.56%, amid cautious investor sentiment.

site_title: US retail sales up 1.2% in July
