summary: US retail sales rose 1.2% in July, following a 2.7% increase compared to the same month in 2019. This is the third consecutive increase, after a 8.4% jump in June. However, sales remain 2.1% lower than the same period last year due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: One-year-old boy among imported coronavirus cases announced on Friday
summary: A one-year-old boy, an Indian national, has been confirmed as one of four imported coronavirus cases in Singapore, with the others being two work pass holders from India. All four individuals have been placed on 14-day stay-home notices and tested while serving their notices. No community cases were reported on Friday, marking the first time since June 1. The total number of patients remains at 55,580, with 51,034 fully recovered and 79 in hospital, while 4,425 are recuperating in community facilities.

site_title: Taiwan cuts 2020 GDP outlook again, but sees recovery ahead
summary: Taiwan's economy is expected to contract 1.56% in 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic, with consumption and tourism severely impacted. However, the economy is forecast to rebound with a 3.92% growth rate in 2021, driven by improved demand for electronics exports. The country's GDP shrank 0.58% in the second quarter, and the government has rolled out a US$35.79 billion stimulus package to mitigate the economic impact. Renewed US-China tensions and potential tariffs on electronics exports may pose additional challenges for Taiwan's economy.

site_title: Leisure travel green lanes can help Changi Airport regain some lost traffic, says Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore may introduce reciprocal green lanes at Changi Airport for tourists from countries with similar or better Covid-19 situations, potentially lifting passenger numbers to 40% of pre-Covid levels. Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung suggested replacing 14-day quarantine with rigorous testing regimes. Singapore could also consider allowing tourists from countries controlling the virus to enter without quarantine, similar to its current arrangements with China and Malaysia. The move aims to restore passenger volume while controlling virus transmission, following the devastating impact of Covid-19 on Changi Airport.

site_title: Sinopec merges two Guangdong-based refineries, lifts more US oil: sources
summary: China's Sinopec has merged two refineries in Guangdong, combining the Zhongke refinery complex and Dongxing Petrochemical plant, to form Zhongke Refining and Chemical Co. The move aims to improve operations in South China, a top oil-consuming region, and increase its crude refining capacity to 300,000 bpd. The new entity will also start a new ethylene complex in September, processing 800,000 tonnes per year. This follows Sinopec's strategy to form regional refining hubs and increase its integration into feedstock supply and crude oil purchases.

images.alt_text: China's Sinopec has merged two subsidiary refineries in Guangdong, two company sources said, as the state refining giant looks to improve operations in the face of rising competition in South China.

site_title: Golden Energy and Resources H1 net profit up 32.4% to US$16.5m
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) reported a 32.4% increase in its first-half net profit to US$16.5 million, driven by a 31.7% surge in production volume to 16.5 million tonnes. The company's coal mining division saw a 26.8% increase in revenue to US$574.2 million, despite a 6.8% drop in average selling price of thermal coal. Gear's diversified portfolio, including the acquisition of the Ravenswood Gold mine, contributed to the company's cautious optimism on the near to medium-term outlook recovery for thermal and metallurgical coal demand and prices.

site_title: Hin Leong founder OK Lim charged with forgery offence, S$3m bail sought
summary: OK Lim, the founder of stricken Singapore oil trader Hin Leong Trading, was charged with abetment of forgery for the purpose of cheating. The charge relates to allegedly instigating an employee to forge a document to secure over US$56 million in trade financing. A bail amount of S$3 million was sought by the deputy public prosecutor. Investigations into other offences are ongoing. Lim, a 70-year-old billionaire, had previously stepped down as chairman of Hin Leong due to a US$4 billion debt pile and potential scrutiny of the company's books.

site_title: JTC to launch Gul Circle site for tender
summary: JTC has accepted an application to sell a 0.37-hectare industrial site at Gul Circle for a minimum bid price of S$2 million. The site, zoned Business 2, has a 20-year tenure and a gross plot ratio of 1.4. The site will be released for sale by public tender on Aug 25 for six weeks, following a reserve list system application. This marks the first industrial land sale under the first half 2020 government land sales programme.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets retreat at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the start of trading on Friday, extending losses from the previous session due to fears of a second coronavirus wave and the US stimulus package stalemate. London's FTSE 100 dropped 0.5% to 6,152.82 points, while Paris's CAC 40 fell 0.6% to 5,010.03. The decline was also attributed to travel restrictions imposed by the UK on France and the Netherlands, and fading hopes of a US stimulus deal.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle as US stimulus impasse drags on
summary: Asian markets fell on Friday due to concerns over the US stimulus impasse, which has been ongoing for weeks. Despite initial hopes that a deal would be reached, senators broke up for summer recess, delaying any potential resolution. This has led to a decline in investor confidence, causing markets to drift. The US economy's struggles and the ongoing trade tensions have taken a toll on global markets, with many investors expressing caution and uncertainty about the future.

site_title: SGX RegCo reports accounting irregularities in Vibrant unit Blackgold to authorities
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has reported accounting irregularities in Vibrant Group's subsidiary Blackgold International Holdings to authorities. A 2019 special audit report by EY Advisory uncovered potential significant misstatements in Blackgold's financial statements, including falsified accounts and inflated sales figures since its acquisition by Vibrant in 2017. SGX RegCo now requires listed companies to consult it before appointing Blackgold management as a director or key management.

site_title: Singapore shares end week in negative territory, STI down 0.56%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week down 14.65 points or 0.56% at 2,581.32 points, as investors remained cautious amid the virus-stricken economy. Major indices in Asia drifted unchanged, despite a recovery in global trade sentiment. ST Engineering was the best performer, gaining 3.67%, while Singapore Airlines and SATS also saw increases in their prices. However, heavyweights Jardine Matheson Holdings and Jardine Strategic Holdings fell, and banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also ended the week in the red.

site_title: Singapore wins rights to host 2028 Lions Clubs International Convention
summary: Singapore has won the rights to host the 110th Lions Clubs International Convention in 2028, expected to attract 20,000 foreign delegates and generate S$58 million in tourism receipts. The event will be held at Marina Bay Sands, with the Lions Clubs of Singapore partnering the Singapore Exhibition & Convention Bureau. The re-selection of Singapore as a host destination highlights the city's strong fundamentals, including a vibrant business culture, excellent infrastructure, and a stable government.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality flags unauthorised loan application, tax delinquency by sponsor
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has flagged two issues: an unauthorized loan application under the US Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) and tax delinquency by its sponsor, Urban Commons. The unauthorized PPP loan application, worth over US$2 million, was made on behalf of the Queen Mary master lessor, despite the former employee no longer being part of the company. Additionally, certain master lessees have failed to pay outstanding sales taxes, lodger's taxes, and tourism improvement district taxes for three EHT properties, resulting in a total amount of US$954,000 in unpaid taxes.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS says worst appears to be over for Sunpower, upgrades to 'buy'
summary: DBS Group Research has upgraded Sunpower Group to "buy" from "hold" with a raised target price of S$0.69. The upgrade comes as China's economic activities resume, potentially boosting Sunpower's green investments growth. The textile sector, which uses Sunpower's green-investment plants, is expected to contribute to the group's revenue. DBS revised its forecast for FY2020 and FY2021, raising its adjusted profit and order book assumptions. Shares of Sunpower rose 4.3% following the upgrade.

site_title: foodpanda, ST Engineering test food delivery using drones
summary: foodpanda and ST Engineering successfully tested food delivery using drones, with an order of ayam penyet delivered in under 10 minutes. The partnership, inked in March, aims to adapt ST Engineering's DroNet solution for short-distance drone delivery. The test flight was hosted by PACC Offshore Services Holdings and marks a step towards making food delivery using drones a reality.

site_title: Kitchen Culture shares sink as firm eyes stake in China fintech Ooway
summary: Kitchen Culture Holdings has proposed to acquire a 30% stake in Chinese fintech firm Ooway Technology for approximately S$23.9 million, to be funded through the issuance of 90 million new shares. The acquisition aims to expand Kitchen Culture's presence in the burgeoning fintech industry and explore new areas such as AI and machine learning. The deal, valued at 17.25% discount to the volume-weighted average price, is subject to conditions including due diligence investigations and shareholder approval.

site_title: Pandemic delivers first crisis lessons to South-east Asia's Grab
summary: Grab, South-east Asia's largest ride-hailing firm, has emerged from the COVID-19 pandemic with a newfound focus on delivery services, having seen a surge in demand for food and grocery delivery. The company laid off around 360 employees in June, but CEO Anthony Tan believes this was a necessary step to set the company up for long-term profitability. With a growing finance business and plans to provide more services for merchants, Grab is doubling down on its efforts to become a universal everyday app, with Tan predicting a faster path to profitability.

site_title: AI unicorn SenseTime mulling Hong Kong, China IPO: sources
summary: SenseTime Group, China's largest AI company, is exploring a dual listing in Hong Kong and China for a pre-IPO valuation of around $8.5 billion. The company has secured $1.5 billion in pre-IPO financing and is considering a simultaneous listing in both markets, betting on investor interest in new listings. SenseTime is at the forefront of China's AI adoption, working with 127 cities to analyze data from cameras, and competes with Alibaba-backed Megvii Technology. Its IPO plans are subject to change and have been delayed due to pandemic-induced market volatility and US blacklisting.

site_title: Tivoli Lodge condo in Geylang up for collective sale with S$17.3m guide price
summary: A freehold condo in Singapore's Geylang area, Tivoli Lodge, has entered private treaty for collective sale with a guide price of S$17.3 million. The 8-storey, 14-unit development has a land rate of about S$795 per square foot per plot ratio and will not incur additional development charges. The site is zoned for residential or institutional use and is about a 15-minute drive from the central business district. Developers consider it an "opportunity for a boutique-sized project" due to its low price quantum, potentially suitable for a co-living space.

site_title: Shell unit shuts Philippine refinery as pandemic slashes margins
summary: The Philippine unit of Royal Dutch Shell has permanently shut its 110,000-barrel-per-day Tabangao refinery in Batangas province due to a pandemic-led slump in margins. The refinery, which began operations in 1962, will be converted into an import terminal. This move follows a decline in the Singapore complex refining margin, which has been mostly negative since March, prompting many Asian refineries to cut output or temporarily shut operations. Other regional closures are likely to follow, according to analysts.

site_title: Australia: Shares post biggest weekly gain
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Friday, recording their biggest weekly gain in six weeks, driven by gains in gold and tech stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 6,126.2, its best performance since early July. Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe called for more fiscal stimulus to revive the economy, which has faced its deepest recession in a century. The index gained 2% for the week, its best performance since early July, as investors await the review of the US-China trade deal and earnings reports from BHP Group and Westpac Banking.

site_title: Australia awaits cruise ship virus inquiry findings
summary: Australia awaits the findings of a public inquiry into the COVID-19 outbreak on the Ruby Princess cruise ship, which disembarked 2,700 passengers in Sydney in March without proper screening. The inquiry, commissioned by the NSW state government, will examine how the virus spread across the country and internationally, resulting in over 600 cases and 20 deaths. The inquiry's report is expected to put pressure on senior officials to take responsibility for handling the crisis, as Australia faces a second wave of infections in the state of Victoria.

site_title: Malaysia bonds blow past peers as rate cuts power rally
summary: Malaysia's bonds have surged in value this quarter, outperforming peers in emerging Asia, due to a series of interest-rate cuts by the central bank. The benchmark three-year yields have fallen almost 40 basis points, and the 10-year bonds now offer a real yield of 4.39%, making them attractive to foreign investors. The country's economy contracted 17.1% last quarter, but net foreign inflows totalled $4 billion in the three months through July, erasing previous outflows. The central bank is expected to lower borrowing costs again in September, further boosting the bond rally.

site_title: Michael Jordan's sneakers sell for US$615,000, new record
summary: A pair of Michael Jordan's game-worn Air Jordan 1 Highs sold for a record-breaking $615,000 at Christie's auction house, shattering the previous record set just months ago. The sneakers were worn by Jordan during a 1985 exhibition match in Italy, where he dunked the ball so hard it shattered the backboard. The shoes feature an actual piece of the backboard in the sole. This sale marks another milestone in the increasing value of rare sneakers, cementing Jordan's legacy as a basketball icon.

site_title: First Resources H1 profit up 47.8% on stronger palm oil prices
summary: First Resources, an Indonesian palm oil producer, reported a 47.8% increase in net profit to US$43.2 million for the half year ended June 30, 2020, driven by higher average selling prices for crude palm oil and refined products. Earnings per share rose to 2.73 US cents from 1.85 US cents in the previous year.

site_title: Indonesia's president calls to 'reboot' economy amid pandemic
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo called for a 'reboot' of the country's economy amid the pandemic, citing stagnation and a need to improve food and energy security, as well as increase domestic natural resource processing. The government expects flat growth this year due to the pandemic, which has infected over 132,000 people and caused nearly 6,000 deaths. Widodo highlighted plans to slash oil imports by using biodiesel made from palm oil, and emphasized the need for downstream processing of raw materials to create jobs.

site_title: Singapore's telecom, travel and leisure sectors face dividend uncertainty: IHS Markit
summary: Singapore's telecom and travel sectors face dividend uncertainty in the second half of 2020 due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. IHS Markit analysts have flagged dividends to be paid out from the telecommunications sector with low confidence, citing a lacklustre year for Singtel, which proposed a reduced dividend payout. The travel and leisure sector is also uncertain, with Genting Singapore's upcoming dividend uncertain due to volatile ex-date patterns. In contrast, firms in Australia, Malaysia, and China have the highest level of dividend uncertainty.

site_title: Seoul: Shares snap nine sessions of gains on bleak China data
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi index closed 1.23% lower on Friday, snapping a nine-session winning streak, amid bleak China data and US job data. China's retail sales slipped in July, while the US jobless claims dropped below 1 million. US lawmakers continue to debate a new coronavirus stimulus package, weighing on sentiment. The economy is seen bouncing back to sequential growth in the third quarter, but a slump in exports remains a concern. Foreigners were net sellers of $390.33 million worth of shares on the main board.

site_title: China's July home prices rise 0.5% m-o-m, 4.8% y-o-y, touch slower from June
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.5% month-over-month in July, matching the June pace, and 4.8% year-over-year, slightly slower than June's 4.9% growth. Consumer confidence is recovering, but policymakers remain cautious of the property sector's risk of overheating. Analysts predict a 3.75% growth this year, while some cities have tightened curbs on home purchases to curb spiking prices.

site_title: US, China to discuss trade deal amid Covid-19 disruption
summary: US and Chinese negotiators will discuss the "phase one" trade deal, signed in January, amid Covid-19 disruption. The deal, which obligated China to import $200 billion in US goods over two years, has seen lagging purchases, raising concerns about its fate. Analysts expect minimal changes, with Washington likely to be the catalyst for any modifications. The talks come as tensions between the two countries worsen, with the US imposing sanctions on China and China cracking down on Hong Kong.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up for fourth straight session
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.17% to 23,289.36, marking its fourth consecutive gain, driven by a weak yen. However, early gains were largely erased by profit-taking, leaving the broader Topix index down 0.05%. The move follows a rally in other Asian markets, including Singapore's STI, which rose 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Asia-Pac SMEs responding well to pandemic, but face challenges in digital transformation: poll
summary: Asia-Pacific small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have responded well to the pandemic by adopting new ways of working and selling, but still face challenges in digital transformation. A study by SAP and Oxford Economics found that APAC firms have prioritized digital maturity and responded better to the pandemic than firms in other regions. The study surveyed 240 APAC SMEs and found that they have made significant strides in digital transformation, but still face challenges in areas such as cybersecurity and data management.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with losses, slipping 0.63% to 25,072.45. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.15% and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.11%. The losses follow a healthy week, with traders monitoring deadlocked US stimulus talks and a China-US review of their trade pact.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.95 points, or 0.19%, to 1,573.47. The index saw a volume of 622.08 million lots worth RM150.30 million.

site_title: Malaysia's economy shrinks most since 1998 Asia crisis
summary: Malaysia's economy contracted by 17.1% in the second quarter, its worst showing since the Asian financial crisis in 1998, due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on trade and consumer spending. The central bank downgraded its forecast, expecting a 3.5-5.5% contraction this year, and has cut interest rates to cushion growth. The recession, marked by a 16.5% decline in GDP, has affected services, manufacturing, and construction industries, with some signs of recovery emerging at the end of the quarter.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's economy contracted by the most since the Asian financial crisis more than two decades ago, with the central bank sharply downgrading its outlook for this year.

site_title: Hyphens Q2 profit up 32% on robust sales of skin health products, supplements
summary: Hyphens Pharma International reported a 32% increase in Q2 net profit after tax to S$2.2 million, driven by higher revenue and other income. This growth was partially offset by higher distribution costs and administrative expenses. Earnings per share rose to 0.72 Singapore cents, up from 0.52 cents in the previous year. The company's proprietary brands saw a significant boost in sales, contributing to the profit increase.

site_title: Q&M Dental first-half revenue slumps 14%, Aoxin Q&M's loss widens
summary: Q&M Dental Group's first-half revenue fell 14% to S$53 million, down from S$61.6 million last year, resulting in a net profit of S$8.1 million, a 2% decrease from the previous year. Earnings per share decreased to 1.03 cents from 1.06 cents last year.

site_title: Baidu Q2 results beat estimates, but overshadowed by iQIYI probe
summary: Chinese search engine giant Baidu reported a 1% drop in Q2 revenue to 26.0 billion yuan, beating analyst estimates. However, the results were overshadowed by iQIYI's announcement that it's under investigation by the US Securities and Exchange Commission, with shares plummeting 19% and Baidu's shares falling 5.5%. The probe is related to allegations of inflating user numbers, revenue, and content prices, and iQIYI is cooperating with the SEC. Baidu CEO Robin Li remains cautiously optimistic about the second half, citing prospects for its artificial intelligence division.

images.alt_text: Chinese search engine giant Baidu posted quarterly revenue a notch ahead of estimates, but its shares slid in extended trade after its streaming service iQIYI said it was being probed by the US Securities and Exchange Commission.

site_title: WeWork gets new US$1.1b commitment from SoftBank, cuts burn rate
summary: WeWork has cut its cash burn rate in half and secured a $1.1 billion commitment in new financing from majority owner SoftBank Group Corp. The company reported a 9% increase in revenue to $882 million in the second quarter, with $4.1 billion in cash and unfunded commitments. Despite a decline in members to 612,000, 48% of new members were from large enterprises. WeWork expects to be cash flow positive in 2021. The company has undergone significant management changes and remains entangled in lawsuits over a $3 billion tender offer.

site_title: China produces record crude steel in July on strong demand
summary: China produced a record 93.36 million tonnes of crude steel in July, 1.9% higher than June and 9.1% higher than July 2019, driven by boosted infrastructure spending and the manufacturing sector's rebound. Average daily output of 3.01 million tonnes in July was lower than June's 3.05 million tonnes. Demand for flat steel products used in cars and appliances, despite heavy rain hurting construction demand, underpinned steel consumption. Blast furnace capacity utilisation rates rose to 95.16% for the fourth consecutive week.

images.alt_text: China produced a record amount of crude steel in July as the government boosted infrastructure spending, while the manufacturing sector rebounded as the world's second-largest economy reopened after lockdown restrictions.

site_title: SEA to face more severe impact from climate change than other regions
summary: New research from the McKinsey Global Institute suggests that Southeast Asia, particularly Emerging Asia, will face more severe impacts from climate change than other regions. By 2050, the region could see 8-13% of GDP at risk due to rising heat and humidity, and the likelihood of extreme precipitation events could increase three- or four-fold in Indonesia. The region has opportunities to address the challenge by prioritizing resilience and decarbonization, potentially leading a global response to climate change.

site_title: New Zealand virus outbreak spreads beyond Auckland
summary: New Zealand's coronavirus outbreak has spread beyond Auckland, with 12 more cases of community transmission reported, including one probable case in the North Island town of Tokoroa. Despite a strict lockdown in Auckland, health officials downplay concerns that the virus could spread rapidly elsewhere, citing that all cases are connected to the Auckland cluster. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern is set to announce whether Auckland's lockdown will be extended and if the area should be enlarged.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain on strength in gold stocks, RBA comments
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 6123.1, driven by gains in gold stocks and reassurance from the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) on policy measures to ease economic pain. RBA Governor Philip Lowe hinted at potential bond buying programs or policy adjustments. This rebound follows a 0.67% drop in the previous session, marking the benchmark's best weekly jump since July 17.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia H1 net profit down 5.7% to S$19.4m after drag by associates
summary: Hong Leong Asia reported a 5.7% drop in net profit to S$19.4 million for the six months ended June 30, 2020, due to lower share of results from associates and joint ventures. Revenue rose 4.2% to S$2.14 billion, driven by its diesel engines unit. The company cited uncertainties, including Covid-19 infection waves and worsening US-China trade tensions, but remains cautiously optimistic about its ability to ride through the challenging second half of 2020.

site_title: Five tips to protect against ransomware targeting SMEs
summary: Dharma ransomware, first spotted in 2016, remains active in 2020 targeting mainly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) due to their vulnerability. With businesses stretched thin to support remote working, the risks from attacks are magnified. Sophos offers five tips to protect against Dharma ransomware: shutting down RDP, checking device inventory and installing latest security updates, keeping regular backups, identifying suspicious behavior, and adopting a layered defense-in-depth security model. SMEs are advised to be aware of the signs of an attacker and remember that there is no single security solution.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index opened higher on Friday, rising 67.27 points or 0.29% to 23,316.88. The broader Topix index fell 2.78 points or 0.17%. Investors adjusted positions after stalled US talks over fresh stimulus.

site_title: Sasseur Reit cuts Q2 DPU by 6% after posting lower year-on-year sales
summary: Sasseur Reit, a Chinese outlet mall owner, reported a 6% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.512 Singapore cents in Q2 2020, due to lower year-on-year sales. Rental income under entrusted management agreements rose 1.4% to S$30.3 million, while excluding straight-line adjustment, EMA rental income was down 4%. This drop was cushioned by the fixed component of EMA rental income.

site_title: Cosco Shipping H1 earnings tumble 69% to S$1.4m
summary: Cosco Shipping International, a logistics service provider, reported a 69% decline in net profit to S$1.4 million for its half-year period ended June 30, 2020, due to rental waivers, weak charter rates, and lower profit margins. Revenue rose 8% to S$86.3 million, driven by earnings from newly acquired subsidiaries and an increased fleet of bulk carriers. No dividend was declared, and the company aims to expand its logistics network in South and South-east Asia through acquisitions and investments.

site_title: Daimler strikes US$2.2b diesel settlements in US
summary: Daimler has approved settlements worth US$2.2 billion over emissions cheating software in its diesel vehicles in the US. The company will pay US$1.5 billion to US authorities and US$700 million to settle a consumer class action lawsuit. The settlements relate to approximately 250,000 diesel passenger cars and vans in the US, following the "dieselgate" scandal. The company's net earnings slumped by 64% last year due to charges and a mass recall of faulty airbags. The settlements will have an impact on Daimler's cash flow for three years, including the next 12 months.

site_title: China's domestic spending slows as economy recovers from virus outbreak
summary: China's retail sales dropped 1.1% in July, exceeding forecasts and indicating sluggish consumer spending despite the country's efforts to control the coronavirus outbreak. This follows a 1.8% decline in June and a 11% drop in the catering industry. Industrial production grew 4.8% in July, below predictions. China's economy is recovering from a historic contraction in the first quarter but faces pressure to maintain growth, with external demand weakening and other countries battling the pandemic.

images.alt_text: China's retail sales dropped in July, official data showed on Friday, indicating that sluggish consumer spending could hold up the country's recovery from the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Facebook, Google step up election protection efforts
summary: Facebook and Google have stepped up election protection efforts ahead of the November US election. Facebook launched its voting information center, while Google announced new features to provide detailed information about voting and registration. YouTube will remove content aimed at manipulation, including videos with hacked information and those promoting voting interference. The move comes after an industry meeting with federal agencies to coordinate on election interference, with Facebook aiming to help 4 million people register to vote.

site_title: National Australia Bank's cash profit falls 6% as loan repayments crawl
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) reported a 6.1% drop in quarterly cash profit to A$1.55 billion due to increased provisions for coronavirus-led loan losses. The bank booked A$570 million in bad debt charges during the quarter. NAB also said 16% of home loan deferral customers had started repayment, with 84% choosing to extend their repayment holidays. The bank warned of increased challenges in meeting its expense target and virus-related outlays affecting cost growth in 2021.

site_title: Isetan sinks into the red with S$317,000 net loss in H1
summary: Isetan Singapore reported a net loss of S$317,000 for the first half of 2020, compared to a net profit of S$1.6 million in the same period last year. The decline in sales and impairment loss on financial assets were the main causes. Loss per share was 0.77 Singapore cents, down from 3.82 cents in the previous year.

site_title: E-commerce tech firm Anchanto raises S$16.6m in ongoing Series C round
summary: E-commerce tech firm Anchanto has raised S$16.6 million in its ongoing Series C round, with investors including Asendia and MDI Ventures. The funds will be used to launch two new products, expand its data platform, and enter three more markets. The company plans to hire skilled talent to accelerate product launches. This funding will support Anchanto's growth in the e-commerce sector.

site_title: Trump administration 'satisfied' with China purchase progress in Phase 1 trade deal: Kudlow
summary: The Trump administration is satisfied with China's progress in meeting Phase 1 trade deal commitments, according to White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow. China is increasing imports of US commodities, particularly for the US agriculture and farm sector. A semi-annual review of the trade deal's implementation will take place on Saturday via videoconference between US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He. This positive development suggests the pact will survive its initial review, which is scheduled to begin on Saturday.

site_title: France and Netherlands added to UK travel quarantine list
summary: Britain has added France and the Netherlands to its travel quarantine list due to rising coronavirus cases in those countries. Travelers arriving in the UK from these destinations after 4am on Saturday will need to self-isolate for 14 days. The move comes after Transport Minister Grant Shapps stated that data shows the need to remove these countries from the list of "coronavirus Travel Corridors" to keep infection rates down.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia chief says fiscal stimulus needed to revive coronavirus-stricken economy
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia's Governor Philip Lowe emphasized the need for fiscal stimulus to revive the economy, which has been severely impacted by the coronavirus pandemic. The bank has already implemented monetary policies, including a record-low interest rate and bond buying program, but Lowe stated that these measures have limits. He believes that the government must provide significant funding to generate jobs and stimulate economic growth, which he considers essential to achieving employment and inflation goals. The RBA will not increase interest rates until these goals are met.

site_title: Reconvened NWC likely to issue updated wage guidelines in September
summary: The National Wages Council (NWC) will reconvene to review its wage guidelines issued in March and aims to release updated guidelines in September. The council's chairman, Peter Seah, emphasized the need to address the challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic on the economy and provide timely guidance to employers. This move comes as the economy continues to navigate the post-pandemic period.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust DPU falls 43.4% to 1.92 S cents for H1
summary: DASIN Retail Trust's distribution per unit (DPU) fell 43.4% to 1.92 Singapore cents for the six months ended June 30, 2020, due to a distribution waiver by major unitholders. Revenue increased 5.2% to S$37.1 million, while net property income grew 6.4% to S$30.3 million. The trust's assets value is expected to support growing demand in the Greater Bay Area.

site_title: Covid-19 vaccine will be free for Americans: officials
summary: US officials have announced that if a Covid-19 vaccine is proven effective, it will be distributed for free to all Americans. The US has invested over $10 billion in six vaccine projects and signed contracts for hundreds of millions of doses. The vaccine doses themselves will be paid for by the government, while clinics administering them will cover costs through private and public insurers. Most commercial insurers have agreed to waive out-of-pocket costs, with delivery expected by January 2021. Officials have denied concerns that the administration may bypass safety precautions to announce a vaccine before the election.

site_title: Wine joins the 2020 debate over privilege and justice
summary: Valentina Passalacqua, a natural-wine producer in Italy, faced backlash after her father, Settimio Passalacqua, was accused of exploiting migrant workers in his agricultural operation. The Italian authorities have not implicated Valentina, but many in the natural-wine community questioned her involvement and accused her of benefiting from her father's economic privilege. Her wines were dropped by several importers, and she has maintained her innocence, stating that her winery and vineyard are independent of her father's business. The case highlights the precarious position of agricultural workers in the wine world and the need for greater transparency and accountability.

site_title: Oil slips after IEA lowers 2020 demand forecast
summary: Oil prices eased on Thursday after the International Energy Agency lowered its 2020 oil demand forecast due to the pandemic, citing a 8.1 million barrel per day decline. Brent crude ended down 1% at $44.96 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate settled down 1% at $42.24 a barrel. Despite the forecast, oil prices remained range-bound due to resilience in equities markets and a weak dollar, with investors awaiting a US stimulus package breakthrough.

site_title: Mexico cuts interest rates for 10th straight time
summary: Mexico's central bank cut its key interest rate for the 10th consecutive time, lowering the inter-bank rate to 4.5% to bolster the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic. Economic activity contracted sharply in the second quarter, and the bank cited this data in its decision. The rate cut aims to stimulate economic growth and mitigate the pandemic's impact.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Friday's open; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks fell at the open on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.6% to 2,581.19. The decline followed a 5-day rally, with 79.6 million securities changing hands. Decliners edged out advancers 69 to 66. Jiutian Chemical rose 8.3% after heavy trading, while the rest of the market fell. The decline is attributed to general market uncertainty.

site_title: Japan's ruling party executive says must avoid rise in property tax: Nikkei
summary: Japan's ruling party executive, Akira Amari, advises against raising commercial property tax, citing the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The tax will be set based on January land prices, which could lead to a bigger tax burden for companies despite expected land price falls. Amari suggests instead using payouts to households and companies to ease the economic pain, rather than cutting the 10% sales tax rate. This move aims to support companies struggling financially due to the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Japan must avoid any increase in property tax for commercial land as the coronavirus pandemic is hurting many companies, Akira Amari, head of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's tax panel, was quoted as saying by the Nikkei newspaper.

site_title: ST Engineering H1 profit slips 4.4% as aerospace, electronics hit by pandemic
summary: ST Engineering's net profit slipped 4.4% to S$257.4 million for the first half of 2020, impacted by impairment of intangible assets and receivables due to the pandemic. Revenue grew 1.7% to S$3.57 billion, but was offset by decline in customer demand and supply chain challenges. The company maintains its FY2020 revenue guidance, expects to receive over S$300 million in government support, and is focusing on cost reduction and talent acquisition to position itself for growth.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering's revenue for the half year inched up by 1.7 per cent on the year to $3.57 billion.

site_title: SBS Transit's H1 net profit falls 27.4% on lower ridership
summary: SBS Transit, a Singaporean transport operator, reported a 27.4% fall in net profit to S$32.6 million for the half-year ended June 30, due to lower ridership during the pandemic. Revenue fell 14.9% to S$603.2 million, with government grants partially cushioning the impact. The company expects revenue to remain lower compared to the previous year, with rail and bus services expected to be affected by the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Fears of financial Iron Curtain grip China as tensions with US rise
summary: China is facing growing fears of a financial "Iron Curtain" due to escalating tensions with the US, which could lead to being shut out of the global dollar system. Chinese officials and economists are discussing worst-case scenarios, including the US freezing or confiscating China's US debt holdings. In response, Beijing is reviving efforts to bolster the yuan's global clout and decrease reliance on the dollar. The Trump administration's push for a partial decoupling of the US and China's economies has increased tensions, with some economists warning of a "broad financial war" that could have devastating global economic consequences.

site_title: Ho Bee Land's net profit up 115% on increased profits from associates
summary: Ho Bee Land's net profit for the half-year ended June 30 rose 115.4% to S$90.6 million, driven by increased profits from associates and jointly-controlled entities. Revenue inched up 1.7% to S$108.8 million, with rental income increasing 2.2% to S$107.3 million. Staff costs and directors' remuneration increased 38.2%, while direct rental expenses fell 23.6%. Despite a grim business outlook due to the pandemic, the group's recurring income base has contributed to its resilience.

site_title: Israel-UAE deal gives Trump a rare win abroad ahead of election
summary: President Donald Trump received praise for the surprise announcement of a normalization deal between Israel and the UAE, with his top national security advisor calling him a "frontrunner for the Nobel Peace Prize." The agreement is seen as a rare diplomatic win for Trump ahead of the US presidential election. The deal was hailed as a significant development in the Middle East, with implications for regional politics and US foreign policy. Trump's advisors believe the move could lead to his nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end four-day winning run as UK's FTSE drags
summary: European stocks ended a four-day winning streak on Thursday, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 closing 0.6% lower and London's FTSE 100 sliding 1.5% due to a stronger pound and ex-dividend trading. Investors favored technology stocks, while cyclical sectors like banks and energy fell. Geir Lode notes that uncertainty surrounding the US-China trade deal and economic recovery may impact the rally in cheaper stocks.

images.alt_text: European stocks broke a four-day winning streak on Thursday as ex-dividend trading and a stronger pound hit the UK's blue-chip companies, while investors sold off banks and energy stocks that have outperformed this week.

site_title: US braces for evictions crisis as aid talks stall in Washington
summary: The US is bracing for a potential eviction crisis as aid talks in Washington stall, leaving tens of millions at risk of homelessness due to the coronavirus crisis. The global health emergency has led to a jobs catastrophe, leaving Americans struggling to pay rent. Hopes for a fresh aid package were dashed due to partisan bickering, exacerbating the economic hardship.

site_title: Qatar Airways extends crew curfew over virus breaches: memo
summary: Qatar Airways has extended its cabin crew curfew to 9pm-7am due to breaches of the country's strict virus control rules, including social gatherings and mandatory masks. The airline's senior vice-president of cabin services wrote to crew, requesting they refrain from participating in social events and citing concerns over the spread of Covid-19. The move comes after Qatar reported 114,281 cases and 190 deaths since the start of the pandemic. The airline has previously warned of potential redundancies and pay cuts due to the global aviation downturn.

site_title: 'Fortnite' maker sues Apple over app restrictions
summary: Fortnite's maker, Epic Games, has sued Apple over the App Store's restrictions, accusing the tech giant of wielding monopoly power. Epic claims Apple's 30% transaction fee is "unreasonable and unlawful," restricting trade and preventing developers from reaching Apple's 1 billion mobile users. The lawsuit seeks to order Apple to change its store rules for all developers, not just Fortnite, which was recently removed from the App Store after Epic added a payment system bypassing the store. The suit argues Apple's rules stifle innovation and favor its own interests.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall below one million
summary: US weekly jobless claims dropped below one million for the first time since the Covid-19 pandemic, falling to 963,000. The decline is attributed to the expiration of a $600 weekly jobless supplement, which lapsed on July 31. President Trump signed an executive order extending the supplement, but reduced the weekly payout to $400, with states covering $100 and a limited emergency disaster relief program funding the remaining $300. The number of people receiving benefits after an initial week of aid totaled 15.486 million in the week ending Aug 1.

site_title: Biden backs nationwide mask mandate to fight virus
summary: US presidential hopeful Joe Biden calls for a nationwide mask mandate for the next three months to combat the coronavirus pandemic, drawing a contrast with President Donald Trump. Biden's proposal, backed by health experts, aims to halt the virus's spread and save tens of thousands of lives. Biden's running mate Kamala Harris also criticized Trump's handling of the pandemic, saying his "mismanagement" has led to a deep health crisis. The move highlights the importance of the pandemic in the election campaign.

site_title: China's debt collectors thrive in economy battered by Covid
summary: China's debt collectors are thriving amid an economy battered by the coronavirus and US-China tensions. Debt recovery firms are expanding, with companies like Whole Scene Asset Management and Bricsman planning to double staff numbers. The industry is driven by a growing wave of non-performing loans, which have increased to 30-50% of some lenders' portfolios. This poses concerns for Beijing's efforts to spur domestic demand and the financial health of consumer lending firms.

site_title: Impossible Foods raises US$200m in fresh funding
summary: Impossible Foods has secured $200 million in fresh funding, bringing its total funds raised to $1.5 billion since its founding in 2011. The company plans to use the funds to expand research, develop new products, and for internal operations. This funding round was led by hedge fund Coatue and included existing investors Mirae Asset Global Investments and Temasek. Impossible Foods' valuation has increased to $4.03 billion, with its latest price per share at $16.15. The company aims to continue its rapid expansion in retail and develop new products to stay competitive in the plant-based market.

site_title: China's days as world's factory are over, iPhone maker says
summary: Taiwanese electronics supplier Hon Hai Precision Industry, also known as Foxconn, plans to split its supply chain between the Chinese market and the US to avoid escalating tariffs. Chairman Young Liu stated that China's time as the world's factory is over due to the trade war, with the company now producing 30% of its goods outside China, up from 25% last June. Foxconn aims to diversify its manufacturing bases in South-east Asia and other regions, with Apple expected to delay its iPhone launch this year.

site_title: MAS puts S$250m to beef up financial-sector innovation, grow Singaporean fintech talent
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced a S$250 million funding boost for the Financial Sector Technology and Innovation (FSTI) scheme over the next three years. The enhanced scheme aims to encourage the expansion of innovation labs, develop Singaporean fintech talent, and support the adoption of artificial intelligence (AI) within the financial industry. Funding for early-stage experimentation will be doubled, and a merit-based tiered funding mechanism will be introduced to prioritize projects demonstrating stronger merits. The move is part of Singapore's efforts to become a "smart" financial center and drive technology-driven growth in the sector.

site_title: Xihe Holdings placed under IJM, accuses OCBC of 'abuse of process'
summary: Xihe Holdings, a Singaporean company owned by Hin Leong founder OK Lim and his son, has been placed under interim judicial managers (IJMs) by a Singapore High Court. OCBC Bank, a creditor, had applied for IJM control over Xihe's restructuring, citing concerns over the Lim family's management. However, Xihe Holdings disputes OCBC's motives, claiming it is an abuse of process to gain control over the Lim family's assets. The court has appointed Grant Thornton Singapore as IJMs, and a majority of Xihe lenders have expressed support for a consensual restructuring.

site_title: Suburban Sanctuary
summary: Retirees Alex Yeow and Jacqueline Loke commissioned architect Yip Yuen Hong to design a 3,390 sq ft home in Serangoon Gardens. The couple, both artists, wanted a small, private home with a large garden. Mr. Yip's design featured a monastic-style layout with a basement on street level, minimizing the impact on the busy road. The interior boasts seamless transitions between indoor and outdoor spaces, with strategically placed windows and natural light shafts. The building materials were chosen for their ease of maintenance and longevity, reflecting the couple's desire to avoid future renovations.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 end lower as stimulus talks stall
summary: US stocks ended lower on Thursday as stimulus talks stalled, despite better-than-expected labor data showing 963,000 new weekly unemployment claims. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.3%, while the S&P 500 shed 0.2%. Investors had taken heart from the economic data, but party divisions in Washington remain a concern. Individual stocks, including Cisco Systems, were also affected by disappointing earnings reports, with Cisco plummeting 11.2%. The market's recovery since March is now seen as dependent on a successful coronavirus vaccine by the end of the year.

site_title: New lifelines for distressed companies
summary: Singapore's new Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Act (IRDA) aims to facilitate debt restructuring and discourage winding up, giving distressed companies a better chance of rescue. The reformed regulations are timely, as corporate defaults and insolvencies continue to rise due to the Covid-19 crisis. The new laws focus on better facilitation of debt restructuring, providing a more favorable environment for companies to restructure and recover.

site_title: UMS Q2 net profit up 43%, proposes one Singapore cent interim dividend
summary: UMS Holdings' net profit rose 43% to S$11.6 million in the second quarter, driven by a 41% increase in semiconductor segment revenue. Revenue from integrated system sales increased 65% to $19.6 million, while component sales rose 22%. The company proposes a one Singapore cent interim dividend, and expects to remain profitable in 2020 despite uncertainties from the US-China trade war and COVID-19 resurgence.

site_title: Darco Water issues letter of demand against ex-CEO for alleged breaches of duty
summary: Darco Water Technologies has issued a letter of demand against former CEO Thye Kim Meng, alleging breaches of duty resulting in losses of US$1.6 million. The allegations concern transactions related to a water project and a solar project, which were led by Thye. Darco is demanding Thye provide written confirmation to pay the amount, with the option to recover further sums. The former CEO was a key driver of transactions during his tenure, but Darco's internal review found the Can Guioc water project was not commercially viable due to technical issues.

site_title: Singapore fashion struts on
summary: Singapore fashion designers have adapted to the pandemic by innovating and diversifying their offerings. Local designer Max Tan's unique monochromatic designs garnered international attention, earning him a spot alongside major brands like Alexander McQueen and Miu Miu. Despite stiff competition and high overheads, Tan has managed to stay in the game, demonstrating resilience in the industry. His success serves as an inspiration to other Singapore designers, who are finding new ways to thrive in the face of challenges.

site_title: Apple's US$44 billion China market threatened by Trump's WeChat ban
summary: US President Donald Trump's executive order banning US companies from doing business with WeChat, a super-app in China, threatens to disrupt Apple's $44 billion China market. The ban, set to take effect in five weeks, could force iPhone users to switch to other brands if WeChat is removed from the global app stores. Analysts predict a 25-30% decline in iPhone shipments and 15-25% decline in other Apple hardware sales. WeChat is a key communication platform in China, used by over a billion users, and its removal could cut off a vital link between China and the rest of the world.

site_title: Coronavirus tests leadership style of Goldman Sachs CEO
summary: Goldman Sachs CEO David M. Solomon's leadership style has been tested by the COVID-19 pandemic. He has demonstrated adaptability and deftness in navigating the crisis, quickly implementing work-from-home policies that helped minimize disruptions and encouraged worker loyalty. However, his decision to request some employees return to the office has sparked grumbling among those who prefer longer stretches of remote work. Despite challenges, Solomon's approach to the crisis has earned praise for being more open and vulnerable, fostering a culture of openness and inclusivity.

site_title: Central Asia offers a vast ocean of possibilities for Asean
summary: Kazakhstan offers vast economic opportunities for Asean countries, particularly in fintech, Islamic finance, and agriculture, as it seeks to establish itself as a reliable source of exported food and a hub for trade and investment. With over 70% of foreign direct investment going to Kazakhstan, the country's business infrastructure is improving to ensure ease of entry. The Astana International Financial Centre (AIFC) has established a framework based on English law and has partnered with Singapore to ensure constructive cooperation in fintech innovation. Asean countries can benefit from Kazakhstan's strategic location between China, Europe, and Russia, and its network of free trade agreements and connections.

site_title: US SMEs shut out of credit boom, stalling nascent rebound
summary: US small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are being shut out of the credit boom, hindering the economic recovery. Despite unprecedented government stimulus, banks are tightening lending standards and pulling back from smaller companies, favoring larger firms. The Federal Reserve's emergency lending programs have been criticized as slow and inaccessible. A prolonged inability to access financing risks stalling the recovery, as SMEs employ 68 million Americans and are critical to regional economies. The situation exacerbates existing inequality problems, with big firms benefiting more than small and financially vulnerable ones.

site_title: Put staff first - happy customers will follow
summary: A recent Harvard Business Review report found that 54% of global respondents believe better employee engagement leads to happy customers, while 53% noted that happier employees result in better products and services. To boost employee engagement, companies are focusing on creating people-centric work environments with flexibility, rewards, and recognition, as well as utilizing technology to improve collaboration and productivity. A democratised selection process for workplace tools is also crucial to ensure employee buy-in and full utilization of technology, ultimately driving customer satisfaction and loyalty.

site_title: Manila malls may be used as e-commerce storage amid retail slump
summary: Philippines' retail landlords are exploring alternative uses for shopping malls due to the retail slump and the COVID-19 outbreak. SM Prime Holdings and Ayala Land are leasing out parking lots for car storage and converting areas into e-commerce back-end facilities and medical clinics. Retail vacancy rates in Manila are forecast to rise to 12% this year, forcing shopping centers to innovate or risk "evaporating." Mall owners are also considering leasing vacant space to co-working companies and repurposing space for storage and warehousing.

site_title: Singapore's Vistas Media Capital lists US$100m Spac on Nasdaq
summary: Singapore-based Vistas Media Capital has listed a US$100 million special purpose acquisition company (Spac) on the Nasdaq, aiming to acquire media and entertainment businesses. The company will focus on tech-based media businesses valued between US$300 and US$600 million. This move reflects the growing interest in blank-cheque vehicles among investors, as fewer companies opt for traditional IPOs.

site_title: CDL to add zing to its portfolio with redevelopments, divestments
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) reported a 99% drop in first-half net profit to S$3.1m, largely due to a pre-tax loss of S$208.2m from its hotel operations segment. The group is redeveloping assets, divesting non-core hotels, and planning to list a Reit on the Singapore Exchange to hold UK commercial properties. CDL's top management remains optimistic about Singapore's private housing market, citing stable pricing and increasing sales. The group is also progressing with redevelopment plans for Fuji Xerox Towers and exploring the redevelopment of Central Mall.

site_title: Business values post Covid-19
summary: Business leaders bear the responsibility of building a better world, as the COVID-19 pandemic exposed the unsustainable spending and debt of pre-pandemic capitalism. The world must prepare for future pandemics and climate change, investing in renewable energy and technology to cope with the consequences. Acceptable business behavior includes respecting personal boundaries, using data analytics responsibly, and providing opportunities for gig and contract workers. Education is key to developing a better world, focusing on creativity and appreciating the beauty of life. Ultimately, business leaders must recognize their responsibility to build a better future for humanity.

images.alt_text: Life is for enjoying. When the effort for profit drives out the beauty of life, the feelings that we as humans have as our greatest gift is potentially lost. We must make more effort to avoid this.

site_title: JTC tests devices to aid safe distancing at three worksites
summary: JTC Corporation is testing devices to aid safe distancing at three construction sites in Singapore, including AI cameras, facial recognition, and thermal scanners. The devices aim to facilitate safe distancing measures and monitor conditions on the ground. A pilot testing platform, BuildSG-CovidSafe, is also being implemented to streamline command and control of workforces and worksites, with plans to roll it out to the rest of the industry by the end of the month.

site_title: Tencent plays down US WeChat ban after results beat estimates
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd. expressed confidence in the impact of US President Donald Trump's ban on its WeChat messaging service, suggesting it may only affect overseas operations. The company emphasized the distinction between WeChat (used outside China) and Weixin (used within China), which is not subject to the ban. Despite concerns, Tencent's earnings results beat estimates, reassuring investors that the ban's impact should be modest.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SYNAGIE Corporation posted its first net profit since its IPO in August 2018, driven by a surge in e-commerce activity during the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue increased 325.6% to S$38.3 million, while gross profit jumped 411.9% to S$12.9 million. The company plans to dispose of its e-commerce business for S$61.7 million to focus on its insurtech business. Meanwhile, Hyflux, a distressed water-treatment firm, has filed an application for a judicial management order after its unsecured working group of bank lenders lost trust in its management.

site_title: Ascott converts some apartments into work suites
summary: The Ascott Ltd, a lodging business unit of CapitaLand, has launched a "work-in-residence" initiative to convert apartments into work suites for use during the day. The service allows guests to book daily, weekly, or monthly packages across over 60 properties in 30 cities worldwide. Rates vary depending on the length of use and location. The move aims to fill a gap left by the Covid-19 pandemic and optimize space usage for various purposes, including hosting cloud kitchens and live-streaming activities.

site_title: Five models look back and forward
summary: Five Singaporean models, Anita AKBAR, LYN WANG, KAIGIN YONG, SIMONE LOWTHER, and SRRI RAMM, reflect on their experiences in the fashion industry. They reminisce about the challenges and changes they've faced, from the heyday of the industry in the 1990s to the current shift towards digital models. Despite these changes, the models express their passion for the craft and optimism about the future of local fashion, with some hoping to transition into design or product development.

site_title: Condo owners should go easy in exercising penalty clauses during Covid-19: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) advises condominium owners and management corporations to exercise restraint in activating penalty clauses for delayed services during the Covid-19 period. Managing agents and facility management companies face challenges due to the pandemic's disruption of on-site work, leading to a tightening of the number of available workers. This advisory aims to promote a more flexible approach to handling delays, considering the extraordinary circumstances.

site_title: The push for Asian designers
summary: The Front Row festival, a virtual fashion event, is set to take place from August 20 to 29, featuring 41 Asian designers from Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines, and Australia. The event includes runway shows, fashion photography, panel discussions, and workshops. Notable designers such as Minju Kim, Carven Ong, and Tube Gallery will showcase their designs, with discussions on how Asian designers can stand out in the current pandemic. The festival aims to help Asian designers pivot onto the digital runway and beyond.

site_title: What the Kamala Harris pick tells us about Joe Biden
summary: Joe Biden's choice of Kamala Harris as his vice-presidential nominee reflects his tendency to align with the day's strongest political currents, hinting at a future that aims to revive the Obama era. Biden's policy agenda and personal style are more liberal than traditional moderate Democrats, making Harris a fitting choice as a representative of the mainstream of his party. This pick showcases Biden's ability to personify the existing party mainstream, rather than being tied to a specific ideological faction.

site_title: Rushed for time
summary: Luxury watchmakers are unveiling new timepieces as the world economy recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic. Patek Philippe's 5303R minute repeater-tourbillon and Girard-Perregaux's Quasar Azure bridges tourbillon are among the latest releases. Franck Muller's Vanguard Revolution 3 Skeleton and Jacquet Droz Grande Seconde Skelet-One also feature complex mechanical movements. These new watches showcase the art of haute horlogerie, with intricate designs and innovative complications.

site_title: German businessman in Wirecard probe dies in Philippines
summary: A German businessman, Christopher Reinhard Bauer, wanted for questioning in the Wirecard accounting scandal, died in the Philippines from "natural causes" on July 27. The Philippine justice minister confirmed the death after obtaining official documents. Bauer's death comes as part of the investigation into Wirecard's 1.9 billion euro disappearance, which was initially claimed to be deposited in two Philippine banks. Authorities in the Philippines and Germany are separately investigating the scandal, with German authorities seeking to question former Wirecard executive Jan Marsalek.

site_title: Rex posts H1 net loss of US$21m after oil production in Oman
summary: Rex International posted a net loss of US$21 million for the half-year ended June 30, 2020, due to higher production costs during the startup phase of its Yumna Field in Oman. Revenue from oil sales was US$14.57 million, while depletion of oil and gas properties was US$10 million. Gross loss was US$12.4 million, compared to a gross loss of US$325,000 a year ago. The company cited higher production costs and lower other income as factors contributing to the loss.

site_title: Australia's AMP outlines US$400m plan for special dividend and buyback
summary: AMP Ltd, Australia's oldest wealth advisory firm, plans to return up to US$400 million to investors in the form of a special dividend and a share buyback, sending its stock surging 14%. The move follows heavy investor outflows due to a public inquiry into improper fees and attempts to deceive regulators. AMP has also been hit by allegations of sexual harassment by senior management. The company will fund the plans with proceeds from the sale of its life insurance unit, which netted A$2.5 billion in cash and 20% of the buyer Resolution Life.

site_title: STI rises 1.28% to 2,595.97 points on Wall Street gains
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.28% to 2,595.97 points, driven by US market gains and a two-day upward movement. Jardine Matheson Holdings and Jardine Strategic Holdings led the gains, while Sembcorp Marine rose two cents on its first day of ex-rights trading. The number of advancing stocks outnumbered declining stocks 295 to 173, with 2.35 billion securities worth S$1.6 billion changing hands.

site_title: Modern Japanese vibe at Nishikane
summary: Nishikane, a modern Japanese restaurant in Singapore, offers a unique omakase experience with a focus on kappo-style cooking and showmanship. Chef Nobuhiro Nishi's playful demeanor and antics are matched by his skilled team, who prepare a range of dishes, including braised wagyu, marinated horse mackerel, and sushi. The meal culminates in two signature dishes, a composition of abalone and seafood, and a claypot crab rice dish with shaved truffles. While the meal is not without its flaws, Chef Nishi's creativity and attention to detail make for a memorable dining experience. Rating: 7.

images.alt_text: Above: Signature abalone, shrimp and uni dish.
Left: Signature ice somen. Right: appetiser of braised waygu and wintermelon with uni.
What a treat! A whole dessert tray. We've never seen a whole dessert tray in a Japaneserestaurant, much less had an invitation to sample everything on it.
Right: Chef Nishi taking black truffles from his little Gucci bag and shaving them over crab claypot rice. Left: clear soup with fillet of greenling fish.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 19.78 points to 1,576.42. The index saw 11.666 billion lots traded worth RM4.971 billion, with 607 gainers and 491 losers.

site_title: Thai PM appeals for unity amid protests
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha appealed for unity in a televised address amid almost daily student-led protests since mid-July, calling for an end to the military's dominance in politics and his resignation. Demonstrators are demanding his removal and an end to military rule. The protests are part of a broader movement to challenge the military's influence in Thai politics.

site_title: UK housing boom gathers pace, but fears of a bust are growing
summary: The UK housing market experienced a rebound in July, with property prices turning positive for the first time since the coronavirus crisis, according to a Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) survey. The RICS monthly house price balance rose to +12, above economists' forecasts. However, concerns are growing that the mini-boom could turn into a bust once a jobs subsidy programme ends and a tax cut expires in March. Experts warn that the economy will recover slowly, and the housing market may face a bust, with first-time homebuyers potentially facing difficulties due to falling incomes and restrictive lending.

images.alt_text: Sales are expected to grow over the next three months but to be falling in 12 months' time.

site_title: SIA Engineering senior management takes further pay cuts
summary: SIA Engineering Company's senior management has implemented a 5% pay cut, with CEO and executive VPs taking a 20-30% pay cut, amid a challenging business environment and continued impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on the aviation industry. This move follows previous cost management measures, including a 12-25% pay cut for senior management. The company remains committed to maintaining adequate liquidity and positioning itself for the eventual recovery of the aviation industry.

site_title: US dollar drops on stock rally, stimulus stalemate
summary: The US dollar fell to its lowest in a week against a basket of currencies on Thursday, trading 0.3% lower at 93.093, due to equity market resilience and a stalemate over US stimulus. Despite rising coronavirus cases and geopolitical tensions, the S&P 500 index reached record highs, benefiting risk-on sentiment and causing the dollar to decline. Analysts attribute the dollar's weakness to the stalemate over US relief packages and the ability of equities to quickly recover from negative drivers.

site_title: Beike owner KE open to secondary Hong Kong or mainland listing after US IPO
summary: KE Holdings, operator of housing platforms Beike Zhaofang and Lianjia, raised around US$2 billion in its US IPO, becoming the biggest US listing by a Chinese company in two years. The company is open to a secondary listing in Hong Kong or mainland China, following Chinese counterparts Alibaba Group, JD.com, and NetEase. KE's CEO Stanley Peng stated that being listed in multiple venues is a capital market strategy and unlikely to be impacted by US-China tensions, which he views as a "worst case scenario".

site_title: Israel and the United Arab Emirates reach historic deal to normalise relations
summary: Israel and the United Arab Emirates (UAE) reached a historic peace deal, normalizing relations between the two Middle Eastern nations. The agreement, brokered by US President Donald Trump, includes Israel suspending sovereignty claims over the West Bank areas it had discussed annexing. The deal, known as the Abraham Accords, will lead to full diplomatic relations normalization and includes agreements on investment, tourism, security, and other issues. Delegations from both countries will meet to sign bilateral agreements and exchange ambassadors and embassies.

site_title: Agritech startup eFishery bags Series B funding led by Go-Ventures and Northstar
summary: eFishery, an Indonesia-based agritech startup, has secured an undisclosed Series B funding round led by Go-Ventures and Northstar Group. Existing investors Aqua-Spark and Wavemaker Partners also participated. The funding will be used for product development and team expansion, focusing on strengthening its product and engineering teams. eFishery plans to double its employee count to 500 by the end of 2020, with a focus on expanding its digital products and services, particularly for its eFisheryFeeder device.

site_title: German businessman in Wirecard probe dies in Philippines
summary: A German businessman, Christopher Reinhard Bauer, who was investigated in the Philippines over the Wirecard accounting scandal, has died from natural causes at a hospital in Manila on July 27. Bauer was wanted for questioning over the 1.9 billion euros missing from Wirecard's accounts, which were initially claimed to be deposited in two Philippine banks. The investigation showed the money had never entered the country's financial system. Bauer's role in the scandal was not specified, but he was described as a former Wirecard Asia Pacific executive.

site_title: China tightens bond sale rules to curb developers' debt
summary: China has introduced new guidelines for residential property developers to curb debt growth, limiting new bond sales to debt refinancing only and capping the proposed bond size at 85% of outstanding debt. The move aims to reduce developers' outstanding debt and prevent frequent debt rollovers. The rules apply to bonds sold on the interbank market and took effect on August 10, following China's housing market recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. This curb on debt growth is part of a broader effort to prevent the property sector from being used as a short-term economic stimulus.

site_title: Revlon sued by lender over US$2b takeover-deal loan
summary: Revlon is being sued by lender UMB Bank over a nearly $2 billion loan used to finance the purchase of Elizabeth Arden in 2016. UMB claims Revlon improperly transferred intellectual property rights used as collateral for the loan in other transactions starting in 2019, seeking a court order to force the return of the collateral, including brand trademarks. Revlon disputes the lawsuit, stating it would fight UMB's "meritless" claims, which are aimed at enriching lenders and blocking Revlon's ability to refinance debt.

site_title: UOL's H1 reverses to S$82.1m net loss due to Covid-19 impact
summary: Singapore property company UOL reported a net loss of S$82.1 million for its first half of 2020 due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. Fair value losses on investment properties and a 28% drop in revenue to S$908.2 million were major contributors to the decline. The group's operations remained profitable, excluding fair value losses, with group pre-tax profit totaling S$196.8 million. CEO Liam Wee Sin urged the government to extend ABSD deadlines, citing the ongoing impact of the crisis.

site_title: MoneyOwl reduces advisory fees, absorbs platform fee
summary: MoneyOwl, a Singaporean financial advisory and social enterprise, is reducing its annual advisory fees and absorbing its third-party platform fee to help Singaporeans cope with their finances. The firm will offer a tiered advisory fee structure, with no fee for accounts under S$10,000, and will launch free group financial resilience workshops. The maximum advisory-plus-platform fees have dropped from 0.83% to 0.6%, benefiting investors across all tiers. The initiatives aim to contribute positively to the community, particularly in light of the challenges posed by Covid-19 and the recession.

site_title: Japan airline ANA in talks to raise up to 500b yen capital from banks: report
summary: Japan's ANA Holdings is in talks with private banks and the Development Bank of Japan to raise up to 500 billion yen (S$6.43 billion) in capital due to expected long-term decline in passenger demand following the Covid-19 pandemic. The airline has not commented on the talks.

site_title: Singapore and Japan to work on resumption of essential travel from September
summary: Singapore and Japan are set to resume essential travel between the two countries, with a focus on expatriates and businessmen, starting from September. The two countries will establish two tracks, a "Residence track" for work pass holders with public health safeguards, and a "Business track" for short-term business travelers with controlled itineraries. The agreement aims to ease restrictions and promote greater economic integration in the region, amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: US: S&P 500 dips at open as labour market rebound falters
summary: The S&P 500 and Dow indexes fell at the open on Thursday, with the Dow losing 54.33 points, or 0.19%, to 27,922.51. The decline was attributed to the expiration of a US$600 weekly jobless supplement, which discouraged some from filing claims. The Nasdaq Composite rose 14.62 points, or 0.13%, to 11,026.86. The jobless claims fall was seen as a sign of a labour market rebound, but the drop in the indexes suggests investors remain cautious due to tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Trump says Hong Kong can 'never succeed' under China control
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that Hong Kong's global financial centre will "go to hell" under tightened Chinese rule, criticizing the territory's loss of autonomy. Trump announced the end of the special US trading relationship with Hong Kong in May, citing Beijing's clampdown on the territory. He believes Hong Kong's markets will suffer and lose its ability to attract business, ultimately failing. This decision comes amid strained US-China relations, with Trump blaming China for the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on his re-election chances.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: MAS commits S$250m to fintech innovation, launching FSTI 2.0. JTC Corporation tests digitalisation technologies to aid safe distancing at construction sites. HYFLUX files judicial management application, and Darco Water issues letter of demand against former CEO. SIA Engineering's senior management takes 20-30% pay cuts. The Straits Times Index rose 1.28% to 2,595.97 points, driven by US market gains.

site_title: Olam 'on track' with listing plans; H1 operational Patmi declines 18.5%
summary: Olam International reported a net profit of S$332.7 million for the first half of 2020, a 44.4% increase from the previous year, driven by a 379% increase in other income. The company's operational units, Olam Food Ingredients and Olam Global Agri, saw their revenues increase by 8.8% and 8.4% year on year, respectively. However, Olam's earnings before interest and taxes declined 40.1% for Olam Food Ingredients due to adverse prices and margin pressures. The company plans to spin off its operational arms in separate listings, with the first expected in the second half of next year.

site_title: Synagie reverses from loss to post S$4.1m H1 profit on higher e-commerce activity
summary: SYNAGIE Corporation has posted its first net profit since its IPO in 2018, with a S$4.1 million profit for the half-year ended June 30, 2020. Revenue surged 325.6% to S$38.3 million, driven by a 435.3% increase in e-commerce segment revenue. The company's gross profit jumped 411.9% to S$12.9 million. The profit reversal is attributed to a surge in demand for Covid-19-related products and higher e-commerce activity during the pandemic.

site_title: Chinese cities find virus in Brazilian chicken wings, Ecuadorian shrimp packaging
summary: Chinese cities Shenzhen and Xian have found traces of the new coronavirus on imported frozen food and packaging from Brazil and Ecuador. Samples from frozen chicken wings and shrimp packaging tested positive for the virus. Authorities have taken precautions and tested individuals who may have come into contact with contaminated products, with no positive results found. The discovery raises concerns over food imports and the possibility of contaminated food causing new outbreaks.

site_title: Franklin Templeton in talks to back Allbirds
summary: Franklin Templeton is in talks to invest in shoeemaker Allbirds at a premium to its US$1.4 billion valuation in 2018. The company, founded by Joey Zwillinger and Tim Brown, posted US$190 million in net revenue last year. The talks are ongoing, and funding terms may still change. Representatives for both parties declined to comment on the matter. This investment would mark a significant boost for Allbirds, which has faced challenges due to US tariffs on imported materials, particularly from China.

site_title: SBS Transit's H1 net profit down 27.4% on lower ridership
summary: SBS Transit reported a 27.4% decline in net profit to S$32.6 million for the half-year ended June 30, 2020, due to lower public transport ridership during the COVID-19 pandemic.
