Revenue fell 14.9% to S$603.2 million, mainly due to lower rail ridership. The company benefited from government grants of S$61.6 million, but expects revenue to remain lower in the coming period.

site_title: China's Huawei, ZTE set to be shut out of India's 5G trials
summary: China's Huawei and ZTE are set to be excluded from India's 5G trials due to national security concerns amid strained relations between the two countries. The Ministry of Communications will restart pending discussions on approvals for private companies, citing a new investment rule amendment that restricts bidders from nations sharing land borders with India. The decision echoes actions by the US, UK, and Australia, which have raised red flags about the companies' Chinese government links, and may delay the auction process into next year.

site_title: JTC awards Jalan Papan site tender to SH M&E Engineering for S$7.9m
summary: JTC has awarded the S$7.9 million tender for the 12,266.6 sqm Jalan Papan industrial site to SH M&E Engineering. The site has a 20-year tenure and is zoned for heavier industrial use. The project completion period is 60 months, and the site is the first of three confirmed land parcels under the 2020 industrial government land sales programme.

site_title: Billionaire founder of Japan's Zozo takes stakes in fashion retailers
summary: Billionaire Yusaku Maezawa, founder of Japan's Zozo, has acquired large stakes in two Japanese apparel companies: 8% in United Arrows and 6% in Adastria. The investments are for friendly purposes, with Maezawa potentially offering advice to management. This move follows his sale of Zozo to SoftBank Group last year, earning him around 150 billion yen. Maezawa's investments aim to capitalize on Zozo's wide range of mid- to high-end fashion brands.

site_title: MOM urges condo owners to exercise restraint in activating penalty clauses during Covid-19 period
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) advises condominium owners and management corporations to exercise restraint in activating penalty clauses during the Covid-19 pandemic. The MOM states that close cooperation among stakeholders is needed to ensure the sustainability of the strata management and facility management sectors. MCSTs and building owners should pay management agents and facility management companies according to contract terms unless there are changes in services required. The MOM also advises against asking for reduced contract fees due to wage support from the Jobs Support Scheme.

site_title: DoorDash faces injunction to reclassify some workers as employees
summary: San Francisco's district attorney filed a preliminary injunction against DoorDash to reclassify its contractors as employees, days after a similar request was granted for Uber and Lyft. The injunction applies to all DoorDash workers in California, citing the company's failure to provide basic workplace protections. DoorDash's internal data suggests most workers want to remain as contractors, but the company is opposed to the effort. The move is part of a broader effort to classify app-based workers as employees, with DoorDash spending millions to support a ballot measure opposing the classification.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close slightly lower
summary: Hong Kong shares closed with small losses, dipping 0.05% to 25,230.67, as concerns over US stimulus talks outweighed hopes for a recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index was flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.06%. The losses came despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a surge in the valuation of eSIM platform Airalo.

site_title: Deutsche Telekom diversifies suppliers 'regardless of politics'
summary: Deutsche Telekom has decided to diversify its suppliers of 5G network equipment, regardless of politics, as the company prepares for the introduction of new 5G networks in Germany. The decision comes as officials in Berlin debate whether to ban Chinese firm Huawei from the market due to national security concerns. Despite relying on Huawei for its German 5G network, Deutsche Telekom says its supplier base is broader in European countries, with U.S. and European suppliers accounting for 60% of its networks. The company also called for the use of open, cloud-based technology in German legislation.

site_title: UMS posts 43% rise in Q2 net profit, proposes one Singapore cent interim dividend
summary: UMS Holdings reported a 43% increase in Q2 net profit to S$11.6 million, driven by a 41% rise in semiconductor revenue. Revenue from integrated system sales rose 65% to $19.6 million, while sales in Singapore jumped 60% and revenue in Taiwan increased 20%. The company proposes a one Singapore cent interim dividend and reported a 2.17 Singapore cents earnings per share. UMS chairman and CEO Andy Luong attributed the strong performance to sustained customer demand and diversification strategy, despite uncertainties from the US-China trade war and COVID-19 resurgence.

site_title: Digitalisation will aid construction companies in keeping to safe distancing rules onsite
summary: Singapore construction companies are using digital technologies to maintain safe distancing measures on site amid the COVID-19 pandemic. JTC Corporation has tested AI cameras, facial recognition, and thermal scanners to monitor worker distances and temperatures. A new online platform, BuildSG-CovidSafe, allows employers to track worker information and receive data from installed devices. The platform, developed by the Building and Construction Authority, aims to streamline command and control of workforces and worksites, with plans to roll it out to the rest of the industry by the end of the month.

site_title: Hedge funds make US$1b from bets against travel companies
summary: Hedge funds have made a profit of $1.01 billion from betting against travel companies by the end of July, with $2.98 billion in short positions outstanding. The coronavirus pandemic has led to huge losses and share price falls in the tourism industry, with Europe's travel and tourism share index falling 30% this year. Big hedge funds such as Citadel and Sandbar Asset Management have taken short positions in companies like Deutsche Lufthansa, Accor, and Carnival Corp, earning profits of over $150 million. Despite a recent modest rally, more short-sellers are entering the market, indicating that the story is far from over.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall below 1m
summary: US weekly jobless claims dropped below 1 million for the first time since the Covid-19 pandemic, falling to 963,000 for the week ended August 8. The decline is attributed to the expiration of a $600 weekly jobless supplement, which has been extended to $400 by President Trump's executive order. Economists credit the supplement for the economy's recovery, while some argue it encourages people to stay at home. The US economy has regained only 9.3 million of 22 million jobs lost, with the unemployment rate still high.

site_title: Ex-StanChart banker Osman Faiz joins AMTD Digital
summary: AMTD Digital has appointed Osman Faiz, a former Standard Chartered Bank executive, as its chief information and operating officer. Faiz brings over 25 years of international banking experience, including roles at StanChart and Permata Bank. He will drive regional banking initiatives and enhance operational efficiencies, leveraging expertise in digitalization and product innovation. This appointment is part of AMTD Digital's push for a digital wholesale banking license in Singapore, alongside a consortium led by AMTD Group.

site_title: US to ease water rules after Trump's shower moan
summary: The US Department of Energy is proposing to ease regulations on shower fittings, allowing multiple showerheads on a single fitting to circumvent water conservation measures. The change comes after President Donald Trump complained about water pressure in showers, which he believes are necessary for his "perfect hair." The proposed rule would apply to each showerhead, not the entire fitting, and would not address the issue of water conservation. The move is seen as part of Trump's efforts to roll back environmental regulations.

site_title: Thermo Fisher ditches bid to acquire Qiagen as offer falls short
summary: Thermo Fisher Scientific ended its bid to acquire Qiagen after its tender offer for the Dutch health-care company fell short, with only 47% of Qiagen shares tendered. The minimum threshold for acceptance was not met, resulting in Thermo Fisher paying Qiagen a reimbursement of US$95 million. Some shareholders had sought a higher price, with Davidson Kempner urging others to reject the offer.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower on weak earnings forecasts
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% to 6,091.0, driven by poor earnings forecasts from major banks and utilities. Commonwealth Bank and AGL Energy forecast lower credit growth and earnings, while Telstra Corp and AMP had mixed results. The financial sub-index lost over 1%, with all "Big Four" banks declining between 1.3% and 2.6%. Industrial and healthcare stocks also fell, with some companies, like AMP, rising despite the overall market decline.

site_title: Ho Bee Land's net profit up 115% on increased profits from associates
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED developer Ho Bee Land's net profit for the half-year ended June 30, 2020, rose 115.4% to S$90.6 million, driven by increased profits from associates and jointly-controlled entities. Revenue inched up 1.7% to S$108.8 million, with rental income increasing 2.2%. The company's business outlook remains grim due to the pandemic, but its portfolio of prime offices in Singapore and London contributed to the group's resilience.

site_title: Seoul: Shares notch longest winning streak since June on stimulus hopes
summary: South Korean shares reached their longest winning streak since June, with the Kospi index rising 0.21% to 2,437.53 points. Investors optimism over stimulus hopes and a surprise jump in US inflation drove the gains. The Kospi has risen 10.91% so far this year and 15.5% in the previous 30 trading sessions. Analysts attribute the rally to a strong belief in continued economic support policies.

site_title: Kallang Bahru industrial building up for sale at S$6.5m guide price
summary: An industrial building at 209 Kallang Bahru is up for sale at a guide price of S$6.5 million. The five-storey building has a total site area of 24,380 sq ft and a gross floor area of 52,797 sq ft, zoned Business 1 with a plot ratio of 2.5. The land has a 60-year JTC leasehold tenure with 13 years remaining, starting Aug 16, 1973.

site_title: Singapore not 'in a hurry' to ban plastic bags, minister says
summary: Singapore is not in a hurry to ban plastic bags due to its unique approach of incinerating plastic waste to generate energy, said Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu. Unlike other countries, Singapore's reliance on plastic waste incineration reduces the value of banning plastic bags. The country aims to pursue plastic recycling efforts, particularly through a "bottle-to-bottle" approach, which could create new jobs and export solutions. Despite recycling only 4% of its plastic waste last year, Singapore companies saved over 12 million pieces of single-use plastic under the WWF's Pact initiative.

site_title: Dubai property market heads for two difficult years, says developer Damac
summary: Damac Properties expects a "difficult" two-year period for Dubai's property market due to the ongoing impact of the coronavirus, which has already pushed down prices and subdued demand. Chairman Hussain Sajwani stated that the lead-up to the Dubai Expo in 2021 may help absorb excess supply, and the company will focus on selling completed and near-completion inventory. Real estate prices are expected to drop further, with ratings agencies S&P Global and Moody's predicting a decline amid economic uncertainty and oversupply.

site_title: UOL posts net loss in H1 FY20 due to Covid-19 impact
summary: UOL, a Singaporean property company, posted a net loss of S$82.1 million for the first half of FY20 due to the impact of COVID-19 on its investment properties, including retail malls and serviced suites. Excluding fair value losses, the group's operations remained profitable with S$196.8 million in pre-tax profit, down 30% from the previous year. Revenue declined 28% to S$908.2 million, with the hotel segment experiencing a 57% drop due to lockdowns and travel restrictions.

site_title: Coronavirus: Four out of five community cases announced on Thursday are unlinked
summary: Singapore reported five new community cases of coronavirus, with four of them being unlinked. Three cases were identified through periodic screening of essential services workers, while the remaining unlinked patient was part of a screening effort for front-line Covid-19 operations. This brings the total number of community cases to nine.

images.alt_text: There were 102 new coronavirus cases confirmed as of Thursday noon (Aug 13), taking Singapore's total to 55,497.

site_title: Aegon H1 earnings miss forecasts, cuts dividend on US coronavirus woes
summary: Dutch insurer Aegon reported lower than expected first-half earnings due to the coronavirus pandemic, citing higher mortality and lower interest rates in the US, where it operates two-thirds of its business. The company withdrew its financial guidance and cut its interim dividend to 6 US cents from 15 US cents. New CEO Lard Friese announced measures to preserve capital and review operations, aiming to transform the company into one with reliable results. Solvency declined to 195% from 201% at the end of 2019.

site_title: Local firms saved 12m pieces of single-use plastics in 2019: WWF-Singapore
summary: Local companies in Singapore have made significant strides in reducing single-use plastics under the WWF-Singapore's Pact initiative. In 2019, over 12 million pieces of single-use plastics were saved by 22 companies, including Grand Hyatt Singapore, Cloversoft, and perromart. These companies have implemented changes such as replacing disposable items with reusable options, increasing recycled content, and eliminating unnecessary packaging. The initiative aims to eliminate all unnecessary plastics, reduce single-use plastics by 50%, and support a circular economy by 2030.

site_title: Hot stock: Medtecs sustains rally on tailwinds of strong results, surges 14.2%
summary: Medtecs International Corporation surged 14.2% on Thursday, following the release of its strong half-year earnings report. The company posted a net profit of US$38.9 million, a 101-fold increase from the same period last year. Medtecs' stock price rose from 3.7 cents to S$1.61, representing a gain of 38 times in the year to date. The company's market cap has grown from S$20 million to above S$800 million, with its weightage in the iEdge SG All Healthcare Index increasing to 11.2%.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher on recovery hopes
summary: Tokyo shares reached a six-month high, closing 405.65 points higher or 1.78% at 23,249.61 on the Nikkei 225 index. The gain was driven by hopes for economic recovery, following recent indicators showing momentum toward recovery. Global shares also surged, with investors regaining optimism about economic recovery. The Tokyo market's strength was also boosted by news about progress on coronavirus vaccine development. Despite some sell-on-rallies, the Nikkei index remained at a high level, with the broader Topix index rising 18.62 points or 1.16% to 1,624.15.

site_title: Released tycoon Lai says Hong Kong needs patient, not radical, democracy campaign
summary: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai, a staunch supporter of the city's democracy movement, was arrested under a new national security law and released on bail. Lai urged patience in the "long-term fight" for democracy, saying pro-democracy activists must be flexible and innovative, rather than radical. He called the current situation a "violation of Hong Kong people's belief in wide-ranging freedoms" and likened it to oxygen. Lai's arrest has sparked widespread support, with his newspaper's shares rising by over 2,000% and a rally of supporters taking place.

site_title: Ant's dual listing could double cross Wall Street
summary: Ant Group's dual listing on Shanghai's Star board and Hong Kong stock exchange could significantly impact Wall Street, with fees potentially doubling for foreign banks. The move, which includes selling 10% of shares in Shanghai and 5% in Hong Kong for a combined $30 billion, could reduce Wall Street's share of the IPO and favor Chinese issuers. With Star hosting 77 IPOs raising $12.8 billion this year, Ant's listing could cement its popularity and limit foreign banks' involvement, potentially altering the global IPO landscape.

site_title: Hyflux group of bank lenders files judicial management application
summary: The Hyflux group of bank lenders has filed a judicial management application, following an extension of the deadline to August 12. The unsecured working group, comprising seven banks, had previously expressed concerns over Hyflux's management and sought to carve out their shares of debt from the company's moratorium. This move comes after the group argued that they could no longer trust Hyflux's management to lead any restructuring efforts.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets retreat at open
summary: European stock markets retreated at the opening on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index sliding 1.0% to 6,214.57 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index dipping 0.1% to 13,042.71 points, and the Paris CAC 40 shedding 0.3% to 5,058.86 points. The declines follow a 0.9% gain for the indices on Wednesday. The retreat is attributed to investors taking profits from the previous day's strong gains.

site_title: MAS commits S$250m to further drive innovation, develop Singaporean fintech talent
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has committed S$250 million over three years to enhance its Financial Sector Technology and Innovation Scheme (FSTI 2.0), aiming to accelerate technology and innovation-driven growth in the financial sector. The scheme, which supports early-stage experimentation of technology and innovation labs, will be enhanced with increased funding support, including doubling the maximum funding quantum for Proof-of-Concept projects and introducing a merit-based tiered funding mechanism. The funding also aims to strengthen the adoption of artificial intelligence and develop Singaporean talent in fintech.

site_title: Swire Pacific risks losing Hang Seng Index membership after 50 years
summary: Swire Pacific, a founding member of Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index, risks losing its 50-year membership due to significant declines in its airline business and market value. The company's shares have lost 43% in 2020, making it the least valuable member on the gauge. Chinese technology firms' increasing presence in the market is also a factor, with three companies eligible to join the index despite having unequal voting rights. The next review will be announced after the market closes on Friday.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB calls NetLink defensive yield play, initiates coverage with 'add'
summary: CGS-CIMB has initiated coverage on NetLink NBN Trust with an "add" rating and a target price of S$1.10, citing its defensive yield play due to high barriers to entry, strong earnings visibility, and stability. The analyst views the trust as a better yield play over real estate investment trusts and telcos, with a potential total return of 19% and an attractive dividend yield of 5.4%. NetLink's sole network provider of residential fibre broadband in Singapore offers a resilient business model, with a 94% penetration rate.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp faces pressure to fix steel unit as losses mount
summary: Thyssenkrupp's steel unit, Europe's No 2 player, is expected to rack up €1 billion in operating losses this year due to cheap Chinese imports, high raw material prices, and weak automotive demand. The conglomerate has outlined plans to sell, keep, or combine the division with a peer, with potential partners including Tata Steel, SSAB, and Salzgitter. This move comes as the sector struggles, and the company faces pressure to address the losses and ensure its long-term viability.

site_title: Airbnb quarterly revenue drops 67%; IPO still planned
summary: Airbnb reported a 67% decline in quarterly revenue to $335 million, down from $1 billion last year, due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on global travel. The company recorded a loss of $400 million for the second quarter. Despite this, Airbnb plans to file paperwork to go public and is still aiming for a stock market debut before the end of the year. Bookings began to recover in June, with a 30% decline compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Union Gas shares gain 9% after H1 earnings climb 76.7% on LPG sales
summary: Union Gas Holdings posted a 76.7% surge in net profit to S$7 million for the half year ended June 30, 2020, driven by its retail LPG business. Shares rose 9% to 36.5 Singapore cents, with revenue growing 27.2% to S$43.2 million. The company attributed the increase to higher demand from domestic households and commercial customers. An interim dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent per share was declared. Union Gas is in a strong position to weather the pandemic, with a S$21 million war chest available for expansion opportunities.

site_title: Gold calms down after wild ride as investors weigh next steps
summary: Gold prices stabilize above $1,900 an ounce after a wild swing, with investors weighing the metal's record-setting rally and potential market shifts. Despite a brief surge in US stocks, gold futures dropped, and the metal's price corrected. Despite this, gold and silver remain among the best-performing commodities this year, driven by negative real yields and stimulus measures. Goldman Sachs forecasts further gains, with some analysts predicting record highs above $2,000 an ounce.

images.alt_text: Gold held above US$1,900 an ounce following wild swings as investors weighed the outlook for the metal's record-setting rally, tracking moves in bond yields, a weaker dollar, as well as an uptick in risk appetite.

site_title: Straits Times Index rises 1.28 per cent to 2,595.97 points
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.28% to 2,595.97 points, driven by strong gains in US markets. Jardine conglomerates Jardine Matheson and Jardine Strategic led the gains, with Jardine Matheson rising US$0.83 to US$41.40 and Jardine Strategic gaining US$0.75 to US$20.70. Sembcorp Marine, set to be hived off from STI, ended 2 cents up at 24.5 Singapore cents after a highly dilutive rights issue. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index and Japan's Nikkei 225 Index also rose, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell due to concerns over US stimulus talks.

site_title: New Zealand central bank official says coronavirus resurgence poses risks to outlook
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank of New Zealand Deputy Governor Geoff Bascand warned that a resurgence of the coronavirus pandemic poses a significant risk to the country's outlook. The bank will consider additional monetary stimulus if there are periods of resurgence and longer lockdowns. Bascand stated that the bank is prepared to implement negative interest rates and a "funding for lending" program to support the economy, which has been impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Twitter to expand rules against misinformation on mail-in ballots, early voting
summary: Twitter plans to expand its rules against misinformation on mail-in ballots and early voting ahead of the US 2020 elections. The platform aims to provide accurate information about voting options and roll out new policies and tools in the next month. Twitter is exploring ways to address mischaracterizations of mail-in voting and other procedures. The move comes amid claims by US President Donald Trump that voting by mail is susceptible to large-scale fraud, despite experts saying routine methods and decentralized elections make it difficult to interfere with mailed ballots.

images.alt_text: Twitter said late on Wednesday it plans to expand its rules against misinformation regarding mail-in ballots and early voting in the US elections this year.

site_title: Darco Water issues letter of demand against former CEO
summary: DARCO Water Technologies is issuing a letter of demand against former CEO Thye Kim Meng, alleging breaches of his duties that caused losses and damages of US$1.6 million. The company claims Meng breached his obligations related to a water project and a solar project, resulting in financial losses. Darco demands that Meng pay the amount, with a deadline for written confirmation set for August 12. The company's solicitors will take necessary steps to protect its interest, including commencing legal proceedings if Meng fails to comply.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars edge up, jobs data upbeat but with caveats
summary: Australian and New Zealand dollar currencies edged higher as risk sentiment improved globally, despite a looming lockdown in Victoria state. The Australian dollar rose to US$0.7170, while the kiwi dollar bounced to US$0.6575. The jobs data for Australia was surprisingly upbeat, but with caveats, indicating a cautious market outlook.

site_title: Asia: Markets track US rally but stimulus battle tempers hope
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday, following a rally on Wall Street, but optimism was tempered by US lawmakers' failure to agree on a new rescue package. The US inflation forecast showed a jump in the consumer sector, fueling hopes for an economic recovery. Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai gained 1.9%, 0.2%, and 0.3% respectively, while Seoul, Taipei, and Singapore added 0.7% each. Despite stalled US talks, investors remain hopeful for a fiscal policy support package and a vaccine.

site_title: Australia records significant fall in new virus cases
summary: Australia's virus-hit Victoria state reported a significant drop in new coronavirus cases on Thursday, with 278 new cases and eight deaths detected. The surge in Melbourne, the capital of Victoria, had pushed daily infection rates over 700 in recent weeks. However, officials warned against complacency, citing "worrying" trends in regional areas. Strict measures, including an overnight curfew and shutdown of non-essential businesses, are believed to be bringing the outbreak under control, but authorities remain vigilant and are considering increasing restrictions to match Melbourne's Stage 4 lockdown.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 6.62 points or 0.43% to 1,563.26. The index saw 627.21 million lots traded worth RM218.86 million, with gainers beating losers 411 to 82.

site_title: Australian unemployment ticks up in July, jobs surge again
summary: Australia's unemployment rate reached a 22-year high of 7.5% in July, surpassing the previous record of 7.4% in June. Employment surged by 114,700, but the participation rate rose to 64.7%, leading to a labor supply imbalance. The number of people out of work, actively seeking work, exceeded one million for the first time, marking a significant increase from the previous month.

site_title: Estate agents warn of boom to bust for UK housing market
summary: The UK housing market experienced a surge in July following Chancellor Rishi Sunak's stamp duty holiday, with house prices rising in every region except London. However, real estate agents warn that the momentum is short-lived due to government support for the economy being withdrawn. The Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) predicts a possible slump, with some forecasting a 22% drop in house prices over the next year. This comes as the UK economy remains in recession and government support measures are being tapered.

site_title: DBS, Doxa launch automated supplier payments solution for construction sector
summary: DBS and local fintech Doxa have launched Singapore's first automated supplier payments solution for the construction sector, called Doxa Connex. The solution aims to speed up payments from main contractors to suppliers, improving cash flow management. Main contractor Tiong Seng Group has signed up as the pioneer adopter, expecting to save time and reduce administrative costs by at least 50%. The solution automates the entire process, from invitation to quote to procurement orders and last-mile payments.

site_title: New digital transformation plan for training and adult education sector launched
summary: Singapore's training and adult education sector has launched a new Industry Digital Plan (IDP) to drive digital transformation amid job uncertainties brought by the Covid-19 pandemic. The plan aims to shift the sector towards more learning at the workplace and digitalization, while strengthening the quality of the ecosystem by reducing red tape. Minister of State for Education and Manpower Gan Siow Huang emphasized the need for the sector to adapt to the new normal, highlighting opportunities for growth and the importance of strengthening workplace training and digitalization.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch lower as financials drag; New Zealand gains
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% to 6117.8, driven by losses in financial stocks, including the 'Big Four' banks. The decline followed a similar pattern to the previous day. New Zealand shares rose, however, as the country reported its lowest single-day rise in new coronavirus infections in over three weeks. Financial stocks dominated losses in Australia, with the banks dropping between 1.4% and 2.7%.

site_title: Being a heartbeat away from the US presidency
summary: US presidential candidate Joe Biden has chosen California Senator Kamala Harris as his running mate, making her the first African-American woman and first Asian-American to run for vice president. Harris's selection could be historic, particularly given the current racial tensions in the US, and may help Biden win the support of African-American voters and moderate Republicans. Harris's background as a centrist Democrat and former attorney general of California could also appeal to independents and moderate Republicans. Biden's advanced age and potential health issues raise concerns about his ability to serve as president, and Harris's experience and energy may help alleviate these concerns.

site_title: Manila malls may become e-commerce storage amid retail slump
summary: Manila malls are being repurposed as e-commerce storage facilities amid the retail slump caused by the coronavirus outbreak in the Philippines. SM Prime Holdings is leasing out parking lots for long-term car storage, while Ayala Land is converting mall areas into e-commerce backend facilities and medical clinics. The shift is driven by Filipinos' preference to avoid high-traffic spots and the pressure on retail landlords to adapt to the changing market. This move is seen as a novel alternative use for malls, helping to mitigate the impact of the recession.

site_title: Vicom posts 30.2% drop in first-half earnings, expects periodic testing to pick up
summary: Vicom, a subsidiary of ComfortDelGro Corp, reported a 30.2% drop in first-half earnings to S$9.7 million, from S$13.9 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 22% to S$39.8 million due to lower business volumes during the pandemic. The company expects to fund investments, including a new building and equipment relocation, with an estimated cost of S$25 million. Demand for periodic vehicle testing is expected to pick up, while emission testing and new car type approvals are expected to remain soft due to a carried-over quota.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at open after Wall Street climbs; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% to 2,569.89 at open, following Wall Street's gains overnight. Gainers outnumbered losers 110 to 45, with Medtecs International up 3.6% after posting strong half-year results. The rally marks a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares begin Thursday higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Thursday higher, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.97% to 25,490.02. This followed strong leads from Wall Street, fueled by economic recovery optimism. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.27% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.44%. The rally comes as investors remain positive despite uncertainty from US trade policies.

site_title: Japan's wholesale price fall eases further as economy emerges from coronavirus jolt
summary: Japan's wholesale prices fell 0.9% in July, a smaller annual decline than in June, as the economy began to recover from the coronavirus pandemic. Demand for goods and services picked up after China and many advanced economies lifted lockdowns, leading to declines in petrol, chemical, and nonferrous metal prices. However, fears of a second wave of infections weigh on business and consumer sentiment, suggesting a shallow price recovery. The decline in wholesale prices is a sign the economy is gradually emerging from the pandemic's damage, but the outlook remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Japan's wholesale prices fell at a smaller annual pace in July than in the previous month as global and domestic demand rebounded, a sign the economy was gradually emerging from the damage wrought by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, Singapore Airlines, SIAEC, ST Engineering, Teckwah, glove makers
summary: Stocks to watch include City Developments Limited (CDL), Singapore Airlines, SIAEC, ST Engineering, Teckwah, and glove makers. Key developments include CDL's 99.1% plunge in net profit to S$3.1 million, Singapore Airlines' voluntary release scheme for cabin crew, and Teckwah's conditional cash offer to take the company private. Other companies reported varying results, with Olam International's net profit rising 44.4% to S$332.7 million and Yanlord Land Group's net profit slumping 59% to 492.9 million yuan.

site_title: SIA Engineering senior management takes further pay cuts
summary: SIA Engineering Company's senior management has taken a 5% further cut to their salaries, effective August 1, 2020, resulting in a 20-30% pay cut for top executives. The move is aimed at proactively managing costs due to the challenging business environment caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The company has also implemented cost management measures in previous months and will maintain adequate liquidity to adjust to the evolving situation.

site_title: Sunpower swings into the black with 21.4m yuan Q2 net profit
summary: Sunpower Group, a mainboard-listed company, reported a net profit of 21.4 million yuan (S$4.2 million) for its second quarter, reversing a net loss of 5.2 million yuan a year ago. Revenue jumped 64.5% to 1.08 billion yuan, driven by its manufacturing and services segment and green investments business. The company achieved "new records" in revenue and profit in H1 2020, with group profit margins and operating cash flow above pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: France sees most new daily virus cases since May
summary: France reported its highest daily increase in new coronavirus cases since May, with over 2,500 new cases and a 2.2% weekly positivity rate. Health officials identified 18 new virus clusters, bringing the total to 896 nationwide. The number of patients in intensive care dropped slightly to 379. This increase comes as many French people take summer holiday, prompting officials to urge continued efforts to prevent the epidemic from worsening.

site_title: US dollar slips as stimulus impasse halts rebound
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.2% against a basket of currencies on Wednesday, halted by a stimulus package impasse in Washington. Investors await signs of a resolution to the economic rescue package. US inflation figures are expected to show a year-on-year growth of 1.1%, down from 1.2% in June. The dollar gained against the yen, while the New Zealand dollar fell 0.4% due to interest rate changes by the country's central bank.

site_title: Hot stock: Sembmarine sees heavy volume as shares go ex-rights
summary: Sembcorp Marine (SMM) shares opened at 24 Singapore cents on their first day of ex-rights trading, down 11 cents from the previous day's close. The stock traded within the 24-25 cents range before rising 8.9% to 24.5 cents. About 24.3 million shares were traded by 11:39 am, making SMM the fifth most actively traded on the Singapore bourse. The company's parent, Sembcorp Industries (SCI), also saw mild gains, rising 2.1% to S$1.95. The recapitalization and demerger proposal was approved by shareholders on Tuesday.

site_title: Olam posts 44.4% rise in H1 net profit to S$332.7m
summary: Olam International, an agri and food giant, reported a 44.4% rise in net profit to S$332.7 million for the first half of 2020, driven by a net exceptional gain from divestments and higher average selling prices. Revenue rose 7.1% to S$17.1 billion, but Ebit fell 18.8% due to lower contributions from the Olam Food Ingredients segment. The company attributed the revenue increase to volume growth and attributed the decline in Ebit to adverse prices and margin pressures.

site_title: DBS Vickers fends off competition with scale and ambition
summary: DBS Vickers, part of DBS Bank, has maintained its competitive edge in the brokerage market despite rising competition. The brokerage has tapped into resources from other parts of the bank, such as capital markets, to provide customers with more offerings and access to large IPOs. DBSV has seen a 25% increase in investor roadshows and a 25% increase in income, with trading volumes increasing in a volatile market environment. The brokerage aims to build on this momentum with its fully integrated digital platform, offering trading, advisory, and wealth management solutions.

site_title: Telstra maintains dividend as profit drops 15%
summary: Telstra maintained its final dividend of 5 Australian cents per share, despite a 15.5% drop in annual profit. The company attributed the decline to tougher competition and slower growth in its mobile business. Telstra also announced it will keep redundancies on hold until February 2021 to provide staff with "certainty" during the Covid-19 pandemic. The company expects underlying core earnings of $6.5 billion to $7 billion in fiscal 2021.

site_title: Yanlord H1 profit falls 59% to 492.9m yuan
summary: Chinese property developer Yanlord Land Group reported a 59% drop in net profit to 492.9 million yuan (S$97.5 million) for its half-year ended June 30, 2020, due to a change in product mix. Earnings per share decreased to 25.52 fen from 61.52 fen in the preceding year. The company cited this change as the main reason for the decline.

site_title: Covid-era gaming surge sends Tencent's sales past estimates
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd. has surpassed estimates with a 29% revenue growth to 114.9 billion yuan in the three months ended June, driven by a gaming surge during the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite economic challenges and a US WeChat ban, the company expects a strong year for its gaming business, with analysts highlighting the potential for a Twitch-like streaming platform. However, a delay in a key gaming title, Mobile Dungeon & Fighter, poses a risk to its outlook.

site_title: Europe: Signs of rebounding economic growth sends FTSE 100 to 3-week highs
summary: London's FTSE 100 closed at three-week highs on Wednesday, driven by upbeat monthly economic growth data and strong earnings from motor insurer Admiral, which saw its shares soar to an all-time peak. The FTSE 100 gained 2% as growth restarted in May and quickened by a record single-month increase in June, beating forecasts. Financials, healthcare, and consumer staples led gains, while a surge in crude prices lifted oil stocks, extending the index's gains to a fourth straight session.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rise on solid economic data
summary: Tokyo shares rose on Thursday, driven by overnight gains on major markets, including Wall Street, as investors increased hopes for economic recovery. The Nikkei 225 index jumped 1.21% to 23,120.61, while the Topix index rose 0.84% to 1,619.09. The rally follows a 5-day streak of gains in Singapore stocks, which await GDP data, and a fresh record close on the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Mnuchin accuses Democrats of playing politics on US aid deal
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin accused Democratic leaders of playing politics to block a new emergency pandemic spending package, which he said should be narrowly targeted. A deal has yet to be reached, despite the White House and Democrats agreeing to cut the proposal down to around $2 trillion. President Trump signed an executive order to provide $400 weekly unemployment benefits, while economists warn that pandemic funding pressures may lead to state and local government layoffs.

site_title: Ascott converts some apartments into work suites, eyes cloud kitchens
summary: Ascott Limited, a lodging business unit of CapitaLand, has launched a "work in residence" initiative, transforming selected apartments into work suites to cater to guests' needs. The company is also exploring space-as-a-service opportunities, including hosting cloud kitchens and live-streaming activities. In Singapore, Ascott has partnered with a food tech company to set up a cloud kitchen in one of its properties, offering in-house guests more dining options. This initiative aims to extend Ascott's service offerings and provide more flexible accommodation options for guests.

site_title: Impossible Foods eyes retail sales for further growth in Singapore
summary: Impossible Foods, the maker of plant-based beef patties, is expanding its retail presence in Singapore to drive growth. The Temasek-backed company has seen a 50-fold increase in its US retail footprint in less than six months. Impossible Foods aims to replicate this success in Singapore, despite yet to launch in grocery stores in the Asian market.

site_title: Law could idle operations in California: Uber chief
summary: Uber's CEO Dara Khosrowshahi says the company may have to temporarily idle operations in California if a court doesn't reconsider a ruling forcing drivers to be classified as employees. The ruling, made by a judge, comes after California Attorney General Xavier Becerra filed a lawsuit requiring ride-sharing firms to classify drivers as employees for benefits. Uber and Lyft have pledged to provide benefits through a social safety net, but plan to appeal the decision, potentially buying more time. The companies may pause operations in California, restarting with a smaller service and higher prices.

site_title: The Rock tops Hollywood pay list as Netflix splurges on A-listers
summary: Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson tops the list as Hollywood's top-paid actor for a second year, earning US$87.5 million, according to Forbes' annual ranking. Netflix's lucrative contracts, including Johnson's US$23.5 million fee for Red Notice, contributed to his earnings. The streaming giant shelled out US$140 million for A-listers, including Ryan Reynolds, Mark Wahlberg, and Ben Affleck, who rank second through fourth, respectively.

site_title: US leaves tariffs on Airbus aircraft unchanged at 15%
summary: The US has maintained 15% tariffs on Airbus aircraft and 25% tariffs on other European goods, despite the European Union's efforts to resolve a long-standing dispute over aircraft subsidies. US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer said the EU had not taken necessary actions to come into compliance with World Trade Organization decisions. Airbus expressed regret over the decision, while Boeing hopes for EU-Airbus negotiations to address the dispute. The EU is expected to retaliate with its own tariffs over subsidies for Boeing.

site_title: CDL profit dives 99.1% to S$3.1m for H1 as pandemic hits all segments
summary: CDL, a Singapore-based property and hotels group, reported a 99.1% plunge in net profit to S$3.1 million for the first half of 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact across all business segments. Revenue fell 32.8% to S$1.07 billion, with hotel operations accounting for 82% of the decline. The group's property development and investment properties segments have remained relatively resilient. Despite the challenges, the company is confident in a future recovery, particularly with the availability of a COVID-19 vaccine next year.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ST Engineering appoints Lim Serh Ghee as chief operating officer, effective Oct 1, replacing his current role as president of the aerospace sector. Jeffrey Lam will take over as president of the aerospace sector. United Hampshire US Reit posted a distribution per unit of 1.78 US cents for Q2, meeting forecast expectations, but lower gross revenue and net property income due to the pandemic.

site_title: Wind and solar power at record high in 2020, coal dips: analysis
summary: Wind and solar power reached a record 10% of global electricity production in the first half of 2020, up from 4.6% in 2015. Despite a pandemic-driven decline in power demand, coal generation fell 8.3% due to increased renewable energy output. The growth in renewables has more than doubled since 2015, but experts say it's not enough to limit climate change, with emissions still rising. The Paris Agreement aims for a 7.6% annual emissions cut this decade, and many major economies now generate at least 10% of their electricity from wind and solar.

site_title: US: Tech shares lead stocks higher, Nasdaq +2.1%
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, led by tech shares, with the Nasdaq gaining 2.1% to 11,012.24. The Dow Jones and S&P 500 also increased, with the S&P 500 reaching a fresh record. The rally came despite a deadlock in federal stimulus talks and investors' concerns about US-China trade tensions. Tech companies such as Apple, Facebook, and Netflix surged, while Tesla jumped 13.1% after announcing a stock split. The US Treasury Secretary and lawmakers remained at odds over stimulus package size.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks rallied on Wednesday, with tech shares leading, as investors shrugged off a deadlock in federal stimulus talks while expressing relief at Kamala Harris's selection as the Democratic vice-presidential nominee.

site_title: R Kelly associates charged with intimidating singer's accusers
summary: US federal prosecutors have arrested three associates of R Kelly, accusing them of using harassment and threats to silence women who accused the singer of sex crimes. The associates, identified as Raymond Brown, Derrell Houston, and Robert Briscoe, are charged with intimidating the accusers. Kelly has pleaded not guilty to multiple sex crime charges in Illinois, Minnesota, and New York.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse changes rules to kick Wirecard out of Dax 30
summary: Deutsche Boerse has changed its rules to allow for the swift removal of scandal-hit payments firm Wirecard from the prestigious Dax 30 index. The new rules, effective August 19, require insolvent companies to be removed two trading days' notice. Wirecard filed for insolvency in June after admitting 1.9 billion euros missing from its accounts. The company's stock has plummeted, and several executives, including ex-CEO Markus Braun, have been arrested on fraud suspicions. Wirecard's final day on the Dax 30 will be August 21.

site_title: New Zealand mulls lockdown extension as virus spreads
summary: New Zealand health officials announced a Covid-19 cluster in Auckland has grown, raising concerns a lockdown may be extended. A high school student in Auckland tested positive, with five confirmed cases and four probable cases, linked to close contacts with existing cases. The cluster's growth has prompted health officials to consider extending the lockdown imposed on Auckland after the virus's return.

site_title: Crude rises 2% after draw in US oil stocks spurs demand hope
summary: US crude oil prices rose 2% after government data showed a 4.5 million-barrel decline in inventories, bolstering hopes for fuel demand in the world's largest economy. US fuel demand reached 19.37 million barrels per day, the highest since March. Crude output dropped to 10.7 million barrels per day, supporting crude oil prices. Despite a forecasted decline in US crude production and a decrease in world oil demand, growing uncertainty over a US stimulus package may weigh on prices.

images.alt_text: Crude prices rose more than 2 per cent on Wednesday after government data showed US oil inventories fell across the board, bolstering hopes that fuel demand in the world's biggest economy will withstand the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: More wealthy Hong Kong citizens buying UK properties
summary: Wealthy Hong Kong citizens are buying UK properties, with some viewing them as "bolt holes" due to China's new security law in Hong Kong. The UK has opened its doors to up to three million British National Overseas (BNO) citizens. Estate agents report a surge in interest from Hong Kong residents, with recent online ads achieving 500,000 hits. The trend is also seen in other cities, including Manchester and Bath. The UK property market is buoyant, but agents and lenders are cautious ahead of the winter due to rising unemployment and falling rents.

site_title: Giving back to communities
summary: Four companies - WhyQ, The Social Kitchen, SP Group, and Standard Chartered Bank - are contributing to Singapore's "City of Good" initiative, supporting communities during the COVID-19 pandemic. WhyQ launched a "Gift-a-Meal" initiative, allowing users to sponsor meals for healthcare workers and vulnerable groups. The Social Kitchen launched two projects, Project SG Makan and Project Makan 2.0, to support local food and beverage businesses and provide meals to families in need. SP Group partnered with agencies to aid seniors with mobility issues, while Standard Chartered Bank contributed to various initiatives, including employee volunteering and supporting students and seniors impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Australia detains cargo ships for alleged labour abuse
summary: Australian authorities have detained at least two cargo ships, the Unison Jasper and the Ben Rinnes, for alleged labour violations. The ships, carrying materials for Cargill Inc and Rio Tinto Group, were detained for failing to ensure seafarers' employment and social rights, including payment of wages, crew repatriation, and provision of fresh food. The detention follows a global crew-change crisis caused by the Covid-19 pandemic, with an estimated 250,000 seafarers working beyond their contract dates. The ships will be detained until they can adequately address the violations.

site_title: More than 7,800 HDB BTO flats in 8 estates launched in combined sales exercise
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has launched a combined sales exercise for 7,862 new Build-to-Order (BTO) flats in eight estates across Singapore. The estates include Bishan, Ang Mo Kio, Geylang, Pasir Ris, Tampines, Choa Chu Kang, Tengah, and Woodlands. The flats are priced from S$90,000 for a two-room flexi flat to S$484,000 for a four-room flat, with applications closing on August 18. This is the second BTO launch of the year, following February's sales exercise, and is expected to meet the demand for new housing options in Singapore.

site_title: Cathay sees low passenger demand, stronger cargo after record loss
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways reported a record first-half loss of HK$9.87 billion due to low passenger demand, but a 44.1% increase in cargo yields. The airline slashed flying capacity in response to the pandemic, and expects a meaningful recovery in passenger demand to take time. Despite this, Cathay sees a brighter cargo market outlook. The airline's revenue plunged 48.3% in the first half.

site_title: A more robust sponsor-based regime for Catalist is needed
summary: A report on Catalist, a sponsor-based regime in Singapore, highlights the need for a more robust system to address conflicts of interest and ensure transparency. The regime has seen 39% of issuers change sponsors in the past decade, with some companies having multiple sponsors. This can lead to conflicts of interest and impaired sponsor responsibilities. The report also notes that many Catalist issuers underperform financially, with 56.5% making losses in FY2019. To address these issues, the Singapore Exchange (SGX) should increase the number of full sponsors, require sponsors to disclose Registered Professionals (RPs) involved, and implement stricter restrictions on sponsor work.

site_title: Apple on cusp of US$2t milestone, defying global pandemic
summary: Apple is on the cusp of becoming the first US$2 trillion American company, defying the global pandemic with strong sales of gadgets, wearables, and new apps and services. The company's shares have roughly doubled from March lows, lifting CEO Tim Cook's net worth to $1 billion. Apple's success can be attributed to its iPhone ecosystem, robust sales of iPads and Mac computers, and its expansion into services such as music, digital payments, and streaming television. Analysts believe Apple's growth momentum will continue, with a "once-in-a-decade" opportunity for iPhone upgrades and replacements. However, the company faces risks from heightened tensions with China and potential headwinds from a possible ban on Chinese-owned apps.

images.alt_text: Shares in Apple have roughly doubled from March lows, an astonishing performance which has lifted CEO Tim Cook's net worth to US$1 billion for the first time, according to a Bloomberg calculation.

site_title: Medtecs soars 44.6% after strong H1 results
summary: Medtecs International Corporation's shares surged 44.6% after reporting strong half-year earnings, with a net profit of US$38.9 million and revenue of US$162.6 million, a nearly 5-fold increase from the same period last year. The company attributed the growth to increased demand for personal protective apparel and higher gross profit margins. An interim dividend of 0.85 US cents has been declared, and the company expects revenue for the second half to exceed the first half, driven by long-term supply contracts and new orders.

site_title: Teckwah's biggest shareholders make cash offer of S$0.65 a share to take company private
summary: A consortium led by Chua Seng Tek Holdings has made a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$0.65 per share to take Teckwah Industrial Corporation private. The offeror has secured 58.04% of the shares and is seeking 90% valid acceptances. The offer price represents a 30-42.5% premium over the closing price and exceeds the highest ever closing price of S$0.555. The offer is intended to provide shareholders with cash certainty and avoid brokerage costs, amid economic uncertainty and low trading liquidity.

site_title: With Sabana Reit merger in question, will ESR move on to next target?
summary: ESR-Reit's proposed merger with Sabana Reit hangs in the balance as nearly all minority unitholders must agree to the deal, with activist fund managers Quarz and Black Crane opposing the transaction. The merger would require over 75% of individual unitholders to vote in favor, with those present and voting representing at least 50% of units. ESR-Reit's sponsor, ESR, holds 20.88% of Sabana Reit, while Quarz and Black Crane collectively control 10%. The deal's fate is uncertain, with some analysts suggesting that Sabana Reit's manager has not fully explored alternative options to boost the Reit's valuation.

site_title: SGX-listed glove makers nosedive on vaccine news, profit-taking
summary: Singapore-listed glove makers Top Glove, Riverstone Holdings, and UG Healthcare saw their shares plummet on Wednesday, shedding gains from recent weeks, following news about Covid-19 vaccines in Russia, Singapore, and the US. The announcements of effective vaccines are expected to curb Covid-19's spread, dampening demand for gloves, leading to profit-taking among investors. Despite this, analysts remain bullish on the glove sector, citing structural demand growth and increased production capacity.

site_title: It's (almost) business as usual at the Salzburg Festival
summary: The Salzburg Festival in Austria is proceeding with concerts, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. A 71-year-old attendee, Jos Baeck, traveled from Belgium to attend the festival, which has been a summer tradition for nearly half a century. The festival is continuing with events, marking a return to normalcy after a year of disruptions.

site_title: After four months in lockdown, some workers just want to go home
summary: Singapore's lockdown of 323,000 migrant workers in dormitories has been prolonged for four months, with some workers serving consecutive stay-home notices despite testing negative. The government plans to start small-scale trials for residents to visit recreation centers on their rest days, but workers express frustration and anxiety over being unable to return home. Many workers are paid minimal wages, and some have resorted to desperate measures, including threatening suicide. The government aims to allow residents from cleared dorms to enjoy their rest days without movement restrictions by October, but workers remain trapped in a cycle of uncertainty.

site_title: Straits Times Index inches up 0.75% to 2,563.20
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.75% to 2,563.20 on Wednesday, with Wilmar International leading the gains after a 38.7% increase in net profit for the half year. The STI had 220 decliners compared to 215 advancers. Asian markets performed better, with South Korean and Hang Seng Indexes up, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped.

site_title: Temasek, Bayer form new company to sell seeds to vertical farms
summary: Temasek Holdings Pte and Bayer AG formed a new company, Unfold, to develop seeds for vertical farms. Unfold raised US$30 million in an initial funding round and gained rights to germplasm from Bayer's vegetable portfolio. The partnership aims to provide high-quality seeds for the growing vertical farming industry.

site_title: London trophy apartment sells for £18.6m after hefty 26% discount
summary: A London apartment once owned by the Onassis family has been sold for £18.6m, a 26% discount from its asking price. The 47 Grosvenor Square property, restored to its former glory, was a fashionable social hub in the 1960s and 1970s. The sale comes as London's wealthiest districts struggle to achieve desired asking prices, with prices down 1.7% in the three months through July. Ultra-high-net-worth buyers are seeking trophy properties in Mayfair, presenting an opportunity for sellers.

site_title: Occidental's lone Permian rig shows severity of shale bust
summary: Occidental Petroleum Corp will operate with just one oil rig in the Permian Basin for the remainder of the year, representing a 95% decline in drilling. The company, heavily indebted with a $40 billion debt pile, is scaling back production and slashing its capital budget by over half. US shale production is expected to decline, with oil production forecast to reach 10.1 million barrels per day, 20% lower than at the start of the year, and only increasing by 350,000 barrels per day next year.

site_title: Condo, HDB rents in July see first uptick since February
summary: Singapore's rental housing market showed a mixed picture in July, with HDB rents rising 1.4% for the first time in four months, while private condo and apartment rents increased 0.4%. The rise in HDB rents may be due to demand from Malaysian workers or their employers, while private unit rents rose in suburbs and city-fringes, but fell in prime districts. Leasing demand for both HDB and private units declined, with private condo and apartment leasings falling 7.2% and HDB flats falling 19.1%.

site_title: Fashion fights back with virtual festival of style
summary: Singapore fashion designer Max Tan is celebrating his 10th year with a virtual fashion festival, "The Front Row," which features 40 local and Asian designers. The event showcases the industry's resilience in the face of the global pandemic crisis. The festival is a show of strength for the fashion industry, with designers sharing their creative ways to stay in the game and supermodels discussing their career and the industry. The event highlights the power of staying talent and staying power in the fashion world.

site_title: Sponsor issues notice of breaches to Eagle Hospitality Trust
summary: Urban Commons, the sponsor of Eagle Hospitality Trust, has sent a breach notice to the trust, claiming it has injected "millions of dollars" to subsidize rent and reserves, but is now due for repayment. UC also claims it has a plan to provide financial support, but has been hindered by EHT's lack of cooperation. A forensic accounting investigation into UC has been launched by FTI Consulting, and UC's co-founders have resigned from EHT's manager due to concerns about unnecessary steps and wasted funds.

site_title: Biden picks Harris as White House running mate
summary: US President Joe Biden has selected Senator Kamala Harris as his running mate, making her the first black woman on a major party US presidential ticket. Harris, a 55-year-old senator from California, will help mobilize African-Americans, a crucial constituency for Democrats. The historic choice aims to unify the American people and counter Republican President Donald Trump's base. Harris is also the first Asian-American on a major presidential ticket, and her selection is seen as a key factor in boosting the Biden campaign's grassroots fundraising and voter turnout.

site_title: Brent Scowcroft's legacy is more relevant than ever right now
summary: Brent Scowcroft, a 95-year-old former US national security adviser, has left a lasting legacy in the world of public service. Known for his integrity, Scowcroft was the model for a modern lieutenant-general and served three US presidents, including Gerald Ford and George HW Bush. He advocated for a fair-minded approach to policy-making, prioritizing the president's awareness of all opinions and ensuring that key advisers felt heard. Scowcroft's legacy is more relevant than ever, as the current administration struggles with national security issues and the importance of personal and policy integrity.

site_title: US consumer prices accelerate in July
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.6% in July, exceeding expectations, driven by increases in auto and apparel costs. Core CPI, excluding volatile food and fuel costs, rose 0.6% for the first time in nearly three decades. Annual core inflation increased to 1.6%, a four-month high, suggesting inflation may return to pre-crisis levels. The rebound in demand from pandemic-induced lockdowns is fueling the price gains, despite the Federal Reserve's expectations of low inflation and near-zero interest rates.

site_title: New York accuses egg producer of price gouging in pandemic
summary: New York's Attorney General Letitia James has accused Hillandale Farms, a major egg producer, of price gouging during the COVID-19 pandemic. The company allegedly quadrupled egg prices in March and April, targeting distributors in New York City and military installations. The lawsuit claims Hillandale profited $4 million from customers during a time of crisis, rather than offsetting increased costs. The company denies the accusations, stating that egg prices have historically been volatile and are now lower than in August 2019.

site_title: SIA offers cabin crew voluntary release scheme
summary: Singapore Airlines is offering a voluntary release scheme (VRS) for its cabin crew due to the impact of the pandemic on travel demand. The scheme, which is open until end-August, allows crew members to opt for early release or retirement with payouts and benefits. The move aims to help the airline group deal with surplus cabin crew amid a decline in flying hours and travel demand. The airline has already seen 4,000 cabin crew apply for a separate voluntary no pay leave scheme, and shares rose 8 cents on Wednesday following the announcement.

site_title: ABN Amro cuts a third of investment bank after virus losses
summary: ABN Amro Bank NV is cutting its investment bank by about a third, shutting down lending outside of Europe, and exiting trade and commodity financing. The move is aimed at turning around the business hit hard by the coronavirus crisis. The bank will retain its global clearing business and expects to incur significant impairments, including a net loss of 5 million euros for the quarter. The decision may result in up to 800 job losses over three to four years, with the bank focusing on European clients in the affected businesses.

site_title: BCA announces measures for construction restart
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore has announced measures to accelerate the resumption of construction work, including allowing companies to resume work outside construction sites without approval and temporarily suspending the 10-accommodation criteria. Over 3,300 projects have been approved to resume work, with 40,000 workers expected to benefit. Employers are required to cohort their workers in dormitories and implement safe management measures. BCA will closely monitor the situation, stepping up audits and inspections at worksites, and has temporarily suspended the 10-accommodation restriction to allow more workers to resume work.

site_title: UK suffers worst recession on record
summary: The UK has suffered its worst recession on record, with a 20.4% plunge in output in the second quarter, the most since records began in 1955. This is worse than any major European economy and marks the country's first recession since 2009. The recession is attributed to the coronavirus lockdowns, with massive job losses and widespread economic damage. The government is under pressure to ensure the withdrawal of support programmes doesn't derail the recovery, with economists expecting the Bank of England to boost monetary stimulus later this year.

site_title: Chinese banks move to comply with US sanctions on HK officials
summary: Chinese state-run banks, including Bank of China, China Construction Bank, and China Merchants Bank, are taking steps to comply with US sanctions on Hong Kong officials, aiming to preserve access to dollar funding and global financial markets. The banks have become cautious in opening new accounts for the sanctioned officials and are reviewing transactions via the US. Foreign lenders like Citigroup have also suspended or increased scrutiny of Hong Kong clients. The move underscores the US ability to use the dollar's dominance in international transactions as a pressure point in the China-US standoff.

site_title: US consumer prices accelerate in July
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.6% in July, accelerating to a 1.0% year-over-year gain. This exceeded economists' forecasts of a 0.3% monthly increase and 0.8% year-over-year growth. Despite the uptick, high unemployment is expected to keep inflation under control, allowing the Federal Reserve to continue monetary support for the recovering economy.

site_title: Bill Cosby files new appeal over sexual assault conviction
summary: Bill Cosby has filed a new appeal against his conviction for drugging and sexually assaulting a woman 15 years ago. Cosby's lawyers argue that five women who gave evidence at his trial prejudiced the jury and that deposition testimony from a civil case should not have been heard in court. The 83-year-old actor, serving a 3.5-year prison sentence, claims it was "fundamentally unfair" that the testimony was used. This is his second appeal, with his previous one ruled against him in December.

site_title: Airbnb close to filing for IPO after travel rebound
summary: Airbnb is planning to file paperwork for a stock market listing, potentially starting trading in the fourth quarter of this year. The San Francisco-based company is preparing to submit documents confidentially with the US Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering (IPO). This move comes after the Covid-19 pandemic sent the travel industry into a tailspin, but Airbnb has seen a rebound in bookings. The company is working with Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs Group on its IPO, following a shift from its original plan to list directly.

site_title: Global firms face heightened risk dealing with fallout in US-China ties
summary: Global firms face heightened risk due to the deteriorating US-China ties, with trade policy becoming a key risk factor. According to Allianz, changes in legislation and regulation, including trade wars and economic sanctions, ranked third in a 2020 global ranking of top business risks. The US has taken steps to isolate China, including expelling Chinese journalists and closing its consulate in Houston, while China has retaliated with sanctions on US citizens. The financial sector is a battleground, with US sanctions having a significant impact on companies like Citi and Standard Chartered.

site_title: Construction firms tell of the delays and triumphs in managing workers
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore has announced measures to hasten the restart of on-site construction work, easing restrictions on foreign workers and allowing companies to resume work outside construction sites without prior approval. The measures include suspending the "10 accommodation" requirement and allowing all firms and workers to resume work without prior clearance. Companies have expressed mixed reactions, with some welcoming the easing of measures and others citing challenges in managing large numbers of workers and navigating government guidelines.

site_title: Higher gold prices push gold mining stocks up; M&A activity expected
summary: Gold prices reached an all-time high above US$2,000 an ounce, but gold miners may not be benefiting from the increase due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on operations. Industry consolidation is expected, despite higher prices. Companies have had to dial back operations due to government restrictions, affecting the gold mining industry.

site_title: Centurion, already under pressure, braces for greater impact of Covid-19
summary: Centurion Corp, a Singapore-based dormitory operator, is bracing for the impact of COVID-19 on its business. The company has seen increases in requests for lease term reviews and rent deferrals, and a slowdown in rent collections due to government assistance. Centurion has set aside a provision for doubtful debts and will pause expansion plans until the COVID-19 situation normalizes. The company's profits rose 16% in the first half, but earnings declined 10% in the second quarter due to additional operating expenses and lower occupancy in its student accommodation segment.

site_title: Teckwah's biggest shareholders makes voluntary cash offer of S$0.65 to take it private
summary: A consortium led by Chua Seng Tek Holdings, Lee Kay Huan Holdings, and Airjet Investments has made a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$0.65 per share to take Teckwah Industrial Corporation private, securing 58.04% of shares. The offer is conditional on 90% valid acceptances and aims to delist the company from the Singapore Exchange to optimize management and resources amid economic uncertainty. The offer price represents a 30% premium over the closing price on July 27, 2020.

site_title: Catalist issuers underperforming, sponsor conflicts need fixing: study
summary: A study by NUS found that over half of the companies listed on SGX's Catalist board incurred losses in fiscal year 2019, with longer-listed companies more likely to underperform. The study also raised concerns about the quality of listings and the independence of top Catalist sponsors, citing potential conflict-of-interest issues. This has sparked worries about the quality of listings on the secondary board, designed for fast-growth companies.

images.alt_text: More than half the companies listed on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) incurred losses for fiscal year 2019, with those having been listed longer more likely to underperform.

site_title: Singapore's openness is advantage amid supply chain changes: Chan
summary: Singapore's openness in trade policy is expected to benefit the country amid global supply chain changes, said Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing. Despite potential trade tensions, Singapore can remain an integrator and a base for businesses, welcoming everyone to operate. This stance will help the country navigate the global economic landscape and potentially capitalize on new trade opportunities.

site_title: AI/ML : Steroid of choice for smart warehouses
summary: A surge in online orders during the COVID-19 pandemic has sparked two "foot races" in the logistics industry: within warehouses and in last-mile deliveries. To keep up with the increased demand, companies are adopting artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML) to optimize warehouse operations and last-mile delivery routes. AI/ML can automate up to 70% of warehouse tasks and optimize delivery paths, saving time, manpower, and fuel. The adoption of AI/ML is seen as crucial to the future of e-commerce, with the potential to create new job opportunities and improve supply chain efficiency.

site_title: Microsoft prices its dual-screen Android phone at US$1,399, will arrive Sept 10
summary: Microsoft's dual-screen Android phone, the Surface Duo, will be priced at US$1,399 and arrive in stores on September 10. The device features two traditional screens separated by a hinge, synchronizing to work together, and is positioned as a tool for productivity, similar to dual-monitor setups. Unlike Samsung's Galaxy Z Fold 2, the Duo uses traditional screens instead of flexible glass.

site_title: America's testing failure means it is still flying blind
summary: The US economy is struggling due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with national income and output 12% below the start of the year. Experts warn that repealing lockdowns could lead to a surge in infections and deaths, harming business activity. With widespread testing failure, the US is "flying blind," making it difficult to forecast the future of the pandemic and its impact on the economy. To recover, the US needs to focus on two objectives: controlling the virus and putting people back to work in high-contact occupations. Competent governance is essential, but given current trends, the worst-case scenario is likely.

site_title: Taiwan's leader urges more nations to press China over Hong Kong
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen called on the international community to condemn China's crackdown on Hong Kong, describing Beijing's approach as "antithetical" to democracy. Tsai, who leads a "bastion of democracy" in the Indo-Pacific, praised US and UK for speaking out against China. Her remarks come amid heightened tensions between the US and China over Hong Kong and 5G technology. Tsai reiterated Taiwan's willingness to engage in dialogue with China but emphasized the island's ability to defend itself, amid concerns of accelerated Chinese plans to gain control over Taiwan.

site_title: Three in four jobs in financial sector go to locals: MAS
summary: Singapore's financial sector created 22,000 net jobs between 2015 and 2019, with 75% of these jobs going to locals. The sector has continued to grow, with 1,500 new jobs created in the first half of 2020. However, retrenchments in the sector are expected to pick up due to the country's recession. To mitigate this, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Institute of Banking and Finance (IBF) are investing in workforce development programs, including reskilling and training subsidies. Financial institutions such as Standard Chartered and DBS have also committed to hiring and training local talent.

images.alt_text: Singapore's financial sector created 22,000 net jobs between 2015 and 2019, and of these, three out of four jobs went to locals, said a top official from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) on Wednesday.

site_title: PropNex's Q2 net profit nearly doubles to S$7.3m
summary: PropNex, a Singaporean real estate agency, reported a net profit of S$7.26 million for the second quarter, nearly doubling from S$3.7 million last year. Revenue climbed 15% to S$105.93 million, driven by higher commission income from project marketing services. The company declared an interim dividend of 1.5 cents and expects private new home sales to pick up in the remaining year. Net profit for the half year reached S$14.84 million, up 161%. The company's shares closed flat at 54 Singapore cents.

site_title: Shell eyes stake in Nayara's US$9b Indian petchem project
summary: Royal Dutch Shell plans to acquire a 50% stake in Indian-based Nayara Energy's planned $9 billion petrochemical project, valued at $8 billion-$9 billion. The project, set to be completed in five years, will produce 1.8 million tonnes of ethylene and 10.75 million tonnes of petrochemicals per year. The project, along with refinery expansion, is estimated to cost nearly $17.39 billion. The Indian environment ministry is set to hold a meeting on the project on August 29-30.

site_title: SoftBank-backed KE set to raise US$2.1b in US IPO
summary: KE Holdings Inc, a Chinese online property platform backed by Softbank Group Corp and Tencent Holdings Ltd, is set to raise US$2.1 billion in its US IPO, priced above an indicative range of US$17 to US$19 per share at US$20 each. The company's valuation is estimated at US$22.5 billion, making it the largest float by a Chinese company in the US since iQiyi Inc in 2018. Despite concerns over worsening US-China tensions, Chinese companies have received a warm reception from US investors, with Li Auto Inc raising US$1.1 billion in a US IPO last month.

site_title: Stock surge in Jimmy Lai's firm unravels after regulator warning
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission warned investors to exercise "extreme caution" after shares of Next Digital, Jimmy Lai's media company, surged 1,100% in two days. The company's stock fell 41% on Wednesday, reversing the gains. The regulator's warning followed the buying frenzy, which was fueled by pro-democracy activists and supporters of Lai after his arrest on suspicion of breaching the national security law. Other pro-democracy-linked companies also saw significant gains before falling back.

site_title: Goldman Sachs, Barclays among bidders for GM's credit card business
summary: Goldman Sachs and Barclays are among the bidders for General Motors' credit card business, which has approximately $3 billion in outstanding balances. Goldman aims to expand its consumer banking arm, while Barclays sees the opportunity to tap into GM's e-commerce technology. GM's cars feature in-dash e-commerce capabilities, allowing drivers to order services on the go. A decision is expected in the next few weeks, as Goldman seeks to strengthen its consumer banking presence and compete with peers like JPMorgan Chase & Co and Citigroup.

site_title: China jewellery group Kingold to delist from Nasdaq
summary: China's jewelry group Kingold Jewelry plans to voluntarily delist from the Nasdaq stock exchange, citing high listing costs and financial concerns. The decision comes after a report alleging the company obtained loans using fake gold bars, which Kingold chairman Jia Zhihong denied.
