Kingold shares fell 33.6% in premarket trade and are expected to be suspended from trading on August 21, with delisting effective August 31. The company's board decided not to appeal the decision and instead opted for voluntary delisting.

site_title: DPM Heng in talks with business and union leaders on effectiveness of support measures to save jobs
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat met with business and union leaders to discuss the effectiveness of job-saving measures, amid Singapore's worst-ever Q2 GDP performance and a likely deepening impact on the labor market due to the pandemic. The talks, which included other office holders and union leaders, aim to assess the impact of support measures and make necessary adjustments. The discussions follow Singapore's economic challenges, including a recent study on becoming a global hub for advanced chip packaging.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher with eyes on stimulus
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by a fall in US crude stockpiles and oil prices, which rose 2.5%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.63%, the S&P 500 edged closer to an all-time high, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.88%. Despite the positive start, investors remain cautious due to a stalemate over a new coronavirus relief bill.

site_title: 3 dead after train derails in Scotland
summary: A passenger train derailed in northeast Scotland, killing three people. The incident occurred in a wooded area near Stonehaven, following heavy rain overnight. Dark smoke was seen billowing from the scene. First Minister Nicola Sturgeon described the incident as "extremely serious." Despite efforts by paramedics, the three victims were pronounced dead at the scene.

site_title: Urban Commons issues notice of breaches to Eagle Hospitality Trust
summary: Urban Commons, the sponsor of Eagle Hospitality Trust, has sent a breach notice to EHT, claiming it injected "millions of dollars" to subsidize rent and reserves, but funds are now outstanding. UC alleges EHT's trustee and advisors are obstructing its plan to provide financial support. A forensic accounting investigation into UC has been initiated by EHT's managers, amid allegations of wrongdoing by UC and its master lessees. The move has caused mistrust among EHT unitholders and damaged UC's reputation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 8.1 points lower on Wednesday at 1,556.64. Volume was 19.2 billion lots worth RM7.985 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 907 to 315.

site_title: ST Engineering announces leadership changes
summary: ST Engineering announces leadership changes, effective October 1. Lim Serh Ghee, current president of aerospace sector, will become chief operating officer, driving operational and cost efficiencies. Jeffrey Lam, current deputy president of aerospace sector, will take over as president, focusing on growth and global integration. Eleana Tan will retire as chief corporate officer, with Vincent Chong praising her contributions and thanking her for her service. The changes aim to strengthen leadership and enable the group to navigate challenges and prepare for long-term growth.

site_title: SIA introduces voluntary release scheme for cabin crew
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is introducing a voluntary release scheme for cabin crew as expectations of a slow recovery in travel mount. The scheme, which is open until August, offers early release or retirement with payouts and benefits. With international travel expected to not return to pre-Covid levels until 2024, the VRS aims to help the airline deal with surplus cabin crew. This comes as SIA and other airlines around the world face challenges due to the pandemic, with pilots and ground staff also agreeing to cost-cutting measures.

site_title: Media mogul Sumner Redstone dead at 97
summary: Sumner Redstone, a media mogul who built ViacomCBS through a series of high-profile takeovers, has died at 97. Redstone's company, National Amusements, announced his death, citing declining health. He built his empire from a drive-in movie chain and led the hostile takeover of Viacom in the 1980s, acquiring Paramount Pictures and CBS. Redstone stepped back from an operational role at 92 and became chairman emeritus, amid a court battle over his mental fitness. His daughter Shari Redstone effectively controlled the empire, but family members had disputed her control.

site_title: Sri Lanka president strengthens Rajapaksa dynasty in new government
summary: Sri Lanka President Gotabaya Rajapaksa has strengthened his family's grip on power by naming two relatives to his new government. His brother Mahinda will lead the government, while Gotabaya will control the defense portfolio, and their elder brother Chamal will keep his position as a Cabinet member. The move comes after the nationalist party's landslide win in a parliamentary election, allowing them to change the constitution and tighten their hold on power.

site_title: Teckwah Industrial's net profit up 16.2% on increase in income received from govt Covid-19 support schemes
summary: Teckwah Industrial's net profit rose 16.2% to S$5.29 million for the half-year ended June 30, driven by increased income from government Covid-19 support schemes. Revenue decreased 2.5% to S$76.69 million due to a decline in its packaging printing-related business. The company declared an interim dividend of 0.5 Singapore cents, unchanged from last year. Its cash and cash equivalents increased by 7.5% to S$50.6 million. Despite the challenges posed by the pandemic and geopolitical tensions, the company plans to manage costs and explore new revenue sources.

site_title: For the art collector with everything, the US$1.5m Covid mask
summary: An Israeli jeweller, Yvel, is crafting a US$1.5 million gold mask studded with 3,600 black and white diamonds, with an N99 filter, for an unnamed US-based Chinese art collector. The client is described as wealthy and outgoing, and the mask will be a work of art rather than a display of wealth. The project involves around 25 artisans and is expected to be completed in October. The jeweller views the mask as a way to protect factory workers' families, rather than a lavish display, and it may be the most expensive mask in the world.

site_title: SoftBank-backed KE set to raise US$2.1b in US IPO
summary: KE Holdings, a Chinese online property platform backed by SoftBank and Tencent, is set to raise $2.1 billion in its US IPO, pricing shares at $20 each, above its initial range of $17-$19. This is the largest US IPO by a Chinese company since iQiyi's $2.4 billion raise in 2018. The strong demand for the offering underscores the growing interest in Chinese companies going public in the US.

site_title: Aruna raises US$5.5m from East Ventures, AC Ventures and Sinar Mas' SMDV
summary: Aruna, a marine and fisheries startup, has raised US$5.5 million in a Series A round from East Ventures, AC Ventures, and SMDV, its existing backers. The funding will be used to expand its reach to more fishermen in Indonesia and scale its operations into new domestic and export markets. The startup's revenue grew 86 times in the first half of 2020, driven by its expansion and increased demand for fresh sea products. Aruna's digital platform connects fishermen to buyers, cutting out the middleman and increasing their profits.

site_title: 800 migrant workers newly quarantined after case discovered in cleared dormitory
summary: Eight hundred migrant workers in Singapore have been quarantined after a case was discovered in a cleared dormitory. The Ministry of Health has not named the dormitory. Despite the Inter-Agency Taskforce completing testing for all workers, about 22,800 workers remain in quarantine. The quarantine period is ongoing.

site_title: Banyan Tree sinks deeper into the red in H1 2020 on Covid-19 impact
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings reported a net loss of S$49.15 million for the six months ended June 30, 2020, widening from a loss of S$2.69 million a year ago due to the impact of Covid-19. Revenue declined 43% to S$75.36 million, affecting hotel investments and fee-based segments. The loss per share increased to 5.85 Singapore cents, compared to 0.32 Singapore cents previously. Travel restrictions, limited airlift, and lockdowns significantly impacted the company's operations.

site_title: STI up 0.75 per cent to 2,563.20
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.75% to 2,563.20 on Wednesday, driven by a 2.1% increase in Wilmar International's net profit. Medtecs International saw its price rise 44.6% after posting a half-year net profit more than 100 times higher than last year's. Despite this, Top Glove fell 0.84% and was the top decliner. Asian markets also performed well, with South Korean shares rising for the eighth straight session.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks post fresh gains
summary: Hong Kong shares closed with gains, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.42% to 25,244.02, boosted by a report that transfer flights to China could resume soon. The Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.63%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 1.26%.

site_title: Malaysian retailer Mr DIY revives US$500m IPO plan
summary: Malaysian retailer Mr DIY Group is reviving its US$500 million initial public offering (IPO) plan, which was postponed in March due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company aims to restart marketing in September and gauge investor interest before potentially launching the IPO in October. This would be the largest IPO in Malaysia since 2017 and could boost the country's stock market, which has seen a slow year with only US$70.7 million worth of IPOs. Mr DIY's sales surged in May and June after the government lifted restrictions.

site_title: ASOS upgrades sales and profit outlook on strong demand, less returns
summary: British online fashion retailer ASOS upgraded its full-year sales and profit outlook, citing stronger-than-expected demand and lower returns. The company now expects revenue growth of 17-19% and pretax profit of £130-150 million. ASOS attributed the better-than-expected performance to robust demand for activewear during the COVID-19 lockdown, which has led to a prolonged shift in customer behavior towards more intentional purchasing. Despite this, the company warned that the consumer and economic outlook remains uncertain.

site_title: China Everbright Water H1 profit drops 3.8% as construction service revenue falls
summary: China Everbright Water reported a 3.8% drop in net profit to HK$404.5 million for the first half of 2020, primarily due to a decline in construction service revenue. Revenue fell 14.7% to HK$2.12 billion, affected by the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on construction progress. The company maintained steady progress in market expansion and project construction, and plans to explore digitalization of management processes to promote urban water business development.

site_title: Bintan Lagoon Resort to close down as Bintan tourism struggles amid Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Bintan Lagoon Resort, a 26-year-old 450-room, five-star resort in Indonesia, will close due to the COVID-19 pandemic's devastating impact on global tourism. Declining visitor numbers and tourism receipts led to the resort laying off 500 employees. The resort's demise is attributed to the pandemic's effects on travel and tourism, highlighting the industry's struggles.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly drop on worries over US stimulus
summary: Asian markets dropped on concerns that US lawmakers might not agree on a fresh stimulus deal, despite expectations of a massive rescue package. Despite initial optimism, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's statement that progress had not been made sparked a sell-off, particularly in Hong Kong and Shanghai. The deadlock between Republicans and Democrats is now at risk of dragging on for weeks, deflating near-term optimism and causing gold prices to fall over 5%.

site_title: Temasek, Bayer form new company to sell seeds to vertical farms
summary: Temasek and Bayer have formed Unfold, a new company that will develop seeds for vertical farms. The venture has raised $30 million in funding and will focus on lettuce, spinach, tomatoes, peppers, and cucumbers. Unfold aims to improve food security, particularly in urban areas, and will offer seeds and optimal techniques for vertical farming. The company will be equally owned by both parties, with plans to expand and potentially seek additional investments in the future.

site_title: HSBC announces two Singapore-based senior appointments
summary: HSBC has announced two senior appointments in Singapore, with Ken Ng becoming the market head for Singapore and Gary Goh taking on the role for Malaysia. Both appointments are effective immediately and will report to Philip Kunz, head of South-east Asia for HSBC Private Banking. The move is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on the region's growing economies, with Kunz stating that Singapore and Malaysia are key hubs for entrepreneurs looking to expand regionally.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte will be Russia vaccine 'guinea pig' as talks begin
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte will be the first recipient of Russia's coronavirus vaccine, dubbed the "guinea pig" in clinical trials. The vaccine, claiming to offer "sustainable immunity," is in the final stage of testing involving 2,000 people. Western scientists have expressed concerns about the vaccine's rapid development, suggesting potential shortcuts. The Philippines is the frontrunner for overseas clinical trials, with Duterte set to receive the vaccine, despite Western concerns.

site_title: China eases travel restrictions for Europeans
summary: China has eased entry restrictions for nationals from 36 European countries, allowing European passport holders with valid residence permits to apply for a Chinese visa without an invitation letter. The new rules, effective immediately, also lift some flight quotas, with Air France set to operate three weekly flights between China and France from August. However, travelers must still undergo Covid-19 tests and a 14-day quarantine, and find their own plane tickets. This move comes after China largely brought the spread of Covid-19 under control and follows months of travel restrictions.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit posts DPU of 1.78 US cents, meeting IPO forecast
summary: United Hampshire US Reit reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.78 US cents for the period from March 12, 2020 to June 30, 2020, meeting its initial public offering (IPO) forecast. The income available for distribution to unitholders was US$8.79 million, a 0.2% increase from the forecast. This is the Reit's first results since listing on the Singapore Exchange's main board in March 2020.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up on weak yen
summary: Tokyo stocks closed moderately higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.41% and the Topix index jumping 1.23%. This follows losses on Wall Street due to renewed pessimism about a new pandemic aid bill. A weak yen sustained market sentiment, but gains were limited due to profit-taking. The US dollar gained to 106.72 yen, while SoftBank Group dropped 2.65% and Sony slid 0.87%.

site_title: Former Sats officer jailed 15 months for offering contracts for cash involving over S$150,000
summary: A former Sats officer, Lim Koon Chuan, was sentenced to 15 months' jail for eight corruption charges involving over S$150,000. Lim, 59, was a cargo technical supervisor at Sats when he took multiple bribes in exchange for helping companies get awarded tender contracts. The charges also considered 14 other offenses. The sentencing marks a significant outcome in the corruption case, with Lim's actions seen as a breach of trust in the tender process at Singapore Changi Airport.

site_title: Ticking timebomb? Thousands of Australia mortgages propped up by virus benefits
summary: Nearly 20,000 Commonwealth Bank of Australia mortgages are held by people receiving jobless benefits due to Covid-19, raising concerns about forced property sales and sharp house price declines once support runs out. The data shows Australia's housing market is being propped up by temporary relief payments for people left jobless by shutdowns. Banks may become aggressive in enforcing loans when payments stop, potentially leading to a sharp downturn in house prices, which could further damage the economy.

site_title: BCA announces measures to accelerate restart of construction projects
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) has announced measures to accelerate the restart of construction projects in Singapore. With almost all foreign dormitories declared Covid-19 free, BCA is allowing companies and foreign workers to resume work outside construction sites without approval. This includes temporarily suspending the 10-accommodation criteria and allowing workers to resume work while cohorting is being carried out in licensed dormitories. Over 3,300 construction projects have been approved to resume work, with BCA focusing on restarting projects safely since June 2.

site_title: PropNex net profit doubles in Q2
summary: PropNex, a Singaporean real estate agency, reported a net profit of S$7.26 million for the second quarter, nearly doubling from S$3.7 million a year ago. Revenue rose 15% to S$105.93 million, driven by increased commission income from project marketing services. The company also declared an interim dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents. For the half-year, net profit jumped 45.2% to S$14.84 million, with revenue increasing 45.2% to S$241.55 million. The group expects private new home sales to recover in the second half of the year, driven by low interest rates and fiscal policy measures.

site_title: Hong Kong's wealthy investors stay put with crisis plans ready
summary: Hong Kong's wealthy investors are staying put despite the city's new national security law, which came into effect on June 30. While some are assessing how the law will impact asset prices and the long-term business environment, most are open to the idea that the law will help stabilize the economy. Capital inflows into Hong Kong's stocks have been significant, with mainland exchange links more than doubling to $16.6 billion since early June. Weighed against fears of capital outflows, Hong Kong's rich investors are taking a wait-and-see approach, with many expecting China's government to prop up the markets.

images.alt_text: They've mapped out exit routes, opened offshore bank accounts and secured overseas passports.

site_title: Australia: Virus resurgence drives New Zealand shares lower; Aussie benchmark falls
summary: New Zealand's stock market fell 1.3% on Wednesday, its worst close in a month, after the country reported its first COVID-19 cases in 102 days. The lockdown has led to a delay in key election steps and expansion of the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's bond-buying program. The Australian benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.1%, weighed down by losses in miners and gold stocks, while the Reserve Bank of Australia warned policy rates might need to go below zero to revive its economy.

site_title: Investors ready for up to US$2.5b in debt for Blackstone's Ancestry.com buy: sources
summary: Blackstone Group is set to acquire Ancestry.com for $4.7 billion, backed by up to $2.5 billion in new debt financing. Bank of America and Credit Suisse have committed financing for the deal, which will be one of the largest sponsor-backed leveraged buyouts since the pandemic. Moody's Investors Service expects demand for Ancestry's products to spike amid the pandemic, and investors are confident in the company's predictable subscription-based cash flows.

site_title: UK in record recession after economy shrinks 20% in Q2
summary: The UK economy contracted by a record 20.4% in Q2, with the country in lockdown due to the coronavirus pandemic. This marks the largest recession on record, following a 2.2% contraction in the first quarter. The economy began to rebound in June with an 8.7% growth, but still remains 6% below its February level. Productivity saw its largest-ever fall, with the hospitality industry worst hit. The Bank of England expects the unemployment rate to rise to 7.5% by the end of the year and the economy to contract by 9.5% for 2020.

site_title: China to suspend Etihad Airways, SriLankan Airlines Shanghai route from Aug 17
summary: China's aviation regulator has announced suspensions on several international flights due to COVID-19 cases. Starting August 17, Etihad Airways will suspend its Abu Dhabi-Shanghai route for a week, while China Eastern Airlines' Manila-Shanghai route will be halted for a week. SriLankan Airlines will halt its Colombo-Shanghai route for four weeks due to high coronavirus cases among arriving passengers. The suspensions aim to curb the spread of the virus.

images.alt_text: China's aviation regulator said on Wednesday that it would suspend Etihad Airways from flying its Abu Dhabi-Shanghai route.

site_title: Singapore's openness places it in good stead amid supply chain reshuffling: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's openness to trade will help it navigate the global supply chain reshuffling, said Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing. Despite slowing global growth and trade tensions, Singapore can remain an integrator and base for businesses, thanks to its high free trade agreement coverage and open borders. The country will continue to uphold the rules-based trading system and work with partners to keep borders open to data flow, aligning with the interests of global multinational corporations. Singapore's openness will give it an edge in facing structural challenges such as geopolitical tensions and supply chain reshuffling.

site_title: New Zealand dollar slips as RBNZ seeks to suck up more bonds
summary: The New Zealand dollar fell to a one-month low after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) announced it would buy NZ$100 billion of government bonds, exceeding its previous target of NZ$60 billion. The RBNZ also warned of considering cutting interest rates below zero to support the economy. This move was seen as a surprise and may indicate the need for further monetary easing. The New Zealand dollar's decline was attributed to the RBNZ's expansion of its bond buying campaign and its willingness to explore unconventional measures to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Airbnb is close to filing to go public after travel rebound: sources
summary: Airbnb is set to file paperwork for an initial public offering (IPO) in the next few weeks, potentially allowing its shares to trade as early as the fourth quarter. The move comes after the travel industry rebounded following the coronavirus pandemic. The San Francisco-based company is preparing to submit documents confidentially with the US Securities and Exchange Commission. If successful, the IPO would represent a swift comeback for Airbnb after the pandemic's impact on the travel industry.

images.alt_text: Airbnb plans to file paperwork for a stock market listing in the next few weeks paving the way for its shares to start trading as soon as the fourth quarter, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Abu Dhabi seeks local investors for US$21b pipeline
summary: Abu Dhabi National Oil Co (Adnoc) is seeking local investors for its US$21 billion pipeline network. The company plans to move its 51% holding into a special-purpose vehicle and sell 20% to local funds, retaining operational control. This comes after a June transaction where Adnoc sold a 49% stake in its gas pipelines to international investors. The move aims to generate additional funding as the emirate grapples with the coronavirus pandemic and plummeting crude prices.

site_title: ABN Amro quits trade and commodity financing in corporate bank overhaul
summary: ABN Amro is exiting trade and commodity financing in its corporate bank, shedding 800 jobs and focusing on local energy markets. The bank, which had suffered significant losses in offshore energy markets, aims to retreat from the US, Asia, Australia, and Brazil, except for clearing operations. The move is part of a broader trend among global banks to reduce their commodities business and cut risk. ABN's restructuring follows a series of failed attempts to overhaul its corporate bank and comes as other banks, such as Natixis and ANZ, have also accelerated a shift to greener finance.

site_title: Combined BTO sales exercise sees more than 7,800 flats launched in eight estates
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has launched 7,862 new flats in eight estates, including Bishan, Ang Mo Kio, Geylang, Pasir Ris, Tampines, Choa Chu Kang, Tengah, and Woodlands. The flats range from two-room flexi to five-room units, with prices starting from S$90,000 for a two-room flexi flat in Woodlands and S$484,000 for a four-room flat in Bishan. Applications for the flats close on August 18, and allocation will be through balloting.

site_title: Gold collapses below US$1,900 as rout extends into the second day
summary: Gold prices plummeted below $1,900 an ounce, extending a slump into a second day, as US bond yields advanced and investors took profits after the precious metal reached a record above $2,000. The drop was fueled by Russia's announcement of a COVID-19 vaccine, prompting a shift in investor appetite towards riskier assets. Despite some predictions of further gains, gold futures tumbled on the Comex, with silver also dropping sharply.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's financial sector created 22,000 net jobs between 2015 and 2019, with three out of four jobs going to locals. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) made this statement. Amid trade tensions, Singapore's openness is seen as an advantage, allowing it to integrate and welcome businesses. The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) announced measures to accelerate the restart of construction projects. Taronga Ventures, an Australia-based venture capital firm, will anchor its Asia headquarters in Singapore. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.75% to 2,563.20.

images.alt_text: Singapore's financial sector has created 22,000 net jobs between 2015 and 2019, and of these, three out of four jobs went to locals, said a top official from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) on Wednesday.

site_title: Condo, HDB rents in July see first uptick since February but demand shows Covid-19 impact
summary: Singapore's rental housing market saw a mixed picture in July, with HDB rents rising 1.4% and private apartments increasing 0.4% for the first time in four months. Demand was impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, with leasing volumes falling 7.2% for private units and 19.1% for HDB flats. Experts attribute the HDB rent increase to demand from Malaysian workers, while private units saw a rise due to a shift in demand from expats opting for cheaper options.

site_title: Europe: London stocks up despite record UK recession
summary: London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.3% to 6,172.75 points, following strong gains across Europe on Tuesday, as the UK economy slowly recovers from a record recession. In contrast, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index fell 0.2% and the Paris CAC 40 was flat. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare shares, while US-EU trade talks remain in focus.

site_title: Catalist stocks underperforming, says study co-authored by Prof Mak
summary: A study co-authored by Prof Mak Yuen Teen found that three-quarters of Catalist stocks underperformed after staying listed for more than seven years. Out of 214 companies, 56.5% made losses in FY2019, with 71% of those listed over seven years experiencing losses. The study highlights conflicts of interest in the sponsorship regime, suggesting that sponsors may not report disclosure or compliance breaches to avoid losing revenue. This has led to a review of the Catalist board being urged.

site_title: Temasek's 'material adverse change' attack draws Singapore's bailout line
summary: Temasek, Singapore's sovereign investment vehicle, has invoked a "material adverse change" clause to exit its $3 billion deal to increase its stake in rig-builder-to-property conglomerate Keppel, citing a significant decline in global oil demand. This decision draws a line on how far the Asian city-state is willing to bail out strategic sectors amid the pandemic. The move also highlights Temasek's cautious approach to investments, following its generous lifeline to Singapore Airlines earlier this year.

site_title: Three in four new jobs in financial sector go to locals: MAS
summary: Singapore's financial sector has created 22,000 net jobs between 2015 and 2019, with three-quarters of new positions going to locals. The median income of locals in the sector was S$7,600, above the national median. Despite a recession, the sector employed over 170,000 workers in 2019 and modest retrenchments occurred in Q1 2020. To support growth, the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Institute of Banking and Finance are exploring training subsidies and reskilling initiatives. Financial institutions such as Standard Chartered and OCBC have pledged to hire and train Singaporeans.

site_title: Australian consumer sentiment sinks amid 'air of panic'
summary: Australian consumer sentiment plummeted 9.5% in August, the largest decline since April, amid a strict coronavirus lockdown in Victoria. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index fell to its lowest level since April, with pessimists outnumbering optimists. The drop was attributed to an "air of panic" and may be an overreaction to manageable virus-related risks. The index for the next 12 months and five years also dropped significantly, while the outlook for family finances fared slightly better. Experts urge caution, citing the potential for a significant recovery in the coming months.

site_title: Cathay Pacific posts record HK$9.87b H1 loss amid pandemic
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways reported a record HK$9.87 billion loss in the first half of 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic. Revenue plummeted 48.3% to HK$27.7 billion, largely due to reduced passenger flying. The airline attributed the decline to lower demand and border restrictions. Despite this, cargo-only flights increased, with freight yields rising 44.1%. Cathay Pacific expects a meaningful recovery in passenger demand to take time.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start lower on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with slight losses, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.09% to 24,868.63, and the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also experiencing losses of 0.38% and 0.26%, respectively. This decline followed US lawmakers' skepticism about a new stimulus package, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell playing down the chances of a quick agreement.

site_title: DBS Vickers remains resilient with digitalisation and collaborative efforts
summary: DBS Vickers, a brokerage arm of DBS Bank, has remained resilient despite the pandemic by adopting digitalization and collaborative efforts. The brokerage's H1 2020 income nearly doubled year-over-year, and its digital trading platform saw a tripling of new accounts opened. Internal collaboration and digital infrastructure enhancements enabled swift deal distribution and investor engagement, including virtual roadshows. DBS Vickers aims to differentiate itself with a powerful digital offering, strengthen its investor network, and expand its online access to more markets globally.

site_title: Bitcoin once again giving bulls hope for US$12,000 and well beyond
summary: Bitcoin's price has surged to around US$12,000, bringing hope for further gains to US$12,000 and beyond. The cryptocurrency's recent run higher has been driven by increased interest from institutional investors, a 50% decrease in the rate of Bitcoin created due to the "halving," and correlations with gold rising to records. Analysts, including JPMorgan and Bloomberg Intelligence, predict potential gains for Bitcoin, with some projecting it could reach US$14,000 or even US$20,000 by the end of the year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.19 points, or 0.46%, to 1,557.55. Losers beat gainers 330 to 159, and volume reached 1.12 billion lots worth RM285.03 million.

site_title: GDP stats to reveal depths of virus-fuelled UK recession
summary: The UK is set to officially enter recession, with GDP predicted to contract by around 20% in the second quarter, the worst in Europe. The economic collapse reflects the impact of the pandemic lockdown, with the country's first recession since 2008. Despite government interventions, including massive asset buybacks and low interest rates, the economy is expected to post the worst performance in the second quarter in Europe. The recession is already causing job losses, with around 730,000 workers removed from payrolls since March, and unemployment is expected to soar in the months ahead.

site_title: South Korea's July jobless rate falls for second month
summary: South Korea's unemployment rate fell to 4.2% in July, its second consecutive decline, as business sentiment improved following the COVID-19 pandemic. This marks a decrease from the decade-peak of 4.5% in May. The drop is attributed to an improvement in business sentiment, suggesting a gradual recovery in the economy.

site_title: Australian police arrest two on suspicion of 'daigou' money laundering
summary: Australian police have arrested two men on suspicion of laundering millions of dollars in illicit drug money through a Sydney-based "daigou" business. The 37-year-old man was arrested on Monday after delivering A$1 million in cash to the daigou business, while the 40-year-old is alleged to be the "coordinator" of the overseas money-laundering enterprise. The pair have been charged with dealing with proceeds of crime, carrying a maximum penalty of 25 years in prison. Daigou, a surrogate shopping business popular with Chinese, has been linked to money-laundering operations due to its cash-intensive nature and ability to transfer dirty proceeds offshore.

images.alt_text: Australian police have arrested two men on suspicion of moving tens of millions of dollars of illicit drug money through a Sydney-based "daigou", a surrogate shopping business popular with Chinese.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares fall as virus fears deepen
summary: Australian shares fell 0.44% to 6,114.60 points, while New Zealand's benchmark index dropped 1.4% to 11,486.27, amid concerns over a worsening coronavirus outbreak in Australia's second-most populous state, Victoria. The state recorded its deadliest day of the pandemic and largest daily rise in infections. Gold stocks plummeted nearly 5% due to a broader lift in risk appetite, while financial stocks rose 0.5% led by Virgin Money UK. New Zealand's central bank is expected to hold interest rates steady at a record low of 0.25%.

site_title: Hatten Land to assign Malacca mixed-use project's IP rights to Tayrona for US$60m
summary: Hatten Land has proposed assigning its intellectual property rights in the Harbour City mixed-use development in Malacca, Malaysia to Tayrona Capital for US$60 million. The deal includes project design and concept, domain names, and marketing materials. Tayrona Capital plans to acquire and complete the project, which has been halted due to a legal dispute with the main contractor. The assignment will raise funds for Hatten Land, strengthening its balance sheet and allowing it to pursue new growth initiatives.

site_title: Ascendas Reit sets up S$7b euro medium-term securities programme
summary: Ascendas Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, has established a S$7 billion euro medium-term securities programme. The net proceeds from the issue of notes or perpetual securities will be used for financing acquisitions, investments, and asset enhancement works, as well as refinancing existing borrowings. OCBC is the sole arranger and dealer for the programme. Units of Ascendas Reit closed at S$3.42 on Tuesday, down 0.9%.

site_title: Trump says 'surprised' at Biden's pick of 'horrible' Harris
summary: President Donald Trump expressed surprise at Joe Biden's choice of Kamala Harris as his vice presidential candidate, calling her "the most horrible" member of the US Senate. Trump stated he was disappointed by Harris's performance during the 2020 Democratic primary and also criticized her behavior during the 2018 Senate confirmation hearings of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh.

site_title: US inks US$1.5b deal with Moderna for 100 million doses of Covid-19 vaccine
summary: The US has entered a deal with Moderna Inc to acquire 100 million doses of its potential Covid-19 vaccine for $1.5 billion, with a price of $30.50 per dose. This is part of the US Operation Warp Speed programme aiming to deliver a vaccine by the end of the year. The deal is one of several with companies such as Pfizer and Johnson & Johnson, securing over 500 million doses for the US.

site_title: Australian Q2 wage growth lowest ever as pandemic rages
summary: Australian wages grew at the slowest pace on record in Q2, rising 0.2% in the three months to June, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. This is the weakest quarterly growth since records began in 1997. Annual wage growth also slowed to 1.8%, below the standard levels for the country. The slow wage growth is another blow to household spending power, following a sharp decline in consumer sentiment due to the ongoing pandemic.

images.alt_text: Australian wages grew at the slowest pace on record last quarter in another hit to household spending power when the coronavirus pandemic has already ruptured consumer confidence and business conditions.

site_title: Google turning smartphones into earthquake detectors
summary: Google has added an earthquake alert system to Android-powered smartphones in California, utilizing the "ShakeAlert" system implemented by the US Geological Survey. The system detects seismic activity using phone accelerometers and sends warnings to users when an earthquake is imminent. Android phones can join a crowd-sourced network to detect earthquakes, forming the world's largest earthquake detection network. The system aims to provide timely warnings to people in the affected area, helping them seek safety before the earthquake hits.

site_title: Trump pick for Latam development bank pushes back against critics
summary: Mauricio Claver-Carone, a senior adviser to US President Donald Trump, is the favorite to lead the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) despite opposition from several countries, including Argentina, Mexico, and Costa Rica. Claver-Carone dismissed the opposition as "subversive" and "paralyzing" and claimed 17 countries have given him public support. The IDB's 28 member countries need at least 15 votes for a candidate to win, with a majority vote required to secure the presidency. The bank's election is set for September 12.

site_title: Toshiba says likely to report Q1 operating loss on coronavirus impact
summary: Toshiba is likely to report its first operating loss in nearly four years due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on electronics sales. The company expects operating losses of 10-20 billion yen for the April-June quarter, a reversal from its last quarterly loss in 2016. This is attributed to a decline in electronic device sales during the virus outbreak.

site_title: Hot stocks: Glove makers Top Glove, Riverstone, UG Healthcare see steep drops
summary: Singapore-listed glove manufacturers Top Glove, Riverstone, and UG Healthcare saw steep drops in share prices on Wednesday, with Riverstone plummeting 13% and Top Glove falling 13.3%. The declines were attributed to Russia's approval of its first Covid-19 vaccine, potentially curbing demand for gloves. Riverstone's shares had spiked to a record high earlier in the week after announcing doubled half-year earnings, while Top Glove had rallied on Monday after announcing a plan to pay remediation fees to migrant workers.

site_title: Virus hits Commonwealth Bank profits in 'challenging' year
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia reported an 11.3% drop in full-year cash profits due to provisions against loan losses caused by the coronavirus crisis. The bank's statutory net profit after tax was A$9.6 billion, up 12.4% from the previous year, but underlying cash net profit fell 11.3% to A$7.3 billion. CEO Matt Comyn attributed the decline to the pandemic's economic contraction and slower recovery pace, with GDP expected to be down 4% in 2020 and 2% in 2021.

site_title: US ban on TikTok could cut it off from app stores, advertisers: White House document
summary: US President Donald Trump's executive order banning China's TikTok could prevent the app from being offered on US app stores and make advertising on the platform illegal, according to a White House document. The order, which must be implemented in 45 days, could disrupt TikTok's operations and funding, amid concerns over personal data safety. Experts say eliminating the app's ability to be offered on Apple and Google stores could cripple its growth, but the US government may not be able to prevent Americans from downloading the app from foreign websites.

site_title: Hot stock: Medtecs jumps 16% after strong H1 results
summary: Medtecs International Corporation's shares surged 16.9% to S$1.14 after posting a net profit of US$38.9 million for the six months ended June 30, 2020, a 101 times increase from the previous year. Revenue grew to US$162.6 million, driven by higher sales of personal protective apparel and healthcare products. The company attributed the strong results to increased demand due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: SingPost revenue up 12% in April-June as e-commerce deliveries climb
summary: SingPost's group revenue increased 12% to S$360 million for the April-June quarter, driven by growth in cross-border e-commerce delivery volumes. However, group expenses rose 22% due to supply chain disruptions and higher costs. As a result, group profit on operating activities nearly halved to S$22 million. E-commerce volumes rose 52% in Singapore and 30% internationally, while letters and printed papers deliveries declined by a third. The company is implementing its Future of Post initiative to re-engineer the postal business.

site_title: GuocoLand appoints new group chief financial officer
summary: GuocoLand has appointed Sim Chee Wah as its new group chief financial officer (CFO), effective Tuesday. He replaces Lim Yoke Tuan, who resigned in July to pursue other career opportunities. Sim, formerly the deputy chief executive and head of investor relations at SingHaiyi, brings experience from 2016, including stints at FEO Hospitality Asset Management and Far East Organization. The appointment follows GuocoLand's shares closing at S$1.39, down 2.1% on the announcement.

site_title: Tesla sets 5-1 stock split and its high-flying stock soar again
summary: Tesla Inc. announced a five-for-one stock split, sending its shares up 7% in extended trading. The Palo Alto-based company aims to make its shares more accessible to employees and investors. Tesla's stock has surged over 200% this year, outperforming General Motors and Ford Motor. The stock split, effective August 31, follows Apple's four-for-one split in late July, making stock splits rare on Wall Street in 2020. The move is unlikely to affect Tesla's inclusion in the S&P 500 index.

site_title: Court tells Uber, Lyft to classify drivers as employees
summary: A California court has ordered Uber and Lyft to reclassify drivers as employees by the middle of next week, complying with a new state law requiring "gig workers" to receive benefits like unemployment and medical insurance. The companies had argued that most drivers want to remain independent, but the judge stated they could not indefinitely delay compliance. Uber has proposed a new model with guaranteed benefits for independent contractors, while the companies can appeal the order within 10 days.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.16% or 37.32 points at 22,787.56, and the Topix index climbing 0.38% or 5.99 points to 1,591.95. The gains came despite losses on Wall Street due to renewed pessimism about a new pandemic aid bill.

site_title: Murdoch's Fox unveils global streaming for news channels
summary: Rupert Murdoch's Fox Corp is launching a global streaming service for its news and business channels, available in 20 countries by the end of the year. The service, Fox News International, priced at $6.99/month, will offer on-demand content from Fox News and Fox Business Channel and be available on multiple platforms. The move comes amid a polarization of news audiences in the US and follows a similar service, Fox Nation, available to US audiences. The streaming service will debut in Mexico on August 20 and in other countries in September.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Medtecs, Koufu, Sembcorp, Keppel, SingPost, Wilmar
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Several Singapore companies released financial updates on Wednesday, including Medtecs International Corporation, which posted a 101 times increase in net profit, and Wilmar International, which saw its profit jump 38.7%. site_title: Medtecs H1 profit surges to US$38.9m on sales of personal protective apparel
summary: Medtecs International Corporation reported a net profit of US$38.9 million for the six months ended June 30, 2020, a 101 times increase from the previous year. Revenue jumped to US$162.6 million, driven by higher sales of personal protective apparel due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Gross profit margins also increased, contributing to the company's strong earnings. An interim dividend of 0.85 US cents has been declared, and Medtecs expects to exceed first-half revenue in the second half of the year.

site_title: How people are reacting to Kamala Harris's VP nod
summary: US President Joe Biden has named California Senator Kamala Harris as his vice-presidential pick. Former President Barack Obama praised the decision, saying Harris is "more than prepared for the job." Other notable reactions include congratulatory tweets from Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders, former Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton, and NBA star LeBron James. Actress Mindy Kaling expressed excitement and noted Harris's historic significance as a Black and South Asian woman holding high office.

site_title: Heathrow's passenger numbers down 88% in July
summary: Heathrow Airport reported an 88% decline in passenger numbers in July, citing ongoing travel restrictions and quarantine measures. The airport, which remains grounded for 60% of its route network, has renewed its call for Covid-19 testing to safely keep routes open and restart others, potentially saving jobs. Heathrow CEO John Holland-Kaye stated that the government can save jobs by introducing testing to cut quarantine from higher-risk countries while keeping the public safe from a second wave of Covid.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain for eighth day on vaccine, recovery hopes
summary: South Korean stocks rose for an eighth consecutive day, closing at their highest level in over two years due to vaccine and recovery hopes outweighing concerns over a new US stimulus package. The Kospi index gained 0.6% to 2,432.35, while the benchmark bond yield rose. Meanwhile, Russia granted regulatory approval to a COVID-19 vaccine after less than two months of human testing, with President Vladimir Putin stating it was the first country to do so.

site_title: Facebook to lmit 'imposter' news sites from political groups
summary: Facebook has announced a policy change to limit 'imposter' news sites from political groups, which are designed to appear as local news but are actually algorithmically generated or repurposed from outside sources. These sites will no longer receive a 'news exemption' for their ads and will be held to the same standards as other political entities. The move aims to protect the integrity of elections, particularly in the lead-up to the election. The sites will remain on the platform but will not have access to news messaging services.

site_title: Airbnb backs OECD approach to digital services tax
summary: Airbnb has backed the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's (OECD) approach to a digital services tax, a major rewrite of global tax rules to address the digital economy. The OECD talks involve over 100 countries, aiming to bridge the divide between the US and Europe. The nearly century-old tax system is not designed for the digital era, and Airbnb supports its improvement. The OECD negotiations have been complicated by the coronavirus pandemic, but the home rental startup believes a new tax regime is necessary.

site_title: Five years after devaluation, China has the yuan it wanted
summary: China's yuan has depreciated by more than 10% against the dollar and euro since its 2015 devaluation, but the current rate of depreciation is considered gentle and steady, sparking less concern. The yuan's value against the dollar is near a six-year low, but capital controls remain strict, and the currency's use outside of China is limited. China's management of the foreign exchange market has helped bolster investor confidence, and analysts expect the yuan to remain relatively stable ahead of the US presidential election.

site_title: SGX expands Asian equity derivatives, to launch 13 futures in August, September
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is expanding its Asian equity derivatives with 13 new futures to be launched in August and September. The new contracts, based on FTSE Russell benchmarks, include regional and single-country futures for Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan, Thailand, and Vietnam. The move aims to meet increasing demand for institutional-grade exchange solutions in Asia, with about $16 trillion in reported fund assets under management tracking the FTSE Russell benchmarks.

site_title: Singapore shares slip at Wednesday's open; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore shares slipped at Wednesday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.7% to 2,527.44. The Ministry of Trade and Industry tightened its economic forecast, predicting a 5-7% contraction this year, and analysts expect activity to take "some quarters" to return to pre-pandemic levels. Healthcare player Medtecs International Corporation gained 23.1% after posting a net profit of US$38.9 million, while banking stocks declined. US stocks reversed course to end in the red, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.4% and the S&P 500 falling 0.8%.

site_title: Spain again grapples with Europe's worst virus infection rate
summary: Spain is facing its worst coronavirus infection rate in Western Europe, with an average of 4,923 new daily cases over the past seven days. The country has nearly 323,000 confirmed cases, the highest in Western Europe, and 95 cases per 100,000 people. Experts say the surge is due to a "perfect storm" of factors, including relaxed social distancing measures and a lack of testing and public education. The government is taking drastic measures to curb outbreaks, including mandatory face masks and public awareness campaigns.

site_title: Oil eases as US stimulus hopes dim, virus cases rise
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures dropping 49 cents to $44.50 a barrel and US WTI crude futures falling 33 cents to $41.61 a barrel. Profit-taking ahead of weekly US oil inventory data and dimmed hopes for a swift US stimulus package contributed to the decline. Despite this, Asian oil demand signs of recovery and European refinery intake growth supported market sentiment, with China's factory deflation easing in July.

site_title: Harris under scrutiny for tough-on-crime prosecutor past
summary: US Senator Kamala Harris is facing criticism for her past work as a prosecutor, with some accusing her of opposing or staying silent on progressive reforms as California's Attorney General. Critics argue that she prioritized upholding laws over challenging them, and failed to intervene in cases involving police violence. However, others defend her record, pointing to successful programs such as "Back on Track" and "Open Justice," which aimed to reduce crime and increase transparency in the justice system. Harris' critics warn that her tough-on-crime reputation could be a liability in the general election campaign.

site_title: Upcoming fiscal support may be more targeted
summary: Singapore's government may consider more targeted fiscal support, potentially excluding better-performing sectors, to address the rising number of retrenchments. Existing schemes like the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) wage subsidy may be extended but scaled down, with some economists suggesting a temporary subsistence income support scheme for retrenched workers. The government aims to focus on redeploying and reskilling workers to move into growing sectors, rather than preserving obsolete jobs.

site_title: Pre-orders of Covid-19 vaccine top five billion
summary: The COVID-19 vaccine has garnered significant pre-orders, with at least 5.7 billion doses pre-ordered worldwide. The US has allocated $9.4 billion to vaccine developers, while the EU has signed agreements with two vaccine developers for 700 million doses. Russia's President Vladimir Putin claims a vaccine dubbed "Sputnik V" has conferred "sustainable immunity" against the novel coronavirus. Multiple countries, including the US, UK, Japan, and Brazil, are racing to develop and distribute a vaccine, with some aiming for results by September or the end of the year.

site_title: 'Fresh Prince of Bel-Air' set for gritty reboot: reports
summary: Will Smith's production company, Westbrook Studios, is developing a gritty reboot of the 1990s sitcom "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" with executive producer Morgan Cooper. The dark, modern-day reimagining is based on Cooper's four-minute trailer, which has garnered over 7 million views. The project will feature hour-long dramatic episodes, telling the story of Will's character becoming involved in a fight with Philadelphia gang members before moving to live with wealthy relatives in Bel-Air. Netflix is reportedly one of the streaming platforms pitching for the show.

site_title: Sembcorp, Sembmarine end lower after investors vote for demerger
summary: Sembcorp Industries (SCI) and Sembcorp Marine (SMM) saw their shares fall after investors voted in favor of a two-part recapitalisation and demerger proposal. SCI rose initially but ended down 2.63%, while SMM rose 2.9% before closing 2.86% lower. The demerger aims to recapitalize SMM and distribute SMM shares to SCI shareholders. Analysts see the successful outcome as a potential start to offshore and marine industry consolidation in Singapore.

site_title: Last month, active managers had worst stumble in two years
summary: Active managers suffered their worst performance in two years in July, with only 28% beating their benchmarks in the S&P 500. The decline was attributed to the dominance of tech giants like Apple, Amazon, and Microsoft, which outperformed the market by nearly 40% this year. Funds that hold these stocks have averaged 8.6% returns, while those that don't have averaged 7.4%. This highlights the challenge active funds face in competing with passive investing, with only 8% of large-cap blend funds beating their benchmarks over the past decade.

site_title: Apple on cusp of US$2t milestone, defying pandemic
summary: Apple is on the cusp of becoming the first US$2 trillion American company, with its market value reaching around US$1.87 trillion, ahead of Amazon and Microsoft. The company's shares have roughly doubled from March lows, driven by strong sales of gadgets, wearables, and services, including new apps and streaming services. Analysts attribute Apple's success to CEO Tim Cook's leadership, which has maintained the company's culture and built on the foundation laid by Steve Jobs. If Apple reaches US$2 trillion, it will be the only company other than Saudi Aramco to hit the milestone.

site_title: Singapore's refining sector showing some recovery in July: Refinitiv
summary: Singapore's refining sector showed recovery in July, with its three refineries reaching full operable capacity of 1.315 million barrels per day, the first time since February 2020. This marks an uptick in demand for transportation and industrial fuels as Covid-19 lockdowns ease, with diesel exports hitting a 20-month high in June and July. However, actual refinery runs have remained at 70% levels, and inventories remain high, indicating that the sector is still far from pre-Covid-19 normalcy.

site_title: SIM, RMIT Online to offer upskilling opportunities for Singapore workforce
summary: The Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) and RMIT Online have partnered to offer "skills-based, industry-designed" online learning opportunities for Singaporeans. The first suite of courses includes areas such as artificial intelligence, agile project management, and cybersecurity. Learners will receive a digital credential upon completion. This initiative aims to address the city-state's skill shortages, which could result in a loss of US$106.82 billion by 2030. The partnership extends a 33-year-long collaboration between the institutions, with RMIT having graduated over 40,000 students in Singapore.

site_title: A new digital game plan for business survival mode
summary: Singapore businesses must adapt to a new digital landscape as the COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the shift towards remote work and digital interactions. The government has allocated over S$500 million to support digital transformation initiatives, with a focus on maintaining workforce productivity and accelerating innovation. However, only 14% of Singapore-based companies have mature AI capabilities, and 57% of employees agree that automation and AI are needed. To survive, businesses must prioritize targeted digital upgrades, modernize core business systems, and leverage existing investments to achieve a faster return on investment.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends in the red on renewed pessimism on stimulus
summary: US stocks ended in the red on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 closing lower for the first time in eight days. The decline was triggered by Republican Senate leader Mitch McConnell's pessimism on a new pandemic aid bill, despite earlier optimism. The Nasdaq also fell 1.7% as investors reacted to the news. Apple, Zoom, and other major tech companies were among the biggest losers, with losses ranging from 3.0% to 7.6%. The market's recent rally appears to have stalled, with analysts attributing the decline to McConnell's comments and a summer lull in trading volume.

site_title: Pro-democracy media tycoon freed on bail amid Hong Kong crackdown
summary: Hong Kong pro-democracy media mogul Jimmy Lai was released on bail Wednesday, a day after being detained under China's sweeping security law. Lai, 71, was among 10 people arrested, including two of his sons, for allegedly colluding with foreign forces and fraud. The crackdown has sparked outrage in the West, with US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo calling it "further proof" of China's erosion of Hong Kong's freedoms. Lai's media group saw a significant increase in stock value after his release, and critics believe the security law has ended key liberties and autonomy in the semi-autonomous city.

site_title: New life insurance sales in Singapore drop 13% in H1
summary: Singapore's life insurance industry saw a 13% decline in new business in the first half of 2020, with total weighted premiums falling to S$1.66 billion. This drop is attributed to strict social-distancing measures during the "circuit-breaker" and Phase One periods, as well as the ongoing recession. However, sales of single-premium policies rose 17% year on year to S$622.9 million. The industry also expanded its workforce, adding 368 new hires, and continues to work closely with authorities to provide protection to Singaporeans during the pandemic.

site_title: Europe: Shares end near 3-week high as auto, travel sectors rally
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 1.7% higher, reaching a near three-week high, driven by gains in auto, travel, banking, and oil sectors. US stimulus bets and encouraging data from China and Germany fueled growth-linked sectors. Carmakers surged 4.4% after China's auto sales rose 16.4% in July, while travel & leisure, oil & gas, and banks jumped 3.7-4.5%. The Stoxx 600 has climbed 38% from its March lows but remains 15% below its record highs.

site_title: German ZEW economic survey lifts euro in thin liquidity
summary: The euro rose 0.5% to US$1.1809 after Germany's ZEW economic sentiment survey exceeded expectations, increasing to 71.5 from 59.3 points in the previous month. Thin August liquidity also contributed to the euro's gain, but some analysts remain cautious, awaiting clearer direction in September.

site_title: Joe Biden picks Kamala Harris as his running mate
summary: US President Joe Biden named Kamala Harris as his running mate, capping a months-long search for a Democratic partner to challenge President Donald Trump in November. Harris, a high-profile black senator from California, was announced as Biden's choice in a social media post. The decision is seen as a significant move to build a broad coalition of voters and unify the American people. Harris, a barrier-breaker for women and minorities in politics, will become the automatic frontrunner in the 2024 or 2028 Democratic nomination if they win.

site_title: Marriott posts bigger-than-expected loss
summary: Marriott International posted a quarterly loss of $234 million, or 72 cents per share, due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on global travel and room bookings. Revenue plummeted 72.4% to $1.46 billion, with room bookings down 84.4%. The company estimates rooms could grow 2-3% for the full year. This marks a 40.3% decline in shares this year.

site_title: The shape of things to come
summary: Singapore has established a centre to advance sustainable aviation in the Asia-Pacific region. The country is also exploring opportunities to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. Additionally, the government has announced plans for DPM Gan's US trade talks and a new grant of up to S$100,000 for businesses affected by tariffs. The government is urging graduates to stay calm, citing better employment rates, and is providing support for workers to future-proof their careers. A study highlights the potential for Singapore to thrive in these emerging industries.

site_title: Very different takes on the same report
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) released its Fourth Greenhouse Gas (GHG) Study on the Internet, which predicts carbon pollution from ships could increase by up to 50% by 2050 if left unchecked. Environmental campaign group Transport & Environment (T&E) seized on this finding, while the shipping industry and industry body presented alternative, more optimistic views. The IMO study's conclusions are being cherry-picked to suit different agendas, highlighting the challenges in interpreting and presenting complex research findings.

site_title: STI sheds 0.05% as investors turn cautious amid GDP plunge
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.36 points, or 0.05%, to 2,544.15, as investor optimism waned after Singapore's worst-ever economic performance for the second quarter. The GDP declined 13.2% in April-June, prompting forecasters to tighten their projection for a contraction of 5-7% in the year. Despite this, some stocks like Venture Corporation and banks gained, with Venture Corporation rising 6.16% and DBS gaining 1.21%.

site_title: AA Reit proposes buying Bulim Street logistics facility for S$129.6m
summary: AA Reit proposes buying a logistics facility at 7 Bulim Street in Singapore for S$129.6 million. The acquisition, valued at S$135.5 million, will add to the Reit's portfolio, increasing its logistics and warehouse cluster to 51.1% and raising rental contributions from master leases to 36.4%. The proposed acquisition is expected to enhance the Reit's income amid challenging market conditions, with a projected 94.2% overall portfolio occupancy rate.

site_title: The high cost of a strong euro currency
summary: The European Union is experiencing a strong economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, with low unemployment and a robust policymaking response. The EU's reputation has been bolstered by its pandemic recovery fund, and investors are taking notice, leading to a rise in the euro's exchange rate. However, this increase poses a risk to the eurozone, which is highly open and dependent on exports, potentially offsetting the benefits of lower risk premia.

site_title: Hong Kong media stock surges after publisher's arrest
summary: Hong Kong media company Next Digital, controlled by publisher Jimmy Lai, surged to a 7-year high after Lai's arrest under the city's national security law. The stock price rose over 1,100% in two days, with retail investors buying shares and copies of Lai's newspaper Apple Daily. The rally is seen as a form of protest against the government, with some calling for the stock exchange to take action against those with political motives. The company's market value increased by over HK$2.6 billion.

site_title: Manufacturing sector grows by 3.5% in H1 2020
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector grew 3.5% in the first half of 2020, driven by the biomedical and precision engineering clusters. The biomedical cluster expanded 27% year-on-year, while the precision engineering cluster grew 12%. However, the transport engineering cluster contracted 1.2%, and the general manufacturing and chemicals clusters declined 0.8% and 5.5% respectively. Experts warn of potential risks, including a slowdown in semiconductor demand and subdued global demand for chemical products, which may impact the sector's growth in the second half of 2020.

site_title: Is work-from-home phenomenon creating a disconnect from reality for property buyers?
summary: A surge in private home sales in Singapore after the second phase of the country's reopening may be driven by both genuine pent-up demand and excessive optimism fueled by the work-from-home (WFH) phenomenon. According to JLL's analysis, 31.8% of new sales occurred in the last two weeks of June, despite the economic recession and job losses. This could have implications for property developers, as buyers may not be aware of their job security or qualify for bank loans. The phenomenon may also lead to developers facing financial risks if buyers default on their purchases.

site_title: Is your portfolio pandemic-proof? It depends on your time horizon
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is causing a "slow-motion train wreck" for the global economy, with businesses facing significant challenges due to lockdowns, reduced demand, and slashed dividends. Only a few sectors, such as healthcare and online services, have been spared the impact. Investors need to reassess their portfolios and consider re-allocating funds to companies that will survive and thrive in the post-pandemic landscape. With time, the worst of the crisis may pass, and great businesses can recover and grow stronger, making them a safe investment option.

site_title: Some SMEs already in process of transforming themselves
summary: Singaporean Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) are transforming themselves to adapt to the post-Covid-19 crisis, exploring new avenues of growth beyond just waiting out the economic downturn. Firms in retail, F&B, aerospace, and hospitality are embracing cross-brand collaborations, joint promotions, and data analytics to drive spending and build loyalty. Some have also invested in automation and vocational training to boost productivity and employment readiness. However, the imminent withdrawal of key financial support, such as the Jobs Support Scheme, threatens progress made by these firms, highlighting the need for government support to preserve jobs and speed up economic recovery.

site_title: Singapore's condo resale volume nearly doubles in July: SRX
summary: Singapore's condo resale volume nearly doubled in July, reaching 978 units sold, compared to 496 in June 2020. The surge in resale volumes is attributed to pent-up demand built-up during the circuit breaker period and an increase in HDB upgraders entering the market. Resale prices rose 0.1% month-on-month, with prices in the OCR increasing 1.6% and in the CCR dropping 1.7%. Overall, resale prices dipped 0.1% year-on-year.

site_title: A legacy that serves as her life's trademark
summary: Noor Quek, 70, is a pioneering private banker and philanthropist in Singapore, leaving a lasting legacy through her professional and charitable work. She founded NQ International in 2007, advising high-net-worth clients on wealth management, and co-founded the Breast Cancer Foundation. Quek advocates for women's empowerment and overcoming gender bias, believing that being a woman can be an advantage in career advancement. Her philanthropic efforts focus on music therapy and breast cancer awareness, with the BCF having raised awareness and provided support for 23 years. Quek aims to be remembered as a kind, caring person who prioritizes family and gives back to society, believing legacy extends beyond financial value to holistic values and actions.

site_title: 24,000 job seekers placed; MOM weekly updates to highlight opportunities
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore has reported that 24,000 job seekers have been placed under the SGUnited Jobs and Skills package as of the end of July. This is part of 92,000 committed opportunities curated by the National Jobs Council, including public sector jobs and private sector jobs. The majority of these placements are for professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs), with traineeships for recent and new graduates forming the largest share. The MOM will release weekly updates on the job situation, highlighting opportunities for job seekers and providing updates on retrenchments and cost-saving measures.

site_title: Facebook creates unit to harmonise payment systems on its platform
summary: Facebook has created a new unit, Facebook Financial, to harmonize payment systems on its platform. The unit, headed by e-commerce veteran David Marcus, aims to improve financial services on the platform. This move is seen as a step towards expanding Facebook's financial services offerings and increasing its presence in the growing fintech industry. The creation of Facebook Financial follows similar efforts by other tech giants, such as Google and Apple, to develop their own financial services.

site_title: Management, boards shouldn't go for low-hanging fruit of layoffs
summary: Singapore's total employment contracted by 121,800 in Q2 2020, with retrenchments more than doubling to 6,700. Economists warn of more layoffs as companies consider cost-cutting measures to survive the pandemic. Management is urged to prioritize transparency, communicate plans, and explore alternative options, such as a four-day workweek or unpaid leave, to minimize the impact on staff. A compassionate approach to layoffs can create more value for companies and lead to stronger long-term success.

site_title: Keppel sees selloff after Temasek walks away from deal
summary: Keppel Corp shares plummeted 11.1% after Temasek Holdings scrapped its S$4 billion partial offer for the conglomerate, citing a material adverse change (MAC) clause triggered by Keppel's S$697.6 million net loss for the second quarter. The stock's lowest close in over four years was S$4.71, and DBS Group Research downgraded Keppel to "hold" from "buy". Despite this, DBS remains optimistic on Keppel's longer-term prospects, and some analysts see value in the stock.

site_title: SoftBank back to black with 1.26t yen profit after record loss
summary: SoftBank reported a 1.26 trillion yen (S$16.3 billion) quarterly net profit, recovering from record losses. The firm sold up to $41 billion in assets to finance a stock buy-back, reducing debts and increasing cash reserves. This move, combined with the recent tech stock rally, has helped SoftBank achieve a "V-shape recovery." CEO Masayoshi Son has defended his strategy, which has faced criticism, and will not offer a forecast due to uncertainties affecting earnings.

site_title: Pompeo pushes to curb China and Russia in Europe
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is on a key tour of Europe with a focus on curtailing China and Russia's influence in the region. He aims to mitigate Russian and Chinese economic and political influence, particularly in the Czech Republic, Austria, Poland, and Slovenia. Pompeo will push back against countries using Chinese-headquartered Huawei telecoms technology in 5G networks and promote US energy and economic ties. He also plans to discuss eastward redeployment of US troops in Europe, with a focus on Poland, and address concerns about dependence on Russian energy.

site_title: Gig workers deserve better: Uber CEO
summary: Uber CEO says gig workers want flexibility but benefits, and proposes a "third way" with benefits funds, medical and disability coverage, and anti-discrimination laws. Drivers value flexibility, but healthcare is a top concern. Uber will establish benefits funds and increase transparency. The company supports laws that protect gig workers, but believes a binary system between employee and contractor is outdated. A proposed law requiring companies to provide benefits and protections for gig workers could benefit millions of Americans.

site_title: China promotes its 'heroic' battle against virus in new exhibition
summary: China has launched a new exhibition, "Unity of Strength," at the National Museum of China, showcasing paintings, sculptures, and calligraphy that depict the country's efforts to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The exhibition highlights the "heroic deeds" of frontline medics and emphasizes the government's success in controlling the virus. Despite criticism from the West over alleged cover-ups, the exhibition promotes a positive narrative, featuring works that glorify the government's response to the crisis. The exhibition is only accessible to Chinese citizens.

site_title: Amazon finally finds a good fit at the mall
summary: Amazon is in talks with mall operator Simon Property Group to set up fulfillment centers in former J C Penney and Sears stores, aiming to offer same-day or one-day delivery to customers. This move would allow Amazon to capitalize on convenient parking lots and curbside pickup services, a key benefit of its Prime membership. The setup would also enable Amazon to compete with other retailers offering pickup services, potentially more profitable than home delivery orders.

site_title: Wilmar's net profit, excluding discontinued ops, up 38.7% in H1
summary: Wilmar International's net profit excluding discontinued operations rose 38.7% to US$610.87 million in the first half of 2020, driven by improved contributions across core segments. Revenue increased 12% to US$22.66 billion, with strong consumer product sales and the consolidation of Goodman Fielders' results. The company expects its food products and feed and industrial products segments to continue performing well, with favorable contributions from palm oil prices.

site_title: New cases in Auckland end New Zealand's 'Covid-19-free' status
summary: New Zealand has ended its 'Covid-19-free' status after four new domestic cases were discovered in Auckland, the country's largest city. The cases, within one family, were reported after 102 days without any domestic transmission. Auckland will move to level 3 restrictions, with people advised to stay away from work and school, and gatherings limited to 10 people. The restrictions will last for three days, with the rest of New Zealand entering alert level 2. The move is seen as a precautionary measure, with the source of the virus unknown.

site_title: Jeffrey Ong hit with 4 more charges involving S$11.7m linked to Allied Tech
summary: Former JLC Advisors managing partner Jeffrey Ong was charged with four additional counts of criminal breach of trust, related to the misappropriation of S$11.7 million from an escrow facility for Catalist-listed Allied Technologies. The charges arise from investigations by the Commercial Affairs Department. Ong's previous charges were linked to the same incident, with the total amount now exceeding S$11.7 million. The charges are the latest in a series of investigations into Ong's actions at JLC Advisors.

site_title: Canadian finance minister's job appears unsure, markets fret over distraction
summary: Canadian Finance Minister Bill Morneau's job appears uncertain after reports of a clash with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, prompting concerns about Ottawa's ability to tackle the coronavirus crisis. Trudeau is said to be uncertain about Morneau's handling of the recovery efforts, while Morneau is unhappy with Trudeau's spending plans. The situation could rattle investor confidence and weigh on the Canadian dollar, with potential replacements including Deputy Prime Minister Chrystia Freeland and former Bank of Canada head Mark Carney.

site_title: Singapore may take 'some quarters' to bounce back from 2020 recession
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to shrink by 5-7% this year due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with a record 13.2% year-on-year GDP contraction in the second quarter. The economy is likely to take "some quarters" to recover, with a possible timeline of returning to end-2019 levels only in the first half of 2022. Despite some sectors showing resilience, downside risks remain, including rising geopolitical tensions and the spread of the virus among workers in dormitories. The government has pledged to support the economy through fiscal measures and a cautious approach to reopening.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Accordia Golf Trust's EGM has been canceled due to two requisitioning unitholders withdrawing their notice, leaving the remaining unitholders with less than 10% voting rights required to convene the meeting. HC Surgical Specialists' CEO Heah Sieu Min has had an appeal to sue him dismissed by the Singapore High Court. Hyflux has had its unsecured working group given a deadline extension to file for a judicial management order until August 12. Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 70% drop in net profit to S$2.79 million for the half-year ended June 30, mainly due to the impact of Covid-19.

site_title: NODX 2020 growth forecast raised to 3-5 per cent
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 6.5% in April-June, exceeding the revised 5.4% rise in the first quarter, thanks to better-than-expected shipments and a low base. The government trade promotion agency, Enterprise Singapore, raised its full-year NODX growth forecast to 3-5% from a contraction of 1-4%. Total trade is still expected to shrink 8-10% this year, but less severe than previously forecast. Despite this, significant downside risks remain, with private-sector economists warning of uncertainties in the Covid-19 situation and geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Singapore crushes massive ivory haul on eve of World Elephant Day
