summary: Singapore has destroyed 9 tonnes of seized ivory, the largest such action globally in recent years, on the eve of World Elephant Day. The ivory, worth S$17.6 million, came from over 300 African elephants and was seized between 2014 and 2019. The destruction aims to disrupt the global supply chain of illegally traded ivory and prevent it from re-entering the market. Singapore also launched a Centre for Wildlife Forensics to identify and analyse specimens involved in the illegal wildlife trade, using DNA analysis and other methods to determine where the items were poached from.

site_title: US: S&P 500 nears record high on stimulus bets
summary: US stocks rose, with the S&P 500 closing near a record high, driven by bets on more stimulus measures and a steady post-coronavirus recovery. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.61%, while the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.23%. Investors are optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Facebook places curbs on ads by US news publishers with political ties
summary: Facebook has introduced a new policy to prevent US publishers with political ties from running ads presented as news articles. Publishers with political affiliations will be eligible for ad authorisation, with publicly disclosed information on paid ads with opinion-based content. The move aims to address fake news and misinformation concerns ahead of the US presidential election in November. Facebook will also limit these publishers' inclusion in Facebook News and restrict their access to the platform.

site_title: Russia names its new Covid-19 vaccine 'Sputnik V'
summary: Russia has approved its first Covid-19 vaccine, 'Sputnik V', for foreign markets, with over 20 countries requesting 1 billion doses. The vaccine was registered after less than two months of human testing, prompting concerns over safety and science. Russian officials, including President Vladimir Putin and Health Minister Mikhail Murashko, have assured that clinical trials will continue and vaccinations of medical staff may begin in September. The World Health Organization has urged Russia to follow established guidelines and has not been officially notified of the vaccine's deployment.

site_title: New Covid-19 cases detected at cleared dormitories
summary: New Covid-19 cases have been detected at dormitories previously cleared of the virus in Singapore, prompting authorities to monitor the situation and implement measures to manage the risk of new outbreaks. The Ministry of Manpower and other agencies have put in place safeguards, including daily temperature checks, swab testing, and staggered pick-up and drop-off times, to ensure workers can safely restart work in the construction, marine, and process sectors. The cases were linked to two dormitories, with six new cases reported at Kian Teck Dormitory and two others at Kian Teck Hostel.

site_title: The other global power shift - technology
summary: The US national security strategy is shifting from great power competition to addressing transnational security threats posed by technology, such as cybercrime, pandemics, and climate change. The rapid spread of information and the empowerment of non-state actors, including individuals and private organizations, have reduced the monopoly of traditional bureaucracy and increased vulnerabilities. The US must work with others to address global public goods, such as climate change and pandemics, and adopt a more collaborative approach to security, rather than relying solely on unilateral action. This requires a new mindset that prioritizes joint goals and power-sharing.

site_title: Sydney's Taronga Ventures to headquarter Asia operations in Singapore
summary: Taronga Ventures, an Australia-based venture capital firm, will establish its Asia headquarters in Singapore to expand its real estate-focused innovation and investment ecosystem. The firm has recently closed its RealTech Ventures Fund, which attracted significant investment from CBRE, Patrizia, and Dexus, and aims to raise $100 million. The Singapore office will support the RealTech Ventures Fund and its growth program, RealTechX, which helps emerging technology companies in the real estate and built environment.

site_title: Boeing's lost MAX orders top 400 this year, 787 deliveries drop
summary: Boeing's 737 MAX orders surpassed 400 for the year, with 43 cancellations in July, including 35 previously disclosed. The company delivered just four jets in July and booked zero new orders. The 787 Dreamliner deliveries also dropped, totaling just four commercial jets. The pandemic has impacted deliveries, with travel restrictions hindering some buyers. Boeing's 787 has become a critical source of cash during the MAX's grounding, with the company awaiting FAA approval to resume flying the model, expected by the end of the year.

site_title: Benin restores monuments to testify to brutal past of slavery
summary: Benin's coastal town of Ouidah is restoring monuments to its painful past as a major slave staging post in the 17th and 18th centuries. The renovation includes the Ouidah fort and history museum, which will showcase artifacts such as chains and guns used in the slave trade. The move aims to educate future generations about the suffering of enslaved Africans and promote tourism in the region. The project is part of Benin's drive to preserve its history and is being led by President Patrice Talon's government, which has allocated a budget of €1 billion for the project.

site_title: Holiday Inn owner points to recovery after first half slump
summary: IHG, owner of the Holiday Inn, reported a 52% drop in revenue to $488 million and an 82% decline in profit to $74 million in the first half of 2020, due to the pandemic. However, the company is seeing "very early" signs of improvement in demand as restrictions ease and traveler confidence returns. Hotel room revenues have shown small but steady improvements, with July RevPAR down 58% compared to the previous year. IHG has cut costs and reduced its fee business by $150 million this year, and has $2 billion in available liquidity.

site_title: 1m without power after violent storm rips US midwest
summary: A violent storm swept across the US Midwest, leaving over 1 million homes and businesses without power in Chicago and surrounding areas. The storm, which may be a derecho, caused 100mph winds, hail, and deadly gusts, destroying trees and homes. Most outages are in Iowa and Illinois, with 280,000 in Chicago and its suburbs. The storm follows Tropical Storm Isaias, which knocked out power to over 2 million customers on the East Coast.

site_title: Rolls-Royce orders inspection of 'worn' Airbus engines
summary: Rolls-Royce has ordered inspections of its 'worn' Airbus engines, specifically the Trent XWB-84 model, due to indications of wear on intermediate pressure compressors in engines aged 4-5 years. The inspection is precautionary, with 100 engines identified and 90% already inspected, showing signs of wear on 1-2 IPC blades in a minority. The move comes after Rolls-Royce recently faced costly repairs for its Trent 1000 engines on Boeing 787 Dreamliners, amid a global pandemic that has impacted the aerospace industry.

site_title: French privacy watchdog opens preliminary investigation into TikTok
summary: France's data privacy watchdog CNIL has opened a preliminary investigation into TikTok, following a complaint received in May. This is the latest in a series of investigations into the Chinese-owned video-sharing app, which is already under scrutiny in the US, European Union, and the Netherlands over privacy concerns. TikTok has stated it is cooperating with the investigation and prioritizing user privacy and safety. The CNIL's investigation is the latest in a global crackdown on TikTok's data handling practices, with President Trump threatening to ban the app unless it sells its US operations to Microsoft.

site_title: Weekday entry restrictions at 4 popular wet markets to be eased
summary: Singapore's weekday entry restrictions at four popular wet markets will be eased starting Thursday, August 13, after a noticeable reduction in weekday queues. The rule, which allowed shoppers to visit the markets only on alternate days, will be lifted. The easing aims to further reduce crowding on weekends by allowing more time for shopping during the week. The restrictions will remain in place on weekends, and other measures such as contact tracing and social distancing will continue.

site_title: Centurion Corp's profits slip 10% in Q2 from costs to manage Covid-19 in workers' dorms
summary: Centurion Corp, a Singapore-listed housing operator, reported a 10% drop in Q2 profits to S$9.13 million due to increased costs to manage Covid-19 in workers' dorms. Revenue slipped 5% to S$31.1 million, mainly affected by early lease terminations and lower occupancy. However, the company's half-year profits rose 16% to S$21.01 million, driven by higher contributions from new properties and lower interest expenses.

site_title: WHO discussing new Covid-19 vaccine with Russia
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is discussing possible prequalification of Russia's newly approved Covid-19 vaccine with Russian health authorities. The vaccine was approved by Russia after less than two months of human testing, with President Vladimir Putin hailing it as evidence of the country's scientific prowess. The WHO is reviewing safety and efficacy data, but no timeline has been set for a final decision.

site_title: Soilbuild Construction sinks deeper into the red for H1 2020
summary: Soilbuild Construction reported a deeper loss of S$17.94 million for the half-year ended June 30, 2020, compared to a loss of S$1.83 million the previous year. Revenue fell 37% to S$69.2 million due to decreased construction activities, particularly during the "circuit-breaker" period in Singapore. The company expects construction progress and costs to be affected in the near term and will implement additional safety measures to resume operations in Singapore. Its order book stood at S$585.8 million.

site_title: Thai PM says protesters 'went too far' by demanding monarchy reform
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha condemned student protesters who issued a 10-point call for monarchy reform, calling their actions "too far". About 3,000-4,000 protesters chanted "Long live democracy" outside Thammasat University in Bangkok, while others demanded the resignation of Mr Prayuth and an end to military domination. Thailand has strict laws against insulting the monarchy, punishable by up to 15 years in prison. The palace declined to comment, and Mr Prayuth expressed concern over the protests, which have broken a decades-long taboo on questioning the monarchy's role.

site_title: US producer prices beat expectations in July
summary: US producer prices rose 0.6% in July, beating expectations, but the 12-month trend remained subdued due to the faltering economy's recovery from the Covid-19 recession. This followed a 0.2% increase in June and a 0.4% decline in the same period last year. The producer price index (PPI) is expected to decrease 0.7% on a year-on-year basis. The rebound in producer prices is a sign of a strengthening economy, but overall inflation remains subdued.

site_title: Occidental posts US$6.6b charge after oil price crash
summary: Occidental Petroleum reported a US$6.6 billion writedown in the second quarter, equivalent to 40% of its market value, due to the collapse in energy prices. The company's shares plummeted 6.8% in after-market trading. Despite producing at the high-end of guidance, Occidental made an adjusted loss of US$1.76 per share, worse than estimates. The writedown increases leverage ratios, potentially raising borrowing costs. Occidental is struggling with a US$40 billion debt burden and is considering selling assets to pay down debt.

site_title: UK department store Debenhams cuts 2,500 jobs
summary: UK department store chain Debenhams has cut 2,500 jobs due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the retail industry. The company, which secured a deal with creditors in April to avoid collapse, cited "long way from returning to normal" trading conditions as the reason for the job cuts. This announcement comes amid a larger trend of UK companies shedding thousands of jobs, with a total of 730,000 positions lost since March. The pandemic has put pressure on retailers, forcing them to adjust store costs and align with realistic expectations.

site_title: First Singapore volunteers given locally co-developed Covid-19 vaccine in trial
summary: The first cohort of local volunteers in Singapore has received a locally co-developed COVID-19 vaccine, Lunar-Cov19, in a trial conducted by Duke-NUS Medical School and Arcturus Therapeutics. The trial involved 100 volunteers aged 21-55 who received a single shot, with data from this phase used to determine the dosage regimens for the next phase. The vaccine, which uses mRNA to encode a protein similar to the virus, may only require a single dose and has been approved ahead of schedule due to pre-clinical trial results exceeding expectations.

site_title: Shadow of coronavirus slowly lifts from Wuhan
summary: Wuhan, the epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak, is slowly recovering from its 76-day lockdown. The city, now free from restrictions, is seeing a return to normal life, with scenes of crowded streets, electronic music festivals, and long lines at breakfast stands. Wuhan's recovery marks a significant milestone in China's efforts to contain the pandemic. The city's streets are now bustling with activity, a far cry from the deserted streets seen in January.

site_title: Koufu's H1 profits plunge 82% to S$2.54m on Covid-19 impact
summary: Koufu Group's H1 profits plummeted 82% to S$2.54m due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact, with revenue decreasing 23.2% to S$88.97m. The company's outlet and mall-management segment saw a 19.4% year-on-year decline, while its F&B retail segment fell 27.2%. Koufu resumed operations in June and expects to remain profitable in the next 12 months, with plans to open new food courts and expand its R&B Tea brand overseas.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Tuesday, down 6.92 points to 1,564.74, with losers outnumbering gainers 722 to 483. The market saw 27.797 billion lots traded worth RM7.803 billion.

site_title: NZ locks down biggest city after first local case of coronavirus in 102 days
summary: New Zealand has locked down its largest city, Auckland, after four new cases of Covid-19 were discovered, marking the first domestic transmission in 102 days. Auckland will move to level 3 restriction for three days, with people advised to stay away from work and school and gatherings of more than 10 people restricted. The rest of New Zealand will enter alert level 2 for three days, with social distancing measures reinstated. The cases are within one family, with one person in their 50s and no history of international travel.

site_title: China extends Hong Kong legislature by at least a year
summary: China's National People's Congress Standing Committee extended Hong Kong's Legislative Council term by at least a year to address the election postponement due to the COVID-19 surge. The current council, set to expire on September 30, will continue to perform duties for no less than one year. The decision affects 70 incumbent lawmakers, including four disqualified from re-election. The move was met with support from 42 pro-Beijing lawmakers, who called for cooperation among lawmakers to ensure effective operation of the legislature.

site_title: China resumes tourist visas to Macau, lifting casino stocks
summary: China has resumed issuing tourist visas for visitors to Macau, allowing mainland residents to travel to the world's largest gaming hub after months of losses. The move reverses a ban implemented in late January to contain the spread of the coronavirus. Macau's gaming revenue had plummeted by over 90% due to Chinese travel restrictions, but the resumption of tourist visas could revive the industry, which had previously generated five times the revenue of the Las Vegas Strip.

site_title: STI sheds 0.05% amid GDP plunge
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.36 points or 0.05% to close at 2,544.15, marking a negative start to the trading week. The decline comes after Singapore's quarterly GDP declined 13.2% in April-June, prompting forecasters to lower their projections for the state's economic contraction. Despite this, HSBC economist Yun Liu believes the worst is over and the economy will gradually bottom out in the third quarter.

site_title: Wilmar's net profit, excluding discontinued ops, up 38.7% in H1 2020
summary: Wilmar International reported a 38.7% increase in net profit, excluding discontinued operations, to US$610.9 million for the first half of 2020. Revenue rose 12% to US$22.66 billion, driven by improved consumer product sales and the consolidation of Goodman Fielders' results. The company's feed and industrial products segment saw a 105% increase in pre-tax profit, while its food products segment grew 21%. An interim dividend of S$0.04 per share was proposed, and the company expects satisfactory second-half performance.

site_title: Airports of Thailand posts worst quarter
summary: Airports of Thailand (AOT) reported its worst quarter ever, with a loss of 2.96 billion baht due to a 66% decline in foreign tourist arrivals and 88% drop in revenue. Flight and passenger numbers plummeted by 88% and 95%, respectively. The company will proceed with a satellite terminal construction, but delay its opening to 2022. This is attributed to the coronavirus-related restrictions and the country's put-on-hold of discussions on a 'travel bubble'.

images.alt_text: Airports of Thailand on Tuesday booked its worst quarter ever after volumes plummeted due to coronavirus-related restrictions.

site_title: Unsecured working group of bank lenders to get deadline extension to put Hyflux under JM
summary: The Singapore High Court has extended the deadline for an unsecured working group of bank lenders to file for a judicial management order for Hyflux until Aug 12. The group, consisting of several major banks, sought to carve their shares of debt from Hyflux's debt moratorium due to concerns over the company's management. Hyflux has until Aug 30 to accept a proposed rescue deal by Middle Eastern utility firm Utico, which remains open for acceptance. The deadline extension gives Hyflux more time to consider the rescue deal and potential judicial management.

site_title: US to label Hong Kong's goods as 'Made in China' in blow to city
summary: The US will label Hong Kong's goods as 'Made in China' starting September 25, in response to President Donald Trump's executive order stripping Hong Kong of its special US status. The move, aimed at limiting Hong Kong's trade benefits, will likely have limited impact on the city's exports to the US, as most shipments are re-exports from China. China has retaliated with sanctions on 11 Americans, further escalating tensions between the two nations.

images.alt_text: The US will order imports from Hong Kong to be labeled as 'Made in China' according to a government document, in the latest escalation of trade tensions between the two nations.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific's net profit sinks 70% in H1 2020
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings' net profit plummeted 70% to S$2.79 million in H1 2020, mainly due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the property-development and hotel-ownership segments. Revenue fell 16% to S$118.07 million, with the property-development segment dropping 11% and hotel-ownership segment falling 39%. The group expects its financial results to be adversely affected in H2 2020 due to ongoing pandemic uncertainty and operational challenges.

site_title: Australia: Shares post three-week closing highs on banks, iron ore miners
summary: Australian shares rose to three-week highs on Tuesday, driven by gains in financials and iron ore miners. The S&P/ASX 200 index settled 0.5% higher at 6,138.7, led by a 1-2.7% gain in the "big four" banks. Steady employment data and improving business conditions also boosted investor confidence. Iron ore miners BHP and Rio Tinto rose 0.9% each, while gold stocks fell over 4% due to a stronger dollar.

site_title: Seoul: Shares scale two-year high on recovery, US stimulus hopes
summary: South Korean shares reached a two-year high, closing up 1.35% at 2,418.67, driven by strong gains in market heavyweights and hopes for US stimulus. The Kospi index has risen for a seventh consecutive session. Despite weak domestic exports data, South Korea is expected to experience the smallest hit to growth among advanced economies this year. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin hinted at a possible agreement on US stimulus as soon as this week.

site_title: New sales in Singapore life insurance sector drop 13% in H1: LIA
summary: Singapore's life insurance sector saw a 13% decline in new sales in the first half of 2020, totaling S$1.66 billion, due to the COVID-19 pandemic and recession. However, sales of single-premium policies rose 17% to S$622.9 million, with 16% coming from CPF Investment Scheme-included products. The industry's total sum assured increased 1% to S$65.7 billion. The decline in new business premiums for retirement policies, however, reversed the upward trend, with a 36% year-on-year decrease.

site_title: Structural features underpin Malaysian Islamic banks' resilience against coronavirus fallout: Moody's
summary: Malaysian Islamic banks' resilience against the coronavirus fallout is attributed to their focus on retail financing, according to Moody's Investors Service. The seven largest Islamic banks in Malaysia, with a heavy concentration on retail financing, are less vulnerable to economic downturns. Most retail financing is secured by residential properties, cars, or low-risk unit trusts, limiting the impact of delinquencies. This structural feature will help these banks withstand economic disruptions, despite declining economic growth and increasing unemployment.

site_title: Koufu's H1 profits dive 82% on Covid-19 impact
summary: Koufu Group's profits plunged 82% to S$2.54 million in the first half of 2020, primarily due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on its food and beverage business. Revenue decreased 23.2% to S$88.97 million, with lower contributions from its outlet and mall-management segment and F&B retail segments. Despite the challenges, the company expects to remain profitable in the next 12 months and plans to open new outlets and expand its retail brands overseas.

site_title: Hot stocks: Sembcorp, Sembmarine see active trading on demerger confirmation
summary: Sembcorp Industries (SCI) and Sembcorp Marine (SMM) saw heavy trading volumes after shareholders approved a two-part proposal, including a demerger of SCI's SMM shares and a rights issue for SMM. The demerger is expected to provide SMM with approximately S$600 million in recapitalization. Analysts believe this deal signals the beginning of offshore and marine industry consolidation in Singapore.

site_title: OCBC, Amundi launch Singapore's first fund with dollar-cost-averaging feature
summary: OCBC Bank and European asset manager Amundi have launched Singapore's first fund with a dollar-cost-averaging feature, the Amundi-OCBC Momentum Fund. The fund aims to smooth out investment purchase prices with regular bite-sized placements, reducing volatility. Investors will receive regular dividends and benefit from capital appreciation. The fund is available to OCBC clients until Dec 31, 2020, with a minimal initial investment of S$5,000. This move is seen as a response to the volatility in financial markets due to the pandemic and geopolitical factors.

site_title: HRnetGroup's net profit down 31.9% on revaluation of assets
summary: HRnetGroup's net profit plummeted 31.9% to S$20.99 million for the half-year ended June 30, largely due to an unrealised loss of S$3.6 million on revaluing financial assets. Revenue fell 1% to S$210.34 million, with the professional recruitment segment declining 30.5% in Singapore and 55.8% in Hong Kong. The company will exercise caution and vigilance to preserve cash and resources amid the pandemic.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Q2 GDP has plummeted by 13.2%, the worst quarter on record, amid the pandemic. Forecasts now predict a full-year recession with a 5-7% contraction. The government will unveil plans to support the economy, including fiscal measures, and Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat has warned that Singapore cannot return to a pre-Covid-19 economy. Despite this, non-oil exports are expected to grow 3-5% in 2020, and job seekers can expect weekly updates on the job situation through the SGUnited package.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks climb more than 2%
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 2.11% on Tuesday, driven by hopes for upcoming China-US trade talks and optimism about a new US stimulus package. The Hang Seng Index reached 24,890.68, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.15%. The gains were also influenced by positive sentiment in Asia, with Singapore stocks notching a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Holiday Inn owner points to recovery after first half slump
summary: InterContinental Hotels, owner of Holiday Inn, reported a 52% drop in revenue to $488 million and an 82% slump in profit to $74 million in the first half of 2020, amid the pandemic. Despite this, the company sees "very early" signs of improvement in demand as restrictions ease and traveler confidence returns. Hotel room revenues have shown small but steady improvements, with July RevPAR down 58% from the previous quarter. IHG aims to reduce costs by $150 million this year and has $2 billion in available liquidity.

site_title: 61 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, lowest daily figure since April 2
summary: Singapore reported 61 new COVID-19 cases on August 11, the lowest daily total since April 2. Two young children, a 1-year-old girl and a 3-year-old girl, were among the new cases, both linked to previous cases and tested while under quarantine. The other 59 cases were imported, with three of them asymptomatic. This marks the lowest daily figure in over four months.

site_title: Peanut traders baffled by Sudan export ban on key cash crop
summary: Sudan has imposed an export ban on raw peanuts, a move that has left traders stunned. The government aims to process the nuts domestically to earn more revenue. This decision has significant implications for the country's agricultural sector, which has long been a major producer of peanuts. The ban is expected to impact the global peanut market and affect the livelihoods of those involved in the industry.

site_title: China is ditching expensive Brazilian soybeans for US supplies
summary: China is shifting its soybean purchases from expensive Brazilian supplies to American imports, following a widening price gap between the two countries. This move could help China meet its US trade deal pledges ahead of an August 15 meeting. The US has recently sold nearly 600,000 metric tons of soybeans to China, with more shipments expected. This shift is expected to boost American soybean exports and support the country's agricultural industry. China's soybean imports are crucial for meeting its phase-one trade deal commitments.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars settle back, data underwhelms
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars declined on Tuesday as the US dollar benefited from a squeeze on crowded short positions. The Aussie fell to US$0.7170, while the kiwi dollar held at US$0.6610. The currencies were affected by a fresh coronavirus lockdown in Victoria, Australia, and data showing a decline in consumer confidence. The New Zealand economy, however, has improved, with less pressure on the Reserve Bank of New Zealand to cut rates.

site_title: Two shophouses in CBD, three in Jalan Besar up for sale
summary: Two shophouses in Singapore's central business district (CBD) and three in Jalan Besar have been put up for sale by tender. The CBD shophouse, with a guide price of S$12 million (S$2,181 psf), is located near the upcoming Maxwell MRT station. The Jalan Besar shophouses have a guide price of S$12 million (S$2,143 psf) and are within walking distance to several MRT interchanges. The sale is expected to attract interest from developers and investors in the prime property market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher, snapping a three-day losing streak, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 1.88% and the Topix index gaining 2.54%. Gains were attributed to Wall Street's rally, as well as developments in the COVID-19 vaccine and US-China trade tensions. Carmakers such as Honda, Nissan, and Toyota surged, while SoftBank Group dropped 2.45% despite announcing a 11.9% quarterly profit increase.

site_title: Fuel hacks by Indian farmers among multiple threats to diesel
summary: Indian farmers are finding creative ways to reduce their diesel costs, using liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) to power their irrigation pumps. This trend, known as jugaad, could potentially chip away at diesel's dominance in the country's energy mix. With diesel prices surging and the government imposing fivefold increases in federal taxes over the last five years, farmers are turning to alternative energy sources like solar power and compressed natural gas. The use of LPG, however, is limited by supply issues, and experts say economics and environmental concerns will drive its adoption.

site_title: Gandhi's iconic glasses go on sale in UK
summary: A pair of iconic glasses worn by Indian independence hero Mahatma Gandhi are set to sell for tens of thousands of pounds in a UK auction. The gold-plated spectacles, which Gandhi gave to a vendor's uncle while working for British Petroleum in South Africa, were discovered by an auctioneer last week. The glasses are considered a rare and important historical find, with online bidding already reaching £50,000. The sale is expected to take place on August 21, with the estimated value of £15,000.

site_title: Hong Kong media stock surges 1,000% after publisher Jimmy Lai's arrest
summary: Hong Kong media stock Next Digital surged 1,500% after publisher Jimmy Lai's arrest under the city's national security law. The stock, controlled by Lai who owns 71%, reached a seven-year high due to a surge in retail investors buying shares online. The rally has lifted the company's market value by about HK$3.7 billion. Lai's supporters are also buying copies of his newspaper Apple Daily, with demand increasing to 550,000 copies.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally at open
summary: European stock markets rallied at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.9%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index jumping 1.0%, and Paris's CAC 40 index rising 1.1%. The rally followed strong gains in Asia.

site_title: Invoice trading platform Incomlend raises US$20m, led by Sequoia
summary: Incomlend, an online invoice trading platform, has raised US$20 million in a Series A round led by Sequoia India. The funding will be used to drive expansion into Europe, South-east Asia, and North Asia, and develop its digital invoice finance underwriting and processing. The platform facilitates trade finance for small and medium enterprises (SMEs), addressing the US$330 million financing gap they face due to tightened regulations. Incomlend has facilitated over 50 countries and aims to increase funded volumes of trade receivables.

site_title: UK job losses hit decade-high, worse seen ahead
summary: The UK job market has experienced its largest decline since 2009, with 220,000 fewer people working in the three months to June. The number of staff on company payrolls fell by 730,000 since March, and economists predict further job losses as the government winds down its job-protection scheme. The unemployment rate unexpectedly held at 3.9%, but pay fell by 1.2% in the April-June period, and job vacancies increased slightly in July. The UK economy is also expected to shrink for the second month, raising concerns about the impact of the coronavirus on the labor market.

images.alt_text: The number of working people in Britain has suffered the biggest drop since 2009 and signs are growing that the coronavirus will take a heavier toll on the labour market as the government winds down its huge job-protection scheme.

site_title: Bayer buys British developer of treatment for menopausal symptoms
summary: Bayer has agreed to acquire British biotech firm KaNDy Therapeutics Ltd for $425 million to strengthen its women's healthcare business with a prospective non-hormonal treatment of menopausal symptoms. The treatment, NT-814, has generated peak annual sales projections of over $1 billion euros. This acquisition aims to revive Bayer's women's healthcare business, which has been impacted by cheaper copies of birth control pills and injury claims related to its Essure device. The deal includes milestone payments of up to $450 million and potentially more than $100 million in sales-dependent payments.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend gains with eyes on trade talks, stimulus
summary: Asian markets continued their upward trend, driven by easing trade tensions and optimism about US stimulus. The US-China trade pact concerns eased, and China excluded Trump administration members from sanctions. Meanwhile, European markets faced a surge in COVID-19 cases, but signs of slowing virus transmission in major states, including New York and Texas, offered relief. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged towards fresh records, despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Swiss investor takes on China in bid to reboot EU solar industry
summary: A Swiss company, Meyer Burger Technology AG, is acquiring solar assets in Germany to restart module production and challenge China's dominance in the European solar industry. The company has bought Solarworld AG's stock and patents and plans to restart production in Germany's "Solar Valley" by next year. With a raised 165 million Swiss francs, Meyer Burger aims to cover almost a third of annual new European panel demand by the middle of the decade, potentially spurring employment and new automated technologies.

site_title: Australia's northern region to face virus measures until 2022
summary: Australia's Northern Territory will maintain its closure to visitors from virus hotspots for at least the next 18 months to protect its Aboriginal population. The region, home to 250,000 people, including 30% Aboriginal, will have strict hard border controls in place. Chief Minister Michael Gunner announced the measure to safeguard the vulnerable population.

images.alt_text: Australia's Northern Territory will be closed to visitors from virus hotspots for a further 18 months to protect its large and vulnerable Aboriginal population, authorities said on Tuesday.

site_title: SoftBank returns to profit after record losses
summary: SoftBank Group has returned to profit after posting a record loss of 1.44 trillion yen in the previous quarter, with a net income of 1.26 trillion yen in the first quarter of 2020. The company's Vision Fund income improved from a 1.13 trillion yen loss to 129.6 billion yen, driven by a global rally in technology shares and valuations for startups in its portfolio. SoftBank's CEO Masayoshi Son has pulled off a "remarkably speedy comeback" after selling off assets and buying back shares at unprecedented rates, pushing up SoftBank's own stock price to its highest in two decades.

site_title: Tencent-backed Waterdrop raises funds at US$2b value: sources
summary: Waterdrop, a Tencent-backed insurance tech startup, has raised approximately US$200 million in funding at a valuation of around US$2 billion. The company, which operates a healthcare crowdfunding platform called Water Mutual, plans to use the funds to expand its business and potentially list on the US stock market through an initial public offering (IPO). Waterdrop's IPO could help it fend off competition from Ant Group in the Chinese healthcare space, where demand for quality medical services is growing due to China's rapidly aging population.

site_title: HelloFresh Q2 earnings surge as lockdown effects persist
summary: German meal-kit delivery firm HelloFresh reported a surge in second-quarter sales and core profit, driven by extended coronavirus lockdowns and increased demand for food deliveries. The company's revenue more than doubled year-on-year to 972.1 million euros, and adjusted EBITDA came in at 153.6 million euros, exceeding July estimates. HelloFresh raised its full-year guidance, citing increased demand and higher customer retention, and now expects 75-95% revenue growth and 9-11% adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization margin.

site_title: Planners closely watching fiscal, monetary policy as Singapore enters worst recession
summary: Singapore's economy is entering its worst recession, prompting the government to unveil fiscal support measures. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat is set to update on plans, while the central bank stands by its monetary policy stance. The government will also share plans for specific sectors in the coming weeks. Despite economic challenges, Singapore has opportunities to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging and has a deep China-Singapore relationship. The country's employment rates show better early data, with graduates advised to stay calm.

site_title: SingPost partners logistics startup Shippit to widen SMEs' access to courier services
summary: SingPost has partnered with logistics startup Shippit to offer discounted rates for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to access courier services. The partnership provides SMEs with a range of delivery options, including direct delivery to Pick Own Parcel Stations and letterboxes, and discounted rates for next-day and economy delivery services. Shippit's platform will also provide data-driven insights to help SMEs optimize shipping costs and enhance customer experiences.

site_title: Sinovac launches late-stage trial for potential Covid-19 vaccine in Indonesia
summary: Sinovac Biotech Ltd launched a late-stage human trial for its Covid-19 vaccine candidate, CoronaVac, in Indonesia involving 1,620 patients. The trial comes as Indonesia grapples with spiking infection numbers. CoronaVac is also undergoing a trial in Brazil with 9,000 participants. The vaccine has shown safety and immune response in a Phase 2 clinical trial in China, with no serious side effects reported. Indonesia's President Joko Widodo attended the trial launch ceremony, stating that a vaccine will be crucial to combatting the virus. Sinovac plans to test the vaccine in Bangladesh as well.

site_title: Singapore condo resale volume nearly doubles in July: SRX
summary: Singapore's non-landed private home resale volume nearly doubled in July, reaching 978 units, with 53.6% of sales coming from the outside central region. The surge is attributed to pent-up demand and HDB upgraders entering the market, with 34.8% of non-landed resale homes bought by HDB owners in July. Overall resale prices rose 0.1% month-on-month, with OCR prices increasing 1.6%, while CCR prices dropped 1.7%.

site_title: Sembcorp, Sembmarine shareholders vote overwhelmingly in favour of demerger at EGM
summary: Sembcorp Marine and Sembcorp Industries shareholders have overwhelmingly voted in favour of a proposed $2.1 billion recapitalization and demerger, allowing Temasek Holdings to acquire a direct stake in the marine arm. SMM shareholders approved a rights issue, while SCI shareholders voted in favour of distributing its SMM shares in specie. The transactions aim to strengthen both companies, with SCI focusing on energy and urban businesses and SMM receiving recapitalization to ride out the industry downturn.

site_title: Jeffrey Ong hit with 4 more charges involving S$11.7m linked to Allied Tech
summary: Former law firm managing partner Jeffrey Ong has been charged with four additional counts of criminal breach of trust related to S$11.7 million misappropriated from an escrow facility for Allied Technologies. The charges bring his total to 57 counts of cheating, forgery, and breach of trust. The S$11.7 million was from Allied Tech's share placement exercise in 2017. Investigations are ongoing.

site_title: Perennial, Qingjian Realty sell 190 units at Forett At Bukit Timah condo
summary: Singapore property developers Qingjian Realty and Perennial Real Estate Holdings sold 190 units of their 633-unit Forett At Bukit Timah condo project at an average transacted price of S$1,880 per square foot. This represents 30% of the total units, which was sold during a virtual booking day event on Aug 8. The project is expected to receive its notice of vacant possession on Sept 6, 2024, and is located near Beauty World MRT station and the future Beauty World Integrated Transport Hub.

site_title: How Singapore nurtured foreign trio who became billionaires
summary: Singapore's strategic approach to attracting foreign talent has contributed to the success of Sea Ltd, a tech giant co-founded by billionaires David Chen, Forrest Li, and Gang Ye. The company's popularity during the pandemic, driven by its mobile game Free Fire and e-commerce platform Shopee, has made it one of the city-state's biggest companies by market value. The founders, who have become citizens of Singapore, attribute their success to the country's meritocratic system and government support. With Sea's market value reaching $58 billion, its founders are now among Singapore's wealthiest individuals.

site_title: Cookware chain Sur La Table sells for around US$90m
summary: Sur La Table, an upscale cookware chain, sold for approximately $90 million in a bankruptcy auction, with a joint venture between CSC Generation and Marquee Brands emerging as the top bidder. The sale, pending bankruptcy court approval, would save around 2,000 jobs. Sur La Table filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in July amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with 121 stores across the US at the time of its filing. The company's assets were acquired by the joint venture, which also agreed to keep at least 50 stores open.

site_title: Royal Caribbean eyes Covid-19 testing to help restart cruises
summary: Royal Caribbean Group plans to implement COVID-19 testing for passengers as part of its new safety measures to resume sailing. CEO Michael Bayley stated that testing is "very likely" to occur, and the company is working with the CDC to approve a return-to-sailing plan by the end of the month. The move aims to mitigate the risk of infection on ships, as the CDC has a no-sail order in place. Royal Caribbean's shares rose 11% in early trading following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Royal Caribbean Group said on Monday testing passengers for Covid-19 was "very likely" going to be part of a new set of safety measures planned to get its ships to resume sailing after months of being docked.

site_title: Tencent Music revenue jumps 18% as paid subscribers flock to expanded library
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment Group's second-quarter revenue surged 18% to 6.93 billion yuan (S$1.37 billion), beating estimates, driven by a 52% increase in paid subscribers to 47.1 million. The company's strong performance comes amid growing tensions between China and the US, but its chief strategy officer dismissed speculation over a potential delisting. Tencent Music has signed partnerships with major music labels and announced a new joint venture music label, further expanding its premium user base.

images.alt_text: China's Tencent Music Entertainment Group (TME) said on Monday its quarterly revenue leaped 18 per cent, beating Wall Street estimates, as it put more music for streaming behind its paywall and grew its paid subscriber base by more than half.

site_title: Lendlease Global Reit's 0.48 S cent Q4 DPU misses IPO forecast
summary: Lendlease Global Reit's Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.48 Singapore cent missed its IPO forecast of 1.28 cents, down 62.7%. The company's gross revenue of S$12.5 million also fell short of the forecast of S$21.5 million, missing by 42.1%. The lower revenue was attributed to Singapore's "circuit breaker" and rental waivers, but was partly offset by higher revenue from the Sky Complex asset.

site_title: Singapore's refining sector shows some recovery in July: Refinitiv
summary: Singapore's refining sector has shown a recovery in July, with its three refineries reaching full operable capacity of 1.315 million barrels per day, the first time since February 2020. This marks an improvement from an average of 80% capacity in the previous quarter and a five-year low of 76% in May, according to Refinitiv Oil Research.

site_title: Taiwan foreign minister says China trying to turn island into 'next Hong Kong'
summary: Taiwan's Foreign Minister Joseph Wu warned that China is trying to turn the democratic island into another Hong Kong, citing a crackdown on dissent and pressure to accept Beijing's conditions. The warning came during a meeting with US Health Secretary Alex Azar, who praised Taiwan's democracy and success in battling the coronavirus. The visit is part of the US's highest-level diplomatic trip to Taiwan since it switched recognition to China in 1979, amid tensions between the US and China over trade, military, and security issues. Taiwan lives under the threat of losing its freedoms to China.

site_title: Sydney Airport plans to raise A$2b to battle virus hit after H1 loss
summary: Sydney Airport Holdings plans to raise A$2 billion in equity to lower debt levels after reporting a net loss of A$53.6 million for the six months ended June 30, due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on travel. The airport's domestic passenger numbers are down 94.2% and international traffic is down 96.8% compared to the same period last year. The company's net debt position will reduce to A$7.1 billion, and a staff job guarantee for its 500 employees will not be extended beyond September 30.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher following US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, following gains on Wall Street, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.79% and the Topix index climbing 0.92%. This follows a long weekend and US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australian business conditions improve, but new lockdown slugs sentiment: survey
summary: Australia's business conditions improved in July, with a rise in the National Australia Bank's index of business conditions to 0, up from -8 in June and a low of -34 in April. However, confidence fell to -14, down from 0 in June, due to a renewed coronavirus outbreak in Victoria. The service sector rebounded from a national lockdown, but the pandemic's impact on tourism and education continues to affect the economy. The Reserve Bank of Australia has warned of a 6% economic contraction this year, and interest rates remain at an all-time low of 0.25%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.81 points, or 0.31%, to 1,576.47 at 9:20am on Tuesday, driven by a 1.36 billion lots volume worth RM420.73 million. The market opened higher, with 471 gainers surpassing 103 losers.

site_title: Singapore 'not returning to a pre-Covid-19 world': Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's economy has taken a record 13.2% plunge in the second quarter, with Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing warning that the country cannot afford to wait out the coronavirus crisis. Permanent changes mean there will be no going back to a pre-Covid-19 economy. Chan pledged to support business growth, job creation, and market access, while strengthening links to global markets and defending Singapore's networks and capabilities. The government will help sectors like food and beverage services with immediate cash flows and help industries that have permanently changed, such as mass-market tourism, pivot into new markets.

site_title: Staycationing Britons start opening wallets in boost to retail
summary: UK consumer spending increased 4.3% in July compared to last year, driven by a boost to the hospitality industry from "staycationing" Britons. Retail sales rose as people bought more takeaway food and visited local shops. While overall travel spending remained 60% lower than last year, essential items like supermarket goods and furniture stores showed significant growth. The government's Eat Out to Help Out programme may further boost sales this month, but uncertainty over job security and the furlough scheme's unwinding may impact consumer spending in the autumn.

site_title: Defying China, Hong Kongers rush to buy pro-democracy newspaper
summary: Hong Kongers rallied in support of pro-democracy newspaper Apple Daily after its owner, Jimmy Lai, was arrested under China's new national security law. Lai was detained on charges including colluding with foreign forces and fraud. In response, the newspaper saw a surge in sales, with over 550,000 copies printed, a 7.5-fold increase from its normal circulation. The move is seen as a show of solidarity against China's crackdown on dissent in Hong Kong, which has sparked outrage in the West.

site_title: Facebook creates unit devoted to financial services
summary: Facebook has created a new unit called Facebook Financial to harmonize payment systems on its platform. The unit, headed by e-commerce veteran David Marcus, aims to build financial services into its offerings and expand commerce opportunities for small businesses. The move comes as the company prepares to launch its digital currency Libra and a digital wallet called Novi. Facebook Financial will handle payments and money services across the platform, aiming to give users the ability to make payments in various ways, including debit, credit, and Libra digital currencies.

site_title: China auto sales surge in July, log fourth straight month of gains
summary: China's auto sales surged 16.4% in July, marking the fourth consecutive month of gains, with 2.11 million vehicles sold. Despite the increase, the year-to-date sales are still down 12.7% at 12.37 million vehicles. The China Association of Automobile Manufacturers expects auto sales to fall around 10% this year unless a second wave of virus infections occurs, potentially leading to a 20% decline.

site_title: 24,000 placed under SGUnited package so far; MOM to give weekly updates on job situation
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) reported that as of the end of July, 24,000 people have been placed under the SGUnited Jobs and Skills package. Future updates will highlight job opportunities and key employment indicators. Preliminary estimates confirm that the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on Singapore's economy and labor market will persist, with softness in the labor market and continued weakness in hiring.

site_title: Marriott posts bigger-than-expected loss as virus hits bookings
summary: Marriott International reported a larger-than-expected quarterly loss due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on global travel and room bookings. The company's shares fell 3.8% and revenue per available room plummeted 84.4%. Despite this, Marriott expects a gradual rise in occupancy rates, but it may take a few years to return to pre-COVID demand levels.

site_title: Japan's current account surplus shrinks to 5-year low as exports plunge
summary: Japan's current account surplus shrank to 5-year low in June, totaling 167.5 billion yen, due to a 25.7% decline in exports and a 14.4% drop in imports. The trade deficit widened to 157.7 billion yen, with a 99.9% drop in foreign tourists contributing to the travel account deficit. Weakening overseas demand raises concerns of a prolonged downturn for Japan's economy, with analysts expecting a 27.2% annualized contraction in the second quarter.

site_title: Isolate yourself or face prison, Finland tells new arrivals
summary: Finland's health minister Krista Kiuru announced that people arriving in the country from coronavirus "risk countries" must self-isolate for 14 days, face a fine, or up to three months' imprisonment. This change comes after reports of planes arriving with infected passengers or those who refused testing. The new rules will apply to all countries except those on Finland's green list, which have fewer than eight new cases per 100,000 population. The measures aim to control the spread of the virus, which has seen 135 new infections in the past seven days.

site_title: Australian employment steady in July, Victoria suffers setback
summary: Australian employment remained steady in July, with a 0.1% decrease nationwide, but Victoria suffered a 1.5% decline due to strict mobility restrictions and curfews. The southeastern state is expected to experience further job losses in vulnerable sectors. Economists predict a 22-year high in the national jobless rate, reaching 7.8%, despite a 40,000 job increase. The decline in Victoria is a setback, and recovery is unlikely until restrictions are eased, according to economists.

site_title: Trump says he is inclined to host G-7 meeting after the Nov 3 election
summary: US President Donald Trump announced he is inclined to host a Group of Seven summit after the November presidential election in a "calmer atmosphere." Trump postponed the June G-7 summit due to the pandemic and has considered expanding the list of invitees. He expressed interest in inviting Russian President Vladimir Putin, stating he doesn't know if he will be invited yet. Trump hopes to reschedule the summit for a date after the election, which would provide a more tranquil atmosphere. No specific date has been set.

site_title: South Korea's Aug 1-10 exports dive as shipments to major trading partners drop
summary: South Korea's exports declined 23.6% in the first 10 days of August, mainly due to a drop in shipments to major trading partners, including China, the US, and Europe. Imports also decreased 24.3% during the same period. The decline is attributed to the ongoing coronavirus crisis affecting demand. Full month trade data for August will be released on September 1.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports tipped to expand 3-5% in 2020; worst-case scenario for world trade now unlikely
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) are forecast to grow 3-5% in 2020, a significant improvement from previous estimates of -4 to -1%. Total trade is expected to fall less sharply, by -10 to -8%. This adjustment comes after second-quarter NODX growth was better than expected, driven by favourable sector-specific exports and output trends. The revised forecasts suggest that the worst-case scenario for world trade is now unlikely.

site_title: New Opportunities in EU-Vietnam Trade; New Opportunities for ASEAN
summary: The EU-Vietnam Free Trade Agreement (EVFTA) has come into effect, significantly reducing tariffs between the two regions. The agreement aims to boost trade and investment between the EU and Vietnam, with 99% of tariffs expected to be eliminated in the future. This follows the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement and the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), which have contributed to increased trade and economic growth in Vietnam, with the CPTPP generating over $3.9 billion in trade surplus for the country.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 3-week high as Covid-19 cases stabilise
summary: Australian shares reached a three-week high on August 11, 2020, as Covid-19 cases in Victoria stabilised, boosting investor sentiment. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.56% to its highest since July 22. Daily infections in Victoria peaked at 725 on August 5 but have been trending lower since a hard lockdown was imposed in Melbourne on July 19. This lifted investor confidence, contributing to the index's gain.

site_title: SGX expands Asian equity derivatives, to launch 13 futures in August, September
summary: SGX is expanding its Asian equity derivatives, launching 13 new futures in August and September. The new futures are based on FTSE Russell indices and include benchmarks for Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan, Thailand, and Vietnam. This expansion meets growing demand for institutional-grade exchange solutions in Asia. The move aims to provide customers with more benchmarks, enhancing SGX's shelf of benchmark equity derivatives.

site_title: China seeks to drop rating requirement for some bond issuers
summary: China's securities regulator proposes removing a requirement for bond issuers on the country's stock exchange markets to seek credit ratings, aiming to ease debt issuance and address excessive competition in the local credit rating industry. The move is seen as part of a broader effort to ease financial stress and arrest a dramatic economic slowdown. The public consultation on the amended draft guidelines will end on September 6, with analysts suggesting it could make it easier for issuers to sell bonds and prompt rating firms to focus on borrowers' business operations and financial data.

site_title: Small businesses in Asean prioritising tech investments for 2020: survey
summary: Small businesses in Southeast Asia prioritize technology investments for 2020, with 64% of surveyed businesses citing it as a top priority. Despite cash flow concerns, 44% plan to increase their technology budget. The focus on technology is expected to intensify as businesses prepare to reopen, with experts noting that digital transformation can lead to long-term competitiveness and resilience.

site_title: HC Surgical shareholder files appeal after failed bid to sue chief executive
summary: A minority shareholder, Serene Tiong, has filed an appeal after the Singapore High Court dismissed her application to sue HC Surgical Specialists' CEO, Heah Sieu Min, for alleged breach of duties. Tiong claimed Dr. Heah breached his duties in relation to the acquisition of an additional stake in Julian Ong Endoscopy & Surgery. The court ordered Tiong to pay S$10,000 in costs. HCSS will continue to liaise with its legal adviser and will update shareholders on material developments.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin Tuesday's session with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with gains on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.17% to 24,662.04, following recent losses. The gains come amid China-US tensions, with Beijing imposing sanctions on 11 Americans in response to similar sanctions from Washington. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index remained flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.07%. Investors appear to be brushing off recent Trump threats, with stocks in other regions, such as Singapore and Europe, also showing resilience.

site_title: AXA weighs sale of Singapore business to raise cash
summary: AXA is considering the sale of its Singapore business to raise funds, with a potential sale process starting as soon as the next few weeks. The Singapore unit, which generated 615 million euros in revenue in 2019, could draw interest from rivals seeking to expand in South-east Asia. This sale, along with a potential sale of an insurance venture in Malaysia, would help AXA pay for its US$15.3 billion purchase of XL Group in 2018. The move follows AXA's CEO Thomas Buberl's efforts to shift focus to property and casualty insurance.

images.alt_text: AXA is considering a sale of its Singapore business as it seeks to raise funds divesting peripheral operations, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust unitholders withdraw requisition notice after sponsor ups offer price
summary: Accordia Golf Trust's trustee-manager announced that two unitholders, Hibiki Path Advisors and CIM Dividend Income Fund, have withdrawn their requisition notice for an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to block the sale of the trust's 88 golf courses in Japan. The remaining unitholders now hold less than 10% of the required voting rights. The trust's sponsor, Accordia Golf, is willing to increase the purchase price to 65.2 billion yen (S$848.4 million) after initial negotiations with Hibiki, the largest minority unitholder, resulted in the withdrawal of the EGM requisition notice.

site_title: Former Paypal executive to lead Facebook Pay
summary: Facebook Inc has named Stephane Kasriel, a former PayPal executive, to lead Facebook Pay, a company executive announced. Kasriel will oversee Facebook Pay and other payments-related initiatives, including WhatsApp payments. A new group will be created to manage these initiatives. Kasriel previously served as CEO of freelance marketplace Upwork Inc.

site_title: US frees more bandwidth for 5G network use
summary: The US has announced the release of 100 megahertz of bandwidth for commercial 5G network use, increasing the mid-band spectrum available for 5G networks to 535 megahertz. The spectrum, previously reserved for the military, will be auctioned off by the Federal Communications Commission in December and could be deployed as early as mid-2022. This move aims to support the development of 5G networks in the US, which lags behind countries like China and South Korea in deploying the technology.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Singapore Airlines, SGX, iFast, Accordia Golf, Tuan Sing
summary: Keppel Corp's Temasek Holdings is pulling out of its S$4 billion partial offer due to the company's S$697.6 million net loss for the second quarter. Singapore Airlines and pilots' union Alpa-S signed a deal reducing pilots' basic salaries by 10%. Singapore Exchange expanded its benchmark equity derivatives. iFast Corp rose after a Bloomberg report on Hong Kong's digitalisation of retirement funds. Accordia Golf Trust's sponsor increased its offer to buy golf courses in Japan, and Tuan Sing Holdings is divesting Robinson Point for S$500 million.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at open despite Q2 GDP plunge; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.3% to 2,553.06 on Tuesday, despite a 13.2% plunge in Q2 GDP, the worst on record. Forecasts for trade growth were adjusted for the third time in 2020, with non-oil domestic exports now expected to grow 3-5% this year.

site_title: Singapore Q2 GDP plunges by 13.2% in worst quarter on record
summary: Singapore's Q2 GDP plummeted by 13.2% year-over-year, the worst quarter on record, due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on business closures and external demand. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) cut its full-year recession forecast to 5-7% contraction, down from 4-7%. Key sectors like construction and manufacturing declined sharply, while services and biomedical manufacturing saw some growth. Analysts predict a sluggish recovery in the second half, with significant downside risks to the economy.

site_title: Oil companies start to take back crude back from US emergency reserve
summary: Energy companies, including Exxon and Chevron, have begun returning 2.2 million barrels of oil to the US government's Strategic Petroleum Reserve, a facility they rented to manage a crude glut in April and May. The companies had stored 23 million barrels in the reserve, and they have until March 31, 2021, to return the oil after paying a small fee. This move follows the collapse in energy demand during the Covid-19 lockdowns.

site_title: US says IMF economic outlook too pessimistic
summary: The US government disputes the IMF's annual review of the US economy, which it claims is too pessimistic and oversteps its mandate by calling for significant changes to the US economy. US Representative Mark Rosen said the government has sufficient resources to address the pandemic, but disagrees with the IMF's suggestion to "broadly remake" the US economy. The IMF predicted a 6.6% contraction in GDP this year, which Rosen considers too pessimistic, and the US government believes the recovery will pick up speed as states reopen.

site_title: Mauritius braces to halt new oil spill as tanker breaks up
summary: Mauritius is racing against time to prevent a new oil spill as the damaged tanker MV Wakashio, carrying nearly 2,000 tonnes of fuel, is at risk of splitting apart. The ship, which ran aground on July 25, has already released over 1,000 tonnes of oil, causing significant ecological damage. Salvage crews have successfully pumped out 500 tonnes, but efforts to pump out more fuel have been hindered by rough seas. Japan has dispatched a team to assist, and France has sent technical equipment and advisers to help with the clean-up.

site_title: McDonald's sues ex-CEO for allegedly lying about sexual relationships
summary: McDonald's sued former CEO Steve Easterbrook for allegedly lying about sexual relationships with employees, violating company policy. Easterbrook was dismissed in 2019 for a consensual relationship with an employee and had previously destroyed information about other relationships. The lawsuit claims Easterbrook committed fraud by misleading the company over his separation agreement and seeks to recover compensation and severance benefits. An internal investigation found evidence of two other relationships, including explicit photographs and videos of company employees.

site_title: Europe: Improving China data spurs mild gains as trade nerves persist
summary: European shares rose 0.3% as improving Chinese economic data boosted cyclical stocks, despite US-China tensions affecting technology shares. China's factory deflation eased in July, driven by rising oil prices and industrial activity recovering towards pre-pandemic levels. Trading volumes were lower due to summer holidays, with the broader European Stoxx 600 index holding to tight ranges.

site_title: Outcry over Hong Kong media mogul Jimmy Lai's arrest
summary: Hong Kong media mogul Jimmy Lai, 71, was arrested on Monday in a police raid on his newspaper office, amid a sweeping crackdown on dissent since China imposed a security law on the city. Lai, along with nine others, was charged with colluding with foreign forces and fraud. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo condemned the arrest, calling it "further proof" that Chinese authorities have eroded Hong Kong's freedoms. The arrests sparked widespread condemnation and a fresh round of criticism over Hong Kong's stuttering freedoms.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong pro-democracy media tycoon Jimmy Lai was arrested on Monday and led in handcuffs through his newspaper office as police raided the building, part of a sweeping crackdown on dissent since China imposed a security law on the city.

site_title: AIMS Apac Reit proposes to buy Bulim Street logistics facility for S$129.6m
summary: AIMS Apac Reit proposes to acquire a 7 Bulim Street logistics facility for S$129.6 million, with an estimated total cost of S$135.5 million. The property, located in the Jurong Innovation District, has a 22.2-year land tenure and a 10-year lease to KWE-Kintetsu World Express. The acquisition will add to the Reit's logistics and warehouse cluster, increasing its rental contribution to 36.4% and overall portfolio occupancy rate to 94.2%. The deal is expected to enhance the Reit's income amid challenging market conditions.

site_title: Stock picking, disrupted - taking on the experts
summary: Ken Teng, a star vlogger, advocates for retail investors to adopt a narrow portfolio of disruptive companies, rather than betting on traditional "value stocks." He believes the world is changing, and investors should follow this approach to potentially achieve better returns. This sentiment reflects a shift in the investment landscape, where traditional pundits are being challenged by vloggers and experts who offer alternative perspectives on the market.

site_title: Trump could give nomination speech at Gettysburg battlefield
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to deliver his renomination speech for the Republican nomination at either the White House or the Gettysburg battlefield, citing the unprecedented circumstances of the COVID-19 pandemic. This move is seen as a grandiose attempt to capitalize on the historic significance of the battlefield, where Abraham Lincoln delivered his famous Gettysburg Address. The decision has sparked controversy, with critics arguing that it is inappropriate and may violate a law separating official duties from campaigning efforts.

site_title: Oil settles higher on Chinese factory data, US stimulus hopes
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, driven by data showing Chinese factories returning to pre-pandemic levels and hopes for US economic stimulus. Brent crude settled up 59 cents to $44.99 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate US crude rose 72 cents to $41.94 a barrel. The US and China are discussing economic relief, and Saudi Arabia's Aramco CEO expects oil demand to rebound in Asia as economies reopen. Iraq also announced plans to cut oil output to comply with Opec+ cuts.

site_title: White House guards shoot person, briefly evacuate Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump was briefly evacuated from a press conference outside the White House after Secret Service guards shot a person, reportedly armed, on the White House grounds. The suspect is on their way to the hospital. Trump said he knew nothing about the suspect's identity or motives and initially believed the person was armed. The incident occurred just after Trump began the press conference, and he returned shortly after the shooting was reported.

images.alt_text: Secret Service guards shot a person, who was apparently armed, outside the White House on Monday, President Donald Trump said just after being briefly evacuated in the middle of a press conference.

site_title: The letters of economic recovery
summary: Singapore has established a centre to advance sustainable aviation in the Asia-Pacific region. The country is also focusing on economic recovery, with initiatives such as a new grant of up to S$100,000 for tariff-hit businesses. Additionally, the government is promoting chip packaging as a potential global hub, and offering support for workers to future-proof their careers. Graduates are advised to remain calm, with early data showing better employment rates, and a study suggests Singapore has the potential to become a global leader in advanced chip packaging.

site_title: Trump's America Inc is TikToking towards mercantilism
summary: US President Donald Trump's approach to business and trade has shifted towards a mercantilist strategy, prioritizing US interests and control over corporations. He has used personal attacks and public battles with companies to achieve his goals, such as pressuring Boeing and Silicon Valley giants. Trump's stance on TikTok, a Chinese-owned app, is also driven by a desire to protect US interests and undermine China's influence. His actions have been criticized for being hypocritical, as the US has long accused China of employing mercantilist tactics.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends mixed as new aid deal remains elusive
summary: US stocks ended Monday's trading session mixed, with the Nasdaq retreating 0.4% to 10,968.36, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 1.3% to 27,791.44 and the S&P 500 rose 0.3% to 3,360.47. Investors await an elusive deal on a new emergency spending package and uncertain pandemic data.

site_title: Medical masks best, cotton good, bandanas worse: droplet study
summary: A study ranked 14 types of face masks, finding that medical masks offer significantly more protection against droplet spread than cotton alternatives, with bandanas and balaclavas providing minimal protection. The study used a laser setup to measure droplet transmission and found that N95 masks reduced transmission to less than 0.1%, while surgical masks reduced it by 90%. Cotton face coverings provided good coverage, but bandanas were less effective. The findings have public policy implications, particularly in the US, where authorities have encouraged textile masks, and experts are calling for increased production and distribution of medical masks.

site_title: Digitalisation of local SMEs could add up to US$24b to GDP by 2024: survey
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can add up to US$24 billion to the country's GDP by 2024 through digital transformation, according to a survey. Digitally mature SMEs enjoy twice as many revenue and productivity gains as those with an indifferent approach to digitalization. The pandemic has accelerated digitalization efforts for nearly 70% of SMEs across the Asia-Pacific region, with 86% believing digitalization will help them develop resilience against similar crises. Governments, educational institutions, and industry bodies must work together to help SMEs seize digitalization opportunities.

site_title: As Trump falters, Democrats and Biden eye an elusive prize: Texas
summary: US President Donald Trump's handling of the coronavirus pandemic has led to increased frustration among Texans, who are increasingly looking to Democrats, particularly Joe Biden, as a viable alternative. With polls showing Biden tied or ahead in Texas, his campaign is investing $280 million in advertising and hiring staff in the state. Democrats believe a successful effort in Texas could expand Biden's chances to win the presidency. However, skeptics point out that Texas is traditionally a Republican stronghold, and Trump's campaign remains confident in his chances in the state.

site_title: Businesses welcome cross-border travel arrangements between Singapore and Malaysia
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have welcomed cross-border travel arrangements, allowing employers to attend essential meetings and workers to see their families more often. The arrangements, which began on August 10, include a reciprocal green lane for short-term travel and a periodic commuting arrangement for long-term work purposes. The Malaysia-Singapore Business Council will provide feedback to governments on improving the arrangements. This move aims to address pressing travel needs, strengthen business ties, and boost the digital economy between the two countries.

site_title: Facebook, Microsoft gripes with Apple's App Store on EU's antitrust radar
summary: Facebook and Microsoft are joining other companies in expressing concerns to the EU about Apple's App Store rules, which they claim create an uneven playing field for developers. The European Commission has opened four probes into Apple, including its App Store and restrictive rules, which require app developers to use its in-app purchasing system. Facebook and Microsoft claim Apple's rules are overly restrictive, particularly for gaming apps, and are seeking more leniency. Apple maintains its rules protect customers and provide a fair playing field for developers, but has allowed some exceptions, such as Sony's PlayStation Remote and Valve's SteamLink.

site_title: Tuan Sing to divest Robinson Point for S$500m
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings is divesting its 21-storey Robinson Point office building in Singapore for S$500 million, expecting a gain of about S$128.3 million. The buyer, One South Bay Group, is a British Virgin Islands-incorporated entity not related to Tuan Sing. The divestment is part of the firm's capital recycling strategy to optimize shareholder returns and is expected to fund committed investments and debt repayment.

site_title: Tech titans say Trump block on worker visas harms US
summary: Tech giants Amazon, Apple, and Facebook have joined a court filing opposing US President Donald Trump's block on worker visas, citing harm to the US economy and workforce. The brief argues that suspending visas for skilled workers will stifle innovation, hinder growth, and ultimately harm US workers, businesses, and the economy. The proclamation, which suspended visas for various categories of guest workers, was issued in June and is set to last through this year. The tech industry titans claim that the suspension will lead to other countries benefiting from the US's move, with global competitors aggressively updating their immigration systems to attract skilled workers.

site_title: Hong Kong property tycoons hit by protests, Covid-19 restrictions
summary: Hong Kong's property tycoons are facing significant financial losses due to months of protests and Covid-19 restrictions. Collectively, they have lost US$7.7 billion this year, with the index tracking the city's developers plummeting 21% - the largest decline among all industry groups. Key players such as Li Ka-shing's CK Asset Holdings and the Kwoks' Sun Hung Kai Properties have seen revenue from property sales and rental income decline sharply, with some slashing rents and vacancy rates rising.

site_title: Australia borders to stay shut as Covid-19 daily deaths reach record
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced internal border closures will likely remain in place until Christmas due to a record single day rise in Covid-19 deaths. The country reported a record 121 deaths on Monday. However, drastic lockdown measures in Melbourne appear to be slowing new infections in the state of Victoria to a near two-week low.

site_title: China factory prices ease, while consumer inflation picks up
summary: China's factory deflation eased in July, with the producer price index (PPI) falling 2.4% from a year earlier, driven by rising global oil prices and increased industrial activity. This marks a recovery in the world's second-largest economy. Consumer inflation, however, picked up, contradicting the easing of factory prices.

site_title: Rush for data centres, telecoms towers may be boon for telcos
summary: Telcos are selling their data centres and telecom towers to free up capital for investments in 5G technology. Deals include Telstra's sale of its data centre to Big Data Exchange, Bharti Airtel's sale of 25% of Nxtra Data to Carlyle Group, and Indonesian telco Indosat Ooredoo's sale of 3,100 telecom towers to Mitratel and Protelindo. Experts say telcos are cash-strapped and need more capital to support 5G rollout, while buyers are attracted to markets with low tenancy ratios and high demand.

site_title: BP's green energy targets will be tough to meet
summary: BP aims to become a major renewable power generator by 2030, but may struggle to meet its 50GW target due to high upfront costs and lower returns from renewable energy investments. The company will need to invest tens of billions of dollars and accept lower returns from oil if it is to achieve its goal. Analysts estimate that BP will need to spend around $60 billion to achieve its target, with high start-up costs and limited project financing options. The company's shares have halved over the past two years, while those of rival Orsted and Iberdrola have surged.

site_title: Superdry's stronger-than-expected sales boosts shares
summary: British fashion retailer Superdry reported stronger-than-expected Q1 sales, with e-commerce revenue growing 93.2% despite a 24.1% decline in group revenue. Store sales fell 58.1%, but trading in stores was better than expected, and the company has boosted its liquidity with a £70 million lending facility. This has sent its shares up 15% and pared 2020 losses to 73%. Superdry's stores reopened 95% after the coronavirus lockdown and the company now has £57.8 million in net cash on its balance sheet.

site_title: Law firms take more extensive cuts amid unprecedented crisis
