summary: Several well-known law firms in Singapore, including Dentons Rodyk and WongPartnership, have imposed pay cuts amid the unprecedented crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Dentons Rodyk reduced its advance bonuses, while WongPartnership cut its front-loaded bonuses by 5-10%. The moves are seen as a way for firms to be prudent and maintain financial stability. The pay cuts are expected to impact lawyers and staff, with some firms considering further restructuring measures if the economic situation worsens. The impact on the legal sector is expected to be significant, with some firms exploring alternative career paths.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's tourism landmark Al-Ula signs agreement with Accor
summary: Saudi Arabia's tourism landmark Al-Ula has signed an agreement with Accor to expand and operate a resort under the Banyan Tree brand, adding 47 new units to its total capacity of 82 high-end villas. The agreement aims to boost the kingdom's tourism sector, which is expected to decline 35-45% this year due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Al-Ula's development is part of a broader push to diversify the economy and attract non-Muslim tourists, with a planned official opening as a year-round destination in October. The project is located in the Ashar Valley, about 15km from Hegra, Saudi Arabia's first Unesco World Heritage Site.

site_title: Johnson fears loss of UK's power and magic if Scotland breaks away
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned that the UK would be weaker if Scotland broke away, citing the union's "greatest political partnership" and the "magic" of their relationship. Despite a 2014 referendum showing Scotland voted 55% to 45% against independence, the Scottish National Party seeks another vote. Johnson's Conservative Party, which governs all of Britain, dismisses any call for another vote, but has visited Scotland to discuss the benefits of the relationship.

site_title: Dollar rally resumes as US-China tensions escalate
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro and Swiss franc on Monday, driven by escalating US-China tensions and fiscal stimulus efforts in the US. The dollar index rose 1% to 93.532, its highest level in a week, as investors sought a safe-haven asset amid trade talks and sanctions. China retaliated with sanctions on 11 US citizens, including legislators, while Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai was arrested under China's new national security law.

site_title: Tuan Sing to divest Robinson Point for S$500m
summary: PROPERTY developer Tuan Sing Holdings is selling its 21-storey freehold office building, Robinson Point, for S$500 million. The sale is expected to result in a gain of about S$128.3 million for the company. The buyer, One South Bay Group, is a British Virgin Islands-incorporated entity not related to Tuan Sing. The divestment is part of the company's capital recycling strategy to optimise shareholder returns, and will allow it to fund committed investments and corporate needs. The sale highlights strong demand for commercial spaces in Singapore.

site_title: Hyundai supply deal may see more hydrogen cars in Sydney
summary: Hyundai Motor Co has signed a supply deal with local producers in Sydney, Australia to produce and supply hydrogen generated from solar and wind power to its hub. The deal aims to demonstrate the feasibility of renewably-generated hydrogen gas for vehicle refuelling, addressing a major barrier to hydrogen car adoption. The agreement is part of Australia's plans to build a hydrogen export industry, with the country's natural advantages in renewable power to manufacture the fuel. This could lead to more hydrogen-powered vehicles on Sydney's streets.

site_title: Italy's richest family builds 2.8b euro side bet to candy giant
summary: Giovanni Ferrero, son of Nutella and Kinder chocolate creator Michele Ferrero, has increased his family's fortune by 40% to 2.8 billion euros through his investment firm CTH's acquisition of Danish cookie baker Kelsen Group. The move aims to diversify the family's wealth and invest beyond the confectionery industry. This strategy follows a similar path taken by other wealthy individuals, such as Zara founder Amancio Ortega and Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates, who are diversifying their fortunes to grow wealth across generations.

site_title: Top US mall operator Simon faces pandemic pain
summary: US mall operator Simon Property Group, the largest US mall owner, reported its smallest quarterly profit in nearly six years due to surging Covid-19 infections in major states, scaring shoppers away from reopened malls. This resulted in tenants being unable or unwilling to pay full rent, affecting the industry already weakened by the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Shoppers at Pennsylvania's King of Prussia Mall, owned by Simon Property Group. The No. 1 US mall owner posted its smallest quarterly profit in nearly six years on Monday.

site_title: Are financial markets none the wiser?
summary: Financial markets have continued to rally despite the collapse of the world economy, sparking concerns about the sustainability of this trend. The US Federal Reserve has emphasized that interest rates will not be raised anytime soon, and the European Union has agreed to a 750 billion euro recovery fund. However, the possibility of Covid-19 infection rates spiking again, vaccine trial failures, and President Trump's aggressive actions against China could lead to a chaotic autumn. Alternatively, the "drip-drip" of the crisis may prompt governments to improve their response, leading to a more positive scenario with potential benefits such as increased productivity and investment in climate change and health systems.

site_title: Hyundai driving global EV sales with new family of Ioniq cars
summary: Hyundai Motor Co is launching a family of electric vehicles under the Ioniq brand to capture 10% of global EV sales by 2025. The company plans to introduce three all-electric models starting in early 2021, including the Ioniq 5, Ioniq 6, and Ioniq 7. The new models will be built on a dedicated EV platform, enabling fast charging capability and ample driving range. Hyundai aims to become the world's third-largest seller of EVs, competing with traditional carmakers Volkswagen and General Motors, and Tesla, which remains the world's EV leader.

site_title: Property developers have not seen the worst yet
summary: Singapore property developers may face challenges ahead, despite a 0.3% increase in private home prices in Q2, led by the core central region. However, economists warn that this uptick might be a blip, with a potential decline in prices and sales volumes in the next two years. Discounts on properties are expected, with developers dangling incentives to move units. Analysts predict a slow declining trajectory in private home prices, with a possible 3-5% decline this year and 20% drop in primary market transactions.

site_title: SIA, Alpa-S agree on pilot pay cut, change to compulsory no pay leave scheme
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and the Air Line Pilots Association - Singapore (Alpa-S) have agreed on a memorandum of agreement, reducing pilots' basic salary by 10% and adjusting the compulsory no pay leave (CNPL) scheme. Captains will take four days of CNPL, First Officers one day, and Second Officers none. The move comes as the airline faces a significant financial crisis due to the pandemic, with SIA operating just 7% of its original capacity.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and the Air Line Pilots Association - Singapore (Alpa-S) have inked a memorandum of agreement (MOA) which will see pilots taking a 10 per cent cut in their basic salary and an adjustment to their compulsory no pay leave (CNPL) scheme.

site_title: Philippine trash trawlers earn little from recent surge in plastics
summary: Filipino trash trawler Virgilio Estuesta finds an unusually high amount of plastics in Manila, but the income from recycling them is not enough to sustain him. The surge in single-use plastics is attributed to the pandemic, with consumers using disposables to ward off virus infections. Environmentalists say the Philippines is a major contributor to plastic pollution in the oceans. Estuesta has had to resort to borrowing money from people due to lockdowns and reduced income from junkyards and businesses closed since March. The pandemic has increased plastic pollution, exacerbating the issue of single-use plastics.

site_title: Going virtual is the new political reality
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the decline of traditional presidential nominating conventions in the US. The conventions, once a key event in determining party nominees, have become virtual gatherings, replacing the need for in-person delegate gatherings and reducing the risk of disease transmission. This shift has reduced the political drama and spectacle of the conventions, with some arguing that televised debates may be more effective in showcasing candidates' abilities. The virtual conventions will be held in Milwaukee and Charlotte, with President Trump and Joe Biden accepting their nominations remotely, playing into the hands of Biden's preference for low-key events.

site_title: Can the finance industry be trusted this time?
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority is battling the insurance industry over policies that cover business losses due to physical damage, but also potentially cover losses due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The regulator argues that the government's guidance to stay home during lockdown constitutes physical damage, while insurers claim it was only a warning. A High Court battle could affect 370,000 customers and cost the sector billions of dollars in payouts. The outcome could impact economic confidence and trust in the finance industry, which is still recovering from the financial crisis.

site_title: Pan Pacific to contribute 25,000 free hotel stays to healthcare workers
summary: Pan Pacific Hotels Group is donating 25,000 complimentary hotel stays to healthcare workers in Singapore, valued at S$6.5 million, to honor their efforts in fighting the Covid-19 pandemic. The "HERO" initiative allows healthcare workers to stay at six Pan Pacific hotels from Dec 1, 2020, to March 31, 2021, with perks such as free buffet breakfast, discounts on dining and spa services. The move is seen as a gesture of appreciation from Pan Pacific's CEO, Choe Peng Sum, to recognize the exceptional service of healthcare workers.

site_title: HDB set to launch first batch of BTO flats in Tengah's new Park district
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore will launch its first batch of Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in Tengah's new Park district, featuring over 1,040 flats, in August 2020. Located near Central Park, the project includes a car-free town centre, a 16,000 sqm neighbourhood centre, and green ways such as a 1.5km-long rainforest walk. The flats will be available for sale this month, with the Tengah town centre set to be completed in 2025, and the entire project expected to provide around 42,000 new homes when fully developed.

site_title: Gold dips as US dollar holds onto gains; US-China ties in focus
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $2,030.10 per ounce on Monday, amid a stronger US dollar and reduced investor optimism due to US-China trade talks and potential easing of stimulus by the US Federal Reserve. The dollar held onto gains after better-than-expected US payrolls data, while speculators reduced bullish positions in Comex gold and silver contracts. Gold had previously hit a record high of $2,072.50 on Friday.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Wilmar International's Chinese unit, YIHAI Kerry Arawana, forecasts a 15-30% year-on-year increase in profit for the nine months ended September 2020, with a potential profit of 4-4.6 billion yuan. Meanwhile, Malaysian glove maker Top Glove is set to pay RM53 million in remediation fees to migrant workers, following a detention order from the US Customs and Border Protection. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss.

site_title: A grand history of small operas
summary: Opera is often associated with grandeur, but compact pieces have been written for centuries. In the last century, composers have explored concise classical music drama, similar in length to a one-hour television drama. Examples include Monteverdi's "L'Incoronazione di Poppea," which blends Homer's siren song and James Joyce's "Ulysses," and William Grant Still's "The Beauty of the Night," which features a string quartet with bluesy and tart chromaticism. These works showcase the diversity and creativity of small opera, challenging the notion that scale is essential to the art form.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing the current CEO. MAS and PBOC agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Asia tech shares sell-off seen as 'buy' opportunity for some funds
summary: Asia's tech shares experienced a sell-off after US President Donald Trump's attack on WeChat and TikTok, wiping $77 billion off the valuations of the four largest Asia technology firms. However, some investors view this as a buying opportunity, citing low valuations and competitive growth drivers. Fund managers expect the US-China tensions to have minimal impact on Asia's tech companies, and a weakening US dollar may prompt foreign investors to look to Asia's tech sector.

site_title: Demand for UK homes climbs after virus lockdown eases: Rightmove
summary: Demand for UK homes surged after the government eased virus lockdown restrictions in mid-May, with sales agreed in England increasing by 50% compared to the same period in 2019. Rental demand also rose 20%. The growth is attributed to consumers reassessing their housing needs and the government's stamp duty break. This has prompted a desire to move to areas with lower population density and good broadband connectivity. Rightmove's first-half results showed a decline in revenue and operating profit due to the lockdown's impact.

images.alt_text: Between June 1 and July 31, demand for sales properties has been 50% higher than in the same period in 2019, with rental demand being over 20% higher, says Rightmove.

site_title: Temasek will not proceed with partial offer for Keppel
summary: Temasek will not proceed with its partial offer for Keppel Corp due to the company's breach of a key term in the deal. Keppel posted a net loss of S$697.6 million for the second quarter, exceeding the 20% profit decline threshold under the Material Adverse Change clause. The Securities Industry Council of Singapore has confirmed that Temasek can invoke the MAC clause, leading to the cancellation of the S$4 billion partial offer.

site_title: Vegetable wholesaler CCL Group sets sights on consumer business
summary: Singaporean vegetable wholesaler CCL Group has opened a physical store, The Village, at Serangoon to cater to its growing retail segment. The move comes after the company pivoted to selling directly to customers amid the Covid-19 pandemic, seeing a 50% drop in sales. CCL aims to capitalize on the stay-at-home trend and provide a holistic shopping experience with a human touch. The store will also offer educational content on food sustainability and wastage issues, targeting busy parents, young adults, and young families. The company plans to expand its B2C business to 30% of revenue by end 2022.

site_title: US tech giants oppose India's 'non-personal' data-curb plan
summary: US tech giants Amazon, Facebook, and Google oppose India's plan to regulate "non-personal" data, which aims to set up a regulator for anonymized or de-identified data. The US-India Business Council (USIBC) has written a letter opposing the proposal, calling it "anathema" to promoting competition and undermining investments in data processing. The plan's proponents argue it will spur the digital ecosystem, but the USIBC claims it will limit foreign trade and investment, contradicting Prime Minister Narendra Modi's calls for US companies to invest in India.

site_title: Wirecard collapse and Germany: The cultural factors
summary: The collapse of Wirecard, a German financial darling, reflects severe shortcomings in Germany's cultural factors, including a lack of transparency, financial capitalism, and effective supervision. Four key cultural factors contributed to the Wirecard fraud: (1) a dismissive reaction to a Financial Times exposé, viewing it as a British attempt to harm Germany's reputation; (2) a penchant for passing the buck and obscuring information; (3) a profound German inferiority complex, which led to a blind trust in Wirecard's financial story; and (4) a reluctance to acknowledge the role of Austrian fraudsters. The Wirecard scandal highlights Germany's lax regulatory environment and the need for soul-searching and reform.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with losses, falling 0.63% due to concerns over the US stimulus package. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 24,376.82, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.37% and 0.44%, respectively.

site_title: Top Glove to pay RM53m to migrant workers to resolve US ban
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysian glove maker, is set to pay RM53 million to migrant workers it employed before implementing new recruitment standards in 2019. The US Customs and Border Protection issued a Withhold Release Order, prompting the company to make the first payment of RM4.4 million. Top Glove continues to engage with the US CBP to resolve the issue expeditiously. The company believes the order was related to foreign labor issues, which had already been resolved.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 6.48 points lower at 1,571.66 on Monday, with 19.6 billion lots traded worth RM7.5 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 617 to 538.

site_title: Coronavirus accelerates European utilities' digital drive
summary: European utilities are accelerating their digital transformation due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has forced them to adopt new technologies to manage critical infrastructure and keep services flowing. Companies such as Enel and Iberdrola have set up parallel backup control rooms and remote work processes, while E.ON has increased its use of drones and automated image recognition software. The pandemic has created advantages for businesses that can operate remotely and provide technology to keep services flowing, with McKinsey stating that utilities that started digital programmes before the crisis have been more resilient.

site_title: Gold dips as dollar holds onto gains; US-China spat in focus
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $2,028.90 per ounce as the US dollar held onto gains, while investors monitored Sino-US trade talks. The stronger dollar and potential market profit-taking contributed to the decline, with speculators reducing bullish positions in Comex gold contracts. Despite this, gold remains a safe haven due to the coronavirus pandemic and resultant global stimulus, with prices rising 33% so far this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 7 points or 0.5% to 1,571.11. The market saw 1.53 billion lots traded, with 474 gainers and 110 losers.

site_title: Money Hacks: How to manage your wealth and plan your legacy (Ep 78)
summary: This episode of Money Hacks discusses managing wealth and planning a legacy for high net worth individuals. Host Chris Lim interviews Angeline Alexander, head of high net worth and affluent segments at Prudential Singapore. Key points include understanding wealth management, wealth preservation, and wealth transfer, as well as a 3-step guide to planning a legacy. Opus by Prudential is highlighted as a wealth management and legacy planning approach for high net worth individuals, and the importance of specialist expert panels in trusts, tax, and business advisory is emphasized.

site_title: India: Stocks gain as investors turn focus to business resilience
summary: Indian stocks rose 0.8% to 38,347.31, driven by investors focusing on business resilience amid rising coronavirus infections. Shares of military goods producers rallied after India banned imports of 100+ items to boost local manufacturing. The S&P BSE Sensex and NSE Nifty 50 Index also advanced, marking its seventh weekly gain in eight.

site_title: Wilmar's YKA forecasts 4-4.6b yuan profit for 9M FY2020
summary: YIHAI Kerry Arawana (YKA), the Chinese unit of Wilmar International, forecasts a 9-month FY2020 profit of between 4 billion yuan and 4.6 billion yuan, a 15-30% year-on-year increase. Revenue is expected to rise 5-10% to between 131-137 billion yuan. This marks a significant boost to Wilmar's China operations, increasing market visibility and awareness.

site_title: Retail rents seen falling up to 15% this year as pandemic bites
summary: Retail rents in Singapore are projected to decline by up to 15% in 2020, with prime suburban malls expected to fall 5% and the rest by 15%. The decline is attributed to the pandemic's impact on businesses, with average prime retail rents falling 5.4% year-on-year. Landlords are offering rent-free periods and incentives to tenants, with some landlords giving up to six months of free rent. The retail sector is expected to face challenging times, but could stabilize in the second half of 2021 if a vaccine is found and the pandemic subsides.

site_title: Indonesia ramps up stimulus spending to revive sluggish demand
summary: Indonesia accelerates stimulus spending with a $50 billion package to boost consumer spending and prevent a recession. The government will disburse 28.8 trillion rupiah as a 13th month salary to civil servants and state pensioners, along with cash incentives to formal workers. This move aims to stimulate the economy, which declined 5.32% in the second quarter due to the COVID-19 outbreak. The government plans to spend a total of $50 billion in the next six months to boost the economy, which is expected to contract 2% this year before rebounding to 6.6% growth in 2021.

site_title: China seeks to scrap ratings requirement for some bond issuers
summary: China's securities regulator proposes removing a requirement for bond issuers on the nation's stock exchange markets to seek credit ratings, aiming to make it easier for firms to sell debt. The move is part of efforts to ease financial stress and arrest a dramatic economic slowdown. The removal of the requirement may help prevent inflated credit grades and make it easier for some issuers to sell bonds, according to analysts. The public consultation on the amended draft guidelines will end on September 6.

site_title: Demand for communications assets on the rise
summary: The global data centre market is experiencing rapid growth, with 63 deals closed in 2020 valued at US$19.9 billion, surpassing totals for 2018 and 2019. Analysts attribute this to the increasing demand for data processing and storage, driven by the need for "ever-larger amounts of data". Investors are seeking assets with key fundamentals such as fibre connectivity, customer demand, and a business-friendly environment. The hyperscale segment is growing significantly, with buyers expected to increase their investments through M&A activities to accelerate time to market.

site_title: No deal for Keppel: Mixed views on what this means for O&M consolidation
summary: Temasek has withdrawn its S$4 billion partial offer for Keppel Corp due to the company's breach of a key term with a net loss of S$697.6 million in the second quarter. The withdrawal, announced ahead of the Aug 31 deadline, has led to mixed views on the timeline for industry consolidation in the offshore and marine (O&M) sector. Analysts expect Keppel O&M and SMM to eventually merge, but the question of when this will happen has become more uncertain. Keppel intends to engage Temasek for strategic collaboration and has maintained its Vision 2030 strategy for long-term transformation.

site_title: Finalising FTAs will be an economic shot in the arm for S-E Asia
summary: South-east Asia's five biggest economies are expected to shrink by 2% in 2020, a better-than-average global contraction. The region's growth engine faces a challenge due to economic uncertainty in key sectors like commodities, electronics, and textiles, and a significant decline in investment, which historically drives manufacturing growth. Finalizing Free Trade Agreements (FTAs) could provide an economic boost, but rebuilding the region's growth momentum will be a complex task.

site_title: Australia reports biggest one day rise in new Covid-19 deaths
summary: Australia reported a record 19 daily COVID-19 deaths, its biggest one-day rise in fatalities, as the country's virus hot spot, Victoria, saw a near two-week low of 322 new cases. This marks a significant increase in deaths, but Australia still has relatively low case numbers and fatalities compared to other developed nations, with around 21,000 cases and 314 deaths.

site_title: Singapore, Japan markets closed on Monday for holiday
summary: Singapore and Japan financial markets were closed on Monday for a public holiday, resuming trading on August 11.

site_title: UK Prime Minister says schools must open in September
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson insists schools must reopen in September due to their social, economic, and moral importance. This decision comes despite concerns about a potential second wave of COVID-19 if schools open without a strengthened test-and-trace system. Johnson stated that schools would be the last places to close in future local lockdowns, prioritizing their reopening.

site_title: Morikawa on cloud nine after first PGA victory
summary: Collin Morikawa won the PGA Championship, becoming the fourth player to achieve this feat before his 24th birthday. The 23-year-old American golfer fired a bogey-free 64 to secure a two-shot victory over Dustin Johnson and Paul Casey at TPC Harding Park. This marks Morikawa's third PGA Tour win and his first major victory. The tournament, held without fans due to the Covid-19 pandemic, was a historic event for Morikawa, who joins a prestigious group of golfers who have won a major before their 24th birthday.

images.alt_text: Collin Morikawa's triumph at TPC Harding Park. He joins Rory McIlroy, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods as players who have won a PGA before their 24th birthday.

site_title: Australia shares firm on US stimulus hopes, NZ rises
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to 6,045.9 points, rebounding from a 0.6% drop on Friday, driven by hopes for US fiscal stimulus. Investor sentiment was boosted by US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's openness to restarting talks. Financial stocks led gains, with Magellan Financial Group and Credit Corp Group up 2.78% and 2.5%, respectively. Meanwhile, Australia's death toll from the pandemic continued to rise, and New Zealand crossed 100 days without domestic transmission of the virus.

site_title: Beirut's blast is a warning for America
summary: A devastating explosion in Beirut highlights the dangers of politicizing truth and reality. The author recalls a dinner party with Malcolm Kerr, the former president of the American University of Beirut, who humorously pointed out that in Lebanese society, even the weather had become politicized. This sentiment echoes the current state of American society, where everything becomes a conspiracy, and truth is lost in the mix. The Beirut blast serves as a warning for America, emphasizing the need to separate facts from politics and avoid perpetuating conspiracy theories.

site_title: Australia borders to stay shut as Covid-19 daily deaths reach record
summary: Australia's federal government will maintain internal border closures until Christmas due to a record single day rise in Covid-19 deaths, with 19 fatalities reported. Despite this, some evidence suggests lockdown measures in Melbourne are slowing new infections. The country's federal system has led to varying measures across states, with Victoria reporting the highest number of daily cases and deaths. Australia's overall case and death numbers remain lower than many other developed nations.

site_title: Italy's richest family builds US$3b side bet to candy giant
summary: Italy's richest family, the Ferreros, have invested $3 billion in the US candy giant Kelsen Group, a 40% increase in the net assets of their investment firm, CTH. This move diversifies the Ferreros' fortune beyond their confectionary industry and provides a de-risking solution. Giovanni Ferrero, the son of Nutella and Kinder chocolate creator Michele Ferrero, is executive chairman of Ferrero Group, which now values at $23 billion, making up the bulk of the Ferrero family's $32.9 billion fortune.

site_title: China's factory deflation slows in July as recovery gains strength
summary: China's factory deflation eased in July, driven by rising global oil prices and industrial activity's recovery. The producer price index (PPI) fell 2.4% from a year earlier, as industrial output returned to pre-pandemic levels. Consumer inflation rose 2.7% in July, while core inflation remained at 0.5%. The recovery is driven by pent-up demand, government stimulus, and resilient exports, but some economists warn of potential stalls due to cautious consumer spending and global infections.

site_title: Oil rallies in Asia as Saudi Aramco sees recovery in demand
summary: Oil prices rose 1.2% in Asia after Saudi Aramco reported a potential recovery in energy demand due to easing coronavirus lockdowns in Asia. The company's CEO, Amin Nasser, stated that oil consumption in the region has almost returned to pre-coronavirus levels. This news boosted oil futures in New York, which had declined 1.7% on Friday. The recovery in oil demand is seen as a positive sign for the oil market, despite ongoing concerns over the US-China tensions and uncertain economic stimulus.

images.alt_text: Oil clawed back lost ground in Asia after Saudi Arabia's state-controlled producer said it expects energy demand to improve.

site_title: Aramco still aims for US$15b investment in India's Reliance
summary: Saudi Aramco is still pursuing a $15 billion investment in Reliance Industries' refining and chemicals business, despite lower oil prices forcing the company to slash investment spending. The deal, valued at $75 billion, would help Aramco join the ranks of top oil refiners and chemical makers. Aramco CEO Amin Nasser stated that discussions are ongoing, and the company will update shareholders on the deal's status. The transaction would aid Aramco in reaching its goal of doubling refining capacity to 8-10 million barrels per day.

site_title: Pandemic putting millions of Europeans on path to a debt crisis
summary: Europe is bracing for a debt crisis as pandemic support plans threaten to tip millions of households into debt. Organizations warn of a 40% increase in debt counseling requests, with 10% of EU households already struggling. A third of households in southern Europe are considered "financially fragile," and UK households would struggle to cover bills if they lost income. Governments' decision to wind down furlough programs could lead to soaring unemployment, exacerbating inequality and threatening broader financial stability.

site_title: US ban on China apps will create 'Western firewall'
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration has banned Chinese mobile apps like TikTok and WeChat, citing national security threats, which critics say risks fragmenting the global Internet and creating an "American firewall." Analysts warn that this move could lead to a competitive and confusing situation for countries in the middle, such as Africa and parts of Asia, and may invite other countries to follow suit. The ban is seen as a move to counter China's rising power and could have significant economic and technological implications for US tech companies.

site_title: Star broker turns to New Zealand as New York luxury market wilts
summary: A luxury real estate broker is listing a New Zealand mansion with a US$16 million price tag, targeting rich buyers fleeing the struggling New York luxury market. The 13,175 sq ft property in Queenstown comes with Covid-19-free status, stunning views, and a six-car garage. The listing is unusual for the broker, known for his work in New York, but the country's low Covid-19 numbers and strict buyer restrictions make it an attractive option. The property is exempt from typical buyer restrictions due to its commercial zoning and can be leased back by the seller for a year.

images.alt_text: Should there be another quarantine, one would seek land, air, safety and security, said Serhant, naming New Zealand as one of the best places to find all of the above.

site_title: One in three UK employers plans to cut jobs in this quarter
summary: UK employers plan to cut jobs this quarter, with nearly 40% of private companies expecting layoffs. The labor market crisis is a growing risk to the post-lockdown recovery as government support is withdrawn. Wage growth is also subdued, with 1% expected increases, down from 2% last year. Despite this, hiring intentions have risen, indicating businesses are reshaping in response to the crisis.

site_title: Asia: Shares on backfoot as focus shifts to US stimulus, China tensions
summary: Asian shares started cautiously on Monday amid US-China tensions and uncertainty over US fiscal stimulus. Despite a 0.7% gain for Australian shares and a 0.4% rise for South Korea's main index, the region's MSCI index fell below a six-and-a-half month peak. US President Donald Trump signed executive orders extending unemployment benefits and banning Chinese tech companies, which could jeopardize US-China trade talks. Investors are also watching for Chinese inflation and economic data, while gold prices held steady at an all-time high.

site_title: US health chief offers Taiwan 'strong' support in landmark visit
summary: US Health Secretary Alex Azar offered "strong" support for Taiwan during a landmark visit, telling President Tsai Ing-wen that her government's response to the coronavirus pandemic was among the world's best. The visit, which has been condemned by China, aims to strengthen economic and public-health cooperation and support Taiwan's international role in fighting the pandemic. Taiwan has had a successful response to the virus, with 480 infections and seven deaths, and Azar praised the country's democratic nature and open society. The visit marks a significant shift in US policy, with the Trump administration prioritizing support for the democratic island.

site_title: Banker sexism at Barclays aired anew in suit from crisis era
summary: A decade after the 2008 credit crunch, sexist comments made by top Barclays bankers during the crisis have resurfaced in a London trial. The comments, which included derogatory remarks about financier Amanda Staveley, were made during phone calls and have shed light on a culture of sexism in the banking industry. Staveley sued Barclays for $2.87 billion, alleging the bank cheated her out of profits. The trial, which is on hiatus until October, has highlighted the persistence of sexist attitudes in the financial world, with some lawyers warning that tolerating such language can lead to harassment and further misconduct.

images.alt_text: In the dark days of the 2008 credit crunch, Barclays Plc's top brass had a money problem. Just over a decade later, we now know they had another: sexism.

site_title: US dollar climbs after jobs data report
summary: The US dollar rose 0.6% after a July jobs report showed a 1.76 million increase in nonfarm payrolls, beating economists' forecasts. This easing of investor worries on the US labor market led to a rebound in the dollar index, which hit its highest in three days. However, the dollar index is still on pace to finish the week down 0.05%, marking its seventh straight weekly loss. Ongoing stimulus talks in Washington and concerns about US-China relations also weighed on the dollar.

site_title: Hyundai shares rise as much as 10% on EV plan announcement
summary: Hyundai shares surged 10.2% to a 5-year high, reaching 162,000 won, after announcing plans to create a family of Ioniq-brand electric vehicles, aiming to become the third-largest EV maker by 2025. Other auto shares, including Kia Motors and parts suppliers Hyundai Mobis and Mando, also rose. The move was seen as a positive development for the company's future growth.

site_title: Amazon looking at turning US mall space into fulfillment centers: WSJ
summary: Amazon is exploring the possibility of turning US mall space into fulfillment centers, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal. US mall operator Simon Property Group has been in talks with Amazon about converting department-store sites into distribution centers. The discussions, which began before the coronavirus pandemic, involve converting space formerly occupied by J.C. Penney and Sears. Amazon and Simon may also consider buying out occupied space from the retailers.

site_title: Australia sticks to plan to reduce JobKeeper support
summary: Australia's government remains committed to reducing its JobKeeper wage subsidy, despite a renewed COVID-19 outbreak in Victoria. The program will decline from A$1,500 to A$1,200 a fortnight at the end of September. Finance Minister Mathias Cormann emphasized the need for a phased transition out of the historically unprecedented crisis-level fiscal support. The government will respond to developments as they arise, amid concerns the economy may take another hit, with Prime Minister Scott Morrison warning of a 2.5% cut in gross domestic product this quarter.

site_title: Britons dining out on Sunak's tab in bid to help sector
summary: The UK government's "Eat Out to Help Out" programme, offering 50% discounts on meals from August 3-31, has seen a surge in bookings for restaurants, with over 73,000 outlets signed up. However, some owners warn the subsidy may not be enough to save businesses, as the threat of a deep recession persists and tighter restrictions on social contact remain a concern. The programme's success has been mixed, with some businesses experiencing a boost but others citing concerns about long-term sustainability and the need for further support.

site_title: Chicago Fed's president says another Covid-19 aid package 'incredibly important'
summary: Chicago Fed President Charles Evans emphasized the importance of another Covid-19 aid package to support workers and vulnerable communities. He stated that public confidence is crucial and that lawmakers must protect small businesses and communities by ensuring they can pay rent and buy food while the virus is not under control. Evans' comments come after the failure of US lawmakers to reach an agreement on a second aid package, leaving tens of millions of unemployed Americans without direct federal support. US lawmakers are open to restarting talks, and President Trump has signed executive orders aimed at addressing unemployment and other issues.

site_title: GBPJPY at inflection point, set to trend lower
summary: The GBPJPY currency pair is at an inflection point, poised to trend lower, according to analysts. The pair has been in a downtrend since 2016, with recent price movements forming an ascending triangle pattern that coincides with a 61.8% Fibonacci retracement level. Stochastics oscillators and Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) indicators also suggest bearish momentum, validating a potential move lower. Support levels are expected at 136.10 and potentially 124.35, if prices break through and are accompanied by bearish momentum.

site_title: South Africa peering into abyss to mine platinum amid pandemic
summary: South Africa's platinum mines face significant challenges amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with reduced demand for catalytic converters and government stimulus packages pushing automakers towards electric vehicles. The industry's investment cycle is nearing its end, with mega open-cast projects at risk of being shelved. The western limb of the platinum belt, once the heartland of the industry, is particularly vulnerable, with some analysts predicting a sharp contraction in production over the next decade.

site_title: NDP celebrations routed across the heartlands
summary: Singapore's 55th National Day Parade (NDP) took place on August 9, 2020, with a scaled-down ceremony due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The parade featured 150 people and traditional elements like the Red Lions free-fall jump and fireworks display, but was split into a morning ceremony and evening show broadcast on TV. Virtual and home activities also took place, including an NDP-themed workout and family cooking programme. The evening show at The Star Performing Arts Centre featured films and performances by Singaporeans, highlighting their efforts during the pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai arrested under national security law: top aide
summary: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai, 71, was arrested under the national security law, accused of collusion with foreign forces. Lai, a prominent democracy activist, was taken away from his home early Monday after police searched Apple Daily, his newspaper, without a warrant. The arrest marks a significant moment in Beijing's crackdown on pro-democracy opposition in Hong Kong. Critics say the law suppresses critical opinion and restricts press freedom, with the Committee to Protect Journalists' Asia programme coordinator calling for Lai's release.

site_title: US Cabinet member to meet Taiwan's leader
summary: US Health Secretary Alex Azar arrived in Taiwan on Sunday for a three-day visit to promote shared democratic values and the island's success in combating COVID-19. Azar's trip is seen as a recognition of Taiwan's achievements and a test of the US's commitment to the island, despite China's condemnation. The visit comes as relations between the US and China are strained, with both sides clashing over trade, military, and security issues. Azar will meet with Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen and other officials, highlighting the US's support for Taiwan's sovereignty.

site_title: HK regulators see US sanctions as having limited impact
summary: Hong Kong financial regulators stated that US sanctions on senior officials have limited impact, as "unilateral sanctions" have no legal status in the city state. Banks in Hong Kong are assessing options, with some considering cutting ties with local clients, amid fears of getting caught in Sino-US tensions. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority declared that banks are under no obligation to comply with US sanctions, and will "forensically examine" banking relationships to determine potential risks.

site_title: Road test: Chinese 'robotaxis' take riders for a spin
summary: Chinese companies, including Baidu, AutoX, and DiDi Chuxing, have launched autonomous taxi pilot projects in cities across China, with plans to deploy fully autonomous vehicles in the next two to three years. The pilot projects aim to accumulate driving time and data to make self-driving cars safe enough for widespread use. While regulatory and technological hurdles remain, companies like DiDi Chuxing and AutoX are optimistic about the future of autonomous vehicles, with some expecting a "sizeable" deployment of vehicles without safety drivers in the near future.

site_title: As the virus deepens Haiti's schooling gap, some fight back
summary: Haiti's schools reopen after the pandemic, but the country's deepening schooling gap is starkly apparent. Wealthy schools like Saint-Louis de Gonzague have spacious campuses and online programs, while poor schools like Tabarre struggle with limited resources, including running water and computers. However, a small number of educators, such as those at Catts Pressoir middle school, are working to build a quality education system that is accessible to all, regardless of wealth.

site_title: Bargain-hunters look to US real estate stocks as S&P nears records
summary: The S&P 500 is nearing record highs, prompting bargain-hunters to look into US real estate stocks, which have seen significant declines this year due to the pandemic. Investors believe a Covid-19 vaccine could boost the sector, and major stocks have seen value cut in half. As the US economy loosens, real estate investment trusts (Reits) may experience a resurgence, offering investors potential gains.

site_title: The growing importance of corporate conscience
summary: Companies are increasingly prioritizing the interests of all stakeholders, including shareholders, customers, employees, and the environment, over mere profit maximization. Guided by a sense of right and wrong, CEOs are committing to lead their companies for the benefit of all stakeholders, as seen in the Business Roundtable's shift from shareholder primacy to stakeholder primacy. This shift is driven by the COVID-19 pandemic, which has highlighted the importance of corporate social responsibility and the need for companies to support their communities and employees.

site_title: Hyundai expects new family of Ioniq vehicles to drive global EV sales
summary: Hyundai Motor plans to launch a family of electric vehicles under the Ioniq brand, aiming to capture 10% of global EV sales by 2025. The company will introduce three all-electric models starting in early 2021, including the Ioniq 5, Ioniq 6, and Ioniq 7. These models will be built on the E-GMP platform, enabling fast charging and a long driving range. Hyundai's competitors, including Volkswagen and General Motors, are also expanding their EV offerings, while Tesla aims to retain its leadership position. The Ioniq brand elevation is part of Hyundai's strategy to become the world's third-largest EV seller.

site_title: Saudi Aramco's profit plunges, sees signs of oil market recovery
summary: Saudi Aramco's profit dropped 73% in the second quarter due to globally lowered oil consumption caused by the Covid-19 outbreak. The world's largest oil exporter attributes the decline to reduced energy demand and prices, which have not been seen in nearly two decades.

site_title: China wants people's rice bowls filled with locally grown grain
summary: China's Agriculture Minister Han Changfu emphasized the importance of domestically grown grain to ensure the country's food security, citing shrinking farmland and extreme weather. The country aims to boost seed varieties and expand machine use in grain production. China also plans to expand genetically modified corn production to enhance yields. The move comes as tensions with the US escalate, with the US imposing tariffs on Chinese imports. China aims to maintain a balance between domestic production and imports, with a focus on securing supplies amid growing shortages of water and labor.

site_title: Trump signs orders extending economic relief for Americans
summary: US President Donald Trump signed executive actions extending economic relief to Americans affected by the coronavirus pandemic, including $400 a week in unemployment benefits and relief for student loans. However, Democratic rival Joe Biden called the measures "half-baked" and criticized Trump for showing weakness in the face of polls showing widespread dissatisfaction with his handling of the crisis. The executive actions may face court challenges and add up to less money than initially appears, with Trump's claims of rapid distribution likely to be disputed.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for August 7, 2020, reveals mixed market trends in the tanker and dry bulk shipping industries. The capesize market has broken out of its downward trend, trading sideways, while voyage rate volatility persists. Panamax owners experienced significant gains, driven by substantial grain demand and rising mineral cargo, particularly coal exports from the Baltic Sea. Ultramax and Supramax vessels faced a weaker market, with incremental daily losses, while Handy vessels remained relatively flat. In the VLCC market, rates remained stable, and Suezmax rates increased slightly.

site_title: Aviation regulator chief suggests pilot error in Air India crash
summary: An Air India Express Boeing 737 crashed on a table-top runway in Kerala, India, killing at least 18 and injuring over 100. The chief of India's aviation regulator, Arun Kumar, suggests pilot error may be a factor, stating the plane landed too far down the runway and breached a safety area. The crash occurred on a runway built on a hill, despite past recommendations to install a safety system. Investigations are ongoing, with the recovery of flight data and cockpit voice recorders, which will help determine the cause of the incident.

site_title: Fewer buybacks, director transactions in results season
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a 1.3% gain over the four trading sessions from Aug 3 to 6, bringing the Straits Times Index's decline in total return for the 2020 year to 18.3%. Fewer share buybacks occurred, totaling S$54,917, down from S$12.6 million in June. Notable director transactions include Neo Group founder Neo Kah Kiat increasing his stake to 79.65%, while Multi-Chem CEO Foo Suan Sai acquired 25,300 shares, increasing his interest to 68.74%.

site_title: Aspen posts RM13.8m net loss for H1
summary: Aspen, a Malaysian developer, reported a net loss of RM13.8 million (S$4.5 million) for the first half of the year, citing the Covid-19 pandemic as the main reason. Revenue fell 37.7% to RM108.2 million, with construction projects and new sales contributing to the decline. Administrative expenses increased 31.6%, while cost of sales and selling expenses also decreased. The company plans to accelerate construction progress to mitigate risks and expects to deliver its ongoing projects on time. Shares closed flat at S$0.085.

site_title: Huawei to stop making flagship chipsets as US pressure bites
summary: Huawei will stop producing its flagship Kirin chipsets starting September 15, due to US pressure and sanctions. The company's HiSilicon division relies on US software and outsourced production to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. This move affects Huawei's mobile phone business, which relies on the Kirin processors for quality. The US has been pressuring governments worldwide to squeeze Huawei out, citing concerns of data spying, but Huawei denies these allegations. The halt in chip production is a significant blow to Huawei's business, according to CEO Richard Yu.

site_title: Oil drilling drops to 15-year low, shale in full retreat
summary: US oil drilling has reached a 15-year low, with active oil rigs in the US falling to 176, the lowest since 2005. Weak oil prices have made drilling unprofitable, prompting energy companies to abandon growth plans and instead channel cash into dividends and shareholder-friendly initiatives. Exxon and Chevron are likely to write off billions of barrels of reserves due to low prices. The decline in drilling is attributed to the pandemic-driven slump in demand and the industry's struggles with debt and restive shareholders.

site_title: Hong Kong privacy chief says US 'doxxed' sanctioned officials
summary: Hong Kong's privacy chief criticized the US Treasury Department for "doxxing" Chief Executive Carrie Lam and other officials by releasing their personal information as part of US sanctions. The US imposed sanctions on 11 Chinese officials, targeting Lam for her role in curtailing Hong Kong's political freedoms. The move has sparked criticism from local officials, with Lam's government calling it "shameless and despicable." The sanctions also emboldened critics of the Hong Kong government, with a UK lawmaker reviving calls for curbs on it.

site_title: UAE central bank relaxes rules on liquidity, funding for banks
summary: The UAE central bank temporarily relaxed rules on liquidity and funding for banks to encourage lending under the Covid-19 economic stimulus plan. Banks are now allowed to go below 100% "net stable funding ratio" but not below 90% and above 100% for "advances to stable resources ratio" but no higher than 110%. This measure aims to support businesses and customers impacted by the pandemic until December 31, 2021, with a total economic stimulus package worth US$70 billion.

site_title: Money FM: Podcasts of the week (Aug 10)
summary: Money FM's Podcasts of the Week (Aug 10) featured discussions on digital marketing, S-Reits and banking stocks, and sustainability from BMW Group. Minister of State Desmond Tan also shared insights on tackling dengue. The podcast covered various topics including investing opportunities, market trends, and economic analysis.

site_title: US official's visit to Taiwan begins, adding to tension with China
summary: US Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar began a high-ranking visit to Taiwan on Sunday, sparking tension with China. Azar aims to discuss the international response to COVID-19, medical equipment, and technology. The visit is seen as a signaling device to Beijing amid deteriorating bilateral relations. China has expressed strong opposition to the visit, labeling Taiwan a "sensitive issue" in US-China relations. Taiwan's Foreign Ministry responded, calling China a "global troublemaker" and urging it to respect Taiwan's foreign exchanges.

images.alt_text: Mr Azar (third from left) arriving in Taiwan on Sunday for the highest- ranking visit by a US official to the island in decades. He is expected to discuss the international response to the coronavirus.

site_title: Barclays being probed by UK privacy watchdog
summary: The UK's Information Commissioner's Office is probing Barclays for allegedly spying on its staff, following earlier media reports. The bank had been using the Sapience software to track employee productivity, but later changed its system to only track anonymized data in response to staff feedback. The ICO emphasized the importance of clear communication and employee awareness regarding workplace monitoring, stating that organizations must be transparent about their monitoring purposes and benefits. The investigation is ongoing, with no completion date specified.

site_title: US political scrapping weighing on market sentiment
summary: US stocks may shed recent gains as a political spat over urgently needed economic support continues. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and President Donald Trump have failed to find a middle ground, with Trump threatening to set fiscal policy by executive order. Economists warn that recent job losses slowing and stimulus may evaporate without additional cash, particularly for the tens of millions of unemployed Americans. The Nasdaq Composite hit a new record high last week, but recent gains in retail sales could be short-lived without further stimulus.

site_title: Canaccord Genuity hires advisers to explore sale
summary: Canaccord Genuity, Canada's largest non-bank brokerage, is exploring strategic options, including a sale of its business, after appointing activist investor Eric Rosenfeld to its board. The company believes its UK wealth business is worth around C$1 billion and undervalued. A sale could be considered, but no final decision has been made. The company's market value rose 6.5% following the announcement.

site_title: Taiwan airlines offer sightseeing flights to nowhere
summary: Taiwanese airlines, China Airlines and Eva Air, are offering sightseeing "flights to nowhere" on passenger jets, with flight attendant lessons for children. The flights, which can be booked at a cost of around NT$5,288 (S$246) for economy and NT$6,288 for business, aim to generate extra cash for airlines struggling due to the pandemic. The flights, which typically last two hours, offer a unique experience and are seen as a way to encourage domestic travel in Taiwan, where the risk of catching COVID-19 is considered low.

site_title: Windows, Gates and a firewall: Microsoft's delicate castle in China
summary: Microsoft has successfully operated in China by complying with strict local laws, despite censorship. The company has 6,200 employees in China and its Windows operating system is widely used, accounting for 1.8% of its turnover. Microsoft's Bing search engine is available, but lags behind local competitors. The company has navigated censorship, operating professional LinkedIn through a local joint venture and avoiding blocking by the "Great Firewall" of China. Despite some challenges, Microsoft has maintained a presence in the country, with President Brad Smith noting that the Chinese market represents a "drop in the ocean" of its business.

site_title: Baby's back: Jennifer Grey to reprise role in new Dirty Dancing movie
summary: Jennifer Grey is set to reprise her role as Frances "Baby" Houseman in a new Dirty Dancing movie, which will star Grey and executive produce. The film will be directed by Jonathan Levine and is expected to be a romantic, nostalgic movie for fans of the original 1987 film. Grey's co-star Patrick Swayze, who played Johnny Castle, passed away in 2009. No plot details have been revealed, but the movie is expected to be a direct sequel to the original.

site_title: Logistics sector responds to pandemic pressure with tech, new business models
summary: The logistics sector is adapting to pandemic pressure by leveraging technology and new business models. Industry players are scaling up digitally to meet new forms of demand, with companies like Yang Kee Logistics and FedEx using cloud-based platforms and AI to enhance visibility and efficiencies. The Singapore Logistics Association recommends piloting bite-sized technology and upskilling the logistics workforce to operate increasingly integrated and automated assets. International organizations, such as DHL and CK Shipping, are also exploring e-commerce and blockchain initiatives to stay competitive. The sector is expected to continue growing, with demand for last-mile delivery projected to rise.

images.alt_text: According to the Singapore Logistics Association, smaller companies can pilot bite-sized technology to complement physical warehouse and distribution operations.

site_title: Man Utd, Inter favourites for Europa League in unique German finale
summary: Manchester United, Inter Milan, and Sevilla are among the top contenders for the Europa League title in a unique German finale. The tournament, which was heavily disrupted by the coronavirus pandemic, will feature a straight knockout format with games played behind closed doors at four venues. The final will take place in Cologne on August 21, with the winner earning a Champions League berth.

site_title: Accordia Golf ups offer price by 3.4b yen; Hibiki to vote in favour of sale
summary: Accordia Golf Trust, the sponsor of mainboard-listed AGT, is willing to pay 65.2 billion yen (S$848.4 million) for its 88 golf courses in Japan, a 3.4 billion yen increase from the original price of 61.8 billion yen. After AGT's largest minority unitholder Hibiki Path Advisors agreed to support the sale, the trustee-manager signed a supplemental deed, and Hibiki and another unit-holder have irrevocably agreed to vote in favor of the proposal. This increases net proceeds to AGT unitholders, with at least 59.98 billion yen to be distributed within 25 business days.

site_title: Closures, layoffs likely to rise, but nation will pull through: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned that closures, layoffs, and unemployment are likely to rise in Singapore, but expressed confidence the nation will get through the crisis. The government plans to help people find jobs and acquire new skills through job-training programs and career pathways. Lee also emphasized the importance of unity and resilience, urging Singaporeans to maintain vigilance and resolve until a vaccine is widely available. Plans for NS Square, a new waterfront development, were also unveiled, which will replace the Marina Bay floating platform and feature a gallery to commemorate National Service.

site_title: France's Macron to host donor conference for blast-stricken Lebanon
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron will host a United Nations-endorsed donors' conference on Sunday to raise emergency relief for Lebanon following the massive explosion in Beirut. The blast killed 158 people, injured over 6,000, and destroyed a significant portion of the city. Macron has promised humanitarian aid but emphasized the need for profound political reform to address Lebanon's problems. The conference will feature participation from US President Donald Trump, Germany, Britain, and other countries, with a focus on emergency aid for reconstruction, food, medical equipment, and schools and hospitals.

images.alt_text: French President Emmanuel Macron will host US President Donald Trump and other political leaders on Sunday for a United Nations-endorsed donors' conference by video to raise emergency relief for Lebanon following this week's massive explosion in Beirut.

site_title: India bans import of 3.5t rupees defence items in buy-local push
summary: India has banned the import of over 100 defence items worth 3.5 trillion rupees (S$64.5 billion) to boost local manufacturing. The ban will be implemented in phases, starting with sniper rifles and light-combat helicopters in December 2020 and long-range land-attack cruise missiles in December 2025. Defence Minister Rajnath Singh aims to secure contracts worth almost four trillion rupees with domestic manufacturers over the next seven years, aiming to reduce reliance on imports and stimulate the economy.

site_title: AIA inks exclusive regional partnership with healthtech startup Holmusk
summary: Insurance company AIA has partnered with healthtech startup Holmusk to provide digital health coaching tools and solutions to its customers. The partnership will offer personalized health coaching services based on specific needs via Holmusk's network of nutritionists and dietitians. The service will be launched first in Malaysia, with plans to expand to other markets. The partnership aims to improve access, convenience, and health outcomes for customers, and is seen as a key step in addressing chronic diseases such as diabetes in under-resourced healthcare systems in Asia.

site_title: Saudi Aramco's Q2 net profit plunges 73.4% on lower oil prices
summary: Saudi Aramco reported a 73.4% drop in Q2 net profit due to lower oil prices caused by the global spread of Covid-19. The company expects 2020 capital expenditure to be at the lower end of its $25-30 billion range. CEO Amin Nasser noted a partial recovery in the energy market as countries ease restrictions and reboot their economies.

site_title: 175 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 1 in the community
summary: Singapore reported 175 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 55,104. The cases include one community case, a 60-year-old Singaporean woman, and 125 migrant workers in dormitories. Three imported cases were also confirmed, with six asymptomatic individuals testing positive while serving stay-home notices. The number of community cases decreased, and 271 patients were discharged, with 48,568 recovered. 145 patients remain in hospital, and 6,174 are recuperating in community facilities.

site_title: Barclays being probed by UK privacy watchdog on accusations of spying on staff
summary: The UK's Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) is probing Barclays over allegations of spying on staff, following media reports that the bank's "Sapience" system tracked employee computer usage. Barclays initially faced criticism in 2017 for its "OccupEye" system, which monitored desk time. The bank changed its approach in February, switching to anonymized data tracking, but the ICO is now investigating whether it was clear about the system's purpose and benefits. The probe aims to ensure employees' right to privacy in the workplace.

site_title: Doing their bit to help the underprivileged
summary: Keppel and its partner Envision have partnered with organizations like the Cerebral Palsy Alliance Singapore to distribute care items, including surgical masks, thermometers, and personal protection equipment, to social service agencies. The initiative aims to support underprivileged communities during the challenging period, with a total of 50,000 packs to be distributed over the next two weeks.

site_title: Meeting in the middle
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have established a "green lane" for business travel between the two countries, aiming to facilitate operations in the post-pandemic era. The arrangement allows for essential business activities, such as negotiations and due diligence checks, to be conducted in person. Experts believe the green lane will enable businesses to reconnect and drive growth, particularly for industries reliant on regional expansions. However, caution is advised, and strict health protocols must be adhered to ensure the schemes work effectively for both countries. The green lane is seen as a step towards revitalizing the Singapore economy and promoting regional trade.

site_title: Despite agreement, China purchase of US agriculture lags
summary: US-China trade negotiations are set to resume on August 15, with the two sides discussing a deal aimed at increasing Chinese purchases of US agricultural goods to $32 billion over two years. However, Chinese purchases have fallen short of the target, reaching only 39% of the semi-annual target at the end of June. Analysts warn that China may cancel orders or buy at cheaper prices if available, while US farmers rely on these deals to sell their bumper crop. The trade deal, dubbed "Phase One," has survived despite tensions and a global economic downturn, but achieving its full potential remains uncertain.

site_title: Hong Kong markets watchdog says it does not think sanctions will affect financial firms
summary: Hong Kong's markets watchdog says US-imposed sanctions on top officials won't affect financial firms' operations. The Securities and Futures Commission believes global firms have prior experience responding to US sanctions and can assess their impact on clients. The watchdog is not aware of any sanctions affecting firms' normal operations in Hong Kong.

site_title: Minority investor protest in ESR-Sabana Reit deal highlights need to focus on more than DPU
summary: Minority investors of Sabana Reit are protesting the proposed merger with ESR-Reit, citing a significant discount of the implied price of Sabana Reit compared to its net asset value (NAV). Unitholders would receive 94 units of ESR-Reit for every 100 units of Sabana Reit, valuing them at S$0.377, 26% below Sabana Reit's NAV. The merger would result in a 20.7% NAV dilution for Sabana Reit unitholders, while ESR-Reit unitholders would benefit from a 5.2% NAV accretion. The deal requires 50% support from Sabana Reit unitholders, and the market price performance of ESR-Reit may influence minority investors' decision to vote for the merger.

site_title: 10 useful inventions by Singapore firms during Covid-19
summary: Singaporean firms have developed 10 useful inventions during the COVID-19 pandemic. These include a sustainable marine fuel that aims to halve its price, a specialist centre for healthcare in Japan, and a platform to provide loans to serial entrepreneurs. Additionally, a startup is rebranding heritage for the younger generation in the otah business. The article also highlights the challenges faced by SMEs, such as vacant units and reduced footfall, as well as the efforts of companies like OCBC to support entrepreneurs. These innovations demonstrate the resilience and adaptability of Singaporean businesses.

site_title: Japan unsuccessful in lifting auto tariffs early in UK trade deal
summary: Japan and the UK agreed to lift auto tariffs for a post-Brexit trade deal in 2026, despite Japan's push for earlier lifting. The deal, which includes phasing out import tariffs on Japanese vehicles, was reached after negotiations between Japanese Foreign Minister Toshimitsu Motegi and British Trade Minister Liz Truss in London. Auto tariffs and agricultural products remain a sticking point in the negotiations, with Britain seeking better terms on agriculture. The UK aims to clinch the trade agreement by the end of the year, when its transition arrangement with the EU expires.

site_title: Twitter expressed interest in buying TikTok's US operations: sources
summary: Twitter has expressed interest in acquiring TikTok's US operations, according to sources. Twitter would need to raise additional capital, which is a challenge given its current borrowing capacity. Microsoft remains the front-runner in bidding for the app's US operations, with a potential deal to be completed by mid-September. US President Donald Trump has stated he would support Microsoft's efforts, but plans to ban TikTok on September 15. Twitter's ability to secure financing for a deal is uncertain, with experts questioning its ability to outbid Microsoft.

site_title: Reits in high-growth markets should gun for short leases: KORE CEO Snyder
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (KORE) CEO David Snyder believes that Reits in high-growth markets should opt for short leases to maximize rent growth. Snyder attributes the portfolio's 14.7% positive rent reversions in H1 to this strategy. He argues that long weighted average lease expiries (WALEs) hinder landlords from achieving positive rent increases in strong markets. In contrast, KORE's portfolio has a short WALE of four years and generates 2.6% annual rent escalation, despite in-place rents being 10.8% below asking rents.

site_title: Aspen sinks into RM13.8 million net loss for first half
summary: Aspen Group Holdings reported a net loss of RM13.8 million (S$4.5 million) for the first half of 2020, citing the Covid-19 pandemic as the main reason. Revenue fell 38% to RM108.2 million, despite a 32% increase in administrative expenses. The company attributed the losses to construction downtime, foreign exchange translation losses, and higher interest payable. Despite this, Aspen sees opportunities in the foreign market, particularly in Penang, and has adapted its sales and marketing activities to be fully online.

site_title: Brazilian billionaire Lemann leads initiative to build Covid-19 vaccine factory
summary: Brazilian billionaire Jorge Lemann is funding the construction of a Covid-19 vaccine factory in Brazil, valued at $25.2 million. The factory, to be built by the Oswaldo Cruz Foundation, will produce 30 million doses of the vaccine per month as of 2021. The initiative aims to increase vaccine production and availability in Brazil.

site_title: Philippines needs 1.56t pesos recovery stimulus, lawmaker says
summary: The Philippines needs a 1.56 trillion pesos (S$43.64 billion) recovery stimulus to help it recover from a record economic contraction. Lawmaker Stella Quimbo says a larger and consolidated response is needed, focusing on wage subsidies and low-interest loans for small businesses. The government has allocated 655 billion pesos since lockdowns, but the near-term outlook for the economy continues to deteriorate, with Fitch Ratings warning of downside risks. A stimulus bill passed in June is still pending in the Senate, with President Duterte's economic managers proposing a smaller spending bill and tax cuts instead.

site_title: Paris imposes face mask order for outdoor markets, River Seine strollers
summary: The city of Paris has introduced a new face mask order for outdoor areas, including markets and strollers along the River Seine, to curb rising coronavirus infections. The measure, which applies to people aged 11 and over, follows a surge in cases in the French capital and its lower-income suburbs. The order will last for a month and carries fines of up to six months in prison for repeated offenders. This move follows similar measures in other European cities to control the spread of the virus.

site_title: Australia's Victoria reports deadliest day of Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Victoria, Australia's second-most populous state, reported its deadliest day of the Covid-19 pandemic with 17 deaths and 394 new cases. The state's total number of deaths is 210, with cases concentrated in Melbourne. To slow the spread, Victoria has imposed a night curfew and tightened restrictions. Despite these measures, cases with unknown sources of infection continue to increase, and the state's reproduction rate remains around one, indicating that each infected person is passing the virus to at least one other person.

site_title: Oil spill threatens ecological disaster as Mauritius declares emergency
summary: A Japanese bulk carrier, MV Wakashio, ran aground on a reef in Mauritius, causing an oil spill that threatens an ecological disaster. Fuel is leaking from the vessel's hull, endangering corals, fish, and marine life in the Indian Ocean. Mauritius has declared a state of environmental emergency, and France is sending specialist teams and equipment to help mitigate the spill. The spill has the potential to be one of the worst ecological crises Mauritius has ever seen, with dire consequences for the island's economy, food security, and health.

site_title: Death toll from Indian passenger aircraft accident rises to 18
summary: An Air India Express plane carrying 190 passengers and crew overshot the runway of the Calicut International Airport in India, killing 18 people, including the pilot and co-pilot, on Friday. The Boeing 737 plane crashed nose-first into the ground due to heavy rain. 16 people were seriously injured and all survivors were admitted to hospitals for COVID-19 testing. Authorities are investigating the cause of the accident, with the flight data recorder and cockpit voice recorder recovered from the site.

site_title: Blackstone, Brookfield among firms eyeing Indian malls: report
summary: Blackstone Group and Brookfield Asset Management are reportedly eyeing stakes in Indian malls hit by the coronavirus pandemic. The investors are in talks to buy stakes in about six Indian malls, including DB Mall and Marina Mall, for launching retail Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits). Mall operators are expected to see revenue halve in the 12 months to March 2021, according to Crisil Ratings. This move comes as the pandemic has severely impacted the Indian retail sector, leading to a decline in mall foot traffic and sales.

site_title: Beijing's top Hong Kong office says US sanctions are 'clowning actions' and 'ridiculous'
summary: Beijing's top Hong Kong office denounces US sanctions as "clowning actions" and "ridiculous," saying they won't intimidate Chinese people. The sanctions, imposed on senior Hong Kong and Chinese officials, freeze assets and prohibit business in the US. The move accelerates deteriorating Sino-US ties, amid China's imposition of national security legislation on Hong Kong. Beijing says the law will bring stability, while critics claim it erodes basic rights and freedoms.

site_title: Debt collectors' profits soar with people flush and easy to find
summary: Debt collectors' profits have surged due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with PRA Group's cash collections increasing 8% and Encore Capital Group's revenue rising by $66 million. The surge in collections is attributed to stimulus checks and lockdowns leaving Americans with extra cash, making them easier to reach. Household debt has fallen for the first time in six years, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. As a result, shares of PRA Group and Encore have climbed 22% this year.

site_title: US judge denies bail to two men accused of aiding ex-Nissan boss Ghosn's escape
summary: A US district judge denied bail to two Massachusetts men, Michael Taylor and his son Peter Taylor, accused of aiding former Nissan boss Carlos Ghosn's escape from Japan. The judge rejected their bail request after Japan had sought their extradition. The Taylors are charged with implementing a sophisticated plan to help Ghosn escape, including hiring a private jet and making multiple trips to Japan. They face extradition and could potentially face financial penalties due to Ghosn's pre-escape wire transfer of $860,000 to a company co-managed by Peter Taylor.

site_title: Japan kept Singapore-based activist investor in limbo over key Toshiba vote: sources
summary: Japan's government delayed approval for Singapore-based activist investor Effissimo Capital Management to vote on Toshiba's board nominees until the day before the company's annual meeting, sparking concerns that the new foreign ownership rules may be used to deter foreign capital from coming to Japan. The rules, introduced in June, require foreign investors to report holdings of 1% or more in Japanese companies, but some investors worry they could also be used to hobble overseas investors. Effissimo ultimately gained 43% of the vote, but the delayed approval raised questions about the government's intentions.

images.alt_text: Activist fund Effissimo Capital Management, the biggest investor in Toshiba, was kept in limbo by Japan's government over a key shareholder vote until the day before the industrial conglomerate's annual meeting, two government sources said.

site_title: Kodak's US$765m government loan on hold pending probe
summary: The US International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) has put on hold a $765 million loan to Eastman Kodak pending probes into allegations of wrongdoing. The DFC stated that recent allegations raise "serious concerns" and will not proceed with the loan unless the allegations are cleared. Congress and the Securities and Exchange Commission are also investigating the deal, and Kodak's board is conducting its own review of the loan disclosure. The loan was announced just over two weeks ago and the hold is expected to impact Kodak's financial situation.

site_title: Wall Street has a plan to remove racist fans from Italian football
summary: AC Milan CEO Ivan Gazidis aims to remove racist fans from Italian football stadiums. He believes tackling overt racism will increase the league's broadcast rights and club values, making it a global brand. Firms like Elliott Management, which bought AC Milan, see the potential for increased revenue by improving the match-day experience and building better stadiums. Gazidis plans to address the issue through a comprehensive strategy, aiming to enhance the product and attract more international investors.

site_title: Gold falls after positive jobs data, London fix sparks selloff
summary: Gold prices fell 2.3% after better-than-expected US jobs data, with the US dollar curbing the metal's haven appeal. The jobs report showed a 1.76 million payroll gain, beating estimates, and the unemployment rate fell more than expected. The London gold price was set lower, and the US dollar headed for its first gain in four sessions, exacerbating selling.
