Despite the drop, gold remains up 33% this year, poised for its biggest annual gain in over four decades.

site_title: UPS, FedEx flex price power on delivery surge, driving up shares
summary: US package delivery companies UPS and FedEx have raised prices to boost profit amid a surge in residential deliveries due to the coronavirus pandemic. UPS plans to apply holiday surcharges of up to $4 per package, while FedEx will increase international surcharges on select routes starting August 10. The moves are expected to drive up shares for both companies. FedEx will also apply holiday surcharges, although the exact details have not been released. The price hikes are a response to the increased demand for delivery services during the pandemic.

site_title: New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern, buoyed by Covid success, launches re-election bid
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has launched her re-election bid, emphasizing her leadership credentials and pledge to steer the country through the economic crisis caused by Covid-19. Ardern's Labour Party is riding high in opinion polls, while the main opposition National Party faces internal ructions and scandals. Ardern squares off against new National leader Judith Collins, who claims her party is more capable of navigating the economic recovery. The two parties have similar policy platforms, focusing on infrastructure spending and job creation, but differ on debt reduction.

site_title: Chinese electric-vehicle maker XPeng files for US IPO
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker XPeng Motors has filed for a US initial public offering (IPO) with a placeholder size of $100 million. The company, which recently closed a $900 million funding round, is seeking to capitalize on investor interest following strong share price gains from Tesla and NIO. XPeng delivered 5,185 units of its first vehicle and 1,966 units of its second model in the first half of 2020. The IPO is being led by Credit Suisse Group, JPMorgan Chase & Co, and Bank of America, with shares set to trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol XPEV.

site_title: Telemedicine firm Hims Inc in talks to go public via Oaktree blank-cheque company: sources
summary: Hims Inc, a telemedicine company, is in talks to go public via a merger with Oaktree Acquisition Corp, a blank-check company, valuing Hims at approximately $2 billion. Oaktree is seeking $100 million in funding to support the transaction. The deal, if completed, could be announced in a few weeks. This comes amid a record surge in SPAC deals as companies opt for going public through these transactions rather than traditional IPOs. Hims has raised $197 million from investors since its founding in 2017 and has expanded into urgent care and mental health services.

site_title: Business closures, layoffs to rise, but Singapore will get through crisis: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned of rising business closures, layoffs, and unemployment, but expressed confidence that the country will overcome the crisis. The government plans to support job seekers and employers with job training programs and schemes like the Jobs Support Scheme. Lee emphasized the importance of unity and resilience, calling for employers to keep their workers and for the population to maintain vigilance until a vaccine is widely available.

site_title: US taxman gives businesses a break for donations to charitable funds
summary: The US Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has clarified that businesses can deduct charitable donations to state funds in exchange for a state tax credit from their federal taxes. This follows changes to how the IRS treats tax benefits from donating to state charitable funds. The regulations, finalized in December, provide a safe harbour for some individuals who donate to these funds for a tax credit. The move aims to address confusion and provides a break for businesses donating to charitable funds.

site_title: Two Black staff members quit Bon Appétit magazine as tensions over race continue
summary: Two Black editorial staff members, Ryan Walker-Hartshorn and Jesse Sparks, quit Bon Appétit magazine, citing inequitable pay and feeling undervalued. They had sought raises and promotions but were met with offers that fell short. The departures come amid criticism of racial inequality and a hostile work environment, following the resignation of former editor Adam Rapoport. Condé Nast has pledged to diversify its staff and is searching for a new editor-in-chief, with Sonia Chopra set to lead Bon Appétit as executive editor.

site_title: At Talkspace, startup culture collides with mental health concerns
summary: Talkspace, a mental health app, has raised concerns about its startup culture colliding with user privacy. A former employee, Ricardo Lori, shared his story of being asked to share his therapy chat logs with the company, which he later realized was a breach of confidentiality. Lori sued Talkspace, claiming he was let go due to his anxiety and depression, and the company settled his lawsuit. Former employees describe the company as having questionable marketing practices and using treatment transcripts as a data resource. Talkspace has been accused of encouraging employees to post fake reviews and using client data for marketing purposes, despite claiming it is used for medical advancements. The company has denied these allegations, but experts say the app-ification of mental health care has real problems, and corporate platforms should prioritize patient welfare over growth.

images.alt_text: Ricardo Lori (pictured) sued Talkspace for discrimination and wrongful termination, claiming he was told that his anxiety and depression were interfering with his work.

site_title: Formula One's betting push is driven by data
summary: Formula One is launching a live in-race betting offering, driven by data analytics, to boost fan engagement and revenue. The sport's exclusive data provider, Sportradar, has developed 22 different betting markets, including overtaking manoeuvres and winning margins. The live betting platform is expected to increase fan engagement and revenue, despite the sport being "late to the game." Formula One's head of digital media, Adam Crothers, believes that the data-rich sport can take a sizeable share of the betting market with a robust data-driven approach.

site_title: Accordia Golf ups offer price by 3.4b yen; Hibiki to vote in favour of sale
summary: Accordia Golf Trust has agreed to increase its purchase price for the 88 golf courses from 61.8 billion yen to 65.2 billion yen, a 3.4 billion yen increase. The revised price, 4.67 billion yen above the book value, translates to an implied consideration of 77.2 Singapore cents per unit, a 36.6% premium to the closing price. Minority unitholder Hibiki Path Advisors, which initially opposed the sale, has agreed to vote in favor of the proposal. The increased price will result in higher net proceeds for AGT unitholders, with at least 59.98 billion yen to be distributed within 25 business days.

site_title: Aveva is in exclusive talks to buy SoftBank-backed OSIsoft
summary: Aveva Group is in exclusive talks to acquire industrial software maker OSIsoft for approximately $5 billion, according to people familiar with the matter. Aveva, which combined with Schneider Electric's industrial software arm in 2018, has beaten out other industrial bidders, including Emerson Electric. The talks are expected to lead to a potential deal within weeks. OSIsoft sells software for various sectors, including oil and gas, utilities, and manufacturing, and is backed by SoftBank Group, which has been selling assets to finance stock buybacks and debt repayment.

site_title: China's once-booming mask makers struggle after price drop
summary: China's mask-making industry is struggling after a surge in production during the pandemic led to a drop in domestic demand and prices. Over 73,000 companies registered as mask makers in the first half of 2020, but many are now facing stricter quality control measures and lower orders. Some companies are backing out of the industry, while others are refocusing on their core business. Chinese authorities now require a certificate of quality for exported masks, further impacting smaller producers. Despite this, China is expected to remain the world's top mask provider, with larger companies ramping up production.

site_title: With Brexit behind him, Boris Johnson tries to stop Scotland from leaving UK
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson is trying to stop Scotland from leaving the UK, six months after Brexit. He sent Treasury chief Rishi Sunak to Scotland and Northern Ireland minister Michael Gove to address nationalist sentiment. Despite polls showing 52.5% of Scots favoring independence, Johnson claims the union is working well. Experts say the pandemic has accelerated centrifugal forces, and Johnson's efforts may be too late. The situation in Northern Ireland is less acute, but businesspeople worry about the impact of a costly trading system.

site_title: Pentagon awards United Launch Alliance, SpaceX launch contracts
summary: The Pentagon has awarded United Launch Alliance (ULA) and SpaceX US$653 million in combined military launch contracts. The contracts, worth approximately US$337 million and US$316 million, respectively, will be issued annually from 2022 to 2024. ULA will receive 60% of the launch services orders, while SpaceX will receive 40%. The move aims to transition the US Department off Russian RD-180 engines and encourage innovation in the space launch market.

site_title: Quebec pension fund suffers with too many malls, not enough tech
summary: Quebec's Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec reported a 2.3% loss in the first half of 2020 due to its heavy exposure to shopping malls and underweighting in technology stocks. The fund's net assets decreased from C$340 billion to C$333 billion. CDPQ attributed its poor performance to its large collection of malls and the decline of Cirque du Soleil Entertainment Group, which was written off due to restructuring. The fund plans to discuss a "digital turn" with its portfolio entities to improve performance.

site_title: Nokia's new CEO outlines neutral stance in superpower tech wars
summary: Nokia's new CEO, Pekka Lundmark, has outlined a neutral stance in the tech industry's superpower conflicts, avoiding taking a side in the US-China trade tensions. Lundmark stated that businesses should focus on their core operations and not drive a political agenda. The move comes as the US is pressuring allies against using Huawei's equipment, and the company has seen increased business due to Huawei's troubles. Lundmark aims to map a path forward for Nokia and plans to hold an investor day to discuss future plans, seeking to turn around the company's performance.

site_title: Singapore lawyers urged not to enter into business deals with clients
summary: Singapore's Court of Three Judges has urged lawyers to avoid business deals with clients to prevent conflicts of interest. The court's decision to disbar lawyer Malcolm Tan Chun Chuen was made due to his dishonest practices, including falsely claiming guaranteed 12% annual profits to persuade clients to invest. The court's warning comes as lawyers face increasing scrutiny over their professional conduct and potential conflicts of interest.

images.alt_text: "As a general rule, it is inadvisable for solicitors to enter into business transactions with their clients since this will often have a real potential to give rise to a conflict of interest."

site_title: Hollywood studios unlikely to buy movie chains, even if they can
summary: A federal judge terminated the Paramount Decrees, a 1948 rule that prevented Hollywood studios from owning movie theaters. Movie theater investors initially saw this as an opportunity for a studio to acquire a chain, but analysts say it's unlikely due to the current state of the industry, with most theaters still closed due to the coronavirus. Studios prefer to invest in direct-to-consumer platforms rather than acquiring theaters, which would be less valuable with the shrinking theatrical window and increased competition from streaming services.

site_title: US: Slowing job growth, stimulus worries weigh on Nasdaq
summary: US stocks closed lower on Friday as a slowdown in employment growth and concerns over a lack of fiscal stimulus weighed on the Nasdaq. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones ended flat to slightly higher, while tech stocks declined, contributing to the Nasdaq's 1% drop. Defensive sectors such as utilities and real estate gained, bringing the S&P 500 1.5% below its record high.

site_title: Fleetwood gets his golf groove going at PGA Championship
summary: England's Tommy Fleetwood shot a six-under-64 to tie for the lowest round at the PGA Championship, vaulting into contention at the halfway stage. Fleetwood, 29, shook off the rust of a 14-day quarantine to start strong, with seven birdies, including four in a six-hole stretch. He is now at six-under 134 and near the top of the leaderboard, alongside big names like Jason Day and Brooks Koepka. Fleetwood is seeking his first major championship and is the highest-ranked player without a US win.

site_title: Brazilian food processor offers 5,200 new jobs in modernisation push, pandemic response
summary: Brazilian food processor JBS SA is hiring 5,200 new workers in Brazil to modernize its production lines and respond to the COVID-19 pandemic. The majority of the new positions will be in slaughtering and deboning beef, poultry, and pork in 16 states, while a minority will be in distribution centers, stores, and other facilities. This move aims to boost output and counter the impact of the pandemic, which forced JBS to remove high-risk workers and led to plant closures. The new hires are part of a larger hiring effort by JBS since March.

images.alt_text: Food processor JBS SA is hiring 5,200 additional workers in Brazil, seeking to boost output in a key export base while fending off the threat of the novel coronavirus, which disrupted some its plants in the second quarter.

site_title: ESPN hikes streaming service price by US$1, with sports returning
summary: ESPN is increasing the price of its streaming service by $1, making it $5.99 a month for new subscribers, starting August 12. The annual subscription remains at $50. The price hike is the first since the service's launch in 2018, with 8.5 million customers now subscribed, up from 2.4 million a year ago.

site_title: Wirecard suspected of lending to partner firms before collapse
summary: German prosecutors suspect Wirecard AG, a payments company, extended large loans to partner firms before its collapse in June. The loans, totaling $1 billion, may have been unsecured and made to companies in Dubai, Singapore, and the Philippines. Wirecard claimed the loans were for advance payments to merchants, but prosecutors allege the company inflated its books with fake assets to attract investors and lenders. The scandal has widened to involve top politicians, regulators, and auditors, and is considered Germany's worst accounting scandal.

site_title: WarnerMedia ousts top streaming executives as part of restructuring
summary: WarnerMedia has ousted top streaming executives Bob Greenblatt and Kevin Reilly as part of a restructuring, with CEO Jason Kilar stating that the move aims to elevate HBO Max globally. This is Kilar's first major action since taking over as CEO. The decision is seen as part of a broader effort to revamp the company's streaming strategy.

site_title: Suez's US$3.5b waste unit draws interest from German retail tycoon
summary: Dieter Schwarz, Germany's richest person, is showing early interest in Suez's planned sale of its continental European waste management business, valued at around $4.85 billion. The business, which includes operations in Germany and the Benelux countries, could attract a bid from Schwarz's Schwarz Group, which controls supermarket chains Lidl and Kaufland. This acquisition would mark Schwarz's second major venture into the sector, following the purchase of Toensmeier Group in 2018. Suez has been preparing to invite bids for the business, which could be its largest ever divestment.

site_title: Thriving on optimism
summary: Eastspring Investments CEO Seck Wai-Kwong shares his experience in the finance industry, tracing his journey from a promising start as a young graduate to being out of a job after a scrapped econometric model project in 1981. The project, initiated by then-MAS chairman Goh Keng Swee, was shut down due to the US economy going into recession despite the model's forecasted growth. This setback taught Seck to balance his natural market instincts with caution, ultimately shaping his career in the finance industry.

site_title: Air India jet with more than 180 passengers skids and cracks in half
summary: An Air India Express Boeing 737, carrying over 180 passengers from Dubai to Kozhikode, India, skidded off a runway during a torrential downpour, crashed into a wall, and split in half, killing at least 11 people and injuring 120. The plane overshot the runway, and extreme weather conditions are suspected to have contributed to the accident. The aircraft was a special repatriation flight carrying Indians stranded in the Persian Gulf due to the coronavirus pandemic. The cause of the crash is under investigation.

site_title: Venezuela's PDVSA changes oil deals to include shipping as sanctions bite: documents
summary: Venezuela's state-run oil firm PDVSA has started offering to ship its own oil as part of crude supply deals to help customers affected by US sanctions. The US has blacklisted vessel owners and shipping operators, and threatened to sanction tankers facilitating Venezuela's oil exports. By including shipping costs in crude deals, PDVSA aims to make its oil more competitive. This move is part of Washington's efforts to weaken socialist President Nicolas Maduro by choking Venezuela's oil exports and depriving the government of its main source of revenue.

site_title: Iceland may introduce LGBTQ workers 'certificate' for businesses
summary: Iceland may introduce a "rainbow certificate" for businesses that employ LGBTQ workers, following its success in achieving equal pay between genders. The National Queer Organisation of Iceland and Reykjavik Pride aim to provide guidelines for companies to foster diversity and create a welcoming labor market. The initiative, similar to Iceland's equal-pay certificate, would recognize businesses that demonstrate support and inclusivity for LGBTQ employees.

site_title: Tencent-backed Chinese realty company KE Holdings eyes US$2b US IPO
summary: KE Holdings, a Chinese real estate services provider backed by Tencent, plans to raise up to $2 billion in its US IPO, offering 106 million American depositary shares priced between $17 and $19. The company's revenue rose 39% in the first half of the year, recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic's impact. KE Holdings will list on the NYSE under the symbol "BEKE", with each ADS representing three class A ordinary shares.

site_title: US dollar climbs after jobs data but logs seventh straight weekly fall
summary: The US dollar rose 0.6% after a stronger-than-expected jobs report, but still logged a seventh straight weekly decline. The US Labor Department's July jobs data showed a 1.76 million increase, easing investor concerns on the US labor market. Despite this, the dollar index remains down 0.05% for the week, its longest streak in a decade. Ongoing stimulus talks in Washington and global economic concerns also weighed on the dollar.

site_title: Prime US Reit posts H1 DPU of 3.52 US cents, up 5.1% from forecast
summary: Prime US Reit reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.52 US cents for the first half of 2020, 5.1% higher than forecast, due to higher net property income and lower trust and interest expenses. The company's gross revenue rose 5.7% to US$71.2 million, driven by contributions from the acquisition of Park Tower. The Reit's portfolio occupancy stood at 93% and aggregate leverage was at 33%. The second distribution of 2.56 US cents is scheduled for September 23.

site_title: Patience and conviction will pay off eventually
summary: Malaysia's value stocks have seen a sharp recovery in recent weeks, with some deep value stocks perking up sharply. Companies like VSTECS Berhad, Rubberex, Poh Kong Holdings Bhd, and Tek Seng Holdings Bhd have traded at discounts to their book value, but have now swung to trading at premiums. Despite this, some value stocks remain undervalued, such as Star Media Group Bhd. The value investing strategy has shown mixed performance over the past decade, with some years seeing an increase in value stocks and others seeing a decline.

site_title: Quarz, Black Crane to vote against Sabana-ESR merger
summary: Singapore fund managers Quarz Capital Management and Black Crane Capital stated they plan to vote against the proposed merger of Sabana Reit and ESR-Reit, collectively owning over 10% of Sabana Reit. This move is expected to impact the deal's success, as the merger requires a majority vote from shareholders.

site_title: US job growth slows sharply in July amid a virus resurgence
summary: US job growth slowed sharply in July, with 1.763 million jobs created, below economists' expectations of 1.6 million. The unemployment rate fell to 10.2% from 11.1% in June, but 31.3 million people received unemployment cheques. A resurgence in Covid-19 infections and lack of action by Congress on a second aid package are blamed for the slowdown, with economists predicting a W-shaped recovery and potential negative employment territory.

site_title: QAF's H1 profit jumps 13 times to S$28.2 million
summary: QAF Limited, the maker of Gardenia bread, reported a 13-fold increase in its H1 net profit to S$28.2 million, driven by strong sales in the bakery, primary production, and distribution segments. Revenue rose 10% to S$462.6 million, with bakery sales up 23% and distribution and warehousing revenue increasing 13%. The company plans to sell its primary production arm to focus on its bakery and distribution businesses, which it expects to normalize in H2.

site_title: Busted retailers use bankruptcy to break leases by the thousands
summary: US retailers, including J Crew and Neiman Marcus, are using Chapter 11 bankruptcy filings to quickly exit costly, long-term leases and shutter thousands of stores. At least 25 major retailers have filed for bankruptcy this year, with more expected. This move threatens to upend the commercial mortgage-backed securities market, which is valued at half a trillion dollars. Retailers can legally reject leases in court, leaving building owners to collect pennies on the dollar, and can sell favorable contracts to other parties to repay creditors.

images.alt_text: As bankrupt firms like J C Penney (left) and Brooks Brothers look to jettison leases, landlords are already feeling the consequences.

site_title: Singapore Business Federation urges firms to turn to retrenchment only as a last resort
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has urged employers to prioritize retaining talent and using retrenchment only as a last resort to manage manpower costs. The advisory aims to encourage companies to adopt responsible retrenchment practices amid rising unemployment due to the Covid-19 pandemic. SBF recommends exploring alternatives such as upskilling, redeployment, and flexible work schedules, and seeking government assistance. If retrenchment is necessary, companies must select employees fairly and transparently, and provide support to affected employees.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has urged employers to protect the Singaporean core, retain talent to grow business opportunities, and to use retrenchment only as a last resort to manage manpower costs.

site_title: Asian markets spooked by US-China tech row
summary: Asian markets fell on Friday following US President Donald Trump's executive orders banning US transactions with China's tech giant Tencent and ByteDance, owner of TikTok. The move added to simmering tensions between the US and China, potentially worsening trade negotiations. Investors took risk off the table, with shares of Tencent and other Chinese tech firms tumbling. The US stimulus package may provide some support, but market uncertainty remains, with fears of Chinese retaliation weighing on markets.

site_title: IReit to take full ownership of Spanish portfolio from Tikehau Capital, DPS at 2.85 cents for H1
summary: IReit Global has proposed acquiring the remaining 60% stake in its Spanish portfolio from Tikehau Capital at a market value of $221 million. The acquisition, subject to shareholder approval, will give IReit full ownership of four freehold office properties in Madrid and Barcelona. The deal is expected to be completed by the fourth quarter of this year. IReit's distribution per stapled security (DPS) fell 2.7% to 2.85 Singapore cents in the first half, but its distributable income remained stable at 13 million euros.

site_title: First person in Singapore charged over Wirecard scandal
summary: A Singaporean, R. Shanmugaratnam, 54, has been charged with falsifying letters related to Wirecard UK & Ireland Ltd, a German payments company at the center of a scandal. Shanmugaratnam, who controlled Citadelle Corporate Services, one of two companies under investigation, faces four charges of document forgery. This is the first case in Singapore linked to the Wirecard scandal, which has raised questions about the integrity of financial transactions.

site_title: Creating an anti-fragile portfolio
summary: Investors seeking anti-fragile portfolios for a world of reduced economic growth may consider adding long volatility strategies to traditional US equities and bonds portfolios. Long volatility strategies, which focus on tail risk and periods of elevated volatility, have delivered crisis alpha during the Covid-19 pandemic but performed better during the global financial crisis and high-volatility years that followed. Adding a 20% allocation to long volatility strategies slightly reduced the annual return of a 60/40 portfolio but significantly decreased maximum drawdowns, making the portfolio less sensitive to economic fluctuations.

site_title: On-demand classes worth your while
summary: Singapore's gyms and fitness studios have reopened with safety measures in place, but some offer on-demand workout classes as an alternative. These classes provide access to a library of workouts, edited videos with clear instructions, and can be done at preferred times. However, they may not be suitable for beginners or those who rely on personal coaching or workout buddies. Seven gyms and studios in Singapore offer on-demand classes, including Boom Singapore, Haus Athletics, and Zoi Yoga, with prices ranging from $19.99 to $75 per month. The Under Armour Sportsmask, designed for sports, has also gained popularity for its breathability and comfort.

site_title: StarHub angling for growth even as Q2 net profit falls 5.6%
summary: StarHub reported a 5.6% drop in Q2 net profit to S$37.3 million, despite a 15% decline in service revenue and 18% lower total revenue. The company is exploring merger and acquisition opportunities and has secured extra credit facilities. Despite this, management downgraded FY2020 dividend guidance and reduced the interim dividend payout to 2.5 cents per share. StarHub expects to pay out at least the same amount in the second half, with service revenue expected to fall 10-12% in the full year.

site_title: iFast cites Bloomberg report after SGX query about its 13% share surge
summary: iFast Corporation's shares surged 13% on Friday after the Singapore Exchange (SGX) queried the company about unusual price movements. The wealth management platform cited a Bloomberg report that Hong Kong had shortlisted two finalists to digitalize its retirement funds system, with iFast mentioned as a potential partner. iFast's shares reached an intra-day high of S$2.245, driven by increased trading and strong business growth, including doubling of net profit and assets under administration.

site_title: More Chinese tech might park operations in Singapore if US data security tensions escalate
summary: Chinese tech firms may shift operations to Singapore as the US clamps down on Chinese tech, citing data security tensions. Companies like ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, and SenseTime have already set up shop in Singapore, with plans to expand. The move allows firms to maintain US operations while keeping a presence in China. However, experts say the US executive orders may not change much for Chinese tech firms, as they appear to be more of a political play. Singapore's business-friendly regulations and intellectual property protection make it an attractive alternative for Chinese tech firms.

site_title: A triumphant return for Jekyll & Hyde
summary: Jekyll & Hyde, a popular bar, has reopened with a new outlet on Neil Road, offering creative cocktails and Mod-Sin food for all-day drinking and dining. The bar, which previously closed due to rent issues, aims to provide a comfortable and relaxing space for customers. Owner Chua Ee Chien describes the new premises as a "laid-back alfresco ground floor" and "cosy second floor." This marks a triumphant return for the bar, which made headlines during the pandemic period.

site_title: HC Surgical shareholder fails in bid to sue chief executive
summary: A Singapore High Court has dismissed a lawsuit by minority shareholder Serene Tiong against HC Surgical Specialists' CEO Heah Sieu Min, who allegedly breached his duties in acquiring a larger stake in a medical practice. The court found the acquisition was made on commercial grounds and in good faith, and Tiong's case was deemed unarguable. Tiong must pay costs of S$10,000 plus disbursements to the company and Dr. Heah. The decision was made on Thursday, following a complaint filed by Tiong in May over alleged misconduct by Dr. Ong.

site_title: Genting Singapore falls after posting losses, cutting dividend
summary: Genting Singapore reported its worst quarterly performance since 2010, logging a net loss of S$163.3 million for Q2, reversing from a net profit of S$168.4 million a year ago. The company cut its interim dividend, a surprise move that surprised analysts. Shares fell 4.9% before regaining some ground to close at S$0.68. Analysts lowered their target prices, citing uncertain near-term prospects, but maintained a "hold" or "add" call for longer-term investors.

site_title: Gold roars past US$2,000 in a perfect storm
summary: Gold prices surged past $2,000 for the first time in history, driven by safe-haven buying amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and uncertainty over the US economy. The dollar remained weak, and 10-year bond yields fell to lows or became negative, making gold an attractive risk-mitigating asset. Despite a weakening US economy, gold prices continued to rise, with the psychological $2,000 barrier being broken each day of the week. Central bankers' comments on the pandemic's impact on their economies also contributed to the surge.

site_title: SICCI, ESG offer SMEs support to expand into Uttar Pradesh
summary: Singaporean SMEs are being offered support by the Singapore Enterprise Solutions (SICCI) and the Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) framework to expand into Uttar Pradesh, India's third-largest economy. Uttar Pradesh has a large population and a high proportion of micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs), making it an attractive market for SMEs. SICCI and ESG aim to provide guidance and resources to help SMEs navigate the Indian market and capitalize on its economic opportunities.

site_title: Steep discounts for Hong Kong's foreclosed homes may portend property price slump
summary: Foreclosed homes in Hong Kong have been sold at steep discounts, sparking concerns that the world's most expensive housing market could be heading for price declines. Foreclosures jumped 54% in the first seven months of the year, with some analysts predicting a 5% drop in 2020 and a larger decline in 2021. The surge in foreclosures could lead to a price slump, with some warning that foreclosures could surge next year to their highest levels since the global financial crisis.

site_title: Can China beat US in the financial cold war?
summary: China is seeking to challenge US dominance in the global financial system, with Beijing's best hope being to alienate its US allies. The country resents the US's control over international payments and wants its own alternative, citing the use of SWIFT, CHIPS, and the US dollar as key tools. China's fledgling Cross-Border Interbank Payment System could potentially use its own messaging protocol, and Beijing is also considering suspending the use of the dollar for foreign exchange controls. The country's goal is to achieve three separations: from SWIFT, CHIPS, and the US dollar, which could give China an opening in the "financial cold war" between the two superpowers.

site_title: KS Energy defends suitability of Kris Wiluan to remain CEO, chairman
summary: KS Energy defends Kris Wiluan's suitability to remain CEO and chairman, stating that charges against him are unrelated to his company duties. The firm claims Kris Wiluan has not breached company policies and has not been disqualified from acting as a director. The nominating committee also finds no hindrance to Kris Wiluan's duties, citing his transparency with the board. Shares of KS Energy plummeted 23.5% on Friday.

site_title: BlackRock pushing harder on social aspects in ESG thrust
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, is increasing its focus on social aspects in its ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) thrust, particularly racial equality, amidst the Covid-19 pandemic. The company expects to vote against management if companies fail to balance stakeholder needs and emphasizes the importance of diversity on boards. BlackRock identified 244 companies that are making insufficient progress integrating climate risk into their business models and took voting action against 53, or 22% of them. The company had direct dialogue with 812 companies and voted against management recommendations at 45% of shareholder meetings it attended.

site_title: With reliefs yet to unwind, Singapore banks sit uneasy about final impact of Covid-19
summary: Singapore's Big Three banks - DBS, OCBC, and UOB - reported sharp dives in earnings due to benchmark rates collapse and the trio lifted provisions as a buffer against defaults when loan moratoriums unwind at year's end. Bank chiefs warned that the next 12 months will hinge on a smooth exit from pandemic relief programs and the unfolding crisis. The banks have frontloaded provisions and maintained steady asset quality, but uncertainty remains on the number of bad loans that will turn bad. Interest income is expected to decrease due to NIM pressure, while fees are expected to moderate as economies gradually reopen.

site_title: The havoc wreaked by the pandemic across the world
summary: Singapore has been battling the COVID-19 pandemic for six months, with 54,797 cases reported as of August 7, 2020. The community cases have decreased to a trickle, averaging two cases daily, while migrant worker cases remain high. Efforts to clear dormitories and swab migrant workers continue. The pandemic has had devastating economic effects, with a 40% drop in GDP and 25% contraction in trade figures. Other countries, including Hong Kong, Australia, and China, are also struggling with the virus. A vaccine is expected to be a game-changer, with over 100 vaccines in development and several entering Phase 3 clinical trials.

site_title: Venture raises interim dividend despite 28.2% fall in H1 profit
summary: Venture Corp, a Singapore-listed electronics manufacturing services provider, posted a 28.2% fall in H1 net profit to S$130.5 million, despite revenue falling 25.5% to S$1.37 billion due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company declared an interim dividend of S$0.25 per share, up from S$0.20 a year earlier. Despite revenue headwinds, Venture's net operating cash flow strengthened to S$252.1 million, and its working capital position improved. The company expects sustained demand from customers in life sciences, medical devices, and semiconductor-related equipment domains.

site_title: Malaysia's Mahathir, 95, to set up new political party
summary: Malaysia's 95-year-old former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced the establishment of a new political party, set to be independent and championing the rights of the Muslim majority. The party aims to fight corruption and will not be part of the current government or opposition alliance. Analysts predict the party's success will depend on securing support from other parties, and Mahathir faces a challenging task in winning back his own seat.

site_title: IReit expands presence in Spain with acquisition from Tikehau
summary: IReit Global has proposed to buy the remaining 60% interest in a Spanish office portfolio from Tikehau Capital for 47.8 million euros (S$77.4 million), valuing the entire portfolio at 136.4 million euros. The acquisition, expected to be completed by the fourth quarter, will increase IReit's geographical exposure to Spain from 9% to 19% of its portfolio. The deal aligns with IReit's strategy of expanding its footprint across Europe and offers attractive asset management opportunities.

site_title: Reits (August 8-9, 2020)
summary: Realty Investment Trusts (REITs) experienced a surge in demand during August 8-9, 2020. US mortgage rates rose for the first time in five weeks, impacting the housing market. In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches is expected to test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents hit a record high, with further increases anticipated. Meanwhile, US investment firm Goldman Sachs acquired a large portfolio of Seoul hotel and retail assets. UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, and New World Group is selling its China property assets.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has urged finance companies to cap their fiscal 2020 total dividends per share at 60% of the previous year's level. The regulator also encouraged finance companies to offer scrip dividends instead of cash. Meanwhile, the Vietnamese subsidiary of Darco Water Technologies has pulled out of a proposed acquisition due to technical issues. Beverage maker Yeo Hiap Seng posted a net loss of $6.73 million for the first half of the year, citing the Covid-19 pandemic as the key reason.

site_title: Japan in deal to buy AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Japan has agreed to buy 120 million doses of AstraZeneca's experimental Covid-19 vaccine, with domestic pharmaceutical firms helping in supply. The deal comes after Japan signed a similar agreement with Pfizer and BioNTech last week. Health Minister Katsunobu Kato stated that two doses of the vaccine, administered per person, could cover 60 million people. AstraZeneca will produce the vaccine substance in Japan with JCR Pharmaceuticals, while importing additional substance from overseas.

site_title: Two Thai protest leaders arrested as discontent rises
summary: Thai police arrested two protest leaders, Anon Numpa and another activist, amid rising discontent over a military-aligned government. The arrests mark the first crackdown on a bold movement calling for democracy and challenging a law protecting the monarchy. Protests have been held daily at universities and town halls, denouncing the government and Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha. The arrests signal a growing crackdown on dissent in Thailand, sparking concerns about the erosion of civil liberties.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end week with gains on telecoms, tech boost
summary: European stocks ended the week with gains, driven by a supportive earnings season and improving economic data, outweighing concerns over US-China tensions. Despite US President Donald Trump's move to ban transactions with WeChat and TikTok, main indices closed higher. Amsterdam-listed Prosus fell 4% due to its investment in Tencent. The rally extended despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty, with mining and healthcare stocks propelling shares higher.

site_title: STI closes 0.53% lower as Trump fires at China tech
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.53% to 2,545.51 on Friday, amid US President Donald Trump's growing attack on Chinese tech companies, including TikTok and WeChat. Asian stock indices also declined, with the Hang Seng Index and Shanghai Composite falling 1.60% and 0.96% respectively. Despite this, the STI ended the week up 0.61%. Thai Beverage was the top loser, while Jardine Matheson rose 1.24%. Earnings season continues next week with several key companies set to report earnings.

site_title: US wholesale inventories decline further in June
summary: US wholesale inventories declined 1.4% in June, less than the estimated 2.0% drop, likely due to a rebound in goods imports after the pandemic disrupted trade. This decrease contributed to a record 32.9% annualized GDP decline in the second quarter. Inventories have declined for five consecutive quarters, with stocks of motor vehicles and parts falling 2.1%. Sales at wholesalers surged 8.8% in June, but still took 1.38 months to clear shelves, down from 1.53 months in May.

site_title: Sterling revives on hopes of a UK-EU trade and services deal
summary: The British pound has risen sharply since July, driven by hopes of a UK-EU trade and services deal and a new Bank of England forecast that the UK economic slump will be less severe than expected. The pound has risen 7% against the US dollar, 5.5% against the Singapore dollar, and 5% against the yen, reaching nearly US$1.317. Sterling strategist Steven Barrow expects the pound to rise to over US$1.40, while others, including Brendan Brown and Dominic Bunning, are more cautious, citing potential credit crisis risks and a downturn in the UK property market. A potential deal on financial services is seen as crucial to the pound's strength.

site_title: OCBC swallows bitter pill on offshore sector
summary: OCBC Bank took a significant hit in Q2, with a 40% decline in net profit due to a S$350m write-down of offshore support vessels backing impaired loans. The bank's provisions for bad loans surged to S$750m, and its OSV portfolio is now less than 0.3% of total outstanding loans. OCBC CEO Samuel Tsien attributed the move to a grim outlook for the sector and a desire to "take care of the past and caution on the future." The bank's shares fell 8 cents to S$8.72.

site_title: Five key milestones in Singapore's sustainability journey as it turns 55
summary: Singapore has achieved significant milestones in its sustainability journey as it turns 55. The country's garden city programme, launched in 1967, has transformed it into a liveable city with lush greenery. The introduction of NEWater in 2003 has ensured the country's self-sustenance over water resources. The Carbon Pricing Act, introduced in 2019, has helped sustain Singapore's green environment and transition to a low-carbon economy. The Resource Sustainability Act has set out measures to reduce waste and promote recycling. The Ministry of Sustainability and Environment has been rebranded to reflect the country's evolving environmental priorities.

site_title: CapitaLand under continued business pressure, but looking for growth openings
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean real estate group, reported a 89% year-on-year decline in H1 2020 net profit to S$96.61 million due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on its retail and lodging businesses. Revenue declined 4.9% to S$2.03 billion, while fee income rose 12%. The group expects continued pressure on its business in H2 but remains cautious and is looking for counter-cyclical opportunities to bolster growth. Its balance sheet remains strong, and it plans to divest non-core assets and focus on cost management to navigate the downturn.

site_title: Broker's take: KGI downgrades ARA H-Trust to 'neutral' on slower recovery
summary: KGI Securities downgraded ARA US Hospitality Trust (ARA H-Trust) to 'neutral' with a lowered target price of US$0.40 due to slower-than-expected results for the first half of 2020. The stapled group's recovery rate for 2020 and 2021 is revised downward. KGI expects pent-up demand to rebound in the second half of 2021, but long-term growth remains intact. The research team factored in higher costs of equity and risks associated with the pandemic in the US, including a potential rights issue.

site_title: Raytheon lobbies Japan to replace Lockheed's US$300m radar deal
summary: US defence company Raytheon is lobbying Japanese lawmakers to replace Lockheed Martin Corp as the supplier of powerful radars for two Aegis Ashore missile defence sites, potentially saving Japan money and time. Raytheon's proposal includes using its SPY-6 radar on refitted destroyers, while Lockheed Martin has a US$300 million contract to build its SPY-7 radars. Japan is reconsidering plans due to mounting costs and concerns over new missile threats, with former defence ministers set to make recommendations to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.

site_title: Thailand's CP Group expands e-commerce with purchase of HK-based Chilindo
summary: Thailand's CP Group acquired Hong Kong-based e-commerce platform Chilindo for US$18 million, expanding its digital business and developing Thailand's digital economy amid the pandemic. The acquisition will complement CP Group's online shopping platform WeMall, which competes with Alibaba's Lazada and Sea's Shopee. The move is expected to increase Thai e-commerce brands' competitiveness in the international market, particularly with the rollout of 5G technology.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Friday, down 10.43 points to 1,578.14, with losers outnumbering gainers 794 to 435. Volume reached 26.6 billion lots worth RM9 billion.

site_title: Oil slips below US$45 per barrel on demand concerns but posts weekly rise
summary: Oil prices fell 1.5% to $44.40 a barrel and 1.7% to $41.22 a barrel due to concerns over a resurgence of coronavirus cases, limiting the weekly gain. The rise in infections in the US and India, with over 700,000 deaths worldwide, remains a dominant issue for fuel demand.

site_title: Facebook Gaming finally clears hurdle, arriving in App Store
summary: Facebook has finally cleared the hurdle to release its Facebook Gaming app in the App Store after six months of negotiations with Apple. The app, which was initially approved for Android devices, was rejected by Apple due to its "main purpose" of distributing games, leading Facebook to remove playable games and alter its app to comply with Apple's rules. The revised app will allow users to watch and create live gameplay streams and participate in gaming communities. Facebook's COO Sheryl Sandberg stated that the company had to remove gameplay functionality to secure Apple's approval, despite the frustration it may cause for users.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on Sino-US tensions, slowing jobs growth
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday due to Sino-US tensions, with the Dow Jones falling 0.24% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropping 0.27% and 0.32% respectively. The slowdown in US employment growth, as reported by data, is also a contributing factor. President Donald Trump's moves to ban WeChat and TikTok have heightened friction with Beijing, adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: US sanctions Hong Kong's Carrie Lam over China crackdown
summary: The US has imposed sanctions on 11 Chinese officials, including Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam, over their roles in curtailing Hong Kong's political freedoms. The Treasury Department stated that Lam is "directly responsible for implementing Beijing's policies of suppression of freedom and democratic processes." The sanctions target those undermining Hong Kong's autonomy, with the US standing in solidarity with the Hong Kong people.

images.alt_text: The US is placing sanctions on 11 top Chinese officials and their allies in Hong Kong, including Chief Executive Carrie Lam, over their role in curtailing political freedoms in the former UK colony, the Treasury Department said Friday.

site_title: Fortescue reviews plans that threaten 60,000 year-old Australian site
summary: Fortescue Metals Group has requested a two-month delay on a heritage exemption request for an iron ore mine expansion in Western Australia, citing concerns over sacred sites and cultural significance to the Wintawari Guruma people. The proposed expansion threatens a 60,000-year-old rock shelter and other sites of cultural importance. This comes as another major miner, Rio Tinto, faces a government inquiry into the destruction of two rock shelters with historical significance. Fortescue has previously protected 6,000 Aboriginal cultural heritage places across its operations.

site_title: Brave new world - the millennial effect
summary: Millennials, born between 1980 and 2000, will continue to reshape the global economy with their spending habits and preferences, accounting for 30% of the world's population. Their distinct characteristics, such as tech-enabled consumption and environmental consciousness, will drive investment themes and equity alpha generation. Companies capitalizing on millennials' consumption patterns, particularly in tech-enabled consumption, infrastructure, health and wellness, and sustainability, will be key drivers of growth. As a result, finding these companies will be critical for investors seeking sustainable investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: As smartphone-wielding, athleisure-wearing and environmentally conscious millennials become the global economy's main source of wealth and spending, this generation's distinct characteristics and preferences will provide sustainable investment themes.

site_title: Pfizer to make Gilead's Covid-19 treatment remdesivir
summary: Pfizer has signed a multi-year agreement to manufacture Gilead's COVID-19 treatment remdesivir, aiming to increase supply and treat over 2 million patients by the end of the year. Gilead will send nearly all its remdesivir supply to the US through September, addressing concerns about access to the drug. Remdesivir is one of the two treatments to have shown effectiveness in treating hospitalized COVID-19 patients in clinical trials.

site_title: Darco unit withdraws from proposed purchase of Canwaco; requests US$1m refund
summary: Darco Water Technologies' Vietnamese subsidiary is withdrawing from its proposed acquisition of Can Giuoc Water Works Limited due to technical issues that remain unresolved despite considerable time. The firm has given CA Trading, the seller, a US$1 million refund. The withdrawal marks a significant setback for the acquisition, which was initially announced in 2017. Darco will update shareholders on further developments and shares of the water treatment player closed flat at S$0.16.

site_title: QAF multiplies H1 earnings 13 times to S$28.2 million
summary: QAF Ltd, maker of Gardenia bread, has reported a 13-fold increase in net profit to S$28.2 million for the six months ended June, driven by a strong demand for its products during the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue rose 10% to S$462.6 million, with bakery sales increasing 23% to S$220.7 million. The company plans to launch a sale process for its primary production arm in H2 to focus on its bakery and distribution units.

site_title: EC World Reit's Q2 DPU down 10.4% on income conservation
summary: EC World Reit posted a Q2 DPU of 1.386 Singapore cents, down 10.4% from the previous year, due to income retention amid a cautious outlook. Gross revenue rose 18.8% to S$28.2 million, while net property income increased 22.1% to S$25.8 million. The Reit retained 10% of its total distribution due to pandemic uncertainties. For H1, DPU dropped 16.5% to 2.544 Singapore cents, despite a 8.7% increase in gross revenue.

site_title: Facebook employees to work from home until July 2021
summary: Facebook employees will be allowed to work from home until July 2021 due to the coronavirus outbreak. The company will also provide US$1,000 for home office needs. This decision follows similar steps taken by other big technology firms, including Google and Twitter. Facebook plans to reopen offices in restricted capacity in areas where government guidance permits, but it is unlikely many locations will reopen in the US and Latin America before the end of the year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tumble as Tencent sinks
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.60% on Friday, with Tencent leading the decline after US President Donald Trump banned Americans from doing business with the platform. The Hang Seng Index fell to 24,531.62, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also dropped. The ban has clouded Tencent's outlook, contributing to the market's sharp decline.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance posts 30.5% fall in H1 earnings, cuts interim dividend
summary: Hong Leong Finance, the financial services arm of Hong Leong Group, reported a 30.5% decline in net profit to S$36.5 million for the half-year ended June, primarily due to higher allowances for loans in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Net interest income fell 19.7% to S$82.2 million, while fee and commission income decreased 27.2% to S$4.8 million. The company also lowered its interim dividend to 3.5 cents per share, down from 5 cents per share last year.

site_title: One stranded tanker signals peril of trading with Venezuela
summary: A Venezuelan tanker, the Victor 1, remained stranded in the Gulf of Oman for over 100 days due to a payment dispute with its charterer, Imperium SA DMCC, which involved allegations of corporate identity theft and a potential US indictment of a Colombian businessman. The tanker was chartered to carry 295,000 barrels of fuel to Venezuela, but the cargo was eventually discharged in the UAE. The incident highlights the risks of trading with Venezuela, which faces severe gasoline shortages due to US sanctions, and the consequences for the Maduro regime.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise ahead of US jobs data; US-China tensions weigh
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.39% on Friday, ahead of US jobs data, despite US-China tensions. The Kospi index jumped 4.55% for the week, its largest gain since early June. The US unemployment rate is forecast to decline to 10.5% and 1.58 million new jobs are expected. US President Trump unveiled bans on US transactions with Chinese-owned apps WeChat and TikTok. Foreigners sold US$65.90 million worth of shares on the main board.

site_title: Singapore Business Federation urges companies to consider retrenchment only as a last resort
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has urged companies to prioritize retaining talent and upgrading capabilities to drive business growth, rather than resorting to retrenchment as a last resort. This advice comes amid expectations of layoffs due to the economic impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. SBF Chairman Lim Ming Yan emphasized the importance of taking a long-term view of manpower needs to protect the "Singaporean core" and transform businesses for eventual recovery.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng sinks into red for H1, cites Covid-19 impact
summary: Beverage maker Yeo Hiap Seng (YHS) posted a net loss of S$6.73 million for the six months ended June, citing the Covid-19 pandemic as the main reason. Revenue fell 12.8% to $162.5 million, mainly due to soft consumer spending and lockdowns. The company's balance sheet remains robust, with S$276.8 million in cash and no bank borrowings. Despite the decline, sales of its evergreen food portfolio grew, and management expects momentum to improve when more countries ease restrictions.

site_title: Thai July consumer mood rises for third straight month as virus restrictions ease
summary: Thai consumer confidence rose for the third consecutive month in July, reaching 50.1, due to easing coronavirus restrictions. However, concerns about unemployment and economic recovery weighed on spending. The index remains near an all-time low of 47.2, indicating ongoing economic uncertainty. The government's stimulus measures, including a 1.9 trillion baht package, have helped mitigate the outbreak's impact, but experts warn of a potential 1-2 million job losses in the fourth quarter and a projected 9.4% economic shrinkage this year.

site_title: Sukuk issuance set for 5% decline after 4 years of growth: report
summary: Moody's Investors Service reports a 5% decline in sukuk issuance expected this year due to the Covid-19 pandemic, ending four years of rapid growth. Despite the decline, sukuk issuance volumes are still expected to reach US$170 billion, the second-highest level on record. The decline is attributed to the pandemic's impact on Malaysia and Indonesia, but activity is expected to pick up in the second half of 2020. Moody's also expects rapid growth in sukuk issuance over the longer term, with Malaysia and Indonesia remaining key issuers.

site_title: South Korean doctors strike over plan to boost medical student numbers
summary: Thousands of South Korean trainee doctors went on strike outside parliament, protesting against a government plan to boost medical student numbers. The plan aims to increase the number of medical students by 4,000 over 10 years, but doctors argue the extra funding would be better spent improving their salaries. The strike comes as South Korea battles smaller Covid-19 clusters, and the government has urged the doctors to call off the strike, warning of a medical gap in emergency rooms and ICUs.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singaporean R Shanmugaratnam faces four charges of falsifying Wirecard-related letters. The Singapore Business Federation urges companies to consider retrenchment only as a last resort. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) urges finance companies to cap dividends at 60% of 2019 levels. Food ordering startup Eatsy shuts down operations, while Quarz and Black Crane vote against Sabana-ESR merger. MUFG Bank launches startup financing joint venture with Israeli fintech in Singapore. The Straits Times Index falls 0.53% due to US president Donald Trump's attack on the Chinese tech sector.

images.alt_text: In the first case before the Singapore courts associated with scandal-hit German payments company Wirecard, Singaporean R Shanmugaratnam has been slapped with four charges of falsifying letters that stated bogus balances held by his company's accounts.

site_title: Tanker line Stena Bulk taps used cooking oil in green push
summary: Stena Bulk, one of the world's largest tanker lines, plans to use used cooking oil as a green alternative to reduce carbon emissions. The company will offer the fuel as part of a carbon-credit scheme, not necessarily on the vessel carrying the client's cargo. However, the high cost of the fuel, around $100 a tonne more than usual, may limit its adoption. Industry experts note that the limited volumes of waste biomass for shipping and scalability issues may hinder the widespread use of these fuels.

site_title: Sun Life sets up Singapore branch office
summary: Sun Life Financial Inc has established a branch office in Singapore, securing a direct insurer (life) licence. The office will offer universal and whole life products to high net worth clients, targeting a sum insured of over US$400,000. This expansion marks a significant milestone for Sun Life, which has a strong presence in eight Asian markets, generating C$240 million in insurance sales in the second quarter of 2020. The Singapore branch aims to deepen the firm's capabilities in the region and bring its trusted expertise to help Singaporeans protect their prosperity for generations to come.

site_title: Venture's H1 net profit down 28.2%; interim dividend raised
summary: Venture Corp, a mainboard-listed electronics manufacturing services provider, reported a 28.2% decline in H1 net profit to S$130.5 million due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue fell 25.5% to S$1.37 billion, but the company's working capital position improved. An interim dividend of S$0.25 per share was declared, up from S$0.20 per share last year. Despite revenue headwinds, Venture expects sustained demand from diversified customers and plans to release new products in early 2021.

site_title: STI closes 0.53% lower on Friday as Trump takes fire at China tech
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.53% to 2,545.51 on Friday, following US President Donald Trump's attack on Chinese tech companies. The Hang Seng Index and Shanghai Composite also declined, while gold prices reached a best week since the global financial crisis. Despite Trump's actions, Asian stocks continued to rally, and investors remain hopeful for a US stimulus package to support the global economic recovery.

site_title: US job growth slows sharply in July
summary: US employment growth slowed sharply in July, with 1.763 million jobs added, beating economists' forecasts of 1.6 million. The unemployment rate fell to 10.2% but remains biased downward by misclassified workers. The economy's recovery from the pandemic is faltering amid a resurgence in Covid-19 infections, putting pressure on Congress to speed up negotiations on a second aid package. Economists warn of a W-shaped recovery, challenging the US stock market's expectation of a V-shaped recovery, and the economy may enter negative territory if the virus resurgence and lack of action by Congress continue.

site_title: British Airways makes progress with job cuts
summary: British Airways is making progress with its plan to cut 12,000 jobs, with over 6,000 employees choosing voluntary redundancy. The airline will send letters to remaining staff on Friday to determine their job status, with some facing a 20% pay reduction and others a 70% cut. The airline is struggling due to the pandemic, currently flying only 20% of its schedule and burning £20 million per day. Trade union Unite argues the cuts are too drastic and has organized protests and threatened strike action.

site_title: Sri Lanka president, brother tighten grip after big poll win
summary: Sri Lanka's President Gotabaya Rajapaksa and his brother have secured an overwhelming majority in the parliamentary elections, winning 150 seats out of 225. This allows them to enact sweeping changes to the constitution, including restoring full executive powers to the presidency. The Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna party and its allies achieved a two-thirds majority, giving the ruling group significant power to implement changes. The results have solidified the Rajapaksa family's grip on power, paving the way for significant constitutional reforms.

site_title: MUFG Bank and Israeli fintech to launch startup financing joint venture in Singapore
summary: MUFG Bank and Israeli fintech Liquidity Capital are launching a 50-50 joint venture, Mars Growth Capital, in Singapore to provide debt financing to Asia-Pacific startups, particularly those unable to access traditional funding. The JV will establish a debt fund with an initial capital commitment of US$80 million and utilize Liquidity Capital's credit-scoring AI platform to forecast revenues. The partnership aims to promote financial inclusion and sustainable growth in the region, enabling MUFG to become more competitive and relevant to its clients. Business operations are expected to begin this year.

site_title: UK's Sunak says BoE forecasts show improvement, but hardship lies ahead
summary: British finance minister Rishi Sunak stated that the Bank of England's new economic forecasts show an improvement, but acknowledge hardship ahead. The forecasts predict the economy won't recover pre-pandemic size until 2021, slightly later than the previous estimate. Sunak expressed optimism about repaying emergency loans and a possible September trade deal with the European Union, but noted hardship lies ahead.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open, before US jobs data
summary: European stock markets opened steady on Friday, awaiting US jobs data, with London's FTSE 100 index flat at 6,027.27 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index up 0.2% at 12,616.04 points, and Paris's CAC 40 down 0.1% at 4,879.77 points. Analysts expect the US labor market report to show a slowdown in employment growth due to the coronavirus resurgence. The US has seen a surge in cases and deaths since June, adding 2,060 deaths in 24 hours.

site_title: HK activist Joshua Wong files court challenge to 2019 poll disqualification
summary: Hong Kong pro-democracy activist Joshua Wong has filed a court challenge against his 2019 disqualification from district polls, citing concerns over electoral laws and the vetting process. The move could pave the way for legal challenges to other disqualifications. Wong, who was disqualified for supporting a non-binding referendum on Hong Kong's future status, faces multiple charges related to protests. The challenge may have implications for this year's postponed elections for the city's legislature, which have been criticized by Western governments as an attempt to weaken the pro-democracy opposition.

site_title: Fashion giant H&M suspends employees over use of racial slur
summary: H&M suspends several employees after discovering a racial slur used in an internal document for its & Other Stories brand. The slur was related to a hat name in the autumn/winter collection. The company apologized and expressed regret over the incident, stating they are taking necessary actions to address the issue.

site_title: ShopBack to officially launch in Vietnam on Aug 8
summary: ShopBack, a cashback startup, will officially launch its website and mobile app in Vietnam on August 8, offering up to 25% cashback from participating merchants such as Lazada and Shopee. The company has seen a month-on-month increase of over 1.5 times in sales and orders in Vietnam, with 4 billion dong (S$236,400) in cashback given out to users. This marks ShopBack's entry into the Vietnamese market, following its successful expansion in nine other Asia-Pacific markets, where it serves over 20 million users.

site_title: Indonesia imposes 10% VAT on Facebook, Disney, TikTok
summary: Indonesia has imposed a 10% value-added tax (VAT) on sales of digital products and services by Facebook, Disney, TikTok, and other tech companies, including Amazon and Google, effective September 1, 2020. The tax aims to create a level playing field between foreign and local companies, and between conventional and digital businesses. The move follows a similar VAT imposition on other tech firms, including Amazon, Netflix, and Spotify, and is expected to generate an additional 600 million rupiah (S$56.1 million) in annual revenue for the Indonesian government.

site_title: Asian refiners to ask for less crude after Saudi cut underwhelms
summary: Asian refiners plan to request less crude from Saudi Arabia for September, following the kingdom's smaller-than-expected cut in official selling prices. At least three buyers will request less oil, while others will seek normal volumes despite disappointment at the cut, which is the first reduction in four months. The cut, which lowers the price of Arab Light by 30 US cents a barrel, falls short of the expected decline of 48 US cents. This may lead to a decrease in Middle Eastern barrel prices and impact the physical market.

site_title: Richemont to ask shareholders permission for conditional share capital increase
summary: Richemont, the luxury goods maker, plans to ask shareholders for permission to issue new shares that can be converted into warrants after three years. The move aims to preserve cash during the Covid-19 pandemic, following a 50% dividend cut. Richemont's sales nearly halved in the three months to June 30, and the company is seeking an extra liquidity buffer. The proposed scheme is part of the company's efforts to navigate the pandemic's economic uncertainty.

site_title: China pharma tycoon's fortune fastest-surging among world's 500 richest
summary: China's Zhifei Biological Products chairman Jiang Rensheng's fortune has surged 256% this year, making him one of China's 10 richest people. His net worth has more than doubled in July, the fastest among the world's 500 wealthiest people, reaching US$19.4 billion. The company's Covid-19 vaccine is undergoing phase one and two clinical trials, contributing to the surge. Jiang owns 56% of the company, which also sells vaccines for diseases such as the flu and meningitis. His wealth has surpassed that of Wu Guanjiang, a former director with an 8% stake in the company.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 3.6 points or 0.2% to 1,585.0. Trading volume was 1.49 billion lots worth RM549.8 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 379 to 139.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip as dour GDP outlook, Sino-US rift weigh
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.6% on Friday as the central bank downgraded its GDP outlook and a US ban on transactions with Chinese companies heightened tensions between the two economies. The Reserve Bank of Australia expects a 6% contraction in annual GDP this year and high unemployment for several years. The S&P/ASX 200 index hovered around the 6,000 point level, with miners falling 1.5% and global miners BHP Group and Rio Tinto receding 1.3% and 2.9%, respectively. The US-China trade tensions remain a concern ahead of a review of the Phase 1 trade deal on August 15.

images.alt_text: Australian shares closed lower on Friday after the central bank downgraded its outlook for the national economy and as a US ban on transactions with China's ByteDance and Tencent heightened tensions between the world's leading economies.

site_title: Malaysia's June factory output dips 0.4% year on year
summary: Malaysia's factory output declined 0.4% year-over-year in June, marking the fourth consecutive month of decline, according to government data. The manufacturing sector, however, showed a 4.7% growth, driven by industries such as electrical and electronics products, food, and transport equipment. Mining and electricity output fell 17.1% and 2.4%, respectively. The recovery in the manufacturing sector was supported by the easing of lockdown restrictions.

site_title: Yum China eyes Hong Kong listing as early as Sept
summary: Yum China Holdings is targeting a potential Hong Kong listing as early as September, with Goldman Sachs and other firms working on the deal. The Chinese restaurant company, which operates US brands including KFC, plans to raise about $2 billion in the offering. This comes amid growing US-China tensions, with US regulators threatening to restrict Chinese firms' access to American capital markets. Yum China's shares have risen 13% this year despite a sputtering recovery from the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Australia's economic recovery slowed by coronavirus second wave: RBA official
summary: Australia's economic recovery is expected to be slower than initially thought due to the country's second coronavirus wave, particularly in Victoria. Reserve Bank of Australia assistant governor Luci Ellis stated that the initial contraction was smaller, but the subsequent recovery is likely to be more protracted, with unemployment staying high for several years. GDP is expected to take several years to return to its pre-pandemic trend path. The RBA will maintain its accommodative approach, keeping interest rates at a record low of 0.25%.

site_title: MAS nudges finance firms to cap dividends, as it did for Singapore banks
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has urged finance companies incorporated in Singapore to cap their fiscal 2020 total dividends per share at 60% of fiscal 2019's level, similar to its guidance for Singapore banks. Finance companies, including Hong Leong Finance and Sing Investments & Finance, are also encouraged to offer shareholders the option of receiving dividends in scrip instead of cash. This move aims to support the financial stability of Singapore's financial sector during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: 242 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 1 in the community and six imported
summary: Singapore reported 242 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 54,797. The cases include 1 community case and 6 imported cases. Migrant workers in dormitories made up the majority of the cases. The government has cleared 14 more dormitories and has seen a decrease in new community cases, with an average of 2 cases per day over the past week. A total of 263 patients were discharged, leaving 48,016 recovered and 6,385 recuperating.

images.alt_text: There were 242 new coronavirus cases confirmed as of Friday noon (Aug 7), taking Singapore's total to 54,797.

site_title: Standard Life Aberdeen H1 profit falls 30%
summary: Standard Life Aberdeen's pre-tax profit fell 30% to £195 million in the first half of 2020 due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on markets. Fee-based revenue dropped 13% to £706 million, and assets under management fell 6% to £512 billion. The company will pay an interim dividend of 7.3 pence per share. The decline was attributed to 2019 outflows, clients switching to lower-fee assets, and a scheduled mandate withdrawal by Lloyds Banking Group.

site_title: Hong Kong to offer free virus testing to whole city, says local media outlet
summary: Hong Kong will offer free, voluntary virus tests to all residents starting in two weeks, according to a report by local media outlet HK01. The move reflects mainland China's aid in boosting Hong Kong's testing capacity, which has been strained by a recent surge in cases. The initiative comes amid deep-seated political mistrust between Hong Kong and Beijing, with concerns over potential DNA sampling. Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam will hold a press conference to announce the details of the free testing program.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong will offer free virus tests to all residents, reported local media outlet HK01 on Friday, a move that reflects the powerful boost that mainland China has provided to the city's effort to contain its outbreak.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares falter on weak Asia markets, profit-taking
summary: Tokyo shares fell 0.39% on Friday, closing at 22,329.94, due to cautious investor sentiment and profit-taking ahead of a long weekend. Weak Asian markets and soft corporate earnings contributed to the decline. The Nikkei 225 index lost 88.21 points, while the Topix index fell 3.14 points.

site_title: Malaysian ex-finance minister charged in graft case
summary: Malaysian ex-finance minister Lim Guan Eng was charged with corruption on Friday in a RM6.3 billion undersea tunnel project in Penang. He pleaded not guilty to soliciting a bribe from a businessman and faces up to 20 years in jail if convicted. Lim, a key opposition figure, claims the case is politically motivated, following a string of investigations into opposition politicians and activists since his party's return to power in 2018.

site_title: Trump hammers China over coronavirus as US health secretary heads to Taiwan
summary: US President Donald Trump intensified attacks on China for its handling of the coronavirus outbreak, claiming Beijing may have intentionally let the virus spread globally. Trump's public approval ratings have fallen amid continued Covid-19 infection rates and economic woes. The US is cracking down on Chinese firms and exports, with Trump signing an executive order to yank back supply chains. Meanwhile, US Health Secretary Alex Azar is set to visit Taiwan, which Beijing considers a renegade province, amidst already high tensions. China has threatened "strong countermeasures."

site_title: China July exports rise at fastest pace in 7 months, but imports fall
summary: China's exports rose 7.2% in July, the fastest pace in seven months, while imports declined, missing market expectations. The country's trade surplus stood at $62.33 billion, exceeding forecasts. The data suggests China's economy is recovering from the pandemic-induced slump, but new export orders remain weak, and the recovery path will be uneven across economies. Rising coronavirus cases worldwide weigh on demand, and China's trade surplus with the US widened to $32.46 billion in July.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge up as investors await US stimulus, jobs data
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.2% on Friday, driven by anticipation of US fiscal aid and positive non-farm payroll data. The Kospi index climbed 3.43 points to 2,346.04. Shares of Korean Air Lines surged 16% after reporting better-than-expected quarterly numbers. The won weakened, and foreigners sold 72 billion won worth of shares. Analysts forecast 1.58 million new jobs and a 10.5% unemployment rate in the US jobs data later in the day.

site_title: Hot stock: SGX queries iFast after shares rise 12%
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) queried iFast Corporation after its shares rose 12% on Friday, reaching an intra-day high of S$2.17. iFast attributed the surge to a Bloomberg article revealing Hong Kong's shortlisting of two finalists to digitize its retirement funds system, with one finalist working with iFast. The company also noted increased trading in recent months due to its growing assets under administration and net profit. iFast declined to comment further on the matter, citing confidentiality requirements.

site_title: US lifts advice to avoid all foreign travel due to pandemic
summary: The US State Department lifted its warning to avoid all foreign travel due to the pandemic, instead advising citizens to exercise caution when traveling abroad. This decision comes as health and safety conditions improve in some countries, but remain unpredictable. The US will consider each country on a case-by-case basis, with some countries receiving a "Level 1" ranking for no special concerns, while others, such as India, remain under a Level 4 warning to avoid all travel.

site_title: Thai craft beer brewers tap out on International Beer Day
summary: Thai craft beer brewers are struggling to survive due to tough booze laws and the pandemic, with many forced to produce their beers abroad and sell them back to Thailand. The kingdom's restrictive laws, including a ban on advertising and logos, make it difficult for small producers to enter the market. The pandemic has also led to border closures and a halt in tourism, further exacerbating the crisis. A proposed amendment to the 2008 Alcoholic Beverage Control Act may provide some relief, but for now, craft beer enthusiasts will have to celebrate without their favorite brews.

site_title: Mark Zuckerberg's fortune surpasses US$100b
summary: Mark Zuckerberg's net worth surpassed $100 billion for the first time after Facebook's record high, driven by optimism over the release of Reels. Zuckerberg, 36, joins Jeff Bezos and Bill Gates as a centibillionaire, with his fortune largely derived from his 13% stake in Facebook. The tech giants' wealth has put them under scrutiny, with calls to tax "obscene wealth gains" and increased regulation. Zuckerberg plans to give away 99% of his Facebook shares over his lifetime.

site_title: AIMS Apac Reit proposes issue of S$125m in perpetual securities at 5.65%
