summary: AIMS Apac Reit proposes issuing S$125 million in perpetual securities at 5.65% as part of its S$750 million debt issuance programme. The Series 002 perps will be issued on August 14, 2020, at par and have a fixed coupon rate of 5.65%. After the first reset date of August 14, 2025, the coupon will be the swap offer rate plus the initial spread of 5.207%. The issuance is part of the Reit's efforts to diversify its funding sources and maintain liquidity.

site_title: Court dismisses HC Surgical shareholder's application to sue CEO
summary: The Singapore High Court dismissed a shareholder's application to sue the CEO of HC Surgical Specialists for allegedly breaching his duties when the company acquired an interest in a medical practice. Minority shareholder Serene Tiong had claimed that CEO Heah Sieu Min breached his duties in relation to the acquisition, but the court found her case to be without merit and lacking in good faith. The court ordered Tiong to pay costs of S$10,000 plus disbursements to the company and Dr. Heah.

site_title: Hilton sees demand rebounding to pre-Covid levels by 2022
summary: Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc predicts room occupancy rates will improve by 5% by early fall, with demand expected to take at least two years to rebound to pre-Covid levels. The company's second-quarter revenue per available room (RevPAR) dropped 81% due to the pandemic. US occupancy has more than doubled since April, reaching 48.1% as of July 25, and Hilton's recovery has been faster in Asia-Pacific. The company posted a loss of 61 cents per share on adjusted basis, with revenue plunging 77.3% to US$564 million.

site_title: Tencent loses US$30b as WeChat ban rocks China stocks, yuan
summary: The Trump administration's executive order banning US residents from doing business with Tencent Holdings' WeChat app has led to a significant drop in the company's market value, erasing US$30 billion. WeChat's parent company plunged over 10% before recovering to 4.3% in Hong Kong. The ban has raised concerns about the deteriorating US-China relationship and potential impacts on companies and economies. Tencent's huge size makes it a dominant position on global indices, with a market capitalization of US$686 billion, and it collaborates with major US corporations.

site_title: China's hottest tech stocks are about to move twice as much
summary: China's ChiNext board, a Nasdaq-like platform, is set to relax its 10% daily trading cap, allowing stocks to move twice as much. The changes will start mid-August and test Beijing's ability to loosen its grip on trading without causing chaos. This move will apply to ChiNext listings under relaxed rules, but not to main boards in Shanghai and Shenzhen. The increased volatility may test an official narrative swinging between encouragement and restraint, as daily moves of 5% or more are common in the market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat ahead of key US data
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on August 7, 2020, ahead of key US jobs data and a Japanese long weekend. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.77 points to 22,418.92, while the Topix index increased 1.33 points to 1,551.21. Investors took a cautious approach due to uncertainty surrounding US data and ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Friday; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.5% to 2,546 points. OCBC Bank posted a 40% fall in Q2 net profit due to surging provisions, while CapitaLand shares dropped 89% in the first half. The US Nasdaq reached a fresh record, while European equities declined.

site_title: Gold smashes record high as safety rush intensifies
summary: Gold reached a record high of US$2,072.50 per ounce, with spot gold up 0.3% at US$2,069.78 per ounce, and US gold futures rising 0.6% to US$2,081.60. The safety rush due to the worsening coronavirus pandemic and economic toll is driving the price up, with a 4.7% weekly gain and 19% weekly gain in silver. Analysts expect gold to hover around US$2,020-2,080 an ounce in the near term, and a below-consensus US employment data release could provide further support.

site_title: Trump issues orders for US ban on WeChat, TikTok in 45 days
summary: US President Donald Trump has issued executive orders banning transactions with ByteDance, owner of TikTok, and Tencent, owner of WeChat, in 45 days. The orders aim to purge "untrusted" Chinese apps from US digital networks, citing national security concerns. Trump claims TikTok may be used for disinformation campaigns benefiting the Chinese Communist Party, while WeChat's data collection poses a threat to Americans' personal information. The ban would effectively prohibit WeChat in the US in 45 days and could lead to Microsoft acquiring TikTok's US operations.

site_title: US mortgage rates plunge to record low 2.88% for 30-year loans
summary: US mortgage rates have reached a record low of 2.88% for 30-year fixed loans, according to Freddie Mac. This marks the eighth time since the coronavirus pandemic that rates have dropped to a new low, boosting the housing market and giving potential buyers more purchasing power. The previous record was 2.98% last month, and experts attribute the lower rates to strengthening demand and giving buyers more purchasing power.

images.alt_text: Mortgages rates have found another record low, potentially boosting a housing market that has been a bright spot for a shaky US economy.

site_title: Hot stock: Genting Singapore falls 4.9% after posting S$163.3m Q2 loss
summary: Genting Singapore's shares fell 4.9% after the resort operator posted a S$163.3 million net loss for the second quarter, its worst quarterly performance since 2010. The company suspended its interim dividend, reversing from a S$168.4 million profit a year ago. Analysts from DBS Group Research, Maybank Kim Eng, and CGS-CIMB lowered their target prices, citing negative earnings adjustments. Despite the losses, Genting Singapore's strong balance sheet and importance to Singapore tourism are expected to tide it over tough times.

site_title: Australia says 1.5m workers in Victoria to get wage subsidy
summary: Australia's Victoria state will provide a wage subsidy to nearly half of its private sector workers, with 1.5 million workers eligible for a two-weekly payment of A$1,500. The six-week lockdown, starting Thursday, aims to contain the second wave of COVID-19 cases. The wage subsidy scheme, JobKeeper, is part of Australia's efforts to prop up the economy, which is forecast to peak at 10% unemployment. The lockdown and wage subsidy are aimed at slowing the spread of the virus, which has infected 13,000 in Victoria.

site_title: Lost Seoul: South Korean middle-class dreams spoiled by soaring house prices
summary: South Korea's middle-class dreams of homeownership are being dashed by soaring house prices. A couple, Baek Seung Min and his wife, considered cutting their income to qualify for a quota system in new developments. The 35-year-old interior designer's plan, to reduce his wife's 58 million won salary, was a drastic measure to secure a property. The couple's decision highlights the challenges faced by South Koreans in affording housing, despite the government's efforts to cool down property prices.

site_title: Trump demand for extra Biden debate rejected
summary: The US election debates commission rejected the Trump campaign's request to add a fourth televised debate with Democratic challenger Joe Biden, citing that three debates would suffice for voter education. The first debate is set for September 29 in Cleveland, Ohio. The commission stated that voters can still watch debates before mailing their ballots and that the debate schedule will be highly publicized. Trump had pushed for an additional debate to counter declining poll numbers and to showcase his stage skills.

site_title: Food ordering startup Eatsy shutters operations
summary: Eatsy, a Singapore-based food ordering and payment startup, has fully ceased operations due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The startup had around 20 staff in Singapore and Indonesia before shutting down in April. Founder Shaun Heng joined CoinMarketCap as chief of staff in May, and employees were assisted in transitioning to other companies. Eatsy had previously informed users of its app in March that it would stop operating on April 1.

site_title: US job gains may have stalled in July amid virus spike
summary: US job gains may have stalled in July due to a spike in Covid-19 cases, with some economists predicting a decline in August. The Labor Department's monthly jobs report, set to be released Friday, is expected to show a gain of about 2 million jobs, but analysts warn this could be lower due to state and local government layoffs and the ongoing virus risk. The job market faces severe challenges, with permanent job losses and closures of small businesses threatening the recovery, and the unemployment rate expected to remain high at 10.5%.

images.alt_text: The promising jobs recovery in May and June may have come to a screeching halt in July as Covid-19 cases spiked and newly rehired workers in some states were sent home.

site_title: Gold hits new record high, on track for ninth weekly rise
summary: Gold reached a new record high of $2,072.50 per ounce, marking its ninth consecutive weekly gain. The surge was driven by a softer US dollar, falling US Treasury yields, and concerns over the global economic impact of rising Covid-19 cases. Gold prices rose 0.3% to $2,068.32 per ounce, with US gold futures also increasing 0.5% to $2,078.70.

site_title: Thailand picks ex-banker as finance minister to battle virus-driven recession
summary: Thailand has appointed Preede Daochai, a former Kasikornbank copresident, as its new finance minister to combat the pandemic-driven recession. The move is part of a wider Cabinet reshuffle, with Supattanapong Punmeechaow, a former PTT executive, becoming a Deputy Prime Minister and overseeing the Energy Ministry. The changes come as Thailand seeks to respond to the economic challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Uber's quarterly sales tumble, ending a decade of growth
summary: Uber's quarterly sales fell 29% to $2.24 billion, marking the end of a decade of growth. The decline was largely due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which reduced ridership by 67%. However, delivery revenue surged 103% and now accounts for a significant portion of the company's strategy. Despite the loss, Uber maintains its goal of turning an adjusted profit by the end of next year and is focusing on cost-cutting measures, including eliminating a quarter of its workforce and exiting some markets.

site_title: Asia: Shares fall after Trump takes aim at China tech firms
summary: US President Donald Trump banned transactions with China's tech giant Tencent and ByteDance, owner of TikTok, causing Asian shares to fall. Asian stocks outside Japan lost 1% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng dropped 2%. Tencent dropped 9%, while mainland China's CSI 300 Index fell 1.3%. Despite this, US stocks edged to fresh records.

site_title: StarHub cuts H1 dividend to 2.5 S cents, service revenue slumps 15% in Q2
summary: StarHub's net profit fell 5.6% to S$37.3 million in Q2, while its first-half dividend was nearly halved to 2.5 Singapore cents a share. This decline was due to closed retail stores and lower revenues from roaming, IDD, and prepaid mobile services, resulting from strict border controls and a decline in travel. The company's full-year payout guidance was also lowered.

site_title: Soilbuild Construction, BBR, Hotel Properties and Koyo warn of H1 losses
summary: Four Singapore-listed companies, Soilbuild Construction, BBR, Hotel Properties, and Koyo International, warned of net losses for their results for the six months ended June 30, 2020, due to government-mandated operating suspensions amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Soilbuild Construction expects a "significant" net loss, while BBR Holdings expects a deeper loss due to suspended operations and increased construction costs. Hotel Properties and Koyo International also reported expected losses, with no provided reasons for the latter. The companies will release their results in the coming days.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open down
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day 0.09% lower, with the Hang Seng Index at 24,909.37. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.5% and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.3%. US lawmakers continue to struggle with a new stimulus package, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, DBS, UOB, CapitaLand, Genting, Wilmar
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 40% decline in Q2 net profit due to provisions for impaired loans, while DBS and UOB shares rose on conservative provisions and unchanged outlook guidance. CapitaLand's net profit dropped 89% due to the impact of Covid-19 on its businesses, and Genting Singapore logged a net loss of S$163.3 million. StarHub reported a 5.6% decline in net profit, and Fraser and Neave's net profit fell 8.2%. Wilmar International's Chinese unit received confirmation from the Shenzhen Stock Exchange to lift a trading halt.

site_title: Quarz, Black Crane to vote against Sabana-ESR merger
summary: Quarz Capital and Black Crane Capital, which collectively own over 10% of Sabana Reit units, announced they will vote against the proposed merger with ESR-Reit. They argue that Sabana Reit is undervalued at 0.94 ESR-Reit units per Sabana Reit unit. The managers are working on alternative options and plan to present them to fellow unitholders soon.

site_title: Europe: London stocks drag shares lower as Glencore, oil stocks weigh
summary: European stocks declined on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 falling 1.3% and the German DAX down 0.5%, weighed down by Glencore's dividend cut and oil stocks. The pan-European STOXX 600 index closed 0.7% lower. US stocks were largely flat, near record levels, as Democrats and White House officials struggled to agree on a stimulus package. The Bank of England also signaled no immediate interest rate cut, contributing to a stronger pound.

site_title: Souvenirs for a Nation
summary: Singaporeans can bring a piece of the nation into their homes with various designs created by local creatives. The list includes a recycled cardboard dragon playground toy, a hand-sewn Singapore Shoulder Sling, the Kizuna Table made from mahogany trees, and an Orchid Saucer and Chopstick Rest. Limited-edition items, such as the Singapore Durian Map Print and Singa the Lion artwork, are also available. Additionally, a smart diffuser with Orchid Island Essential Oil and a furniture line by Grafunkt and Onlewo can add a touch of Singaporean heritage to any home.

site_title: Airbus shareholders in US file fraud lawsuit over disclosures, corruption probes
summary: Airbus shareholders filed a class-action lawsuit against the company, alleging securities fraud for misleading them about its ability to manage corruption accusations over nearly 4.5 years. The lawsuit seeks unspecified damages for alleged violations of US securities laws. Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury and former CEO Tom Enders, along with CFO Dominik Asam and former CFO Harald Wilhelm, are named as defendants. The lawsuit comes after Airbus agreed to a $4 billion settlement of corruption charges by US, UK, and French authorities.

images.alt_text: Airbus was sued on Thursday by shareholders who accused the European planemaker of securities fraud for misleading them about its ability to avoid and manage corruption accusations over nearly 4-1/2 years.

site_title: Uber sees US$1.8b loss as pandemic stalls revenue
summary: Uber reported a US$1.8 billion loss in the recently ended quarter due to the pandemic's impact on its shared-ride business, with revenues dropping 29% and ride-hailing bookings declining 75%. However, the delivery segment, Uber Eats, saw revenues more than double to US$1.2 billion. The company expects to achieve profitability by the end of 2021, excluding debt and other costs. Despite the losses, Uber shares remain strong, with the company continuing to invest in new products and safety technologies.

site_title: Oil settles below 5-month highs amid fuel demand worries
summary: Oil prices settled below 5-month highs as concerns about depressed fuel demand due to the coronavirus pandemic outweighed optimism about Iraq's supply cuts. Brent crude fell 8 cents to $45.09 a barrel, while US crude dropped 24 cents to $41.95, following a four-day gain. Analysts expect prices to correct in the near future due to weak demand, with JPMorgan trimming its oil demand forecast for the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Oil prices hovered below five-month highs on Thursday, falling after a session in which bearish sentiment about fuel demand counteracted optimism about Iraq's supply cuts, pushing the benchmarks in and out of positive territory.

site_title: Federal Reserve unveils alternative to Facebook's Libra
summary: The US Federal Reserve unveiled its alternative to Facebook's Libra, a digital currency and payments system called FedNow. The system aims to provide instant access to payments, addressing security concerns and enabling uninterrupted 24/7 processing. FedNow will be designed with security features to support payment integrity and data security, and will be launched in two to three years. The system's design was influenced by thousands of comments from interested parties, including concerns about Libra, and will include features such as fraud protection tools and ability to work with private payment systems.

site_title: CapitaLand H1 profit plunges 89% to S$96.6m on Covid-19 restrictions, tenant support
summary: CapitaLand's net profit dropped 89% to S$96.6 million for the six months ended June 30, 2020, due to the impact of Covid-19 measures on its residential, retail, and lodging businesses. The company cited the closure of residential sales offices, non-essential retail trades, and reduced occupancy of lodging assets as major factors. Tenant support measures, including government-mandated landlord obligations and the group's own initiatives, also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Pool sales in US, Europe skyrocket as consumers splash out on coronavirus 'cocoons'
summary: US and European consumers are splashing out on home pools and hot tubs as a way to cope with the coronavirus pandemic, leading to a surge in demand. Manufacturers are struggling to meet the increased orders, with some resorting to overtime and hiring more staff. The trend is seen as a result of "cocooning" - staying at home and creating an oasis - and is expected to continue until a vaccine is found and normalcy returns.

site_title: More European nations tighten virus curbs as global deaths top 700,000
summary: European countries tightened virus curbs, imposing travel restrictions and containment measures amid fears of a second wave of coronavirus infections. Global deaths surpassed 700,000, with Europe accounting for over 200,000 fatalities. New measures include mandatory tests for travelers from high-risk zones, quarantines, and lockdowns in several countries, including Australia, Germany, Finland, and others. The situation remains "extremely delicate," with uncertainty over the severity of the second wave and the effectiveness of response measures.

site_title: Taiwan in talks to make first purchase of sophisticated US drones
summary: The US is negotiating a deal to sell at least four sophisticated SeaGuardian drones to Taiwan, valued at around $600 million, in a move likely to ratchet up tensions with China. The sale, if approved by Congress, would be the first drone sale to Taiwan and would provide the island with a significant boost in surveillance capabilities. China claims Taiwan as its own territory and has denounced the potential sale, which could further strain relations between Beijing and Washington.

site_title: OCBC takes knife to offshore support sector exposure; Q2 profit down 40%
summary: OCBC's Q2 net profit fell 40% to S$730 million due to a S$350 million write-down on offshore support vessels. The bank's allowances surged to S$750 million, up from S$111 million a year ago. OCBC's OSV portfolio is now down to less than 0.3% of total outstanding loans. The bank declared an interim dividend of 15.9 cents per share, down from 25 cents a year ago. OCBC's NPL ratio rose to 1.6% and its CET1 ratio was 14.2%. The bank's shares fell 1.82% to S$8.64.

site_title: US dollar nurses losses ahead of non-farm payrolls data
summary: The US dollar experienced losses against major currencies ahead of the non-farm payrolls report, which may indicate slowing economic momentum. Rising US coronavirus infections, declining Treasury yields, and a lack of consensus on fiscal stimulus contributed to the dollar's decline. Analysts predict further dollar weakness, particularly against the euro, yen, and Swiss franc, as investors become more cautious. The dollar teetered near a five-year low against the Swiss franc and a four-month low against the yen, with the euro reaching its strongest level since March.

images.alt_text: The US dollar nursed losses against major currencies on Friday ahead of the US non-farm payrolls report, which some investors fear could reinforce the view that economic momentum is slowing.

site_title: Far East Orchard sinks into S$853,000 net loss for first half
summary: Far East Orchard, a hotel operator and property developer, reported a net loss of S$853,000 for the first half of 2020, compared to a net profit of S$5.8 million the previous year. The company attributed the loss to a decline in hotel occupancy due to the COVID-19 pandemic. However, it noted that demand for isolation and accommodation facilities offset the decline in revenue. The company expects occupancy booking to increase as the academic year starts, but faces uncertainty in its property development business amid the pandemic.

site_title: Cut in employers' CPF rate, more wage reform among measures NWC can push for: economists
summary: Singapore's National Wages Council (NWC) is expected to play a crucial role in helping the country weather the COVID-19 recession. Economists suggest that the council should push for a reduction in employers' Central Provident Fund (CPF) contributions and wage reform to support the economy. The NWC, comprising 20 members from employers, workers, and the government, has the power to set wage guidelines that can help companies take measures to save jobs and restart business. Experts recommend that the council consider recommendations such as freezing or cutting salaries, extending the Job Support Scheme, and protecting the informal sector.

site_title: Prime US Reit posts H1 DPU of 3.52 US cents, 5.1% above forecast
summary: Prime US Reit reported a first-half distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.52 US cents, 5.1% above its initial public offering (IPO) forecast. The higher DPU was due to increased net property income (NPI) and lower trust and interest expenses, following the accretive acquisition of Park Tower in Sacramento. NPI rose 7.6% to US$47.5 million, while income available for distribution was 15% above the IPO forecast. The company plans to pay out a second distribution of 2.56 US cents on September 23.

site_title: Trump reimposes 10% tariff on Canadian aluminum
summary: US President Donald Trump announced the reimposition of a 10% tariff on Canadian aluminum, citing Canada's alleged "flooding" of the US market with the metal. The tariffs take effect on August 16, following a previous exemption as part of the USMCA free trade deal. Trump stated that Canadian producers had failed to meet commitments to avoid harming US aluminum jobs. The move is in response to a "surge" in aluminum imports from Canada over the past year, threatening domestic production.

site_title: US jobless claims fall to pandemic low of 1.19 million
summary: US jobless claims fell to a pandemic low of 1.19 million in the week ended Aug 1, according to Labor Department data. This represents a decline of 249,000 from the previous week, surpassing economists' median forecast of 1.4 million. The broad decline across nearly all states suggests the labour market is improving.

site_title: Facebook launches TikTok-like product inside Instagram
summary: Facebook has launched Reels, a short-form video service similar to TikTok, as a feature within its Instagram app. The product was tested in several countries before its US launch, and celebrities such as Jessica Alba and Mindy Kaling have already promoted it. The move comes after Microsoft's talks to acquire TikTok's US operations and escalates a rivalry between Facebook and TikTok. Reels allows users to record and share vertical videos with special effects and music, and is expected to attract American teenagers.

site_title: F&N's 9M earnings down 8.2% on pandemic, East Malaysia floods
summary: F&N, a Singapore-based beverage maker, reported a 8.2% decline in 9-month net profit to S$118 million due to lower soft drink sales in Malaysia and printing-plant closures amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue from the beverage segment fell 8% to S$339.1 million, while the dairies segment saw a 2% increase in revenue to S$879.3 million. The company's gearing ratio increased to 18.9% due to higher borrowings.

site_title: Sembmarine says recapitalisation critical to fix its liquidity needs
summary: SEMBCORP Marine (SMM) has reiterated the need for a proposed S$2.1 billion recapitalization to address its liquidity needs. The transaction involves a demerger from Sembcorp Industries (SCI) and distribution of shares to Temasek Holdings, with only a few bank facilities affected. SMM expects banks to refinance existing borrowings and provide additional facilities, but warned that shareholders who opt out of the rights issue will see their shareholdings diluted. Shareholders must submit proxy forms by August 8 to vote in favor of the resolutions.

site_title: Lessons for Singapore from a crisis
summary: Singapore approaches its 55th National Day amidst a deep recession due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The crisis has revealed the nation's resilience and taught valuable lessons about itself and its people. Experts share insights on investing in value stocks, creating anti-fragile portfolios, and the return of local businesses, such as Jekyll and Hyde, the iconic bar that closed during the circuit-breaker period. The nation is also moving towards a zero-waste future and promoting financial literacy, particularly for women.

site_title: China warns US against 'dangerous moves' on Taiwan: Xinhua
summary: Chinese Defense Minister Wei Fenghe warned US Defense Secretary Mark Esper to avoid escalating tensions with China over Taiwan and the South China Sea, following the US announcement of a senior official's visit to Taiwan. The US rejected China's claims of sovereignty in both areas, and Esper called for greater transparency on COVID-19 and international obligations. The phone call came as the US and China continue to engage in a diplomatic campaign, with the US accusing China of human rights violations and attempting to colonize the South China Sea.

site_title: Restaurant favourites return to Pan Pacific Singapore
summary: Pan Pacific Singapore reopens two of its top restaurants, Hai Tien Lo and Keyaki, on August 7, offering refreshed Cantonese and Japanese cuisine. Hai Tien Lo features new Cantonese flavors, while Keyaki serves classic Japanese cooking with seasonal ingredients. The restaurants, closed since the pandemic, aim to rediscover their cuisine and welcome diners again.

site_title: A resounding Yes! to faster SGX RegCo enforcement actions
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has proposed changes to speed up its enforcement actions, including the ability to impose public sanctions except fines, to hold companies accountable for corporate malfeasance. The proposed changes have received approval from market watchers, who see it as a step towards greater and swifter accountability. The measures aim to address the lack of results from previous initiatives addressing corporate malfeasance, with the hope that increased powers will lead to improved governance and a fairer marketplace.

site_title: Lebanon police scuffle with demonstrators angered by blast
summary: Lebanese security forces clashed with anti-government demonstrators in central Beirut on Thursday, following a blast that killed nearly 150 people and wounded over 5,000. The protesters, angry over the government's incompetence, vandalized stores and lobbed stones at security forces. Police responded with tear gas, wounding some demonstrators. The blast, triggered by a fire in a warehouse containing 2,750 tonnes of ammonium nitrate, has raised questions about the government's negligence. A second resignation, following the initial one, has been reported, amid calls for a leadership change.

images.alt_text: Lebanese security forces on late Thursday fired tear gas to disperse dozens of anti-government demonstrators angered by a cataclysmic blast widely seen as the most shocking expression yet of their government's incompetence.

site_title: First Singaporean man charged over Wirecard scandal
summary: A Singaporean man, R Shanmugaratnam, has been charged with four counts of falsifying letters related to Wirecard's accounts. Shanmugaratnam, an officer at Citadelle Corporate Services, allegedly misrepresented balance amounts in escrow accounts, ranging from 30 million to 178 million euros. If convicted, he could face up to 10 years in jail or a fine. The case is one of the first linked to the Wirecard scandal, which led to the German company's insolvency in June.

site_title: Stakeholder capitalism - emergence of corporate conscience
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the evolution of organizations' broader value to society, shifting from mere profit maximization to a more balanced approach that considers the interests of all stakeholders. Guided by a sense of right and wrong, companies are increasingly prioritizing stakeholder primacy over shareholder primacy, with many adopting purpose-driven strategies and reconstituting their portfolios to focus on sustainability and social responsibility. This shift is driven by a growing recognition of the importance of corporate conscience and the need for companies to demonstrate leadership, commitment, and alignment with employees, customers, and broader society.

site_title: ESR-Reit will not raise offer price for Sabana in proposed merger
summary: ESR-Reit will not increase the proposed merger offer price for Sabana Reit, maintaining the exchange ratio of 0.940 ESR-Reit units to one Sabana Reit unit. The decision comes after activist fund Quarz Capital Management criticized the offer price as "too low." Sabana Reit's manager clarified that the proposed merger is not an asset sale, citing factors such as trading unit prices, pro forma dividend accretion, and potential upsides. The agreed exchange ratio is at a 4% premium to the implied volume-weighted average price of Sabana Reit units.

site_title: US: Nasdaq surges 1.0% to finish above 11,000 for the 1st time
summary: The Nasdaq Composite surged 1.0% to finish above 11,000 points for the first time, reaching a fresh record, despite stalemate in Washington over an emergency spending package. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.7% and the S&P 500 climbed 0.6%. New jobless benefits applications hit a pandemic low, but the 1.2 million figure remains high. Investors await Friday's jobs report, which may show the impact of the US coronavirus spike on hiring. Large tech companies like Apple and Facebook rose, while chip company Western Digital plummeted 16.1%.

site_title: DBS, UOB shares up on conservative provisions; OCBC rises ahead of results
summary: Singaporean banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC rose on Thursday, with DBS shares up 2.87%, UOB up 1.75%, and OCBC up 1.85%, driven by conservative provisions set aside by DBS and UOB, as well as unchanged outlook guidance in their quarterly results. OCBC will announce its second-quarter results on Friday, further fueling the market's upward trend.

site_title: UOB debt workout teams to assess those on debt holiday
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has set up restructuring teams to assess borrowers on debt holiday amid the gradual unwinding of government relief measures. The bank expects a relatively low impact, with asset prices unlikely to collapse due to extensive government income support worldwide. UOB's net profit dropped 40% to S$703 million in Q2, with provisions against bad loans surging to S$396 million. The bank guides for total provisions to remain between S$2-3 billion for the next few quarters, with credit costs expected to rise when loan moratoria end.

site_title: JustCo to open two co-working centres in Singapore
summary: JustCo, a co-working space provider, plans to open two new centres in Singapore, OCBC Centre East and The Centrepoint, with a combined capacity of over 2,000 members. The new centres will be home to clients such as L'Oreal, Riot Games, and foodpanda, with L'Oreal housing its Asia-Pacific team for the travel retail business. JustCo will adopt a new payment model and relocate its headquarters to a larger space at The Centrepoint, citing the need for collaboration and staff morale as the company expands.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: Chef Willin Low's Mod-Sin omakase at Roketto Izakaya celebrates Singapore's National Day with a 8-course meal featuring local dishes with a charity element, where 10% of orders go to FoodBank. The Cloud Forest at Gardens by the Bay reopened on August 6 after months of closure, offering a special promotion for conservatory ticket purchases. The Rooftop Hawker Bash at Cé La Vi celebrates Singapore's traditional cuisine with a four-day event featuring local chefs and hawkers.

site_title: Investment trusts - The missing link in Singapore's capital markets
summary: Singapore's asset management sector can benefit from greater access to private equity opportunities by retail investors through listed investment trusts (LITs). LITs are permanent capital vehicles that allow investment teams to invest across various asset classes, providing a fixed amount of capital to the investment manager. This structure enhances transparency and reduces administrative burdens. LITs can hold illiquid assets, such as private equity, and provide a long-term investment approach, similar to Singapore's sovereign fund GIC. The new variable capital company (VCC) structure can be leveraged to list investment trusts on Singapore's equity markets, reinforcing the asset management sector and promoting greater transparency in private markets.

site_title: Singapore property plays 'too cheap to ignore' amid attractive valuations: DBS
summary: DBS Group Research has called Singapore's property developers "too cheap to ignore" due to attractive valuations. The research team highlighted CapitaLand, City Developments Ltd (CDL), UOL Group, and Frasers Property as stock picks with "buy" ratings and target prices. DBS believes the developers' well-capitalized balance sheets and low-interest rates position them as buyers, limiting exposure to potential portfolio deterioration. The analysts expect most developers to see resilient demand in the post-Covid-19 world, with improvement expected in the second half of 2020.

site_title: Nissan Kicks E-Power review: Nissan's Kicks is an electric car in disguise
summary: Nissan's Kicks E-Power is a sport utility vehicle that pairs electric drive with petrol convenience. The car features "E-Power" technology, which allows it to drive like an electric vehicle without the need for charging. The review praises the car's ability to balance electric efficiency with petrol convenience, making it an attractive option for those who want the benefits of electric driving without the drawbacks.

site_title: Singapore's hub status hangs on how Asean pulls together: think tank
summary: A Singapore-based think tank suggests that the region's recovery from the pandemic hinges on greater transparency and integration among Asean countries. Chairman Simon Tay emphasizes the importance of close discussions and harmonization to build trust and develop green travel lanes. He urges Singapore to take the lead in bringing the region together, citing the need for greater transparency and cooperation to maintain its status as a regional hub.

site_title: HDB resale volume surges in July; prices inch up
summary: HDB resale flat prices in Singapore increased by 0.4% in July, reaching 2,470 units sold, a 0.7% rise from June. This surge suggests the HDB market remains resilient despite the pandemic. Analysts attribute the increase to a steady demand for HDB flats.

site_title: Adidas e-commerce boom helps out as store traffic picks up
summary: Adidas' sales are recovering faster than expected after the COVID-19 pandemic, driven by a surge in e-commerce. The company reported better-than-expected overall sales for the latest three months, with store operations returning to normal. Third-quarter revenue is expected to fall by a mid to high single-digit percentage, but this is better than the 34% decline in the second quarter. Shares rose 1.3% after the announcement, limiting this year's decline to 16%. The company expects to turn an operating profit in the third quarter and is preparing to unveil a new strategy cycle in 2021.

site_title: US dollar recoups overnight losses
summary: The US dollar strengthened on Thursday, recouping overnight losses, amid fading risk appetite. The dollar rose to 0.1% against the day's close at 92.821, after hitting a two-year low of 92.495 earlier in the day. The euro reached a two-year high against the dollar at $1.1916, while the euro zone economy showed signs of expansion. Analysts worry that government support programs may be masking underlying economic damage, and investors await a US government aid package agreement.

site_title: South Korea tries to tame rampant real estate market
summary: South Korea has implemented 23 measures to cool its rapidly increasing real estate market since President Moon Jae-in took office in 2017. Despite tougher mortgage restrictions and new taxes, housing affordability has worsened to its worst on record. The government has introduced loan limits, debt repayment restrictions, and capital gains taxes to curb prices, but critics argue these measures disproportionately affect lower-income individuals. New measures aim to supply over 132,000 new homes in Seoul by 2028, easing building height limits and converting state-owned properties into residential areas.

site_title: How resilient leaders think
summary: Resilience in leadership is about emerging stronger from adverse circumstances, according to Insead professor of management practice Narayan Pant. It starts with self-leadership, followed by leading teams and organizations. Pant emphasizes that resilience is not just about survival, but about learning from experiences and adapting. To build resilience, one must be mindful of thoughts, acknowledge the power of negative thoughts, and practice observing them as separate entities. This can be achieved through mindfulness, cognitive behavioral approaches, and developing a productive attitude when faced with unexpected outcomes.

site_title: Driving disruption in the car business
summary: UCars, a Singaporean car portal, has introduced a digital auction system for used cars, allowing drivers to sell their vehicles quickly and for top dollar. The platform charges dealers a flat fee of S$88, compared to rival services that charge both buyers and sellers a fee, resulting in higher bids. The COVID-19 pandemic has increased the platform's relevance as it minimizes human contact and promotes social distancing. UCars is also rolling out an online car valuation tool to complement its digital auction system, aiming to increase convenience and trustworthiness for consumers.

site_title: Pelosi says Congress will resolve Covid-19 aid but must help needy
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi stated that Congress will resolve differences over the next Covid-19 aid package, with a focus on providing assistance to those most in need. She emphasized the importance of directing aid where it will do the most good, ensuring it reaches the most needy individuals. A deal is expected, but no specific timeline has been announced.

site_title: A spicy noodle story
summary: Two chef-driven hawker outfits, Pang's Hakka Noodles and Laifabar, are making a name for themselves with their delicious noodles. Pang's Hakka Noodles offers traditional yong tau foo with a focus on quality and a protective sheen of shallot-infused lard. Laifabar, on the other hand, serves modern wonton noodles with a zing from its sambal-based chilli sauce. Both stalls are worth visiting, especially Laifabar's eclectic menu and affordable prices. With their commitment to quality and innovative flavors, these hawker outfits are definitely worth trying this National Day weekend.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Wilmar International's Chinese unit, YIHAI Kerry Arawana (YKA), has received confirmation from the Shenzhen Stock Exchange's ChiNext Board that it meets listing and disclosure requirements, progressing its long-awaited initial public offering (IPO).

site_title: Genting Singapore posts S$163.3m loss in Q2 due to Covid-19 closure
summary: Genting Singapore reported a net loss of S$163.3 million in Q2 FY2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which led to a 94% decline in revenue to S$41.3 million. Gaming revenue plummeted to S$6.5 million, while non-gaming revenue fell 92% to S$16.3 million. The company attributed the losses to a "devastating" impact of the pandemic, despite implementing cost-containment measures. Genting is now pessimistic about its overall financial performance for the year, citing ongoing travel restrictions.

site_title: Genting Singapore posts S$163.3m Q2 loss in worst quarterly showing since 2010
summary: Genting Singapore reported its worst quarterly loss since 2010, with a net loss of S$163.3 million in Q2 FY2020 due to the temporary closure of Resorts World Sentosa and zero revenue. The company implemented cost-containment measures, but revenue plunged 94% year-on-year to S$41.3 million. Genting expects a pessimistic financial performance for the year due to ongoing travel restrictions and a S$4.5 billion mega-expansion plan for RWS.

site_title: Redesigning tomorrow's organisation today
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is driving the emergence of a low-touch economy, leading to significant changes in organisations, jobs, and work environments. Key shifts include delayered structures, self-managed teams, and rearranging business functions. The future of work will see the deconstruction of jobs to focus on value-added work, and the rise of robotic-process-automation (RPA) and AI. Organisations will need to redefine their culture, prioritising trust and communication, and adapt to new staffing models, including remote work and flexible employment arrangements.

site_title: Pandemic driving South-East Asian shoppers online
summary: Nearly 8 in 10 Singaporeans will make an online purchase this year, driven by the pandemic. They are also the most willing to spend, with almost 6 in 10 dropping at least US$50 on each purchase. This trend is faster than initially expected for South-east Asian consumers.

site_title: Toyota posts weakest quarterly profit in nine years as pandemic slams car sales
summary: Toyota posted its weakest quarterly profit in nine years, with operating profit plummeting 98% to 13.9 billion yen due to the coronavirus pandemic, which halved its car sales and nearly wiped out its bottom line. Despite this, shares rose 2.3% as analysts expected a loss. Toyota reiterated its annual operating profit forecast of 500 billion yen, its lowest in nine years, and expects global sales to fall 13% in the year to March 2021, marking its lowest sales in nine years.

site_title: Seoul home price surge is fastest in the world
summary: Seoul's home prices have surged over 50% since 2017, the fastest pace in the world, despite over 20 cooling policies. The government's measures, including tighter mortgage rules and tax penalties, aim to curb speculation but have instead priced out many young families, including those with high incomes. Critics argue the policies favor wealthy individuals, exacerbating inequality. The city's housing market has become unaffordable, with the average household needing over 14 years of income to buy a home, up from 11 years in 2017.

site_title: We the (food) citizens of Singapore
summary: Singapore's food heritage, shaped by its multicultural identity, is a significant part of the country's identity. Chefs and cookbook authors reflect on the direction of heritage cuisine, questioning whether it should stay rooted in the past or evolve. With a new generation of cooks, there's a need to balance tradition with innovation. The Singaporean food scene is expected to continue to evolve, incorporating new flavors and techniques while maintaining its unique cultural essence. This shift is expected to be driven by the creativity and perspectives of younger chefs and home cooks.

site_title: Samsung upgrades folding smartphone in bid to rev up sales
summary: Samsung unveiled a second-generation folding smartphone to boost sales, following a 29% decline in Q2 smartphone sales compared to last year. The company lost its top position to Huawei, China's leading smartphone brand. The new smartphone aims to capitalize on remote work and education trends driven by the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: The Samsung Galaxy Z Fold2 smartphone. Samsung gambled that consumers would pay more expensive prices, analysts say.

site_title: Manulife says cost containment key to 10%-12% core earnings growth
summary: Manulife Financial plans to achieve 10%-12% core earnings growth through cost containment, according to CEO Roy Gori. The company comfortably beat analyst estimates for second-quarter core profit, with core general expenses dropping 5% from a year earlier. Manulife expects $1 billion in expense efficiencies by year-end, citing cost containment as a key driver for its growth target.

site_title: Microsoft expands TikTok takeover ambitions to entire global business, reports FT
summary: Microsoft is reportedly seeking to buy all of TikTok's global business, following a deal to buy the assets of TikTok in North America, Australia, and New Zealand. The company has not disclosed its offer price, but sources suggest ByteDance executives value TikTok at over $50 billion. A deal for TikTok in India fell through, but Microsoft is exploring adding regions including Europe to the deal. TikTok faces a Sept 15 deadline to either complete a sale of its US operations to Microsoft or face a ban in the US.

site_title: Asean+3 likely to grow 6% in 2021: AMRO
summary: Asean+3 economies, including Singapore, China, and Vietnam, are expected to grow 6% in 2021, according to AMRO's latest forecast. This follows a flat 2020, with the region contracting by 2.6% due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Effective measures to contain the virus are crucial for a strong recovery, with AMRO warning of the risk of renewed outbreaks and lockdowns. China is expected to be the highest-growing economy, with Singapore and Vietnam sharing the top spot.

site_title: Testing of dorm workers to end by Aug 7, most construction work to resume soon: taskforce
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 testing of migrant workers in dormitories will be completed by August 7, allowing most construction projects to resume by mid- to late August. The government expects a volatile period in the next two weeks, but will monitor the situation and implement regular testing every 14 days. Taskforce co-chair Lawrence Wong also mentioned the possibility of extending a temporary relief measure for the property sector, which was introduced in May to mitigate the impact of the pandemic on construction timelines and home sales.

site_title: DBS sees margin squeeze as interest rate cuts bite in Q2
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, reported a 22% fall in second-quarter net profit to S$1.25 billion, mainly due to provisions and flat total income. Net interest margin (NIM) fell to 1.62% from 1.91% a year ago. DBS chief Piyush Gupta expects top line and NIM to deteriorate over the rest of the year due to interest rate headwinds. The bank maintained its guidance for full-year profit and total allowances, with provisions against bad loans surging to S$849 million in the second quarter.

site_title: LTA chief to step down, will be replaced by JTC head; JTC and SLA to get new CEOs as well
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA), JTC Corporation, and Singapore Land Authority (SLA) will have new chief executives starting next month. Ngien Hoon Ping, the current LTA chief, will step down to join the FairPrice group, while Ng Lang will replace him at JTC. Tan Boon Khai will take over Ngien's role at SLA. Simon Ong Hung Eng, the current SLA deputy chief executive, will act as acting chief executive. The changes were announced by the Ministry of Transport, Ministry of Trade and Industry, and Ministry of Law, praising Ngien's leadership and achievements in transforming the LTA and other authorities.

site_title: New Audi A4 puts more at your fingertips
summary: Audi's new A4 features a mild hybrid electric system and advanced infotainment system, allowing for improved fuel efficiency and smartphone integration. The car's comfort-focused suspension results in a less engaging driving experience, but its intelligent features, such as voice-to-text capabilities and personalized settings, are notable. The A4 also boasts a luxurious cabin and Virtual Cockpit screen with multiple modes. With a starting price of SGD 192,490, the A4 aims to outsmart competitors in the luxury car market rather than outrunning them.

site_title: Recovering from the EU's Recovery Fund
summary: European Union leaders have agreed on a 750 billion euro (S$1.2 trillion) rescue package, known as Next Generation EU, to aid member states hit by the Covid-19 crisis. However, the plan lacks essential fiscal sustainability conditions, including an orderly sovereign-debt restructuring mechanism. The recovery fund's 2.8% grant component is too small, and funds won't be available until 2021, limiting its effectiveness. A meaningful fiscal union is unlikely, leaving the euro zone at risk of national sovereign-debt defaults, and a European Monetary Fund (EMF) is needed to provide conditional financial support and manage debt restructurings.

site_title: US jobless claims dip in latest week to 1.19m
summary: US jobless claims dropped to 1.19 million in the latest week, below expectations. The four-week average for initial unemployment claims remained at 1.33 million. Total workers receiving benefits fell to 16.1 million, but the insured unemployment rate remained high at 11%.

site_title: Malaysia's former finance minister Lim Guan Eng arrested by anti-graft officials
summary: Malaysia's former finance minister Lim Guan Eng was arrested by anti-graft officials on Thursday in connection with a US$1.5 billion undersea tunnel project. He will be charged in court on Friday. Lim, a senior opposition leader, served as finance minister until February when the ruling coalition collapsed. The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission made the arrest, citing allegations of corruption.

site_title: Most building projects to resume by end of next month amid new protocols
summary: Singapore's construction sector is expected to resume most projects by the end of next month, with migrant workers returning to work by mid-to-late August, following new protocols to combat COVID-19. The government has introduced temporary relief measures for the property sector, including a six-month reprieve for residential, commercial, and industrial development projects. The taskforce is also reviewing work-from-home arrangements due to requests from companies for more flexibility, with a focus on maintaining a high degree of remote work to reduce public transport congestion and minimize risk.

images.alt_text: Mr Wong has warned that the construction sector must adapt to a very different environment with new protocols in place.

site_title: ST Index advances 1.04%; Yangzijiang among top actives
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.04% to close at 2,559.10, driven by positive updates on the Covid-19 vaccine and speculation over a US stimulus package. Local banks DBS and UOB also saw gains, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's shares rose 3.74% after reporting full yard activity in the second quarter. Oil prices edged higher to US$45 per barrel.

site_title: Sewelô stunner
summary: Louis Vuitton has brought the world's second-largest rough diamond, the Sewelô, to Singapore for a one-week viewing period. The 1,758-carat diamond, discovered in Botswana in 2019, is estimated to be 2 billion years old and will be cut into smaller stones by HB Company of Antwerp. The diamond's potential to yield a 900-carat or 300-carat diamond with satellites is being assessed. Louis Vuitton's purchase of the diamond signals its serious intention to dominate the high jewellery market, with the company collaborating with Lucara Diamond Corporation and HB Company to cut and polish the stone.

site_title: Wilmar's Chinese unit gets nod from listing committee of Shenzhen Exchange
summary: YIHAI Kerry Arawana (YKA), the Chinese unit of Wilmar International, has received confirmation from the listing committee of the Shenzhen Stock Exchange's ChiNext Board to proceed with its initial public offering (IPO). YKA meets the listing and disclosure requirements and will submit to the China Securities Regulatory Commission for final registration approval. The spin-off listing is expected to boost Wilmar's China operations by increasing market visibility and awareness. YKA's market capitalization is estimated to be around S$19.7 billion, according to a July report.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 20.44 points to 1,588.57, driven by a gain of 716 to 468 gainers to losers. Volume was 16.690 billion lots worth RM8.561 billion.

site_title: Sri Lankan president's party ahead in election vote count
summary: Sri Lankan President Gotabaya Rajapaksa's ruling party, Sri Lanka Podujana Party (SLPP), is leading in vote counting after a parliamentary election, with early trends showing a 70% vote share in the Sinhalese-dominated south. The final tally is expected by midnight, with Mr. Rajapaksa hoping to install his brother Mahinda as the next prime minister. The election result is seen as a step towards restoring full executive powers to the presidency, which Mr. Rajapaksa believes is necessary for the country's economic and military security.

site_title: Li Ka-shing's CK Group to cap costs as profit outlook dims
summary: Li Ka-shing's CK Group reports a 29% drop in first-half profit due to geopolitical and pandemic-related challenges. The conglomerate is cutting spending and cutting its planned interim dividend to conserve cash. Chairman Victor Li stated that the company needs to prepare for unexpected surprises and potential acquisitions. The core ports and retail businesses may not be as profitable in the second half as they were last year, according to the group's warning.

site_title: Bukit Batok ActiveSG gym, FairPrice Hub's Decathlon visited by infectious Covid-19 patients
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore has added several locations to its list of places visited by infectious Covid-19 patients, including an ActiveSG gym in Bukit Batok, a Sheng Siong store in Teban Gardens Road, and FairPrice Hub's Decathlon outlet. The locations were visited by patients who were still infectious, and those who visited these places between 30 minutes and two weeks ago are being monitored for health. There were 301 new cases confirmed on Thursday, with 293 remaining cases linked to migrant workers in dormitories.

site_title: SGX RegCo to get more powers to speed up disciplinary action
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) is proposing to gain more powers to speed up disciplinary action against listing rule breaches. The changes aim to allow SGX RegCo to mete out public sanctions, except for fines, to maintain investor confidence and preserve market integrity. This move follows concerns that the industry-led Listings Disciplinary Committee (LDC) has been ineffective in dealing with breaches. The proposed changes will enable SGX RegCo to take swift action against listing rule breaches and maintain market stability.

site_title: Thakral posts 91% fall in H1 profit to S$241,000
summary: Thakral Corp, a property investor, posted a 91% fall in H1 profit to S$241,000 due to Covid-19 related closures and lockdowns. Revenue declined 15% to S$43 million, with the real-estate investment division seeing a 15.7% drop. The lifestyle division, however, achieved higher sales of houses, showing resilience. Thakral plans to cut costs and return to profitability for the lifestyle division, while taking a conservative approach in Japan.

site_title: US: Wall St opens slightly lower; fresh stimulus awaited
summary: US stock indexes opened slightly lower on Thursday, awaiting the government's new stimulus package to boost the economy. The Dow Jones fell 30.70 points, or 0.11%, to 27,170.82, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite dropped 4.46 and 8.42 points, respectively, at the opening bell. Weekly jobless claims dipped slightly, providing a glimmer of economic relief. The market's focus remains on the stimulus package, which could impact the economy's recovery.

site_title: Singapore SMEs urged to consider Uttar Pradesh for overseas expansion
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are being encouraged to consider Uttar Pradesh, India as a potential destination for overseas expansion. The state offers opportunities in the automotive industry, manufacturing, and agriculture, and has a large population comparable to that of Brazil. A webinar organized by the Singapore Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SICCI) and Enterprise Singapore (ESG) aimed to raise awareness of these opportunities. Indian officials, including the cabinet minister of MSME and Export Promotion, attended the event, highlighting the potential for collaboration and investment in the region.

site_title: Resorts World Sentosa layoffs have led to 'stronger Singaporean core', says Manpower Ministry
summary: The Ministry of Manpower in Singapore reported that the layoffs at Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) have led to a stronger local core, with 75% of the remaining staff being citizens and permanent residents, up from 66% before. Most retrenched workers were foreign nationals, with some alleging discrimination. The Ministry acknowledged a small group of retrenched workers raised concerns but noted no widespread issues.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) proposes a new enforcement framework to improve swifter outcomes for enforcement actions. Local banks' shares rose despite Q2 earnings declines, driven by conservative provisions and unchanged guidance. ESR-Reit and Sabana Reit agree on an exchange ratio for a proposed merger. Sembcorp Industries and Sembmarine urge investors to vote in favor of a demerger and recapitalization. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.04% on Thursday, driven by positive updates on the Covid-19 vaccine and speculation on a US stimulus package.

site_title: F&N's 9M earnings down 8.2% on Covid-19 impact, East Malaysia flood
summary: F&N's 9-month earnings fell 8.2% to S$118 million due to lower soft drink sales in Malaysia and printing-plant closures amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The beverage segment saw a 14.2% increase in profit before interest and tax, while the dairies segment remained resilient with a 2% increase in revenue. The P&P segment posted a loss before interest and tax of S$19.4 million. F&N's gearing ratio increased to 18.9% due to higher bank borrowings.

site_title: STI closes 1.04% higher on Thursday; YZJ among top actives
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.04% to close at 2,559.10, marking its third consecutive day of gains. The index was boosted by positive updates on the Covid-19 vaccine front and speculation over the US stimulus package. Analysts from DBS Research believe the bear market has bottomed, predicting a gradual recovery. About 1.63 billion securities worth S$1.32 billion changed hands on Thursday, with gainers outnumbering losers 238 to 193.

site_title: Insurer AXA says 1b euro asset sale collapses, income slides
summary: French insurer AXA reported a 40% decline in first-half net income to 1.43 billion euros due to a 1 billion euro asset sale collapse and increased Covid-19 related claims. The company dropped its 2020 earnings target and will not make a fourth-quarter shareholder payout. Underlying earnings fell 72% to 544 million euros, largely due to business interruption contracts and event cancellations. AXA's board of directors decided not to propose an exceptional distribution of reserves to shareholders in the fourth quarter, following discussions with regulators.

site_title: AstraZeneca in first Covid-19 vaccine deal with Chinese company
summary: AstraZeneca has signed a deal with Chinese company Shenzhen Kangtai Biological Products to produce its potential Covid-19 vaccine, AZD1222, in mainland China. The deal underscores AstraZeneca's frontrunner position in the global vaccine development race and marks a significant partnership for China, which is seeking to secure access to effective vaccines. Shenzhen Kangtai must produce at least 100 million doses by the end of the year and 200 million by the end of next year, with the potential for further cooperation in other markets.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower on Thursday, closing 0.69% down to 24,930.58, amid concerns over China-US tensions and US stimulus talks. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.26%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 0.62%. The benchmark Hang Seng Index was impacted by recent gains, as investors await developments in US stimulus talks and China-US relations.

site_title: SGX RegCo proposes new enforcement framework for swifter outcomes
summary: SGX RegCo proposes a new enforcement framework to enable quicker and more forceful action against listed companies. The proposed changes include giving SGX RegCo the power to impose all public sanctions except fines, which will remain the exclusive ability of the Listings Disciplinary Committee. The proposal also requires all issuers to have a whistleblowing policy in place to protect whistleblowers within the company. The move aims to address concerns that few public enforcement actions have taken place in recent years.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher as mining, energy stocks firm
summary: Australian shares rose 0.68% to 6,042.2, driven by gains in mining and energy stocks following higher commodity and oil prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index had earlier risen 0.8% after Wall Street's gains, but pulled back after the domestic government increased its unemployment forecast due to lockdowns in Victoria. Mining stocks, including BHP and Rio Tinto, surged 2-4% while energy companies Santos and Ampol advanced 3-2%.

site_title: Sunningdale posts S$8.25m H1 net profit; lowers interim dividend to 1.8 cents
summary: Sunningdale Tech, a precision manufacturer, reported a net profit of S$8.25 million for the six months ended June, reversing a S$292,000 loss in the same period last year. Revenue fell 14.7% to S$275.1 million due to a slowdown in global automotive markets and government closures. The company lowered its interim dividend to 1.8 cents per share, down from 3 cents a year ago.

site_title: Singapore banks' shares climb despite fall in Q2 earnings
summary: Singapore banks' shares rose on Thursday despite a decline in Q2 earnings. DBS and UOB reported a 22% and 40% drop in net profit, respectively, due to higher provisions set aside. Despite this, analysts found some cheer in the banks' conservative provisions and unchanged outlook guidance. DBS's shares rose 3.38% to S$20.50, while UOB's shares rose 2.16% to S$19.84. Analysts expect the banks to maintain strong fundamentals in 2020-2021, despite weakening loan quality and profitability.

site_title: Singapore likely to rebound from recession, achieve 7% GDP growth in 2021: report
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to rebound from a recession in 2021 with a 7% GDP growth, according to a report by the Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (Amro). The country's growth will recover in the second half of 2020, driven by the manufacturing and financial services sectors, while tourism and hospitality will continue to suffer. The region's economy is expected to slow sharply this year to 0.1% but rebound strongly to 6% in 2021, led by China's strong recovery.

site_title: Uber pulls Latin American U-turn by joining taxi ranks
summary: Uber is adapting to Latin America's coronavirus crisis by joining taxi ranks in several countries, including Chile, Colombia, and Brazil. The move comes as the ride-hailing company faces regulatory challenges and competition from Didi, its Chinese rival. Uber has launched a taxi service in Chile and plans to do the same in Sao Paulo, Brazil, and is considering expanding to Mexico. The shift may indicate that Uber needs to adapt its model to local markets, and both Uber and Didi are looking to Latin America as a key growth area.

site_title: Credit Agricole sees provisions rise as Covid hits big clients
summary: Credit Agricole, a French bank, set aside more than expected provisions for souring loans in the second quarter due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on its retail clients and large corporate customers. Provisions rose to 842 million euros, beating estimates. Revenue was in line with estimates, while net income was better than expected. The bank's capital markets and investment banking division saw revenue climb 38% due to a 44% increase in fixed income business. CEO Philippe Brassac said the bank emerged unharmed from a disruptive quarter, having massively supported its customers.

site_title: Penguin posts 53.2% drop in H1 earnings amid Covid-19, weak oil prices
summary: Penguin International, a high-speed aluminium craft builder, reported a 53.2% drop in H1 earnings to S$3.9 million due to the Covid-19 pandemic and weak oil prices. Revenue fell 26.1% to S$50.1 million, with gross profit decreasing 32.9% to S$12.6 million. The company built six new vessels in H1, but operating conditions remain tough, with demand for new vessels weakening and crewboat charter rates falling. Penguin has halted or slowed down some uncommitted build-for-stock vessels and obtained a S$5 million unsecured term loan to conserve cash.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit highest close in nearly 2 years
summary: South Korean stocks reached a near two-year high, closing at 2,342.61, driven by strong corporate earnings and hopes for US stimulus. The Kospi index rose 1.33% after a four-day winning streak led by Samsung Electronics. Foreigners invested $136.86 million in shares, and concerns about a stalling global economy led to increased calls for fiscal aid. This boost in investor sentiment has fueled the rally, despite ongoing uncertainty from US trade policies.

site_title: Japan stocks fall on grim earnings season; Toyota bucks trend
summary: Japan's Nikkei index fell 0.43% to 22,418.15, while the Topix index dropped 0.31% to 1,549.88, due to a downbeat earnings season amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Toyota Motor Corp rose 2.29% after avoiding a loss in the last quarter, bucking the trend. Analysts say the decline in corporate profits may have bottomed out, with some expecting gradual earnings recovery.

site_title: Hong Kong close to picking winner to digitise pension system
summary: Hong Kong is close to selecting a winner to digitize its pension system, which could benefit over 4 million savers by lowering fees. Two finalists, a consortium led by Ping An Insurance Group and a group led by Hong Kong billionaire Richard Li's PCCW, are vying for the contract. The goal is to create an electronic platform by 2022, centralizing data and making it easier for people to consolidate accounts and switch plans. The winner could reap around HK$37 billion in revenue over the next decade.

site_title: New portal to help Singapore SMEs navigate government support schemes
summary: A new business portal is set to launch in Singapore on August 11 to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) navigate government support schemes. The portal aims to aid SMEs in weathering the Covid-19 pandemic and seize new opportunities. Minister of State for the Ministry of Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling announced the launch, noting that SMEs have faced difficulties in accessing the various support schemes. The portal is expected to provide a one-stop solution for SMEs to find the right government support for their needs.

site_title: HDB resale volume in July highest in two years
summary: Singapore's HDB resale market saw its highest volume in two years in July, with 2,470 flats sold, a 0.7% increase from June. Prices rose 0.4% to 132.9 on the resale price index. Analysts attribute the surge to pent-up demand during the "circuit-breaker" period and the end of the minimum occupation period for newer flats. Predictions suggest a gradual increase in resale prices, with potential gains of 0.6-1.2% by the end of the year.

site_title: US dollar gains as appetite for risk subsides
summary: The US dollar gained against a basket of currencies, reaching a two-year high, as appetite for risk decreased in London. This followed a record high in US service industry orders but a decline in hiring, indicating a faltering labor market recovery. Analysts attribute the dollar's gain to positive news and a decrease in risk aversion, but warn that the damage to the US dollar's role as a safe haven has been significant. Markets are now focused on US jobs data and fiscal aid negotiations, with lawmakers yet to agree on a new package of government support.

images.alt_text: The US dollar gained as appetite for risk dwindled in London early on Thursday, as markets waited for US jobs data and updates about fiscal aid negotiations in Washington.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS raises Riverstone's target price, citing 'strong surge in margins'
summary: DBS Group Research has raised its target price on Malaysian glove maker Riverstone Holdings to S$5.51, citing strong surge in margins. The brokerage firm maintained its "buy" call on the counter, citing stellar H1 2020 results, higher average selling prices, and improved margins. DBS analysts expect Riverstone's earnings to grow 10% in 2020 and 13% in 2021, driven by a spike in global demand for healthcare examination gloves and clean-room gloves.

site_title: Temasek unit Dornier MedTech launches urology community platform
summary: Dornier MedTech, a unit of Singapore's Temasek Holdings, is launching UroX, a community platform to connect talents, technologies, and funding to solve urology problems. The platform, UroX, aims to innovate and address pressing urology challenges. Two initiatives will be rolled out: the UroXChallenge, offering up to S$500,000 in funding, and UroChange, a series of webinars and events with renowned urology experts. The goal is to bring more creative treatment options to benefit patients and physicians.

site_title: Jeff Bezos sells US$3.1b of Amazon shares after wealth jumps
summary: Jeff Bezos, Amazon's CEO, sold $3.1 billion worth of shares, adding to his earlier $4.1 billion sale, amid a surge in Amazon's stock value due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Bezos' net worth has increased by $74.9 billion this year, making him worth $189.8 billion. His wealth is now $70 billion ahead of Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates, and he's on the cusp of another record: a fortune exceeding $200 billion. The sale comes as Bezos testified before Congress, alongside other tech CEOs, about the industry's power and influence.

site_title: Thailand picks ex-banker as finance chief to fight crisis
summary: Thailand has appointed Preede Daochai, a former co-president of Kasikornbank, as its new finance minister to help combat the country's worst recession in its history. The move comes as the nation faces an 8.5% contraction in gross domestic product. The new finance minister, along with newly appointed central bank governor Sethaput Suthiwart-Narueput, and deputy prime ministers Supattanapong Punmeechaow and Don Pramudwinai, will shape the government's response to the pandemic-driven recession. The reshuffle is part of a wider Cabinet reshuffle aimed at addressing Thailand's economic challenges.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades Hutchison Port Holdings Trust to 'buy' on attractive dividend yield
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust) to "buy" from "hold" due to its attractive 11.3% dividend yield. The research team raised its target price to US$0.14 from US$0.12, citing improved earnings forecasts. The end of the trust's debt repayment program in 2021 may allow for higher dividends. DBS also raised its fiscal 2020 forecast for the trust's dividend payout to 9 Hong Kong cents.

site_title: US sends first shipment of crude to Saudi Arabia in over a decade
summary: The US has sent its first shipment of crude oil to Saudi Arabia in over a decade, according to US Census data. The shipment, approximately 550,000 barrels, was sent in June, a move that has not been recorded by the US Energy Information Administration. This is a significant development, as US crude exports have surged since Washington lifted a ban in 2015, averaging 2.75 million barrels per day in June. The shipment may have been part of another shipment headed to a different country, but it marks a rare instance of US crude exports to Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: European stock markets dropped at the open on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 1.1% to 6,035.95 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also declining 0.1% and 0.6% respectively. The Bank of England froze its interest rate, contributing to the downturn.

site_title: TikTok to open its first European data centre in Ireland
summary: TikTok plans to open its first European data centre in Ireland, investing approximately 420 million euros, to store European user data safely and create hundreds of new jobs. The move comes amid US President Donald Trump's threat to ban the service in the US if it doesn't sell its US operations. The data centre, expected to be operational by early 2022, will enable faster loading times and align with Ireland's status as a major European data centre hub.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollar bulls take a breather on poor economic news
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars retreated from multi-month highs amid negative economic news from Australia and New Zealand. The Aussie dollar fell to US$0.7190, while the kiwi dollar remained at US$0.6632. Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's lockdown announcement in Victoria state is expected to cut A$10-12 billion from national GDP and increase borrowing needs. The Reserve Bank of Australia has resumed buying government debt to keep yields down.

site_title: Gold steadies near record high as US dollar stumbles
summary: Gold prices held steady near record highs on Thursday, steady at US$2,039.75 per ounce, as a weaker US dollar and hopes of more stimulus measures underpinned the metal's safe-haven appeal. This follows an all-time high of US$2,055.10 on Wednesday. The US dollar stumbled, providing support to gold prices.

site_title: Toyota's Q1 profit nearly wiped out as coronavirus erodes car sales
summary: Toyota Motor Corp reported a 98% plunge in Q1 operating profit to 13.9 billion yen due to the coronavirus pandemic, which halved global sales. This is the company's worst profit since 2011. Despite this, Toyota maintained its annual operating profit forecast of 500 billion yen, its weakest in nine years. The company expects a 13% drop in global car sales to March 2021.

site_title: Credit Agricole seeks to reclaim technology it developed with Wirecard
summary: French bank Credit Agricole plans to reclaim technology it developed with Wirecard, a German payments firm that filed for insolvency in June due to a 1.9 billion euro global fraud. The partnership aimed to facilitate online payments for merchants. Credit Agricole CEO Philippe Brassac stated that the bank will try to get back something related to its development, with a focus on reclaiming at least what was developed by Wirecard. This move comes after Credit Agricole reported a 22% drop in quarterly profit.

site_title: Chasen posts Q1 net profit of S$257,000, sees recovery across business segments
summary: Chasen Holdings, a logistics firm, reported a 9% decline in profit after tax to S$257,000 for Q1, down from S$282,000 in the previous year. The company attributed the decline to the COVID-19 pandemic, citing new business from its third-party logistics segment and government grants in its operating countries. Despite the decline, Chasen expects a recovery across its business segments.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders weigh stimulus, China-US tension
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday as traders weighed the outcome of US stimulus talks and China-US tensions. Despite a two-day rally, investors remained cautious due to the rapid spread of the pandemic and concerns over a potential trade war. The US added below-forecast jobs in July, while China-US tensions continued to escalate. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, but the region's markets were affected by the uncertainty, with Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Shanghai experiencing declines.

site_title: FSL Trust announces sale of three ships, following Q2 profit decline
summary: FSL Trust has announced the sale of three containerships, FSL Eminence, FSL Elixir, and YM Enhancer, to unaffiliated third parties. The vessels, each with a capacity of 4,250 TEU, were owned by FSL Trust since 2008 and are expected to be delivered to their buyers as soon as practically possible. The sale follows a 34.7% decline in FSL Trust's net profit to US$1.33 million for Q2 FY2020, primarily due to an 11% fall in revenue to US$14.5 million.

site_title: Siemens beats forecasts for industrial profit
summary: Siemens posted an 8% increase in adjusted industrial profit for the third quarter, beating analyst forecasts, despite falling orders and revenue. The company's industrial business saw an operating profit boost due to an accounting gain and cost savings. Siemens' industrial profit rose to 1.79 billion euros, surpassing the expected 1.17 billion euros. The company's industrial business weathered the effects of the coronavirus pandemic, with Siemens citing cost-saving measures and an accounting gain as key factors in its success.

site_title: Blackstone to acquire Ancestry.com for US$4.7b; GIC retains stake
summary: Blackstone Group agreed to acquire genealogy provider Ancestry.com for US$4.7 billion, including debt, as part of a bet on the growing interest in family-tree chasing and personalized medicine during the pandemic.
