Ancestry.com, the world's largest DNA services provider, has over three million paying customers and earns more than US$1 billion in annual revenue. Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC will retain a significant minority stake in the company after the deal, marking a significant jump in valuation from four years ago.

site_title: Australia's Victoria state reports 471 new coronavirus cases
summary: Australia's Victoria state reported 471 new coronavirus cases, with eight deaths in the last 24 hours, marking its deadliest day of the pandemic. This surpasses the previous day's record of 725 cases.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS says Singapore property plays 'too cheap to ignore' amid attractive valuations
summary: DBS Group Research has called Singapore's property developers "too cheap to ignore" due to attractive valuations. The research team cites well-equipped and capitalized developers capable of overcoming near-term operational headwinds. DBS's stock picks include CapitaLand and City Developments Limited, with "buy" ratings and target prices of S$3.70 and S$10.50 respectively. Analysts believe implied valuations have priced in a 10-15% portfolio deterioration, unlikely given low interest rates, and that most developers have turned their inventory quickly, limiting exposures.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks track Wall St higher, won strengthens to 5-month high
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1.2% on Thursday, tracking gains on Wall Street, with the Kospi index gaining 28.67 points to a 5-month high. The won strengthened to a 5-month high against the US dollar, while benchmark bond yields edged up. Hyundai Motor Co shares soared 7.8% on upbeat July sales and hopes of higher electric vehicle sales. Foreigners were net buyers of 39.5 billion won worth of shares, and the MSCI's Asia-Pacific index rose 0.31%.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality to open Tokyo serviced residence on Aug 7
summary: Frasers Hospitality is set to open its 22-storey serviced residence, Fraser Suites Akasaka, in Tokyo on August 7. Located in the central business district, the 224-room property is surrounded by major corporations, embassies, and the Tokyo Broadcasting System Television building. Despite the Covid-19 pandemic, Tokyo remains a key gateway city for business, and Frasers Hospitality is adapting to changes in travel advisories. The serviced residence features larger rooms with unobstructed views of the Tokyo skyline and offers facilities such as a gym, restaurant, and golf simulator.

images.alt_text: The 224-room property is located in Tokyo's central business district.

site_title: US plan for 'highest level' Taiwan visit in decades angers China
summary: The US announced its highest-level visit to Taiwan in decades, with Health Chief Alex Azar set to meet President Tsai Ing-wen. The visit, which has angered China, comes as relations between the US and China plunge to historic lows. Beijing views Taiwan as its own territory and has vowed to one day seize it, calling for the US to cancel the visit. The visit is seen as a move to recognize Taiwan's successful handling of the coronavirus pandemic and its democratic governance, but is likely to further strain relations with China.

site_title: Philippine economy dives into recession in worst slump on record
summary: The Philippine economy contracted by 16.5% in the second quarter, entering recession for the first time in 29 years, due to the world's longest and strictest coronavirus lockdown. This is the largest quarterly GDP decline since 1981. The economic downturn is expected to worsen with the reimposition of quarantine controls, leading to record-high unemployment and subdued inflation. The central bank has room for policy easing if needed, having already slashed interest rates to a record-low 2.25%.

images.alt_text: ING Bank and UN children's agency UNICEF have launched an initiativein the Philippines called 'Fintech for Impact' to support start-ups developing digital solutions that aim to empower young people, children and families.

site_title: Levi CEO hunts for good lease deals to add stores amid pandemic
summary: Levi Strauss & Co CEO Chip Bergh is seeking opportunities to add branded stores amid the pandemic, accelerating the company's lease renegotiation timeline. The health crisis has shaved off over $1 billion from the company's sales expectations for 2020, now predicting $4.1 billion in revenue. Bergh sees the crisis as a chance to expand, despite a dramatically shifted retail industry with shoppers prioritizing groceries and household staples over apparel. The company is also considering store closures in areas with high Covid-19 cases and re-evaluating its holiday season strategy.

site_title: Shift to impact investing for real change and returns
summary: Investors are shifting towards impact investing, a style of investing that aims to generate both financial returns and positive social and environmental impact. Traditional sustainable investing, which focuses on ESG (environmental, social, and corporate governance) factors, may not truly prioritize impact. To address this, impact investing measures outcomes and considers measurable positive effects alongside financial returns. Investment managers are encouraged to use impact accounting frameworks, such as the Impact Management Project (IMP) framework, which simplifies the evaluation process and provides a more manageable approach for startups and investors alike.

site_title: Australia: Shares advance as miners, Wall Street surge
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to 6,041.5, tracking Wall Street's gains after strong corporate earnings and US stimulus hopes. Domestic miners, including BHP and Rio Tinto, surged to their highest in over 9 years as commodity prices strengthened. Energy stocks also rose, driven by oil prices hitting a five-month high. The gains came despite the Covid-19 crisis deepening in Australia, with Victoria reporting a record 15 deaths.

site_title: JustCo opening two more co-working centres in Singapore with total capacity of 2,000
summary: JUSTCo is set to open two new co-working centres in Singapore, OCBC Centre East and The Centrepoint, with a combined capacity of 2,000 members. Global enterprises L'Oreal, Riot Games, and foodpanda will occupy approximately 300 employees at these spaces, with L'Oreal housing its Asia-Pacific team for travel retail at OCBC Centre East. The new centres are expected to open in August and October, respectively.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, down 0.25% or 56.11 points at 22,458.74, as investors digested US economic indicators, vaccine news, and earnings reports. The broader Topix index slipped 0.33% or 5.08 points to 1,549.63. This follows a rally on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Pompeo offers US$10m reward over election interference
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced a $10 million reward for information leading to the identification or location of individuals who interfere with US elections, acting at the direction or under control of a foreign government. This comes amid concerns of election interference, particularly from Russia, which was accused of meddling in the 2016 US election. Pompeo's statement follows previous intelligence findings that suggest Russia and other US adversaries may attempt to interfere in the November elections.

site_title: Trump says he would be in favour of helping US airlines
summary: President Donald Trump expressed support for US$25 billion payroll assistance for US airlines financially devastated by the coronavirus pandemic. Trump stated he would be in favour of helping the airlines, regardless of their party affiliation. This comes after a group of Senate Republicans backed the payroll assistance plan.

site_title: KS Energy CEO Kris Wiluan faces 112 charges for alleged false trading, market rigging
summary: KS Energy CEO Kris Taenar Wiluan faces 112 charges related to false trading and market rigging, allegedly directed by Wiluan to manipulate the company's share price between 2014 and 2016. The charges are under Section 197 of the Securities and Futures Act in Singapore.

site_title: Asean+3 growth tipped to slow sharply to zero in 2020 before rebounding strongly to 6% in 2021: AMRO
summary: Asean+3 economic growth is expected to sharply slow to zero in 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, but rebound strongly to 6% in 2021, according to an updated forecast by AMRO. This marks a significant shift from the previous outlook in April, which projected 2.2% growth in 2020 and 5.5% in 2021. The pandemic's impact on the global economy has cast a long and uncertain shadow over the region's growth prospects.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.8% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 2,552.66. Despite lower Q2 earnings from local lenders DBS and UOB, the market saw gains from other counters, including Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin higher on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading higher on Thursday, boosted by hopes of a COVID-19 vaccine and optimism over a potential US stimulus deal. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.39%, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.09%. The gains came despite US President Trump's latest threats to extend market volatility.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks opened on a positive note on Thursday boosted by vaccine hopes, while there was still optimism US lawmakers would hammer out a stimulus deal.

site_title: DBS says moratoria still masking Covid-19 damage; Q2 net profit down 22%
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, reported a 22% fall in second-quarter net profit to S$1.25 billion due to provisions and flat total income. The bank's chief, Piyush Gupta, expects top line and net interest margin to deteriorate over the rest of the year due to interest rate cuts. Moratoriums are masking the true damage brought by Covid-19, and the bank is building up its general provisions. DBS maintained its guidance for the rest of the year, with full-year profit before allowances expected to be around 2019 levels.

site_title: ESR-Reit will not raise offer price for Sabana in proposed merger
summary: ESR-REIT has confirmed that its proposed merger with Sabana Reit will proceed with a fixed exchange ratio of 0.940 ESR-Reit units per Sabana Reit unit. The company's manager will not increase the scheme consideration in any way, except in a competitive situation, where it reserves the right to do so. The final offer price remains unchanged, and the merger is expected to proceed as planned.

site_title: US adds 1,242 Covid-19 deaths in 24 hours: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US reported 1,262 new Covid-19 deaths and 53,158 cases in the 24 hours ending August 6, bringing the total deaths to 157,930 and cases to 4,818,328. The US is the worst-hit country, surpassing half a million cases in Florida and over 500 inmates testing positive in an Arizona jail. Despite the surge, President Trump remains optimistic, stating that the virus will "go away like things go away."

site_title: Sembcorp, Sembmarine urge investors to vote in favour of demerger
summary: Sembcorp Industries and Sembmarine are urging investors to vote in favor of a proposed S$2.1 billion recapitalization and demerger. The demerger will result in Temasek Holdings having a direct stake in the marine arm. Shareholders will vote on three inter-conditional resolutions at an EGM on Aug 11, including distributing SMM shares in specie, undertaking a rights issue, and waiving investors' rights to receive a mandatory takeover offer from Temasek. A simple majority is required for all three resolutions.

site_title: Bank of England set to sit tight on Covid-19 stimulus for now
summary: The Bank of England is expected to keep its benchmark interest rate at 0.1% and its bond-buying stimulus program unchanged at £745 billion. The central bank will monitor the economy's slowdown and consider taking borrowing costs below zero. The decision comes as the UK economy faces a surge in unemployment, with the Monetary Policy Committee set to review its outlook and bond purchases. The Bank of England is waiting to see the full extent of the economic impact of the pandemic before making further moves.

site_title: New York prosecutors subpoenaed Deutsche Bank in Trump probe: NYT
summary: Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance subpoenaed Deutsche Bank, Donald Trump's longtime lender, in a criminal investigation into Trump's business practices. The subpoena, issued last year, sought financial records, and the bank complied by providing detailed records. Vance's investigation, sparked by hush payments to women claiming Trump had affairs, now appears to be examining "possibly extensive and protracted criminal conduct" at the Trump Organization, including insurance and bank fraud. The scope of the probe has been raised, posing a serious legal threat to Trump and his business.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, up 11.39 points or 0.73% to 1,579.52. The index saw 901.07 million lots traded worth RM368.77 million, with gainers beating losers 505 to 64.

site_title: Alibaba Pictures plans to delist from SGX on Dec 4
summary: Alibaba Pictures Group, a Chinese film company, plans to delist from the Singapore Exchange's mainboard on December 4, 2020. The last day of trading will be November 11, and shares will be suspended on November 12. After delisting, the company's shares will only be publicly traded on the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong, citing a lower trading volume in Singapore. The company cited its Hong Kong listing as being "more geographically aligned" with its mainland China business operations. The Singapore Exchange gave the go-ahead for the delisting on June 18.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, UOB, Wilmar, Sembcorp, Sembmarine, Singtel
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Several Singaporean companies reported significant changes in their financial performance, including DBS (-22% net profit drop) and UOB (-40% net profit drop). Wilmar International acquired a former Coca-Cola bottling plant for S$29.5 million. Sembcorp Industries and Sembmarine are urging investors to vote in favor of a demerger to address liquidity needs. Singtel announced a cloud business partnership with Bharti Airtel and Amazon Web Services. Other companies, such as NetLink NBN Trust and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, also reported significant changes in their financial performance. Trading halts were also requested by Tuan Sing Holdings and QAF.

site_title: Singapore Medical Group H1 profit nearly halves to S$3.5m on lower revenue
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) reported a 49.5% drop in net profit to S$3.5 million for the first six months of 2020, due to lower revenue and gross profit. Revenue fell 12.8% to S$38.9 million, mainly due to deferred non-essential medical services and travel restrictions. Gross profit decreased 23.1% to S$15.9 million. Despite the challenges, SMG's business operations showed resilience, and the company remains confident in emerging from the pandemic as a stronger organization.

site_title: Asean-6 online spending to hit US$150b by 2025, driven by Covid-19: Report
summary: Asean-6 countries are expected to reach $150 billion in online spending by 2025, driven by the COVID-19 pandemic. The average per-consumer spend is projected to triple from $124 in 2018 to $429, with Indonesia accounting for half of the region's online retail value. The shift to online habits has accelerated, with 310 million consumers making online purchases this year, up from 250 million in 2018. Tech firms are advised to adapt to the new norm by investing in omnichannel strategies and recognizing the rise of insurgent brands.

site_title: Australia to spend A$1.66b on cyber security for private sector after rise in attacks
summary: Australia plans to spend A$1.66 billion over 10 years to enhance cyber security for private companies and households, following a rise in cyber attacks. These attacks cost around A$29 billion, or 1.5% of the country's GDP. The new package aims to bolster the defenses of critical infrastructure, support businesses, and boost community awareness. Additionally, Australia will increase funding for the Australian Signals Directorate to counter foreign cyber attacks, following a previously determined link between China and a 2019 parliament attack.

images.alt_text: Cyber attacks on businesses and households are costing about A$29 billion or 1.5 per cent of the country's Gross Domestic Product, according to Mr Morrison's prepared remarks seen by Reuters.

site_title: Japan marks 75th anniversary of Hiroshima atomic bomb
summary: Japan marked the 75th anniversary of the Hiroshima atomic bombing on August 5, 2020, with a scaled-back ceremony due to the coronavirus pandemic. Survivors, relatives, and foreign dignitaries attended the event, which included a silent prayer and a livestream tour of affected buildings. The ceremony aimed to promote world peace and honor the victims of the bombings, which killed around 140,000 people in 1945. The event highlights the dwindling number of bomb survivors, known as "hibakusha," and the need for global action against nuclear weapons.

site_title: Fulham win play-off, returns to EPL
summary: Fulham won the English Premier League play-off final against Brentford 2-1 in extra time, earning a £135 million return to the EPL. Defender Joe Bryan scored two goals, including a late winner in the 105th minute, after the match ended 0-0 at the end of regular time. The victory marks Fulham's return to the top division after a 73-year absence, while Brentford finishes third in the English Championship, just shy of automatic promotion.

site_title: CSE Global's H1 earnings rise 47.7% on contributions from newly-acquired units
summary: CSE Global, a tech-solutions provider, reported a 47.7% rise in H1 earnings to S$15.1 million, driven by contributions from newly-acquired units in the US and Australia. Revenue rose 39.1% to S$255.6 million, with income from the Americas and Asia-Pacific growing 51.7% and 21.6% respectively. The company declared an interim dividend of 1.25 cents per share and maintained a net-debt position, despite higher staff costs and expenses.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends at another record as stocks extend rally
summary: US stocks ended at record highs, with the Nasdaq rising 0.5% to 10,998.40, its third consecutive record close. The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 1.4% and the S&P 500 gained 0.6% despite disappointing employment data. Optimism over potential fiscal support and positive vaccine news boosted shares, with Johnson & Johnson and Disney rising. Airline shares also rallied after 16 Republican Senators backed payroll assistance funding.

site_title: 1MDB scandal fugitives hiding in China: Malaysian police
summary: Malaysian police believe alleged 1MDB mastermind Najib Razak and other suspects are hiding in China, urging Chinese authorities to help hunt them down. The scandal, which involved billions stolen from a sovereign wealth fund, led to Najib's conviction in 2018 and his loss of power. Other suspects remain at large, with authorities seizing RM3 billion of assets linked to suspect Daim Zainuddin.

site_title: Reflections on Singapore heritage food
summary: Singaporeans often associate National Day with food, particularly heritage dishes like chicken rice and bak chor mee. However, with a new generation of chefs, there's a debate about whether heritage cuisine should stay rooted in the past or evolve. Meanwhile, local designers have created unique, stylish merchandise, such as shoulder bags and mahogany dining tables, showcasing the sophistication of Singaporean design. Two chefs have also opened new eateries serving traditional Hakka and Chinese dishes, offering a taste of heritage hawker fare.

site_title: US wants to eliminate Chinese apps from US app stores
summary: The US is expanding its Clean Network programme to ban untrusted Chinese apps from US app stores and block American-made apps from being pre-installed on Chinese-made phones and equipment. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo claims these apps pose security risks and are used for CCP content censorship. The US also aims to limit Chinese service providers' ability to collect and process sensitive data in the US. The move targets Chinese tech giants Alibaba, Baidu, and Tencent, following President Trump's warning to sell TikTok to an American company or face shutdown.

site_title: New relief fund and pledge of 1,000 jobs extended to hospitality and F&B workers
summary: Singapore-based Park Hotel Group and YMCA of Singapore, along with home-services company Helpling, have launched a relief fund and pledged 1,000 jobs for hospitality and F&B workers affected by the coronavirus pandemic. The Uplift Fund, with an initial S$500,000 contribution, aims to raise S$3 million to provide one-time relief sums of S$500 to S$1,000 to eligible applicants. Helpling has also pledged to train and hire 1,000 workers, offering them roles as full-time home-cleaning and hygiene specialists with wages up to S$3,000 a month.

site_title: Biden, Trump scramble to replan nomination speeches
summary: US President Donald Trump and challenger Joe Biden are scrambling to replan their nomination speeches amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Biden will deliver his speech virtually from his Delaware home, while Trump has suggested holding his acceptance ceremony at the White House, breaking with presidential decorum. Trump's campaign is struggling with a badly wounded economy and surging pandemic, and his reelection bid is seen as increasingly uncertain, with some experts predicting Biden's victory.

site_title: London rents expected to slump to six-year low
summary: London rents are expected to drop to a six-year low, with a 3-5% decline predicted by the end of the year. The slow reopening of the economy and shift to remote work have reduced demand, and the prospect of a fresh lockdown further clouds the UK economy's outlook. Some areas of central London are seeing steeper declines, with landlords flooding the market with previously short-term visitor properties. This uncertainty will impact demand in some markets for the rest of the year, according to Zoopla's head of research.

site_title: UOB starts restructure work for debts paused on payments; Q2 profit down 40%
summary: UOB, a Singaporean bank, has set up restructuring teams to assess borrowers who have taken a debt holiday amid the gradual unwinding of government relief measures. The bank's second-quarter net profit dropped 40% to S$703 million, hurt by weaker income and a surge in provisions set aside for loan moratoria. Credit costs rose to 67 basis points, and the bank expects credit losses to be spread out over two financial years. Despite the challenges, UOB's regulatory loss allowance reserve rose slightly, and the bank projects that about 10-15% of loans under moratoria may sour into bad debt.

site_title: Competition panel concludes probe after GrabFood, Deliveroo act on complaint
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has concluded an investigation into the online food delivery and virtual kitchen sectors after a cloud kitchen operator complained that GrabFood and Deliveroo were excluding its merchants. The probe began in September 2019 amid industry tensions. No specific conclusions or penalties were mentioned in the statement, but the CCCS is now saying the investigation is complete.

site_title: Oil prices fall as jump in Covid-19 cases stokes fuel demand fears
summary: Oil prices fell for the first time in four days, dropping 16 cents to $44.27 a barrel for Brent crude and 17 cents to $41.53 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate. The decline was attributed to rising COVID-19 cases worldwide and in the US, which reduced market confidence in a pickup in fuel demand. Despite a slight increase in US factory data, traders were cautious due to concerns about the impact of the pandemic on the energy market.

site_title: Brazil cuts interest rate to new low as virus rages
summary: Brazil's central bank cut the benchmark interest rate to 2% from 2.25%, its lowest level since 1998, in an effort to stimulate the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic. The move aims to boost growth and inflation control. The bank also left room for a potential second cut in the easing cycle, which has reduced the rate from 6.5% in June 2019.

site_title: Samsung upgrades folding smartphone in move to rev up sales
summary: Samsung unveiled its second-generation folding smartphone, the Galaxy Z Fold2, along with other new gadgets, aiming to boost sales in a market hit by the pandemic. The device features a 15.7cm cover screen and a 19.3cm main screen, and is "completely re-engineered for greater durability." Pricing and availability were not disclosed, but the Galaxy Note20 will be available in the US later this month starting at $999.99. The move comes as Samsung faces declining smartphone sales, with the company losing market share to Huawei.

images.alt_text: Samsung on Wednesday unveiled a second-generation folding smartphone along with other new gadgetry aiming to jump-start sales in a market hit hard by the global pandemic.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close higher as commodities shares rally
summary: European stocks rose 0.5% on Wednesday, driven by gains in mining and oil shares, with London's FTSE 100 and Germany's DAX indices up 1.1% and 0.5% respectively. Positive earnings reports from companies like Deutsche Post AG and Vonovia also contributed to the rally. Despite concerns over surging coronavirus cases and worsening US-China diplomatic ties, investors focused on the return to modest growth in the euro zone and a rebound in retail sales.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The Central Depository (CDP) in Singapore has been fined S$32,000 for mailing dividend cheques to outdated addresses, putting 200 account holders at risk of having their personal data disclosed. The incident occurred last year. The incident is a result of CDP's failure to update its records.

site_title: Najib's conviction may be a chance for Malaysia to finally move on
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak was sentenced to 12 years in jail and a fine of RM210 million for abuse of power and money laundering. The conviction may give Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin a chance to strengthen his government by distancing himself from Umno's corruption and promoting a more progressive party. Muhyiddin's coalition, Pakatan Harapan, had previously relied on Malay-based parties to secure rural votes, but Najib's conviction could weaken Umno's hold on these voters. With Najib planning to appeal, Muhyiddin may use the time to foment internal strife within Umno and consolidate his own position.

site_title: Online retail sales spike points to sustained structural shift
summary: Singapore's retail sector experienced a month-on-month rebound in June, with sales growing 51.1% on a seasonally adjusted basis, driven by a low base from store closures in May. However, overall sales still declined 27.8% year-on-year, with online sales making up 18.1% of total retail sales. Experts predict sustained structural shifts in shopping behavior, with online sales expected to remain elevated despite a return to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: New Ford CEO Farley eyes expansion into tech fields
summary: New Ford CEO Jim Farley plans to expand the automaker's operations into related technology fields, including software, fleet management, and electric vehicle charging. Farley aims to create new growth initiatives that could create value for the company. Amid the coronavirus crisis, Ford must tackle restructuring of its global operations, saddled with large amounts of debt, and navigate a painful restructuring process. Farley will work alongside outgoing CEO Jim Hackett during a two-month transition period.

site_title: Hiroshima 75 years on
summary: Hiroshima marks 75 years since the atomic bombing on August 6, 1945, which killed over 140,000 residents and left survivors, known as hibakusha, with lasting trauma. KEIKO Ogura and Mitsuo Kodama, two of the few survivors, share their experiences of witnessing devastation and loss. Despite the city's destruction, Hiroshima has been rebuilt and now serves as a peaceful memorial park, highlighting the need for a world free of nuclear weapons and mass destruction.

site_title: Newbie Simply Sakal bags management contract for 843-unit Siglap condo
summary: Sakal Real Estate Partners, a 27-month-old residential management-services company, has secured a major contract to manage the 843-unit Seaside Residences in Siglap, Singapore. The contract is part of Sakal's strategy to disrupt the traditional, labor-intensive management sector by leveraging technology for timely responses to estate management issues. With this win, Sakal aims to reduce its clients' overall management expenditure by 25% and expand its staff to 40 by year-end, with revenues expected to triple within a quarter.

site_title: Disney's 'Mulan' to skip most movie theatres for streaming
summary: Walt Disney's live-action 'Mulan' will bypass most movie theaters and directly release on the company's streaming platform in September. US subscribers to Disney+ will pay $30 to stream the film, with varying prices in other countries. The decision comes amid uncertainty over US movie theater reopenings due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: India woos companies that are leaving China
summary: India is attracting global companies fleeing China due to rising labor costs and supply line disruptions caused by the pandemic. The German footwear brand Von Wellx is moving its entire production from China to India, creating over 10,000 jobs. The move is seen as a success for India's efforts to woo companies leaving China. This marks an early example of India's push to capitalize on the migration, with the Indian government collaborating with Von Wellx to set up a factory in Agra, Uttar Pradesh state.

site_title: PhillipCapital dubs Koufu 'best in class', sees move to new facility as major catalyst
summary: PhillipCapital initiated coverage on Koufu Group with a "buy" recommendation, citing its "best in class" defensive business model and superior growth profile. The brokerage forecasts strong free cash flow and high return on equity, with a target price of 80 Singapore cents. Koufu's move to a new facility is seen as a major catalyst, expected to accrue cost savings through improved productivity and operational efficiency. The firm also estimates a potential special dividend from the sale of existing central kitchen properties.

site_title: STI closes 0.68% higher with bank earnings in the spotlight
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.68% on Wednesday, driven by hopes of US fiscal stimulus and capital inflows into treasuries and gold. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,532.69, with Venture Corp and Yanlord Land leading the gains. Bank earnings will be in focus this week, with DBS Group and United Overseas Bank reporting earnings on Thursday.

site_title: Oil prices hit 5-month high as US crude stockpiles, dollar fall
summary: Oil prices rose to a 5-month high on Wednesday, driven by a decline in US crude inventories and a weaker dollar. Brent crude jumped 1.7% to $45.17 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate oil rose 1.2% to $42.19 a barrel. The dollar's decline made oil cheaper for foreign holders, while progress in US coronavirus relief talks also supported prices. However, rising coronavirus cases threaten fuel demand recovery, with global consumption expected to decline by 7% year-on-year through Q3.

site_title: SORA benchmark gets teeth against financial misconduct
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has prescribed the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (SORA) as a financial benchmark under the Securities and Futures Act, aiming to enhance market confidence and integrity. The move follows the industry-led transition from the Swap Offer Rate (SOR) to SORA, a more robust and suitable benchmark for Singapore dollar (SGD) financial markets. MAS will also enhance transparency and data availability, including the issuance of SORA-based floating rate notes and the publication of daily statistics and a SORA Index.

site_title: We need a monument to the unknown America
summary: A memorial to the "Unknown God" in Rome's Palatine Museum serves as a thought-provoking example of the power of memorialization. The altar, dedicated to Agnostos Theos, or the "Unknown God," presents a striking contrast to traditional depictions of deities, symbolizing the blessing of absence and the sacralization of nothingness. This concept has implications for discussions on memorials and statues, as they often represent an argument, rather than an ambivalent one, and can be seen as a form of pragmatic hedge-betting for deities that have escaped attention.

site_title: Borrowers in Malaysia can tap targeted relief from Oct 1: report
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, plans to extend targeted relief to borrowers after a blanket moratorium expires on September 30. This move could benefit more than 3 million individuals and businesses in need, with economists predicting that labour market strains and uncertain economic recovery could lead to additional eligibility. The relief is expected to be available from October 1.

site_title: NetLink logs 12.4% rise in Q1 net profit despite labour constraints
summary: NetLink NBN Trust reported a 12.4% increase in Q1 net profit to S$23.5 million, despite a 3.3% decline in revenue due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Installation revenue fell by S$4.7 million, while diversion revenue declined by S$900,000. Ebitda rose 3.4% to S$68.8 million, and net operating cash flows strengthened to S$65.1 million. The company attributed the results to government relief grants and a strong balance sheet.

site_title: With prolonged turbulence, SIA likely to draw on further S$6.2b of bonds
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is likely to draw on further S$6.2 billion in bonds to tap into its standby issuance, according to a report by UOB Kay Hian. The airline's prolonged turbulence, coupled with a bleak industry outlook, suggests it may require more cash. SIA's passenger capacity is expected to recover to 7% by the end of the July-September quarter and less than half of its pre-pandemic levels by the end of the current financial year. The airline has already used S$2 billion of its recent rights issue proceeds for bridging loan repayment and operating expenses.

site_title: Wilmar buys former Coke bottling plant in Tuas for S$29.5m
summary: Wilmar International is purchasing the former Coca-Cola bottling plant in Tuas, Singapore for S$29.5 million. The property, spanning 489,000 sq ft, is expected to be used for Wilmar's food distribution operations and Aalst Chocolate's manufacturing operations, in which Wilmar holds a 50% stake. The sale, brokered by CBRE, is expected to proceed on vacant possession, with the site zoned for Business 2 use under the Urban Redevelopment Authority's Master Plan 2019.

site_title: Borrowers in jobs at risk face tighter processing for new home loans
summary: Singaporean home buyers with variable incomes in virus-hit industries are facing tighter credit assessment when applying for new mortgages. However, existing borrowers seeking to refinance to cheaper loans are receiving supportive treatment from banks, with eased debt servicing criteria. This shift in lending policies reflects the changing economic landscape and the need for banks to balance risk and support for affected borrowers.

site_title: Smart buildings in a Covid-free World
summary: Smart buildings are evolving to prioritize public health and safety in a post-Covid-19 world. AI and IoT systems will automate facilities management and monitoring processes, optimizing space utilization and reducing energy consumption. Technologies such as thermal imaging, facial recognition, and fever detection will be integrated to enhance safety measures. Voice-activated controls and touchless entry systems will become the norm, while robotic applications will aid in public hygiene and sanitation. Regulatory inspections and audits will ensure compliance, and smart building systems will become ubiquitous, minimizing the impact of future pandemics and natural disasters.

images.alt_text: The smart cities and buildings of tomorrow must evolve to create more secure and resilient working and living spaces.

site_title: Chinese developers issue $6b in offshore dollar bonds in July
summary: Chinese property developers issued $6 billion in offshore dollar bonds in July, a 33% increase from the same period last year, as they sought to capitalize on robust investor demand ahead of market uncertainty. Despite a 40% decline in total volume so far this year, the industry is expected to continue issuing debt to refinance maturing bonds, with Moody's predicting $45.4 billion in maturities in the next 12 months. The strong demand is attributed to improving high-yield emerging markets and unattractive onshore rates.

site_title: Gargling solution flies off Japan's shelves after governor touts anti-virus effect
summary: Japanese drugstores were stripped bare of gargling solution after Osaka Governor Hirofumi Yoshimura suggested it could help fight coronavirus, sparking panicked buying. A study showed a smaller viral load in patients with mild symptoms after regular gargling with povidone-iodine solution. Shares of Meiji Holdings Co, which sells the medicine, skyrocketed before returning to pre-announcement levels. Experts expressed skepticism, citing concerns of false negatives for PCR tests. The Japanese government will closely monitor the research, while some experts warn of potential misuses of the treatment.

site_title: HK's richest family loses US$8b in a single year
summary: Hong Kong's richest family, the Kwoks, have seen their fortune shrink by almost $8 billion in the past 12 months, with shares of Sun Hung Kai Properties trading at less than half the company's net assets. The decline reflects a sobering outlook for the city, battered by its worst political and economic crises since 1997. The family's net worth now stands at $30 billion, with the company diversifying into mainland China to mitigate risks. Analysts question whether the family's strategy will be successful, citing challenges in generating outsized returns in China and the threat of China's increasingly assertive role in Hong Kong.

site_title: US dollar stays weak amid signs of lagging economy
summary: The US dollar remains weak amid signs of a lagging US economy, with the euro rising 0.5% to $1.1862. The decline in US bond yields and a hardening perception of the US economic recovery have contributed to the dollar's weakness. Investors are also weighing the prospects of further Federal Reserve easing. The euro's rise reflects the unity shown by Europe in tackling the coronavirus-induced slowdown, while the US economic recovery is seen as lagging.

site_title: Majority of registered voters oppose US election delay: poll
summary: A majority of registered US voters oppose delaying the November presidential election due to the coronavirus pandemic, with 66% rejecting the idea. A Reuters/Ipsos poll found 54% believe President Donald Trump wants to postpone the election to help his re-election chances, while 42% think he wants to have a better chance of winning. The poll also showed Democratic candidate Joe Biden leads Trump by 10 percentage points in support, with 44% believing Biden would be better at steering the nation's response to the pandemic.

site_title: UK tells drugmakers to stockpile 6-week supply for Brexit
summary: The UK government has urged pharmaceutical companies to stockpile a six-week supply of medicines before the country leaves the EU's customs regime at the end of the year. This move aims to avoid potential shortages of drugs due to Brexit-related disruptions. The government has retained dedicated freight capacity for essential goods, but companies are also encouraged to prepare alternative routes to bypass congested crossings. The call for stockpiling has drawn criticism from the opposition Scottish National Party, which claims the government is prioritizing Brexit over public health.

site_title: Glove maker Riverstone doubles H1 earnings to RM137.5m
summary: Malaysian glove maker Riverstone Holdings reported a 119.3% surge in net profit to RM137.5 million for the six months ended June, driven by increased demand for its healthcare products. Revenue jumped 30.5% to RM626.7 million.

site_title: Citi on track to grow retail wealth business in Singapore
summary: Citi has announced its plans to double its retail wealth market share in Singapore over the next few years remain on track, with the appointment of Ashmita Acharya as head of retail banking for Citibank Singapore. Acharya, currently Asia-Pacific and EMEA head of segments, will support Citi Singapore's goal of doubling wealth management clients by 2025. The bank has also appointed Chan San San as Asia-Pacific and EMEA Citigold Private Client (CPC) business head, as the CPC business in Asia is the fastest-growing globally.

site_title: Thai central bank holds rates steady, sees gradual recovery in economy
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) held its benchmark interest rate at 0.5% and signaled a gradual recovery in the economy, despite the ongoing impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The central bank expressed concerns about deflation and the risk of a second wave of infections, while also monitoring the currency's gains, which threaten to undermine exports. The BOT is considering unconventional monetary policies, such as yield-curve control, to support the economy. The country's economy is forecast to contract 8.1% this year, with a recovery expected to take at least two years.

site_title: Synagie shares up 6.9% on proposed e-commerce business disposal
summary: Synagie Corporation shares rose 6.9% on Wednesday after the company announced plans to dispose of its e-commerce business for S$61.7 million, allowing it to focus on its insurtech business. The sale, which requires shareholder approval, involves the entire e-commerce, e-commerce enabler, and logistics business. Synagie will distribute 18 cents per share to shareholders, equivalent to its current share price. The company expects to report a net profit for the first half of the year, driven by increased e-commerce activity due to the Covid-19 situation.

site_title: COE prices up on smaller quota
summary: The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices in Singapore rebounded at the latest tender, with prices rising across all categories due to a 29% reduction in COE supply for the August-October period. COE premiums for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp increased to S$33,000, while those for larger vehicles and motorcycles rose to S$37,102 and S$7,701, respectively. The price hikes are attributed to reduced supply, leading to higher demand and increased prices.

images.alt_text: Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums rebounded across the board at the latest tender on Wednesday on the back of a smaller quota.

site_title: Arsenal to sack 55 staff as Covid-19 hits revenues
summary: Arsenal Football Club has announced plans to lay off 55 staff due to the financial impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The club cited severe hits to revenue from broadcasters, matchday, and commercial activities as the reason. Despite implementing cost-cutting measures, including voluntary pay cuts among players and senior staff, the club must reduce costs further to ensure sustainability. The move has sparked backlash from fans, who contrast the large sums paid to key players with the lost jobs of staff.

site_title: Virgin Australia to slash workforce, focus on short haul under Bain Capital
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd plans to cut nearly a third of its workforce, around 3,000 jobs, as part of its overhaul under new owner Bain Capital. The airline aims to focus on domestic and short-haul international flights, targeting the value-for-money market. Virgin expects a three-year recovery to return demand to pre-pandemic levels. The airline's creditors, owed nearly A$7 billion, are set to vote on the sale on September 4, with support from employee creditors and the administrator expected to overcome objections from bondholders.

site_title: Singapore to get first dibs on any successful Arcturus Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Singapore has partnered with US firm Arcturus Therapeutics Holdings to secure a vaccine for COVID-19, with the first doses potentially reserved for the country. Arcturus is developing a single-shot vaccine, Lunar-Cov19, which has reached the clinical trial phase and aims to produce up to 30 million doses in its initial batch. The vaccine's effectiveness and timeline for market release are unclear, but Singapore's funding and early access may give it an advantage in the global vaccination effort.

site_title: TikTok takes steps to curb misinformation ahead of US elections
summary: TikTok has updated its content policies to curb misinformation ahead of the US presidential elections. The app is working with the US Department of Homeland Security to protect against foreign influence. Users can now report election-related misinformation on the app itself. This move comes amid rising US-China tensions and a looming deadline of September 15 for TikTok to either sell its US operations to Microsoft or face a ban. The updates aim to address concerns over the app's alleged links to the Chinese government.

site_title: Tencent in talks to create US$10b online giant
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd is in talks to merge China's biggest game-streaming platforms Huya Inc and DouYu International Holdings Ltd, aiming to dominate the $3.4 billion arena. Tencent, which owns 37% of Huya and 38% of DouYu, seeks to become the largest shareholder in the combined entity. The merger, valued at $10 billion, would solidify Tencent's position in the gaming industry, but details have yet to be finalized.

site_title: UK businesses grow at fastest pace in 5 years in July after Covid slump
summary: UK businesses experienced the fastest growth in over 5 years in July, with the IHS Markit/CIPS composite PMI reaching 57.0, its highest since June 2015. The services sector also saw a five-year high in growth, with the PMI rising to 56.5. The recovery is attributed to the reopening of restaurants, cafes, and pubs after the lockdown. However, concerns remain about the pace of recovery, with some sectors, such as entertainment and arts venues, still struggling, and the employment index remaining below 50.

site_title: TradeGecko sale validates exit potential of similar Asean startups
summary: TradeGecko, a Singapore-based software-as-a-service firm, has been acquired by Intuit Inc for over $80 million, marking one of the largest exits in the region since the Covid-19 outbreak. This deal validates the exit potential of South-east Asia's SaaS startups, indicating substance to the hype among venture investors. The sale's success mirrors the growth of Singapore's startup ecosystem, suggesting that the region's tech startups can attract significant investment and achieve successful exits.

site_title: Atlantic Navigation, Seroja, Luzhou Bio-Chem, Ntegrator expect H1 losses
summary: Four SGX-listed firms, Atlantic Navigation, Ntegrator International, Seroja Investments, and Luzhou Bio-Chem Technology, have guided for expected losses in the six months ended June due to the Covid-19 pandemic and macro-economic uncertainties. Atlantic Navigation expects a loss in Q2 and H1, while Ntegrator expects a loss in H1 due to a significant revenue decline. Seroja's losses will stem from discontinued operations, and Luzhou Bio-Chem did not specify the reason for its anticipated loss. The companies' shares closed flat to unchanged, with some down 3.66%.

site_title: Virgin Atlantic aims to land debt restructuring by Sept 3
summary: Virgin Atlantic Airways is set to agree and implement a £1.2 billion recapitalisation plan by September 3, after filing for Chapter 15 protection from creditors in the US. The airline, which has cut over 3,500 jobs due to the Covid-19 pandemic, is seeking support from UK stakeholders and creditors to avoid triggering minimum cash covenants in some of its bonds. The deal, which includes £200 million from Virgin Group and £170 million from Davidson Kempner Capital Management, aims to restructure the airline's debt and ensure its survival.

site_title: Gold soars to record high; some see correction soon
summary: Gold prices have reached a record high of over $2,000 per ounce, rallying 30% this year due to economic stress from Covid-19. Market watchers, including AxiCorp's Stephen Innes and TD Securities' Bart Melek, believe the gold rally has legs, with some predicting prices will reach $2,100 in the first half of 2021. However, others, such as the Singapore Bullion Market Association's Albert Cheng, see consolidation at $2,000 and a potential correction. The ongoing low interest rates and government stimulus support gold's upward trend, but a potential tightening of monetary policy could lead to a correction.

site_title: Wendy's signals sales recovery on breakfast strength after Covid-19 dent
summary: Wendy's reported a sales recovery in June and July, driven by its new breakfast items, as the US lifted lockdown restrictions. The company's quarterly profit beat Wall Street expectations, with sales rising 8.2% in July and 5.1% in June, after a 4.4% decline in the second quarter. Wendy's plans to invest $13 million more in the breakfast category and resume share repurchases in 2020. Analysts express confidence in the company's ability to thrive despite the Covid-19 crisis.

site_title: Sabana defends ESR deal valuation but Quarz says reasoning 'absurd'
summary: Sabana Reit's manager defended the proposed deal with ESR-Reit, stating that the merger is not an asset sale and that unitholders will benefit from a stronger, larger, and more resilient enlarged Reit. The manager cited the Reit's consistent trading at a discount to net asset value and the potential benefits of scale, diversification, and pro forma dividend accretion. In contrast, activist fund Quarz Capital Management criticized the offer price as "absurd" and questioned the manager's ability to improve the Reit's valuation, citing the Reit's low occupancy rate and lack of strategic transactions since 2019.

site_title: Euro zone business activity resumes growth in July
summary: The Euro zone business activity resumed modest growth in July, with the Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) climbing to 54.9, better than the previous month's 48.5. The recovery in the service industry was not as sharp as expected, but improved in several countries, including Germany, France, and Spain. Retail sales rebounded in June to pre-lockdown levels, and businesses in Britain expanded at the fastest rate in over five years after restaurants reopened. Despite optimism, companies cut headcount, and the employment index remained below break-even.

site_title: 47 employers placed on watchlist for possible discriminatory hiring practices
summary: 47 employers in Singapore have been placed on the Fair Consideration Framework (FCF) watchlist for potentially discriminatory hiring practices, with 30 in the financial and professional services sectors. These employers will have their Employment Pass applications scrutinized and may face penalties, including cut back work pass privileges. The move aims to ensure fairness for workers and prevent nationality bias in hiring.

site_title: Life, liberty or the pursuit of happiness in a post-Covid 19 era
summary: The US is navigating a post-Covid-19 era, weighing the need to re-open businesses against the risk of infection surges and healthcare facility overloads. A University of Pennsylvania simulation study suggests that fully re-opening the economy could save 15 million jobs at a cost of 80,000 lives. Meanwhile, Singaporeans prioritize saving lives over economic costs, with 80% preferring to mitigate loss of life. Serologic tests and comprehensive testing regimens are being implemented to combat false positives and negatives, and policymakers are emphasizing the importance of contact tracing and mobile app adoption to contain the disease.

site_title: Malaysian glove maker Harps weighs US$500m IPO
summary: Malaysian glove maker Harps Holdings is considering an initial public offering (IPO) in Kuala Lumpur to raise approximately US$500 million. The company, which acquired Central Medicare in 2015, has strong demand for gloves due to the coronavirus pandemic. Despite Malaysia's rising stocks, IPO activity has been slow due to political and economic uncertainties. The IPO is still in its early stages, and details, including size and timeline, are yet to be confirmed.

site_title: Procurri's H1 earnings up 1.4% with lift from government relief
summary: Procurri Corp reported a 1.4% increase in H1 earnings to S$2.65 million, despite a 25.6% decline in net operating cash flows due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company's gross profit fell 16% to S$32.9 million, but revenue rose 1.6% to S$110.5 million, lifted by government relief programs. Procurri's chairman and CEO, Sean Murphy, said the company is well-positioned for sustainable growth despite challenging conditions, and plans to implement unified systems globally to drive efficiency. Shares closed flat at S$0.30.

site_title: After blast, Lebanon has less than a month's grain reserves
summary: Lebanon's main grain silo at Beirut port was destroyed in a blast, leaving the country with less than a month's grain reserves. Despite this, the economy minister stated that there is no bread or flour crisis, citing sufficient flour reserves to cover market needs for a month and a half. Lebanon is exploring alternative storage areas and coordinating with international agencies to address the supply chain issue, with four ships carrying 28,000 tonnes of wheat en route to the country.

site_title: US trade gap narrows to US$50.7b in June on rising exports
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed to $50.7 billion in June, a decline of $4.1 billion from May, driven by a record 9.4% increase in exports and a 4.7% rise in imports. The trade gap has narrowed sharply in the first half of the year, dropping to $274.3 billion from $297.4 billion in 2019. Deficits with China have also decreased, falling to $142.2 billion, down $40 billion from the same period in 2019. Experts warn that weak global growth and subdued demand may continue to impact trade activity.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on Disney boost, healthcare earnings
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by a surprise quarterly profit from Disney and upbeat results from healthcare companies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.36%, the S&P 500 gained 0.42%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.24%. The positive sentiment ahead of service sector data lifted investor confidence, despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Moderna prices Covid-19 vaccine at US$32-37 per dose for smaller volume deals
summary: Moderna has priced its experimental Covid-19 vaccine at $32-$37 per dose for smaller volume deals, higher than the US deal for Pfizer's vaccine candidate. CEO Stéphane Bancel stated that prices for larger volume agreements will be lower. The company has received nearly $1 billion from the US government to speed up vaccine development and is in talks with several countries for supply agreements. Enrollment for Moderna's late-stage vaccine study is on track to be completed in September, with the vaccine aiming to halt a pandemic that has claimed over 700,000 lives worldwide.

site_title: New York Times digital business overtakes print for first time
summary: The New York Times' digital business surpassed its print business for the first time in the second quarter, driven by a 30% increase in digital subscription revenue. The shift towards a subscriber-backed model has helped the publisher, which added 669,000 digital subscribers in the quarter. Digital-only subscriptions were launched in 2011 and offer podcasts, recipes, and other content. Despite a 43.9% drop in advertising revenue, the company's total revenue fell 7.5% to $403.75 million, beating analysts' estimates.

site_title: Sharp reports 38% drop in Q1 operating profit, beats analyst estimates
summary: Sharp Corp reported a 37.8% drop in Q1 operating profit to 9 billion yen (S$116.7 million), beating analyst estimates. The decline was attributed to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on electronics and office printer sales. Despite the drop, Sharp forecast a 55.4% rise in operating profit for the year to 82 billion yen, driven by strong demand for home appliances. The company also plans to spin off low-margin businesses.

site_title: Telkom Kenya pulls plug on merger with Bharti Airtel's Kenyan unit
summary: Telkom Kenya has abandoned plans to merge with Bharti Airtel's Kenyan unit, citing difficulties in securing regulatory approvals. The decision was made despite potential benefits from the deal, including creating a stronger competitor in the market. Telkom Kenya cited growing demand for internet services, driven by the coronavirus crisis, and employee opposition to staff layoffs as reasons for the change in direction. The company will instead focus on its alternative strategic plans, including its recent launch of commercial internet services to rural areas using balloons.

site_title: India widens China app ban to cover more from Xiaomi, Baidu
summary: India has expanded its ban on Chinese mobile apps to include Xiaomi's Mi Browser Pro and Baidu's search apps, following a border clash between the two nations in June. This move comes after India outlawed 59 Chinese apps in June, including ByteDance's TikTok and Alibaba's UC Browser. The ban, not publicly announced, affects around 100 apps, including clones and different versions of the already banned apps. The decision is part of India's efforts to counter China's dominant presence in its internet services market.

site_title: NetLink logs 12.4% rise in Q1 PAT despite manpower constraints
summary: NetLink NBN Trust reported a 12.4% increase in profit after tax (PAT) to S$23.5 million for Q1 FY2021, despite a 3.3% decline in revenue due to restricted manpower and access amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Installation revenue fell by S$4.7 million, mainly due to fewer orders and service activations. Despite this, fibre connections rose 3.3% to S$2.9 million, cushioning the impact of the pandemic. NetLink's Q1 results were largely driven by a strong fibre connection revenue growth.

site_title: STI closes 0.68% higher on Wednesday as spotlight falls on bank earnings
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.68% on Wednesday, driven by hopes of US fiscal stimulus and a surge in gold prices. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,532.69, with top gainers including Venture Corp and Yanlord Land. Bank earnings will be in focus, with DBS Group, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC reporting earnings this week. Despite a cautious stance from regulators, analysts see Singapore banks as relatively less constrained than European banks, which have been restricted on dividends and share buybacks.

site_title: Yangzijiang's Q2 net profit falls 17% on lower trading volume
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 17% drop in Q2 net profit to 773.9 million yuan, driven by lower trading volumes. Revenue fell 32% to 4.8 billion yuan, with the trading segment experiencing a 50% drop in income. However, the shipbuilding segment remained robust, with revenue at 3 billion yuan and a gross profit margin of 22%. The company attributed the decline to lower charter rates and Covid-19's impact on the vessel market, but noted strong new order wins and a diversified shipbuilding portfolio.

site_title: Honda posts Q1 net loss but forecasts full-year profit
summary: Honda reported a net loss of 80.87 billion yen (S$1.05 billion) for the first quarter due to the coronavirus pandemic, a 46.9% decline in sales. The company forecasts a full-year net profit of 165 billion yen, down 63.8% from the previous year. Honda suspended production and sales in many countries, but has resumed operations in all production bases. The automaker expects slower sales in the US and Japan, but aims to sell more vehicles in China, where the auto market is rebounding.

site_title: COEs rebound due to supply shrinkage
summary: COE certificates rebounded across the board in Singapore's latest tender, driven by a 29% shrinkage in supply for the August-October period. COE prices rose for all vehicle types, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp increasing to S$33,000, commercial vehicles to S$24,100, and motorcycles to S$7,701. Industry watchers attribute the surge to reduced supply, resulting in higher prices.

site_title: Facebook launches TikTok-like product inside Instagram
summary: Facebook has launched Reels, a short-form video service similar to TikTok, as a feature within its Instagram app in the US and over 50 other countries. The move comes after Microsoft's talks to acquire TikTok's US operations and amid a rivalry between Facebook and TikTok. Reels allows users to record and share vertical videos with effects and soundtracks, and is seen as a response to TikTok's popularity among American teenagers. The launch escalates a fight between Facebook and TikTok, with both companies accusing each other of copying each other's ideas.

images.alt_text: Facebook rolled out its own version of social media rival TikTok in the United States and more than 50 other countries on Wednesday, embedding a new short-form video service called Reels as a feature within its popular Instagram app.

site_title: BMW losses almost US$800m as sales slide during lockdowns
summary: BMW reported a second-quarter loss of 666 million euros (S$1.08 billion) due to a decline in luxury car sales during the coronavirus lockdowns. Despite deliveries recovering in China, the company expects an operating profit for the year, but its automotive Ebit margin slumped to -10.4% from 6.5% in the previous year. BMW's outlook doesn't factor in a potential second wave of Covid-19 infections or a more sustained recession.

site_title: CSE Global's H1 earnings rise 47.7% with newly-acquired US, Aussie units
summary: CSE Global, a tech-solutions provider to the oil and gas and mining industries, reported a 47.7% increase in earnings for H1 FY2020 to S$15.1 million, driven by contributions from newly-acquired US and Australian units. Revenue rose 39.1% to S$255.6 million, with income from the Americas and Asia-Pacific growing 51.7% and 21.6% respectively. The company declared an interim dividend of 1.25 cents per share and has a growing order book, but remains in a net-debt position.

site_title: Majority of registered voters oppose US election delay: poll
summary: A Reuters/Ipsos poll found that 66% of registered US voters oppose delaying the November presidential election due to the coronavirus pandemic, while 23% support a delay. Most Americans, including 8 out of 10 Democrats and 5 in 10 Republicans, reject the idea. The majority, 54%, believe President Trump wants to postpone the election to help himself get re-elected. The poll also shows that Joe Biden leads Trump by 10 percentage points in support among registered voters, with 44% believing Biden would be better at handling the pandemic.

site_title: Tencent to consolidate China's game streaming platforms Douyu and Huya: sources
summary: Tencent Holdings is set to merge game streaming platforms Douyu and Huya, aiming to consolidate its dominance in the industry. As the biggest shareholder of Huya and owner of over a third of Douyu, Tencent seeks to control or become the largest shareholder of the merged entity. Huya and Douyu are China's top two video game streaming sites, with users watching e-sports tournaments and professional gamers. The deal is expected to further solidify Tencent's position in the gaming industry.

images.alt_text: China's biggest video game and social media company Tencent Holdings is driving a merger of Twitch-like game streaming platforms Douyu and Huya, as it seeks to consolidate its dominance in the industry.

site_title: Indonesia's Q2 GDP contraction draws mixed views from economists
summary: Indonesia's second-quarter GDP contracted by 5.3% year-on-year, surpassing private-sector economists' predictions of 4.7%. This is Indonesia's weakest showing since the 1999 Asian Financial Crisis. Economists are divided on the outlook, with Barclays slashing its 2020 GDP forecast to a 1.3% contraction, while DBS maintains its forecast of a 1% contraction. Citi is revising its forecast upwards, expecting the economy to rebound in Q4. The central bank is expected to keep its policy rate steady for now, but may cut rates later this year if the economy continues to weaken.

site_title: Over 3 million SMEs, individuals in Malaysia could tap targeted relief from Oct 1: UOB economists
summary: Malaysia's central bank has announced a targeted relief extension for individuals and SMEs affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. Starting October 1, those who have lost their jobs or remain jobless for three months may qualify for a three-month loan moratorium extension. Those with reduced salaries will receive lower loan instalments for at least six months. The move aims to support those still struggling, while allowing those who can afford to pay to resume repayments and reduce debt.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore retail sales fell 27.8% in June after the partial reopening of the country, despite looser coronavirus restrictions. This decline was attributed to the end of the "circuit breaker" period in April and May, which had previously limited sales. The results suggest that while some restrictions have been lifted, the impact of the pandemic on the retail sector remains significant.

images.alt_text: Among the new initiatives by MAS is the issuance of SORA-based floating rate notes on a monthly basis, starting from Aug 21, 2020.

site_title: Glove maker Riverstone doubles H1 earnings to RM137.5m; raises interim dividend to 4 sen
summary: Malaysian glove-maker Riverstone Holdings has posted a 119.3% surge in net profit to RM137.5 million for the six months ended June, driven by increased demand for health-care examination gloves and face masks. Revenue jumped 30.5% to RM626.7 million, with a 31.6% blended gross profit margin expansion. The company has declared an interim dividend of 4.00 sen, up from 1.55 sen last year, and boosted net operating cash flows to RM222.2 million. Riverstone aims to expand production capacity to 14-15 billion pieces of gloves by FY2023 and reduce reliance on labor.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks firm on US stimulus deal hopes; won closes at 5-month high
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1.4% on Wednesday, tracking a firmer finish on Wall Street, with hopes of a US stimulus deal. The benchmark Kospi closed at a 5-month high, while the won closed at a 5-month high and the benchmark bond yield fell. Foreigners were net sellers of 51.8 billion won worth of shares. The won ended trading at 1,188.8 per US dollar, 0.45% higher than its previous close.

site_title: UK businesses grow at fastest pace in 5 years in July after Covid slump
summary: The UK economy experienced its fastest business growth in over five years in July, with the IHS Markit/CIPS composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 57.0. This marks a five-year high and a significant recovery from the Covid-19 lockdown. Services PMI also rose to a five-year high of 56.5, driven by the reopening of restaurants, cafes, and pubs on July 4. However, economists warn that Britain may take years to recover the record 25% of output lost during the lockdown, and the employment figures remain a concern.

site_title: Singapore migrant worker mental health in spotlight after self harm incident
summary: A migrant worker in Singapore, who self-harmed and was pictured bloodied in a stairwell, has raised concerns over the mental health of thousands of low-paid workers confined to dormitories due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The lockdown has taken a heavy toll on workers, with many facing uncertainty over their jobs and families, leading to extreme distress and mental anguish. Authorities have responded by providing counseling services and working with NGOs to address mental health needs, but rights groups say more needs to be done to support the vulnerable workers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.81 points to 1,568.13. Volume reached 15.575 billion lots worth RM8.267 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 797 to 390.

site_title: Thai central bank keeps key rate at record low on signs of gradual recovery
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, kept its key interest rate at a record low of 0.50% for the second consecutive meeting, citing signs of a gradual economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. The economy is expected to shrink by 8.1% this year, but the bank sees inflation returning to target next year. Analysts expect a slow recovery, with household spending and tourism affected by social restrictions and foreign travel bans. The bank is monitoring the situation and ready to take action in case of an emergency.

site_title: US to pay over US$1b for 100m doses of J&J's potential Covid-19 vaccine
summary: The US government has agreed to pay Johnson & Johnson (J&J) over $1 billion for 100 million doses of its potential Covid-19 vaccine, with a price of $10 per dose. This contract, in addition to a previous $456 million payment, brings the total investment to $1.456 billion. The vaccine is being developed in one and two-dose regimens, and the US is paying $19.50 per dose for Pfizer and BioNTech's candidate, which requires two doses per person treated.

site_title: Singapore's Sea enjoys 880% stock rally that's trouncing Tesla and everything else
summary: Singapore-based Sea Ltd has seen an 880% stock rally, outperforming Tesla and other tech companies, making it the world's best-performing large-cap stock. The company, which offers gaming, e-commerce, and payments services, has surged in value despite being loss-making, with revenue growing 163% to $2.2 billion in 2019. Despite skepticism from some analysts, Sea's CEO Forrest Li remains confident, citing the company's execution and growth potential. The company's market value has surpassed $65 billion, making it Singapore's most valuable listed firm, and it has attracted prominent investors such as Tencent and Tiger Global Management.

site_title: UK insurer Hastings agrees to higher than expected £1.66b cash offer
summary: UK insurer Hastings has agreed to a £1.66 billion takeover by Finland's Sampo and South Africa's Rand Merchant Investment (RMI). The deal, which includes a £1.66 billion cash offer and an interim dividend, represents a 47.1% premium to Hastings' closing share price. The acquisition aims to expand Sampo's presence in non-life insurance and beyond Nordic markets, while RMI will hold a 30% stake in Hastings. The deal follows a 27% surge in Hastings shares since talks emerged, driven by the potential for technological know-how and pricing systems expertise.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished higher, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.62% to 25,102.45. Investors are tracking US stimulus talks, driving gains. The Shanghai Composite Index added 0.17% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.80%. These gains follow a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a fresh record close for the US S&P 500. Despite US trade uncertainty, investors remain positive, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: MAS to enhance transparency, data availability of SORA to catalyse greater activity
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to enhance transparency and data availability of the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (SORA) to catalyze greater activity in SORA markets. MAS will prescribe SORA as a financial benchmark under the Securities and Futures Act, aiming to safeguard the benchmark's integrity and boost market confidence. These initiatives complement the industry-led transition roadmap, with the goal of developing "vibrant and robust" SORA markets.

site_title: SMIC founder 'optimistic' China can catch up with US in semiconductors
summary: China's largest chipmaker SMIC founder Richard Chang expressed optimism that China can catch up with the US in the next generation of semiconductors through persistent research and development and investment in new raw materials. Chang's comments come amid heightened tensions between the US and China over Huawei Technologies, which has accelerated China's push to improve its domestic chip industry. Chang cautioned that US efforts to contain China's technology sector should not be underestimated.

site_title: Europe: Shares lifted by positive earnings reports
summary: European shares rose 0.7% on Wednesday, driven by positive earnings reports and stimulus from central banks. Ahold Delhaize jumped 5% after raising its sales outlook, while Vonovia rose 2.9% on an 8% increase in core profits. However, BMW slid 3% due to a second-quarter operating loss. Investors are looking past declining earnings forecasts, expecting the global stimulus to prop up stock markets until recovery takes hold.

site_title: Thai central bank leaves policy rate unchanged at record low, as expected
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, left its one-day repurchase rate unchanged at a record low of 0.50% for a second straight meeting, as expected. This decision aims to support the economy after easing measures to contain the coronavirus outbreak. The unanimous vote followed a Reuters poll predicting no policy change, with 16 of 18 economists forecasting no change. The decision maintains the current monetary policy to mitigate the pandemic's impact on tourism and domestic consumption.

site_title: Commerzbank expects net loss for 2020 after Q2 profit decline
summary: Commerzbank, a German bank, expects to post a net loss for 2020 after a 21% decline in its second-quarter net profit to €220 million. The bank's net profit in the second quarter is down from €279 million in the same period last year. This decline is attributed to various factors, including a leadership crisis and economic uncertainty.

site_title: CDP fined S$32,000 for personal data breaches over dividend cheques sent to outdated addresses
summary: The Central Depository (CDP) in Singapore has been fined S$32,000 for mailing dividend cheques to outdated addresses, putting 200 account holders at risk of having their personal data disclosed. The breach occurred after the firm migrated its software system in 2018, capturing both updated and historical addresses. This incident, along with others, led to fines for CDP and two other organizations, and warnings for six others that failed to implement reasonable security measures to prevent unauthorized disclosure of personal data. The Personal Data Protection Act was breached.

site_title: Travel bans may force football clubs to forfeit European games next season
summary: UEFA has issued guidelines for European soccer clubs to follow if they're participating in the upcoming season's competitions. If a club fails to inform UEFA of travel restrictions 48 hours prior to a draw, they'll be given a 3-0 defeat. Clubs must also find a neutral venue if their opponent can't travel to the country, and forfeit the game if they can't propose an alternative. These rules apply to qualifying rounds and play-offs of next season's European competitions.

images.alt_text: UEFA said it would publish a list of known travel restrictions between countries before each draw is made.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as corporate earnings, Covid-19 cases loom
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Wednesday as investors awaited corporate earnings, while a spike in domestic Covid-19 cases raised risk sentiment. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,001.3 points. Earnings from top lenders and energy giants are due this week, with many companies pushing guidance down or withdrawing it. Victoria reported a record rise in Covid-19 cases, adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: KS Energy CEO Kris Wiluan faces 112 charges for alleged false trading, market rigging
summary: Indonesian tycoon Kris Taenar Wiluan, CEO of KS Energy, faces 112 charges for alleged false trading and market rigging. Wiluan is accused of instructing his employee to execute trades in KS Energy's shares to "push up" the price, between 2014 and 2016. Wiluan, 71, and his employee Ho Chee Yen, 56, face charges under the Securities and Futures Act. Both have surrendered their passports and are out on court bail. Wiluan claims he acted with transparency to help smaller shareholders, but denies creating false trading or market rigging transactions.

images.alt_text: Kris Wiluan was also accused of instructing a CIMB Securities trading representative to execute trades in KS Energy's shares "with a purpose to push up" its prices.

site_title: Broker's take: PhillipCapital says Koufu a 'buy' on superior growth, potential asset sale
summary: PhillipCapital initiated coverage on Koufu Group with a "buy" recommendation, targeting S$0.80, citing its superior growth profile, defensive business model, and historical record of generating positive free cash flow. The brokerage expects strong free cash flow and high return on equity, positioning Koufu well above its peers. A potential asset sale of its central kitchen properties could also lead to a special dividend, adding 1.4 cents to the share price or a 2.1% dividend yield.

site_title: Jurong Point Popular among places visited by infectious coronavirus patients
summary: A Popular bookstore at Jurong Point in Singapore has been added to the list of public places visited by Covid-19 patients while they were still infectious. The visit occurred from 12.05pm to 2.30pm on July 26. The Ministry of Health (MOH) is monitoring the health of individuals who were at these locations for two weeks from the date of their visit. This is part of the MOH's efforts to track and contain the spread of the virus.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall from one-week high on dour earnings, firmer yen
summary: Japanese shares fell from a one-week high on Wednesday, weighed down by downbeat earnings reports and a firmer yen. The Nikkei index ended 0.26% lower at 22,514.85, with telecommunications and consumer discretionary sectors leading the declines. Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group's net profit more than halved, and Sony Corp's shares fell 1.61% due to concerns over its future earnings. More Japanese companies are set to report earnings in the coming days, highlighting the economic blow from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Indonesia's Q2 GDP shrinks by 5.3% y-o-y, sharper than expected
