Tech stocks led gains, with semiconductor and tech manufacturing sectors experiencing significant increases. AEM Holdings, Sunningdale Tech, and UMS also saw substantial gains. Analysts attribute the rally to positive economic data and hopes for further stimulus, predicting more gains for global equity markets.

site_title: Thai PM asks student protesters 'not to create chaos'
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha asked student protesters not to create chaos as they demand reform of the constitutional monarchy. He promised Parliament would consider protesters' demands to amend the 2017 constitution and set up a committee to discuss possible changes. The protesters, who have been gathering in small groups, are calling for the dissolution of Parliament and new elections. Prayuth also promised to establish a mechanism to gauge the views of young people and has formed a committee to discuss constitutional changes.

site_title: Former Fuji Xerox boss claims his dismissal was 'orchestrated', in S$1.5m lawsuit
summary: Former Fuji Xerox Singapore managing director Bert Wong is suing the company for wrongful dismissal, claiming his dismissal was "orchestrated" by high-level executives. Wong, who was nearing retirement, was sacked in December 2017 despite a three-month investigation finding no evidence of fraud. He is seeking over S$1.5 million in damages, alleging corporate betrayal and conspiracy. Fuji Xerox denies the claim, calling it "paranoia" and counterclaiming that Wong caused nearly S$3 million in losses through reckless business transactions. The High Court hearing continues.

site_title: White House, US Congress Democrats to continue effort on coronavirus aid
summary: US Democrats and White House officials will attempt to finalize a fifth coronavirus-aid bill on Tuesday, following several days of closed-door negotiations. Despite progress on some issues, significant differences remain. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer stated that while "some progress" was made, "a lot of issues" are still outstanding. The bill aims to stimulate the economy and provide aid to the unemployed.

site_title: Telco SoftBank's Q1 cash flow jumps 50% as broader group retrenches
summary: SoftBank's domestic wireless unit, SoftBank Corp, reported a 50% increase in adjusted free cash flow to 236 billion yen in the April-June quarter, driven by securitisation of receivables. The company aims to cut costs and reduce debt, with CEO Ken Miyauchi stating no large deals will be made for a while. SoftBank Group has cut its stake in the telco to 62.1% and plans a record 2.5 trillion yen share repurchase, fueling a divergence in market valuation. The company reported a 4% rise in operating profit, beating analyst estimates.

site_title: Google Cloud prepares for Black Friday 'peak on top of peak'
summary: Google Cloud is preparing for a surge in fourth-quarter sales from US retailers as they anticipate record online shopping during the holidays due to Covid-19 lockdowns. The company has adopted a new linear growth model to predict increased server needs for retailers around Black Friday, with revenue potentially increasing by 30% compared to the last two years. This is driven by retailers such as Kohls and Wayfair relying on Google Cloud to handle increased shopping demand, and the company's predictive algorithms benefiting from the pandemic.

site_title: SGX to launch two international Reit futures, in Asian first
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is set to launch two international real estate investment trust (Reit) futures products, the SGX FTSE EPRA Nareit Asia ex-Japan Index Futures and the SGX iEdge S-REIT Leaders Index Futures, on August 24. These products will track Reits listed in Singapore, Hong Kong, Malaysia, and Thailand, catering to global institutional investors. The launch comes amid rising demand for real estate-related investment products, building on SGX's existing single stock futures. The move is expected to increase investor interest in the local Reit market, which has seen 45% of global Reit IPOs debut on SGX.

site_title: Broke and helpless: Philippines virus lockdown maroons dozens at airport
summary: A partial coronavirus lockdown in the Philippines has left dozens stranded at Manila airport, with over 27 million people in the capital and surrounding provinces affected. The lockdown has shut businesses, halted public transport, and grounded flights, forcing many to survive on food handouts. The government has struggled to contain the surge in cases, which have more than quintupled since June, with new cases reported every day. The lockdown has also crippled the economy, with a "big drop" in economic activity predicted in the first half.

site_title: Hong Kong developer Swire Properties obtains HK$1b green loan from OCBC
summary: Swire Properties, a Hong Kong developer, has secured a HK$1 billion (S$177.4 million) green loan from OCBC Bank for five years. The loan will support the developer's green initiatives, including energy-efficient technologies and sustainable building practices, at its properties globally. The loan is part of Swire Properties' efforts to implement its Sustainable Development 2030 Strategy. The move is seen as a significant step towards sustainable financing in the real estate industry, with OCBC Bank aiming to build a S$25 billion sustainable finance portfolio by 2025.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 2% on Tuesday, following a record lead from Wall Street and a drop in new virus infections. The Hang Seng Index rose 488.50 points to 24,946.63, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.11%. The gains were driven by healthy gains across Asia and investors' optimism about the city's economic recovery.

site_title: China won't allow a TikTok 'smash and grab' by US, warns state media
summary: China's government warns that it won't allow the US to acquire TikTok's US operations through Microsoft, calling it a "smash and grab" and "theft". The Beijing-backed state media, China Daily, says China will take action against Washington if the sale is forced, without specifying options. The US threat comes amid concerns over data collection and national security. China has criticized the US for employing double standards in trying to ban TikTok, while a spokesperson for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs declined to comment on the specific business activity.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets extend gains at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on Tuesday, building on the previous session's gains. London's FTSE 100 index edged up 0.1% to 6,035.51 points, while the eurozone's Dax 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices rose 0.5% and 0.6% respectively. The gains were driven by positive economic data, with stocks in the mining and healthcare sectors performing well.

site_title: Malaysia approves Lynas' application for waste treatment facility
summary: Malaysia has approved Lynas Corp's application to build a permanent disposal facility for its rare earth waste. The facility will be built at a site identified by the Pahang state government. The approval was granted following the renewal of Lynas' licence to operate in the country last year, which included requirements for a permanent disposal facility.

site_title: Richard Branson space-bound in early 2021, says Virgin Galactic
summary: Richard Branson is expected to become the first passenger to reach space on Virgin Galactic's aircraft in the first quarter of 2021, pending successful test flights. The company has received $250,000 from 600 people to reserve a seat, and two manned flights are planned for the fall. The spacecraft will reach an altitude of 80 km above the Earth's surface, creating weightlessness for a few minutes, before descending and landing at Spaceport America in New Mexico. This marks a significant step towards commercial space travel, which Virgin Galactic aims to begin.

site_title: Goldman Sachs names new equity capital head for Australia, New Zealand
summary: Goldman Sachs has named Ian Taylor as the new head of equity capital markets for Australia and New Zealand, based in Sydney. He replaces Sarah Rennie, who left for Jarden in May. Taylor returns to Goldman Sachs after leading advisory services at Galaxy Digital Holdings in New York. He previously worked at Goldman Sachs for over 18 years in various capital markets roles. Aaron Lamshed will be promoted to head of syndicate in Sydney.

site_title: Taiwan provisionally approves dexamethasone as coronavirus treatment
summary: Taiwan has provisionally approved the use of dexamethasone as a coronavirus treatment amid a shortage of the antiviral drug remdesivir. The decision comes as Taiwan faces a low stock of remdesivir, with only 78 doses available to treat 54 seriously ill patients. Dexamethasone, a cheap and widely-used steroid, has shown promise in reducing mortality rates in Covid-19 patients, with Japan and the UK also approving its use. Taiwan's approval is seen as a potential solution to the remdesivir shortage, which has been exacerbated by the US buying nearly all global supplies.

images.alt_text: Taiwan provisionally approved the use of dexamethasone, a cheap and widely-used steroid, to treat the new coronavirus, as the island faces a shortfall of the antiviral drug remdesivir after the United States bought nearly all global supplies.

site_title: Pizza restaurant launches Spain's first virtual waiter app
summary: A pizza restaurant in Palafrugell, Spain, has launched the country's first virtual waiter app, Funky Pay, to minimize coronavirus risk. Customers can browse menus, order, and pay via their phones, while a waiter brings the order to the table. This integration marks the first time a purpose-designed app has been integrated into a restaurant's ordering system in Spain. The move aims to reduce face-to-face contact and promote social distancing.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks at near 2-year high on US data, stimulus breakthrough
summary: South Korean stocks reached a near two-year high on Tuesday, closing 28.93 points higher or 1.29% at 2,279.97, driven by strong US manufacturing data and efforts to pass a coronavirus relief bill. US manufacturing activity accelerated to its highest level in nearly 1.5 years, helping investors look past broader economic concerns. The Kospi's gain marked the largest daily increase in a week, as the benchmark bond yield rose and the Korean won inched down.

site_title: Japanese bank MUFG's profit more than halves on credit-related costs
summary: MUFG, Japan's largest lender, reported a first-quarter net profit of 183.5 billion yen, more than halving from 389.2 billion yen a year earlier due to credit-related costs. The bank's credit-related costs for the quarter were 145 billion yen, exceeding its estimated 450 billion yen for the current financial year. Despite this, MUFG retained its full-year profit forecast of 550 billion yen. The bank's net interest income rose 5.6% year on year, driven by its traditional lending business.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up 1.7% on bargain hunting
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index rose 1.70% on Tuesday, closing at 22,573.66, as investors sought bargains following recent declines. The rally was fueled by a cheaper yen and gains on US stocks, including a record high on the Nasdaq. Japanese shares, including Japan Airlines and Sony, also saw significant gains, while SoftBank Group fell after failing to declare taxable income. Despite the rally, trading remains cautious due to concerns over the coronavirus pandemic's impact on domestic businesses.

site_title: Hugo Boss reports strong China rebound in June
summary: German fashion house Hugo Boss reported a strong growth rebound in China for June, with online sales increasing 74% in the second quarter. Despite an overall 59% decline in sales due to lockdowns, the company's shares rose 2.3% in early trade. Analysts attribute the growth to a shift towards casual wear during the pandemic, reducing demand for Hugo Boss's smart suits.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise most in two weeks on Wall Street rally
summary: Australian shares rose 1.88% to a two-week high, driven by a tech-led rally on Wall Street and upbeat US data, including a rebound in manufacturing activity. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,037.6. Despite a bumpy economic recovery predicted by the Reserve Bank of Australia, investors were lifted by positive Chinese data and a strong US manufacturing report. The tech sub-index rose over 3% and energy stocks advanced 2.6%.

site_title: Hindu temple in Yishun added to list of places visited by infectious Covid-19 cases
summary: A Covid-19 patient visited the Holy Tree Sri Balasubramaniar Temple in Singapore on July 31 while still infectious, according to the Ministry of Health. The patient was at the temple for 2 hours and has been added to the list of locations visited by infectious cases, prompting close contacts to monitor their health for two weeks. There were 295 new cases confirmed, including 7 imported cases linked to India, with 31,346 total cases and 53,346 total reported cases.

site_title: Gold steadies near record high as virus concerns persist
summary: Gold steadied near its record high of $1,976.19 per ounce on Tuesday, driven by ongoing concerns over the global economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite a rise in risk sentiment due to positive US economic data, gold prices were supported by warnings from the World Health Organization that the pandemic's road to normality will be long. Central banks' stimulus measures and lower interest rates have also contributed to gold's 30% gain this year.

site_title: South Korea to convert golf courses, military sites into residential apartments to supply new homes
summary: South Korea plans to supply over 132,000 new homes in Seoul by 2028 through measures such as easing building height limits and converting military sites into residential areas. The move aims to stabilize the real estate market, which has seen a 44% increase in home prices over the past three years. The government will relax building height limits in central Seoul to encourage rebuilding of old apartments, and convert state-owned properties like the Taereung golf course and Camp Kim military base into residential developments.

site_title: Oil giant BP slashes dividend as virus hastens moves to curb oil output
summary: Oil giant BP slashes its dividend for the first time in a decade, cutting it to 5.25 cents a share, as the company accelerates its shift to greener energy following the COVID-19 pandemic. BP targets a 40% decline in hydrocarbon production and a 10-fold increase in low-carbon investment by 2030, with plans to return 60% of surplus cash as share buybacks. The move is seen as a response to the pandemic's devastating impact on the oil business, with European peer Royal Dutch Shell also slashing its payout in April.

site_title: Gold ETF holdings are booming
summary: Gold-backed exchange-traded funds (ETFs) have surged to 3,365.6 tonnes, surpassing Germany's holdings and trailing only US reserves. This increase is driven by investor concerns over the global outlook, including the coronavirus pandemic, stimulus measures, and geopolitical tensions. Gold prices have reached a record this year, with forecasts predicting further gains, including a potential climb to $2,300 per ounce by Goldman Sachs. ETFs allow investors to trade gold without physical delivery, fueling the boom in gold-backed investments.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover loses court battle over Defender trademark
summary: Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) lost a UK court battle over the trademark for the shape of its iconic Defender SUV. The UK Intellectual Property Office found the design wasn't distinctive enough, dismissing JLR's appeal. This allows the Ineos Group, owned by billionaire Jim Ratcliffe, to proceed with the Grenadier off-road vehicle. The court upheld that differences in design may not register with average consumers, despite being significant to specialists.

images.alt_text: Jaguar Land Rover lost a UK court bid to get the trademark rights for the shape of its iconic Defender SUV, freeing billionaire Jim Ratcliffe's Ineos Group to go ahead with the Grenadier off-road vehicle.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars edge up as RBA says to buy more bonds
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars edged higher, with the Aussie dollar reaching US$0.7134 and the kiwi dollar reaching US$0.6617, after the Reserve Bank of Australia announced it would buy more government bonds to keep yields down. The RBA kept interest rates steady at 0.25% and reiterated that the Covid-19 economic downturn was not as severe as initially feared, but cautioned on the impact of a new lockdown in Victoria state.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars edged higher on Tuesday and bonds got a boost after the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) said it would again step into the market to buy government debt to keep yields down near its target.

site_title: HSBC to hire 3,000 wealth planners in China amid rising tension
summary: HSBC plans to hire 2,000 to 3,000 wealth planners in China over the next four years to boost sagging profits amid rising tensions between Beijing and Western governments. The move comes as the bank faces criticism over its dealings with Huawei and China's security law on Hong Kong. Despite reporting a $26 million loss for its wealth and personal banking business in China, HSBC aims to capture high-growth opportunities in Asia, particularly in mainland China. The bank's CEO, Noel Quinn, stated that HSBC is well-positioned to bridge the economies of east and west, despite current challenges.

site_title: Heavy rains in South Korea displace more than 1,000 people, 13 dead
summary: Heavy rains in South Korea have displaced over 1,000 people and killed at least 13, with another 13 missing. The floods, which inundated 5,751 hectares of farmland and damaged infrastructure, were caused by a North Korean border dam being opened without advance notice. President Moon Jae In held an emergency meeting to address the situation. Crews have begun repairing flooded roads and bridges in Seoul, and neighboring North Korea has warned of possible flooding due to heavy rainfall. The incident has raised concerns about the region's preparedness for natural disasters.

site_title: Injury, obesity, stress: e-sports starts wising up to health problems
summary: A new e-sports federation, backed by Chinese gaming giant Tencent, has pledged to address health problems in the sport, following the retirement of top player Jian Zihao due to Type 2 diabetes and hand injuries. The federation, Global Esports Federation, aims to promote holistic health and has set up an education, culture, and wellness commission. However, the body faces challenges, including a lack of buy-in from publishers and rival governing bodies, to establish credibility and real meaningful global coordination.

site_title: Aviation sector has biggest pandemic default risk: insurance poll
summary: A survey of 76 underwriters from 46 firms in Lloyd's of London and the broader London commercial insurance market found that the aviation sector carries the biggest risk of corporate default due to the coronavirus pandemic. Only 29% of credit and political risk insurers have seen claims related to the virus, but pandemic-related credit insurance claims are expected to rise later this year or early next year. The aviation sector, along with oil and energy, and tourism, are the top concerns for insurers, with airlines such as Virgin Australia and Air Mauritius ceasing operations due to lockdowns.

images.alt_text: The aviation sector carries the biggest risk of corporate default as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Sony reports first-quarter net profit rise of 53.3 per cent
summary: Sony reports a 53.3% increase in first-quarter net profit to 233.25 billion yen, driven by significant growth in game and network services, and financial services segments. However, operating profit slipped 1.1% due to strong gains in equity securities. The company warns annual profits will likely decline 12.4% due to negative factors such as manufacturing slumps and pandemic-related cancellations. Annual sales are forecast to increase 0.5% to 8.3 trillion yen. A new PlayStation version is expected later this year, which has helped sustain the firm's share price.

site_title: AirAsia to resume Singapore-Malaysia flights on 'green lane' scheme
summary: AirAsia to resume daily flights between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore, as well as weekly flights to Penang, Kota Kinabalu, Kuching, and Ipoh, starting August 17 under Singapore and Malaysia's Reciprocal Green Lane scheme. The move comes as both countries announced the opening of cross-border travel for essential business and official purposes. The flights are subject to further government announcements.

site_title: French bank SocGen reshuffles management structure
summary: French bank Societe Generale (SocGen) announced a wide management reshuffle to reduce costs and boost synergies following consecutive quarterly losses. The bank cut deputy chief executive roles to two and created new deputy general manager positions. Key changes include Severin Cabannes leaving his deputy CEO position and Philippe Heim dropping his role, while Slawomir Krupa will become deputy general manager and head of global banking activities globally. The moves aim to strengthen the group's synergies and reduce costs, following a second-quarter loss of 1.26 billion euros.

images.alt_text: French bank Societe Generale announced on Tuesday a wide management reshuffle in a move to reduce costs and boost synergies following two consecutive quarterly losses.

site_title: Frasers L&C Trust to sell stake in facility, buy two properties from sponsor; Q3 revenue doubles
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) has proposed acquiring two properties in Australia and the UK from its sponsor Frasers Property for a total of S$89.9 million. The trust will also sell its remaining 50% stake in a cold storage facility in Australia for A$152.5 million. The proposed transactions are expected to be accretive and contribute to stable distributions. FLCT's revenue nearly doubled to S$103.7 million for the three months ended June 30, 2020.

site_title: World's top pork producer goes on defensive over virus response
summary: Smithfield Foods Inc, the world's top pork producer, has taken out a full-page ad in the New York Times to defend its efforts to keep employees safe and supply food during the pandemic. The ad accuses critics of spreading false narratives and misinformation about worker safety. Despite over 16,200 meat plant workers testing positive for the virus and 86 deaths, Smithfield claims to have implemented measures to keep staff safe and reward them. The company's CEO, Ken Sullivan, acknowledged that social distancing is challenging in its facilities, but the ad dismisses criticism as an attempt to distract from its response.

site_title: Cotton growers in Australia whacked again as Chinese buyer shuts
summary: Cotton growers in Australia are facing financial losses after a Chinese buyer, Weilin Trade Pty Ltd, went into administration, leaving about 100 growers A$20 million out of pocket. The shutdown comes amid a global supply chain slowdown due to the pandemic, with a glut of US cotton in the market. Australian cotton prices have fallen to A$480 per bale, down from A$620 in January, and demand is expected to take time to recover, with forecasts of a 13-15% drop in global consumption.

site_title: Bond titans led by Pimco double down on their big bet on Europe
summary: Investors at top bond managers Pimco, Axa Investment Managers, and AllianceBernstein are doubling down on their bets on European bonds, despite the region's economic woes. Italian and Spanish debt have rallied to pre-lockdown levels, with yields near all-time lows. Despite risks, including Italy's extreme debt burden and populist parties, investors see a "monetary anchor" that shields sovereign balance sheets and a potential for yields to rise. A 750 billion euro economic rescue package has bolstered confidence, with some predicting yields could fall to 0.75%.

site_title: Malaysia open to settling 1MDB case against Abu Dhabi state fund
summary: Malaysia is open to settling its 1MDB case against Abu Dhabi's state investment fund, IPIC, if a settlement offer aligns with Malaysia's intent to retrieve assets and ensure justice. Attorney-General Idrus Harun stated that negotiations are ongoing, and Malaysia has not dropped its proceedings. The country is seeking to recover $3.5 billion paid by 1MDB or reduce its liability for bonds jointly guaranteed by IPIC. This comes after Malaysia won a ruling to allow public hearings and former premier Najib Razak was sentenced to 12 years in prison over 1MDB-related charges.

site_title: Singapore's Equis raises 100b won to build waste-to-energy facilities in South Korea
summary: Singapore-based Equis Development has completed a 100 billion won (S$115.3 million) equity capital raise to construct four waste-to-energy facilities in South Korea, processing over 470,000 tonnes of waste annually. Construction starts in Q4 2020, with operations expected to begin in 2022. Equis Development will retain a 10% stake in the facilities, with plans to expand into future waste-to-energy and waste treatment facilities, committing over $2 billion to the sectors in the next two years.

site_title: Grab to launch retail investment product, consumer loan platform
summary: Grab Financial Group is launching two new products: AutoInvest, a micro-investment platform allowing users to invest as low as S$1, and a third-party loan platform offering personal loans from licensed bank partners. Users can invest in fixed income funds with estimated returns of 1.8% per annum and withdraw funds at any time. The loan platform is expected to launch later this year, while the "buy now, pay later" line of offerings will be expanded in October.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street surge, focus turns to Capitol Hill
summary: Asian markets advanced on Tuesday, following a record close on Wall Street, driven by tech stocks and US data beating forecasts. However, the spread of the virus and strict containment measures remain concerns. Investors are now focused on Washington, where Democrats and Republicans are battling to pass a new stimulus package to save the US economy. The outcome could impact global markets, with leaders of top companies urging lawmakers to reach a consensus.

site_title: Nippon Steel to appeal S Korea ruling allowing seizure of assets
summary: Nippon Steel Corp announced plans to appeal a South Korean court ruling that allows for the seizure and sale of its assets in the country as compensation for forced wartime labor during World War II. The ruling, made in 2018, ordered Nippon Steel to pay 100 million won to four South Koreans. The court had previously approved the seizure of part of Nippon Steel's domestic assets, with a deadline for the process to begin set for Tuesday. The appeal will likely face significant opposition from Japan, highlighting ongoing tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Asian institute for digital finance to start operations in Singapore by end-2020
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore, National Research Foundation, and National University of Singapore will jointly establish the Asian Institute of Digital Finance (AIDF) by the end of 2020. Led by Duan Jin-Chuan, AIDF will offer a Master's program, scholarships, and training for post-doctoral fellows in digital finance and fintech. The institute will focus on foundational and interdisciplinary research projects, developing financial services for sustainability and resiliency, and promoting entrepreneurship through its "Fincubator" program. The goal is to build fintech leadership pipeline for Singapore and the wider region.

site_title: GIC, Temasek buy shares in India's Bandhan Bank amid holder's 106b rupee stock sale
summary: BlackRock and Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC have bought shares in India's Bandhan Bank, acquiring a significant stake after the bank's main shareholder, Bandhan Financial Holdings, sold 106 billion rupees (S$1.94 billion) of its stake to meet RBI ownership rules. The sale, which included Temasek Holdings and SBI Mutual Fund, comes as the bank faces regulator-imposed ownership restrictions. Bandhan Bank's shares plunged 10.5% after the transaction, but the sale is seen as a strategic move to improve corporate governance and reduce concentration risk.

images.alt_text: BlackRock and Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC bought shares in Bandhan Bank as the main shareholder of India's most profitable bank sold 106 billion rupees (S$1.94 billion) of its stake to meet the regulator's ownership rules.

site_title: Intuit to buy Singapore inventory software maker TradeGecko
summary: Intuit Inc has agreed to acquire TradeGecko, a Singapore-based inventory and order management software platform for small retailers and wholesalers in over 100 countries. The acquisition is expected to close in September and will integrate TradeGecko's system into Intuit's QuickBooks accounting suite. This move aims to help small businesses manage their orders and inventory more effectively, giving them new paths to growth.

site_title: Japan's Mitsubishi UFJ Trust to bolster testament business with will-making app
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Trust and Banking plans to launch a will-making app in September to bolster its testament business in Japan's aging population. The app aims to encourage users to create wills, increasing contact with potential customers. The company hopes to achieve 500,000 app downloads by fiscal 2026, with roughly 8% of Japanese people over 65 years old having created a will in 2019, compared to 40-50% in the US and Germany.

site_title: Northern Ireland faces Brexit food time bomb on new paperwork
summary: Northern Ireland is facing significant challenges due to Brexit, with the UK's departure from the EU set to introduce extra paperwork for animal products transported from the rest of Britain. The new requirements, including export health certificates, are expected to increase costs by an estimated 40,000 pounds per shipment, potentially forcing some supermarkets, including Tesco and Marks & Spencer, to pull out of the province due to thin profit margins.

site_title: Poultry farmers in India seeking US$2.7b after virus scare
summary: India's poultry industry is seeking US$3.7 billion in loans due to a virus scare that led to a 70% slump in chicken prices in March, forcing farmers to cull large numbers. The industry, which employs 5 million people and produces 95 billion eggs annually, needs bank financing to recover from the losses. With a risk of default on existing loans, the industry is urging banks to provide funding to expand and pay back the money. The industry's chairman, Suresh Chitturi, emphasized that the industry needs cash to survive, not handouts.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 5.00 points or 0.32% to 1,577.61. Volume was 598.14 million lots worth RM318.88 million. Gainers beat losers 369 to 85.

site_title: Japan will respond if South Korea seizes Japanese assets: deputy PM Aso
summary: Japan's Deputy Prime Minister Taro Aso warned that his country would respond if South Korea seizes Japanese assets over wartime forced labor disputes, stating it's a breach of international law. Aso emphasized the importance of avoiding such a move, indicating Japan's preparedness to take action. This comes amid ongoing tensions between the two nations over historical issues.

images.alt_text: Japan would need to respond if South Korea seizes Japanese assets over wartime forced labour disputes, Deputy Prime Minister Taro Aso said on Tuesday, describing such a move as being in breach of international law.

site_title: Taxpayers get PayNow QR as payment option in DBS-Iras tie-up
summary: Taxpayers in Singapore can now pay their taxes using PayNow QR through the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore's (Iras) myTax portal. This new payment option is available for major tax types, including individual income tax, corporate income tax, and property tax, covering over 80% of Iras's total tax collections. Taxpayers can use their SingPass/CorpPass to log in, scan the QR code with their digital banking app, and complete the payment in real-time, with instant settlement and real-time status updates.

site_title: UK plans S$1.7b in building projects to boost economy
summary: The UK government plans to invest $2.34 billion in building projects, including 900 million pounds in a "Getting Building Fund" and 360 million pounds for homes on brownfield land. The projects aim to create 45,000 new homes and 85,000 jobs, helping to ease unemployment and generate revenue amid the country's worst recession in 300 years. The government also announced a Green Homes Grant programme, offering up to 10,000 pounds in energy efficiency grants for 600,000 homeowners.

site_title: White House adviser Navarro suggests Microsoft divest China holdings
summary: White House trade adviser Peter Navarro suggested Microsoft divest its China holdings if it were to buy TikTok, citing concerns over data security and potential compromise. The US President has agreed to give ByteDance 45 days to negotiate a sale of TikTok to Microsoft. Navarro stated that Microsoft's operations in China, including its 6,000 employees and partnerships, pose a national risk due to potential Chinese censorship, surveillance, and monitoring. This move comes as President Trump plans to ban TikTok in the US unless a sale is agreed upon.

images.alt_text: White House trade adviser Peter Navarro suggested on Monday that Microsoft Corp could divest its holdings in China if it were to buy the Chinese owned short-video app TikTok.

site_title: Singapore governance and transparency index hits new high
summary: The Singapore Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI) 2020 reached an all-time high score of 67.9 points, surpassing last year's score of 59.3. Despite the Covid-19 pandemic, Singapore-listed companies improved in corporate governance disclosures, measured by base scores, bonuses, and penalties. This marks a significant increase in governance and transparency.

site_title: Subaru forecasts weakest annual profit in 9 years due to coronavirus
summary: Subaru forecasts its annual operating profit to drop 62% to 80 billion yen (S$1.04 billion), its lowest in 9 years, due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on global car demand. The Japanese automaker expects a sales hit, particularly in the US, where coronavirus infections continue to climb. This is Subaru's biggest quarterly operating loss in nearly 11 years, with a 15.7 billion yen loss in the April-June quarter.

site_title: Facebook leases workspace at landmark New York building
summary: Facebook has leased all office space at the 1912 Beaux Arts Farley Building in Manhattan, a 67,820 sqm deal marking a major expansion of the company's NYC operations. The tech hub will allow Facebook to grow teams in NYC, with the leased space expected to open in late 2021. This reinforces NYC's position as the nation's second tech hub, with Facebook's NYC operations comprising over 4,000 employees, more than half of whom are engineers.

site_title: Hot stock: AEM Holdings surges 10% after H1 profit more than doubles
summary: AEM Holdings' shares surged 10% after the company reported a more than doubling in its first-half net profit to S$55.3 million. Revenue rose 81.7% to S$273.7 million, driven by higher sales orders from existing and new customers. The company has proposed a 25% interim dividend of five Singapore cents per share, up from two cents last year. AEM's stock has surpassed its 52-week high and is one of the most heavily traded counters on the Singapore bourse.

site_title: US 'cloud' supremacy has Europe worried about data
summary: Europe is concerned about data privacy as European companies increasingly rely on US tech giants for cloud services, potentially allowing American companies to control data. Deals have been announced with Google Cloud, Amazon Web Services, and Microsoft by companies such as Renault, Orange, Deutsche Bank, and Lufthansa. This trend may compromise data sovereignty, with experts warning that Europeans may be ceding control of their data to American tech giants. The reliance on US cloud services raises questions about data security and privacy.

images.alt_text: Renault, Orange, Deutsche Bank, and Lufthansa recently plumped for Google Cloud. Volkswagen signed up with Amazon Web Services. The French health ministry chose Microsoft to house its research data.

site_title: Venture firm Blackbird raises A$500m fund for Australia startups
summary: Blackbird Ventures, a prominent Australian venture firm, has raised its fourth fund, totaling A$500 million, marking its largest to date. The firm, which invested in Canva, a graphic design business valued at US$6 billion, has A$1.3 billion in committed capital. Blackbird's previous investments include A$261 million in 2018, with notable funding rounds led by the firm. This new fund increase is expected to support the growth of Australian startups, addressing the country's cash shortage despite its high potential for returns.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, extending the previous session's rally, driven by a cheap yen and gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.98% to 22,413.38, while the Topix index advanced 1.18% to 1,540.58.

site_title: Australia retail sales rise 2.7% in June but outlook muddy
summary: Australian retail sales rose 2.7% in June as shops reopened, but adjusted for inflation, sales slipped 3.4% in the June quarter, the largest drop since 2000. A second wave of coronavirus infections in Victoria has cast a cloud over the outlook. Consumer spending is expected to deteriorate further with Victoria declaring a "state of disaster" after a surge in infections since late June.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Keppel, SGX, Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust
summary: CapitaLand divested a 40% equity stake in a Guangzhou development unit for S$78.6 million. Keppel Corp shares fell 4.1% after analysts considered a potential lowered offer price for Temasek Holdings' partial offer.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain 2% on Wall Street rally, upbeat data
summary: Australian shares rose 2% on a tech-led Wall Street rally and strong manufacturing data, marking their best intraday session in two weeks. The Nasdaq Composite reached an all-time high overnight, driven by Microsoft's pursuit of TikTok's US operations. Investors also bet on further US stimulus as Congressional Democrats and White House negotiators made progress on a coronavirus relief bill.

site_title: CapitaLand Reits top corporate governance ranking
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust, CapitaLand Mall Trust, and Ascott Residence Trust topped the Singapore Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI) ranking of real estate investment trusts (Reits) and trusts. The index saw a 6.2-point increase in mean scores, from 78.6 to 84.8, marking an improvement in corporate governance. Reits and trusts generally outperformed companies in terms of governance, likely due to more comprehensive disclosures required under the Code on Collective Investment Schemes. 11 Reits and business trusts were excluded from the ranking due to various reasons.

site_title: US adds 46,321 Covid-19 cases in 24 hours: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US reported 46,321 new Covid-19 cases and 532 deaths in 24 hours, according to Johns Hopkins University. The country has now recorded 4,711,323 total cases and 155,366 deaths, making it the worst-hit country in the world. Despite President Trump's claim that the virus is "receding" in parts of the US, White House advisor Deborah Birx warned that the country is entering a new phase of the pandemic with rural areas at risk. Globally, over 18 million people have been infected and 680,000 have died.

images.alt_text: The United States added 46,321 new coronavirus cases in 24 hours on Monday, according to a tally by Johns Hopkins University.

site_title: iX Biopharma gets enhanced patent protection in the US for lead drug
summary: iX Biopharma has received a second notice of allowance from the US Patent and Trademark Office for its lead drug Wafermine, enhancing intellectual property protection until October 2030. This further secures the company's WaferiX delivery technology platform and Wafermine's market exclusivity. The patent protection increases Wafermine's attractiveness as an in-licensing asset, and the company has filed corresponding patent applications in other jurisdictions.

site_title: Korea's Noroo Holdings opens agri-solutions hub in Singapore
summary: Korea's Noroo Holdings has opened its global agriculture solutions hub in Singapore, driving innovation in the food industry. The hub, Noroo Singapore, has secured over S$1 million in revenue and imported close to a million canned food items in the last month. It brings hard-to-reach food items from around the world to Asia, including European Union-certified food from Ukraine, at a low cost. The hub aims to increase access to sustainable agriculture solutions, seeds, and indoor vertical farms for farmers in Southeast Asia, promoting food security and reducing reliance on middlemen.

site_title: More aerospace firms jettison jobs; further pain if pandemic drags on
summary: Aerospace firms Pratt & Whitney and Boeing in Singapore have cut jobs, with Pratt & Whitney laying off nearly 20% of its staff and Boeing letting go of a few positions. The layoffs are part of a larger trend in the sector, which may face further pain if the pandemic drags on. Analysts suggest that the aerospace industry must balance reducing its workforce with retaining skilled workers.

site_title: AIG posts US$7.9b loss driven by deal to unload risks
summary: American International Group (AIG) reported a $7.9 billion second-quarter loss due to a sale of a majority stake in a business of runoff policies and costs from the pandemic and civil unrest. The loss was $6.7 billion, largely offset by an adjusted net income of 66 cents per share, which beat analyst estimates. AIG's property-casualty business improved profitability, with a decrease in catastrophe costs and an adjusted accident year combined ratio of 94.9. The life and retirement operation declined 16% due to losses from private-equity investments and increased death benefits.

images.alt_text: American International Group Inc posted a US$7.9 billion second-quarter loss driven by the sale of a majority stake in a business of runoff policies, as well as costs from the pandemic and civil unrest.

site_title: ISEC Healthcare expects Q2 loss; 'significantly lower profit' for H1
summary: ISEC Healthcare, a medical eye care services provider, expects a net loss for the three months ended June 30, with a "significantly lower profit" for the first half of fiscal 2020. The loss is mainly due to an impairment loss of goodwill related to the general health services business segment.

site_title: Utico extends Hyflux offer deadline to Aug 30
summary: UTICO has extended the deadline of its proposed rescue deal for Singapore's Hyflux until August 30, allowing the company to accept the offer until the end of the month. The offer, valued at S$485 million, aims to save Hyflux from judicial management and provide the highest possible recovery for retail investors. A judicial manager application is expected to be filed by August 7, and Hyflux's acceptance of the offer before August 6 could strengthen its position.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Tuesday, tracking gains in Europe and the US. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.84%, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.25%. The rally comes after a drop in new infections in the city.

site_title: Irish factory activity rebounds in July from lockdown lows: PMI
summary: Ireland's manufacturing sector experienced its fastest growth in almost two years in July, rebounding from Covid-19 lockdown lows. The AIB IHS Markit manufacturing PMI survey showed a 57.3 reading, above 50, indicating growth. Output and new orders expanded at their fastest rates ever recorded, while the 12-month outlook remained subdued. This rebound comes despite Ireland's gradual reopening and ongoing restrictions, with the government advising against non-essential international travel and limiting gatherings.

site_title: EU's top diplomat urges delay in vote on Inter-American Development Bank chief
summary: EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell has urged a delay in the vote for the Inter-American Development Bank's new president due to the coronavirus pandemic and the US nomination of Mauricio Claver-Carone, a hawkish Latin America adviser to President Donald Trump. Borrell cited the lack of precedent for a US candidate and the potential for controversy, despite Claver-Carone being favored to win the September 12 election with support from at least 15 countries. A postponement would require the support of other countries, which may be difficult to achieve.

site_title: Aid talks continue as US CEOs urge Congress to help small businesses
summary: US business leaders, including Walmart, Facebook, and Starbucks, urged Congress to pass a new round of emergency spending to help small businesses affected by the coronavirus pandemic. The White House and Democratic leaders in Congress continued talks on a new aid package, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi calling the discussions "productive." However, Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer said issues remain outstanding, and a deal is unclear. The CEOs warned of a "catastrophic" impact on the economy and employment if aid is withheld, and the Treasury Department announced plans to borrow $1 trillion to support the economy.

site_title: JAL logs US$885m quarterly loss because of pandemic
summary: JAPAN AIRLINES (JAL) reported a quarterly net loss of US$885 million, its largest under a new accounting method, due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on air travel. Sales plummeted 78.1% to 76.4 billion yen, with international passenger traffic collapsing 98.6% and domestic traffic falling 86.7%. The company cited uncertainty surrounding the pandemic and expects domestic passenger demand to take more time to recover. JAL's rival ANA Holdings also reported a record net loss of 108.8 billion yen for the same period.

site_title: NZX partners with BNP Paribas to boost capital flows
summary: New Zealand's NZX stock exchange operator has partnered with BNP Paribas to boost offshore capital flows. BNP Paribas Securities Services aims to become a general clearing participant by mid-2021, enabling it to clear and settle transactions for itself and other market participants. This partnership is expected to offer a cost-effective solution for managing large trading volumes, and NZX sees it as an important endorsement of its markets development strategy. The partnership will introduce BNP Paribas' third-party clearing model to direct members in New Zealand and remote brokers.

site_title: South Africa's Eskom seeks to recover US$220m from Guptas, ex-bosses
summary: South Africa's state-owned power utility Eskom has issued summons to 12 former executives and the Gupta family, seeking to recover $220 million allegedly siphoned from the company in corrupt deals. The move targets those involved in "state capture" scandals under former President Jacob Zuma, which saw millions of dollars diverted through government and state agencies. The government has welcomed the action, calling it an "essential milestone" in the fight against corruption, with the main opposition party describing it as a "step in the right direction".

site_title: Spain's ex-king Juan Carlos heads for exile under corruption cloud
summary: Spain's former King Juan Carlos, 82, has announced he will go into exile amid corruption investigations, including allegations of receiving $100 million from Saudi Arabia. The decision comes after investigations in Switzerland and Spain, where media reports have exposed the murky management of funds allegedly paid to Juan Carlos. His son, King Felipe VI, accepted the decision, stating his father's historic importance in Spain and democracy. The ex-monarch's lawyer said he is not trying to escape justice and will remain available to prosecutors.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at open tracking Wall Street gains; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% to 2,500.57 on Tuesday, driven by gains from banks and semiconductor stocks, with AEM Holdings and iX Biopharma leading the gains. Healthcare stocks also saw significant movement, including Medtecs International and Hyphens Pharma. The STI's rally was partially offset by weaker performances from Singtel and Keppel Corp. The US stock market, including the Nasdaq and Dow Jones, also gained ground on Monday, with the Nasdaq reaching a fresh record.

site_title: Bleak outlook for US shale industry amid global drop in energy demand
summary: The US shale oil industry faces a bleak outlook due to a global drop in energy demand amid the coronavirus pandemic. Oil prices remain within a $2 range, making it difficult for US shale producers to post profitable results. The industry has struggled with over 190 bankruptcies since 2010, and a price of above $50 a barrel is needed for its viability. As global energy consumption shifts towards renewable sources, oil demand growth projections are being questioned, and the US shale industry's production is likely in terminal decline.

site_title: US spells out changes for Boeing 737 MAX to fly again
summary: US aviation regulators have outlined new requirements for the Boeing 737 MAX to fly again. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has identified changes to address the "unsafe condition" of the aircraft, including upgrades to an anti-stall system and modifications to a sensor system. New software and revised flight manuals are also required. The changes will be subject to a 45-day public comment period. The FAA will only permit the jet to fly again when it is satisfied with the model's safety concerns, following the grounding of the aircraft since March 2019 following two deadly crashes.

site_title: VIDEO: The Cutting Edge with Forrest Li
summary: Forrest Li, CEO and chairman of Sea, shared his entrepreneurial journey during a virtual forum. Sea, founded in 2009, has grown into a US$54.2 billion company from its early days as a games publisher. Li discussed the company's evolution into a regional heavyweight in gaming, e-commerce, and digital finance. The company went public on the New York Stock Exchange in 2017.

site_title: Oil rises more than 1% on hopes for economic recovery
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Monday, with Brent crude reaching $44.15 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude reaching $41.01 a barrel, driven by positive economic data from the US, Europe, and Asia. US manufacturing activity accelerated to its highest level in nearly 1-1/2 years, and a similar survey showed manufacturing activity across the euro zone expanded for the first time since early 2019. However, concerns about rising Covid-19 cases and oversupply from Opec's decision to lift supply cuts weighed on oil prices.

site_title: Back on track: Europe's fading night trains win reprieve
summary: Europe's night train network, once a quintessential travel experience, is experiencing a revival due to growing awareness of carbon emissions from air travel and shrinking airline sectors. France, Austria, and Sweden are leading the effort to restore overnight connections, with France aiming to relaunch routes by 2022. The French government plans to invest 20 million euros annually to keep night trains running, while Austria plans to invest 500 million euros to buy new trains. Industry participants acknowledge the need for innovation, citing concerns over confined spaces and limited passenger capacity.

site_title: HSBC's split personality is dragging it down
summary: HSBC reported a 57% decline in second-quarter adjusted pretax profit, missing estimates, and raised loan loss projections due to the Covid-19 pandemic. CEO Noel Quinn is considering accelerating restructuring plans, which could lead to 35,000 job losses. The bank faces geopolitical headwinds, with strained relations between the UK/US and China. To address these issues, some analysts suggest splitting the Asian business from the rest, potentially creating two separate companies with separate management teams and listings. This move could help HSBC satisfy government and legal expectations and potentially resume dividend payments.

site_title: Britain's struggling banks reveal its economic weakness
summary: Britain's biggest banks, HSBC, Barclays, Lloyds, and NatWest, are struggling with economic weakness, revealing significant loan losses due to the COVID-19 lockdowns. The banks have set aside huge sums to cover potential losses, with Lloyds and NatWest seeing over half of their market values wiped out. Analysts expect provisions to total $27 billion this year, with HSBC accounting for over a third. The UK's weak economy, high unemployment, and Brexit uncertainty are contributing factors, with unemployment expected to reach 9% by the end of the year.

site_title: UK to ditch 'outdated' rules to speed housing construction
summary: The UK Government plans to overhaul its planning rules to speed up housing construction, aiming to accelerate development in "growth" and "renewal" zones. The reforms will strip out bureaucracy, introduce a streamlined path to development, and enable smaller companies to compete with large corporations. However, the District Councils' Network has expressed skepticism, stating that the current system is not broken, but rather the funding and powers needed to build affordable and green homes are lacking. The changes are part of the government's "Build Build Build" initiative to boost the economy after the pandemic.

site_title: In pursuit of success and meaning: Sea founder shares his journey
summary: Forrest Li, founder of Sea Ltd, shares his entrepreneurial journey, citing Steve Jobs' 2005 commencement speech as a source of inspiration. Li replayed the speech daily to build confidence, eventually leaving his corporate job to become an entrepreneur. Li's advice to aspiring entrepreneurs emphasizes the importance of staying hungry and foolish to pursue success and meaning.

site_title: Europe: Manufacturing rebound, US stimulus hopes lift stocks
summary: European stocks rose 2.1% on Monday, driven by a modest expansion in euro zone manufacturing activity and hopes of fresh US stimulus. German stocks outperformed, rising 2.7%, after factory activity expanded for the first time since 2018. Automakers, miners, and construction firms led the gains, with carmakers up 3.8%. However, analysts expressed caution about a sustained recovery due to concerns about COVID-19 restrictions and employment cuts.

site_title: China tries to build a road to economic recovery
summary: China is attempting to boost its economy by investing in infrastructure projects, with a focus on construction and manufacturing. However, the country's increasing reliance on debt to fund these projects poses significant risks. As a result, China's economic recovery efforts are being hindered by concerns over debt levels and potential financial instability. The government's efforts to stimulate growth through large-scale projects may not be enough to offset the risks associated with its growing debt burden.

site_title: US luxury chain Lord & Taylor files for bankruptcy as retail market woes pile up
summary: Lord & Taylor, a US luxury department store chain, filed for bankruptcy protection as the coronavirus outbreak accelerates the demise of struggling retailers. Acquired by clothing rental startup Le Tote in a $100 million deal last year, both companies are seeking Chapter 11 protection from creditors. This move marks the latest setback for a company tracing its roots to 1826, amidst a retail market plagued by the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore's visitor arrivals in June sink to 2,200 from 1.6m a year ago
summary: Singapore's visitor arrivals in June plummeted to 2,200, a significant drop from 1.6 million in June 2019. Despite this, the average length of visitors' stays increased to 55.2 days, up from 3.6 days in 2019. The decline in arrivals is attributed to Stay-Home Notice requirements and medical tourism, which is expected to drive visitor numbers in the coming quarter as Covid-19 measures ease.

site_title: Data tools help Zalora, partners navigate Covid-19 changes
summary: Singapore retailers Zalora and its partners are leveraging data analytics to navigate the Covid-19 pandemic and stay ahead in the online shopping market. Data tools help them understand customer needs and make informed business decisions. The ability to quickly adapt to changing consumer behavior is crucial in this competitive landscape. By leveraging data, retailers can stay ahead of their competitors and drive business growth.

site_title: US issues alert about malware used by Chinese government
summary: The US Department of Homeland Security's Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has issued an alert about a type of malware known as Taidoor, linked to the Chinese government. The malware, used since 2008, is used in ongoing espionage to gain intelligence, particularly in sectors such as law, defense, and technology. The alert aims to "enable network defense and reduce exposure to Chinese government malicious cyber-activity." This comes as the US has been warning organizations about potential national security risks from China, including a recent investigation into TikTok's ownership by ByteDance.

images.alt_text: The US government issued an alert on Monday that a type of malware seen frequently by security researchers in the last decade is tied to the Chinese government, the latest in a series of American warnings about China's cyber capabilities this summer.

site_title: TikTok US ban? Creators and fans are hopping mad
summary: US President Donald Trump has sparked chaos on TikTok after announcing he may ban the video app, citing security concerns due to its Chinese parent company ByteDance. The move has sent influencers and fans into a frenzy, with many creating farewell videos and urging their followers to join other platforms like Instagram and YouTube. The app has become a crucial outlet for Generation Z activists and politically-minded young people, and its potential shutdown could have significant implications for the entertainment industry and advertising. Microsoft has resumed talks with ByteDance to address security concerns, offering some hope for the app's survival.

site_title: Emerging markets bear the brunt of Covid-19 pains
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has disproportionately affected emerging markets and developing economies (EMDEs), despite lower infection and death rates compared to the US and Europe. However, undercounting may contribute to the discrepancy. EMDEs face higher poverty rates, poorer healthcare, and fewer remote jobs, exacerbating the pandemic's economic and health consequences.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore stocks see a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with key events including NTT DC Reit's public offer being 9.8 times oversubscribed and Creative Technology warning of potential revenue shortfall. Meanwhile, the US stock market opens lower due to fresh tariffs on Canada, and London's Heathrow considers increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade. MAS and the PBOC also plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Microsoft in talks to buy TikTok's US operations from China's ByteDance
summary: Microsoft is in talks to acquire TikTok's US operations from China's ByteDance, a potential blockbuster deal that could reshape the social media industry. The US tech giant declared its interest after President Donald Trump reversed a planned ban of TikTok, giving the two firms 45 days to come to a deal. The acquisition would further inflame US-China relations.

site_title: Singapore's lowered dividend yield still outperforms region
summary: Singapore's lowered dividend yield remains attractive, outperforming the region at 4.4%, according to DBS' Janice Chua. Despite a 25% drop in market value, Singapore's dividend yield surpasses the MSCI World Index and MSCI Asia ex-Japan Index. Analysts expect corporate earnings to take a hit from the Covid-19 economic fallout, but dividend payouts are expected to fare better than elsewhere in the region.

site_title: Gold pauses after surge to record as week opens
summary: Gold surged to a record high in July, driven by a weaker US dollar, record low US real yields, and simmering geopolitical tensions. The metal rose 11% in July, its biggest monthly gain since 2012, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid the pandemic and economic uncertainty. Gold prices are expected to rise further, with some strategists predicting a potential top of $3,000 per ounce, driven by ongoing economic instability and easy monetary policies.

site_title: Trump's TikTok assault opens new front in US tech war with China
summary: The US is expanding its tech war with China by threatening to ban TikTok and other Chinese-owned apps. This move could significantly hinder access to global user data, a valuable resource in the modern internet economy. The US decision is likely to be followed by a similar pressure campaign against Huawei Technologies Co, as seen with some allies banning the company from 5G networks. The US action could have enormous ramifications for global economies, particularly those of the US and China.

site_title: US: Nasdaq climbs 1.5% to record close as stocks gain
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index reaching a record close of 10,902.80, up 1.5%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also gained, driven by Microsoft's 5.6% jump as it works towards a potential acquisition of TikTok. Analysts attribute the market's boost to the Federal Reserve's monetary easing programs, despite ongoing coronavirus concerns. Talks in Washington on a federal relief package are ongoing, with leading lawmakers far apart on a package.

site_title: Australia July house prices fall for 3rd month
summary: Australia's house prices fell 0.6% in July for the third consecutive month, weighed down by a coronavirus lockdown in Victoria. Despite a 7.1% increase from July last year, prices in the capital cities dropped 0.8% and Sydney fell 0.9%. The housing market has been insulated by record low interest rates, government support, and loan repayment holidays. However, with fiscal support set to taper and repayment holidays expiring, the medium-term outlook is uncertain, with potential for urgent sales to test the market's resilience.

site_title: Hyphens Pharma expands brand portfolio with hair-loss products
summary: Hyphens Pharma has acquired the trademarks for hair-loss products CG 210 and CG4S in Singapore and Malaysia, allowing it to sell and distribute the products in the two countries. The company, which already owns Ceradan and TDF Derma Formula, adds scalp care to its dermatology portfolio with the patented topical botanical hair growth-promoting agent. The products have demonstrated safety and efficacy in over 10 clinical studies and have sold over 2 million units worldwide, contributing to the company's revenue and profitability.

site_title: Travellers to Singapore must wear monitoring device if serving SHN at home
summary: Singapore authorities will require incoming travellers serving a 14-day stay-home notice (SHN) to wear an electronic monitoring device starting August 10. The device tracks the individual's location and sends notifications to authorities. Those aged 12 and below are exempt. The measure aims to enhance compliance and reduce Covid-19 transmission risk. The devices use GPS and 4G/Bluetooth signals, store no personal data, and have no voice or video-recording function.

site_title: Japan's ninja arts hold key to survival, says first winner of graduate degree
summary: Genichi Mitsuhashi, 45, becomes the world's first winner of a master's degree in ninja studies, emphasizing the practical survival techniques of Japan's covert warriors. Mitsuhashi, a black-clad ninja, was drawn to learn after being held at gunpoint in Brazil at 19. He now teaches martial and ninja arts, grows his own crops, and runs an inn in Iga, a city traditionally known as the home of many ninjas. Mitsuhashi advocates for a comprehensive approach to learning from ninjas, including self-defence and sustainable living.

images.alt_text: Genichi Mitsuhashi, a 45-year-old modern ninja, also grows his own crops - rice and vegetables - just as many of his predecessors, who sprang from peasantry in feudal times, did.

site_title: STI in 3rd straight session of retreat on fears of Covid-19 resurgence
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 44.91 points, or 1.78%, to 2,484.91 for the third straight day due to fears of a Covid-19 resurgence. The industrials-heavy index was dragged down by property and bank counters. Top loser Jardine Matheson fell 7.23% after missing earnings expectations, while top gainer UG Healthcare rose 14.57%. Regional markets were mixed, with the Hang Seng and KLSE falling, while Japan and China's equities advanced.

site_title: Hotel chain dodges existential crisis
summary: RedDoorz, a hotel chain, has successfully navigated the COVID-19 pandemic, avoiding an existential crisis despite significant challenges. Founder Amit Saberwal attributes the company's resilience to the timely funding round, which raised $70 million, and its ability to adapt and execute. RedDoorz initially focused on the unbranded hotel segment in South-east Asia, before expanding into the premium market. The company has since restructured its business, cut costs, and is now poised for a bright future as the travel industry recovers.

site_title: National Wages Council to reconvene this year
summary: The National Wages Council in Singapore will reconvene this year, following a meeting with the National Trades Union Congress and Singapore National Employers Federation to discuss the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on the labour market. Manpower Minister Josephine Teo emphasized the need for close consultation between workers and employers. The reconvening of the council comes as the labour market faces significant challenges due to the pandemic.

site_title: From plague to protein: Israeli firm seeks to put locusts on the menu
summary: An Israeli firm, Hargol Foodtech, is cultivating locusts for human consumption in the Golan Heights, aiming to provide a sustainable source of protein. The insects, which are kosher in some Jewish traditions, are raised in climate-controlled cages and sold as powder for use in food products. The company's goal is to overcome the "yuck" factor in Western markets, with plans to launch locust-enhanced pancake mix and smoothie powders worldwide. While kosher certification is required, some experts believe the product could become a viable alternative to traditional animal protein sources.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Suntec Reit announced the practical completion of its Melbourne office development, Olderfleet, with a long weighted average lease expiry of 11 years. The development is expected to enhance the Reit's income and improve earnings and distribution to unitholders. CapitaLand sold 40% of its equity stake in Guangzhou Kai Ke Xing Mao Real Estate Development to an unrelated purchaser for S$78.6 million. AEM Holdings reported a more than doubling in first-half net profit to S$55.3 million, with revenue rising 81.7% and proposed an interim dividend of 5 cents per share.

site_title: Collapse of UK retailer DW Sports puts 1,700 jobs at risk
summary: UK retailer DW Sports is expected to appoint administrators after closing 25 of its 75 retail sites due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company has 1,700 staff and will continue to trade during administration, with its gym operator DW Fitness First remaining unaffected. The move highlights the struggles of UK retailers, with 190 more businesses collapsing into administration since March, including Laura Ashley and Carluccio's.

site_title: Singapore sends strong signal on tax avoidance
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Finance has announced plans to introduce a 50% surcharge on tax avoidance arrangements, effective for adjustments made to tax assessments for Year of Assessment 2023 and subsequent years. This move aims to deter taxpayers from exploiting loopholes and sends a strong signal to the local and international community that tax avoidance will not be tolerated. The proposal is in response to increased scrutiny and pressure from developed countries and international organizations, and is seen as a timely and shrewd move to promote Singapore as a favored jurisdiction for doing business.

site_title: Dollar rallies after weakest month in a decade
summary: The US dollar rallied against a basket of rivals on Monday, recovering from its weakest monthly performance in a decade, with a 4% drop in July and a 10% decline from its March peak. Analysts attribute the rally to a squeezing out of crowded short positions and safe-haven demand amid rising geopolitical tensions between the US and China, as well as a lack of agreement on US fiscal stimulus.

site_title: EDBI invests in fraud protection firm Vesta to fuel its Asia-Pacific expansion
summary: EDBI has invested in Vesta, a fraud-protection fintech firm, to fuel its Asia-Pacific expansion. Vesta will use the funds to expand its fraud and approval enhancement platform across the region through a new regional headquarters in Singapore. The investment, combined with a recent US$125 million equity investment from Goldfinch Partners, will help the Portland-based firm enhance its services for telecommunications and e-commerce companies.

site_title: Natixis CEO departs as it reports Q2 loss
summary: Natixis, a French investment bank, reported a second consecutive quarterly loss of 57 million euros. The bank's board of directors appointed Nicolas Namias as the new CEO, replacing Francois Riahi. This comes after Natixis' Q2 loss, marking a significant challenge for the bank's management.

site_title: Could it get any worse in the US?
summary: US President Donald Trump's response to the COVID-19 pandemic and economic downturn has been widely criticized, with the country experiencing its worst economic quarter in 75 years, a 9.5% decline in GDP. Despite the dire situation, Trump has failed to come up with a coherent strategy to reverse the downturn and has instead suggested postponing the November election, which has been met with opposition from both Democrats and Republicans. The US has a welfare state that provides assistance to the unemployed and needy, but the numbers show a stark reality of widespread suffering, with thousands of jobless Americans roaming the streets and businesses shutting down.

site_title: July PMI turns positive, but employers' hiring sentiment still weak
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sentiment turned positive in July for the first time in six months, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 50.2 points. However, economists caution that this improvement may not translate to better hiring sentiment in the second half of 2020. The positive PMI is a moderate improvement, but it is unclear if it will lead to increased hiring by employers.

site_title: SocGen extends losing streak with 1.26b euro loss
summary: SocGen reported a 1.26 billion-euro loss in the second quarter due to charges at its trading unit, extending a losing streak. Equities-trading revenue declined 80% after structured products were hit for a second straight quarter. CEO Frederic Oudea is reducing risks and seeking to increase profitability while maintaining the bank's leading position in equity structured products. The bank expects to cut up to 450 million euros of costs by 2022. SocGen's stock fell 4.4% in early trading, with the bank's revenue from trading fixed-income securities, currencies, and commodities jumping 154% in the second quarter.

site_title: Construction spending falls to one-year low in June
summary: US construction spending fell to a one-year low in June, dropping 0.7% to $1.355 trillion, the lowest level since June 2019. Private construction projects declined 0.7%, while residential projects fell 1.5%, but nonresidential projects saw a 0.2% gain. Public construction projects also dropped 0.7%. The decline was lower than economists' forecast of a 1.0% rebound.

site_title: Temasek's offer for Keppel may stay but at a lower price: analysts
summary: Analysts are keeping their 'buy' calls on Temasek's potential partial offer for Keppel Corporation, despite cutting target prices due to the offer price possibly being lowered. This move is driven by the need for sector consolidation.

site_title: StanChart Singapore gets boost in presence with FTA backing
summary: Standard Chartered Bank Singapore has been designated as the country's first Significantly Rooted Foreign Bank (SRFB) under the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (FTA). This designation allows StanChart Singapore to establish more places of business in Singapore. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is also considering offering an additional full bank license via an enhanced SRFB framework. This move is expected to boost StanChart's presence in the country, potentially expanding its digital presence as well.

site_title: Singapore Fintech Festival back in December with round-the-clock events
summary: The Singapore Fintech Festival (SFF) is set to return in December with a hybrid online-offline platform featuring round-the-clock events. The festival, which was postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic, will now take place from Dec 7 to 11 and will include exhibitors from various fintech, urban solutions, and other sectors. The event aims to bring together the global innovation community and will feature keynote speakers, networking opportunities, and one-on-one virtual meetings. The festival's theme is "People and Talent," honoring individuals who have shown resilience amid challenges and created new opportunities.

site_title: Remote working trend a blip in office life, says Manulife US Reit
summary: Manulife US Reit, a US office real estate investment trust, expects US office workers to return to their cubicles despite the remote working trend. A survey during the pandemic showed only 2% of US workers preferred working from home full-time, citing the importance of physical office spaces for company branding, culture, and productivity. The Reit's distribution per unit rose 0.3% to 3.05 US cents for the first half of the year, with occupancy at 96.2% and a weighted average lease expiry of 5.7 years.

site_title: Schumer backs TikTok US operations sale
summary: US Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer backs a US company purchasing TikTok to protect users' data, citing concerns over Chinese Communist Party laws that may require data sharing with the government. Microsoft is prepared to discuss a potential purchase, with President Donald Trump giving ByteDance 45 days to negotiate a sale. White House trade adviser Peter Navarro suggests Microsoft could divest its Chinese holdings if it buys TikTok, raising concerns about potential compromise.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng reverses to losses in H1 2020 on Covid-19 impact
summary: Chip Eng Seng, a Singaporean property development and construction firm, reported a net loss of S$24.4 million in the first half of 2020, reversing from a net profit of S$15.2 million the previous year. The decline was attributed to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, with 42.5% of revenue lost due to closed construction sites. The firm expects the construction sector to remain challenging and has yet to resume work at most sites. Profit margins narrowed due to additional costs and disrupted supply chains.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia bags 97.23% of Tasek at close of offer
summary: Hong Leong Asia secured 97.23% of Tasek Corp Bhd shares through an unconditional voluntary takeover offer, as of the close of offer on August 3, 2020. The offer price was raised to RM5.80 per share, with the shares of Tasek Corp set to be suspended on August 11.

site_title: Suntec Reit announces completion of premium Melbourne office development
summary: Suntec Reit announced the completion of its premium Melbourne office development, Olderfleet, on July 31, 2020. The 58,000 sq m building features 56,000 sq m of office space and 2,000 sq m of retail space, with a pre-commitment of 97% and a five-year rent guarantee. The development is expected to enhance the Reit's income and earnings, with long weighted average lease expiries and annual rental escalations of 3.5-4%. Income commencement is expected to occur this month.

site_title: CGS-CIMB drops target price on loss-making AirAsia X to zero
summary: CGS-CIMB has cut its target price on AirAsia X Berhad to zero, downgrading the budget carrier to "reduce" following its dismal first-quarter results. The airline posted a net loss of RM549.7 million, a 10-fold increase from the same period last year, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Revenue fell 21% and seat capacity decreased. The brokerage believes the company's survival depends on securing a new RM500 million bank loan, but this is unlikely due to lack of shareholder support.

site_title: Changes to Indonesia's foreign ownership of property could give it US$10b annual boost
summary: Indonesia's government has tabled a draft law that would allow foreign investors to purchase and own strata-titled apartments and condominiums in the country, potentially injecting $5-10 billion into the economy annually. The Omnibus Bill aims to ease doing business in Indonesia and cut red tape, with changes expected to boost foreign investment in the property sector. Regions such as Bali, Jakarta, Batam, and Lombok are expected to benefit from foreign investor interest, with analysts predicting a multiplier effect through increased tax revenues, jobs, and economic growth.

site_title: Indian restaurant offers 'Covid curry' to scared customers
summary: An Indian restaurant in Jodhpur, India, is attempting to reassure customers about eating out during the pandemic with a "Covid Curry" and "Mask Naans". The fried vegetable balls are shaped like the coronavirus, while the breads resemble surgical masks. The restaurant claims the curry has extra Indian herbs and spices that are good for health. Despite relaxed curbs, customers remain fearful of eating out, with the country reporting over 1.8 million cases and 38,000 deaths from the virus.

site_title: ESG gains traction in China as foreign investor base expands
summary: China's awareness of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues has increased due to government initiatives and foreign investor participation. Foreign investors' holdings of Chinese equities reached a record of 1.77 trillion yuan in 2019.
