The Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect programme and lifting of foreign investment restrictions in 2019 have contributed to China's equity markets' expansion onto the international stage, propelling ESG issues to the forefront.

site_title: US manufacturing expands at fastest pace since March 2019
summary: US manufacturing expanded in July at the fastest pace since March 2019, with the Institute for Supply Management's gauge increasing to 54.2 from 52.6. This marks the first expansion since March 2019, driven by firmer orders and lean inventories. The production gauge rose to 62.1, the highest level since August 2018, while the orders gauge climbed to 61.5, the strongest since September 2019. However, the pace of improvement risks moderating due to ongoing coronavirus challenges and high unemployment nationwide.

site_title: Keppel shareholders should 'hope for the best, prepare for the worst' on Temasek's offer
summary: Keppel Corp posted a record quarterly loss of S$697 million due to huge impairments, breaching a key metric for Temasek Holdings' S$4 billion partial offer. The loss is a significant concern, with Keppel's cumulative PAT for the 12 months ending June 2020 standing at a negative S$165 million. Temasek must decide on invoking the Material Adverse Change clause by Aug 31, potentially walking away from the deal. Analysts speculate that Temasek may stick to its original plan to raise its Keppel stake to a majority holding, but a deal at the current price tag may be challenging.

site_title: LMIRT completes divestment of Binjai Supermall for 262b rupiah
summary: LMIRT completes the divestment of Binjai Supermall for 262 billion rupiah (S$24.5 million). The transaction is part of the revised conditional sale-and-purchase agreement, with 10% of the consideration held in an escrow account and 5.4% refundable deposit returned to the buyer. This divestment, along with the recent Pejaten Village sale, brings LMIRT's total retail malls to 21 and major retail spaces to seven in Indonesia.

site_title: Singapore's PMI turns positive for the first time in 6 months
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector showed signs of improvement, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) turning positive for the first time in 6 months in July, rising to 50.2 points. However, economists caution that this may not translate into improved hiring sentiment, citing a continued contraction in the employment and supplier deliveries indices. The electronics sector PMI also edged up to 49.2 points, but remains in contraction territory. Experts predict a modest increase in manufacturing momentum, but warn that the outlook remains soft due to global supply disruptions and trade uncertainty.

site_title: Google to invest US$450m to acquire 6.6% stake in ADT
summary: Google to invest US$450 million to acquire a 6.6% stake in home security firm ADT, partnering to combine Google Nest hardware products with ADT's installation, service, and professional monitoring network.

site_title: Marathon posts smaller loss than feared, points to improved demand
summary: US oil refiner Marathon Petroleum posted a smaller-than-expected quarterly loss of $868 million, or $1.33 per share, due to recovering demand for gasoline and other products. The company's adjusted loss was better than analysts' estimate of a $1.75 loss. The sale of its Speedway gas stations to Japan's Seven & i for $21 billion is expected to close in 2021 and will help strengthen Marathon's balance sheet. Despite a large debt of $32 billion outstanding through 2025, Marathon's shares rose 6% after the announcement.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson spray approved for suicidal people
summary: Johnson & Johnson's Spravato, a nasal spray, has been approved by the FDA as the first antidepressant for people with suicidal thoughts and a plan to act on them. The approval applies to 11-12% of Americans with major depressive disorder, and Spravato has been used by about 6,000 people for treatment-resistant depression since its approval in 2019. The decision to study Spravato in depressed people actively contemplating suicide was made to capitalize on its quick-acting properties, which may differ from older antidepressants.

site_title: Google debuts US$349 Pixel 4a after pandemic delay
summary: Google has launched the Pixel 4a smartphone at a price of US$349, the successor to its budget-friendly Pixel 3a. The device features a 5.8-inch OLED display, 6GB of RAM, 128GB of storage, and a high-quality camera, similar to the Pixel 4. The phone's affordable price aims to expand Google's audience and boost sales, following a 52% increase in Pixel shipments in 2019. A 5G version of the Pixel 4a is also planned for release in the fall, along with a new high-end model, the Pixel 5.

site_title: UOB launches digital bank TMRW in Indonesia
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has launched its digital bank TMRW in Indonesia, following its initial launch in Thailand in 2019. The bank aims to provide a fully digital banking experience to Indonesia's digitally savvy consumers, with a user-friendly account-opening process and 24/7 chatbot support. TMRW's features include QR code payments and a game-based savings approach, designed to be fun and non-judgmental, to help users meet their financial goals. The bank seeks to capture a S$10 billion market opportunity in ASEAN, with Indonesia's 96% mobile phone ownership rate seen as a key advantage.

site_title: TA Corp expects 'significant net loss' for H1 2020
summary: TA Corp, a property and construction firm, expects a "significant net loss" for the first half of 2020 due to the impact of Covid-19 measures on its businesses. The company will disclose its financial performance within 45 days. The announcement follows a preliminary assessment of its unaudited results for the six months ended June 30.

site_title: Vatican says ex-pope's condition 'not particularly worrying'
summary: The Vatican clarified that former pope Benedict's condition is "not particularly worrying" and that he is overcoming an acute phase of a painful but not grave ailment. Benedict, 93, has been in frail health for some time and was recently diagnosed with shingles, a viral infection common among older people, according to his biographer. The Vatican's statement came after reports suggested the ex-pope's condition was serious.

site_title: US: Earnings, Microsoft boost Wall St as investors await stimulus
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Monday as Microsoft's strong earnings and upbeat quarterly reports lifted sentiment, despite a lack of a fiscal coronavirus relief deal. The Dow Jones rose 0.43%, the S&P 500 gained 0.52%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.96%. Investors appear to be brushing off recent Trump threats, focusing instead on the pursuit of Microsoft's TikTok operations.

site_title: Philippines fears for economy, income as tough lockdown returns
summary: The Philippines is set to reimpose a strict lockdown in Manila and nearby provinces for two weeks due to a surge in COVID-19 cases. The measure is expected to significantly impact the economy and incomes, following a previous lockdown that pushed the country to the brink of recession. The lockdown is being implemented to prevent a collapse of the healthcare system, which is struggling to cope with the rising cases. The move is seen as a drastic measure to halt the spread of the virus and revive the economy, which had been one of Asia's fastest-growing economies before the pandemic.

site_title: Tyson Foods names former Alphabet employee new CEO
summary: Tyson Foods has named Dean Banks, a former Alphabet employee, as its new CEO, replacing Noel White in October. Banks joins Tyson after serving as a project lead at Alphabet's 'X' division. The company is navigating production challenges due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with sales falling to $10.02 billion in the third quarter. Despite this, the company beat analysts' estimates, earning $1.40 per share excluding items. Banks' appointment comes as the meat industry struggles to restore normal production levels due to worker absenteeism.

site_title: Asean PMIs show normalisation but far from sustained recovery: Barclays
summary: Southeast Asia's purchasing managers' indices (PMIs) show signs of normalisation but a sustained recovery remains elusive, according to Barclays Research. The region's PMIs improved in July, but confidence in the business environment remains low, and domestic demand remains weak. Indonesia and Thailand saw improvement, but Thailand's reopening has been slow due to weak domestic demand. The Philippines' manufacturing PMI declined to 48.4, and Malaysia's PMI hovered around the 50 level, with a slight decrease in July. A rate cut in Malaysia signals growth jitters amid tariff threats.

site_title: Clorox names longtime executive CEO, beats estimates on pandemic-led demand
summary: Clorox named Linda Rendle as CEO, beating quarterly estimates due to the surge in demand for disinfectant and cleaning products during the pandemic. The company's health and wellness division saw a 33% sales increase, accounting for over 40% of total sales. This boom in sales is attributed to people focusing on cleaning their homes, hands, and goods during lockdowns.

site_title: STI closes 1.78% lower on Monday, dragged by JMH
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.78% on Monday, closing at 2,484.91 points, for the third straight day. The decline was driven by fears of a Covid-19 resurgence globally and weaker US markets in August. Jardine Matheson Holdings (JMH) was the top loser, falling 7.23% after its first-half net profit missed expectations. However, some counters, such as UG Healthcare and Medtecs International, rose, with UG Healthcare gaining 14.57%.

site_title: CapitaLand pares stake in Guangzhou development unit for S$78.6m
summary: CapitaLand has sold 40% of its stake in Guangzhou Kai Ke Xing Mao Real Estate Development (GKK) to an unrelated buyer for S$78.6 million. GKK owns a mixed-use site in Guangzhou, China, with plans for an integrated development. The sale is part of a series of transactions by CapitaLand and other shareholders. The sale does not affect the development plans, which remain unchanged.

site_title: Money Hacks: Why sticking to an asset allocation framework is key in volatile times (Ep 77)
summary: Asheesh Chanda, founder and CEO of Kristal.AI, emphasizes the importance of sticking to an asset allocation framework during volatile times. He identifies four key pillars for asset classes and allocation, including building discipline and avoiding emotional investing. Chanda also discusses the benefits of passive investment approaches for beginner investors, advising against active approaches. The conversation highlights the need for financial discipline and adaptability in navigating uncertain market conditions, particularly during the COVID-19 era.

site_title: Singapore Fintech Festival returns in December with round-the-clock virtual and physical events
summary: The Singapore Fintech Festival and Singapore Week of Innovation and Technology will return in December with a hybrid online-offline platform, featuring round-the-clock events. The festival, running from Dec 7-11, will include exhibitors in various areas, networking opportunities, and keynote speakers discussing hot-button issues such as financial inclusion and sustainability. Physical events will also be held in certain cities to showcase local initiatives and start-ups. The event aims to bring together the global innovation community despite travel and meeting constraints, with a focus on "People and Talent" and engaging the African fintech community.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Standard Chartered Bank Singapore is set to boost its presence in the city-state following the recent EU-Singapore free trade agreement. Singapore's visitor arrivals plummeted to 2,200 in June, a significant drop from 1.6 million last year. Thakral Corporation has acquired land in Australia to expand its retirement resort portfolio, while UOB launched its digital bank TMRW in Indonesia. Pratt & Whitney is trimming 20% of its Singapore headcount, citing a need to streamline operations. The Straits Times Index fell 1.78% on Monday, closing at 2,484.91 points.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 31.14 points to 1,572.61. Losers outnumbered gainers 707 to 505, with a total trading volume of 13.129 billion lots worth RM8.241 billion.

site_title: Northern Irish Nobel Peace Prize winner John Hume dies
summary: Northern Irish politician John Hume, Nobel Peace Prize winner in 1998, has died at 83 after a short illness. Hume, former leader of the SDLP, shared the prize with David Trimble for helping forge the 1998 Good Friday peace agreement. His death is described as a "historic moment of deep sadness" by SDLP leader Colum Eastwood, marking the loss of a significant figure in Ireland's 20th-century politics.

site_title: Japan's Seven & i seals US$21b deal for Marathon Petroleum's Speedway gas stations
summary: Japan's Seven & i Holdings has agreed to buy Marathon Petroleum Corp's Speedway gas stations for US$21 billion, marking one of the biggest deals this year. The acquisition will help Seven & i expand beyond Japan, where its stores face shrinking population, economic growth, and price competition. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the deal suggests global dealmaking is not entirely halted. The move will shift Seven & i's focus to international markets.

site_title: Chinese tech stocks soar as US measures spur support hopes
summary: Chinese tech stocks surged 7.3% on Monday, driven by expectations of US support for Chinese-owned software companies. The gains come amid signs that the US may ban TikTok and other apps deemed national-security risks. US Secretary of State Michael Pompeo's comments suggest a possible widening of US measures. Investors believe China will step up support in the technology sector to boost domestic development, lifting related shares. Key companies including ByteDance, Guangdong Advertising Group, and Shunya International Martech saw significant gains.

images.alt_text: Mainland-listed technology shares surged on Monday, driven by expectations of support from Beijing in response to US moves on Chinese-owned software companies.

site_title: WHO: There may never be a Covid-19 'silver bullet'
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) stated that there may never be a single "silver bullet" answer to the Covid-19 pandemic, despite efforts to develop effective vaccines. WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus expressed this sentiment during a virtual press conference, indicating that a comprehensive approach to combating the virus is more likely.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end in red
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed in red on Monday, falling 0.56% to 24,458.13 due to investor concerns over China-US tensions and rising virus infections. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.75% and the Shenzhen Composite Index jumped 2.60%.

site_title: Singapore's visitor arrivals in June sink to 2,200
summary: Singapore's visitor arrivals plummeted to 2,200 in June, down from 1.6 million a year ago, with a total of 2.7 million for the first half of the year remaining unchanged from the previous year. Overnight visitors declined to 1,800, but the average length of stays increased to 55.2 days. The decline in visitor arrivals is attributed to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, which has significantly impacted the tourism industry.

site_title: Japan retailer Nojima bets on longevity as population shrinks
summary: Japan retailer Nojima has introduced a policy allowing its 3,000 regular employees to stay on the job until 80, defying Japan's fast-ageing and shrinking population. The policy, which began last month, is part of a broader effort to utilize senior workers as the labor force contracts. Nojima's executive director sees the policy as beneficial to customers, citing the importance of elderly staff providing courteous service to older customers. The move is seen as a potential solution to Japan's aging workforce, with 28% of the population aged 65 or older.

site_title: AEM's net profit more than doubles on higher revenue
summary: AEM Holdings reported a 151% increase in first-half net profit to S$55.3 million, driven by higher revenue and operational cost-efficiency. Revenue rose 81.7% to S$273.7 million, with all business segments experiencing higher sales orders. The company proposed a 25% payout of 5 cents per share in interim dividend. AEM revised its FY20 revenue guidance upwards to S$460-480 million and increased R&D spend by S$4.2 million in the second half to support new projects.

site_title: Microsoft says in talks to buy TikTok's US operations from China's ByteDance
summary: Microsoft is in talks to acquire TikTok's US operations from China's ByteDance, a potential blockbuster deal that could reshape the social media industry. The move comes after US President Donald Trump reversed a planned ban of TikTok, giving Microsoft 45 days to come to a deal. The proposed acquisition would offer Microsoft a chance to become a major competitor to Facebook and Snap, and ByteDance has started talks with a tech company, according to an internal letter. The deal would also allow ByteDance to avoid divesting its US operations, which the US government had deemed a national security risk.

site_title: Euro zone factory activity bounced back to growth in July
summary: Euro zone factory activity expanded for the first time since early 2019 in July, rebounding after restrictions were eased to combat the coronavirus. The manufacturing activity index rose to 51.8, its first time above the 50 mark since January 2019, driven by a surge in demand. The European economy contracted 12.1% last quarter, but the recovery is expected to continue, with production growing at the fastest rate in over two years. However, policymakers remain concerned about factory headcounts, which reduced at a sharp rate.

site_title: 226 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including prison inmate and 9 imported
summary: There were 226 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, bringing the total to 53,051, as of Monday noon. The cases include one community case and 9 imported cases, with a prison inmate also confirmed, who had arrived before border measures were implemented. The inmate was tested as part of the Singapore Prison Service's proactive screening.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb, London steady at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 index increasing 0.6% to 12,390.33 points and Paris's CAC 40 adding 0.3% to 4,798.38. London's FTSE 100 index remained steady at 5,897.09 points. The rally follows overnight gains in Tokyo.

site_title: Suzuki Q1 profit nearly wiped out as coronavirus hits India sales
summary: Suzuki Motor Corp reported its worst quarterly operating profit on record due to plummeting car demand in India, its largest market, affected by the novel coronavirus. The company's operating profit was 1.3 billion yen, higher than a forecasted loss, but it booked an extraordinary loss of 15.4 billion yen due to factory shutdowns. Suzuki secured 400 billion yen in financing to help it navigate the pandemic, and declined to forecast full-year profit and dividends citing uncertainties. The company's global vehicle sales dropped 64% in April-June, with India accounting for nearly half of its global car sales.

site_title: Australia's Infigen forecasts 'materially lower' earnings
summary: Infigen Energy, an Australian takeover target, forecasts "materially lower" earnings due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on wholesale electricity prices. The company suspended dividend payments indefinitely and expects a return to normal conditions once the pandemic is contained. Oversupply of electricity, exacerbated by maintenance delays, is also affecting revenue. Infigen supports Iberdrola's bid, with the Spanish company increasing its offer price to A$0.92 per share.

site_title: JAL logs US$885m quarterly loss on pandemic
summary: Japan Airlines reported a quarterly net loss of $885 million due to the pandemic's halt on air travel worldwide. The company's net loss for April-June was 93.7 billion yen (S$1.22 billion), a significant decrease from a quarterly profit of 12.9 billion yen in the same period last year. Quarterly sales plummeted 78.1% to 76.4 billion yen. The airline cited deep uncertainty surrounding the pandemic and said the pickup of international travel remained "unforeseeable."

site_title: At least 40 infected with Covid-19 on Norway cruises amid scramble to trace passengers
summary: At least 40 passengers and crew on a luxury cruise liner, MS Roald Amundsen, have tested positive for Covid-19. The ship, which operated Arctic voyages, has been tracing passengers from two recent trips. Four crew members were hospitalized, and 32 more staff members were infected. The Norwegian Institute of Public Health is seeking to verify information from passengers, who have been told to self-isolate. The ship is scheduled to sail around the British Isles in September, and authorities are working to contain the outbreak to limit its spread.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on US rallies, cheap yen
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday, ending a six-day losing streak, as investors took heart from US rallies and a cheaper yen. The Nikkei 225 index gained 2.24% to 22,195.38, while the Topix index rose 1.78% to 1,522.64. This follows Wall Street's gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Squat electric for teens shakes up battle for Paris's streets
summary: Paris is introducing the Citroen Ami, an electric vehicle with a top speed of 45 km/h and room for two passengers, allowing 14-year-olds to drive it. The vehicle is part of a battle among four major European automakers for dominance in the French capital's car-sharing market, where car-sharing fees are cents per minute. The service, Free2Move, targets profitability by the start of next year and aims to appeal to urban consumers in line with Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo's environmental platform.

site_title: Quarz Capital's recent trail of activist calls
summary: Activist investor Quarz Capital Management has been actively engaging with listed companies in Singapore, including Sabana Reit, Teckwah Industrial, Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-HTrust), and SingPost. Quarz has raised stakes in these companies, criticizing their management and calling for improvements, such as increased cash returns to shareholders and mergers to enhance value. The firm has also recommended divestitures and one-off cost reporting to improve transparency. Its efforts have led to changes in some companies, including the merger of A-HTrust and Ascott Reit, and the sale of struggling subsidiaries by SingPost.

site_title: SocGen posts second quarterly loss in a row
summary: Societe Generale (SocGen) reported a 1.26 billion euros second-quarter loss due to a writedown on its trading business and increased provisions for loans impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic. The bank's revenue dropped 15.7% to 5.3 billion euros, with a review of its Global Markets unit leading to a 1.34 billion euros impairment. SocGen plans to reduce the risk profile of its trading unit, resulting in 200-250 million euros in lost revenue.

site_title: Chinese beer lovers leave facemasks and worries behind as festival opens
summary: China's Qingdao beer festival opened with thousands of attendees, marking a return to pre-pandemic normalcy. Despite the global pandemic, the event was held with limited capacity, mask-wearing staff, and health checks. The festival, which runs until late August, features over 1,500 types of beer and allows attendees to socialize and enjoy live shows and fireworks. The event is seen as a chance for people to "go back to normal life and clink glasses," with many revellers expressing happiness and relaxation.

site_title: Millions return to lockdown in Philippines as virus cases soar
summary: The Philippines has announced a two-week lockdown in the capital city of Manila and surrounding provinces due to a surge in coronavirus cases, with over 27 million people affected. The lockdown, which will restrict public transport and domestic flights, aims to slow the spread of the virus, which has killed over 2,000 people. The government has blamed poor compliance with restrictions for the increase in infections, which have been concentrated in Manila and Cebu.

site_title: Victory Point in Balestier up for sale again with lower guide price of S$13.5m
summary: Victory Point, a mixed-use development in Singapore's Balestier Conservation Area, is being relaunched for sale via public tender at a guide price of S$13.5 million. The freehold development, comprising a shophouse and a six-storey apartment block, sits on a 3,463 sq ft site zoned for commercial and residential use. The property has "potential for strong capital value and rental upside" and may be attractive to co-living operators and businesses seeking contiguous space, with a tender closing on Sept 14.

site_title: National Wages Council to reconvene this year amid Covid-19's rising toll on Singapore jobs
summary: The National Wages Council (NWC) in Singapore will reconvene this year amid the rising toll of the Covid-19 pandemic on jobs. Manpower Minister Josephine Teo announced the decision after meeting with union and employer representatives. The council's recommendations, released earlier this year, aimed to protect 150,000 jobs from layoffs, with many employers implementing flexible work schedules and supporting workers with reduced pay to find additional income. Unemployment rates rose to 2.9% in June, with retrenchments more than doubling in the second quarter.

site_title: Grab snags US$200m from S Korean private equity firm
summary: Grab Holdings, the South-east Asian ride-hailing leader, has snagged US$200 million from Seoul-based private equity firm Stic Investments. Stic will invest US$100 million from one of its funds and co-investors will contribute the remainder. This deal comes despite the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on consumer businesses, allowing Grab to continue funding its services. Grab has raised over US$10 billion to date, valuing it at US$14.3 billion. Stic Investments, with US$4.5 billion under management, has invested in companies like BTS and Masan Group, expanding its presence in the region.

site_title: Lord & Taylor files for bankruptcy as retail collapses pile up
summary: Lord & Taylor, a 192-year-old department store, filed for bankruptcy protection as the coronavirus outbreak accelerates the demise of struggling retailers. The company, acquired by clothing rental startup Le Tote for $100 million last year, is seeking Chapter 11 protection from creditors. Lord & Taylor operates 38 locations, which have been temporarily closed since March 2020. This filing marks the latest in a string of retail bankruptcies amid the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Lord & Taylor, the floundering department store company that traces its roots to 1826, on Sunday became the latest retailer to file for bankruptcy protection as the coronavirus outbreak accelerates the demise of chains that were already teetering.

site_title: National Service as a Criteria for Success
summary: Goh Seng Wee, Co-Founder & Managing Director of Brain-Too-Free Ventures, emphasizes the importance of National Service (NS) in shaping individuals for success. As a former NSman, he credits his NS training for developing his business approach, leadership skills, and adaptability. Goh believes that NS performance records can be a reliable indicator of a person's potential to excel in various roles, including entrepreneurship. He advocates for promoting a NS-friendly culture and supporting National Service, as exemplified by his own company's NS Mark (Gold) accreditation and recognition at the Total Defence Awards.

site_title: Cameroon tomato farmers count losses to wild weather and lockdown
summary: Cameroon's tomato farmers are facing significant losses due to wild weather and the country's coronavirus lockdown. Heavy rainfall and drought have cut harvests, while lockdowns have made it difficult to transport and sell produce, driving down prices. Farmers have struggled to recover loans and are concerned about the impact on their livelihoods, with estimates suggesting losses of up to 90% in some areas. The government has promised support, but farmers say they need state subsidies to stay in business, and the lack of accurate weather information has exacerbated the crisis.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat as investors brace for business closures
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Monday due to investor concerns over potential business closures amid the ongoing pandemic. The country's second-largest city Melbourne imposed a nightly curfew, while neighboring states increased precautions. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.03% to 5,926.1 points, reflecting investor sentiment. The move comes as investors weigh the impact of strict movement restrictions on the country's economic recovery.

site_title: Travellers to Singapore must wear monitoring device if serving SHN at home
summary: Singapore authorities announced that from August 10, all incoming travellers serving a 14-day stay-home notice (SHN) outside dedicated facilities will need to wear an electronic monitoring device. The device tracks the individual's location using GPS and 4G/Bluetooth signals, and will send notifications to authorities if the person attempts to leave their residence or tamper with the device. Those aged 12 and below are exempt, and the device will not store personal data or have voice/video-recording capabilities. The measure aims to enhance compliance with SHN regulations and reduce the risk of COVID-19 transmission.

site_title: Indonesia's July inflation rate eases to 1.54%: stats bureau
summary: Indonesia's inflation rate eased to 1.54% in July, the lowest since May 2000, according to data from the country's statistics bureau. This is below Bank Indonesia's target range of 2-4% for 2020. The annual core inflation rate also decreased to 2.07%. The decline is attributed to sluggish consumption amid the novel coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: US engine maker Pratt & Whitney trims about 20% of Singapore headcount
summary: Pratt & Whitney, a US engine maker, has announced a 20% reduction in its Singapore headcount, primarily affecting foreign workers. The move, which will impact around 400 employees, is part of the company's efforts to adapt to the prolonged recovery timeline for commercial aviation. The affected employees will receive support, including job fairs and employability workshops, and will be eligible for union membership benefits. The company cited prolonged recovery timelines and cost-containment measures, such as temporary pay cuts, as reasons for the layoffs.

site_title: Japan's ninja arts hold key to survival, says first winner of graduate degree
summary: Japan's first master's degree graduate in ninja studies, Genichi Mitsuhashi, 45, credits the martial arts with holding the key to survival after a life-threatening experience in Brazil at 19. Mitsuhashi completed a two-year program on ninja history, traditions, and survival techniques at Mie University. Like many historical ninjas, he grows his own crops and teaches martial arts at his dojo, promoting a comprehensive way of life that includes self-defense, sustainability, and humility.

site_title: India's factory activity contracted at a sharper pace in July
summary: India's factory activity contracted at a sharper pace in July, with the Nikkei Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index falling to 46.0 from 47.2 in June, marking its longest spell of contraction since March 2009. Renewed lockdown measures due to surging coronavirus cases weighed on demand and output, raising the chances of a sharper economic contraction. The economy is expected to shrink at its sharpest pace since 1979 this fiscal year, with business optimism about the coming 12 months hitting a five-month high in July.

site_title: How to propel retail adoption of AI in SEA
summary: Southeast Asia's retail sector can benefit from AI adoption, with 44% of consumers spending more on online grocery purchases during quarantine. However, only 67% of retailers have integrated AI into their business models, making it a competitive disadvantage. To address this, businesses must invest in AI solutions, establish AI hubs, and create an enabling culture. Countries like Singapore are already investing heavily in AI innovation, and policymakers and industry players must work together to address ethical, legal, and security issues. By doing so, retailers can drive long-term growth and stay competitive in the region.

site_title: UK engineer Senior posts loss as pandemic, Boeing's 737 crisis weigh
summary: UK engineer Senior Plc reported a first-half loss due to higher costs and reduced sales from the coronavirus pandemic and Boeing's 737 MAX crisis. The company, which counts Boeing and Caterpillar as major customers, has implemented layoffs and furloughs to cope with the crisis. Senior has shelved its interim dividend, citing the need to conserve resources. The company's struggles are part of a broader downturn in the air industry and manufacturing sector.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end flat as stalled US stimulus offsets data optimism
summary: South Korean stocks closed flat on Monday, driven by dented hopes of a new US stimulus plan and rising coronavirus cases. Despite optimism over domestic data, the benchmark Kospi rose 1.67 points to 2,251.04. White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows expressed skepticism about reaching a stimulus agreement soon, offsetting positive data.

site_title: Japan Q1 GDP unchanged at 2.2% annualised contraction after 2nd revision
summary: Japan's economy contracted 2.2% annually in Q1, unchanged after a second revision, according to the Cabinet Office. The quarterly contraction was 0.6%, also unchanged, and below economists' median forecast of 0.7%. The revisions were made due to revised capital spending data from the finance ministry, which had fewer respondents due to coronavirus disruptions. The data reflects the ongoing impact of the pandemic on Japan's economy.

site_title: Hong Kong government's election delay may be unlawful: bar association
summary: The Hong Kong government's decision to postpone the city's legislature election by a year, citing public health concerns, may be unlawful according to the city's bar association. The election, postponed by emergency legislation, would have been the city's first official vote since Beijing imposed a sweeping security law. The postponement has sparked concerns over democratic freedoms in Hong Kong.

site_title: HSBC reports 69% drop in first-half profit
summary: HSBC Holdings PLC reported a 65% drop in first-half pre-tax profit to $4.32 billion, lower than analysts' estimates of $5.67 billion. The bank's credit impairment provisions surged to $6.9 billion, driven by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on businesses. HSBC warned of a hit to its core capital ratio and expects total provisions against bad debts to be between $8 billion to $13 billion in 2020. The bank's revenues fell 9% in the six-month period, and CEO Noel Quinn stated that the bank will monitor the implications on its business plan and dividend policy amid high uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Monday; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) slipping 0.6% to 2,515.90. The decline follows the previous week's trend. Genting Singapore was the most active counter, falling 2% after naming Winston Hauw Sze Shiung to its board. The decline in STI is attributed to no specific reason mentioned in the article.

site_title: Oil edges lower on oversupply concerns as Opec+ set to raise output
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday as concerns over oversupply and a potential slowdown in fuel demand due to the COVID-19 pandemic weighed on prices. Opec+ is set to raise output in August, adding 1.5 million barrels per day to global supply. Brent crude futures slid 8 cents to $43.44 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 12 cents to $40.15 a barrel. The Opec+ decision is expected to encourage US shale producers to ramp up output, further contributing to the supply glut.

site_title: Coffee prices seen rising slightly by end-2020 despite higher surplus
summary: Coffee prices are expected to rise slightly by the end of 2020, with arabica futures projected to finish the year at $1.20 per pound and robusta futures at $1,390 per tonne, a 0.9% and 3.42% increase respectively. Despite a larger global coffee surplus, driven by a larger supply of arabicas, prices are expected to rise due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on demand and the influence of stimulative policies.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, SGX, Singapore Airlines, DBS, OCBC, UOB
summary: Key stocks to watch include Keppel Corporation, which will decide by end-August whether to invoke a material adverse change pre-condition based on its second quarter results; Singapore Exchange (SGX), which proposed a final quarterly dividend of 8.0 cents per share; and DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank, which are expected to see their net profits decline amid growing pressure to pull back on dividend payouts.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.40 points, or 0.46%, to 1,596.35. The market saw 319 gains and 141 losses.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit over 1-month low as Victoria imposes harsh virus curbs
summary: Australia's shares fell to a one-month low on Monday, driven by financial stocks and the imposition of strict movement restrictions in Victoria to curb Covid-19 cases. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 0.7% to 5,888.7, its lowest since June 30. Financials led declines, with the "Big Four" banks losing 2.9-4.1%. Energy stocks also fell, while miners rose due to firmer commodity prices. The Reserve Bank of Australia meets on Tuesday, with investors focusing on the central bank's outlook for the economy.

site_title: Gold hits record high as virus fears, weaker US dollar boost demand
summary: Gold reached a record high of $1,984.66 per ounce due to a weaker US dollar and concerns over the global economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The US has seen over 4.6 million cases and 17.96 million global cases, with widespread infections in rural and urban areas. The softer dollar made gold more affordable for holders of other currencies. Speculators reduced bullish positions in COMEX gold and silver contracts, contributing to the price surge.

images.alt_text: Gold rose to an all-time high on Monday as a softer US dollar and fears over the global economic fallout from surging coronavirus cases lifted demand for the safe-haven metal.

site_title: Textiles industry faces scrutiny after Leicester outbreak
summary: The city of Leicester, UK, has faced scrutiny over its thriving textiles industry amid allegations of modern slavery and low wages. Despite the government easing lockdown measures, Leicester became a Covid-19 hotspot, prompting officials to reimpose social distancing rules. Labour Behind the Label reports that 75-80% of Leicester's textile production is for Boohoo, with workers earning as little as £2 an hour. The industry's poor working conditions and lack of transparency have raised concerns, with some factories operating in dilapidated buildings and workers being told to come to work despite testing positive for coronavirus.

site_title: Asia's factory pain eases as China's activity jumps
summary: Asia's factory pain eased in July as manufacturing activity in China expanded at its fastest pace in nearly a decade, driven by improved domestic demand. This suggests China's economy will help cushion the pandemic's impact on global growth. However, concerns about a second wave of infections may weigh on global demand, keeping any rebound in Asia's factory output feeble. Despite this, some analysts expect a gradual recovery in the region's factory output.

site_title: Trump to give TikTok's Chinese owner 45 days to reach deal to sell: sources
summary: US President Donald Trump has agreed to give ByteDance, the Chinese owner of TikTok, 45 days to negotiate a sale of the popular short-video app to Microsoft Corp. The negotiations will be overseen by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US. A deal can be blocked by the panel. The deadline for the sale was not specified, but Trump's decision comes amid concerns over data security and national security.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Monday with losses
summary: Hong Kong shares started trading on Monday with losses, dipping 0.12% due to concerns over the spread of coronavirus and lingering China-US tensions. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.67% and the Shenzhen Composite Index climbed 0.91%. The Hang Seng Index fell to 24,566.81, while the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index reached 3,332.18.

site_title: China says chips for mobile devices using Beidou navigation system in mass production
summary: China has begun mass production of 28-nanometre chips for mobile devices using the Beidou navigation system, with 22-nanometre chips to follow. This move is part of China's efforts to build a complete industrial chain of chips and navigation services. The development comes after China successfully launched its final Beidou satellite in June, marking a significant step in challenging the US-owned Global Positioning System (GPS).

site_title: UK to ditch 'outdated' planning rules to speed construction
summary: The UK's Local Government Secretary Robert Jenrick will announce reforms to the country's planning rules to speed up construction and stimulate the economy. The new system aims to streamline bureaucracy, introduce guidelines for architecture, and level the playing field for smaller companies. The goal is to reduce the average time for a standard housing development to go through the planning system from five years to a shorter period. However, critics argue that the reforms will not address the underlying issues with the housing delivery system, which remains "broken" despite having planning permission.

site_title: US adds 47,508 Covid-19 cases in 24 hours: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US reported 47,508 new Covid-19 cases and 515 deaths in 24 hours, according to Johns Hopkins University. This is a slight dip from the previous five days, which all recorded more than 60,000 new infections.

images.alt_text: The US notched 47,508 new coronavirus cases in 24 hours on Sunday, according to a tally by Johns Hopkins University.

site_title: Hot stock: SGX climbs after unveiling surprise higher dividend
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) rose 4.16% after announcing a surprise 8.0 Singapore cents per share final quarterly dividend, up from 7.5 cents a year ago. The stock closed at S$8.51, driven by analysts' positive comments on the bourse's growing and sustainable dividend policy. Several analysts raised their target prices and upgraded SGX to "buy" or "add" ratings, citing potential upside from new product offerings and expanded customer acquisitions.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly lower as virus forces new lockdowns
summary: Asian markets fell on Monday as coronavirus infections surged, forcing new lockdowns and sparking worries about the global economy. Total cases topped 18 million, with fresh restrictions imposed in Australia, Britain, and the Philippines. The US stimulus package remains stalled, with Democrats and Republicans at odds. Despite some cheer in Japan's economic data, the region's markets were largely lower, with Hong Kong and Manila experiencing significant declines. Economists warn of a prolonged recovery, citing the need for ongoing monetary and fiscal support.

site_title: Manulife US Reit posts 0.3% rise in H1 DPU to 3.05 US cents
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a 0.3% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.05 US cents for the first half of 2020, from 3.04 cents a year ago. Gross revenue rose 18.3% to US$98.6 million, and net property income grew 18.8% to US$62.2 million. The increase was attributed to newly acquired properties and a lower portfolio carpark income. The manager plans to focus on asset, lease, and capital management, while sustaining environmental, social, and governance initiatives.

site_title: Trump days away from moving against TikTok: Pompeo
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to announce strong action against Chinese-owned video sharing app TikTok to protect national security, according to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. Pompeo claims TikTok feeds personal data on American citizens directly to the Chinese Communist Party, posing significant national security risks. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has previously suggested the app should be sold or blocked in the US, citing concerns over data security. Negotiations for Microsoft to buy TikTok's US operations are on hold following Trump's threat to bar the app.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 1.19% and the Topix index gaining 1.04%. The rally was driven by Wall Street gains and a cheap yen against the dollar. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a fresh record for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq. Investors remain optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday as investors took heart from rallies on Wall Street and a cheap yen against the dollar.

site_title: StanChart to boost presence in Singapore as first 'significantly rooted foreign bank' here
summary: Standard Chartered Bank Singapore has been designated as the country's first "Significantly Rooted Foreign Bank" (SRFB), marking a significant boost to its presence in the Republic. As an SRFB, StanChart Singapore can expand its operations to 50 places of business, with up to 35 being branches, and is eligible to set up a digital-only bank with a lower paid-up capital. The bank's CEO, Patrick Lee, expressed commitment to Singapore's financial stability and development, and welcomed the enhanced SRFB framework, which may grant an additional full bank licence. This move is seen as a strategic step for StanChart Singapore, with the bank having a US$80 billion balance sheet and a significant global management team based in Singapore.

site_title: Plague to protein: Israeli firm seeks to put locusts on the menu
summary: An Israeli firm, Hargol Foodtech, is cultivating locusts on a commercial scale to produce a sustainable source of protein. The company's goal is to provide a healthier and more sustainable alternative to traditional livestock farming. Locusts are high in protein and contain all essential amino acids, but their consumption is limited in Western cultures due to the "yuck" factor. Hargol is working to overcome this hurdle by turning locusts into powder and adding it to various food products. The company aims to obtain kosher certification, which would enable them to market their product in mainstream Israeli cuisine and potentially in other countries.

site_title: Australian house prices fall for third month in July: CoreLogic
summary: Australian house prices fell 0.6% in July, marking the third consecutive month of decline, according to data from CoreLogic. The drop was attributed to the reimposition of a coronavirus lockdown in Victoria, affecting the Melbourne market. Despite this, prices remain 7.1% higher than July last year, and the national index has fallen only 1.6% since April. Experts expect the housing market to face challenges as loan repayment holidays expire and fiscal support tapers, with "urgent sales" likely to become more common.

site_title: Singapore drone startup Performance Rotors secures funding from Dutch MNC Royal Vopak
summary: Singapore-based drone startup Performance Rotors has secured an undisclosed sum of funds from Dutch multinational Royal Vopak to expand into overseas markets in Asia, Europe, and the Middle East. Despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, Performance Rotors' CEO Keith Ng expressed gratitude for Vopak's investment, citing the value of their services. The deal aims to enhance the company's presence globally.

site_title: Decline of Singapore's famed shopping strip shows city's pain
summary: Singapore's iconic Orchard Road shopping strip, once a hub of luxury and entertainment, is struggling due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Many high-end retailers, including Modesto's and Chanel, have closed or significantly reduced operations. Sales have plummeted, with some stores reporting a 90% decline. The economic downturn has also hit the tourism industry, with global travel restrictions costing the city-state around $20 billion in lost receipts. Experts suggest that Orchard Road needs to reinvent itself to attract consumers, but with the pandemic's impact still being felt, it's unclear if the area can recover its former glory.

site_title: China wealth manager Hywin plans foray into Singapore
summary: Hywin Wealth Management, a Shanghai-based wealth manager, plans to expand into Singapore to cater to its Chinese clients in the region. The company aims to attract $500 million in assets within the first year, following a team of 10-15 people. This move comes as Singapore's asset management market is expected to grow to $4 trillion by 2025, and Hong Kong faces increasing US-China political tensions. Hywin will retain its Hong Kong operations and leverage them to build its business in the Greater Bay Area.

site_title: Hot stock: Keppel sheds over 4% in early trade on uncertainty over Temasek offer
summary: Keppel Corp's shares dropped 4.6% in early trade on Monday amid uncertainty over Temasek's partial offer, which could be canceled if the conglomerate fails to meet certain conditions. Keppel posted a record quarterly net loss of S$697.6 million, breaching conditions for the offer. Analysts maintain "buy" or "add" recommendations, but reduced target prices, citing the stock's undemanding valuation. Temasek has options to waive the breach, invoke the material adverse change clause, or lower the offer price with approval. If the deal falls through, Keppel's share price could drop to its previous trough of S$4.88.

site_title: UOB launches finance academy for employees
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has launched the UOB Finance Academy, a three-month training program designed to equip employees in the bank's finance function with soft and technical skills required to become future leaders. The program builds on UOB's Better U learning and development program and offers modules on risk management, financial analysis, and leadership development. The inaugural cohort of 230 finance employees will receive a certificate jointly issued by UOB and the Institute of Banking and Finance Singapore, and the program is approved under Workforce Singapore's Professional Conversion Programme.

site_title: Thakral to expand Australia retirement resort portfolio with site acquisition
summary: Thakral Corp has acquired 13.4 hectares of land in Lake Cathie, New South Wales, Australia, for its GemLife joint venture. The site will be developed into a lifestyle resort for people over 50, expanding GemLife's portfolio to 10 resorts. The resort, GemLife Rainbow Beach, will feature 179 homes and is expected to start construction in Q1 2021, with completion by Q4 2021. The investment is seen as a "sustainable and positive return" despite the Covid-19 pandemic, with the number of people aged 65+ set to nearly double in Australia over the next two decades.

site_title: Cathay Pacific offers early retirement to older pilots
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd is offering a voluntary early retirement scheme to Hong Kong-based pilots approaching retirement age, in an effort to cut costs amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The scheme will pay pilots three months basic salary for each year remaining before their normal retirement age, plus a further one month allowance payment. The airline has taken other cost-cutting measures, including executive pay cuts and special leave schemes. Cathay aims to reduce costs and streamline operations, with a comprehensive review of its operations expected to be completed by the fourth quarter.

site_title: Neo Group chairman ups stake after resilient results
summary: Neo Group chairman Neo Kah Kiat increased his stake in the company after the firm reported a 21.2% increase in net profit to S$6.3 million for FY20. The company's strategy of nurturing diversity through its highly synergistic business segments has delivered resilient performances, according to Neo. Meanwhile, First Sponsor Group non-executive chairman Calvin Ho Han Leong increased his deemed interest in the mixed property developer to 46.03%. PropNex executive director Kelvin Fong Keng Seong also increased his interest in the company to 8.15%.

site_title: Brazil's Eletrobras to invest 6b reais a year through 2035
summary: Brazil's state-owned power company Eletrobras plans to invest 6 billion reais (S$1.51 billion) per year until 2035 to expand its power generation and transmission. The investment could more than double to 12.6 billion reais per year if the government successfully privatises the company, which is a priority for the energy minister. However, the privatization requires congressional approval and faces a challenging political battle.

site_title: US dollar rises amid biggest monthly drop in a decade
summary: The US dollar rose against a basket of currencies on Friday, marking its biggest monthly decline in a decade. The dollar index fell 4.1% for July, largely due to a surge in new Covid-19 cases in US states and weakening economic data. This decline reversed a trend of dollar strength seen in recent months.

site_title: Iran, UAE top diplomats discuss virus in rare talks
summary: Iran's Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif held a videoconference call with UAE Foreign Minister Sheikh Abdullah bin Zayed Al Nahyan, discussing the region's coronavirus outbreaks and other issues. Zarif stated they agreed to continue dialogue, focusing on "hope" as the region faces challenges and tough choices ahead.

site_title: Bollywood star Bachchan discharged after catching coronavirus
summary: Bollywood star Amitabh Bachchan, 77, was discharged from hospital after three weeks of treatment for mild coronavirus symptoms. Bachchan's actor-son Abhishek and daughter-in-law Aishwarya Rai remain hospitalized, while granddaughter Aaradhya was discharged last week. Bachchan's discharge came as Indian Home Minister Amit Shah tested positive for the virus, and India reported over 1.7 million cases and 37,000 deaths. Bachchan expressed gratitude to his family, fans, and hospital staff, saying he would undergo solitary quarantine in his room after testing negative.

site_title: China abandoning path to openness, says Switzerland
summary: Switzerland's foreign minister, Ignazio Cassis, stated that China is moving away from the path of openness and the West will respond more decisively if it continues. Cassis cited China's lack of political liberalization and rising human rights breaches as reasons for this shift. The move affects Switzerland's relations with China, particularly regarding Hong Kong's autonomy under the "One Country, Two Systems" principle. If China sticks to its new course, the Western world is expected to react more decisively, with Cassis warning that Switzerland must defend its interests and values more robustly.

site_title: Bond investors alarmed over UK economy turn to BOE for answers
summary: The UK bond market is sending warning signals to the Bank of England (BOE) ahead of its meeting this week, with traders expecting interest rates to follow soon. Yields out to eight years are below 0%, and real yields are hovering near record lows, straining savers and pension funds. The BOE faces a challenging decision as the UK grapples with a recession, rising coronavirus cases, and the end of the Brexit transition period. Traders predict a 10-basis-point interest rate cut to 0% by March, with some speculating the BOE could move into sub-zero territory.

site_title: Will MAS dividend cap prompt DBS, OCBC and UOB to downplay their performance?
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has capped local banks' dividend payouts for FY2020 at 60% of FY2019 levels, prompting concerns that DBS, OCBC, and UOB may downplay their performance. The move was seen as a surprise, with shares in the three banks declining 3-4% following the announcement. Analysts suggest that the banks may front-load bad loan provisions to conserve capital, as MAS aims to ensure they have ample buffers to sustain lending activities amid uncertainty.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Kashkari suggests 4-6 week shutdown
summary: US Federal Reserve President Neel Kashkari suggests a potential 4-6 week "lockdown" to control the coronavirus, which could aid the economy's recovery. Kashkari states that if the virus is brought under control, the economy can mount a robust recovery. He also notes that Congress can afford to spend large sums on coronavirus relief efforts, citing the nation's budget gap can be financed domestically. Kashkari's comments come as negotiations over a coronavirus relief bill between the Democratic-led House and Senate Republicans stall.

site_title: Coronavirus threatens property's dominance of Philippine stock market
summary: The Philippine property sector is struggling, with a 27% decline in the first half of 2020, outperforming only the country's benchmark index. The sector's losses have erased its valuation premium, and a surge in coronavirus cases, remittance decline, and departure of gaming operators are clouding its outlook. Analysts attribute the decline to weak consumer demand, citing the pandemic's impact on spending habits. Despite cheap valuations and government infrastructure initiatives, some analysts remain cautious, while others see long-term potential for the sector to rebound.

site_title: SpaceX capsule splashes down in Gulf of Mexico
summary: SpaceX's Crew Dragon Endeavour successfully splashed down in the Gulf of Mexico on Sunday, marking the first water landing for a US spacecraft since the Apollo-Soyuz mission in 1975. The capsule, carrying two astronauts, re-entered the Earth's atmosphere and deployed its parachutes without any issues. Pilot Doug Hurley described the experience as an "honour and privilege." The successful landing is a significant milestone for SpaceX's Crew Dragon program, demonstrating its capabilities and paving the way for future space missions.

site_title: The investigation that led police to stolen Banksy in Italy
summary: Police used wire-taps and surveillance to track down Banksy's stolen artwork, "The Sad Young Girl," after it was stolen from the Bataclan club in Paris in 2019. The thieves, caught on CCTV, loaded the door into a van and took it to Italy, where it was hidden in a hotel and later an abandoned farm. A year later, police detained three men in France suspected of involvement, leading to a joint operation with Italian authorities that resulted in the artwork's recovery on June 10, 2020. Nine people were ultimately detained, with two charged with robbery and four with receiving stolen goods.

site_title: Melbourne braces for closures, losses as it emerges from night-time curfew
summary: Melbourne, Australia's second-most populous city, has emerged from its first night-time curfew to contain the spread of the resurgent coronavirus. The state of Victoria imposed the curfew on Sunday as part of the country's harshest movement restrictions. The federal government backed the move, with Prime Minister Scott Morrison saying it was "regrettably necessary" to stop the spread of the pandemic. Residents are bracing for further closures and job losses, marking a challenging time for Melbourne as it navigates the pandemic.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: The Singapore Government has quoted taxable book-entry bonds. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. In market news, US stocks opened lower amid a fresh tariff salvo by President Trump on Canada. Companies such as Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO.

site_title: When is a financial institution not a financial institution? When it's Wirecard
summary: Wirecard, a German fintech company, has been accused of accounting fraud, with a 1.9 billion euro hole found in its balances. The company had skirted regulatory scrutiny by jurisdiction-shopping and using intra-group structuring. Wirecard's CEO, Markus Braun, and three board members were arrested, and the company filed for insolvency. The scandal exposes vulnerabilities in the expanding universe of fintech, electronic payments, and virtual businesses. Wirecard's ability to operate in multiple jurisdictions with minimal supervision has allowed unscrupulous management to take advantage of regulatory arbitrage.

site_title: A tale of two markets: tech versus travel and retail
summary: US tech stocks reached new records as earnings growth exceeded expectations, while travel and retail companies suffered due to fears of a fiscal cliff and weak July jobs numbers. Without a stimulus deal, the economic outlook is grim, with a possible spending cliff and mass layoffs. Analysts predict that the digital economy will continue to boom, but the physical economy remains in tatters, with the largest contraction since World War II. A vaccine breakthrough could restore consumer confidence and expand the economic recovery, but its effectiveness and duration are uncertain.

site_title: UK reviewing Covid curbs that include London lockdown: reports
summary: The UK is reviewing COVID-19 curbs, including a possible London lockdown, amid a surge in infections. Local government secretary Robert Jenrick said restrictions will be targeted at specific areas, rather than a blanket approach. The government aims to balance controlling the virus while rebooting the economy, which is facing its worst recession in 300 years. Possible measures include tightening quarantine rules, travel curbs, and banning overnight stays if infection rates spike in London. The reports of a London lockdown are considered speculation by the Prime Minister's office.

site_title: Temasek to decide by end-Aug on pre-condition for Keppel offer
summary: Temasek Holdings, a unit of the Singaporean investment firm Temasek, will decide by the end of August whether to invoke the material adverse change (MAC) pre-condition in its pre-conditional partial offer for Keppel Corporation. The offer, which would raise Temasek's stake in Keppel to 51%, was conditional on Keppel's second-quarter results. Keppel's record quarterly net loss of $697.59 million breached certain conditions, making it unlikely the MAC pre-condition will be satisfied. Temasek will disclose its decision by August 31, and if the MAC pre-condition is invoked, the offer will be withdrawn.

site_title: Nuclear ambitions at Britain's biggest construction site
summary: The UK's largest nuclear plant, Hinkley Point C, is nearly 40% complete after four years of construction. The project, led by Electricite de France (EDF), aims to generate electricity for six million homes by 2025. Despite delays caused by the coronavirus pandemic, the site is transforming into a power station using 208,000 tonnes of steel reinforcement, equivalent to laying railway tracks from London to Rome. The plant features a "core catcher" safety feature to prevent a Fukushima-type disaster, and EDF has taken precautions to restrict collaboration with Chinese partner China General Nuclear Power Corp due to strained diplomatic relations.

site_title: Heads of Sentosa Golf Club roll up sleeves in Serapong renovation
summary: Sentosa Golf Club, the world's first golf club to join the United Nations' Sports For Climate Action Initiative, has rolled up its sleeves to help with ongoing renovations to its Serapong course during the Covid-19 pandemic. The club's heads of department volunteered their services to complete almost nine holes of the course. This initiative aligns with the club's focus on environmental protection and sustainability, as well as its commitment to achieving the global climate goals set out by world leaders.

site_title: Lockdown lets German bankers get jobs without leaving home
summary: German lenders are filling vacant banking positions through video conferencing and digital means due to travel and contact restrictions during the coronavirus crisis. This shift has allowed individuals to secure banking jobs without having to leave their homes. The trend is attributed to the challenges of job hunting during the pandemic, with some lenders opting for digital recruitment methods to maintain social distancing.

site_title: DBS unveils new digital planning tools to boost financial resilience
summary: DBS, a Singaporean bank, has launched new digital financial planning tools to boost financial resilience and retirement planning among its customers. The bank found that one-third of its customers had negative cash flow in the first six months of 2020. DBS's new solutions include a Map Your Money interactive dashboard and a retirement planning portal, which provide personalized retirement planning and estate planning services. The bank is also collaborating with the Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board to train its wealth planning managers and loan specialists on CPF schemes, aiming to empower Singaporeans for a head start in retirement planning.

site_title: Alliance expands in managed healthcare
summary: Alliance Healthcare is expanding its managed healthcare services business, targeting a higher-margin and more scalable business. The company, which listed in May last year, has taken a 55% stake in home-based care startup Jaga-Me and rolled out a digital health platform for corporate clients. Doubling down on managed healthcare could help Alliance develop a more profitable business, with a higher Ebitda margin of 24.7% compared to 4.3% for its GP services segment. The company has also secured a two-year contract with 38 major public healthcare institutions and has regional ambitions through a three-year agreement with managed care solutions provider Inova Care.

site_title: Singapore market retreats slightly in July on pandemic fears
summary: Singapore's stock market retreated in July due to ongoing pandemic concerns, with the total market capitalisation falling to S$758 billion from S$761.6 billion in June. The number of losing stocks (321) outnumbered gaining stocks (216).

site_title: British Airways pilots take pay cut to end row over job losses
summary: British Airways pilots have agreed to a 20% pay cut, tapering to 8% over two years, in exchange for limiting job losses to 270 pilots, a reduction from the initial 1,255 redundancies. The deal aims to help the airline weather the global slump in air travel caused by the novel coronavirus. This comes as the industry faces disruptions and new curbs on travel, with a full recovery unlikely before 2024. The agreement also avoids the airline's threat to fire and rehire pilots on new terms if a deal couldn't be reached.

site_title: Singapore banks face scrutiny on asset quality at upcoming Q2 results
summary: Singapore banks are expected to face scrutiny on asset quality in Q2 due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with potential loan default risk from virus-battered SMEs weighing on earnings. Analysts predict a decline in net profit for the three major banks, with DBS and UOB expected to see a 37% and 39% year-on-year drop, respectively. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has signaled that government relief measures will have to start tapering off by end-December 2020, raising concerns about the full impact on banks' earnings.

images.alt_text: Citi analyst Robert Kong said Q2 is likely to be the quarterly earnings trough for DBS and UOB. He is looking at DBS's Q2 profit falling 37 per cent year-on-year; OCBC, 29 per cent; and UOB, 39 per cent.

site_title: Dividend cap on Singapore banks to weigh down sentiment
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority has mandated banks to cap their total dividends per share for FY2020 at 60% of the previous year's amount, aiming to shore up capital amid uncertain economic conditions. Analysts have reset dividend estimates and project a sharp decline in share prices in the near term. This move follows a broader effort to support the financial sector during a challenging time.

site_title: Goldman Sachs building M&A dealmaking app as socialising dries up
summary: Goldman Sachs is developing an M&A dealmaking app to help clients navigate the remote-working world, where socializing is drying up. The app will analyze how different company divisions perform relative to peers, providing insights to matchmakers. This move aims to capitalize on the boom in work-from-home executives seeking ways to maintain their dealmaking skills without relying on in-person networking. The app is part of Goldman Sachs' efforts to adapt to the changing business landscape.

site_title: Amid Covid-19 pandemic, mopeds have a moment in car-loving US
summary: During the Covid-19 pandemic, mopeds have gained popularity in the US, particularly in New York City, where commuters are shunning public transport. Ride-sharing company Revel has seen a surge in demand, with its New York fleet growing to 3,000 vehicles, and scooter retailers reporting a significant increase in sales. However, concerns over safety have led Revel to pause its New York services following two fatal crashes. Despite the risks, many residents are opting for cheaper, fun alternatives to four-wheeled transportation.

site_title: Businesses hail Singapore-Malaysia 'green lane', but worry about costs
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have officially established the "green lane" for business travel, allowing for short-term essential business and official travel via air and land links between the two countries for up to 14 days. The Reciprocal Green Lane (RGL) and Periodic Commuting Arrangement (PCA) schemes aim to facilitate cross-border work, but some companies are concerned about the costs, including Covid-19 swab tests, accommodation, and medical treatment. Employers worry about the financial burden and the process of re-hiring ex-employees whose work permits were cancelled, and the PCA scheme's limitations in handling medical treatment costs.

site_title: Victoria declares disaster, sets curfew to curb Covid-19
summary: Victoria, Australia's second-most populous state, declared a state of disaster on August 2, 2020, and imposed a nightly curfew for Melbourne to contain a resurgent Covid-19. The restrictions, including a six-week stay-home order, aim to curb record numbers of infections. The measures will remain in place for six weeks, with the curfew set to start immediately.

site_title: Rediscovering Singapore
summary: Singapore's tourism sector faces challenges amid international travel curbs, but experts suggest boosting domestic tourism through creative promotion, innovative experiences, and leveraging digital platforms. The STB's SingapoRediscovers campaign aims to encourage locals to explore hidden gems, such as lesser-known food corners, outdoor parks, and cultural attractions. Potential strategies include virtual tours, augmented-reality experiences, and partnerships between businesses and local communities. By embracing digital innovation and showcasing Singapore's diverse activities, the sector can capitalize on pent-up demand and stimulate local tourism.

site_title: Japan's August factory activity shrinks at slowest pace in six months: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity shrank at the slowest pace in six months in August, according to the au Jibun Bank Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI), rising to 47.2 from 45.2 in July. This marks a slowdown in contraction, but the sector remains limited by the pandemic, with firms cutting prices due to weak demand. Analysts expect a modest third-quarter rebound, with a firmer recovery expected to take time due to global infection concerns and US-China trade uncertainty.

site_title: Russia preparing mass vaccination against coronavirus for October
summary: Russia's health minister, Mikhail Murashko, announced plans for a mass vaccination campaign against the novel coronavirus starting in October, after a vaccine completed clinical trials. The Gamaleya Institute's adenovirus-based vaccine will be administered to doctors and teachers first, with wider vaccinations to follow. The move has raised concerns about Russia's prioritization of national prestige over science and safety. The country reported 95 additional deaths and 5,462 new cases, bringing the total to 14,058 deaths and 845,443 cases.

site_title: Can Indonesia turn a trickle of FDIs into a deluge with new industrial parks?
summary: Indonesia is developing an industrial park in central Java to attract Chinese manufacturers fleeing US trade and economic sanctions. The Batang Special Economic Zone aims to create 30,000 jobs and invest $850 million, with seven foreign investors, including LG and Panasonic, already committed. Other companies, such as Alpan and Denso, are also relocating from China due to tariffs. However, critics say Indonesia needs to improve its business environment, citing excessive red tape and regulations, and the government must deliver on its promises to woo investors.

site_title: Apple's Taiwan suppliers, Samsung apply for India's smartphone scheme
summary: Apple's Taiwan suppliers, Foxconn, Wistron Corp, and Pegatron Corp, have applied for funds from India's $6.65 billion smartphone manufacturing scheme. The Production-Linked Incentive (PLI) plan aims to boost local production and create 300,000 jobs. Apple assembles some iPhones at Foxconn and Wistron's plants in southern India, while Pegatron is in talks to set up operations. Samsung Electronics Co Ltd, which has a large mobile phone manufacturing plant in New Delhi, has also applied for incentives. The government expects the scheme to generate $154 billion in smartphone production over five years.

site_title: 313 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 1 in the community
summary: Singapore reported 313 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 52,825. The cases include one community case and five imported cases, with the majority being migrant workers living in dormitories. The number of community cases has decreased, with only one case reported on Saturday. The Ministry of Health closed 36 Covid-19 dormitory clusters and discharged 249 patients, with 46,740 now fully recovered.

site_title: US$2,000 may be a new normal for gold
summary: Gold prices have surged to a high of $2,000 per ounce in July, driven by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and economic uncertainty. The US Federal Reserve maintained the federal funds rate at 0-0.25%, and the US Dollar Index futures plummeted, making gold more attractive. However, some analysts warn that the rally could be hindered by weaker domestic demand from India and China, and that a retracement of gold prices is possible. The World Gold Council notes that a strong rally could be hindered by weaker demand, making $2,000 per ounce a potential new normal.

site_title: Jet fuel demand outlook sours after fleeting market optimism
summary: Jet fuel demand has soured after a brief moment of optimism in early July, when flights increased in the US and shipments to the West Coast from Asia were made. However, a resurgence in coronavirus cases has led to a decline in passenger air traffic, with international flights down over 80% from last year. Despite record-high jet fuel stocks in Europe, subdued imports and high exports have not boosted demand. The US has seen a slight increase in jet fuel imports, but air travel has stalled, and stocks remain at a record high.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for July 31, 2020, reveals improved sentiment in the capesize market, with the timecharter average rising $1,282 to $18,296. The C3 Brazil-China route gained $1.53 to $17.47, while the C5 Australia-China route posted $1.16 to $7.155. In contrast, the panamax market remained under pressure, with rates globally for the early part still severely under pressure. The ultramax/supramax market declined 36 points from Monday, and the handysize index remained flat with limited activity.

site_title: SoftBank to maintain stake in Arm after partial sale: Nikkei
summary: SoftBank Group will maintain its stake in chip company Arm Holdings, even if it sells part of it to Nvidia or through an initial public offering. The Japanese conglomerate is currently negotiating terms with Nvidia after receiving an approach. SoftBank acquired Arm for $32 billion in 2016 and is exploring options, including a partial sale or public offering, as part of its debt reduction plan. A sale would not be part of its asset monetization program. The company's stake in Arm's future is uncertain, but it will likely keep some ownership.

site_title: UAE starts up first Arab nuclear plant
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) has successfully started up its first Arab nuclear power plant, the Barakah Nuclear Energy Plant, located on the Gulf coast west of Abu Dhabi. The plant, built by a consortium led by the Korea Electric Power Corporation, has achieved first criticality and started producing electricity. The plant has a capacity to generate 5,600 megawatts of electricity, around 25% of the nation's needs. The UAE aims to diversify its energy economy, reduce dependence on fossil fuels, and project its image as a regional leader in science and technology.

site_title: British trade minister to meet top US officials next week, USTR says
summary: British Trade Minister Liz Truss will meet US officials in Washington next week to assess progress on a free trade agreement. The talks, scheduled for Monday and Tuesday, come as the UK has started trade negotiations with other countries after leaving the EU. The US has expressed a priority for a deal, but progress has been slow due to the pandemic. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said a third round of negotiations is needed to bring the deal to a closure. No deadline has been set for the talks.

site_title: Over 80 killed by bootleg alcohol in Indian state
summary: Over 80 people have died in India's Punjab state after drinking toxic bootleg alcohol, with 25 arrested. The deaths occurred in three districts, with 11 in Gurdaspur, 12 in Amritsar, and 63 in Tarn Taran. The illicit booze was sold for as little as 10 rupees per liter. Punjab's chief minister has ordered a special inquiry into the deaths, promising to spare those found guilty. This incident is part of a larger issue, with hundreds dying each year from poisoned alcohol made in backstreet distilleries.
