site_title: Temasek unit to decide by end-Aug on material adverse change pre-condition regarding Keppel offer
summary: Temasek's unit, Kyanite Investment Holdings, will decide by end-August whether to invoke the material adverse change pre-condition regarding its S$4 billion offer for Keppel Corporation, following the conglomerate's record quarterly net loss of S$697.59 million in Q2 FY2020. The pre-condition requires Keppel's cumulative net profit to be over S$556.9 million, which it failed to meet. If the MAC pre-condition is invoked, the offer will be withdrawn. The decision will be disclosed by August 31, 2020.

site_title: Credit Suisse targeting savings of 2% to 3% per year
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Thomas Gottstein aims to cut costs by 2-3% annually, with savings reinvested in the business. This translates to around 400 million Swiss francs in annual savings. Gottstein cited efficiency improvements and digitization as key areas for cost reduction, particularly in group-wide functions and wealth management. He also expressed optimism about the bank's trading business and private banking sales, which increased by 4% in the first half of the year. The goal is to achieve these savings without compromising the bank's business.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse chief executive officer (CEO) Thomas Gottstein wants to cut costs by 2-3 per cent each year.

site_title: Hong Kong's mom-and-pop investors squeeze funds as IPOs sizzle
summary: Hong Kong's stock market is facing a challenge as global fund managers compete with individual investors for shares in new initial public offerings (IPOs). Retail investors have participated in record numbers in recent IPOs, forcing big investors to hold onto shares for at least six months. This has led to a growing number of funds becoming "cornerstone" investors, prioritized before deals launch. The high retail demand risks over-valuing companies, particularly biotech startups, according to bankers.

site_title: DBS unveils new digital financial planning tools to bolster financial resilience
summary: DBS unveils new digital financial planning tools to help Singaporeans boost their financial resilience and prepare for retirement. The bank found that one-third of its customers experienced negative cash flow between January and June 2020. DBS's new solutions include a digital advisory tool, NAV Planner, and a retirement planning portal, which will help customers visualize their future retirement needs and access relevant services such as CPF nomination and will writing. The bank is also using facial recognition technology and artificial intelligence to estimate customers' retirement needs based on lifestyle choices.

site_title: Australia's Victoria declares disaster, sets curfew to curb Covid-19
summary: Victoria, Australia declared a state of disaster on August 2, 2020, amid a resurgent Covid-19 pandemic, imposing a nightly curfew from 8pm to 5am in Melbourne for six weeks. The restrictions, part of the state's harshest movement restrictions, aim to contain the disease, with record numbers of infections reported. Schools will move to remote learning, and supermarkets and restaurants will remain open for takeaway and delivery services. The move follows a surge in community transmissions and cases of unknown origins, with 671 infections and seven deaths reported in the state.

site_title: TikTok's Chinese owner offers to forego stake to clinch US deal: sources
summary: ByteDance, the Chinese owner of TikTok, has agreed to divest its US operations in a bid to save a deal with the White House, which had threatened to ban the app due to national security concerns over personal data. Under the new proposal, Microsoft will take over TikTok's US business, and some US-based investors may be given minority stakes. This concession comes after President Donald Trump announced plans to ban TikTok, citing concerns over data security and the influence of the Chinese Communist Party.

site_title: India's crop planting gathers pace, buoyed by bountiful monsoon rains
summary: India's crop planting has accelerated due to the monsoon rains, with farmers planting 14% more land than last year. Rice, corn, cotton, and soybean crops saw significant increases, with soybean output expected to jump by at least 15%. Sugar cane and pulse planting also rose, while oilseed planting remained steady. The early monsoon coverage helped farmers speed up planting, with the weather office predicting above-average rainfall in August and September. This boost is critical for farm output and economic growth, with 55% of India's arable land relying on monsoon rains.

site_title: Eastman Kodak top executive got Trump deal windfall on an 'understanding'
summary: Eastman Kodak's executive chairman, Jim Continenza, received 1.75 million stock options as part of an "understanding" with the board, shielding his stake from dilution by a US$100 million convertible bond deal. The deal, announced after the options were granted, led to a 10-fold increase in Kodak's stock, making Continenza's gains worth around $83 million. Experts say the move is unusual, as executives are typically paid to grow long-term value, not to cover short-term losses.

site_title: Trump gets highest ratings of convention, trails Biden
summary: President Donald Trump's acceptance speech at the 2020 Republican convention drew a TV audience of 23.8 million viewers, the highest ratings for the GOP in a year marked by campaign challenges. This trailed Biden's Democratic convention, which drew 24.6 million viewers. The speech was watched on 13 networks, with Fox News Channel leading the ratings at 9.18 million. Trump spoke about combating the pandemic, law and order, and his economic policies, criticizing Biden's economic record. The event was notable for being held outdoors at the White House due to the coronavirus.

site_title: Singapore banks' weak operating environment weighing on ratings: Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings has warned Singapore banks that their core capital ratios should be maintained at around 14% over the next few years to avoid a rating downgrade. The banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, have targeted CET1 ratios between 12.5% and 13.5%. Fitch noted that deteriorating asset quality and profitability will put downward pressure on capital ratios, and that the banks' earnings and profitability scores are expected to fall by about a third from end-2019. A negative outlook on the banks' ratings has been placed due to limited rating headroom.

site_title: Philippines to update Covid-19 strategy as healthcare workers seek 'timeout'
summary: The Philippines' health department plans to update its COVID-19 strategy within a week amid a record surge in cases. The country reported 4,963 new infections, bringing its total to 98,232, and 2,039 deaths. Medical frontliners are calling for stricter lockdowns, citing a collapse of the healthcare system. The Department of Health will support healthcare workers' calls for a "timeout" and implement localized lockdowns. The government is reluctant to revive strict curbs, but will marshal efforts to control the spread of the disease.

site_title: Trump assails Biden as he accepts Republican nomination
summary: US President Donald Trump formally accepted the Republican nomination for a second term, delivering a scathing attack on rival Joe Biden, portraying him as a far-left extremist who would usher in a lawless America. Trump claimed a Democratic victory would exacerbate racial strife and the coronavirus pandemic, despite the pandemic having killed over 180,000 Americans. The speech came after days of civil unrest and violence in Kenosha, Wisconsin, where police shot a black man, and amid a fresh wave of protests over the latest high-profile police shooting of a Black American.

site_title: Money FM: Podcasts of the week (Aug 3)
summary: Money FM's "Podcasts of the week" features Sim Bock Eng discussing the importance of making a will to protect loved ones and Alfred Chia on Sora vs other floating interest rates for home loans. Meanwhile, Market Focus Weekly covers Asia's markets reacting to various factors, including US-China relations and the US dollar's decline. Additionally, other popular topics include CEO salaries, the incoming OCBC CEO, and the need for Singaporeans to save $1.39 million for a comfortable retirement.

site_title: India Supreme Court approves payment plan for telcos including Bharti Airtel
summary: India's Supreme Court approved a 10-year payment plan for telecom companies, including Bharti Airtel and Vodafone Idea, to clear combined back-fees worth 1.4 trillion rupees ($25.83 billion). The court rejected a 20-year payment timeline and allowed the federal government to collect the amount in installments. Bharti Airtel's shares rose 5.1% after the verdict, while Vodafone Idea's shares fell 15%. The ruling provides partial relief to cash-strapped Vodafone Idea, but analysts warn that the company's debt issues remain a concern.

site_title: Richard Branson splits up US$1.7b stake in Virgin Galactic
summary: Richard Branson has distributed his US$1.7 billion stake in Virgin Galactic Holdings to a firm controlled by him and Aabar Space, an Abu Dhabi investment company. The distribution, following a sale of shares to support his business empire, gives Branson greater control of his most valuable listed holding. Virgin Galactic shares slid 2.9% to US$22.21 after the announcement, paring this year's gain to 93%. The move comes as Branson's broader business empire, including Virgin Atlantic Airways, faces challenges amid the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Global investors drive record inflows into Chinese bonds in July
summary: Foreign investors made record net purchases of Chinese bonds through Bond Connect in July, totaling 75.5 billion yuan (S$14.87 billion), driven by yield premiums over US debt. Total trading volumes reached 446.9 billion yuan, up 5.9% from the previous month. Spreads between Chinese and US government bonds hit a record high of over 257 basis points, reflecting differing central bank approaches to monetary policy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with gains on Friday, driven by a Federal Reserve move expected to keep interest rates low for the foreseeable future. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.56% to 25,422.06, while the Shanghai Composite Index surged 1.60% to 3,403.81. The Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 1.97% to 2,305.62. The positive sentiment was attributed to the ultra-low interest rates, which traders welcomed.

site_title: SingHaiyi's Celine Tang continues to build stake
summary: SingHaiyi Group's managing director Celine Tang increased her stake in the company to 64.47% after acquiring 5,960,900 shares between Aug 21 and 26. This followed her previous acquisition of 5,960,900 shares between Aug 13 and 19. The company's total return for the 2020 year declined 0.3% in the recent trading sessions. Other notable transactions include Ho Bee Holdings' acquisition of 123,700 shares of Ho Bee Land, Indofood Agri Resources' acquisition of 859,300 shares by PT Indofood Sukses Makmur Tbk, and UOB-Kay Hian Holdings' chairman and managing director Wee Ee-chao increasing his stake to 30.59%.

site_title: More than 200 traineeships available in maritime sector
summary: Singapore's Maritime Sector Sees 200+ Traineeships Launched, Amid Resilience Amid Covid-19. Senior Minister of State for Transport and Foreign Affairs Chee Hong Tat announced the SGUnited Traineeships Programme, providing opportunities for fresh and recent graduates, as well as mid-career workers. The maritime sector has remained resilient, with lower container throughput decline compared to other sectors. The Ministry of Transport and MPA will expand talent in the sector, including partnering companies for training and updating the Skills Framework for Sea Transport.

site_title: Tycoon Kris Wiluan loses bid to keep IJMs away from debt-hit KS Energy
summary: Singapore-listed oil services firm KS Energy has been placed under interim judicial management (IJM) after tycoon Kris Wiluan lost a bid to keep the company away from debt. OCBC, the lender, cited the "alarming developments" of 112 charges against Wiluan as grounds for the IJM application, which was granted by High Court Justice Aedit Abdullah. Wiluan's son and son-in-law, who own nearly 66% of the company, will manage the firm until a JM hearing is held on September 10.

site_title: Cloud data specialty firm Snowflake files to go public
summary: Cloud data specialty firm Snowflake filed with US regulators for an initial public offering, aiming to raise $100 million. The startup, valued at $12.4 billion in a private funding round, reported $264.7 million in revenue last year, despite a net loss of $348.5 million. Snowflake, which relies on data centers hosted by Amazon, Google, and Microsoft, plans to list on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol "Snow." The company's IPO comes amid a trend of businesses connecting with customers online, with Palantir and Airbnb also confidentially filing for stock listings.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 5.5-month high on coronavirus treatment bets
summary: Australian shares rose 1.1% to a 5.5-month high on Tuesday, driven by gains in financials and tech stocks amid potential medical advances against the coronavirus pandemic. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 6,160, with financial stocks advancing 2.6% and technology stocks reaching an all-time high. The US FDA authorized blood plasma treatment and the US government considered fast-tracking an experimental vaccine, boosting risk sentiment.

site_title: UAE becomes first Arab nation to open a nuclear power plant
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) has become the first Arab country to open a nuclear power plant, sparking concerns about regional security and environmental impact. The South Korean-designed plant, which will provide a quarter of the country's electricity, aims to reduce the UAE's reliance on oil. However, analysts fear that the move could destabilize the Gulf region and increase the risk of nuclear proliferation, as other Arab countries, including Saudi Arabia, also plan to develop nuclear energy programs. The UAE has insisted that its intentions are peaceful, citing collaborations with international organizations and the US.

images.alt_text: The United Arab Emirates became the first Arab country to open a nuclear power plant Saturday, raising concerns about the long-term consequences of introducing more nuclear programmes to the Middle East.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB reports 82% fall in Q2 profit
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group Holdings reported a 81.6% drop in Q2 net profit to 277.1 million ringgit, largely due to the coronavirus pandemic's economic impact. Revenue fell 13.5% to 3.9 billion ringgit. The bank expects continued weaker performance for the remainder of 2020, citing uncertain economic conditions and elevated provisions.

site_title: Tech unicorns rushing to go public defy sleepy summer season
summary: Tech unicorns are rushing to go public, defying the typically sleepy US summer season. Five companies, including Unity Software, Sumo Logic, and Asana, filed to go public with the US Securities and Exchange Commission, while others, such as StepStone Group and biomedical companies, also filed. This surge in IPOs, led by special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs), has topped $16 billion in August, the highest month since 2014. Software companies have seen a 91% increase in their offer prices, outpacing the overall market.

site_title: URA steps up tracking of repeated issue of OTPs
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is cracking down on a practice in Singapore where private developers issue options to purchase (OTPs) repeatedly, inflating home sales figures and risking unsold stock. This arrangement allows buyers to re-issue OTPs upon expiry without forfeiting the booking fee. The URA's tightening monitoring aims to prevent such practices, discouraging developers from engaging in this tactic.

site_title: Travellers from South Korea to serve SHN at dedicated facilities from Aug 29
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore announced updated border measures for travellers arriving from South Korea on Aug 29. From then on, travellers who have visited South Korea in the last 14 days, including transit, will be required to serve a 14-day stay-home notice (SHN) at dedicated facilities instead of their own residence. They will also undergo a Covid-19 test before the end of the SHN.

site_title: Singapore-Malaysia 'green lane' travel to commence on Aug 17
summary: Singapore and Malaysia will allow residents to travel between the two countries for business under the Reciprocal Green Lane (RGL) and Periodic Commuting Arrangement (PCA) schemes starting August 17. The RGL scheme will cover air and land links for up to 14 days, while the PCA scheme only covers land crossings. Applications for both schemes will be accepted starting August 10, and successful applicants will receive a SafeTravel Pass for a single entry into Singapore. Travellers will be required to undergo COVID-19 tests and follow specific requirements upon arrival.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on fresh virus hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index advancing 1.35% to 23,296.77, and the Topix index gaining 1.13% to 1,625.23. The rally follows news of a newly approved coronavirus treatment, boosting investor hopes. The gains were also influenced by positive market sentiment from Wall Street, where stocks extended their rallies. The closing prices were the highest in nearly a week, as investors looked beyond tariff uncertainty and Fed views.

site_title: Miner finds 442-carat diamond that may be worth US$18m
summary: A miner at Gem Diamonds' Letseng mine in Lesotho has discovered a 442-carat diamond, potentially worth up to $18 million. The find is rare and comes at a time when the global diamond industry has been severely impacted by the pandemic. This is the second record-breaking discovery at the mine, following a 910-carat stone sold for $40 million two years ago. The discovery confirms the mine's ability to consistently produce large, high-quality diamonds.

site_title: US: S&P 500 opens at record high for fifth straight day
summary: The S&P 500 opened at a record high for the fifth consecutive day, with gains of 10.14 points or 0.29% to 3,494.69. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 109.02 points or 0.38% to 28,601.29, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 63.94 points or 0.55% to 11,689.28. Strong risk appetite was fueled by the prospect of super-low interest rates and bets on a medical solution to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Dawn of AI golden age
summary: Swami Sivasubramanian, VP of machine learning at AWS, predicts the dawn of the "golden age" of machine learning and artificial intelligence (AI). With democratized access to computing infrastructure and data storage, startups and small firms are now using state-of-the-art deep learning tools and algorithms. This has led to widespread adoption across various industries, including healthcare, finance, and e-commerce. Companies are leveraging machine learning to improve customer experiences, detect anomalies, and accelerate drug discovery. However, misconceptions about machine learning persist, including the need for constant refinement and investment in data strategy. Sivasubramanian advises leaders to focus on customer needs and iterate to improve model accuracy.

site_title: Travellers from Brunei, NZ can enter Singapore without serving SHN
summary: Singapore is lifting travel restrictions for visitors from Brunei Darussalam and New Zealand, allowing them to enter without serving a Stay-Home Notice (SHN) but instead undergoing a Covid-19 test upon arrival. Travelers from these countries must apply for an Air Travel Pass (ATP) 7-30 days prior to entry. Other low-risk countries/regions will have a reduced 7-day SHN, while all other travelers will continue with a 14-day SHN.

site_title: US: Nasdaq closes at all-time high as strong tech sector offsets jobless data
summary: The US stock market closed at an all-time high on Thursday, with the Nasdaq leading the way, as tech stocks continued to drive gains despite weak jobless data and a decline in business conditions. The Nasdaq rose 1.06% to a record high, while the S&P 500 and Dow also rose, with Apple, Amazon, and Microsoft leading the gains. Investors are optimistic about a recovery, with the Federal Reserve backing companies, but some analysts caution that the market may be getting too exuberant.

site_title: China's chicken production continues to surge, reducing appetite for imports
summary: China is producing a record 14.85 million tonnes of chicken meat in 2020, a 8% increase from last year, as the country reduces its reliance on imports amid fears about the safety of foreign meat. Despite a slump in demand due to the coronavirus, China's chicken producers are expanding production, boosting demand for key feed grains like corn and soybeans, and pushing down poultry prices. The expansion could lead to smaller purchases of imported frozen chicken, with prices expected to continue to decline.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks recover early losses to close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks recovered from early losses, closing higher on Wednesday. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.26% to 23,110.61, while the Topix index gained 0.18% to 1,613.73. Investors bought on dips following two days of declines, with sentiment not as bad as the index staying above the 23,000 level, according to a broker. This follows overnight gains on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 notched its first closing record since February.

site_title: Oil firms evacuate staff, curb offshore production ahead of twin storms
summary: Oil producers in the US Gulf of Mexico have evacuated staff and reduced crude oil production by 13% ahead of twin storms Laura and Marco, which are forecast to make landfalls along the central Gulf Coast. The storms, which may become hurricanes, are rare to occur simultaneously in the Gulf, raising concerns about double-barrel hits to coastal communities. Neither storm is expected to become a major hurricane, but their potential tracks cover a wide area of the Gulf Coast.

site_title: Sustainable debt seen outperforming unless recovery V-shaped
summary: Sustainable debt has outperformed traditional bonds this year, with green bonds returning 8.3% in 2020 compared to 7.1% for American corporate notes. This is largely due to lower exposure to oil-exporting countries and higher investor demand for ESG assets. However, unless the global economic recovery is V-shaped, ESG bonds may not continue to outperform, according to Emso Asset Management. The company attributes this to the economic recovery and commodity concentration in non-ESG issuers. Sales of sustainable notes have increased 29% to $195 billion this year.

site_title: Oracle enters race to buy TikTok's US operations: FT
summary: Oracle Corp has held preliminary talks with TikTok's Chinese owner, ByteDance, to buy the app's US operations. This move comes after Twitter Inc expressed interest in acquiring TikTok's US operations, and Microsoft Corp was previously considered the favorite to clinch a deal. Oracle's consideration of a deal marks a shift in the ongoing bidding war for TikTok's US operations, which also involves ByteDance and other potential buyers. The Financial Times reported the talks, citing people briefed on the matter, but Oracle, ByteDance, and TikTok declined to comment.

site_title: Spot gold may retest support at US$1,911
summary: Spot gold may retest its support at US$1,911 per ounce due to a wave pattern and projection analysis. The metal is currently riding a wave from US$2,014.97, which was briefly stopped by the support level. A bounce triggered by the support may be brief, and a break above US$1,950 could lead to a gain into the US$1,958-1,973 range.

images.alt_text: A break above US$1,950 could lead to a gain into the US$1,958-1,973 range, says Reuters market analyst Wang Tao.

site_title: Driven to win
summary: CrowdStrike CEO George Kurtz has successfully merged his passions for car racing and cybersecurity, pioneering a new approach to providing cybersecurity to companies through cloud-based endpoint security. The company, founded in 2011, has rapidly expanded and achieved significant growth, reaching $1 billion in annual revenues within the next couple of years. Kurtz attributes the company's success to its focus on prevention rather than detection, using AI-driven analytics to identify and prevent threats. CrowdStrike's agent software collects diagnostic information from endpoint devices and applies machine learning algorithms to identify patterns of malicious activity. With agents in 176 countries and collecting three trillion online events per week, CrowdStrike has developed a unique approach to cybersecurity, leveraging "community immunity" to build defenses against sophisticated threats.

images.alt_text: "One of the biggest aspects of motor racing is that even if you win you say: 'What could we have done better?' That is the mindset we bring to CrowdStrike," said CrowdStrike CEO George Kurtz.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, OCBC, Golden Agri, UOL, SBS Transit, Rex
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

Several Singaporean companies released their half-year financial results on Friday, with mixed outcomes. ST Engineering's net profit edged down 4.4% to S$257.4 million, while OCBC Bank's shares rose 1.2% after a creditor-backed judicial management was placed on Xihe Holdings. Golden Agri-Resources plummeted into a net loss of US$156.9 million, while UOL and SBS Transit reported significant declines in net profit due to fair-value losses and lower rail ridership. Rex International and UMS Holdings reported losses, while Ho Bee Land's net profit more than doubled to S$90.6 million.

site_title: China dronemaker DJI makes sweeping cuts in 'Long March' reforms
summary: China's drone giant DJI Technology Co has made significant cuts to its sales and marketing teams, reducing its corporate team from 180 to 60 and consumer team from 40-50 to around three. The company has also downsized its global video production team from 40-50 to three and laid off a marketing team of six in South Korea, amid coronavirus headwinds and mounting pressure in key markets.

site_title: Malaysia's economy shrinks the most since 1998 Asian financial crisis
summary: Malaysia's economy contracted by 17.1% in the second quarter, its worst showing since the 1998 Asian financial crisis. The contraction was driven by a decline in exports and consumer spending due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The central bank now expects the economy to contract 3.5-5.5% this year, down from a previous range of 0.5-2%. The economy's performance is the largest year-on-year contraction in the region so far, despite less restrictive lockdown measures.

site_title: Which 'cide are you on?: How misuse of pesticides poses challenges for Singapore's vegetable supply chain
summary: Singapore's vegetable supply chain faces challenges due to the misuse of pesticides in Malaysian farming. Traces of banned organochlorine pesticides were found in surface water and tap water in the Cameron Highlands in 2015, and pesticide contamination persists. The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) has rejected 7% of vegetable consignments due to pesticide residues exceeding limits, but industry insiders suspect many hazardous consignments slip through undetected. Smuggling and under-declaring are common problems, and consumers can play a role by buying imperfect produce and supporting organic farming. The SFA has adopted a risk-based approach to food safety, but more enforcement and audits are needed to address the issue.

images.alt_text: WHICH 'CIDE ARE YOU ON? The misuse of pesticides and other chemical poisons in farming is a challenge for the entire vegetable supply chain. Regulators can step up enforcement, but consumers have a role to play too.

WHICH 'CIDE ARE YOU ON? The misuse of pesticides and other chemical poisons in farming is a challenge for the entire vegetable supply chain. Regulators can step up enforcement, but consumers have a role to play too.
"Think of buying organic as a donation or contribution to protect the environment." - Fung Chee Siang, who owns organic farm Hatiku Agrikultur in Cameron Highlands, Malaysia (above).
The Singapore Food Agency says out of 7,073 vegetable consignments it inspected last year, 497 were rejected. The top three veggies that fail pesticide tests are chilli, parsley and Chinese celery.

"In the organic world we say it's not organic farming that is too expensive, it's conventional farming that is too cheap because we've left the problem to our future generation. So we push for true cost accounting." - Tai Seng Yee, executive director of Zenxin Organic Food.

Hatiku Agrikultur grows a small quantity of a wide variety of veggies (above: nasturtium and red kale) and practises crop rotation so that there is not enough food to attract large numbers of pests to feast and multiply in the farm.

site_title: China names Zhang Gong as head of market regulator
summary: China has appointed Zhang Gong as the head of the State Administration for Market Regulation, replacing Xiao Yaqing who has been appointed as the Minister of Industry and Information Technology. This move aims to strengthen market regulation and oversight in China.

site_title: Saved by the bell?: How Singapore's new insolvency laws could extend lifelines for distressed companies
summary: Singapore's new insolvency laws, the Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Act (IRDA), aim to extend lifelines for distressed companies. The laws empower liquidators and judicial managers to secure third-party funding to unwind unfair transactions and hold directors accountable. This change allows for more cases of liquidators being appointed and actions pursued against directors. The IRDA also includes features of Chapter 11 of the US bankruptcy code, providing a more creditor-friendly omnibus legislation. The roll-out of the IRDA is seen as a victory lap for reforms that began seven years ago, aiming to galvanize Singapore's debt-workout ecosystem and raise its corporate-rescue game globally.

site_title: Global Invacom H1 earnings tumble 78.2% to US$345,000
summary: Global Invacom reported a 78.2% decline in its net profit to US$345,000 for the half year ended June 30, 2020, due to reduced orders and production disruptions caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue fell 26.6% to S$52.8 million, with lower demand in America and Europe offset by increased demand in Asia. The company remains well-placed to return to growth as the market emerges from lockdown, according to executive chairman Tony Taylor.

site_title: China's property investment in July quickens to over one-year high
summary: China's property investment in July rose 11.7% from a year earlier, the fastest clip since April 2019, driven by solid construction activity and easier lending. This growth quickened from June's 8.5% and outpaced the 1.9% increase in the January-June period. Property sales by floor area rose 9.5% and new construction starts increased 11.3% on-year. The rebound in the property market is attributed to cheaper credit and relaxation of urban residential curbs, but some analysts warn of a potential bubble in select cities.

site_title: London's financial district looking like 'ghost town' as workers stay away
summary: London's financial district has been largely deserted by workers due to ongoing pandemic concerns, despite government encouragement to return to offices. The city's traditional hub, the City, is eerily quiet, with only a few tourists strolling the streets. Companies like BT and Barclays are opting for relaxed approaches to returning staff, while others, such as Google, are encouraging remote work until next year. The government's push for a return to work is expected to continue, but concerns over public transport and childcare issues remain major obstacles.

site_title: Biden, Harris launch campaign with call to 'rebuild' post-Trump US
summary: Democratic presidential hopeful Joe Biden and his running mate Kamala Harris launched their campaign with a call to "rebuild" the US after one term of President Donald Trump. Biden and Harris emphasized the need to address police violence, racial disparities, and the COVID-19 pandemic. Harris criticized Trump, calling him "just isn't up for the job" and "whining." Biden promised to fix the country's problems and inspire a new generation of Americans, particularly young girls, with Harris' story as a role model.

site_title: Golden Agri-Resources H1 loss widens to US$156.9m
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a net loss of US$156.9 million for the first half of fiscal 2020, compared to a net loss of US$46.4 million in the same period last year. Revenue increased by 7.1% to US$3.39 billion due to higher average selling prices for crude palm oil. The company's upstream segment saw a 8.9% revenue increase, while its downstream segment saw a 7.3% increase. However, the Indonesian government's reinstatement of the export levy partially offset revenue growth.

site_title: Building smart solutions
summary: Visal Leng, Asia-Pacific president of Johnson Controls, emphasizes the need for buildings to be flexible, resilient, and cognitive post-pandemic. The company has been working on solutions for safety, security, and wellness, with a focus on air quality and filtration. Leng predicts that offices will evolve to be more collaborative and technology-driven, with fewer workstations but more conference rooms. Buildings will also become "smarter" with AI technology that can self-regulate and optimize energy usage. Johnson Controls is exploring digital solutions, including home monitoring and automation, to enhance comfort and safety in residential buildings.

site_title: Oil climbs on positive China data, rising demand
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, driven by improved Chinese factory data and rising energy demand, but traders remained cautious due to US-China tensions and uncertainty over a US stimulus package. Brent crude rose 1.2% to $44.94 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 1.7% to $41.91 a barrel. Analysts expect oil demand to rebound in Asia as economies open up, but US fiscal stimulus uncertainty and ongoing trade tensions with China pose a threat to prices.

site_title: Hot stock: Keppel sinks 11.7% after Temasek pulls offer; DBS downgrades it to 'hold'
summary: Keppel Corp's shares plummeted 11.7% after Temasek Holdings pulled its S$4 billion partial offer, citing a breach of material adverse change (MAC) clause due to the conglomerate's net loss. DBS downgraded Keppel to 'hold' and cut its target price to S$5.50 from S$6.40. Analysts predict a short-term sell-off, but some see it as a buying opportunity, citing Keppel's diversified business and long-term transformation strategy.

site_title: Chinese firms dominate bid to build Congo dam
summary: Chinese firms, including China Three Gorges and State Grid, have agreed to form a single consortium to build Africa's biggest hydropower plant, Inga III, in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The $14 billion project aims to generate 11,050 megawatts of power, with the development of the smaller 4,800 megawatt version being opposed by the Chinese and Spanish groups. The Congolese government remains open to receiving other developers, but the formation of the consortium is seen as a crucial step towards realizing the project.

site_title: Food ordering startup Eatsy shutters operations
summary: Eatsy, a Singapore-based food ordering startup, has ceased operations after generating S$66,200 in revenue and a net loss of S$912,700 for the year ended June 30, 2019. The company's founder, Shaun Heng, has joined CoinMarketCap as chief of staff, while the remaining employees were helped transition to other companies.

site_title: US hits 5 million virus cases as Trump criticised over relief package
summary: The US has reached 5 million coronavirus cases, with over 162,000 deaths, as President Donald Trump was criticized for unilaterally extending a virus relief package. Trump's executive orders, which include deferring payroll taxes and providing temporary unemployment benefits, were deemed "absurdly unconstitutional" by senior Democrat Nancy Pelosi. The package's inadequacy has raised concerns among Democrats, who may face a legal challenge. Meanwhile, growing infections in Europe prompted measures such as mandatory face masks and social restrictions, with some countries experiencing crowded beaches despite health warnings.

images.alt_text: The United States on Sunday reached the extraordinary milestone of five million coronavirus cases as President Donald Trump was accused of flouting the constitution by unilaterally extending a virus relief package.

site_title: Grab to launch retail investment product, consumer loans platform
summary: Grab's financial services arm, Grab Financial Group (GFG), is launching a micro-investment product, AutoInvest, and a third-party consumer loan platform. AutoInvest allows users to invest as low as S$1 while spending in Grab's ecosystem, with returns of 1.8% per annum. The loan platform, set to launch in Singapore later this year, will offer personal loans from licensed bank partners, with no transaction fees for applying. GFG aims to expand its financial services offerings, despite gunning for a Singapore digital full-bank licence.

site_title: WHO says China team interviewed Wuhan scientists over virus origins
summary: A World Health Organization (WHO) team in China has had "extensive discussions" with Wuhan scientists about the origins of Covid-19. The team, consisting of two specialists in animal health and epidemiology, met with Chinese counterparts and received updates on epidemiological studies, genetic analysis, and animal health research. The WHO believes the virus likely originated from bats and had another intermediary animal host. The results of the investigation are eagerly awaited, particularly after the US accused the WHO of being China-centric. A broader team of experts will soon be dispatched to further investigate the virus's origin.

site_title: Banker sexism at Barclays is aired anew in suit from crisis era
summary: A London trial has revealed sexist comments made by several Barclays bankers during the 2008 credit crisis, including referring to financier Amanda Staveley as a "tart" and "dolly-bird". The comments, made during phone calls, have focused a spotlight on the banking world's treatment of women. Staveley sued Barclays for £1.6 billion, claiming the bank cheated her out of profits. The trial, which is on hiatus, has highlighted the persistence of sexist attitudes in the financial industry, with some lawyers saying similar phrases are still commonly used in discrimination cases.

site_title: Japan lifts final restrictions on French beef
summary: Japan has lifted its final restrictions on French beef imports, 20 years after they were imposed due to concerns over BSE (mad cow disease). The ban, which initially targeted British beef, was extended to all EU-produced beef products in 2000. France, the EU's largest beef producer, can now export meat to Japan without any age limit, including minced meat, after a final round of negotiations. This decision offers new commercial opportunities for the French cattle industry, with Japan importing only a small amount of French beef in 2018.

site_title: Another watchdog at US State Department abruptly gone
summary: The US State Department's acting inspector general, Stephen Akard, abruptly quit his post just months after being installed, raising concerns about the department's leadership and oversight. Akard's departure comes as his office finalizes a report on Secretary of State Mike Pompeo's decision to bypass Congress to sell $8.1 billion in arms to Saudi Arabia. The move has been criticized by lawmakers, who warn that the weapons sale will lead to more suffering in Yemen. The department has announced Diana Shaw as the new acting inspector general, sparking concerns about the Trump administration's efforts to weaken oversight and accountability.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as resurgent virus spurs fears of unemployment
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% to 6,004.3 on Friday, driven by heightened coronavirus-induced restrictions in Melbourne, which led to a six-week lockdown. Fears of further economic damage and unemployment, with unemployment potentially peaking at 14%, sparked concerns. Heavyweight miners, such as BHP Group and Rio Tinto, declined, while energy stocks rose, led by Woodside Petroleum and Santos.

images.alt_text: Australian shares retreated on Friday, with miners leading losses, as heightened coronavirus-induced restrictions following a second wave of infections stoked fears of further economic damage and unemployment.

site_title: Yanlord unit, GIC affiliate ink agreement to co-invest in China residential projects
summary: Yanlord Land, a unit of property developer Yanlord, has signed an investment agreement with an affiliate of Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC to co-invest in China residential projects. The agreement is worth up to 7 billion yuan (S$1.4 billion) and will run for seven years with an option to extend for two more years. Yanlord will own 51% of the project companies, while GIC's affiliate will own the remaining 49%. This collaboration strengthens Yanlord's presence in China and creates value for shareholders, with the company's shares closing 0.83% higher on the day.

site_title: Electric-vehicle startup Canoo said to be in talks for Hennessy SPAC deal
summary: Canoo, an electric vehicle startup, is in advanced talks with Hennessy Capital Acquisition Corp IV, a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC), to merge and take Canoo public. The deal, valued at over $2 billion, would raise $300 million in new equity and allow Canoo to sell its vehicles on a subscription basis. Canoo plans to begin selling its first vehicle next year and has said it intends to offer electric vehicles on a subscription basis. The talks are private, but terms have not been finalized and the deal could still fall apart.

site_title: Singtel associate Bharti Airtel partners with Amazon to grow cloud business
summary: Bharti Airtel, a Singtel associate, has partnered with Amazon Web Services (AWS) to expand its cloud business in India. The partnership aims to offer a wider range of cloud products, including data analytics, artificial intelligence, and security services, to enterprise clients. The move is expected to give AWS direct access to Airtel's 2,500 large enterprise customers and over a million emerging businesses, with Airtel customers receiving sales and support from both companies. The Indian public cloud services market is expected to reach $7.1 billion by 2024.

images.alt_text: Singtel associate Bharti Airtel and Amazon Web Services (AWS) will join forces to develop the Indian telecoms firm's cloud business, allowing it to offer a wider range of products to its enterprise clients, the two companies said on Wednesday.

site_title: Is TikTok a good buy? It depends on what's included
summary: US President Donald Trump has approved a bid by Microsoft to acquire TikTok's US operations, provided Microsoft meets unspecified demands and a Sept 15 deadline. However, the acquisition process is complex due to TikTok's tight integration with its Chinese parent company, ByteDance. The core algorithm that makes TikTok addictive could be difficult to recreate, and preserving the platform's creator culture and exclusive deals with popular creators are also concerns. Experts believe the opportunity to buy TikTok is a once-in-a-decade deal for the right acquirer, but the process will be challenging.

images.alt_text: A million questions are swirling around a possible TikTok-Microsoft deal.

site_title: Lessons from a crisis for Singapore
summary: Singapore's response to the COVID-19 pandemic has provided valuable lessons about the nation's capabilities and limitations. The initial response was deemed a model, but a surge in cases in crowded foreign worker dormitories highlighted the need for better decision-making and public communications. Experts recommend investing in specialists with deep knowledge in virology and data science to inform policy decisions. The government's economic support measures have been effective, but existing inequalities in society, such as those faced by low-wage migrant workers, remain a challenge. Poor corporate governance structures have also been exposed, with several commodity trading companies failing due to the economic downturn. The pandemic has underscored the need for a more progressive wage model, improved regulation, and audit of private companies.

site_title: Argentina says strikes US$65b debt deal to break impasse
summary: Argentina has reached a deal with three creditor groups to restructure $65 billion in sovereign debt, potentially helping the country climb out of its ninth sovereign default and revive its recession-hit economy. The agreement includes adjusting payment dates and legal clauses to sweeten the deal without increasing principal or interest payouts. The new bonds will begin amortizing in 2025 and mature in 2029, with payment dates set for January 9 and July 9. The deal aims to provide significant debt relief and allow Argentina to return to financial markets when needed.

site_title: Asian Pay TV Trust's Q2 net profit down 32.5% on higher costs
summary: Asian Pay TV Trust (APTT) recorded a 32.5% drop in Q2 net profit to S$4.74 million due to increased operating costs and pricing competition. Revenue rose 4.8% to S$75.5 million, but segments saw declines, with basic cable TV revenue down 3.5% and premium digital cable TV revenue down 4.4%. The trust expects to maintain an ordinary interim distribution of 0.25 cents per unit for the rest of 2020. APTT attributes its challenges to video piracy, competition from IPTV, and consumer demand for discounts.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends at fresh record as stocks gain
summary: US stocks ended a session higher, with the Nasdaq reaching a fresh record, as markets monitor Washington negotiations on a relief package. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also advanced, with the Nasdaq climbing 0.4% to 10,941.17. Analysts expect Washington to act, despite unclear timing. Tensions between the US and China escalated over TikTok, with China accusing the US of "bullying." Individual companies saw gains, including Ford and Take-Two Interactive, while Eastman Kodak fell following a government loan investigation.

site_title: IMF says coronavirus may shrink global imbalances further in 2020
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) reported that global current account imbalances narrowed to 2.9% of global GDP in 2019, and are expected to narrow further to 2.6% in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Commodity exporters and tourism-dependent countries are likely to experience deficits, with Saudi Arabia projected to go from a 5.9% surplus to a 4.9% deficit in 2019. The US dollar's current account position is expected to narrow to 2% in 2020, while China's current account surplus is projected to grow to 1.3% in 2020.

site_title: How to win friends and influence people - Shinzo Abe style
summary: Japan's alliance with the West is strengthening 75 years after its defeat in WWII, with Tokyo's economic and security ties with the US deepening. Japan's post-war business success has led to its growing international influence, with the country committing to major trade agreements, including a bilateral deal with the US and an EU-Japan trade agreement. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has forged a personal bond with US President Donald Trump, neutralizing criticism of Japan's trade practices and strengthening US-Japan ties. The growing closeness of US-Japan ties is driven by concerns about China's rise, and Abe is seeking to overturn Japan's post-war pacifist security identity to become more externally engaged, including potentially abolishing Article Nine of the country's Constitution.

images.alt_text: Mr Abe and Mr Trump during a bilateral meeting on the sidelines of the 74th session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York City in September 2019.

site_title: New wave of lockdowns take hefty toll on Indian diesel sales
summary: India's diesel sales have plummeted 13% in July from the previous month and 21% year-on-year, according to official data, as provinces impose lockdowns to curb rising infection rates. The decline exceeds the typical 8% drop at this time of year, raising concerns about the country's ability to import crude and potentially impacting global diesel prices. Indian Oil Corp has reduced plant throughput to 75% and predicts a prolonged slump in fuel demand.

images.alt_text: Diesel sales at India's three biggest fuel retailers dropped 13 per cent in July from the previous month and were down 21 per cent year-on-year, according to preliminary data from officials with direct knowledge of the matter.

site_title: Singapore hedge fund boosts cash on growing risk of US-China armed clash
summary: A Singaporean hedge fund, APS Asset Management, is boosting cash allocations amid growing concerns of an armed clash between the US and China. Founder Wong Kok Hoi believes investors have underestimated tensions between the two superpowers, and a small-scale conflict could trigger market panic. He's increasing cash holdings and favoring domestic firms that supply Chinese consumers, while also holding stocks that could weather the conflict. Wong sees the US-China rivalry as part of a broader Thucydides Trap, where rising powers lead to conflict.

site_title: Thais 'cast a spell' for democracy in Harry Potter-theme protest
summary: Thailand's young protesters, inspired by the Harry Potter theme, held a rally against the government, vowing to "cast a spell" for democracy. For two weeks, they have held daily protests, denouncing the military-aligned government of Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha and the lese majeste law that shields the monarchy from criticism. The protesters, mostly young Thais, accused the government of corruption and mishandling the economy, which has been hit hard by the pandemic. The movement has grown increasingly bold, targeting the powerful elite and calling for greater democracy.

site_title: Top US, Chinese officials optimistic on Phase One trade deal after phone call
summary: US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin spoke with Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He in a phone call, indicating progress on the Phase One trade deal. Both sides are committed to the agreement's success, with discussions focusing on intellectual property rights, financial services, and forced technology transfer. China has increased purchases of US goods, particularly farm products, but still lags behind the agreed-upon first-year increase of $77 billion. The two countries aim to implement the deal, despite President Trump's previous reluctance to engage with China.

site_title: Russia says oil output in July unchanged from June levels, in line with Opec+ deal
summary: Russia's Energy Ministry reported that the country's oil output in July remained unchanged from June levels, in line with the Opec+ agreement. This decision is expected to ease oil output cuts in August, as agreed upon by Opec and other major producers including Russia.

images.alt_text: Russia's Energy Ministry said on Sunday that the country's oil output in July was unchanged from levels seen in June, in line with an Opec+ agreement.

site_title: With eye on China, India looks to increase barriers on imports from Asia
summary: India plans to increase barriers on imports from Asia, mainly China, to prevent re-routing of Chinese goods with little added value. The government is considering raising quality standards, imposing quantity restrictions, and stricter disclosure norms on imports of base metals, electronics, and other items. This move aims to reduce dependence on Chinese goods and promote self-reliance amid strained ties with Beijing.
